column5: 21 YEARS
Directed by Michael Dunaway and Tara Wood

Variety recently published a headline wondering whether Richard Linklater‰Ûªs indie hit ‰ÛÏBoyhood‰Ûù would be remembered at Oscar time. If you judge by the encomiums for this director in the documentary ‰ÛÏ21 Years: Richard Linklater,‰Ûù it should. (The title comes from the notion that an artist‰Ûªs career can be summarized within its first 21 years.)

Mr. Linklater‰Ûªs frequent alter ego Ethan Hawke, a fan of the director‰Ûªs since his debut feature, ‰ÛÏSlacker,‰Ûù is particularly eloquent. Mr. Hawke and Julie Delpy share undisguised enthusiasm for their experience on the ‰ÛÏBefore‰Ûù pictures: ‰ÛÏBefore Sunrise,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBefore Sunset‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBefore Midnight,‰Ûù for which the three shared an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay, as they did (with Kim Krizan) for ‰ÛÏSunset.‰Ûù That series represented Mr. Linklater‰Ûªs first years-long explorations of real-time chronology, experiments that reached their apex with ‰ÛÏBoyhood‰Ûù (here cryptically referred to only as ‰ÛÏThe 12-Year Project‰Ûù).

Present are stars from his movies, including Jack Black (from Mr. Linklater‰Ûªs biggest hit, ‰ÛÏSchool of Rock‰Ûù); Keanu Reeves (‰ÛÏA Scanner Darkly‰Ûù); and Matthew McConaughey (‰ÛÏDazed and Confused,‰Ûù which kicked off Mr. McConaughey‰Ûªs career, as well as those of Ben Affleck, Parker Posey, the actor Anthony Rapp and many others). Directors, including an admiring Jason Reitman, also weigh in. Many attest to Mr. Linklater‰Ûªs gift for blending the seemingly mundane with humor, rich dialogue and a persistent philosophical curiosity. (Maddeningly missing is Mr. Linklater himself.)
1 hour 19 minutes; not rated
Richard Linklater
The luminaries in ‰ÛÏ21‰Ûù pay deserving tribute to Mr. Linklater. Soon, perhaps, so will the Academy.
Opens on Friday

Once he‰Ûªs hooked, however, Nick and his monitor rapidly become the patsies of this unseen psycho and his elaborate plans, as well as the focus of some masked French hackers who may want to help or may just want to practice their English. I really have no idea.

Before then, the plot is simplicity itself, as Nick (Elijah Wood), an entertainment blogger, is contacted online by a creepy British stranger who offers him the chance to spy on his favorite starlet (Sasha Grey) through her computer and phone cameras.

Smothered by a storm of visual tics ‰ÛÓ and the tiniest of nods to ‰ÛÏRear Window‰Ûù (1954) ‰ÛÓ any social commentary takes second place to multitasking gimmickry, like Nick‰Ûªs ability to speed-drive his car while staring at his laptop. Was it wrong to wish that both of them would crash?

A maddening tangle of freeze frames and screens within screens, ‰ÛÏOpen Windows‰Ûù clearly wants to say something about ubiquitous surveillance and invasion of privacy. But the exposed flesh of its imperiled celebrity and the army of eager peepers it attracts offer only weak reminders of a real-world tabloid narrative.

Cleverly designed but hellish to watch, Nacho Vigalondo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏOpen Windows‰Ûù unfolds entirely on a computer screen whose manipulators are sometimes visible and more often not. The result is a thriller with so many viewpoints, feints and fake-outs that it swiftly disappears up its own URL.

But Gigi is a bit of a, um, red herring; the movie has much more on its mind than the rescue of a lone pelican. By its end, we know about pelicans‰Ûª habits, their struggles with DDT and oil spills, their interactions with fishermen. We, like Ms. Irving, have come to appreciate them.
Judy Irving injects just enough of herself into her ‰ÛÏPelican Dreams‰Ûù to distinguish this sweet film from an episode of the PBS series ‰ÛÏNature.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs a nicely photographed study of California‰Ûªs brown pelicans, fascinating birds with a spectacular divebombing method of feeding. Ms. Irving, who previously examined the avian world in ‰ÛÏThe Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill,‰Ûù mixes in dashes of self-discovery, learning about the birds herself as she goes along and relating her thoughts and insights through narration.

The film begins on the Golden Gate Bridge, where one particular pelican, weak from not eating or perhaps just confused, has landed and stopped traffic. Ms. Irving names the bird Gigi ‰ÛÓ despite admonitions from a wildlife rehabilitation worker who notes that people in his line of work resist naming the animals so as not to view them as pets ‰ÛÓ and checks in on the bird through the course of the film.

The story of Abraham Lincoln‰Ûªs childhood, ‰ÛÏThe Better Angels,‰Ûù is also a Christ story in a strange key. It opens with black-and-white images of the Lincoln Memorial, some suggestive of the view of an awe-struck visitor. The absence of color holds your eye (black-and-white has become a palette for gimmicks and obscure auteurs), as do several arcs traced by the camera, as if that visitor were looking up and even searching. The camera movements seem familiar not only because they mirror the physical effort of what it‰Ûªs like to tilt your head and stretch your neck, to gape up at a cathedral window or gathering clouds, but also because they evoke Terrence Malick.
‰ÛÏThe Better Angels‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Some smoking and animal abuse.

The characters scarcely say anything. There‰Ûªs a great deal of murmuring, and the movie is threaded with snatches of ordinary talk and a hushed, intermittent voice-over taken from the reminiscences of Lincoln‰Ûªs cousin, Dennis Hanks, that fills in a few blanks. There are scenes of hard work, of Lincoln‰Ûªs father, Tom (Jason Clarke), chopping wood and plowing a field, but there are many more scenes of Abe and others, including his mother, Nancy (Brit Marling), staring into the distance and sometimes drifting through the grass as the camera hovers like an attentive supplicant. The sense of predestination hangs heavily over the movie, but not a sense of life. The historian Garry Wills once described Lincoln as ‰ÛÏa Transcendentalist without the fuzziness‰Ûù; this Abe is all fuzz.

Mr. Malick didn‰Ûªt make this movie, although it was a project that he was once interested in directing; rather, he has helped shepherd it into existence, giving his blessing by serving as a producer. ‰ÛÏThe Better Angels‰Ûù was written and directed by A. J. Edwards, who has worked on several of Mr. Malick‰Ûªs recent titles, including ‰ÛÏThe New World,‰Ûù and has now for reasons that are at once understandable and baffling made his own Malickian movie. Not Malick, Malickian, because ‰ÛÓ in its wandering and rushing cameras; its grandly sheltering sky and trees; its lovely people walking and gazing and sometimes twirling in the tall grass; and its evocations of a Christian paradise lost and surely refound ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Better Angels‰Ûù proudly announces itself as an aesthetic pastiche.

The tour of the memorial is prefaced by a quote from Lincoln, ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏall that I am, or hope to be, I owe to my angel mother,‰Ûù raising expectations of the childhood scenes that soon follow. The young Abe (the pretty Braydon Denney) is introduced in Indiana in 1817 sitting with a book and a faraway gaze not far from the tiny cabin in which he and his family live. Abe does a lot of staring and some reading, at one point opening ‰ÛÏThe Pilgrim‰Ûªs Progress,‰Ûù which Mr. Edwards shows in close-up as if to ensure we read its subtitle, too: ‰ÛÏFrom This World, to That Which Is to Come.‰Ûù Mr. Edwards doesn‰Ûªt connect this to the boy Lincoln was or the man he became: His filmmaking method is by turns elliptical and overbearing.
THE INVISIBLE FRONT
In Lithuanian, with English subtitles
Directed by Jonas Ohman and Vincas Sruoginis
Opens on Friday

Independence finally came in the early 1990s. This film, somewhat clumsy yet full of illuminating interviews, seems mostly like an exercise in building national pride, but it holds lessons for anyone trying to resist an overwhelming force. NEIL GENZLINGER

‰ÛÏThe Invisible Front,‰Ûù a documentary about the doomed resistance movement that tried to block the Soviet takeover of Lithuania in the aftermath of World War II, might seem just an interesting bit of fading history were it not for two very timely echoes. One, of course, is that although the Soviet Union is no more, Russia seems to have taken over the role of exerting muscle in neighboring countries. The other is that the resistance fighters in Lithuania, like some contemporary people in strife-torn places, put too much hope in the idea that the United States would ride to their rescue.

The film centers on the story of Juozas Luksa, a resistance leader who escaped from Lithuania in 1948 to, among other things, try to generate support for the partisans abroad, and then returned to the country voluntarily with the help of the C.I.A. His story didn‰Ûªt end well ‰ÛÓ among those heard from in the film is the fellow partisan who ultimately betrayed him ‰ÛÓ and the resistance was crushed.
1 hour 27 minutes; not rated

The film, to be released as a two-part, three-hour mini-series through video-on-demand platforms on Tuesday, should be seen in its entirety. In its stunted theatrical version, the second half is a sketchy digest of events that leaves you feeling cheated.

Richard Hoffmann (Jan Josef Liefers), the family patriarch, is a surgeon; his wife, Anne (Claudia Michelsen), is a nurse; and their son, Christian (Sebastian Urzendowsky), is a sensitive bookworm with a rebellious streak. In a country plagued by shortages and power blackouts, they live more comfortably than most of their neighbors. Behind closed doors, they laughingly ridicule the Communist overseers who gather dirt on everyone, including them, and use it with fiendish ruthlessness.

In both ‰ÛÏThe Tower‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏWest,‰Ûù the major character is driven to the brink of insanity by paranoia and hopelessness. ‰ÛÏThe Tower,‰Ûù in its full three-hour version, is the better film because of its sweeping overview of a society that operates on fear, secrecy and duplicity ‰ÛÓ and doles out harsh prison sentences to anyone who is overheard criticizing the regime.

As the days drag on, Nelly finds herself in a limbo that is even more depressing than the world she left behind, and she becomes increasingly paranoid. Ms. Triebel‰Ûªs passionate performance is almost the equal of that of Nina Hoss as a persecuted doctor in Christian Petzold‰Ûªs recent film ‰ÛÏBarbara.‰Ûù But ‰ÛÏWest,‰Ûù for all its intensity, becomes too bogged down in detail to be as strong as it might have been.

‰ÛÏThe Tower‰Ûù is a condensed version of a devastating German television mini-series about life in East Germany in the 1980s as experienced by a cultured family in suburban Dresden. Directed by Christian Schwochow, who grew up in Leipzig and East Berlin, this epic-scale story spans the last seven years before the demise of East German Communism. It‰Ûªs far from the first film to show how the Stasi, the East German secret police, infiltrated everyday life so thoroughly that no one could trust anyone, and how society was gripped by institutionalized paranoia.

After Christian is caught reading forbidden Nazi literature and refuses to say who gave it to him, he is pressured to atone by joining the army. The film‰Ûªs most excruciating moments depict his East German Army training by bullying buffoons who force one poor overweight soldier to eat feces. With their barking cruelty, these officers might as well be Nazis, except for their bumbling incompetence.

Although Nelly‰Ûªs Russian boyfriend, the father of her son, Alexej, died in a car accident, she is grilled by British, French and American agents, who think he may still be alive and working for the Stasi. They follow her wherever she goes.

The ambitious Richard foolishly fancies himself above the fray and keeps a mistress who‰Ûªs had a child. When Stasi officials show up and remind him of the political follies of his youth, he is pressured to be their puppet. His career and family endangered, he disintegrates.

‰ÛÏThe Tower‰Ûù reminds us that the slogan ‰ÛÏthe personal is political‰Ûù applies more than ever in a world where privacy has all but vanished, and any intrusion can be justified in the interests of security.

‰ÛÏThe Tower‰Ûù won several awards after its broadcast on German television in 2012. The debut of the truncated film, being shown at Cinema Village in New York, coincides with the opening of ‰ÛÏWest,‰Ûù Mr. Schwochow‰Ûªs similarly themed adaptation of a novel by Julia Franck, at Anthology Film Archives. Set several years earlier, in the late 1970s, ‰ÛÏWest‰Ûù tells the story of Nelly (JÌ_rdis Triebel), a beautiful organic chemist who leaves East Berlin with her young son, only to find herself trapped for months in a dreary West Berlin refugee center.

The pleasures of understatement abound in the assured drama ‰ÛÏThe Way He Looks,‰Ûù a quiet, closely observed high school romance set in SÌ£o Paulo, Brazil. Leonardo (Ghilherme Lobo), a shy classical music fan, is beginning to think more independently: He weighs joining an overseas transfer program, perhaps studying in the United States. His mother is skeptical; Leonardo is also blind, which the movie wisely doesn‰Ûªt belabor. Leonardo‰Ûªs best friend, Giovana (an effortlessly naturalistic Tess Amorim), shares gossip with him and accompanies him to school.

This winning movie ‰ÛÓ directed by Daniel Ribeiro, making his feature debut ‰ÛÓ dexterously weaves the social challenges of adolescence into a story of broader self-discovery. The film is Brazil‰Ûªs foreign-language entry to the Academy Awards. That‰Ûªs no surprise.

But it is Gabriel (Fabio Audi), the new kid in class, who shakes up Leonardo‰Ûªs world, taking him to the movies (Gabriel whispers what‰Ûªs taking place on screen), gliding down city streets with him on his bicycle, sharing vodka at parties and turning him on to the gentle charms of the band Belle and Sebastian. The impish Gabriel may be pursued by the eager Karina (Isabela Guasco), but it‰Ûªs clear where his heart lies. And if Giovana has designs on Leonardo, she‰Ûªs too smart and cares for him too much to let his budding ardor for Gabriel cost her their own relationship.

Similarly, for all the emphasis on hard work, Ms. Meshel-Dillman doesn‰Ûªt show it being done. She gives us the bustle and chaos of rehearsals, but not the gaffes and try-agains that tighten and refine a sequence and take the students from the studio to the bright lights onstage.

This is a sympathetic, even sweet, account, but it‰Ûªs too soft. Ms. Meshel-Dillman shows no real naysayers: parents who question the sacrifice or overwhelmed students. And though we hear about disappointment, we see little of it. (One girl cries, talking about a role she didn‰Ûªt get.)

The film has admiring profiles of some of the more talented students. And we hear from parents, who appreciate the discipline and real-life lessons that school imparts ‰ÛÓ about disappointment and the prerogatives of talent. Not every girl, after all, gets to be a Sugar Plum Fairy.

Filmed at the Marat Daukayev School of Ballet in Los Angeles, the movie takes us from auditions to opening night of an elaborate ‰ÛÏNutcracker‰Ûù involving dancers ages 3 to 19. (And beyond. Some dads are conscripted for the party scenes.) Ms. Meshel-Dillman, herself a former dancer who trained at the School of American Ballet, has a clear and present fondness for the Daukayev school and its students, and for Marat Daukayev, the former Kirov dancer who runs it.

There are no trade secrets or magic formulas revealed in ‰ÛÏGetting to ‰Û÷The Nutcracker,' ‰Ûù Serene Meshel-Dillman‰Ûªs documentary about a dance school preparing for a big performance. The unsurprising way you get to ‰ÛÏThe Nutcracker‰Ûù? Practice and hard work.

Showcasing the best and the worst in human nature, Orlando von Einsiedel‰Ûªs devastating documentary ‰ÛÏVirunga‰Ûù wrenches a startlingly lucid narrative from a sickening web of bribery, corruption and violence.

The setting is the magnificent ‰ÛÓ and protected ‰ÛÓ Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, home to many of the world‰Ûªs last mountain gorillas and the region‰Ûªs best hope for economic stability. In a country already weakened by a tumultuously bloody history (outlined in a brief prologue), that hope became even more fragile with the 2010 discovery of oil beneath Lake Edward and the arrival of a British petroleum company, SOCO International. As multiple forces collided for control of the park ‰ÛÓ including a powerful rebel group seeking a percentage of oil profits ‰ÛÓ Mr. von Einsiedel and his crew members (who had originally planned a film about the dangerous work of the park‰Ûªs 400 rangers) found themselves caught in a literal war between conservation and exploitation.
‰ÛÏI am not special,‰Ûù he insists. The audience may beg to differ.

Using hidden cameras and the invaluable assistance of the fearless French journalist MÌ©lanie Gouby, Mr. von Einsiedel mixes extraordinary footage of rebel tanks and clandestine palm-greasing with lush panoramas of serene wildlife. Villains, it seems, are everywhere, but it‰Ûªs the film‰Ûªs heroes who stick in the mind: Andre Bauma, the gentle ranger who would die to protect the orphaned gorillas in his care; Emmanuel de Merode, the park‰Ûªs soft-spoken Belgian warden, whose astonishing courage calms everyone around him; and Rodrigue Katembo, a section chief trying to gather evidence of illegal oil company activities.

The prospect of Toni Servillo‰Ûªs playing not one but two roles in a state-of-the-union comedy could tantalize any admirer of his delectable turns in ‰ÛÏThe Great Beauty‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIl Divo.‰Ûù But with its switcheroo fable of a despondent politician and his unstable identical twin, Roberto AndÌ_'s ‰ÛÏViva la LibertÌÊ‰Ûù wobbles between being wispily suggestive of finer existential meaning and generational commentary, and being basically a handsomely dressed-up ‰ÛÏDave‰Ûù for post-Berlusconi Italy.
VIVA LA LIBERTÌÊ

Everyone buys the impersonation; Giovanni‰Ûªs eccentric speeches inspire colleagues and crowds alike; and, just like that, 50 percent of the film becomes deeply uninteresting. Away from the action, Enrico seeks refuge with a married ex-girlfriend (Valeria Bruni Tedeschi) and gets involved with a film shoot, but his time off feels diffuse and hastily sketched.

Mr. Servillo‰Ûªs twin siblings are a bit like the classical masks of tragedy and comedy, Enrico‰Ûªs jowly glumness next to Giovanni‰Ûªs Groucho-eyebrowed insouciance. But Mr. AndÌ_ flows ineffectually back and forth between the brothers, making elegant use of some Verdi but less so of Mr. Servillo.

In Mr. AndÌ_'s adaptation of his own novel, the opposition leader Enrico Oliveri (Mr. Servillo) goes AWOL after an embarrassing speech at a party conference. In a pinch, his chief operative (Valerio Mastandrea) installs Enrico‰Ûªs brother, Giovanni, a philosophy professor and mental patient.
Opens on Friday
Directed by Roberto AndÌ_

This sly actor recognizes the fantasy‰Ûªs limits by giving Giovanni, a consummate holy fool, a nagging vacuousness. But ‰ÛÏViva la LibertÌÊ‰Ûù amounts to a rather uninspiring satire at this point for a country frustrated by political decrepitude.
1 hour 34 minutes; not rated
In Italian, with English subtitles

The brainchild of the Warsaw Rising Museum, this labor-intensive movie uses material shot by six talented propaganda cinematographers during the failed resistance to Nazi occupiers as the Soviet Army waited in the wings. (There‰Ûªs a film-historical echo: Similar compilation efforts were a staple of Soviet cinema at the time.) The black-and-white footage has been colorized, but the modest palette seems to sharpen contrast and movement. More innovatively, lip reading helps determine what the filmed subjects might have been saying, translating it into speech voiced by actors. (That said, some of the dialogue, when people‰Ûªs mouths aren‰Ûªt visible, appears to be conjecture.)

That‰Ûªs not the only performance by actors: ‰ÛÏWarsaw Uprising‰Ûù is marred by a fictional audio drama among three characters (two cameraman brothers and an American airman) who provide an unnecessary, distracting and at times amateurish frame to this resourcefully, even wittily, edited tour. But the flaws don‰Ûªt detract from the film‰Ûªs casual and calamitous sights ‰ÛÓ from soldiers shaving and hanging out, to a no-man‰Ûªs-land conference with a Nazi, to a sorrowful survivor of bombardment who looks as if he might crumble and blow away.

An extraordinary but problematic effort in you-are-there archival work, ‰ÛÏWarsaw Uprising‰Ûù presents life on the ravaged ground in this Polish city in August 1944. Vivid restored wartime footage shows Poles huddled in air raid bunkers, slurping soup, flirting with soldiers, dodging sniper fire or going for a dip, all with a breathtaking sense of tangible detail.
These two demimondes smash together in the circuitous aftermath of a gangland shootout and Michiko‰Ûªs dragooning of a hapless nerd as her paid boyfriend.

For all its flashes of would-be perversity, the rambling adventure is sentimental at heart, fueled by Hirata‰Ûªs worship of filmmaking, Mr. Sono‰Ûªs Japanese and Western movie references, and the fortuitous matching-up of violent outsiders who have mutually compatible needs.

But Mr. Sono‰Ûªs nearly 15-year-old script is hit or miss, and most of the patchy film ‰ÛÓ which is not even especially lunatic, as far as Japanese comedy goes ‰ÛÓ feels like a drawn-out windup to the splattery finale.
Mr. Sono‰Ûªs latest feature owes the most to his superior four-hour binge, ‰ÛÏLove Exposure.‰Ûù

Sion Sono‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWhy Don‰Ûªt You Play in Hell?‰Ûù strives to be madcap with its collision-course pairing of characters: a run-and-gun guerrilla filmmaking squad; yakuza tough guys obsessed with moviemaking; and a ruthless former child actress run amok. But goofball antics and a terrific, raucous finale can‰Ûªt make up for the essential slackness of its repetitive comedy and punk chest thumping.

Here, a yakuza boss, Muto (Jun Kunimura), is furious to learn that his beloved daughter, Michiko (Fumi Nikaido of ‰ÛÏHimizu‰Ûù), a former toothpaste-ad sensation, has lost her role in a new movie. Meanwhile, an ardent and directionless director, Hirata (a straining Hiroki Hasegawa), and his crew have been kicking around for years, waiting for their big break.
In some filmmaking quarters, excess has turned into a short-circuiting shorthand: Make a movie nutty enough, and the eccentricity is expected to drown out considerations of quality.

‰ÛÏBad Turn Worse‰Ûù pays homage to the Oklahoma-born crime novelist Jim Thompson (‰ÛÏThe Killer Inside Me‰Ûù), who died in 1977 and who is quoted reverently by Billy Joe‰Ûªs girlfriend, Sue (Mackenzie Davis), an aficionado of mystery stories. Thompson said there were 32 ways to tell a story but only one plot: Things are not as they seem. That‰Ûªs a sly leitmotif that runs through the screenplay.

The baddies all live in a Texas cotton mill town, which the movie portrays as an arid, dead-end hell. More than thieves, they are cackling sadists who relish describing in graphic detail the sexual humiliations they‰Ûªll wreak upon their enemies‰Ûª girlfriends. By far the most colorful is Giff (Mark Pellegrino), an overseer at the mill, which doubles as a money-laundering operation run by a gangster, Big Red (William Devane), who doesn‰Ûªt appear until the end of the movie.

A juicy neo-noir like ‰ÛÏBad Turn Worse‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt have to make total sense to grab you. All it has to do is spit like a snake enough times to show that it means business. And this small, nasty directorial debut by the brothers Zeke and Simon Hawkins, from a screenplay by Dutch Southern, has a whole den of poisonous reptiles from which to sample venom.

Other baddies are Billy Joe (Logan Huffman), Giff‰Ûªs larcenous, hormonally overcharged teenage employee with a twangy whine and a distant resemblance to Zac Efron, and a corrupt sheriff (Jon Gries) who speaks entirely in sinister innuendo. If the atmosphere of pervasive evil is wildly exaggerated, it gives the film a steady charge of adrenaline, and you wonder how far it will dare to go.

The trouble begins when Giff discovers $20,000 missing from his safe, accuses a Mexican worker of stealing it and repeatedly kicks him in the face, then shoots him dead even after someone else has taken the blame.

One of the many incongruities is Sue‰Ûªs attachment to Billy Joe, or B. J., who makes drunken, lewd proposals to other women in her presence and has nothing going for him but his boyish good looks. Yearning for Sue is B. J.‰Ûªs best friend, Bobby (Jeremy Allen White), who, like Sue, is bound for college in a few weeks. The three are best friends until Bobby and Sue hook up, and B. J. gets wind of their betrayal.

A subtext of class resentment runs through the story in which B. J., a younger version of Giff, realizes he is trapped in a hellhole from which his friends have a chance of escape. Underneath his swaggering arrogance, there is no end of bitterness and despair.

Dragging the chains of ‰ÛÏThe Big Chill‰Ûù (1983) and its predecessor, ‰ÛÏReturn of the Secaucus 7‰Ûù (1980), may be too much for this slight ensemble drama, but the director, Chris Lowell, is going more for mood than glittering ripostes. Convening at the lakeside house where Daniel (Ryan Eggold) grew up and where every room contains a seminal high school memory, the group sinks into a whiskey-lubricated nostalgia. Veneers slip, and latent desires surface as Daniel, recently bereaved and now confronted by an old love who‰Ûªs trailing a new fiancÌ©, slides into defiant self-pity.

When a character name-checks Ernest Hemingway and Gertrude Stein right out of the gate, it suggests that the people we‰Ûªre about to meet are at least capable of intelligent conversation. But don‰Ûªt get your hopes too high: The seven childhood friends who reunite as adults in ‰ÛÏBeside Still Waters‰Ûù may be educated, but they still manage to spend most of their weekend getting wasted, naked and indiscreet.
More important, Mr. Lowell knows when to fold ‰Û÷em: Given more than 76 minutes with this lot, we might start to wish that the drinking games and skinny-dipping chaser had a much darker outcome.

Bathed in a nostalgic glow that just avoids maudlin, the group‰Ûªs problems ‰ÛÓ a sexless marriage, an unexpected job loss ‰ÛÓ bark but don‰Ûªt bite. Scenes flirt with clichÌ©, yet the writing has spark (one very funny sequence cuts among radically different interpretations of the previous night‰Ûªs revelries), and Tim Naylor‰Ûªs photography is pretty.

Such a choice is not entirely absent from ‰ÛÏBeyond the Lights,‰Ûù but Ms. Prince-Bythewood has always had a sure sense of the complex interplay of ambition and desire in women‰Ûªs lives. She showed as much in her debut feature, ‰ÛÏLove & Basketball,‰Ûù which still holds up nicely after 14 years, and also in the made-for-HBO adaptation of Terry McMillan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDisappearing Acts,‰Ûù which is worth seeking out. In those films, as in this new one, facile notions of ‰ÛÏhaving it all‰Ûù are pushed aside in favor of an attempt to see what kind of bargain might be struck between the needs of the heart and the equally important demands of work and success.
‰ÛÏBeyond the Lights‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Language and sex, nasty and sweet.

Kaz, with his collection of inspirational quotations, his hatred of lying and his extraordinary pectoral muscles, holds out the possibility of authenticity and emotional fulfillment. Macy Jean, who started out as the poor, white, single mother of a biracial daughter, insists on the compromises necessary to find security and a measure of power. Other, less nimble movies might simplify Noni‰Ûªs predicament, forcing her to decide between happiness and fame, which is to say between Kaz and her career.

Kaz faces these choices, too, of course. But this is very much Noni‰Ûªs story, and Ms. Mbatha-Raw‰Ûªs film, and both Mr. Parker and his character seem to recognize that with gallantry and good humor. ‰ÛÏBeyond the Lights‰Ûù may be a fantasy ‰ÛÓ movies about love, like songs about love, tend to fall into that category ‰ÛÓ but it is an uncommonly smart and honest fantasy. What it wants us to believe, most of all, is that despite all the ugliness and exploitation in the world of entertainment, the bond between artist and audience is a real and sustaining form of love in its own right. And the movie is marvelous proof of its own argument.

This is what I meant about silly and stirring, and I meant both as compliments. Movie romances are not supposed to follow the strict conventions of realism, and Ms. Prince-Bythewood‰Ûªs script contrives enough twists, coincidences and tearful confrontations to produce the necessary gasps, giggles and sniffles. It sprinkles some glittery celebrity cameos among the scenes of earnest striving and ornaments Mark Isham‰Ûªs emotive score with even more emotive songs, culminating with a second a cappella rendition of ‰ÛÏBlackbird.‰Ûù At that moment, as in quite a few others, ‰ÛÏBeyond the Lights‰Ûù perfectly mirrors the swooning, swirling, unself-conscious access to feeling that pop music can provide.

‰ÛÏBeyond the Lights,‰Ûù Gina Prince-Bythewood‰Ûªs occasionally silly, frequently stirring romantic melodrama, was originally going to be called ‰ÛÏBlackbird,‰Ûù after the Nina Simone song at its yearning heart. That song, a blunt, anguished, barely metaphorical reckoning with the intimate psychic violence of racism and sexism, is performed several times by Noni, the film‰Ûªs suffering pop star. The first time is as a young girl (played by India Jean-Jacques) at a South London talent show, where we are introduced to the two forces that will rule her destiny: a stunning vocal gift and a ruthless stage mother.

But celebrity can be a lonely state, and Noni, in the glare of her fame, feels invisible, as unloved and unrecognized as Nina Simone‰Ûªs blackbird. One night, she indulges a self-destructive impulse and is rescued by Kaz (Nate Parker), a Los Angeles police officer who has been assigned to her security detail. As she dangles from a hotel balcony, he says three words that, at least temporarily, restore her will to live: ‰ÛÏI see you.‰Ûù

That magic, of course, is the product of an often cruel and impersonal machinery in whose gears aspiring artists like Noni often find themselves caught. The real conflict is not between Noni and Kaz, or even between the two of them and an indifferent world, but rather between Noni‰Ûªs sense of herself as a singer and the industry that wants to turn her into a slick, packaged, disposable commodity.

A decade and a half later, Noni ‰ÛÓ now played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw, so impressive earlier this year in ‰ÛÏBelle‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is a Rihanna-ish diva on the verge of superstardom. She appears, in leather lingerie and lavender hair extensions, in barely-safe-for-work music videos as the sidekick and plaything of a cretinous white rapper named Kid Culprit (Colson Baker, a.k.a. MGK), who is also her kind-of boyfriend. Noni‰Ûªs mother, Macy Jean (Minnie Driver), controls every aspect of her daughter‰Ûªs career and personal life, combining the roles of chaperone, manager and pimp.

How Noni is seen, and by whom, is the film‰Ûªs main dramatic concern. It also rests its gaze on Kaz, a thoughtful, stoical fellow whom circumstances frequently conspire to render shirtless. Honest, hard-working and immune to glamour (though not to beauty), he embodies a fantasy of manhood and represents, for Noni, a possible refuge from the frenzy and superficiality of her working life. He also has some symmetrical issues of his own to deal with, notably his father (Danny Glover), a police captain who sees in Kaz the fulfillment of his own thwarted ambition. Just as Noni has been groomed for stardom, so has Kaz been prepared for political glory. A seat on the City Council is coming open, and a tabloid romance with a troubled chanteuse might harm his electoral chances.

‰ÛÏBrahmin Bulls,‰Ûù a warm if ultimately slight debut feature from Mahesh Pailoor, hinges on an interesting complication of sympathies. Invited to a conference in Los Angeles, Ashok (Roshan Seth), an academic in Boston, decides to go there and pay a visit to his son, Sid (Sendhil Ramamurthy), an architect on the verge of a divorce. Ashok has an ulterior motive: He yearns to reunite with Helen (Mary Steenburgen), a flame he hasn‰Ûªt seen in 20 years. The film raises the prospect of an autumnal fling, but it has less conventional goals in mind.

Gaining in astringency as it goes along, ‰ÛÏBrahmin Bulls‰Ûù avoids the formulaic version of this story, in which the stubborn son learns from the more experienced father. Instead, Sid grows more sympathetic as Ashok becomes less so. At first, the father seems comfortable in any context, the sort of person who can disarm a stranger. But that facade hides a past of difficult choices and regrets.

It‰Ûªs hard to find fault with the performances, though, particularly Mr. Seth‰Ûªs. This veteran actor (‰ÛÏGandhi,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏIndiana Jones and the Temple of Doom‰Ûù) never reduces a tricky role to caricature.

Mr. Pailoor (who wrote the screenplay with Anu Pradhan) shows a taste for blunt metaphor. Maya (Monica Raymund), a fellow architect Sid tentatively romances, compares planning buildings to raising children. A tennis motif is used to suggest friction between father and son. Ashok insists that Sid plant new trees in his yard.

The more recent, and more conventional, feature is a familiar-feeling tale about a married summer farm laborer (Joe Swanberg, who has directed Ms. Decker in his own films) far from home and drawn to the playful, isolated daughter (Sophie Traub) of his boss (Robert Longstreet). The setup‰Ûªs clichÌ©s grow harder to ignore, despite a welcome mischievous streak and some bucolic imagery.

Mr. Longstreet‰Ûªs gruff head of the household is inexplicably a jerk and then a monster, and it‰Ûªs hard to buy him and the stolid Mr. Swanberg as country boys here. When the laborer‰Ûªs wife finally visits, it‰Ûªs just in time for a menacing dinner and house party.

Ms. Decker especially likes to cut away from a shot just as or before it catches an actor‰Ûªs glance (or catches our eye). It‰Ûªs a device that risks growing mannered. And that‰Ûªs one problem with her second feature, which is named, like her debut, with cryptic lyricism at the border of feyness: ‰ÛÏThou Wast Mild & Lovely.‰Ûù (These two films, totaling roughly two and a half hours, are being released at the same time in theaters and online.)

In fact, a frightening detour takes place early on in this thorny debut feature from Josephine Decker: Sarah gets an S O S call from a never-seen person, who wakes up in an apartment of male strangers. That moment sets another tone that also fades in and out of the film, which mostly involves Sarah and Isolde‰Ûªs wanderings at the Balkan-music gathering. Much of the time, Sarah is flirting with a diffident boy, but those highly symbolic woods are always nearby and sometimes all around us.
While both films have rough patches and look-at-me asides, ‰ÛÏButter on the Latch‰Ûù thrives on its casually true snapshots of confusion and connection.

There‰Ûªs a devilishly fun moment in ‰ÛÏButter on the Latch‰Ûù when a woman recounts an unusually rejuvenating visit to a notorious East Village massage parlor. Isolde (Isolde Chae-Lawrence) tells the anecdote to Sarah (Sarah Small) at a Balkan-music retreat somewhere in the California woods. The apparently improvised bit is nicely timed, part of catching up between friends, but the scene also expresses something about where storytelling takes us and what lies around the corner, mirroring a sensation native to desire and its tantalizing pleasures and dangers.

Ms. Decker follows the two friends into the forest more than once, seemingly with the light of nothing more than miner‰Ûªs lamps. At other times, the mobile camerawork stops for sometimes affected tableaus of oddity or beauty ‰ÛÓ a slug, a shock-haired old woman, figures in white dresses. The willfully oblique storytelling and fugue sequences owe a lot to other hand-held film journeys in the past decade, from here and abroad, that are often also concerned with the quickening turns and nonlinear textures of fear and passion.
El Chapo‰Ûªs arrest in February doesn‰Ûªt necessarily detract from the potency of the central implication: that he operated through a combination of collusion, corruption and silence.

As their journey begins, the directors, Angus Macqueen and Guillermo Galdos, drive with a drug distributor through the South Side of Chicago, a destination for El Chapo‰Ûªs product. In Mexico, their interview subjects later include a journalist, a retired general involved in a 1993 arrest of El Chapo and a man identified as a retired cartel boss who describes the stranglehold of the country‰Ûªs drug culture. If your son is killed, he says, ‰ÛÏyou take your other son to the killers to see if he can work for them.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏDrug Lord‰Ûù can be murky in explaining how its makers achieve their startling access. (While you suspect that El Chapo won‰Ûªt sit down for an interview ‰ÛÓ we hear a story of how he intimidated interrogators with his relaxed attitude in a maximum-security prison ‰ÛÓ they do manage to meet with his mother.) Driven by mostly Spanish-language folk music, the movie provides a potent if piecemeal counterbalance to the sensationalism of ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad.‰Ûù

In a sense, the documentary ‰ÛÏDrug Lord: The Legend of Shorty‰Ûù is an experiment that went awry. The project began as an effort by two filmmakers to see if they could find JoaquÌ_n GuzmÌÁn Loera, known as El Chapo, or Shorty, who was one of the world‰Ûªs most wanted drug traffickers.
‰ÛÏDumb and Dumber To‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) because of course it is.

To that end, as it were, this sequel is just, uh, packed, or perhaps smeared, with a whole lot of poop jokes. There are diaper gags, lots of them, mostly pretty funny, and a couple of peekaboo looks at a feline rear end. That same puss ends up swinging from a chandelier, which in another movie might be the center of an elaborately staged set but here feels like an easy throwaway. The Farrellys are still not much interested in film as a visual medium, and when Lloyd and Harry aren‰Ûªt smacking each other or dropping their pants, you might as well be listening to a radio play. There‰Ûªs a story, but it doesn‰Ûªt matter, certainly not to the leads or the good-natured sidekicks like Kathleen Turner and Rob Riggle.

In ‰ÛÏDumb and Dumber To,‰Ûù Peter and Bobby Farrelly ‰ÛÓ and the stars Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels ‰ÛÓ have boldly if unoriginally returned to the scene of their inaugural crime: their 1994 directing debut, ‰ÛÏDumb and Dumber.‰Ûù An anti-classic of its disreputable, guffawing type, it wasn‰Ûªt the first movie to elevate human idiocy into an intentional art; Jerry Lewis and ‰ÛÏCaddyshack,‰Ûù among many others, got there long before Lloyd (Mr. Carrey) and Harry (Mr. Daniels) hit the road in their memorably fuzzy puppy-mobile with the wagging tongue.

But ‰ÛÏDumb and Dumber,‰Ûù which presented itself as an invigorating blast of odorous fun, earned its laughs partly because it didn‰Ûªt soften its no-frills absurdity and heartburning guff about life being a box of chocolates. Mostly, it delighted by giving Mr. Carrey, after his ‰ÛÏAce Ventura‰Ûù success, the chance to run wild with his rubber-band physiognomy and gift for squirming comedy. (Few comics can shove a laugh back down an audience‰Ûªs throat as quickly.) Both he and Mr. Daniels have slowed down without cleaning up their act.

‰ÛÏI watched you sleep, and I thought, this is the most beautiful person ever made,‰Ûù coos Noah (James Wolk), a dreamboat with a dimpled chin who works at a family clinic in ‰ÛÏAlways Woodstock.‰Ûù Catherine (Allison Miller), the object of his fawning adoration, is an aspiring singer-songwriter who moved back from big, bad New York City to her childhood home in Woodstock, N.Y., after being fired from her job at a big, bad record company. The night she meets Noah, she winds up at his clinic after drinking herself into oblivion at the karaoke bar he owns.

It would be an understatement to call Catherine immature in this laugh-free romantic comedy. A spoiled brat prone to tantrums would be a more accurate description of this walking nightmare, whose talent is as minuscule as that displayed by the first-time filmmaker Rita Merson, who wrote and directed.

This is a movie that runs on magical thinking. The old homestead is a shambles when Catherine returns, but almost overnight, it is transformed into an immaculate cottage. And Catherine, despite having little musical ability or stage presence, is taken seriously: Such miracles happen only in movies as bad as ‰ÛÏAlways Woodstock.‰Ûù

Heading off to explore his lupine lineage, Cayden ‰ÛÓ who, in werewolf form, bears an unfortunate resemblance to a 1970s-era Kenny Rogers ‰ÛÓ lands in the middle of a dÌ©tente between peaceful ‰ÛÏtown wolves‰Ûù and vicious ‰ÛÏpure bloods,‰Ûù who fry up their victims while huddling around a campfire like homeless mongrels. We‰Ûªre about to learn, however, that their top-hatted leader (Jason Momoa) shares more with our hero than a determination to mate with Angel (Merritt Patterson), a knockout whose ownership of the local bar makes her doubly desirable.
Cayden: ‰ÛÏThat‰Ûªs really hot.‰Ûù

As unoriginal as its title, David Hayter‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWolves‰Ûù is yet another hoary, hairy transformation narrative featuring lycanthropy as a metaphor for coming of age. In the case of Cayden (Lucas Till), a golden-boy quarterback, manhood means more than mastering rage and making peace with a first name that no one can spell. It also means that shaving could now be a full-body chore.

Silly beyond words, ‰ÛÏWolves‰Ûù is indifferently acted and unconvincingly realized. Battle scenes fall flat when only a handful of extras merit full makeup (suggesting a less than elastic budget), while the rest are left to slobber and crouch unenhanced. Their embarrassment is nothing, however, when compared with that of Mr. Hayter‰Ûªs dialogue.
Oh, Cayden, you‰Ûªve got her in a hayloft; know when to stop talking.
‰ÛÏWolves‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Tooth-and-claw sex and a cannibalistic cookout.
Angel: ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªd only ever kill anyone who threatens the ones we love.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏKirk Cameron‰Ûªs Saving Christmas‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Coerced merriment.

‰ÛÏKirk Cameron‰Ûªs Saving Christmas‰Ûù begins with its host, the former star of ‰ÛÏGrowing Pains‰Ûù and now an evangelical Christian, sitting in an easy chair in front of a fully decorated Christmas tree. In his view, the holiday is under siege. ‰ÛÏThere are some people who would love to put a big wet blanket on all of this,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏThey don‰Ûªt want us to love Christmas so much and celebrate it the way we do.‰Ûù

To illustrate this Bill O‰ÛªReilly-ready premise, Mr. Cameron stages an intervention ‰ÛÓ his word ‰ÛÓ with a hypothetical brother-in-law, Christian (played by the director, Darren Doane), who isn‰Ûªt feeling the seasonal cheer. Christian worries that Christmas has become too materialistic, too removed from the Bible.

His account would constitute perhaps 10 minutes of conventional screen time, but ‰ÛÏSaving Christmas‰Ûù has been minimally edited. In a rambling introduction, Mr. Cameron reaches for his mug of hot chocolate three times. The movie further stalls with pregnant pauses, broad comic mugging, an endless dance routine and outtakes. (Mr. Doane tells an actor that the digital camera can ‰ÛÏroll all day.‰Ûù) ‰ÛÏSaving Christmas‰Ûù seems determined to win any perceived war on Christmas through brute force.

With a smile so wide and laughter that sounds so forced you half-expect the camera to pull back to reveal hostage takers, Mr. Cameron explains how several facets of the holiday ‰ÛÓ the tree, Santa Claus, gifts ‰ÛÓ have roots in religious tradition.

All of which Mr. Kurosawa, adapting a 2009 novel by Kanae Minato, expresses by crisply framing every shot to imbue it with tension, selectively bleeding colors out of his palette and making the most of Yusuke Hayashi‰Ûªs trenchant score, with its violins and bagpipes. He‰Ûªs fashioned a fathomless echo chamber in which spiritual confusion and aggression keep turning into each other, and penance comes to sound like a very dark joke.

Throughout, Asako (Kyoko Koizumi), the dead girl‰Ûªs mother, keeps reappearing in heels like some black-widow figure, a vengeful ghost out of Japanese folk tales or a telenovela confidante. Her notion of atonement grows recondite, to say the least, as her saga undergoes Ouroboros twists that now might remind some of David Fincher, whose film ‰ÛÏSeven‰Ûù influenced Mr. Kurosawa‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCure.‰Ûù

But things don‰Ûªt play out quite so nobly as the traditional-sounding title of this typically unnerving film from Mr. Kurosawa (‰ÛÏPulse,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏCure‰Ûù) might suggest. Separate chapters reveal the girls‰Ûª subsequent lives as adults stuck in various states of arrested development or faced with what you might call extreme stress tests. Mr. Kurosawa expertly modulates an uncanny flow of energies between shame and grief, between venal urges and high-minded moral demands. The women‰Ûªs travails suggest something that‰Ûªs part curse, part mythic cycle of guilt and part kaleidoscopic dread.

One of the women, a beauty spa worker named Sae (Yu Aoi), remains fearful of strange men and finds an apparent match in an awkward mate who is the heir to an industrial fortune. But this man turns out to be a control freak with an infantilizing fetish. Another survivor, Maki (Eiko Koike), has become a strict, devoted teacher but finds herself enmeshed in a toxic politics of hero worship and scapegoating at her school. Akiko (Sakura Ando), an unstable homebody in permanent sweatpants, lives with her overprotective parents. And Yuka (Chizuru Ikewaki), a flower-shop manager, nurtures a virulent jealousy of her sister and her husband, a police officer.

There‰Ûªs plenty of time for all their troubles to develop, bloom and decay, sometimes all at once, because ‰ÛÏPenance‰Ûù is the four-and-a-half-hour theatrical release of a Japanese mini-series originally broadcast in 2012. The resurgent Mr. Kurosawa, who‰Ûªs had a low profile in the United States since his 2009 recession drama ‰ÛÏTokyo Sonata,‰Ûù takes naturally to the multiple panels this serial canvas affords by fleshing out distinctive tales. Each is tightly wound around a character‰Ûªs peculiar psychological and moral predicament, and in turn further nested in even creepier ways.

Like some infinitely more routine horror movie, the fateful stories of Kiyoshi Kurosawa‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPenance‰Ûù radiate outward from a terrible shared trauma. In the prelude, set 15 years ago, a stranger abducts a girl in front of her four friends, who then learn she has been murdered in the school gym. Out of shock or fear, they can‰Ûªt identify the killer to the police. Instead of commiserating, the victim‰Ûªs wealthy mother lashes out and (over snacks) condemns them to a lifetime of atonement.

Loitering patiently outside bars and diners, snuggled in parkas and sometimes pajamas, the cold and the curious line the nighttime streets as the hunk of granite inches by. They don‰Ûªt get to see, as we do, the marvelous archival film of Mr. Heizer‰Ûªs past projects or explore his revolutionary vision of so-called negative space. Nor are they privy to the jaw-dropping task of procuring permits from the route‰Ûªs 22 cities and countless official bodies. Denied the illuminating context provided by the film‰Ûªs experts ‰ÛÓ especially the museum‰Ûªs ebullient director, Michael Govan ‰ÛÓ the onlookers become an unfiltered chorus of wonder, outrage and everything in between.

Capturing that amazement and much more besides, Doug Pray‰Ûªs sneakily compelling documentary ‰ÛÏLevitated Mass‰Ûù accompanies the 340-ton boulder on its surreal journey from the California desert to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. More than 100 miles and innumerable logistical nightmares later, it would be delivered into the hands of the sculptor Michael Heizer and become the artwork of the title, but it‰Ûªs the rubbernecks en route that give this stone its heart.

‰ÛÏNothing ever happens on this street,‰Ûù one young woman says as a gargantuan tractor-trailer crawls past, bearing a humongous boulder and surrounded by a swarm of anxious construction engineers. ‰ÛÏAnd now something amazing just happened.‰Ûù

To some, the procession screams squandered resources (albeit private ones), while to others, it signifies nothing less than the hand of the Divine. To most, however, the cavalcade ‰ÛÓ like Mr. Heizer‰Ûªs work ‰ÛÓ is an opportunity to ask life‰Ûªs most valuable question: ‰ÛÏWhy?‰Ûù

Milan, a character based on Mr. Mumin‰Ûªs experiences in New York, is celebrated back home but is eager for success in America. Preparing for a recording, he struggles with money and rehearsals, particularly after his band‰Ûªs bass guitarist bows out. Much of the movie simply watches Milan as he drives, tapping rhythms on the steering wheel, meeting passengers both encouraging and not.

‰ÛÏLove Hunter‰Ûù kicks off on an energetic note, when a taxi passenger, having discovered that her driver is a musician, offers a hefty tip if he can cheer her up with a song. Milan (Milan Mumin, of the Serbian band Love Hunters) pulls over, retrieves a guitar from his trunk and gives her a sidewalk concert. At once fantastical and gritty, this sort of uninflected street vignette sets the movie apart.

Nemanja Bala and Brane Bala, brothers who wrote and directed, regard Milan‰Ûªs single-minded focus on his music without judgment or romanticism; Milan may be playing for an audience of one, but that‰Ûªs not the same thing as selfishness. In its feel for nocturnal light, this is one of the most refreshing New York independent features since Ramin Bahrani‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMan Push Cart.‰Ûù Both acoustically and dramatically, Mr. Mumin is a winning performer.

The arrival of his girlfriend (Jelena Stupljanin) in New York challenges their relationship. Then there is Milan‰Ûªs new bass player (Eleanor Hutchins). The pair make great music; is it something more? The film delicately illustrates how the emotions of performance and life can bleed together.

Between ‰ÛÏSerial Mom‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGod Bless America,‰Ûù not to mention the moonlighting criminals who populate binge television, vigilantes in sheep‰Ûªs clothing are familiar by now. ‰ÛÏMiss Meadows‰Ûù gives the old perverse routine a whirl with a weirdly soul-baring Katie Holmes as a prim-and-proper gunlady, but despite an eccentric streak (which turns erratic), the script doesn‰Ûªt allow much room for the premise to take flight.

Ms. Holmes brings not only suitable dimples and nerve to her role but also an abject panic and sadness (and maybe madness) quivering beneath the grammatically correct surfaces of Miss Meadows. The character also emerges as more than an officious schoolmarm, for she picks and chooses from the platter of old-fashioned values: driving a respectable old roadster and tending a perfect garden but singing in a church choir for fun, not faith.

The dark comedy (punctuated by the catchphrase ‰ÛÏToodle-oo‰Ûù) doesn‰Ûªt always come off, and the filmmaking is more off-kilter than necessary, with capricious camerawork and pacing. The odd little spikes in approach make for something better than disposable indie satire, but it all still feels underdeveloped.

Miss Meadows ‰ÛÓ her preferred manner of address ‰ÛÓ is a glove-wearing substitute teacher who won‰Ûªt hesitate to quick-draw her pistol when confronted with maniacs in her suburban world. As her mother affirms in their telephone chats, God needs a little help sweeping away the evildoers. But Miss Meadows is in danger of being exposed when the wholesome local sheriff (a winning James Badge Dale) courts her.

Joining them, Mr. Darling cobbles together a right-versus-might narrative of hippy-dippy sentiment and ham-handed images as the 2012 standoff unfolds. Sun-dappled interviews with beaming amateur farmers lay out the benefits of locally grown veggies, but their opponents are not so prettily lighted or ideologically indulged. When the geneticist Damon Lisch complains about the occupation‰Ûªs disruption of his research, his concerns are scoffed. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs not that delicate,‰Ûù one farmer says dismissively.

The farm in question is a section of the 104-acre Gill Tract, owned by the University of California since 1928 and used mainly for agricultural research and recreation. Tired of fighting a long-in-the-works plan to sell a small parcel for residential and retail use, proponents of urban farming finally moved in, planted seeds and refused to leave.

Just causes don‰Ûªt always inspire good documentaries, and while ‰ÛÏOccupy the Farm‰Ûù might garner sympathy for the grass-roots movement that gives the film its title, that doesn‰Ûªt mean its argument is even close to being fairly constructed. Rather than present an evenhanded assessment of the issues at stake, the director, Todd Darling, is so busy fist-pumping for urban farming ‰ÛÓ and so dazzled by his granola heroes ‰ÛÓ that naysayers must be demeaned and denigrated.

Equally egregious are the selective and irrelevant on-screen facts that accompany shots of university officials, one of whom ‰ÛÓ we are told as his image freezes to black and white ‰ÛÓ has written about ‰ÛÏSoviet and Kremlin leadership.‰Ûù I guess we didn‰Ûªt need to know that he also served on a committee dedicated to preventing nuclear war.
‰ÛÏRed Army‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Some salty language.

But there are two sides to every story, and from the Russian perspective, the Lake Placid games are a minor, unfortunate episode in a glorious and sometimes tragic history. The Soviet squad that lost in 1980 won gold medals in the next two Olympics and is almost universally regarded as the greatest hockey team ever assembled. In 1991, the system that spawned and sustained it ‰ÛÓ making national heroes and political pawns of its members ‰ÛÓ collapsed, an event that altered the course of global sports, along with everything else. Former Soviet players made their way to the N.H.L., where they did not always find a warm welcome.

Good sports movies are always about more than sports. ‰ÛÏMiracle,‰Ûù Gavin O‰ÛªConnor‰Ûªs 2004 feature about the 1980 American team, with Kurt Russell as Herb Brooks, is a fable of underdog grit and can-do spirit. ‰ÛÏRed Army‰Ûù touches on themes of friendship and perseverance, and also offers a compact and vivid summary of recent Russian history. It provides as clear an explanation as I have seen for the appeal of Vladimir V. Putin, who has revived some of the patriotic sentiments that held the old system in place, including the emphasis on sports as an expression of national greatness. For Mr. Fetisov, a former minister of sports, a member of the National Assembly and a prosperous businessman, this is a happy ending. It may also give Mr. Polsky or some future documentarian material for a sequel.

Life for the Soviet players was a tangle of contradictions. They were celebrities in a society devoted to conformity, and as high-ranking members of the Soviet military, they enjoyed privileges denied to most of their fellow citizens. But their lives were also restricted and controlled to a degree that caused resentment and heartbreak. Their year-round training regimen under Mr. Tikhonov kept them away from their families for months, and they chafed under his impersonal, rigid discipline.

Mr. Fetisov was at the core of a team distinguished by speed and fluidity. The architect of their approach was Anatoly Tarasov, a coach whose roly-poly physique seemed at odds with his devotion to grace and finesse on the ice. He borrowed techniques and ideas about training and strategy from ballet and chess, other great Soviet obsessions, making his players perform somersaults and pirouettes in skates and heavy pads. In archival footage, he appears jolly and cherubic, in notable contrast to his successor, Viktor Tikhonov, a K.G.B. man who looks like a caricature of the gray-faced, dogmatic Brezhnev-era apparatchik.

This stirring, crazy story ‰ÛÓ a Russian novel of Tolstoyan sweep and Gogol-esque absurdity ‰ÛÓ is recounted in ‰ÛÏRed Army,‰Ûù Gabe Polsky‰Ûªs jaunty collage of a documentary. Mr. Polsky is a tireless researcher and a dogged interviewer, sometimes to the annoyance of his subjects. In an early sequence, his pushiness earns a raised middle finger from the great defenseman Vyacheslav Fetisov, but Mr. Fetisov‰Ûªs occasionally grumpy participation is crucial to the film. As handsome as any movie star, thoughtful and temperamental, he is both narrator and hero, and serves as a guide to the curious, vanished world of high-level Communist athletics.

But there were also those gold medals, and a genuine camaraderie that Mr. Fetisov and his colleagues look back on with nostalgia. When they make their way, post-U.S.S.R., into the commercial world of the N.H.L., ‰ÛÏRed Army‰Ûù takes a poignant, slightly surreal turn, with cheesy American and Canadian television clips stepping in for old Russian newsreels and Western show business vulgarity sweeping aside the pomp and bluster of official Communism. The mid-‰Ûª90s provided a happy second act for Mr. Fetisov and his erstwhile teammates, who reunited as the Russian Five to win back-to-back Stanley Cups for the Detroit Red Wings.

Americans of a certain age, even those otherwise indifferent to hockey, are likely to have vivid memories of the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., when a bunch of American college players upset a formidable Soviet team. It was the Miracle on Ice, a Cold War victory greeted with chants of ‰ÛÏU-S-A! U-S-A!‰Ûù and, according to Herb Brooks, the United States coach, proof that our way of life was better than theirs.
‰ÛÏRosewater‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence and beatings.

Maziar (the Mexican actor Gael GarcÌ_a Bernal) is arrested soon after the movie opens, when his mother, Moloojoon (Shohreh Aghdashloo), shakes him awake. Having returned to Iran, he is back in his old bed, surrounded by mementos and memories that will haunt him throughout his time in prison. As he‰Ûªs being driven away, the story flashes back to around the time when Maziar first arrives in Iran intending to cover the coming elections. Mr. Stewart packs a lot into these initial scenes, filling in details about Maziar‰Ûªs life ‰ÛÓ including the pregnancy of his girlfriend back in London and the dead father and dead sister who remain poignantly alive for him ‰ÛÓ and setting his personal liberation story within the larger political context of the liberating aspirations of the Green Movement.

In interviews, Mr. Bahari has described his ordeal as Kafkaesque. That‰Ûªs a familiar modern shorthand for bizarre, impenetrable nightmares and fitting here given that Mr. Bahari was accused of phantom crimes, like being a Zionist. That‰Ûªs getting ahead of the story, however, which begins in 2009 or maybe, really, in 1979, the year of the Iranian Revolution. Or perhaps it begins in 1953, when the United States and Britain backed a coup d‰ÛªÌ©tat that led to the ouster of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran, cementing the shah‰Ûªs power and contributing to the anti-Americanism that ‰ÛÓ in all its absurd and deadly serious iterations ‰ÛÓ is spectacularly on display in ‰ÛÏRosewater.‰Ûù

Among its virtues, ‰ÛÏRosewater,‰Ûù the directorial debut of Jon Stewart, is an argument for filmmakers to start their trade after they‰Ûªve looked beyond the limits of their own horizons. This fictional movie tells the story of the real Maziar Bahari, an Iranian-born journalist living in London who was arrested in Iran while covering the 2009 elections for Newsweek. Accused of being an agent for foreign intelligence organizations, he was thrown into the Evin Prison, where he was interrogated and beaten, partly for the surreal reason that he had appeared on ‰ÛÏThe Daily Show With Jon Stewart.‰Ûù Mr. Stewart‰Ûªs interest in the material is obviously personal, but his movie transcends mere self-interest.

Even in prison, Maziar is engaged in political dialogue about Iran, though now also with the dead and not just the living. As days turn into weeks and then months, and the beatings and maddeningly circular, sometimes surrealistically comic interrogations blur, Maziar learns to escape through fantasies and memories. He conjures up his father (a very good Haluk Bilginer), a gracefully stern and ghostly presence who offers advice and gently harangues him. Maziar‰Ûªs sister (Golshifteh Farahani) also appears, offering comfort and guidance. There is insanity inside these walls, but Maziar, having opened himself to the world ‰ÛÓ to Chekhov, Pasolini and Leonard Cohen ‰ÛÓ had already freed his mind long ago. The trick, as you learn, was getting the rest of him out, too.

Mr. Stewart adapted the movie from Mr. Bahari‰Ûªs 2011 memoir, which was written with Aimee Molloy and published as ‰ÛÏThen They Came for Me‰Ûù but has been promotionally repackaged as ‰ÛÏRosewater.‰Ûù The book‰Ûªs original title echoes the oft-quoted line from the German pastor Martin NiemÌ_ller, ‰ÛÏThen they came for me ‰ÛÓ and there was no one left to speak for me.‰Ûù As a famous call to speaking out (originally against Nazism), it underscores the universal tug of Mr. Bahari‰Ûªs ordeal even as it carries the complicating weight of the Holocaust. ‰ÛÏRosewater‰Ûù is the better title, partly because, as Mr. Stewart makes clear, it‰Ûªs the specifics of Mr. Bahari‰Ûªs story ‰ÛÓ his voice, memories, fantasies, ghosts and abiding love of Leonard Cohen ‰ÛÓ that distinguishes it.

Once Maziar is in prison, and the world and its distractions fall away (and Mr. Bernal‰Ûªs over-bright, over-deployed smile dims), so do any qualms about the star. Whatever the reason Mr. Bernal was hired, whether it was a question of getting the movie financed or simply a matter of directorial taste, his intensely sympathetic screen presence suddenly makes sense. And it‰Ûªs in Evin Prison that Mr. Stewart does his best work, specifically in the scenes between Maziar and the man who gives the movie‰Ûªs title its nauseating, sickly meaning, the guard (an excellent Kim Bodnia) whose rosewater perfume can‰Ûªt obscure the stench that wafts off his body and announces his presence to his blindfolded prisoner. ‰ÛÏI could smell him,‰Ûù Mr. Bahari writes, ‰ÛÏbefore I saw him.‰Ûù

This restless telescopic movement ‰ÛÓ with its back and forth between the long view and the close, the political and the personal ‰ÛÓ continues as Maziar reports on the election, cruises the streets, conducts interviews and takes the pulse of the people. Working with the cinematographer Bobby Bukowski, Mr. Stewart gives the movie a run-and-gun tremble that‰Ûªs familiar from documentaries and war movies. This visual approach, along with the dusty, churning streets (with Jordan standing in for Iran), swirling crowds and looming images of Iranian leaders, contributes to the you-are-there authenticity that, at first, fights with some of Mr. Stewart‰Ûªs other choices, including casting a well-known Mexican actor as his lead and having the Iranian characters speak in accented English.

A pretty young actress. A casting call. A private meeting with the lecherous man who has the power to give her the role. ‰ÛÏStarry Eyes‰Ûù tries to wring a horror movie out of this tired old setup but, halfway in, seems to realize it has nothing new to offer and becomes a mere gorefest.

Alexandra Essoe plays the actress, Sarah, who is frustrated by her inability to break into the business and prone to hair-pulling fits even before she goes on the fateful casting call. She makes the decision that actresses in this story line always seem to make, only to find that in succumbing to the lecher she has also sold her soul.

So far so good, but then Kevin Kolsch and Dennis Widmyer, who jointly wrote and directed, appear to run out of ideas, sending Sarah on a writhing, sputtering killing spree through her circle of friends and roommates that isn‰Ûªt particularly scary, just gross. Ms. Essoe does pretty well with what she‰Ûªs given. It would be nice to see her in a more substantive movie.

Maybe the filmmakers think they‰Ûªre saying something about prostituting oneself, in one way or another, in pursuit of the hollow goal of stardom. If so, the idea is hardly original. There are hints of satire beneath the goings-on, but if that was the intent, it‰Ûªs too veiled.

You don‰Ûªt hear much of what Mark, who‰Ûªs most expressive when he‰Ûªs grunting and grappling on a mat, says other than in 1984 he was a champion, winning the gold medal hanging from his neck. The scene cuts away before he‰Ûªs finished his speech, but like his solitary wrestling, it helps establish the narrowness of his world and the movie‰Ûªs thematic terrain. By the time a school official is writing Mark his $20 check, Mr. Miller has announced at least some of what he wants to tell us about America. Mark is so isolated visually and narratively that even when he eats ‰ÛÓ he scarfs fast food alone in his car, and slurps instant noodles in his grim apartment ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs no question that you‰Ûªre watching the emergence of a character‰Ûªs existential condition rather than some guy chow down.

Much of what‰Ûªs publicly known about the relationship between the real figures in this strange tale comes from news reports that broke after a catastrophically violent episode upended both their lives. Directed by Bennett Miller from a screenplay by E. Max Frye and Dan Futterman, ‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù is prefaced by the common assurance that it‰Ûªs based on a true story, although all the usual caveats apply, with changes, elisions and so forth. This is familiar ground for Mr. Miller, whose films include two fictions rooted in history, ‰ÛÏCapote‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMoneyball,‰Ûù which, along with being just really good stories, take diagnostic pokes at the national character and its swamp of confusing, contradictory ideas about material success, hard work, self-invention and, inevitably, what it is to be a man.

‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù has another good story, though it‰Ûªs a slippery one. Beautifully acted and impeccably mounted, it is light on historical details and heavy on atmosphere, character and chintz. The first time you see Mark he‰Ûªs alone in a gym wrestling with a grappling dummy, an apparatus that looks like an anthropomorphized boxing bag, complete with head and stubby arms. It‰Ûªs a crude pas de deux, somewhat like watching Gene Kelly get frisky with a beanbag, and hypnotic because of its exotic choreography. It‰Ûªs also off-putting because there‰Ûªs something slightly comic and borderline pathetic about a man who is, for all intents and purposes, wrestling with himself. Soon after, Mark delivers a speech to some school kids ‰ÛÓ he wants to tell them about America ‰ÛÓ for which he earns a princely $20.

Mr. Miller does his finest work with his three superb leads, though I wish he had made more room for Mr. Ruffalo, who enters and exits as Dave flashes in and out of Mark‰Ûªs life. Some of the best scenes in the movie are of the brothers, including an early one in which they train in their old gym, hitting and grasping in a pantomime of aggression and affection, the crowns of their heads touching like the antlers of young stags testing each other. It‰Ûªs rare to see such physical male intimacy on screen, especially among men not bonded by war. And it‰Ûªs in the depictions of this intimacy, in its tangle of bodies and desires ‰ÛÓ the images of John squirming on top of and below other men say more than any of his pitiful speeches ‰ÛÓ that ‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù rises to the occasion of real tragedy.

Much of ‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù takes place at this increasingly unfunny funny farm, with its rolling hills, patrician veneer, expensive kitsch, tiptoeing servants, stable of horses and a wizened, wagging finger in the form of John‰Ûªs disapproving mother (Vanessa Redgrave). Mr. Miller‰Ûªs handling of the earlier stages in John and Mark‰Ûªs relationship is impeccable and sometimes lightly, uneasily comic. Mr. Carell‰Ûªs physical transformation is perverse, hypnotic and a touch distracting, and you may find yourself searching for the familiar face behind the pasty skin and large prosthetic nose that juts from John‰Ûªs face like a cruel joke. Little by little, with long stares, an old man‰Ûªs shuffle and strange phrasing, Mr. Carell transforms the character from a figure of ridicule into something truly grotesque.

In ‰ÛÏFoxcatcher,‰Ûù an eerie horror story about one American have and one have-not, a startlingly transformed Steve Carell plays John EleuthÌ¬re du Pont, the chemical company heir. A dabbler extraordinaire and apparent fantasist whose family fortune was partly created on battlefields across the world ‰ÛÓ as a producer of gun powder, dynamite and plutonium ‰ÛÓ the real du Pont collected monumental amounts of shells, birds and stamps as well as guns and, as the wealthy can do, other human beings. Among the most remarkable of these was an Olympic wrestler, Mark Schultz, who, as embodied by Channing Tatum, is the latest in a seemingly never-ending line of poetic male primitives.
‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence and language.

Mr. Miller, however, wants more than just an ordinary American sideshow, and he unwisely tries to expand the story when just telling it would have been enough. At times he seems to be trying to resurrect the idea of two Americas that‰Ûªs crucial to ‰ÛÏCapote,‰Ûù which tracks Truman Capote‰Ûªs investigation into the murder of an ordinary family by a pair of killers. But there‰Ûªs no one here like Capote to guide you through the murk and no one who gives the spectacle of human struggle its spark, as the baseball savant Billy Beane does in ‰ÛÏMoneyball.‰Ûù Mark and John make a fine odd couple in ‰ÛÏFoxcatcher‰Ûù (things get seriously weird at the farm), but they never evolve into the kind of deep, meaningful figures who can carry the weight of Mr. Miller‰Ûªs symbolism and all those American flags.

The checks have many more zeros after Mark is summoned to the du Pont estate, a vast swath of prime real estate in Newtown Square, Pa. There, John has created a wrestling facility that he‰Ûªs baptized Foxcatcher Farm, and which, through his patronage, he hopes or more rightly expects will lead to Olympic glory. Mark accepts the offer to live and train at Foxcatcher, dazzled by John‰Ûªs wealth and quasi-religious pitch ‰ÛÓ a hash of patriotism, paternalism, entrepreneurialism and old-fashioned hucksterism. Despite Mark‰Ûªs appeals, though, his older brother, Dave (Mark Ruffalo), himself a gifted wrestler who doesn‰Ûªt want to uproot his family, declines to join the crusade. When John learns that he‰Ûªs been turned down he pauses so long that it‰Ûªs clear the word no is foreign to him.

And he, too, is a haunting figure, an enigmatic alloy of decency, selfishness, murderous rage and tenderness. Originally the film‰Ûªs exaggerated, folkloric comic spark, he winds up as its reality principle and the bearer of its tragic weight. It may take time to absorb the sorrow of ‰ÛÏThe Homesman,‰Ûù to appreciate the odd rhythms and jarring surprises of its plot and to grasp its unsettling ideas about the American West and the larger civilization that conquered it. The movie shows us a cruel and beautiful place where grit is rewarded and goodness is betrayed, where venality and righteousness coexist and are sometimes hard to tell apart. A place that might look like home.

The three are tied up and locked into a boxy wagon, which encounters some of the usual western trouble ‰ÛÓ a lawless gunslinger, a band of Indians, bad weather ‰ÛÓ as well as some less familiar problems. Mr. Jones‰Ûªs primary interest is in the two main characters, who at first look like archetypal figures but evolve into complex, vulnerable, unpredictable human beings. Ms. Swank starts out emphasizing Mary Bee‰Ûªs strength and stoicism, her acceptance of disappointment and her natural courage. At the end, we are left with a sadder, more enigmatic picture. Mary Bee, who once annoyed Briggs, now haunts him.

Mary Bee is treated with frank admiration by the local minister (John Lithgow) and with grudging respect by other neighbors. But the words flung in her direction ‰ÛÓ on two separate occasions, by two different men, both spurning her offer of marriage ‰ÛÓ are ‰ÛÏbossy‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏplain.‰Ûù The point of ‰ÛÏThe Homesman,‰Ûù directed by Tommy Lee Jones and based on Glendon Swarthout‰Ûªs novel of the same name, is not that these adjectives are inappropriate. Ms. Swank is about as far from plain as it‰Ûªs possible for a human being to be. The point is that even in situations where toughness is paramount and survival is at stake, a woman will still be judged by her looks and her docility.

In the early scenes, Mary Bee ‰ÛÓ walking behind a mule-drawn plow, tending livestock, making supper and playing silent music on an embroidery keyboard ‰ÛÓ evokes the world of John Ford. She has carried civilization into the wilderness and in the face of adversity has upheld its values of cleanliness, godliness and culture. Briggs, on the other hand, arrives on the scene in a literal blast of Looney Tunes slapstick. After a bomb is sent down his chimney, he stumbles into the frame in his long johns, covered in soot, a plume of smoke rising from his disheveled head. It‰Ûªs as if Yosemite Sam had turned up in the pages of a Willa Cather novel.

Set in a flat, unforgiving stretch of the American frontier in the decade before the Civil War, ‰ÛÏThe Homesman‰Ûù is both a captivating western and a meticulous, devastating feminist critique of the genre. Mr. Jones, who rides alongside Ms. Swank as a whiskery ruffian known as Briggs, uses western iconography to dismantle a familiar set of romantic myths. Most basically, the journey Briggs and Mary Bee undertake is not further into the West but back toward the East. It is a trek that originates in failure, passes through frustration and concludes on ambiguous notes of sorrow, resignation and cynicism.

As an actor, Mr. Jones is well within his comfort zone playing an irascible old coot. As a director, he is both canny and bold, dropping bits of backwoods humor into an austere landscape dominated by violence and anguish. (This is his second feature, after ‰ÛÏThe Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada.‰Ûù) The reason Briggs and Mary Bee are headed back across the river to Iowa is that three local women have gone mad and need to be brought back home. The causes of their distress are clear enough: dead children, bad land, brutal husbands. They need to be sent away for their own good but also because their presence is a rebuke to the fledgling settlement‰Ûªs idea of itself.
‰ÛÏThe Homesman‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Flesh and blood.

Plenty of words might describe Mary Bee Cuddy, the Nebraska farmer played by Hilary Swank in ‰ÛÏThe Homesman.‰Ûù A paragon of pioneer self-sufficiency, she is capable and conscientious, industrious and morally upright. Her prosperity looks like the visible reward of a sturdy work ethic, and she takes pride in her tidy and well-appointed wooden house, set amid the sod-sided hovels of her fellow homesteaders.

Mary Bee accepts the job of transporting the women and extorts Briggs‰Ûªs help after she saves his life. Her compassion and his patience are tested by their passengers. Gro Svendsen (Sonja Richter), a Norwegian woman with an especially nasty mate, howls and bites. Arabella Sours (Grace Gummer), barely more than a child, refuses to move or speak, clutching the rag doll that is her substitute for the babies she lost. Theoline Belknap (Miranda Otto), who drowned her own baby in a latrine, stares at the others, wide-eyed and disheveled.
Like most Bollywood movies, ‰ÛÏKill Dil‰Ûù is a cocktail of familiar ingredients. Here, the mix is one part outlaw buddy film with one part romance, served with songs and twists.

Instead, Dev (Mr. Singh) finds love, in the form of Disha (Parineeti Chopra), an educated woman with a referred-to but never-seen job of reforming criminals. (Hard to imagine she‰Ûªs good at it. She has no clue about Dev.) Soon, Dev buries his gun and declares to his buddy Tutu (Mr. Zafar) and the heavens, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm tired of being bad.‰Ûù

Dev, a grade-school dropout, has trouble finding work in the sleek office towers of the new economy. When he finally lands a job, his rickety office has pictures of Gandhi on the wall. And Dev and Tutu‰Ûªs living quarters ‰ÛÓ on a roof with a view of a highway overpass, where the sky is always a muted, polluted yellow ‰ÛÓ might as well be in a different city from Disha‰Ûªs glamorously suburban digs.

‰ÛÏKill Dil‰Ûù has excellent songs by Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy, and one memorable, stakes-clarifying dance sequence that juxtaposes two styles: the macho moves of the criminals (led by Govinda) and the alluringly feminine ones of Disha‰Ûªs world, where Dev is playing hooky. It‰Ûªs easy to know which side to root for.

Directed by Shaad Ali, ‰ÛÏKill Dil‰Ûù is a production of Yash Raj Films, which mostly churns out candy-coated tales set in a fantasy India. But Mr. Ali‰Ûªs movie has glimmers of reality and even of a social conscience.

If ‰ÛÏKill Dil‰Ûù (‰ÛÏdil‰Ûù means heart in Hindi) breaks no new ground, its twists are worth considering. In the opening sequences, we meet two orphaned boys raised on the wrong side of the law (‰ÛÏbreast fed on gulps of blood‰Ûù). They quickly grow up to be killers played by movie stars (Ranveer Singh and Ali Zafar, underused in a glowering, change-of-pace role), their hair bouncing prettily as they run from crime to crime.
Like many recent Hindi movies, ‰ÛÏKill Dil‰Ûù asks the audience to admire its heroes‰Ûª outlaw gumption. But after the shoot-‰Ûªem-up opener, the movie stops wanting us to applaud their violence.

The children, who are eager to have their pictures taken for a school yearbook, want to look like the models and entertainers they see on television. The curly-headed Junior dreams of being a pop singer with a slick, shiny coiffure. His friend imagines herself as a skinny, tiara-crowned beauty contestant. Obsessed with his appearance, Junior continually inspects himself in the mirror and experiments with hair-straightening techniques, one of which involves a gooey mixture of mayonnaise and mashed avocado.

Junior has a sympathetic champion in his indulgent paternal grandmother, Carmen (Nelly Ramos), who has a blow dryer and gives him grooming tips. In a metaphorically loaded scene, he is photographed curly-headed on one side and slick-haired on the other. The dueling hairstyles suggest an inner conflict between conformity and individuality in a restrictive environment. More than conveying ambiguous sexuality, they reflect the narrow range of self-expression in Venezuela under Hugo ChÌÁvez, who at the time of the film was ailing but still alive.

‰ÛÏBad Hair‰Ûù is an uncomfortably accurate depiction of a poignant mother-son power struggle in a fatherless family in which each knows how to get under the other‰Ûªs skin. The instinctive and volatile characters in this hard little gem of a film have no awareness of the boundary issues so dear to the hearts of contemporary therapists.
