They have neither the time nor the money for the luxury of intervention. They need all their resources merely to survive.

In a quietly transfixing scene from the Venezuelan director Mariana RondÌ_n‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBad Hair,‰Ûù the camera gazes through the eyes of a 9-year-old, Junior (Samuel Lange), as he and a playmate (MarÌ_a Emilia SulbarÌÁn) survey the teeming Caracas housing development across the street and make up stories about its residents. What they see in a giant building that resembles a dingy, crumbling factory is a social microcosm of the impoverished Venezuelan capital, where the threat of violence hangs in the air.

His beautiful but grim widowed mother, Marta (Samantha Castillo), works on and off as a security guard. She has all but given up hope of a better life and desperately tries to make ends meet while bringing up two children, of whom Junior is the older. Unlike Marta, Junior is still young enough to dream. And he watches with longing as his mother lavishes his baby brother with the kind of physical intimacy for which he yearns.

This coolheaded neorealist movie doesn‰Ûªt waste time wringing its hands over the impoverished lives it observes or fretting about psychological quirks. Marta reads Junior‰Ûªs lack of interest in sports and obsession with his appearance as signs that he might be gay. Blaming herself for his supposed effeminacy, she drags him to a doctor, who pronounces him healthy but in need of male role models. Afterward, she forbids him to hang out with a friendly neighborhood teenager who runs a grocery stand.

Carmen makes Junior a foppish outfit that he despises because he thinks it looks like a dress. Already, he has begun to absorb the message that looking girlish is dangerous for a boy. Marta, in a foolhardy effort to teach him masculinity, leaves his bedroom door ajar so he can observe her having perfunctory, joyless sex with a manly role model. Watching from his bed, Junior turns away.

It is a daily struggle for the angry, determined Marta to find someone to look after the baby while she‰Ûªs at work and to make enough to pay for his day care. When she loses her job, she does what has to be done, even if it means sleeping with the boss who fired her in exchange for work.

Mr. Bar-Lev includes searching, painful interviews with Paterno‰Ûªs widow and two of his sons, and with Matt Sandusky, Jerry Sandusky‰Ûªs adopted son, who offers a harrowing glimpse into the household of a serial pedophile. There are conversations with critics and partisans of Penn State and its football team, including a student who thinks the punishment of the university went much too far and a lawyer who believes it did not go far enough.

The answers, especially as articulated in a report overseen by Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the F.B.I., only deepened the sense of crisis at Penn State. Suspicions about Mr. Sandusky had been raised as early as 1998, but nothing was done. The N.C.A.A. banned the team from bowl games and nullified all victories from 1998 to 2011, taking away Paterno‰Ûªs status as the most winning coach in major college football.

Later the halo will be painted over, and a statue of Paterno, a landmark for fans and tourists, will be uprooted from its place outside the football stadium. The cause of this downfall is well known far beyond Central Pennsylvania. In 2012, Jerry Sandusky, a longtime defensive coach under Paterno, was convicted on 45 counts related to the sexual abuse of children. Mr. Sandusky had used his charity, which ostensibly helped poor and vulnerable youngsters, as a way of finding and grooming victims and camouflaging his crimes in good works.

But Mr. Sandusky‰Ûªs actions are not the subject of ‰ÛÏHappy Valley,‰Ûù which recounts the sorry tale of his trial and its aftermath. His monstrousness has been amply documented in Pulitzer Prize-winning reporting by Sara Ganim and others at The Patriot-News in Harrisburg, Pa., and in exhaustive, sometimes prurient coverage on national television. Mr. Bar-Lev, whose other documentaries include ‰ÛÏThe Tillman Story‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMy Kid Could Paint That,‰Ûù is more interested in the storm of shame, denial and anger ‰ÛÓ the crisis of faith ‰ÛÓ that washed over State College as attention turned from Mr. Sandusky to the team and the university administration. Did anyone know that a sexual predator was at large in the football program, using its prestige to his own despicable ends? Did anyone try to stop him?

‰ÛÏHappy Valley,‰Ûù even as it revisits past events, has a chilling timeliness. Mr. Sandusky‰Ûªs crimes are his alone, but there are enough other scandals related to college sports to suggest a pattern of dysfunction. Big-time college sports represent an area of American culture where democratic values give way to other, more atavistic impulses: the worship of authority, the celebration of discipline and conformity, the absorption of the individual‰Ûªs voice into the roar of the crowd. Societies where statues are erected in honor of living people and then pulled down in disgrace are not usually happy places.

‰ÛÏHappy Valley‰Ûù also records some ugly and disturbing moments, including the campus riot the night after Paterno‰Ûªs firing, when students knocked down lampposts and upended cars. A strain of self-pitying defensiveness is evident among Penn State loyalists, who defiantly chant Paterno‰Ûªs name at gatherings and ritualistically blame ‰ÛÏthe media‰Ûù for the university‰Ûªs woes.

The people on screen in ‰ÛÏHappy Valley,‰Ûù Amir Bar-Lev‰Ûªs powerful new documentary, frequently describe Penn State football as a religion. This is almost not a metaphor. The film pays periodic visits to a large outdoor mural in State College, Pa., where Nittany Lion luminaries are depicted as if they were figures in an Italian Renaissance tableau of biblical luminaries. At one point, a halo is painted in over the head of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State head football coach who died in 2012, a few months after being fired from the position he had held for 46 seasons. Mr. Bar-Lev‰Ûªs interview subjects sometimes describe Paterno as a god or a saint, and he is almost universally recalled as a beloved and benevolent patriarch.

The implications of the film extend far beyond State College, which is at once an isolated enclave of sports fanaticism and a symbol for other such places. The cult of personality around Paterno ‰ÛÓ a man paradoxically hailed as a deity and praised for his modesty ‰ÛÓ is hardly unique. In many states, the highest-paid public employee coaches a college football or basketball team. At the end of ‰ÛÏHappy Valley,‰Ûù we see merchandise featuring the name and likeness of Paterno‰Ûªs successor, Bill O‰ÛªBrien (who has since left for the N.F.L.).

Yet these random encounters, as well as brief interviews with band members and offbeat turns by an a cappella choir and a bunch of belting old folks, effortlessly capture the bond between this former steel town‰Ûªs spirit and the ineluctable tug of Mr. Cocker‰Ûªs lyrics.

It‰Ûªs something of a shame, then, that Florian Habicht‰Ûªs fond, featherweight documentary ‰ÛÏPulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets‰Ûù prefers not to dig too deeply into those working class riffs or the psyche that produced them. Joining the band in Sheffield, England, for its 2012 hometown farewell show, Mr. Habicht ‰ÛÓ echoing Pulp‰Ûªs biggest hit ‰ÛÓ gets down among the common people. Winkling out a selection of chatty characters, including a cheery newspaper vendor and two wisecracking old ladies in a market, he shapes a kooky, affectionate tribute that‰Ûªs happily superficial.

Onstage, getting intimate with a monitor and strutting wildly, Mr. Cocker is a jagged mass of geeky ecstasy; but the dark longings that produced some of his best songs are never plumbed. Listening to them anew, I found myself wishing that Mr. Habicht had taken inspiration more from their seedy, sad desires than from the sherbet chords and bubble gum beats that wash them down.

There was a time in the 1990s in Britain when everyone seemed to be singing Pulp songs. Kitchen sink stories of awkward lust and washing dishes, of inept sex and inevitable aging, they left lewd, lingering images of blue collar yearning. As written by Jarvis Cocker, a founder of the group and its gyrating frontman, the music at its best evoked Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook‰Ûªs work for Squeeze, whose 1979 hit ‰ÛÏUp the Junction‰Ûù remains a tiny miracle of songwriting.

For all we know, Mr. Serra‰Ûªs immersive period film might be a lost chapter from Casanova‰Ûªs memoirs, and this eccentric filmmaker, too, goes way beyond conventional expectations. The opening candlelit alfresco banquet, set in Switzerland, sets a suitable tone, given the notorious 18th-century libertine‰Ûªs appetites. But rather than serial romances pursued across the Continent, much of what follows consists of desultory pleasures enjoyed by Casanova at home and, later, affairs with servants at a Carpathian boarding house.

The dark count is suddenly just there, an apparition of the gothic in Casanova‰Ûªs playground of life. There‰Ûªs no lunging, dueling between legends or arterial spray, as this Dracula (Eliseu Huertas) fits the mold of a fleeting wraith, bellowing after a bloody drink but embodying a mood as much as a myth.

Mr. Serra has said his film portrays the eclipse of Enlightenment rationality by the violent forces of Romanticism. It‰Ûªs a tidy overarching conceit, but the film‰Ûªs lived-in feel does make for one vivid way of imagining shifts in thought.

Mr. Serra plunges us into the earthy sensualism and longueurs of Casanova‰Ûªs daily life. The bewigged man of mysterious means gets his kicks quoting Montaigne to his befuddled servant, slurping down oysters and fruit and giggling over acts of defecation (his own ‰ÛÏgifts‰Ûù and others‰Ûª). Letting darkness fall where it may and conversations linger, the filmmaker gets inside unfiltered experience as he did with the travails of Don Quixote in ‰ÛÏHonor of the Knights‰Ûù (which amounted to a series of drolly hilarious blackout sketches) and the Three Wise Men in ‰ÛÏBirdsong.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs a form that‰Ûªs perhaps no more open-ended than the wide-ranging intimate travels of the mind and body in Casanova‰Ûªs memoir, but Mr. Serra notably resists the pull of his idol‰Ûªs confessional storytelling (and isn‰Ûªt as witty). ‰ÛÏStory of My Death‰Ûù is no adaptation, and it‰Ûªs free to grow opaque, quite literally, with a lot of elliptical, dimly lit tÌ»te-ÌÊ-tÌ»tes involving Casanova (VicenÌ_ AltaiÌ_, a poet and critic) or his servant Pompeu (LluÌ_s Serrat, who played Sancho Panza in ‰ÛÏHonor‰Ûù). As nightfall appears to drop permanently on the film, lovely guitar strumming on the soundtrack is replaced by rumbling drum rolls.

You might also say that Mr. Serra moves from journal-like escapades and moments, each held for the fixed camera, into an all-encompassing saturnine poem of darkness. A stubborn obscurity in several senses prevents him from investing every minute of his film with the same richness and immediacy, but it‰Ûªs still an alchemical experiment well worth witnessing.

According to Casanova‰Ûªs extravagant, improbable memoir, ‰ÛÏThe Story of My Life,‰Ûù his earliest childhood memory involves being locked in a chest by a witch to treat childhood nosebleeds and hallucinating a bejeweled woman descending from the chimney. It should therefore surprise no one that Albert Serra‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStory of My Death,‰Ûù which stars Casanova, also co-stars Dracula ‰ÛÓ here, a sveltely pompadoured, pug-face figure in black who invites farm girls back to his castle with the far-out line ‰ÛÏWe go way beyond.‰Ûù

By the time the vampire in the chador is skateboarding down a dark, desolate street, the director Ana Lily Amirpour has ensured that ‰ÛÏA Girl Walks Home Alone at Night‰Ûù will roll on in your memory. The vampire, a Persian-speaking waif called the Girl (Sheila Vand), also wears a striped fishing shirt and an occasional smear across her mouth that isn‰Ûªt lipstick. She‰Ûªs taken the skateboard from a nameless tyke (Milad Eghbali), whose indomitable quality and threadbare clothes evoke the children populating Abbas Kiarostami‰Ûªs early films and, in turn, those of Italian neorealism. Whatever the inspiration, the kid is just one of a number of character types drifting through Ms. Amirpour‰Ûªs cinematic fun house.

Shot for what seems like two well-spent dollars and change, this black-and-white movie opens with a male beauty, Arash (Arash Marandi), a gardener who‰Ûªs been dolled up to resemble James Dean but looks more like a James Franco cousin. Wearing a T-shirt and jeans, his hair flopping prettily, Arash is posed in a desolate vista that brings to mind ‰ÛÏGiant,‰Ûù the 1956 wide-screen soap in which James Dean pines for Elizabeth Taylor through a fog of complications and under a coat of crude oil. (It may summon up Texas, but everyone speaks Persian, which produces a mild estrangement effect.) Arash doesn‰Ûªt appear terribly tortured, though he‰Ûªs burdened by his addict father, Hossein (Marshall Manesh), a swamp of misery indebted to a pimp, Saeed (Dominic Rains).

There are other types milling around the periphery, including a prostitute, Atti (Mozhan Marno), and a rich woman, a so-called princess, Shaydah (Rome Shadanloo). For the most part, however, Ms. Amirpour, in her feature directing debut, spends her time switching between Arash and the Girl, whose lives unfold on nearly parallel story tracks that ‰ÛÓ detail by detail, incident by incident ‰ÛÓ gradually converge. In one scene, the pimp seizes Arash‰Ûªs Thunderbird to help satisfy Hossein‰Ûªs debt; in another, the Girl watches as the pimp, hunkered down in the Thunderbird, threateningly shakes down the prostitute. Time and again, the relationships in the movie are defined by the exchange of money and the tremors and eruptions of violence that invariably accompany its circulation.

Ms. Amirpour shot her movie in Bakersfield, Calif., and she has obviously watched her share of Sergio Leone westerns. She can fill a wide-screen frame, and if you don‰Ûªt mind narrative repetition and passages in which nothing much happens, beyond pretty people staring at other pretty people, you may not mind that she has trouble filling this overlong movie, which comes in at 107 minutes, when 70 would have done nicely. Still, she gives you much to look at, including an image that looks like Madonna (it‰Ûªs Margaret Atwood!) on the Girl‰Ûªs wall that suggests that time (and life) stopped for the vampire in the 1980s. The image reflects the movie‰Ûªs humor and feminism, and suggests Ms. Amirpour‰Ûªs complex relationship to appropriation.

That complexity is suggested by the Girl‰Ûªs look, which conjures up the ‰ÛÏPapa Don‰Ûªt Preach‰Ûù music video in which Madonna wears a shirt and a pixie do borrowed from Jean Seberg. The video is a model of pop-culture intertextuality that makes a virtue out of its wide-ranging sampling, and much of its fun came from peeling its thickly layered influences. Something similar initially seems at work in ‰ÛÏA Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.‰Ûù This is a movie that, after all, invites you to play a game of Name That Allusion, with Dean, Leone and so forth. Yet even as Ms. Amirpour draws heavily from various bodies of work with vampirelike hunger, she gives her influences new life by channeling them through other cultural forms, including her chador-cloaked vampire. The Girl isn‰Ûªt actually alone: She has lots and lots of company.

One new couple is trying to get things together. One longtime couple is trying not to break apart. One paunchy, white-bearded man in a towel is trying to get some satisfaction in a steam room. And one angelic 11-year-old is learning that his priest doesn‰Ûªt want to hear about a young boy‰Ûªs sexual stirrings. With those stories, Sergio Tovar Velarde‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏ4 Moons‰Ûù (‰ÛÏCuatro Lunas‰Ûù) paints a spirited and sensitive portrait of gay boys and men in 21st-century Mexico.

Strikingly photographed by Yannick Nolin, with occasional full-frontal male nudity, graphic sexual encounters and rooms full of bare buttocks (a sex club scene), this quiet romantic drama never soars but keeps its sense of humor and its balance while taking its subject matter for granted in the best possible way.

The film‰Ûªs tone flirts with smugness, though it never crosses the line. At the end, the boy (Gabriel Santoyo) who visited the priest shows off his culinary talents to his parents, topping every entree with a single, perfect strawberry, and his narrow-minded father struggles to embrace the revelation that his only son is gay.

Alonso EchÌÁnove is particularly sympathetic as the bearded man, who turns out to be a noted poet ‰ÛÓ the kind to whom colleges dedicate special days ‰ÛÓ with a loving wife, grown daughters and little grandchildren.

Maybe it‰Ûªs unrealistic to have a supposedly straight young man (Gustavo Egelhaaf) realize that he‰Ûªs gay and invite his new boyfriend over to meet his parents, to whom he‰Ûªs just come out, in a single scene, but it‰Ûªs a nice concept.

To be too specific about what those fantasies are would constitute a spoiler, but suffice it to say that Harry (Jonathan Sadowski), a graduate student, hooks up with an older woman (Connie Nielsen) he meets at a bar, but at the same time begins to become serious about a woman closer to his age (Sara Paxton) he has also just met.

‰ÛÏAll Relative,‰Ûù a tepid romantic comedy written and directed by J. C. Khoury, thinks it‰Ûªs being surprising, but really it‰Ûªs merely weaving several male sex fantasies together and making nothing insightful out of the resulting story.

You will figure out the resulting complication long before Harry does, and the rest of the movie, despite decent performances, is a predictable collection of misunderstandings and angst over what secrets to keep. It ends with the biggest male fantasy of all: that casual sex has no consequences, no matter whom it is with.

‰ÛÏDeath Metal Angola‰Ûù makes its most important point first: Few places on earth could have a better excuse to sing about blood, murder and rage than Angola, a West African nation that emerged from 27 years of civil war in 2002 and is still one of the poorest countries on the planet. But what we have here is a rather sweet story of the plan to hold Angola‰Ûªs first national rock concert in its bombed-out, rubble-strewn, second-largest city, Huambo.
The concert itself was a bold, life-affirming project, but with a couple of additional extended music sequences, Mr. Xido‰Ûªs film might have been more powerful and way more hardcore.
‰ÛÏDeath Metal Angola‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Tough talk, in subtitles.
Frankly, death metal sounds a lot scarier in its Wikipedia entry than it looks in this documentary from Jeremy Xido.

About an hour into ‰ÛÏDeath Metal Angola,‰Ûù suspense builds as to whether the concert will actually take place, and there‰Ûªs a satisfying coda. Along the way, though, the tale of Sonia Ferreira‰Ûªs reasons for running an orphanage in Huambo is often more compelling than her efforts, and those of Wilker Flores, to mount the concert. Ms. Ferreira‰Ûªs questioning of a new boy seeking refuge is a minidrama.

The most violent lyric heard in the film, sung in death metal‰Ûªs characteristic low growl, is ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm gonna take your soul.‰Ûù The mood more often expressed is that of smiling, Portuguese-speaking African children jumping up and down, chanting ‰ÛÏrock ‰Û÷n‰Ûª roll.‰Ûù

Underlying this overlong and overheated enterprise is a surfeit of ambition. Maybe too much: Its screenwriters, the Vicious Brothers ‰ÛÓ comprising Colin Minihan, the director, and Stuart Ortiz ‰ÛÓ had wanted to make ‰ÛÏExtraterrestrial‰Ûù for years but instead opted for the low-budget indie ‰ÛÏGrave Encounters,‰Ûù a video-on-demand hit. ‰ÛÏExtraterrestrial‰Ûù feels like a wish-fulfillment project; perhaps less self-indulgence was in order.

College students ‰ÛÓ played by Freddie Stroma (the handsome one), Jesse Moss (the unstable one), Melanie Papalia (the pill-popping one) and Anja Savcic (the dim one) ‰ÛÓ head to the family country retreat of the sensible April (Brittany Allen) for a weekend of fun and partying, only to discover a crash-landing U.F.O.
column9: ‰Ûù but you might be surprised by the number"

column5: You would never mistake the horror movie ‰ÛÏExtraterrestrial‰Ûù for the Steven Spielberg classic ‰ÛÏE.T. the Extraterrestrial,‰Ûù but you might be surprised by the number of scenes this picture borrows from other movies: the threatened woman in the phone booth, from the first ‰ÛÏMatrix‰Ûù; furtive, emaciated, long-armed aliens, as in ‰ÛÏDark Skies‰Ûù and countless other films; ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity- style snatches of ‰ÛÏfound‰Ûù video. A character grabs a carving knife at one point
column8: there are young people imperiled in a cabin in the woods.""ou would never mistake the horror movie ‰ÛÏExtraterrestrial‰Ûù for the Steven Spielberg classic ‰ÛÏE.T. the Extraterrestrial

column5: Each violently encounters the aforementioned visitors, who make entrances with a tremendous ruckus before absconding with their prey to another spaceship, hovering in the sky. (Its interior evokes ‰ÛÏThe Matrix,‰Ûù with a soupÌ_on of ‰ÛÏAlien.‰Ûù)

However you look at it, ‰ÛÏFood Chains‰Ûù is a mouthful. Gathering at least three films under one rousing umbrella ‰ÛÓ the fair-wage struggle of tomato pickers in Florida ‰ÛÓ this emphatic and empathetic documentary (directed by Sanjay Rawal and narrated by Forest Whitaker) presents the plight of our farm laborers as modern-day slavery.

Using this standoff as a frame, ‰ÛÏFood Chains‰Ûù enriches its argument with a brief history of low-wage field workers and unenforced laws, as well as pointed comments from a handful of relevant interviewees. Segments on the wine and clothing industries, however, only dilute our building connection to the tomato pickers, showering us with too many examples of exploitation and neglect.

It‰Ûªs very hard to disagree. Required to pick a minimum of 480 pounds of fruit per hour (hands moving so quickly that you would swear the film has been sped up), the workers average around $42 for a nine-hour shift.

The predicament of the pickers ‰ÛÓ who the author Eric Schlosser suggests in the film may constitute one facet of ‰ÛÏa new peasantry‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is more than enough to move and shame us. How miserable does your day have to be to transform the breeze from a pesticide spray into a blessing?

‰ÛÏWe live like animals in cramped housing,‰Ûù one man says, as Mr. Rawal shows us jam-packed trailers and ragtag encampments. The ability to improve these conditions lies not with the farmers, we are told, but with the fast-food industry, restaurants and supermarkets whose contracts with buyers set the economics of the supply chain. But when a coalition of tomato pickers in Immokalee, Fla., began agitating for companies to pay a penny more per pound for their tomatoes, the state‰Ûªs largest supermarket chain, Publix, refused to blink.

The conflict between past and present is even more agonizing for Gerald (Thierry Saintine), a left-wing news commentator and political firebrand whose broadsides on a Haitian radio station in New York keep those who left apprised of atrocities still taking place back home. The son of Max (Carlo Mitton), a right-wing bigwig connected to death squads, Gerald has changed his last name and married an American woman. The past catches up with him with the news that his father left the country after losing a power struggle.

Ms. Benoit‰Ûªs screenplay is unapologetically schematic in its depiction of a cross-section of Haitian exiles, but each story forcefully registers. The movie regularly flashes back to the turning points in the characters‰Ûª lives when they decided to leave Haiti. All of them ‰ÛÓ even Micheline ‰ÛÓ still have a deep love for their native country. The movie‰Ûªs perspective is probably closer to that of Yannick, who is openly scornful of her mother‰Ûªs upward mobility and snobbery.

Deep, unanswerable questions are raised. Having relocated, do you deny your heritage and reinvent yourself, like Micheline (Michele Marcelin), a real estate broker living in an upscale suburban neighborhood? Or do you stay in touch with your homeland, like Yannick (the novelist Edwidge Danticat), the oldest of Micheline‰Ûªs two daughters; she‰Ûªs a teacher and political activist who remained in Haiti after Micheline left. Yannick not only risked her life to stay but also sacrificed opportunities for a higher education in the United States. She does not regret her choice.

When the proud, dapper Max knocks on Gerald‰Ûªs door, Gerald reluctantly takes him in for the night but announces he cannot stay. Angry demonstrations break out when Max is spotted by Haitians in Gerald‰Ûªs Brooklyn neighborhood. A pathetic soul, Max raises a ruckus at a bank where he goes to take out money and discovers his account has been emptied. Rarely have the words ‰ÛÏDo you know who I am?,‰Ûù accompanied by threats, fallen on deafer ears. The unspoken question that hovers in the air is whether forgiveness of a parent is possible when that parent, no matter how fragile (Max coughs up blood), is a monster.

From the moment Yannick arrives on her doorstep, she is a walking rebuke to her mother‰Ûªs self-transformation. Micheline goes ballistic when Yannick hangs the laundry out to dry, because the neighbors will see. When Yannick takes a walk, Micheline tells her that here, people go to a gym to exercise.

A third arrival, Vita (Patricia Rhinvil), is the wife of Ronald (James Noel), a cabdriver who demonstrated for free elections in Haiti and was forced to flee, leaving Vita at the mercy of officers who raped her. Although they love each other, Vita is still so traumatized that she shrinks from Ronald‰Ûªs touch.

Their clash drives one of several interlocking stories in this profound meditation on how exiles cope with strong mixed emotions about their shared history. Micheline, whose husband was a casualty of the regime in Haiti, camouflages her heritage by posing as French, all but erasing her former identity and keeping her younger daughter in the dark about her background.

There is no sugar coating in these fraught relationships. What‰Ûªs done is done, the consequences must be faced, and the choices are painful. The past can‰Ûªt be shrugged off lightly. Like it or not, you have to live with it.

‰ÛÏStones in the Sun‰Ûù is a wrenching portrait of Haitian exiles struggling to build new lives in New York City after fleeing their country in the late 1980s. Jean-Claude Duvalier had departed, but his generals remained in power and continued his reign of terror. The film, written and directed by Patricia Benoit, is a powerfully acted exploration of the different ways that people deal with the traumatic wounds of the past.
Opens on Friday
LATE PHASES

A blind Vietnam veteran is all that stands between a hungry werewolf and the frail residents of a retirement village in ‰ÛÏLate Phases,‰Ûù a sprightly horror movie about finding new purpose for old bones.

Matching the movie‰Ûªs homely feel, Robert Kurtzman‰Ûªs old-school effects produce an endearingly shaggy creature that‰Ûªs pleasingly tactile and beholden to the laws of physics. And if the central transformation scene strains fruitlessly for the sky-high bar of Rick Baker‰Ûªs groundbreaking work on ‰ÛÏAn American Werewolf in London‰Ûù (1981), it‰Ûªs no matter: ‰ÛÏLate Phases‰Ûù is really concerned with change of a different sort. Before, Ambrose was resigned to death‰Ûªs waiting room; now, he has a reason to work out.

Working in English for the first time, the Spanish director AdriÌÁn GarcÌ_a Bogliano forgoes the veiled menace of his 2013 mystery, ‰ÛÏHere Comes the Devil,‰Ûù for something altogether less subtle. Skipping critical narrative beats ‰ÛÓ Ambrose instantly decides that ‰ÛÏWerewolf!‰Ûù is the answer to ‰ÛÏWhat just happened?‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the plot favors simplicity over rationality with a cheerful insouciance that‰Ûªs hard to dislike. Much of this good will is inspired by Mr. Damici, whose testy line readings and credible sightlessness give Ambrose‰Ûªs neighborhood perambulations an oddball intensity. I didn‰Ûªt see him blink once.
Directed by AdriÌÁn GarcÌ_a Bogliano

Our gruff hero is Ambrose (Nick Damici, far from geriatric), a brusquely independent widower who‰Ûªs closer to his service dog, Shadow, than to his harried son. Deposited in his new home, he quickly deflects a delegation of glammed-up grannies scenting fresh meat. They‰Ûªre not the only ones: A terrifyingly gory first night will leave poor Shadow flayed and Ambrose‰Ûªs closest neighbor chomped to bits.
1 hour 35 minutes; not rated

There‰Ûªs nothing fancy about ‰ÛÏLittle Hope Was Arson,‰Ûù a documentary on the 2010 church fires in East Texas, and that‰Ûªs the beauty of it. The filmmaker, Theo Love, presents the people in the story as they are, without passing judgment and without apology, whether they are investigators or pastors or just ordinary folks caught up in the inexplicable. It‰Ûªs Americana unvarnished and, because of that, as absorbing as it is respectful.

The film isn‰Ûªt just about the crime. (Both men later pleaded guilty and are now in prison.) It‰Ûªs about coming to grips with what happened, and it avoids a pat ending. Yes, some who lost their churches voice the ideal of Christian forgiveness, but you can feel in this well-conceived film that even for them, the effects of the fires will be felt for years to come.

Ten churches were burned in January and February 2010 before two young men, Jason R. Bourque and Daniel G. McAllister, were arrested. The film relates the tale as a detective story, but one that is also a sociological study ‰ÛÓ of a region that takes its Christianity seriously, and of individual families in a hardscrabble area. Some of its interviews are startling in their plain-spokenness, a rare thing in documentaries these days, when so many people, schooled by exposure to television, are savvy and guarded when on camera.

He still snaps photographs, which he says can be justified to the extent that it helps others. (A traveling display of his work raised money for construction on the monastery.) Reminiscing about Mr. Vreeland‰Ûªs life in Europe and America, friends and family marvel at his decades-long transformation. When John Avedon, Mr. Avedon‰Ûªs son, notes that Mr. Vreeland still polishes his shoes, Mr. Vreeland replies that it‰Ûªs so they will last longer.

While the movie leaves little doubt that Mr. Vreeland‰Ûªs work is heartfelt, it also gives off an air of designer tourism, inviting us to gawp at the disjunction between the subject and his surroundings. (He rides New Jersey Transit in full monastic regalia.) This superficial movie plays like a fashion shoot with robes.
Directed by Guido Santi and Tina Mascara

Becoming a Buddhist monk and ‰ÛÏrenouncing worldly ways‰Ûù apparently don‰Ûªt preclude starring in a documentary about your life. In ‰ÛÏMonk With a Camera: The Life and Journey of Nicholas Vreeland,‰Ûù the conceit is that the subject, known to his friends as Nicky, went from a lifestyle of privilege to one of asceticism and simplicity. Mr. Vreeland, a photographer who worked with Irving Penn and Richard Avedon and a grandson of the legendary fashion editor Diana Vreeland, is now an abbot at a monastery in India.
The Life and Journey of Nicholas Vreeland

We‰Ûªre told that the Dalai Lama considered him instrumental in developing American Buddhism before naming him an abbot. Richard Gere, one of the celebrity pals interviewed, is present for the investiture.
1 hour 30 minutes; not rated
MONK WITH A CAMERA
Opens on Friday

Perhaps the most in need of healing is a cop, Wolfie (Thomas Jane), who keeps a poster for ‰ÛÏThe Wild Bunch‰Ûù in his home and has a habit of engineering situations that allow him to shoot suspects and claim self-defense. He then runs to an irate priest (Danny Aiello) for confession. (‰ÛÏThou shalt not kill,‰Ûù the priest reminds him, loudly.)
‰ÛÏReach Me‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, sexual assault.

‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre either toothless or ruthless,‰Ûù Stallone‰Ûªs character, who paints as a hobby, advises his protÌ©gÌ© (Kevin Connolly). A mobster (Kelsey Grammer) tells an underling that if he doesn‰Ûªt take care of business, ‰ÛÏI will take care of you.‰Ûù Clearly, they‰Ûªve all read the wrong screenwriting manual.

This self-help guide, we‰Ûªre told, has ‰ÛÏgone viral,‰Ûù a process once known simply as becoming a best seller. Among those touched by its lessons are a paroled arsonist (Kyra Sedgwick), a rapper (Nelly) and the henchmen (Omari Hardwick and David O‰ÛªHara) of a golfing gangster (Tom Sizemore).

The movie returns its writer and director, John Herzfeld, to the milieu of his wan Tarantino knockoff, ‰ÛÏ2 Days in the Valley,‰Ûù employing similar contrivances (two story lines converge through a car accident) but adding aphorisms.

Casting Sylvester Stallone as a gossip-site publisher obviously modeled on Matt Drudge is one of many counterintuitive ideas that backfire in ‰ÛÏReach Me.‰Ûù In this preposterous ensemble piece, residents of the greater Los Angeles area become better people through the extended influence of a motivational book.

Mr. Saura chooses the Seville Expo ‰Ûª92 pavilion as his studio for capturing an array of discrete performances by older and younger artists against painterly stage backdrops. Everything seems to occur on some idealized plane: the dancer Sara Baras, above, moving across the floor in a dress, a blazing whipcrack of red; Montse CortÌ©s belting out a soleÌÁ por bulerÌ_as for the ages; the guitar virtuoso Paco de LucÌ_a sauntering in like a returning hero to strum a perfect tune.

This album cover aesthetic can be overkill for the already theatrical rigor of these musical forms. But Mr. Saura again collaborates with one of the best cinematographers ever to have splashed color on screen, Vittorio Storaro (‰ÛÏThe Conformist,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now‰Ûù). More than once the eye wanders to trace a voluptuous fold of clothing or the play of amber light.

Mr. Saura‰Ûªs museum of dance lacks subtitles or lengthy explanations. This keeps the visuals fluid and intact, but even unambiguous flamenco could use some translation of lyrics. And when a final shot takes us outdoors to the real world, it‰Ûªs possible to wonder whether a certain spontaneity, or a different kind of energy, has been missing from Mr. Saura‰Ûªs immaculately vibrant film.

For decades now, Carlos Saura has been cinema‰Ûªs chief archivist of Iberian performing arts, most notably with his ‰ÛÏFlamenco Trilogy‰Ûù in the early 1980s, and more recently with a documentary on Portugal‰Ûªs fado tradition. ‰ÛÏFlamenco, Flamenco,‰Ûù a sequel to his ‰ÛÏFlamenco,‰Ûù from 1995, collects more impassioned song and dance.

The Swiss city was a draw for gays at the time, partly because homosexuality was not illegal there, and Mr. Ostertag, a gay teacher at a girls‰Ûª school, finds both a welcoming community and the cutie-pie drag singer Mr. Rapp at the Circle. The durable thread of their romance is traced through the stresses of co-workers‰Ûª suspicions and the police crackdowns after a series of murders involving gay cruising.

While the actors Matthias HungerbÌ_hler and Sven Schelker are satisfactory as the young Ernst and RÌ_bi, the movie has the measured, dutiful quality of docudrama (and some on-the-nose dialogue). But it‰Ûªs a chapter in history well worth bringing to light.

Stefan Haupt‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Circle‰Ûù takes its name from an underground journal and gay club in Zurich in the mid-20th century. Our entrance to this corner of history comes through the story of Ernst Ostertag and RÌ_bi Rapp, which is told through documentary interviews with this sweet, be-sweatered elderly couple and a conscientious dramatization of their courtship in the 1950s.

The sense of an invisible world being revealed is more potent than the film‰Ûªs fairly standard portrayal of closeted life. Mr. Ostertag and Mr. Rapp‰Ûªs commentary and snippets of interviews with other veterans of the time are deftly inserted between scenes, dabbing in warm, personal detail (and a couple of times even elegantly maintaining shot continuity). It‰Ûªs a responsible and respectful way to tell the couple‰Ûªs story instead of simply appropriating it and leaving the real people in the dust.

There‰Ûªs a clever bit in the latest ‰ÛÏHunger Games‰Ûù in which Katniss Everdeen, the boundary-smashing butch goddess of dystopian cinema, acts in a propaganda video. The idea is for Katniss, who‰Ûªs both the spark of a revolution and its flinty strength, to rouse the masses with a heroic scene. Slicked up in lipstick and a Joan of Arc breastplate, she delivers her lines ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏwith energy,‰Ûù the video director hopefully instructs her ‰ÛÓ but the scene needs tweaks. Eventually, they get it right, and the video ends with a call to ‰ÛÏjoin the fight,‰Ûù an exhortation that‰Ûªs clearly addressed to more than one audience. It‰Ûªs a funny, self-aware moment, given how extreme the stakes have become in this fascinating and strange pop epic.

There are a fair number of those war room scenes, which makes the movie feel far more claustrophobic than its antecedents. To an extent, since the rebel leaders are strategizing from a bunker, the sense of entrapment works for the story, as do the physical limitations presented by District 13, which is underground and organized around a dimly lit, multilevel atrium that looks like a repurposed silo. Yet you grow antsy in District 13, both because it‰Ûªs such a dreary militarized world ‰ÛÓ created for maximum defensiveness, and that‰Ûªs it ‰ÛÓ and because it locks up Katniss, who was made to roam. It‰Ûªs a relief when she steps outside, even to go hunting with her best friend, Gale (Liam Hemsworth), whose moony, lovesick shtick has become a drag.

More than two years later, the off-screen battlegrounds have shifted, but Ms. Davidson‰Ûªs take remains as valid as ever. And ‰ÛÏMockingjay Part 1‰Ûù is indisputably a war movie, from tearful start to unsettling end. Its director is Francis Lawrence, who did the honors in the second one, and he does a serviceable job again of pulling the parts together. If you haven‰Ûªt seen the earlier movies, you may get a little lost; it doesn‰Ûªt matter. If you‰Ûªve watched them and forgotten certain details, it also doesn‰Ûªt matter. ‰ÛÏMockingjay Part 1‰Ûù is streamlined, blunt and easy. The Capitol, the base of Panem power, is after Katniss, who is squirreled away in a part of the country, District 13, once thought to have been destroyed. Led by President Alma Coin (Julianne Moore, equal parts iron and silk), District 13 is now leading the charge against the Capitol.

One of the pleasures of big-ticket blockbusters is that the smart ones (Harry Potter, most obviously) often come stuffed with the best acting talent money can buy. The script for ‰ÛÏMockingjay Part 1,‰Ûù credited to Peter Craig and Danny Strong, gets the job done, but the performers matter far more than the words they deliver. When Ms. Moore sits around a table with Jeffrey Wright (as Beetee, a tech whiz) and Philip Seymour Hoffman (Plutarch, a strategist), you‰Ûªre both watching a scene and seeing how great actors can give emotional and psychological specificity to blather about the art of war and the fate of a people. Hoffman, who looked so uncomfortable in ‰ÛÏCatching Fire,‰Ûù is here loose, funny and stingingly real.

The ‰ÛÏHunger Games‰Ûù books and movies have always invited different readings, including as an allegory for the agonies of adolescence, but on screen, those interpretations have receded as the series has unfolded, and the story‰Ûªs focus has sharpened. When the curtain rises on the third movie (the full, unwieldy title is ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1‰Ûù), the games are over, and the subject of the series ‰ÛÓ war ‰ÛÓ has been revealed. Though, of course, it‰Ûªs been there all along, as Amy Davidson wrote in The New Yorker on the eve of the first movie‰Ûªs release in 2012: ‰ÛÏAmerica has been at war for a decade now; is it really a coincidence that the biggest movie of the year is the first in a trilogy in which torture, terror, asymmetric warfare and the manipulation of public opinion all play a role?‰Ûù

Each ‰ÛÏHunger Games‰Ûù movie makes so much noise ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs where the deafening clamor of commerce meets the roar of true fan love ‰ÛÓ that it‰Ûªs a wonder you can detect the human heartbeat under the tumult. But it‰Ûªs there, thumping and sometimes racing in a franchise that, more than most industrial movies and even putative indies, speaks to both its audience and its time. There‰Ûªs heart in the vague yet stirring liberation story that comes to the fore in this chapter and that‰Ûªs echoed in real-life struggles around the world. And it‰Ûªs there, of course, in Katniss, the backwoods savior who, as played with guileless appeal by Jennifer Lawrence, is mounting an attack on the forces of oppression.
‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). War violence and torture.

These forces include anyone who has ever doubted the appeal of female-driven stories, which, considering that 85 percent of the top-grossing movies from 2013 have male leads, means most of the people making films. But there‰Ûªs more here than gender equality. Last year, the second installment, ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games: Catching Fire,‰Ûù topped the year‰Ûªs box office. It‰Ûªs easy to see why. ‰ÛÏMockingjay Part 1‰Ûù returns to the series backdrop: a totalitarian country ‰ÛÓ Panem, a stand-in for any number of nations ‰ÛÓ that rose from the ashes of a postapocalyptic North America. Katniss has surmounted her station as a slave by emerging victorious from the annual gladiatorial games that pit (usually child) combatants against one another. Her very survival has made her an existential threat to Panem.

The war scenes are more of a relief ‰ÛÓ stuff blows up, etc. ‰ÛÓ which is complicated. FranÌ_ois Truffaut is said to have observed that there‰Ûªs no such thing as an antiwar movie because all war movies make combat look fun, which isn‰Ûªt true, even if many turn death into easy-to-consume spectacles. ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù has never been antiwar, and while some object to a fiction in which adults send children to slaughter one another, what‰Ûªs truly appalling is that this isn‰Ûªt a grotesque fantasy but a bitter truth of human civilization. The scene in the first movie of combatants racing into the start of the games to kill and die is shocking only because it acknowledges that truth.

That shock lingered, but the ugliness of those deaths was mitigated by Katniss, whose very individuality, her grit, roughness and decency, serve as a rebuke to the Capitol. In her struggle to keep herself alive along with her other love interest, the insufferably dull Peeta (Josh Hutcherson, still miscast!), Katniss personalizes ‰ÛÓ humanizes ‰ÛÓ the fight. That humanity is crucial to her evolution as a classic charismatic revolutionary hero. She‰Ûªs the one who embodies, articulates and justifies the battle and breaks collective chains, even as she‰Ûªs being folded into District 13‰Ûªs militaristic operation. Plutarch and the rest of the rebel leaders understand that, but when they make that first propaganda video, they get it wrong because, by writing the script for her, they also silence her.

‰ÛÏMockingjay Part 1‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt silence Katniss, but in some respects, it sidelines her. She still has plenty to say and do, though not enough, partly because, in chopping the last book into two movies (‰ÛÏPart 2‰Ûù lands next year) and by embracing the blockbuster imperative ‰ÛÓ big bangs and action ‰ÛÓ the filmmakers lose sight of her. That‰Ûªs most evident with a rescue that Katniss doesn‰Ûªt physically participate in. The rescue happens midway through the final book, but it‰Ûªs been turned into the movie‰Ûªs culminating set piece, one that Katniss ‰ÛÓ like you ‰ÛÓ witnesses unfold on screen. It‰Ûªs perfectly watchable in a generic, action-flick way. Yet as Katniss Everdeen stands gaping at the rescue, with widening and watering eyes, it‰Ûªs hard not to feel that for the first time in this series, the filmmakers are treating her just like, well, the girl.
Still, a catalog of the movie‰Ûªs pleasures barely does justice to this lost-and-found delight.

Adapting a Hans Christian Andersen story, Mr. Grimault wrote the screenplay with Jacques PrÌ©vert (‰ÛÏChildren of Paradise‰Ûù). The film takes place in Tachycardia, where King Charles XVI ‰ÛÓ the numbers are tallied aloud whenever his name is spoken ‰ÛÓ is an avid if inept hunter. That hunting makes him a nemesis of the hero, a showman of a mockingbird.

The French animated film ‰ÛÏThe King and the Mockingbird‰Ûù has been more influential than known or seeable, at least in the United States. The movie is belatedly opening here in a subtitled restoration, with special dubbed showings for children.

With its muted rose and yellows, the angular animation is classical but inventive, even surreal. Tachycardia collapses periods, combining an ostensibly medieval setting with a futurist streak. When the king rides a rocket-shaped elevator to his secret apartment on the 296th floor, you could easily see it as a gag on ‰ÛÏThe Jetsons.‰Ûù A giant automaton with spotlight eyes seems the source of the key design in ‰ÛÏThe Iron Giant.‰Ûù

Released in France in the 1950s in a version that the animator Paul Grimault called ‰ÛÏan impostor‰Ûù and completed, after an overhaul, in 1979, ‰ÛÏThe King and the Mockingbird‰Ûù is commonly cited as an influence on Studio Ghibli, from Japan. Yet in its humor, its fairy tale origins and the characters‰Ûª rounded features, it plays more like a vintage Disney work, only nimbler and freer.

Mr. Abbott ‰ÛÓ in a role far from the boyfriend he played opposite Allison Williams in ‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ nicely underplays, as do all of the actors, even the spry, appealing Ms. Ellis, an Australian actress who has the showiest part here. The movie digs into issues of class, domestic abuse, sibling rivalry and mental illness, but refrains from any easy answers. With strong assists from the cinematographer Zachary Galler and her ex-husband, the composer Sondre Lerche, Ms. Fastvold, previously a director of music videos, has painted a resonant tableau of dysfunction.

The Norwegian director Mona Fastvold, who makes her feature debut with the thriller ‰ÛÏThe Sleepwalker,‰Ûù knows her way around mood. This spare study of two couples ‰ÛÓ Andrew (Christopher Abbott) and Kaia (Gitte Witt), who has inherited an estate they are renovating; and Kaia‰Ûªs sister, Christine (Stephanie Ellis), and her wealthy boyfriend, Ira (Brady Corbet) ‰ÛÓ is set in Massachusetts but has a Scandinavian sense of reserve.

Andrew is a brooding construction worker, while Ira works with the United Nations. Kaia is in quiet denial about her past, while Christine is ‰ÛÓ a handful. She‰Ûªs pregnant with Ira‰Ûªs baby. She inconveniently drops in to stay with her sister with no notice. She‰Ûªs a somnambulist and once set a house on fire.

Ms. Schwartz‰Ûªs parents, Peggy and Robert Schwartz, who divorced, both say that to varying degrees they had convinced themselves of the Sicilian-ancestry story, even though Lacey Schwartz‰Ûªs biological father, Rodney Parker, was an acquaintance of family and friends. Some are shown attending Mr. Parker‰Ûªs funeral, where Ms. Schwartz was announced as one of his children. But even that incident doesn‰Ûªt open the floodgates of conversation.

Even so, the film shows some sympathy toward Peggy, who acknowledges that her relationship with Mr. Parker predated her marriage to Robert. Few moments in recent nonfiction cinema are as piercing as the one in which Ms. Schwartz asks her mother if she might have settled down with Mr. Parker had he not been black.

‰ÛÏLittle White Lie‰Ûù is, in part, the story of Ms. Schwartz‰Ûªs evolving view of her background. As a child, she thought of herself as white and even wished for a lighter complexion. College changed that: Although she didn‰Ûªt declare a race on her application, she says Georgetown considered her a black student based on a photograph. She was welcomed by the Black Student Alliance and began to experience the influence that race has on everyday life.

The documentary ‰ÛÏLittle White Lie‰Ûù would be provocative simply for what it says about race and identity. The director Lacey Schwartz grew up Jewish in Woodstock, N.Y., yet something seemed off. Her peers would ask if she was adopted. At Ms. Schwartz‰Ûªs bat mitzvah, a member of her synagogue assumed she was an Ethiopian Jew. Her family attributed her darker skin to a Sicilian great-grandfather. Only gradually did Ms. Schwartz, now 37, begin to suspect what might seem obvious to an outsider: that her biological father was black.

That shift in perspective might be startling enough, but the movie goes one step further by charting the effect that Ms. Schwartz‰Ûªs transformation has on her family members and the awkward sense in which her embrace of a biracial identity might be seen as a repudiation of them. The film is a searing portrait of collective denial ‰ÛÓ a diagnosis from which Ms. Schwartz doesn‰Ûªt exempt herself.

‰ÛÏLittle White Lie‰Ûù examines how the secret rippled through the years. Graced with old photographs and footage, Ms. Schwartz, who narrates, films key confrontations with her parents. Anyone expecting a warm reception from the pained-looking Robert, whom she still calls her father, is at the wrong movie.

Last time around, Mr. Spacey‰Ûªs character carried the cruelty of Buddy Ackerman, his movie producer in ‰ÛÏSwimming With Sharks,‰Ûù to demonic extremes. He has just a walk-on role this time. Jamie Foxx also reappears briefly as the ex-con the friends consulted in the first movie. These cameos amount to little more than items on a checklist.

Most of the humor in ‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses‰Ûù revolved around extreme caricatures embodied by Jennifer Aniston and Kevin Spacey. Ms. Aniston‰Ûªs Dr. Julia Harris, a sexually insatiable dentist who molested her male patients while they were under anesthesia and verbally and physically harassed her soon-to-be-married assistant (Mr. Day), has returned with her potty mouth intact. As cheerfully raunchy as ever, she now runs a 12-step program for sex addicts that she uses to recruit partners. Ms. Aniston still brings a twinkling levity to a role that in less capable hands would be a hateful gorgon. But the novelty of a beautiful woman aggressively harassing a male underling has faded.

To refresh your memory, the original ‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses‰Ûù starred Jason Bateman, Jason Sudeikis and Charlie Day as bumbling idiots who decide that the only way to rid themselves of their monstrous supervisors is to kill them. The three friends had only marginal comic chemistry in the first film and have even less in the sequel.

What ‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses 2‰Ûù lacks in nasty repartee, it tries to make up for in poorly staged comedy chases and break-ins. It is the Hollywood equivalent of a rambunctious little boy pointing to the toilet and squealing, ‰ÛÏMommy, look what I made!‰Ûù

‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses 2,‰Ûù one of the sloppiest and most unnecessary Hollywood sequels ever made, isn‰Ûªt dirtier or more offensive than its 2011 forerunner. But it is infinitely dumber and not half as funny.

Top dog among the new baddies is Bert Hanson (Christoph Waltz, miscast), a sadistic retail mogul who agrees to bankroll the triumvirate‰Ûªs new invention, a bathroom accessory called the shower buddy, only to betray them. Bert has a spoiled, sociopathic son from hell (Chris Pine), whom the inventors kidnap and hold for ransom.

This disgracefully slapdash farce, directed by Sean Anders from a screenplay he wrote with John Morris, brings back many of the same stars from the first film in token appearances to try to maintain an illusion of continuity. But the story doesn‰Ûªt even try to make sense. You often have the queasy feeling that the screenplay was improvised on the spot.
‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses 2‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for crude sexual content and language.

‰ÛÏPenguins of Madagascar‰Ûù promises a reasonable share of wit the minute it opens with a voice-over by Werner Herzog, in a sendup of his documentary on Antarctica, ‰ÛÏEncounters at the End of the World.‰Ûù That film posed the question of whether penguins could exhibit insanity. In the case of this spirited animated movie, the answer is assuredly yes.

Although ‰ÛÏPenguins of Madagascar‰Ûù might look like a down-market spinoff ‰ÛÓ the original vocal stars, including Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, Jada Pinkett Smith and Sacha Baron Cohen, don‰Ûªt participate ‰ÛÓ the decision to focus on the series‰Ûªs comic relief has resulted in the loosest and perhaps funniest film of the brand.
‰ÛÏPenguins of Madagascar‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Penguin insanity.

Dave (a sporting John Malkovich), who sometimes barks orders in the form of actors‰Ûª names (‰ÛÏNicolas, cage them‰Ûù; ‰ÛÏRobin, write this down‰Ûù), plans to kidnap penguins from zoos and aquariums and transform them, ridding them of their cuteness. There will be no more cheering crowds and, as the movie acknowledges in a separate gag, no more documentaries.

In their quest to thwart Dave‰Ûªs plot, the penguins have competition: a squad of Arctic animals commanded by a wolf known only as Classified. That Classified‰Ûªs voice belongs to the ubiquitous Benedict Cumberbatch is almost as amusing as any of the jokes.

After a narrative setup that provides the wisp of a tether to the earlier movies, the four penguin main characters infiltrate Fort Knox ‰ÛÓ to visit a vending machine filled with discontinued cheese-puff snacks. They are soon whisked away by the genetic researcher Dr. Octavius Brine, actually a disguised, disgruntled octopus named Dave, with whom the penguins resided during a stint at the Central Park Zoo.

Visually, the movie, which can be watched in pointless 3-D, has little to set it apart, although a few of the mutant-penguin designs are worthy of the ‰ÛÏGremlins‰Ûù director, Joe Dante. Still, the lack of originality is offset by sheer silliness, including Classified and Skipper‰Ûªs Abbott and Costello-style argument over whether there‰Ûªs a long I in ‰ÛÏdiversion.‰Ûù The word fits the movie.

The heroes are a feathered task force of secret-agent-like penguins, led with military discipline by Skipper (the voice of Tom McGrath). Literalists who complain that penguins do not live in Madagascar should note that the title refers to the ‰ÛÏMadagascar‰Ûù movie franchise.

The end of the earth lends itself to some strange sights, which Mr. Powell shows off: meringue-like whirls of ice, glittering stars, green apparitions in the sky and, perhaps most of all, a pall of round-the-clock dark for part of the year. The scientists, computer professionals, convenience store managers and others who choose to stick it out there seem to do so out of sheer awe before the sublime. For them, it‰Ûªs too special a place to leave.

It‰Ûªs also a hard place to leave for much of the year: Flights out stop for months at a time. Mr. Powell (who met his wife there) lightheartedly portrays the residents as part of a kind of permanent summer camp, a brotherhood and sisterhood of nerds and oddballs who must get along. But for many viewers, the true promise of this frigid little utopia might be as a rare refuge from hustle and bustle in a world that expects constant connectivity.
‰ÛÏAntarctica: A Year on Ice‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for mild thematic elements and language.

The extremes of ‰ÛÏAntarctica: A Year on Ice‰Ûù might seem routine to fans of nature documentaries, but the photographer and director Anthony Powell produces some dazzling imagery in his droll study of isolation way, way down under. His varied tour of Antarctica‰Ûªs scientific stations and their long-term residents is like a jokey, expertly shot slide show from another world.
Throughout the movie, you have the feeling of being dragged along on an impromptu journey by a filmmaker who is traveling without the benefit of a GPS device.

As the initially contemptuous Sophia warms to her babysitter, ‰ÛÏBefore I Disappear‰Ûù tries to pluck your heartstrings. But as an actor, Mr. Christensen, who wrote and directed the film, doesn‰Ûªt have the requisite likability factor. Nor does Ms. Ptacek, who is too old for the role, which she also had in the short version.

Richie, who has slashed his wrists, steps out of the red bathtub water where he is waiting to die, slaps on a bandage and goes to meet his officious, intellectually precocious niece, Sophia (Fatima Ptacek). Accompanying her to school, he visits a class where this humorless, bossy little girl recites an Emily Dickinson poem in English and in Mandarin.

In this grungy atmospheric elaboration, set in Manhattan‰Ûªs seedier environs, Richie (Mr. Christensen), a self-loathing loser who ekes out a living scrubbing toilets in a bowling alley, is about to kill himself when he receives a call from his bitter, estranged sister, Maggie (Emmy Rossum). She entreats him to look after her young daughter while she concludes some urgent, mysterious personal business. (We learn later that she has been arrested.)

With no word from his sister, Richie drags Sophia on a surreal all-night tour of downscale locales that evokes a David Mamet play set in 1980s New York or Martin Scorsese‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAfter Hours.‰Ûù The movie‰Ûªs liveliest moment is a fantasy sequence in the bowling alley in which Sophia leads a synchronized dance. But most of the additions to a short film that required no fleshing out contribute only half-baked plot complications involving assorted lowlifes.
All mood and no substance, ‰ÛÏBefore I Disappear‰Ûù is Shawn Christensen‰Ûªs feature-length expansion of his Academy Award-winning 19-minute film, ‰ÛÏCurfew,‰Ûù from 2012.

I was an easily frightened child, and nothing scared me more than certain picture books. Something about the static images, the simple words and the unseen menaces hidden between pages made books much more sinister than, say, movies, and quite a few volumes that now seem perfectly innocuous were banished from my bedroom shelves. I had forgotten about this youthful phobia until I saw ‰ÛÏThe Babadook,‰Ûù the debut feature by the Australian director Jennifer Kent. Or rather, until I came home from the screening, went to bed and woke up in the throes of the kind of nightmare that was the reason I had shunned those books in the first place.

That bond is also freighted with tenderness, longing, resentment and all kinds of other emotional baggage. Somehow, Ms. Kent has folded all of this into a highly effective little ghost story, one that is as simple and austere as the Babadook book itself. The off-kilter camera angles, echoing sound effects and lurid cinematography (by Radek Ladczuk) certainly help, and so do the two lead actors. Noah Wiseman has a demonic sweetness that recalls some of the evil children of ‰Ûª70s scare-cinema. And Ms. Davis‰Ûªs performance is a tour de force of maternal anguish. At times, she seems as fragile and addled as Mia Farrow in ‰ÛÏRosemary‰Ûªs Baby,‰Ûù as Ms. Kent pulls Polanskian strings of helplessness and paranoia. But then all of a sudden, the mood shifts and you wonder if you should be afraid for Amelia or afraid of her.

Or so it seems. The brilliance of ‰ÛÏThe Babadook,‰Ûù beyond Ms. Kent‰Ûªs skillful deployment of the tried-and-true visual and aural techniques of movie horror, lies in its interlocking ambiguities. For a long time, you‰Ûªre not sure if the Babadook is a supernatural or a psychological phenomenon. Once you‰Ûªve started to figure that out ‰ÛÓ or to decide that you‰Ûªre too freaked out for it to matter ‰ÛÓ another, more disturbing question starts to arise. Maybe the monster is all in someone‰Ûªs head, but if so, whose? Sam‰Ûªs? Amelia‰Ûªs? Yours?

As ‰ÛÏThe Babadook‰Ûù proceeds, ratcheting up both the suspense and the odd, surreal comedy that accompanies but does not diminish it, every boundary in Amelia and Sam‰Ûªs world seems to collapse. When a demon runs wild, uncontained by the walls of houses or the pages of a book, its origin hardly matters. But Ms. Kent has enough of a Freudian streak to know that the familiar is scarier than the alien, and that nothing is more fraught with dreadful possibility than the bond between parent and child.
In any case, you will be scared. And also, perhaps even more scarily, moved.

The Babadook is a black-hatted, long-taloned, snaggletoothed figure ‰ÛÓ a sort of monochrome, pen-and-ink Freddy Krueger ‰ÛÓ who lives between the bright red covers of a story that shows up in the house of Amelia (Essie Davis) and her 6-year-old son, Sam (Noah Wiseman). Their household is a creepy place, even before the visitor arrives. Amelia, who works in a nursing home, is a sad, frazzled woman, still reeling from the death of her husband some years earlier and increasingly distraught by Sam‰Ûªs erratic behavior. Looking a little like a kindergartner dressed up for Halloween as AC/DC‰Ûªs Angus Young, Sam swerves from cowering terror to uncontrollable rage. He causes trouble in school, attacks his cousin and turns his mother‰Ûªs days and nights into a gantlet of anxiety, embarrassment and worry.

Ms. Kent twists the possible answers around, scrambling your sense of standard horror-movie rhythm. Nighttime brings the usual terrors ‰ÛÓ noises just out of frame, shadowy corridors, flickering lights ‰ÛÓ but daylight offers no particular comfort. When Amelia and Sam leave home, bad things happen, and their fear is compounded by humiliation. When they return, traumatized and tired, their unwelcome guest is lying in wait. The world outside is a cold, grotesque place, especially when Amelia has to endure the pitying, judgmental company of her sister and other moms. Home is haunted by the memory and the apparent threat of death.

The film ignores the health care debate while providing fuel for all possible arguments in it, from ‰ÛÏSee how many people need medical care?‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏThese people can‰Ûªt possibly afford mandatory premiums.‰Ûù

If you were unaware that there are people in the United States who don‰Ûªt receive proper health care, ‰ÛÏRemote Area Medical,‰Ûù a documentary about the nonprofit organization of that name, certainly shows you what they look like, in blunt, tooth-decaying detail. But beyond that, it maddeningly refuses to take a stand or explore the questions it raises.

The organization stages mobile clinics that provide free care to people in out-of-the-way parts of the United States and other countries. The film is a simple chronicle of a three-day clinic in Bristol, Tenn., which drew hundreds of people, some of whom lined up a day or more in advance. We see lots of teeth being pulled, some from patients who look as if they had never seen a dentist. We hear people talking about how chronic health problems have reduced their quality of life.

But we hear only a fleeting reference to the Affordable Care Act, and broader issues that ought to be examined are not. Are there not enough doctors and dentists in Appalachia, and if so, what can be done about that? Can one visit to a pop-up clinic really undo years of neglect? What responsibility do people have to ensure their own health? (Smoking and obesity are much in evidence among the crowd at the clinic.)

Despite low production values, ‰ÛÏThe Historian,‰Ûù unrelated to the Elizabeth Kostova novel, sustains curiosity over what, for a debut, is a long running time. Yet the film ultimately lands uneasily on the line between inside and insular, recalling an old saw about universities: The fights are so fierce because the stakes are so small.

In ‰ÛÏThe Historian,‰Ûù life at a university classics department barely stops short of brawling. The movie conveys this hostile atmosphere almost immediately, when the domineering department leader, Dr. Valerian Hadley (William Sadler), corrects a student. ‰ÛÏThe Romans didn‰Ûªt invent crucifixion,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏThey perfected it.‰Ûù He uses the student for a pantomime demonstration.

With economic pressure to keep students from dropping their classes, he and Val seem locked in a barely acknowledged competition to make antiquity sound more sensational. They also both have eyes on Anna (Jillian Taylor), a ceaselessly chipper doctoral student who falls into Ben‰Ûªs bed at screenplay speed. But Val, as her adviser, can hold her hostage indefinitely. The movie furthers the notion of academia as a quasi-incestuous realm when Ben starts a fling with a professor of polymer science (Leticia Jimenez).

The film is the feature writing and directing debut of Miles Doleac, who teaches Latin at the University of Southern Mississippi. This fictional movie plays as both exposÌ© and expurgation ‰ÛÓ a way for its maker to vent frustrations with the academic system. Our point of entry is a visiting professor, Dr. Ben Rhodes, played by Mr. Doleac himself.

Just a few years ago, this film might have felt radical and counterintuitive, like a daring, inspired leap from one era to another, or an excavation of the hidden history of the present. Instead, it has the shiny, hollow ring of conventional wisdom. It‰Ûªs kind of perfect, and also kind of stale.

More fundamentally, ‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game‰Ûù is a parable of disruption. It not only provides an origin myth for the digital age, but it also projects the ideology of the present back into the past. Turing, an eccentric visionary stuck in an organization that is bureaucratic, hierarchical and wedded to tradition, is an apostle of innovation. Commander Denniston lectures him about the importance of ‰ÛÏorder, discipline and chain of command‰Ûù for the war effort, but the solving of Enigma decisively rebuts this old-fashioned notion. The strategic acumen of generals and the tactical valor of soldiers is incidental. What won the war was data, and the heroes were the tech guys (and the one woman) who worked late, snacked freely, fiddled with crossword puzzles and geeked out over a piece of hardware that looked like a giant toy. Hut 8 at Bletchley Park serves as a prototype for the corporate campuses of Apple, Google and Facebook.

‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game‰Ûù derives some easy amusement from the friction between this ‰ÛÏodd duck‰Ûù and the prevailing culture of his native pond. The film‰Ûªs notion of Britain ‰ÛÓ not inaccurate, but also not hugely insightful ‰ÛÓ is as a land of understatement, indirection and steadfast obedience to norms of behavior that seem, to a fiercely logical mind like Turing‰Ûªs, arbitrary and incomprehensible. At Bletchley Park, the country estate where teams of linguists and mathematicians are working under military supervision to break Enigma, he is seen as stubborn and arrogant. The head of Bletchley, Commander Denniston (Charles Dance), finds him insufferable, as does Hugh Alexander (Matthew Goode), the suave, clever playboy who runs the Enigma project until Turing, with an off-screen assist from Winston Churchill, displaces him.

The Bletchley section, enlivened by the indispensably charming Keira Knightley as Joan Clarke, the only woman on the Enigma team, is the heart of the film, though it is also the most familiar and in some ways the least challenging part. (Earlier dramatizations include Hugh Whitemore‰Ûªs play ‰ÛÏBreaking the Code‰Ûù and Michael Apted‰Ûªs silly, Turing-free 2002 movie ‰ÛÏEnigma.‰Ûù) Mr. Tyldum, a Norwegian filmmaker perhaps best known for the slick thriller ‰ÛÏHeadhunters‰Ûù (2012), orchestrates a swift and suspenseful race against the clock with a few touches of intrigue and ethical uncertainty. Mark Strong pops out of the shadows now and then as a silky, cynical MI6 spymaster, perhaps the only person in the British political establishment who fully appreciates Turing‰Ûªs oddity and his genius.
‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Illicit sex, cataclysmic violence and advanced math, most of it mentioned rather than shown.

All of this is a lot for a single movie to take in, and ‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game,‰Ûù directed by Morten Tyldum from a script by Graham Moore, prunes and compresses a narrative laid out most comprehensively in Andrew Hodges‰Ûªs scrupulous and enthralling 1983 biography. The film interweaves three decisive periods in Turing‰Ûªs life, using his interrogation by a Manchester detective (Rory Kinnear) as a framing device. Turing tells the investigator ‰ÛÓ who thinks he is after a Soviet spy rather than a gay man ‰ÛÓ about what he did during the war. Later, there are flashbacks to Turing‰Ûªs school days, where he discovered the joys of cryptography and fell in love with a slightly older boy named Christopher Morcom.

‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game,‰Ûù meanwhile, settles for a partial appreciation. Turing‰Ûªs sexuality is mystified and marginalized, treated as an abstraction and a plot point. There is no sense that, between his chaste, intense and brief passion for Christopher and the anonymous encounter that led indirectly to his arrest, love, sex or romance played any significant part in Turing‰Ûªs life at all. Mr. Hodges‰Ûªs biography, threaded with quotations from Walt Whitman, gives eloquent and sensitive testimony to the contrary. For their part, the filmmakers, though willing to treat Turing as a victim of bigotry and repression, also nudge him back toward the closet, imposing a discretion that is at once self-protective and self-congratulatory. It‰Ûªs not that we need to see him having sex ‰ÛÓ the PG-13 rating must be protected, I guess ‰ÛÓ but that a vital aspect of his identity and experience deserves more than a whisper and a wink.

An Alan Turing biopic is, all in all, a very welcome thing. Chances are that you are reading this, as I am writing it, on a device that came into being partly as a result of papers Turing published in the 1930s exploring the possibility of what he called a ‰ÛÏuniversal machine.‰Ûù His decisive contribution to the breaking of the Nazi Enigma code gave the Allied forces an intelligence advantage that helped defeat Germany, though the extent of his wartime role was kept secret for many years. The secret of his homosexuality was revealed when he was arrested on indecency charges in 1952, caught up in a Cold War climate of homophobia and political paranoia and subjected to the pseudoscientific cruelty of the British judicial system.

The adult Turing is played by Benedict Cumberbatch (his younger self is Alex Lawther), expanding his repertoire of socially awkward intellectual prodigies, real and fictional. What has made Mr. Cumberbatch so effective as Sherlock Holmes and Julian Assange ‰ÛÓ and what makes his Alan Turing one of the year‰Ûªs finest pieces of screen acting ‰ÛÓ is his curious ability to suggest cold detachment and acute sensitivity at the same time. If he did not exist, 21st-century popular culture would have to invent him: a sentient robot, an empathetic space alien, a warm-blooded salamander with crazy sex appeal.

His Turing, whom the film seems to place somewhere on the autism spectrum, is as socially awkward as he is intellectually agile. He can perceive patterns invisible to others but also finds himself stranded in the desert of the literal. Jokes fly over his head, sarcasm does not register, and when one of his colleagues says, ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre going to get some lunch,‰Ûù Turing hears a trivial statement of fact rather than a friendly invitation.

The film‰Ûªs sexual politics may be musty and retrograde, but in other respects, it is very much a document of the present. There are lines of dialogue that sound either anachronistic or ‰ÛÓ it may amount to the same thing ‰ÛÓ prophetic. It is thrilling and strange to hear the words ‰ÛÏdigital computer‰Ûù uttered a half-century before any such thing existed, and when Turing says ‰ÛÏthink differently,‰Ûù it is impossible not to hear a grammatically fastidious premonition of the once-ubiquitous Apple advertising slogan. Another sentence ‰ÛÓ a slightly clumsy invocation of the power of imagination ‰ÛÓ is repeated three times and sounds each time as if it had been plagiarized from a TED talk.

‰ÛÏThe Imitation Game‰Ûù is a highly conventional movie about a profoundly unusual man. This is not entirely a bad thing. Alan Turing‰Ûªs tragically shortened life ‰ÛÓ he was 41 when he died in 1954 ‰ÛÓ is a complex and fascinating story, bristling with ideas and present-day implications, and it benefits from the streamlined structure and accessible presentation of modern prestige cinema. The science is not too difficult, the emotions are clear and emphatic, and the truth of history is respected just enough to make room for tidy and engrossing drama.

David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Immortalists‰Ûù at first looks to be a horse race portrayal of two men competing to achieve eternal life through scientific means. Aubrey de Grey ‰ÛÓ his name seems lifted from a Poe story ‰ÛÓ is an amply bearded British scientist with a multipronged strategy for combating the deleterious effects of aging. His counterpart here is Bill Andrews, an American who likes to run ultramarathons and has his own petri dish proposal for cheating cell death.

That much is (relatively) clear, but this sly documentary rises above its speculative hook by shifting to show the very human, and very mortal, sides of these would-be warriors of eternity. Mr. de Grey scorns the waste of a civilization resigned to the idea of dying, but his composure breaks when he realizes that his mother‰Ûªs death leaves him no remaining family. Mr. Andrews finds that his can-do attitude doesn‰Ûªt always suffice in the business world, and he is blindsided by a friend‰Ûªs cancer.

Rather than glibly proclaim these events to be punishments for hubris, the filmmakers illustrate the shortcomings of blind idealism and the notion that emotional complications are intrinsic to being human. Love, and stuff, still must be reckoned with in a world of eternal life: A pledge of everlasting devotion by Mr. Andrews‰Ûªs partner acquires new dimensions here, while hoarding by Mr. de Grey‰Ûªs mother tacitly raises the question of what an unshrinking population does with all its possessions.
Even immortality has its limits, and so does this dawdling film. But it shows some potential dangers of forever.

What ‰ÛÏTouch the Wall‰Ûù lacks is an inventive or compelling presentation. Heavy with platitudes about goals and attitude, it could easily be a short special on ESPN. It may be that these two swimmers just make their grueling training regimens look easy (painful-looking ice baths excepted). But this glossy movie never really makes us feel the strain.

The film captures the sisterly bond that grows between them, but its strongest aspect is in showing the magnified impact that minute differences can have on swimmers‰Ûª lives. Kara fails to qualify for a $30,000 stipend by 0.03 of a second. Missy‰Ûªs father says he resisted joining his daughter at a world championship in Shanghai, reflecting on the financial cost of being present ‰ÛÓ just for two minutes of swimming. Late in the film, Kara, watching the trials from a hotel room, emphasizes that the most deserving swimmers don‰Ûªt always finish first.

There is a bit of ‰ÛÏA Star Is Born‰Ûù in ‰ÛÏTouch the Wall,‰Ûù a documentary that traces the diverging fortunes of two Olympic-level swimmers. We watch Kara Lynn Joyce, a four-time silver medalist, as she joins a team in Colorado, where she trains alongside Missy Franklin, then in high school. Together, they prepare to try out for the 2012 United States Olympic team.

Kara, 25 during the earliest scenes, appears to have reached the point in a swimmer‰Ûªs career when performance starts to decline. Missy, who went on to win four gold medals in London, is on the verge of the sport‰Ûªs equivalent of superstardom.

One of the group‰Ûªs elaborate schemes involves a seemingly blind driver; anyone with a few extra bucks can get a license in this corrupt system. Their mission and prankster efforts are noble, but the motivations aren‰Ûªt initially clear. Though who could blame them for wanting to expose pension officials who hound poor retirees for kickbacks, gangsters who bully business owners and traffic officers who threaten to ticket drivers who don‰Ûªt pay bribes?

The story is further delayed when another vigilante in the making, Nikhil (Emraan Hashmi), tries to join the group. He finds their work admirable, yet his true allegiance is murky: A reluctant police officer, he‰Ûªs been enlisted to go undercover and infiltrate the group.

In ‰ÛÏUngli,‰Ûù written and directed by Rensil D‰ÛªSilva, four young professionals ‰ÛÓ led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda ‰ÛÓ set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai. They are giving the finger to unscrupulous police officers and officials (‰ÛÏungli‰Ûù is the Hindi word for finger), and finding ingenious ways to expose those misdeeds publicly.

While Mr. D‰ÛªSilva‰Ûªs basic structure and pacing are fairly fluid, his movie suffers from Bollywood‰Ûªs typical kitchen-sink approach to filmmaking. There is tension-filled action (successfully executed); attempts at comedy (more groans than chuckles); and a dash of romance (halfhearted puppy love). Much of that feels like filler, especially when it is revealed why the friends vowed to enact these reprisals: The perpetrator of the near-fatal beating of their CrossFit instructor used his money and connections to avoid a conviction. It‰Ûªs a reminder that exposing corruption is one step; ridding the system of it is another.
‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, swearing, drug use, blisters.

The structure of ‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù is as complicated as its themes. The ‰ÛÏaction‰Ûù on the trail ‰ÛÓ walking, thinking, pitching the tent at night and packing it up in the morning ‰ÛÓ is punctuated by looping reminiscences of the life that preceded it. What is most audacious about the film, directed by Jean-Marc VallÌ©e (‰ÛÏDallas Buyers Club‰Ûù) from a screenplay by Nick Hornby (yes, that Nick Hornby), is how closely it follows and how fully it respects Ms. Strayed‰Ûªs free-associative, memory-driven narrative. In its thrilling disregard for the conventions of commercial cinematic storytelling, ‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù reveals what some of us have long suspected: that plot is the enemy of truth, and that images and emotions can carry meaning more effectively than neatly packaged scenes or carefully scripted character arcs.

‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù is the story of a very long walk, a trek of over 1,000 miles along the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail, from the Southern California desert to the lush forests of Oregon. Based on Cheryl Strayed‰Ûªs best-selling memoir, the film begins, like the book, in the middle of the journey, with a scene that at once celebrates the sublimity of nature and the spirit of solitude and douses such romanticism in a demystifying spray of cold water.

Ms. Strayed‰Ûªs book, written in a frank, funny voice that only occasionally drifts into clouds of self-help abstraction, is a complicated blend of grief memoir and travelogue. It tries very hard not to stick to the well-marked autobiographical path, blazed by St. Augustine in his ‰ÛÏConfessions,‰Ûù from sin to salvation, even as it passes through some classically Augustinian moral territory. Before setting out on her trek, the author had been using heroin and cheating on her husband.
