She insists, however, that her goal is not redemption but self-acceptance, not a catalog of regrets but a clear view and welcoming embrace of experience in all its forms.

The paradox of all these accounts of lonely wandering is that they actively solicit the companionship of readers and viewers. Cheryl Strayed needed to be alone in the vast American outdoors, but she also needed to tell us about it. The film adaptation of her book ‰ÛÓ itself already a classic of wilderness writing and modern feminism ‰ÛÓ provides another reason to be grateful that she did.

Cheryl, played by Reese Witherspoon with grit, wit and unblinking honesty, reaches the top of a rocky outcropping with a panoramic view of surrounding mountains. Her panting, sweaty, irritated presence contrasts with the tranquil glory of the landscape, her contemplation of which is interrupted by the loss of a toenail and then of a hiking boot. That mishap elicits a keening howl of frustration and a perfectly self-defeating gesture of protest as she hurls the other boot away.

In due course, we will come to know a lot more about Cheryl ‰ÛÓ about her childhood and her sex life, about the death of her mother and the end of her marriage ‰ÛÓ but we start out with the crucial information that this is not a woman who makes things easy, for herself or anyone else. The story ‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù has to tell is partly about how Cheryl deals with hardship, and about how, following a piece of long-ago maternal advice, she learns to put herself ‰ÛÏin the way of beauty.‰Ûù But it is also about her appetite for difficulty and her insistence on confronting ugliness, inside and out.

Mr. VallÌ©e‰Ûªs approach places enormous pressure on Ms. Witherspoon, who appears in nearly every frame of ‰ÛÏWild.‰Ûù The overstuffed backpack she hoists onto her shoulders is a metaphor not only for the baggage the character is carrying but also for the scale of the actress‰Ûªs undertaking. It is clear from the beginning that her task is not to make us like Cheryl, but to help us understand her. And since Cheryl doesn‰Ûªt understand herself ‰ÛÓ she can‰Ûªt really say why she‰Ûªs on the Pacific Crest Trail in the first place ‰ÛÓ a certain amount of patience will be required. We are not going to be charmed, teased, flattered or befriended. We will start walking and see what happens.

And it is Cheryl‰Ûªs specific and ordinary suffering that connects us to her and allows us to share her adventure. ‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù the book is part of a literary tradition that stretches back to Thoreau and Wordsworth, and the movie is part of a more recent trend that includes ‰ÛÏInto the Wild,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ127 Hours‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTracks.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù has its shortcomings. There is too much montage in the middle and too much voice-over at the end, and maybe not quite enough detail about some of Cheryl‰Ûªs relationships (which is to say not enough Gaby Hoffmann, who plays her best friend). But you wouldn‰Ûªt want a movie that celebrates imperfection, improvisation and the importance of mistakes to be slick or seamless. What makes its heroine worth caring about ‰ÛÓ what makes her a rare and exciting presence in contemporary American film ‰ÛÓ is not that she‰Ûªs tidy or sensible or even especially nice. It‰Ûªs that she‰Ûªs free.

‰ÛÏWild‰Ûù may be full of natural beauty ‰ÛÓ Yves BÌ©langer‰Ûªs cinematography unostentatiously captures the infinite colors and vistas of the West ‰ÛÓ but it is also a celebration of the power of art. Cheryl, a budding writer, is also a devoted reader, filling log books with quotations from Emily Dickinson, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Adrienne Rich and James A. Michener (the subject of a recollected argument with Bobbi). Those words crystallize some of the film‰Ûªs ideas, while its feelings are carried along on a current of music: a well-timed Grateful Dead cover; hummed and whistled snatches of ‰ÛÏEl Condor Pasa,‰Ûù by Simon and Garfunkel; and an unexpected a cappella ballad that delivers a clean and overwhelming catharsis near the end.

What happens is that a series of encounters in the wilderness ‰ÛÓ mostly with men, some of them scary, some of them kind, almost all of them intrigued by the presence of a solitary woman so far from civilization ‰ÛÓ dissolve into montages of memory. The dominant figure in these is Cheryl‰Ûªs mother, Bobbi, an almost magical, not quite tragic figure played by Laura Dern. Bobbi‰Ûªs death from cancer is the great trauma of her daughter‰Ûªs life, and while the movie is careful not to posit grief as the cause of Cheryl‰Ûªs reckless, risky behavior, it does lay out a row of dots for her and the audience to connect.

The underbaked Israeli comedy ‰ÛÏZero Motivation‰Ûù opens with soldiers waiting to be bused to a remote artillery base. Among the riders are the movie‰Ûªs two young heroines, who scramble aboard, commandeer adjoining seats and settle in with shared headphones that tether them to each other. It isn‰Ûªt long, though, until the bus breaks down. The passengers disembark and then reboard, and the women lose their seats, forcing them to spend the rest of the trip standing and looking unhappy, a state that more or less describes their default mode over the rest of the movie.

The files and monitors, as well as the simple video games that Zohar plays, suggest that the story takes place a few years back. Some of the office workers sing pop tunes, but I can‰Ûªt remember anyone‰Ûªs ever tuning into the news on the radio or television, which underscores that this is a sketchy idea of a world rather than a persuasively lived-in one. Everything looks authentic, at least on the surface, from the desert dust to the messy desks and the sad, barren barracks. The characters, however, are largely cartoons, and their day-to-day exchanges are as vaguely defined as their interior lives. Zohar grimaces a lot and is a fighter; Daffi smiles a lot and is a dreamer.

Ms. Ivgy and Ms. Tagar have animated faces that, in the short term, help distract you from the lack of character development and visual interest. Zohar‰Ûªs struggles with their officious boss, Rama (Shani Klein), a figure of suggestive pathos, pad the story, as does Daffi‰Ûªs wish to be reassigned. For the most part, the real world, including Israeli politics, hovers off screen, though, if you‰Ûªre inclined, you could read the movie as a vaporous critique of the country‰Ûªs militarization. Or not. Ms. Lavie tucks in a few fantasy sequences here and there, adding hints of surrealism. But as she moves her characters from situation to situation ‰ÛÓ a bloody suicide and an attempted rape interrupt the longueurs ‰ÛÓ it becomes evident that she had some ideas for a movie, if not enough.

The writer and director, Talya Lavie, puts a mild comic spin on this scene, largely at the expense of the two women, Zohar (Dana Ivgy) and Daffi (Nelly Tagar), who journey from triumph to defeat, with smiles and frowns, within minutes. (Their unhappiness is ostensibly the audience‰Ûªs gain.) They continue to travel down that narrative road even after they‰Ûªve arrived at the base, an island-like desert outpost where droopy conscripts serve out their military service while fighting monotony, bureaucratic irrationality and one another. Boredom is a particular challenge for Zohar and Daffi, who, like the other female soldiers, work in the base‰Ûªs human resources office, a claustrophobic suite crammed with bodies, desks, files and bulky computer monitors.

Ms. DeLia serves it up in fragmentary fashion, with lots and lots of writhing, brooding, meaningfully vacant stares and so on. Several scenes are in danger of being unintentionally comic. Her efforts to translate psychological distress onto film are sometimes interesting but not very convincing. She is far from the first young filmmaker to mistake the struggles of a would-be artist for something profound, of course. Maybe she‰Ûªll produce more insightful work in the future, and we can all look back on this film as part of her learning process.

The movie, directed by Jennifer DeLia, explores the anguished creation process used by Billy (James Wirt) to produce his artworks, which would make dandy posters on the wall of some college student‰Ûªs dorm room. At a bar, he meets a pretty singer named Kaia (Savannah Welch), who goes with him back to his warehouse-like apartment and helps him explore just why he‰Ûªs so danged tortured. Mommy issues are involved.

Way back in 1982, Todd Rundgren named one of his albums ‰ÛÏThe Ever Popular Tortured Artist Effect,‰Ûù winking at a character type that had already become a clichÌ©. The fictional title character in ‰ÛÏBilly Bates‰Ûù was only just being born about that time. He grew up to be the caricature.

Like the well-known Bible verse from Corinthians, ‰ÛÏComet‰Ûù espouses that the greatest of these is love. Time and space are the runner-up elements in the mix of this film, from the first-time feature director Sam Esmail, yet faith and hope are there, too, in its take on rational pessimism and irrational optimism.
‰ÛÏComet‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language of the head and lower regions.

Those sorts of telegraphed messages ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏI won‰Ûªt let you go, I promise,‰Ûù says Mr. Long‰Ûªs Dell, helping Ms. Rossum‰Ûªs Kimberly cross cars of a speeding train ‰ÛÓ almost derail ‰ÛÏComet.‰Ûù But this flash of filmmaking is structured in an inventively cut, deconstructed time that confronts the nature of chance. As the characters wonder, maybe it‰Ûªs all a dream. Oh, the epistemology of it all.

‰ÛÏComet‰Ûù aims to be a serious look at romance, and Justin Long and Emmy Rossum serve it well as the fraught-with-freakish-intelligence couple at its center. Both appear to be naturals at the film‰Ûªs snark-free, zippy dialogue, which would outrun an Aaron Sorkin script in a verbal race. (Mr. Esmail also wrote the screenplay.) They handle, without apparent strain, pregnant, self-aware lines like ‰ÛÏSometimes it‰Ûªs not about knowing the ending.‰Ûù

The visions (a meteor shower, Paris) are romantic and lovely, and there‰Ûªs a sense of commitment to the enterprise that pretty much overcomes the near bathos and proves involving. (Ms. Rossum and Mr. Long, for example, are among the executive producers.) These occasionally obnoxious, certainly neurotic young lovers have beating, sometimes broken hearts, and that, as the apostle Paul once noted, tends to trump all.

In ‰ÛÏThe Black Power Mixtape 1967-1975‰Ûù (2011), Mr. Olsson drew on Swedish television archives for material about the American civil rights struggle, with guest voice-overs by musical artists. ‰ÛÏConcerning Violence‰Ûù recruits Lauryn Hill as its voice of authority, intoning Fanon‰Ûªs words while they are also blared in large letters across the screen to accompany records of colonial struggle in Africa, from the 1960s to the 1980s. A black intellectual recalls numbing torture, a white Rhodesian gripes about servants who anticipate freedom, and rebels in Mozambique envision a new order.

Mr. Olsson‰Ûªs news clips are purposeful and bursting with interest (although Fanon‰Ûªs major concern, Algeria, goes omitted). They‰Ûªre used in harmony and occasionally in counterpoint to Fanon‰Ûªs critique, which proclaims colonialism to be an annihilating force, and violence a necessary and liberating tool for the oppressed. But the energy here feels more like that of a lecture than of a film; it‰Ûªs an analytical tonic that‰Ûªs potent to the point of bitter.

You can‰Ûªt say that ‰ÛÏConcerning Violence,‰Ûù Goran Hugo Olsson‰Ûªs found-footage essay, doesn‰Ûªt warn you. Its affirming prologue, starring the critical theorist Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, refers to the writings of the psychiatrist and philosopher Frantz Fanon as a ‰ÛÏteaching text,‰Ûù and what follows is a clip of soldiers in helicopters, gunning down cattle. True to form, this documentary is a didactic illustration of Fanon‰Ûªs 1961 anticolonialist broadside, ‰ÛÏThe Wretched of the Earth,‰Ûù abridged and sharpened to its ferocious point.

Directed by Joanna Bowzer, the darkly humorous ‰ÛÏDelusions of Guinevere‰Ûù makes some sly and smart observations about what passes for celebrity status today. As Guinevere (Ariana Bernstein) becomes obsessed with social media and her growing presence on it, she sheds her relationships with close friends and family. A trade worth making, she seems to decide, as she pursues a minor fame as an end in itself.

Twenty years ago, Guinevere James was a child actor in a hit commercial. Nowadays, she‰Ûªs still acting, but with no visibility whatsoever. While scrambling for work, she stumbles onto a way to get back on the radar, posting videos of herself eating breakfast cereal. (If you don‰Ûªt think that could be a thing, you don‰Ûªt know YouTube.)

Shot in and around Brooklyn and Manhattan, this low-budget film is often static and awkward. Sequences involving a 20th-anniversary reunion with other child actors from the commercial are stilted and predictable; others, with Guinevere‰Ûªs ever-supportive friends, are mostly sitcomish. Smaller scenes, though, like those when Guinevere interacts with her tough-minded lawyer of a sister or an old classmate from high school, have a realness to them.

Most striking, however, is the movie‰Ûªs corrosive appraisal of the acting life: the degrading auditions, the inevitable rejections, the experimental theater work. Suggesting that Guinevere consider other options, her former agent muses on how difficult and pointless a career it can be. ‰ÛÏOut of all of life‰Ûªs choices, why would you want to pretend to be someone else?‰Ûù

Banir, who suffers from a hereditary blood disease, is portrayed as Lake‰Ûªs mirror image: Each man is a dying true believer sidelined in a changing world. (In the funniest scene, Lake has an outburst when told he can‰Ûªt smoke in a restaurant in Romania.) Because Lake‰Ûªs condition causes inappropriate reactions and unreliable perception, his foul-mouthed criticism of what he sees as botched C.I.A. operations is open to interpretation.

Even without an intellectual dimension, ‰ÛÏDying of the Light‰Ûù would make a decent espionage picture, a companion to the similarly character-driven ‰ÛÏA Most Wanted Man.‰Ûù The notion of an undercover agent with an untrustworthy mind is a great gimmick ‰ÛÓ and on a commercial level, ‰ÛÏDying of the Light‰Ûù sometimes plays as just another high-concept vehicle for a comically overacting Mr. Cage. But Mr. Schrader‰Ûªs vision is strong enough to rage against the hackier calculations.
‰ÛÏDying of the Light‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Swearing; impalement by finger.

Nevertheless, what emerges in ‰ÛÏDying of the Light‰Ûù is an uncommonly contemplative cat-and-mouse thriller: a meditation on mortality and fanaticism, themes familiar to Mr. Schrader, whose explorations of the subjects include his work as the screenwriter of ‰ÛÏTaxi Driver‰Ûù and as the director of ‰ÛÏHardcore‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMishima: A Life in Four Chapters.‰Ûù

Paul Schrader is credited as the writer and director of ‰ÛÏDying of the Light,‰Ûù but that authorial attribution comes with an asterisk: The cut reaching theaters isn‰Ûªt his. In protest, Mr. Schrader; his stars Nicolas Cage and Anton Yelchin; and one of his executive producers, the filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn, have appeared online in T-shirts emblazoned with the text of a nondisparagement clause.

Mr. Cage plays Evan Lake, a three-decade C.I.A. operative who delivers rallying talks to recruits, telling them that the organization didn‰Ûªt outlive its usefulness when the Berlin Wall fell. Lake yearns to catch Muhammad Banir (Alexander Karim), a terrorist the agency says is dead and won‰Ûªt investigate, even when evidence suggests otherwise. Lake, who can‰Ûªt abide a murderer going free, has started to experience symptoms of frontotemporal dementia.

The title suggests otherwise, of course, and one of the tragedies of Alzheimer‰Ûªs for the friends and family of the afflicted person is that the sufferer seems present and absent at the same time. ‰ÛÏStill Alice‰Ûù examines both the philosophical and emotional aspects of this paradoxical situation, and the principal vehicle for the inquiry is Ms. Moore‰Ûªs exquisitely nuanced performance. From the early scenes, when brief memory lapses signal that something is wrong, through the subsequent deterioration of her cognitive ability, she conveys both the collapse of Alice‰Ûªs inner world and the panic it causes. The structure of her face seems to change from scene to scene, as her eyes grow duller, her mouth and jaw slacker. As she did in ‰ÛÏSafe,‰Ûù she finds a way to communicate the pathos of emptiness.
‰ÛÏStill Alice‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Strong language and sexual allusions, as well an incurable disease.

There are tensions at the beginning between Lydia and her mother ‰ÛÓ in an early scene, Alice picks apart her daughter‰Ûªs life choices with relentless, passive-aggressive skill ‰ÛÓ but Lydia is also frequently the only member of the family brave or honest enough to accept who her mother becomes and to find ways of staying connected to her.

It‰Ûªs not that the others fail, exactly. Alice‰Ûªs husband, John (Alec Baldwin), a research physician, works hard to be tender and supportive, as do the other children, played by Kate Bosworth and Hunter Parrish. The problem is that the film, concentrating on the accurate portrayal of Alice‰Ûªs condition, leaves the other characters undeveloped, and their social and domestic milieu hastily sketched. The test of realism in a movie like this ‰ÛÓ the thing that would separate it from a conventional, made-for-television disease melodrama ‰ÛÓ is whether you can imagine lives for the secondary characters when they aren‰Ûªt on screen.

‰ÛÏStill Alice‰Ûù lacks that kind of thickness. It surrounds Alice and her family with the signifiers of a perfect, privileged life: impressive jobs, well-raised children, a Manhattan brownstone and a lovely beach house, neither one too showy. But all of this feels like a too tidy garden that has been planted for the sole purpose of introducing a blight and observing its ravages. The story is sad and sincerely told, but it is too removed from life to carry the full measure of pain that Alice deserves.

But the film as a whole functions mainly as a scaffolding for this remarkable feat of acting, and also for Kristen Stewart‰Ûªs excellent work as Alice‰Ûªs younger daughter, Lydia. The success of the ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù movies has allowed Ms. Stewart‰Ûªs gifts to be underrated, but her more recent roles (here, in ‰ÛÏ Camp X-Ray‰Ûù and in ‰ÛÏClouds of Sils Maria,‰Ûù which will open next year) should help re-establish her as an insightful and unpredictable talent.

‰ÛÏStill Alice‰Ûù is a movie that addresses a nightmarish circumstance with calm, compassionate sensitivity. Based on Lisa Genova‰Ûªs novel and directed by Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland, it follows the deterioration of a Columbia linguistics professor who learns she has early-onset Alzheimer‰Ûªs disease. Alice Howland (Julianne Moore), along with her husband and three children, must endure a cruel and absurd ordeal that has no real chance of growing easier. With what seems like shocking rapidity ‰ÛÓ the film‰Ûªs chronology is appropriately fuzzy ‰ÛÓ Alice slides from a witty, intelligent, capable adult into a fragile and confused shadow of her former self.

Foolishly cavalier about her day job at a real estate agency, Sasha tells everyone that she is really a musician (her idol is Patti Smith), although there are scant signs that she is actually writing songs or studying music. When Paige helpfully arranges for her to meet a slightly older woman, Sasha scoffs.

Susanna Fogel‰Ûªs eensy-weensy comedy, ‰ÛÏLife Partners,‰Ûù squeezes more juice from its concept than I thought possible in such a small movie. A lifelong friendship between two women is challenged when one of them falls in love, and their cozy co-dependence comes to an end.

If this all sounds trivial, it is. But in their trivial way, the characters‰Ûª disagreements and petty conflicts are painfully familiar signs of immaturity, and to a degree, ‰ÛÏLife Partners‰Ûù might be taken as a gently needling critique of the millennial generation.

Tim, to whom Paige becomes engaged after some disagreements about his clothes and her ignorance of his favorite movie (‰ÛÏThe Big Lebowski‰Ûù), has a zany imagination. His marriage proposal is a message scrawled on his back, which he bares when he asks her to inspect him for signs of skin cancer. He is the first person to stand up to Paige, who, like her grating mother (Julie White), refuses to admit that she is ever wrong. Paige‰Ûªs obstinacy extends to her refusal to reimburse a next door neighbor whose car she damaged while driving and texting.

Sasha (Leighton Meester), a receptionist, and Paige (Gillian Jacobs), an environmental lawyer, are both 29, acutely aware of the passing time and under pressure to put their lives on steadier tracks. They are so close that they almost seem to share a secret language, and the relaxed intimacy of their friendship goes a long way toward filling the absence of serious romantic partners.
‰ÛÏLife Partners‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language and sexual content.

Sasha belongs to a quasi-incestuous clique of lesbians who are continually changing partners. The movie casts an acutely knowing eye on smart, likable, sexually freewheeling women whose depiction seems authentic, down to the tiniest details of their tastes in television and fashion. If there‰Ûªs a common trait, it is their self-centeredness and stubborn insistence, when faced with conflict, that they are in the right.

The strengths of ‰ÛÏLife Partners‰Ûù are its comfortably lived-in performances and the screenplay‰Ûªs accumulation of minute details about the characters. The core of the drama is Sasha‰Ûªs bereavement over her best friend‰Ûªs partial abandonment. To her chagrin, she realizes that her days of dawdling and procrastination are over; it‰Ûªs time to grow up.

Sasha, who is gay, gravitates toward bratty, clingy, younger women, some of whom still live with their parents. Paige‰Ûªs search for Mr. Right is fruitless until she meets Tim (Adam Brody), a nice-looking, considerate, slightly nerdy dermatologist. Sexual orientation is not an issue: Neither Sasha nor Paige harbors a secret yearning for the other. They are totally comfortable talking about any subject, including their love lives.

‰ÛÏA Spell to Ward Off the Darkness‰Ûù is a collaboration between two stalwarts of the experimental-film scene: the British director Ben Rivers (‰ÛÏTwo Years at Sea‰Ûù) and the American Ben Russell (‰ÛÏLet Each One Go Where He May‰Ûù).

In its own way, each section ponders ways of engaging with the natural world ‰ÛÓ even the concert segment, which has primal screams instead of lyrics. Avant-garde cognoscenti are surely already in line, yet the film is accessible and often hypnotic on an intuitive level.

In a hallucinatory prologue that begins at what can‰Ûªt quite be discerned as dawn or dusk, the camera pans a lakeside landscape, and trees seem to dissolve into sound waves. The first movement explores an Estonian commune, the kind of place where a man and a woman discuss power structures while the woman breast-feeds an infant. A nonspeaking member, played (or embodied?) by the musician Robert A. A. Lowe, wanders off, initiating the second movement, in which he boats and hikes in solitude in Finland. He then dons face paint, and in the third movement is shown playing in a black-metal band.

With interests that range from the formal properties of film to its ethnographic potential, neither director is easily pigeonholed. Their descriptions of ‰ÛÏSpell‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªve called the movie ‰ÛÏcinema-sorcery of the most embodied sort‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏa proposition for cinema as both a way forward and a way for the present‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ do little to make it less abstract. Perhaps it‰Ûªs best to go in cold, to preserve the incantatory qualities the title promises.

Mr. Farrell, who gives the strongest performance, infuses John with a desperate, wild-eyed intensity. With his slicked black hair and cunning gaze, he is at times practically a dead ringer for Dirk Bogarde‰Ûªs diabolically crafty valet in ‰ÛÏThe Servant,‰Ûù though not as bright. As he and Miss Julie imbibe copious amounts of the baron‰Ûªs wine, John strips off layers of his social conditioning about class and sex until he is exposed as a floundering lost soul.

Aside from the change of setting, Ms. Ullmann‰Ûªs version is quite orthodox. Much more convincing than Mike Figgis‰Ûªs 1999 screen adaptation, starring Saffron Burrows, it is a grueling slog through a hell of torment, cruelty and suffering.
In a fit of postcoital revulsion, John views Miss Julie as a whore he would like to shoot to death. She considers him a rat.

It is Midsummer‰Ûªs Eve, and the baron is away but soon to return. As the three clomp around the country estate, you can hear the ruckus of the villagers celebrating outside the locked gates. But you never see the revelers, who were so prominent in the play‰Ûªs 1951 Swedish screen adaptation, directed by Alf Sjoberg. Nor do you hear about the title character‰Ûªs being the daughter of a staunch protofeminist.

The drama, which proceeds with painstaking deliberation, is a kind of Rorschach test whose interpretation depends on which elements the director and the actors choose to emphasize. As the characters chase one another around in a circle, the movie evokes Sartre‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNo Exit,‰Ûù by way of Ingmar Bergman.

Their hostility is exacerbated by their acute class consciousness. After Miss Julie and John have shed their armor, they have no illusions, and life becomes momentarily unbearable until they have collected themselves. Only Kathleen, miserable but secure in her Christian faith, has a solid foundation. While showing the nearly blank expression of an obedient servant, Ms. Morton conveys layers of suppressed anguish as she watches her possible future husband disintegrate, then reassemble his parts, in a deadly power struggle. Once put back together, those parts constitute the oppressive social constructs that pass for the self.

That thought is worth keeping in mind while watching Liv Ullmann‰Ûªs austere screen adaptation of the play, which has been relocated from Sweden to Ireland during the same period. This version has three characters: Miss Julie (Jessica Chastain), the beautiful daughter of a wealthy baron; John (Colin Farrell), her father‰Ûªs ambitious, beady-eyed valet; and Kathleen (Samantha Morton), the long-suffering cook of the house and John‰Ûªs churchgoing fiancÌ©e, whom he treats with lordly condescension. This household is a closed system, and its atmosphere is intensely claustrophobic.

Foremost among the film‰Ûªs entangled themes is the battle of the sexes, portrayed as an atavistic struggle for dominance. At different moments in the play, Miss Julie and John grovel and kiss each other‰Ûªs shoes. As their courtship heats up, their game of attraction and repulsion evokes two wild animals, sniffing and spitting, backing away, then pouncing and grappling in a rite that seems more painful than ecstatic. Sex is synonymous with surrender to bestial instincts that trump civilized decorum and open chasms of fear, loathing, shame and degradation.

The patriarchal world of August Strindberg‰Ûªs dour late-19th-century tragedy ‰ÛÏMiss Julie‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ with its rigid social hierarchy of masters and servants, and its entrenched puritanical ethos ‰ÛÓ may seem remote to Americans. But when you remember that there are still societies in which men rule with an iron hand, and women are stoned to death for breaking convention, it doesn‰Ûªt seem so distant.

The acting is uneven. Ms. Chastain‰Ûªs Irish accent is shaky at best. Bit by bit, however, she peels away the layers of her character‰Ûªs self-protective hauteur to reveal a frightened little girl. Once she has shed her patrician airs, what remains is an empty shell.
‰ÛÏMurder of a Cat‰Ûù is a pleasant enough comic thriller, though it‰Ûªs the lead character ‰ÛÓ not the cat ‰ÛÓ you might most want to see murdered.

He‰Ûªs Clinton Moisey (Fran Kranz), a grown man who still lives with his mother (Blythe Danner) and seems to spend most of the day in his bathrobe. When he finds his beloved cat dead ‰ÛÓ shot with a crossbow ‰ÛÓ he becomes a self-appointed private eye in the ‰ÛÏBored to Death‰Ûù tradition and tries to solve the crime.

The film‰Ûªs best feature is its supporting cast, especially Nikki Reed as a woman who owned the same cat (it was moonlighting, alternating between the two homes), J. K. Simmons as the local sheriff, and Greg Kinnear as the owner of a Walmart-like store that figures prominently in the mystery.

These secondary characters are fun, but Clinton is mostly annoying. It may be that this script read more amusingly than it plays, or that overuse has cost man-child characters their ability to be endearing. Whatever the reason, the film, a first feature from Gillian Greene (wife of the director Sam Raimi, a producer here), has to settle for ‰ÛÏsometimes amusing comedy‰Ûù when it was probably aiming for ‰ÛÏcult hit.‰Ûù

With its whom-do-you-trust plotting, Mr. Skjoldbjaerg‰Ûªs fight-the-power film plays like too many stories of corporate malfeasance. The gray look suggests the view through the thick spectacles worn by one of Petter‰Ûªs colleagues; shots are partly obscured or all too faithful to the cramped environment of oil workers.

Mr. Hennie, who starred in Morten Tyldum‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHeadhunters,‰Ûù gets stuck on a couple of beleaguered facial expressions. (Wes Bentley, as an American oil worker, keeps popping up to surprise Petter and glower.) Mr. Skjoldbjaerg, who also tapped Norwegian history with his bank robbery re-enactment ‰ÛÏNokas,‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt convey a creeping atmosphere of moral rot so much as an irksome glumness.

On a training dive, Petter (Aksel Hennie) sees his brother die, apparently because of human error. His nosing around leads to an awkwardness with management and his being locked into a pressure chamber. He suspects its air supply is tainted, which means that a humble gas canister becomes a hotly disputed piece of evidence.

Blessed with the discovery of oil in the North Sea in 1969, Norway went on to save its billions in profits for a rainy day, turning its residents into millionaires on paper. As if to suggest that this paradisiacal state of affairs has a sinful side, Erik Skjoldbjaerg‰Ûªs murky thriller ‰ÛÏPioneer‰Ûù rolls out a plodding tale of corruption during an oil extraction project in the early 1980s.
‰ÛÏPioneer‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language.

The lower they travel, the more distressed their marriage becomes. Chloe flirtatiously bums cigarettes off the captain (Billy Campbell). She feels betrayed when she hears that Peter, a writer, has received a book deal. He hasn‰Ûªt told her, even though the project will require him to spend a year away from her.

Working with an assortment of cameras, the cinematographer, Michael Simmonds, does wonders with the southern light. While the movie features its share of ice, penguins and whales, it is less a landscape film than a claustrophobic chamber play, suffused with close-ups and shallow focus. Yet lacking a formal script, the actors struggle with a plot so elemental that it might have played more persuasively as a silent-screen melodrama.

Not trusting his film‰Ûªs paranoid atmosphere to be sufficient, Mr. Cohen clumsily inscribes his influences. He includes a scene of Chloe watching Roman Polanski‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKnife in the Water‰Ûù on her laptop. (Giving a sense of how personal this project may be, Mr. Cohen dedicates ‰ÛÏRed Knot‰Ûù to his wife.)

‰ÛÏRed Knot,‰Ûù the feature debut of Scott Cohen, a New York artist, takes an imposing backdrop and adds the slenderest of stories. This largely improvised movie, a fiction that has documentary elements, was shot on a sea voyage to Antarctica, with actors mingling among the other passengers. The narrative concerns a pair of newlyweds, Peter (Vincent Kartheiser) and Chloe (Olivia Thirlby), who treat the trip as a sort of substitute honeymoon.

‰ÛÏWe felt like we were changing the world,‰Ûù says one of the women interviewed in Mary Dore‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Beautiful When She‰Ûªs Angry,‰Ûù about the early years of the women‰Ûªs liberation movement. And as Ms. Dore‰Ûªs movie reminds us, feminists didn‰Ûªt just feel as if they were changing the world ‰ÛÓ they changed it.

The publicity notes say that ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Beautiful‰Ûù is the rare documentary on this subject made for theatrical release. But it might have been a better fit for television, where you can imagine its being an ‰ÛÏEyes on the Prize-type series with chapters digging deeper into aspects of the story. One chapter could cover the present generation of feminists
column6: who show up only in this movie‰Ûªs final minutes. Because there‰Ûªs another thing this movie makes clear: The fight isn‰Ûªt over.""he publicity notes say that ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Beautiful‰Ûù is the rare documentary on this subject made for theatrical release. But it might have been a better fit for television
column7: where you can imagine its being an ‰ÛÏEyes on the Prize"-type series with chapters diggi""e publicity notes say that ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûª"

column5: Ms. Dore‰Ûªs movie packs a lot in, taking us on a whirlwind tour of those early years, roughly 1966 to 1971. Here are consciousness-raising groups; the birth of the National Organization for Women; protests at the 1968 Miss America Pageant; marches; poetry readings; ‰ÛÏOur Bodies, Ourselves‰Ûù; snippets of ‰ÛÏThe David Frost Show‰Ûù (‰ÛÏWhy are you so sensitive?‰Ûù he asks his feminist guests); schisms in the movement (race, class, the lesbian ‰ÛÏLavender Menace‰Ûù); and discussions of abortion, child care, sex, work and motherhood.

As filmmaking, ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Beautiful‰Ûù is meat and potatoes: It gets the job done without frills. Ms. Dore combines historical footage and contemporary interviews with Susan Brownmiller, Rita Mae Brown, Kate Millett, Alix Kates Shulman and Ellen Willis, among others. (She frequently ‰ÛÓ and movingly ‰ÛÓ cuts from a modern interview to images of the speaker in her movement days.)

Frannie (Leslie Bibb) certainly has her reasons: She‰Ûªs been in a car accident, and her arm and leg are in casts; tasks like bathing, raiding the refrigerator and getting around her apartment building can be an ordeal. But Devon (Thomas Sadoski) owes her: Frannie nursed him for years while he fought cancer, losing her job in the process. Now a healthy Devon, having cut a $6 million software deal with Yahoo, is hanging at her apartment, watching TV, washing her hair and taking her to the doctor.

The film‰Ûªs director, Liz Tuccillo ‰ÛÓ a former writer for ‰ÛÏSex and the City,‰Ûù an author of ‰ÛÏHe‰Ûªs Just Not That Into You‰Ûù and now developing a sitcom for Lauren Graham ‰ÛÓ is predictably facile with comic rhythms, though her dialogue tilts toward the glib, and her characterizations toward the familiar. Mr. Sadoski (Olivia Munn‰Ûªs love interest in ‰ÛÏThe Newsroom‰Ûù) underplays opposite Ms. Bibb, expertly conceding the spotlight.
‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs a little needy,‰Ûù Devon‰Ûªs new wealthy girlfriend says.
‰ÛÏYou get dramatic sometimes,‰Ûù Devon says to his ex-girlfriend Frannie, in the mildly amusing rom-com ‰ÛÏTake Care.‰Ûù

Ms. Bibb, perhaps best known for her role in the TV series ‰ÛÏPopular,‰Ûù gamely subjects herself to humiliating positions as she struggles around an apartment, but she overreaches with her glares, lip biting and strained smiles. As her rival, Betty Gilpin (from ‰ÛÏNurse Jackie‰Ûù) demonstrates that a measure of restraint goes a long way.

Mr. Traub, who also serves as the film‰Ûªs cinematographer, is the son of Ms. Yeh, and he has inherited her sure eye for composition. The other director, Mr. Holsten, was a maker of the winning 2012 documentary ‰ÛÏOC87,‰Ûù a study of obsessive-compulsive disorder. His gift for portraiture shows only further refinement here.

There is much healing in ‰ÛÏThe Barefoot Artist,‰Ûù Glenn Holsten and Daniel Traub‰Ûªs fascinating documentary portrait of the artist Lily Yeh. Ms. Yeh is also what you might call a global community organizer: She has led residents in blighted areas in creating colorful structures and sites: a school in Beijing, a memorial to those killed in Rwanda in 1994, a meditation garden in India, a center for the arts in North Philadelphia. Now in her 70s, Ms. Yeh, who runs the nonprofit Barefoot Artists, is a tireless believer in using art to soothe deep wounds.

Here she addresses some in her own family, notably those left by her father, a general in China under Chiang Kai-shek who left his arranged marriage and his children to marry Ms. Yeh‰Ûªs mother. (His second family moved to Taiwan after the Communist takeover.) Ms. Yeh travels to China to meet the other side of the family and to seek their forgiveness for her father‰Ûªs neglect, which tormented him with guilt to his dying day. Her relatives‰Ûª accounts of suffering under Mao‰Ûªs regime, which penalized them for her father‰Ûªs political allegiances, have profound emotional power.

But ‰ÛÏThe Foxy Merkins‰Ûù has its longueurs and deflates in a repetitive, unfunny sequence of police raids on a hotel where Margaret is practicing her trade. Behind its transgressive affectations, ‰ÛÏThe Foxy Merkins‰Ûù is a sweet, playful divertissement.

Margaret (Lisa Haas), the heroine of Madeleine Olnek‰Ûªs sly, loose-jointed satire ‰ÛÏThe Foxy Merkins,‰Ûù is probably no one‰Ûªs idea of a lesbian prostitute, or a midnight cowgirl. Brand-new to New York, the stocky, bespectacled Margaret camps out in a restroom in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where she sleeps, wrapped in clear plastic. But as she wanders the city, she is avidly cruised by closeted suburban women who ogle from their car windows and do double takes when they pass her on the sidewalk.

The movie is little more than a collection of comic sketches built around the adventures of Margaret and Jo (Jackie Monahan), her heterosexual mentor in sex work. (Ms. Monahan wrote the screenplay with Ms. Haas and Ms. Olnek.) In the scenes of Margaret and Jo together, the movie sustains the tone of an absurdist buddy comedy.

One of its charms is its cheerful demolition of female stereotypes, gay and straight, as Margaret embarks on her unlikely new career. A particularly funny scene depicts an erotic fetish called motorboating. Another is Margaret‰Ûªs chance meeting in a cemetery with a salesman (played with wonderful deadpan gravity by Alex Karpovsky) peddling pubic toupees for women, known as merkins.

It‰Ûªs a funny opener but also a somewhat curious one, because the story soon shifts elsewhere, never to return to this little apartment with its gently duplicitous wife who‰Ûªs lied to spare her husband. (‰ÛÏWhat he doesn‰Ûªt know won‰Ûªt hurt him,‰Ûù she says.) Alfredo does pop up later in the story, but his main function is to help set a comic tone and introduce an idea about human relations that runs through the film like a musical refrain. People lie in ‰ÛÏThe Passionate Thief‰Ûù: Sometimes they lie for love, as the conductor‰Ûªs wife appears to do, and occasionally they lie out of cruelty. At other times, they lie simply for expediency. (Cinema, Mr. Monicelli winks, tells its own lies.)

Mr. Monicelli wrote the film with the same prolific writers he had worked with for his 1958 hit, ‰ÛÏBig Deal on Madonna Street‰Ûù: Agenore Incrocci, Furio Scarpelli and Suso Cecchi D‰ÛªAmico, who all had a hand in some of the most important Italian movies of the 20th century. In a 1999 interview with the online journal Offscreen, Mr. Monicelli said his film characters always attempt a great enterprise and fail. ‰ÛÏSo in Italian comedy, there is almost always a sad ending,‰Ûù he said, ‰ÛÏor lack of a happy ending.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏThe Passionate Thief‰Ûù opens with glittering images of Rome after dark, including a street panorama in which a motorcyclist, seen only in long shot, yells out, ‰ÛÏAlfredo, Alfredo!‰Ûù A slight camera movement reveals that he‰Ûªs yelling up to a terrace where a woman materializes, waves and walks into a cramped apartment that shifts the story from the bustle of the city to the hum of family life. Alfredo (a funny Mac Ronay, warbling his lines) turns out to be her husband, a subway conductor on his way to work, who mournfully insists that she celebrate New Year‰Ûªs without him. She assures him that they won‰Ûªt, sees him to the door and immediately breaks out the party favors.

The voluptuary Roman god Bacchus probably started the party that continued at Nero‰Ûªs orgies and kept going in the feverish blowouts by Federico Fellini, Luchino Visconti and, more recently, Paolo Sorrentino. The party goes all night in ‰ÛÏThe Passionate Thief,‰Ûù a 1960 film from Mario Monicelli that tracks an accidental trio ‰ÛÓ played by the fantastic, weird combo of Anna Magnani, Ben Gazzara and TotÌ_ ‰ÛÓ who scramble and scheme through Rome on a New Year‰Ûªs Eve filled with shrieks of laughter, desperate actions and consuming pleasures. Shot in black and white, the movie has been gorgeously restored and is having its first New York theatrical run at Film Forum.

There isn‰Ûªt much of a story in ‰ÛÏThe Passionate Thief,‰Ûù though much ‰ÛÓ including shimmering life, lust and comedy ‰ÛÓ happens. After being abandoned by some acquaintances, Tortorella meets up with an old friend, Umberto (TotÌ_, blessed with one of cinema‰Ûªs eternal mugs), who‰Ûªs been enlisted to help a pickpocket, Lello (an alluring, brutish Mr. Gazzara, dubbed into Italian). There‰Ûªs a comedy of errors at a lavish party, filled with revelers and balloons, and later, quieter moments in the deserted streets. There‰Ûªs also a bit that plays like a spoof of the fountain scene in Fellini‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLa Dolce Vita,‰Ûù and strips the romance off that watery interlude, and a long sequence with a mansion filled with polite Germans that carries a post-World War II sting. Mr. Monicelli‰Ûªs humor and fluid visual style are joys.

Ms. Magnani plays Tortorella, an actress first seen working as an extra on the set of a religious spectacle (a foreshadowing of the bacchanalia to come) being shot at CinecittÌÊ Studios. Wearing a formless, back-lot schmatte and a lopsided mass of curls that sits on her head like a drunken toy poodle, she is acting her heart and lungs out, yelling ‰ÛÏMiracle, miracle‰Ûù with upraised arms and tonsils almost showing. Soon, the director calls it a day, and she‰Ûªs tearing the wig off and slipping into a fur, excitedly hurtling toward an evening that flickers with alternating currents of promise and disappointment. ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs always alert, always available,‰Ûù someone says of Tortorella, a characterization that sounds mean but which the divine Ms. Magnani turns into a woman‰Ûªs soulful quest.

That‰Ûªs not quite true of ‰ÛÏThe Passionate Thief,‰Ûù which ends at the crossroads of defeat and struggle, the place that, for all the miles the characters rack up, is really where we‰Ûªve been all along. In other films, that might be a bad finish; here, it‰Ûªs a blissful assertion of survival.

And we watch him. Owner of one of the great faces of Japanese cinema, Mr. Fukumoto, warm-eyed and hollow-cheeked, was made to be looked at. Dying with panache might be a near-obsolete talent, but holding an audience‰Ûªs attention will never go out of style.

Directing with an old-fashioned tenderness toward his unassuming star, Ken Ochiai conjures a swan song to a waning art form and those who practice it. Sweet and simple, Hiroyuki Ono‰Ûªs story contrasts the humility and professionalism of the old-guard performers with the brash entitlement of their younger replacements. As computer-generated swords supersede the real thing, and more fantastical stories supplant traditional period tropes, Kamiyama and his cohort watch from the sidelines.

Drawing from real life, the sentimental tale ‰ÛÏUzumasa Limelight‰Ûù observes the end-career humiliations of Kamiyama (the renowned Seizo Fukumoto), a septuagenarian actor whose imaginative deaths at the end of a blade have earned him regular work and legendary status. Now, however, his stiffening body threatens to make his signature move, the ‰ÛÏprawn bend,‰Ûù almost impossible, and when his long-running samurai series is canceled, his skills are downgraded to theme park attractions for swarming tourists.

Being killed on screen isn‰Ûªt as easy as it looks, as actors who make their living by dying will attest. In Japan, those who aspire to expire ‰ÛÓ mostly in the country‰Ûªs many and bloody samurai dramas ‰ÛÓ are colorfully called ‰ÛÏkirareyaku,‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏsliced-up actors.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏImagine,‰Ûù says Sunni (Christa Nicola), the documentary‰Ûªs director. ‰ÛÏThe last people who walked these tunnels died thousands of years ago.‰Ûù

In ‰ÛÏThe Pyramid,‰Ûù an archaeological team and a documentary crew get stuck in an ancient Egyptian tomb that is armed with booby traps and protected by feral, inbred cats. Clearly, this is not a situation to which logic applies. The movie nevertheless adds a veneer of realism, setting the action during the unrest of August 2013.

A father-daughter archaeologist pair, Miles (Denis O‰ÛªHare) and Nora (Ashley Hinshaw), share exposition duties, reading the hieroglyphics to understand what might be down there. (Miles pleads with everyone not to use the word ‰ÛÏcurse.‰Ûù) The answers aren‰Ûªt satisfying, and ‰ÛÏThe Pyramid,‰Ûù despite an unpretentious matinee vibe, is mostly interesting in seeing how little light can be on screen before a bare minimum of suspense and coherence dissipates. There is, truly, not much to see in this movie.
She fails to wonder whether that‰Ûªs a bad sign. Viewers also shouldn‰Ûªt ask questions, like who could be filming overhead shots.

The film is another example of the found-footage genre, in which the movie you‰Ûªre seeing has supposedly been shot, at least partly, by its characters. One camera belongs to a NASA rover, which is damaged after venturing into the recently discovered pyramid. The humans go in after it.
‰ÛÏThe Pyramid‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Toxic air, wild animals, giant spikes.
‰ÛÏMagician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Don‰Ûªt worry ‰ÛÓ no one explains the origin of Rosebud, more‰Ûªs the pity.

Like one of those machines that can inhale a car and spit out a tidy cube of squashed components, ‰ÛÏMagician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles‰Ûù is a near-indigestible lump of clips and quips and snipped opinions. Assembled chronologically and delivered at warp speed (there‰Ûªs enough astonishment here for double the 94-minute running time), this potted history of one of our rarest moviemaking talents offers nothing new for fans and seems likely to overwhelm the uninitiated.

Following his subject from child prodigy to complicated legend, the director, Chuck Workman, touches down so lightly on the mile markers of Welles‰Ûªs life that he barely leaves an imprint. Artistic triumphs and financial flops, often one and the same, roll by in spotless slices, as do the voices of luminaries, living and dead (John Houseman, how you are missed), who sing Welles‰Ûªs praises. Choosing breadth over depth ‰ÛÓ most maddeningly in a section dealing with the butchered ending of ‰ÛÏThe Magnificent Ambersons‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Mr. Workman faithfully records a career plagued by projects still unfinished or undone by legal disputes or lack of financing.

Similarly, Welles‰Ûªs colorful personal life ‰ÛÓ a rich stew of wives, lovers, feuding daughters and paternity rumors ‰ÛÓ is skated over as if it were quicksand. What‰Ûªs left offers little flavor of the mind behind the work, so when a former classmate describes Welles as having ‰ÛÏabsolutely no empathetic skills‰Ûù (and then rejects a characterization of him as humble with a disgusted ‰ÛÏugh‰Ûù), our ears prick up. But the revelations aren‰Ûªt pursued, leaving the man whom the actress Jeanne Moreau beautifully pronounces ‰ÛÏa destitute king‰Ûù perched on his throne. If, as he claimed, he aspired to make movies ‰ÛÏfor something except entertainment,‰Ûù what that might have been remains anyone‰Ûªs guess.

One of the ideas that Mr. Rock teases throughout ‰ÛÏTop Five‰Ûù is whether the stakes are different when the funnyman with that gift is black. That becomes prime fodder for the interview that Andre does with Chelsea Brown (a wonderful Rosario Dawson), a reporter for The New York Times assigned to write a profile of him. Wearing a brimmed hat that she might have borrowed from Annie Hall, Chelsea is rapidly transformed from Andre‰Ûªs interrogator ‰ÛÓ he berates her for asking hack questions ‰ÛÓ into his inevitable romantic foil. Initially accompanied by Andre‰Ûªs entourage, including his friend and body man, Silk (JB Smoove, superb), the two break free and begin walking and talking through a New York that‰Ûªs seductively romantic, partly because it‰Ûªs grounded in real ideas about how we live now.

In Chris Rock‰Ûªs fast and blisteringly funny ‰ÛÏTop Five‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a romantic comedy that‰Ûªs also an extended riff on art, identity, authenticity and what it means to be a black entertainer ‰ÛÓ Mr. Rock plays Andre Allen, a comic in crisis. A stand-up star turned movie-franchise brand, Andre has climbed to the top of the box office playing Hammy, a kind of ‰ÛÏLethal Weapon‰Ûù enforcer in a bear suit with a gun and a Schwarzenegger-style tag line: ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs Hammy time!‰Ûù (The words ‰ÛÏ600 million worldwide‰Ûù are stamped on a movie trailer in blood-red letters.) Now, though, Andre is trying to get serious with ‰ÛÏUprize!,‰Ûù a painfully misbegotten historical drama in which he plays a Haitian slave revolutionary.

At once tightly structured and loosely played, ‰ÛÏTop Five‰Ûù unfolds over the course of a day that softens into night as Andre and Chelsea travel ‰ÛÓ on foot, by car and by subway ‰ÛÓ from one part of the city to the next. In a raucous high-voltage scene, they visit Andre‰Ûªs old stomping ground, a housing project where, after he exchanges a quick, sour word with an old-timer (Ben Vereen in a sharply honed small part), they swing by an apartment. There, with bodies and furniture crowding the living room and photographs of President Obama adorning the walls, Andre‰Ûªs friends and presumably some of his earliest comic foils ‰ÛÓ played by Tracy Morgan, Sherri Shepherd, Leslie Jones, Michael Che and Jay Pharoah, among others ‰ÛÓ snap jokes and insults, putting more touches on his portrait.

Mr. Rock has far more on his mind than a catfight. In ‰ÛÏTop Five,‰Ûù he sifts through ‰ÛÓ with on-point jokes, boisterous slapstick, affecting honesty and a sharply honed and earned sense of history ‰ÛÓ issues of artificiality and authenticity, the spectacle of black celebrity and the imperative of personal meaning. Andre has become famous by playing Hammy the Bear, a character that completely obscures his blackness and his maleness. Both Hammy and the Haitian revolutionary represent two familiar ‰ÛÓ and Mr. Rock seems to suggest ‰ÛÓ permitted modes of black expression: clowning and suffering. In setting Andre on his search for self, Mr. Rock has carved out a third way, in the process creating a black character who‰Ûªs fully human and a comedy that‰Ûªs wholly a blast.

Andre may be the main attraction, but Mr. Rock‰Ûªs generosity as a filmmaker here means that Chelsea has plenty to say and do. Beat for beat, laugh for laugh, Ms. Dawson fluidly keeps pace with Mr. Rock, whether their characters are arguing about multiculturalism or revisiting Andre‰Ûªs career highs and hilarious, horrible lows, one of which is recounted in a gaspingly funny, raunchy flashback with a fantastic Cedric the Entertainer. Mr. Rock‰Ûªs acknowledged debt to Richard Linklater‰Ûªs peripatetic ‰ÛÏBefore‰Ûù triptych is evident in all the two-shots of Andre and Chelsea walking and talking, but also in how it‰Ûªs a given from the start that they‰Ûªre equals. Chelsea gives as good as she gets, yet never at the expense of Andre‰Ûªs other love interest, Erica (Gabrielle Union), a reality-television star.
‰ÛÏTop Five‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Raw, raw, raw.

Comics ‰ÛÓ they (still) don‰Ûªt get no respect! In some ways, ‰ÛÏTop Five‰Ûù revisits the question of art and its uses that merrily hums through Preston Sturges‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSullivan‰Ûªs Travels‰Ûù (1941), about a director who wants his next picture to be ‰ÛÏa true canvas of the suffering of humanity.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏStardust Memories‰Ûù (1980), Woody Allen‰Ûªs woebegone pastiche of ‰ÛÏ8 å_,‰Ûù Mr. Allen plays Sandy Bates, a director troubled by a similar crisis in comedic faith. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt feel funny,‰Ûù Bates says. ‰ÛÏI look around the world, and all I see is human suffering.‰Ûù When Bates shows some executives his latest film, one asks, ‰ÛÏDoesn‰Ûªt the man know that he has the greatest gift that anyone can have ‰ÛÓ the gift of laughter?‰Ûù

The movie opens with Andre trying to publicize ‰ÛÏUprize!,‰Ûù which is about to hit (and flop). Shooting in New York, Mr. Rock, who wrote and directed ‰ÛÏTop Five,‰Ûù sets the scene at warp speed with a compressed career retrospective that fills in Andre‰Ûªs history, his greatest hits and current aspirations. Charlie Rose, playing himself, pops by briefly and early to solidify Andre‰Ûªs place in the rarified celebrity firmament. Time magazine, Mr. Rose explains, anointed Andre the funniest man in America, an honor that‰Ûªs soon slyly undercut when a fan asks Andre when the next Hammy movie hits. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt feel like doing funny movies anymore,‰Ûù Andre says later, ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt feel funny.‰Ûù Given how funny the movie and Andre both are, Mr. Rock makes it tough to take this lament seriously.

He reluctantly agrees to teach her, but his strategy is unorthodox: She has to see the board as a city, and she will discover the game by exploring New York. When the time comes for her to understand how a rook moves, for instance, Norman tells her to find a real-life castle. Exactly how this implausible form of applied learning helps her win is unclear, but it‰Ûªs the sort of fantastical conceit ‰ÛÓ chess as a metaphor for life ‰ÛÓ that should probably be accepted.

Cartoonish in its depiction of class disparities, ‰ÛÏA Little Game‰Ûù gains some subtlety from its performers: Mr. Abraham, an old pro, does fine work alongside Ms. Ballard, a newcomer. But nothing in the film charms like a closing credit: ‰ÛÏFilmed entirely in New York City. Obviously.‰Ûù
A precocious 10-year-old girl learns a bit about chess and even more about life in ‰ÛÏA Little Game,‰Ûù a serviceable family film that is hardly a worthy rival for ‰ÛÏSearching for Bobby Fischer.‰Ûù

Growing up in Greenwich Village, Max (Makenna Ballard) begins private school at the insistence of her parents, a handyman (Ralph Macchio) and a cook (Janeane Garofalo) who can barely afford the tuition. After a classmate (FÌÁtima Ptacek) teases her for a lack of chess knowledge, Max wanders into Washington Square Park and strikes up an acquaintance with Norman (F. Murray Abraham), a curmudgeonly street player who pronounces Google as if it rhymed with ‰ÛÏkugel.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏA Little Game‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Unsupervised city wandering.

At various moments, ‰ÛÏAfter the Fall,‰Ûù originally titled ‰ÛÏThings People Do,‰Ûù recalls films like ‰ÛÏThe Company Men‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTime Out,‰Ûù in which prosperous male breadwinners lose their jobs and their footing. Eventually, it turns into a thudding, humorless retread of ‰ÛÏFun With Dick and Jane,‰Ûù as Bill resorts to crime to make ends meet.

Its woebegone protagonist, Bill (Wes Bentley), a saucer-eyed descendant of the character Mr. Bentley played in ‰ÛÏAmerican Beauty,‰Ûù was recently fired from his job as an insurance adjuster after authorizing too many generous payouts. A happily married father of two young boys, he is a caricature of a sensitive good guy who preaches ethics to his children.

Bill‰Ûªs opposite and the movie‰Ûªs Mephistophelean mouthpiece is Frank (Jason Isaacs), a cynical, hard-drinking police detective whom Bill meets at a bowling alley where they hang out during the day. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs fear that keeps us in line,‰Ûù Frank preaches. ‰ÛÏThere ain‰Ûªt no sin. There ain‰Ûªt no virtue. There‰Ûªs just things people do.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏAfter the Fall‰Ûù belongs to a type of movie that is too lazy to connect the dots and fill in the blanks between its supposedly teachable moments. The perfunctorily staged robbery scenes are devoid of adrenaline. And Mr. Bentley‰Ûªs wide-eyed stare conveys only a mild sense of alarm.

What is it about Albuquerque that seems to poison men‰Ûªs souls? Is it the disparity between the arid topography and the bizarre proliferation of swimming pools? Is it the scorching desert sun? While watching ‰ÛÏAfter the Fall,‰Ûù the directorial debut of Saar Klein, a celebrated film editor whose credits include two Terrence Malick films, I thought of ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad,‰Ûù set in the same surreal territory. Both convey an apocalyptic sense of good and evil. But where ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad‰Ûù sent a deepening chill of foreboding, ‰ÛÏAfter the Fall‰Ûù screams its moralism in your ear.
‰ÛÏAfter the Fall‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has strong language and sexual situations.

Mr. Klein leaves it to the cinematographer, Matthias Koenigswieser, to evoke the dread that is missing in a movie that lacks kinetic drive and suspense. An eerie sequence late in the film aims for a surreal, Malickian desolation, but it is an isolated conceit unattached to the story or to the characters: a pretentious flourish in an allegory that is all flourishes and no substance.

The screenplay, by Mr. Klein and Joe Conway, makes a stab at redeeming Bill by giving him pangs of conscience. In the most embarrassing scene, an old man in a supermarket observes Bill putting on a mask to hold up the store and is so frightened that he has a near-fatal asthma attack. Bill, good Samaritan that he is, kneels in the aisle to help save him. At this point, my gag reflex kicked in.

The first of the movie‰Ûªs many incongruities is the refusal of the honest, upright Bill to tell his wife, Susan (Vinessa Shaw), about his plight. But the flaw at the heart of the movie is the decision of this goody-two-shoes to commit a series of robberies to support the family. The only word to describe Bill‰Ûªs solution to his fall from grace is ‰ÛÏludicrous.‰Ûù

The filmmakers are out to convince us that a treatment developed in Japan can help, with its focus on sessions for reading, writing and performing computational tasks. The therapy and its results, as reported here in scenes at the Eliza Jennings home in Cleveland, offer hope, but the film recording it all has only a little more appeal than a pleasantly narrated DVD to train employees of assisted-living facilities. At least it‰Ûªs a peek inside life in such places.

And, more important, we get to know the people who are undergoing the treatment: Bea, Mae, Mary and especially Evelyn. They have great faces and rich personalities, enhanced by interviews with family and tales of their lives before dementia. They exist as much more than their symptoms. If Evelyn can‰Ûªt take away our fear, she at least humanizes it.

The documentary ‰ÛÏDo You Know What My Name Is?‰Ûù introduces us to people with forms of dementia, like Alzheimer‰Ûªs. It‰Ûªs a condition that frightens many of us, because we‰Ûªre worried that we‰Ûªll have it or will care for someone who has it, or because we‰Ûªve had experience with it. Films like ‰ÛÏAway From Her‰Ûù and the current release ‰ÛÏStill Alice‰Ûù meaningfully illustrate the challenges of the diagnosis.

‰ÛÏNoah,‰Ûù with its stone giants and Emma Watson, may have been too strange for some viewers. ‰ÛÏExodus,‰Ûù by contrast, crowded with well-known actors, is nowhere near strange enough. More than anything else, it recalls the wide-screen, Technicolor biblical pageants of the 1950s and early ‰Ûª60s, bland and solemn spectacles that invited moviegoers to marvel at their favorite stars in sandals and robes.

And when it does, ‰ÛÏExodus‰Ûù becomes, briefly, an interesting movie. The biblical book of the same title tells two entwined stories. One is an epic of national liberation and self-assertion, in which the Israelites discover a political identity and begin to organize themselves as a people. The other is a kind of love story, about the often contentious relationship between the Israelites and their god, who is a complicated literary character, by turns compassionate and stern, steadfast and fickle. He and Moses don‰Ûªt always get along.

Strangest of all is Christian Bale as Moses, raised in the Egyptian royal court as a brother to Ramses and blind to his true heritage. Eventually, of course, Moses discovers his Jewish roots, which means that he stops shaving, starts herding goats and, unless my ears deceive me, takes to peppering his speech with stagy old-man Yiddish inflections, as though preparing to lead his people from the fleshpots of Egypt into a borscht belt Canaan. You think this desert is dry? You should try my wife‰Ûªs brisket.

To be fair, there is some good stuff here, too. Mr. Scott is a sinewy storyteller and a connoisseur of big effects. He turns the 10 plagues into a science-fiction apocalypse and stages the climactic pursuit of the Hebrews by the Egyptian army with the thundering precision of a cavalry battle in a John Ford western. (The parting of the Red Sea, unfortunately, is a digital washout.) But in the past, this director has also shown a knack for intimacy and intensity, for moments of feeling that stand out amid the fight-and-flight adrenaline rushes. Think of the eerie quiet of ‰ÛÏAlien,‰Ûù the whispery enigmas of ‰ÛÏBlade Runner‰Ûù or the loose, raw humor of ‰ÛÏThelma & Louise.‰Ûù

That was a long time ago, and the committee-written script of ‰ÛÏExodus‰Ûù has little room for the human dimensions of the story, which contains some of the most psychologically complex episodes in the Torah. The movie does provide a brief interlude of romance and domesticity, when Moses, stopping at an oasis, catches the eye of a kohl-eyed beauty with a blue tattoo on her lip. That would be Zipporah, whose tribe he joins for a while. They have a son, and Moses teaches him to throw a baseball ‰ÛÓ technically I guess you‰Ûªd have to call it a rock ‰ÛÓ before destiny calls him away.

The Egyptian oppressors, with their heavy eyeliner and clingy linen robes, festoon their highfalutin pseudo-Oxbridge speech patterns with lisps and sighs. (The script is credited to a squad of competent dramaturges, none of them, alas, named Oscar Wilde.) John Turturro as the relatively nice pharaoh is out-camped only by Ben Mendelsohn as a corrupt, mincing viceroy. Even the manly and muscular Joel Edgerton as the bad pharaoh, Ramses, tries to play along, caressing snakes, fluttering his lashes and gorging on crab legs. Such women as there are in the movie ‰ÛÓ if you doze off you might miss Sigourney Weaver, Hiam Abbass and Tara Fitzgerald ‰ÛÓ mostly stand around holding trays and pitchers while the men thunder and hiss.

Longer than the average Hollywood feature film and shorter than the average Passover Seder, ‰ÛÏExodus: Gods and Kings‰Ûù tells the well-known story of how Moses led the enslaved Israelites out of bondage in Egypt. The timing of the movie‰Ûªs release ‰ÛÓ a few days before Hanukkah ‰ÛÓ may be a bit puzzling, but it does provide a nice bookend for 2014. We had a blockbuster Sunday school lesson in March in the form of Darren Aronofsky‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNoah,‰Ûù and now we have Ridley Scott‰Ûªs attempt to bring another famous chunk of the Hebrew Bible to life, in 3-D no less.
‰ÛÏExodus: Gods and Kings‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Blood, wild beasts, flies, boils, frogs, locusts, cattle disease, fire, darkness, death of the firstborn.

While it lasts, though, ‰ÛÏExodus‰Ûù has the makings of a provocative study of power, rebellion and loyalty. To paraphrase a Passover song, that would have been enough. What we get instead is both woefully insufficient and much too much.

In Mr. Scott‰Ûªs film, God appears to Moses in the person of a young boy (Isaac Andrews), a bold and in some ways genuinely radical choice. His spooky, icy voice urges Moses toward extremism ‰ÛÓ a reversal of Mr. Aronofsky‰Ûªs rendering of Genesis, in which Noah‰Ûªs fanaticism goes beyond the divine mandate ‰ÛÓ for reasons that Moses is unable to understand. He wants to help free his people, but he also feels a residual kinship with Ramses, a bond that must be severed completely. His military insurgency is not enough.

Alas, Mr. Scott is not Mel Brooks. ‰ÛÏExodus‰Ûù is ludicrous only by accident, which isn‰Ûªt much fun and is the surest sign of what we might call a New Testament sensibility at work. But the movie isn‰Ûªt successfully serious, either. Not for the first time, Mr. Scott confuses excessive scale with authentic grandeur, and while some of the battle scenes have a rousing, kinetic sweep, there are far too many slow aerial surveys of Memphis, the Egyptian capital, a city bristling with columns and other priapic monuments.

The casting of ‰ÛÏExodus,‰Ûù with mostly American, British and Australian actors in Middle Eastern and African roles, has raised some eyebrows, and while these choices represent a failure of imagination and sensitivity, they are also consistent with that old, stale tradition. So is the curious decision to encourage the performers to speak in strange, geographically and historically preposterous accents.

He spends most of the movie trying to hide his expulsion from his parents. He spars with the principal and, with an all-access smile, gets people to do things they shouldn‰Ûªt. Felix‰Ûªs brother (Marcus Johns, like Mr. Dallas, a star of Vine‰Ûªs world of six-second skits) turns out to be even more reckless. But the tech-gadget-heavy plotting is so preposterously weak that it‰Ûªs hard to look past the cheap laughs or half-baked direction (by a YouTube veteran, Alex Goyette).

Actor and cameraman are often the same person in a Vine video, and Mr. Dallas is certainly at ease talking into the lens. His character, Felix, does it a lot. But then, so did Ferris Bueller (and Dobie Gillis, for that matter), usually with more reason and charm. In fact, Felix is generally a misjudged creation: not funny enough to keep his behavior toward friends, an ex and parents from seeming bratty.
‰ÛÏExpelled‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for some crude language.

Some of these bits might work better looped on Vine (for example, Felix being slapped with a piece of food). Stretched over an 85-minute feature, however, Mr. Dallas‰Ûªs brand of easy goofing just feels like coasting.

Demographically, the high school caper ‰ÛÏExpelled‰Ûù has some curiosity value because it features Cameron Dallas, who has over six million followers on Vine, the video-sharing service. But comedically, this film about a prankster who is finally thrown out of school does not represent the debut of a great talent, whether in front of or behind the camera.

With is eager to write about an activist, Liv (Lola Kirke), who has run topless around Wall Street. (Oddly, mosaicking obscures the breasts in the initial protests, though the prurient and liberated will find plenty of nudity later on.) Liv and With become fast friends, spearheading an awareness campaign with the help of a public relations expert (Zach Grenier).

The logistics of raising money and securing permits for the cause are not the most compelling or irreverent subject. The movie‰Ûªs goal is straightforward advocacy ‰ÛÓ something it has accomplished simply by getting you to read this review.

The scripted drama ‰ÛÏFree the Nipple‰Ûù presents itself as part of a broader movement that advocates a woman‰Ûªs right to go topless in public. This form of nudity, provided it‰Ûªs nonlewd and noncommercial, has been ruled legal by New York State‰Ûªs highest court, although it has caused confusion among the police. The film suggests that the right to exposed nipples is a matter of free speech and equal protection and that breasts should not be demonized when violent images saturate the media.

‰ÛÏFree the Nipple‰Ûù is first and foremost the cinematic equivalent of a billboard. Our surrogate for this crusade is an improbably named journalist, With (Lina Esco, making her first feature as a director). Because the film sees social forces as aligned against public toplessness, With is fired after pitching an article on the issue to her newspaper, which wants more palatable reports. (Is this really 2014?)

Jacki Weaver appears as a truly groan-worthy sexpot, and Rita Moreno as a naggy downstairs neighbor, both underwritten roles. But the sunsets from Lily‰Ûªs condo look magnificent, presumably thanks to Mr. Zsigmond, and that view might make you want to retire right now.

The credits of ‰ÛÏSix Dance Lessons in Six Weeks‰Ûù evoke a lost film from the 1970s, featuring both the John Cassavetes collaborator Gena Rowlands and the storied cinematographer Vilmos Zsigmond. The reality of this new film from Arthur Allan Seidelman is that it‰Ûªs a cornball odd-couple comedy: Prim older woman meets a brassy young gay man. Still, it‰Ûªs extraordinary just watching the peerless Ms. Rowlands wring the most out of the repartee in this adaptation of a play by Richard Alfieri.

In the titular series of lessons, Lily Harrison (Ms. Rowlands) learns tango, fox trot and other life-improving moves from an instructor, Michael Minetti (the energetic Cheyenne Jackson), who makes house calls. She pardons his self-destructive sass; he coaxes her out of self-pitying doldrums. The soppy, instructive story of acceptance feels handed down from another era, though Ms. Rowlands can fire off a one-liner at 20 paces, and she effortlessly conveys oh-my-oh-me adorable.

The French filmmaker Serge Bozon, who has also worked as a critic, received a warm reception for ‰ÛÏLa France‰Ûù (2008), a beguiling musical fairy tale set during World War I. He blends genres less successfully in the peculiar and abrasive ‰ÛÏTip Top,‰Ûù in which two eccentric internal affairs officers investigate the murder of a police informant. The victim had worked as a cop in Algeria before seeking sanctuary in France.

The sleuths make an odd team. Esther (Isabelle Huppert, sending up her trademark severity) is known for her intimidating style; in an interrogation, she fires inquiries at rapid speed, barely giving the subject a chance to speak. The mousy Sally (Sandrine Kiberlain), who has been demoted for ‰ÛÏincompatibility with police ethics,‰Ûù is secretly a peeping tom.

The humor of this situation ‰ÛÓ or of any of the movie‰Ûªs strained wackiness ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt particularly translate. It also does little to illuminate the more serious commentary on immigration, the legacy of colonialism and the tensions within the country‰Ûªs Algerian communities.

At one point, she listens in on Esther‰Ûªs pugilistic love life with her husband, GÌ©rald (Samy Naceri), who, like Sally‰Ûªs romantic partner, is of Arab descent. What Esther and GÌ©rald do to each other might be called rough sex, but it looks more like a consensual back-alley brawl. In a running joke, Esther spends the film‰Ûªs last third tasting the blood dripping off a resulting cut on her nose.

Every movie set in Los Angeles is also about all the many films made in it. In that sprawling back lot, illusions about men, women, God and country are manufactured, which are often harshly at odds with the city‰Ûªs off-screen reality. Mr. Anderson nods to the complex relationship between those real-life and representational histories, folding in march-of-time moments alongside evocations of Robert Altman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Long Goodbye.‰Ûù The one place where Mr. Anderson‰Ûªs film slips is in a strip scene that‰Ûªs straight from the book and is at once bleak ‰ÛÓ the woman disrobing confesses to selling herself out ‰ÛÓ and a fantasy of female erotic power. It‰Ûªs a beautifully staged and played interlude, but also the one time when Mr. Anderson is himself seduced by an illusion. It harshed my mellow.

Labyrinthine in the extreme, the story opens with a slinky number, Shasta Fay Hepworth (Katherine Waterston), sliding into Doc‰Ûªs beach shack, all Ali MacGraw hair and come-hither murmurings. Like the wild young thing in Raymond Chandler‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Big Sleep,‰Ûù the one who calls Marlowe cute, Shasta has been hanging around with the usual shady characters. One, Mickey Wolfmann (Eric Roberts), a real-estate developer and serial philanderer, has mysteriously gone missing. Shasta thinks this could be bad news (Wolfmann has a wife, and she has a lover) and asks Doc to find out what happened, a request that sends him down assorted narrative byways, tangled freeways and bottomless rabbit holes, sometimes in an abused Dodge Dart.

Like Wolfmann and Fenway, the L.A.P.D. belong to another story about Los Angeles, one that didn‰Ûªt need Charles Manson for a villain. It‰Ûªs a story that‰Ûªs been told in narratives about Chavez Ravine, a largely Mexican-American neighborhood demolished by the city that became the home of Dodger Stadium, and in films like Charles Burnett‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKiller of Sheep,‰Ûù a masterpiece about a black family in 1970s South-Central. At one point, Doc drives down to South-Central (now called South Los Angeles) and, with the camera riding alongside him, looks out at some black children racing alongside his car, an image that echoes one in Mr. Burnett‰Ûªs film. Soon after, Doc seems to be hallucinating a line of men ‰ÛÓ like Indians in a western ‰ÛÓ running through the flatlands like ghosts.

Doc‰Ûªs search for Wolfmann takes him across Los Angeles and its environs, as well as in and out of homes, offices and states of being. He‰Ûªs nudged in one direction by an ex-con, Tariq Khalil (Michael Kenneth Williams), and steered in another by an ex-heroin addict, Hope Harlingen (Jena Malone). She introduces a second missing man, her husband, Coy (Owen Wilson), former needle user and saxophonist turned snitch who works for anti-subversive concerns, including some Republican activists and Nixon boosters called Vigilant California. The two missing men aren‰Ûªt missing for long and mostly function as doppelgÌ_ngers ‰ÛÓ one rich and master of his universe, the other poor and apparent slave of his ‰ÛÓ who, with another matched set, help establish the dialectical lay of this contested land.

Mr. Anderson, a Los Angeles son and its reigning cinema laureate, knows California‰Ûªs plagues and pleasures well. His films are filled with its light and malevolent forces, its faith healers and dream peddlers. Bodies writhe like Cecil B. DeMille extras in ‰ÛÏBoogie Nights,‰Ûù in which a pornutopia is found and lost, while a prophet rises in ‰ÛÏMagnolia‰Ûù with a Kubrickian flourish. In ‰ÛÏThere Will Be Blood,‰Ûù an oil speculator who sounds like John Huston (it‰Ûªs Chinatown, Jake) gushes crude and blood; in ‰ÛÏThe Master,‰Ûù a religion is born on the bodies of broken men. (Psst, it‰Ûªs Scientology.) Like some filmic equivalent of Kevin Starr, the pre-eminent historian of California, Mr. Anderson tells the state‰Ûªs story with big-picture sweep, intellectual cool and unforced sympathy.

In Paul Thomas Anderson‰Ûªs cinematic love-in ‰ÛÏInherent Vice,‰Ûù Joaquin Phoenix plays Doc Sportello, a Los Angeles shamus in Jesus sandals trucking through the sunshine and noir like a stoner Philip Marlowe. Based on the 2009 Thomas Pynchon novel, the film is set in 1970, the year after Charles Manson freaked the city out and its good vibrations faded into an endless summer bummer. That‰Ûªs the gospel according to Joan Didion, at any rate, who in ‰ÛÏThe White Album‰Ûù writes that many people she knew believed the 1960s ended Aug. 9, 1969, the day the Manson Family began its Helter Skelter frenzy. Somehow Doc, a hippie crowned in a halo of pot smoke, never got the message.

The L.A.P.D. is the stomping (and beating) ground of a lieutenant detective, Bigfoot Bjornsen (a terrific Josh Brolin), Doc‰Ûªs tormentor and secret sharer who, with him, completes the story‰Ûªs other set of doppelgÌ_ngers. A thick coil of muscle almost bursting Bluto-like from his overly snug undertaker suits, Bigfoot wears a flattop so sharply planed it looks like a slice of his head was left on the barbershop floor. He‰Ûªs a cartoonish villain, but a serious threat as well as a figure of sneaky pathos. Much like Kevin Spacey‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏL.A. Confidential,‰Ûù Bigfoot earns extra cash working in the entertainment industry and pops up on Doc‰Ûªs television both in a real-estate commercial and as an extra in ‰ÛÏAdam-12,‰Ûù the show that, with ‰ÛÏDragnet,‰Ûù helped whitewash the Police Department‰Ûªs reputation.
‰ÛÏInherent Vice‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence.

Doc drifts through this territory and past its weird and menacing claim holders with a doper‰Ûªs what-me-worry smile, his jaw slacking with bafflement or wonderment, sometimes both. With his head of laid-back angel curls and Neil Young mutton chops ‰ÛÓ the excellent playlist includes several of Mr. Young‰Ûªs songs ‰ÛÓ Doc comes across as a counterculture holdout, the last of the pre-Manson hippies. He takes an occasional deep snort (he generally goes with the flow), but his drug of choice is pot. That helps distinguish him from the speed freaks and pill poppers, but his hippy M.O. (beach shack, Army jacket, dirty feet, marijuana haze) also sets him apart from the straight world, from Wolfmann, Fenway and the guardians of their galaxy, the Los Angeles Police Department.

That land ‰ÛÓ thirsty and beautiful, with its listing palm trees and choking smog ‰ÛÓ is the brass ring in this classic California tale of land grabbers like Wolfmann and power mongers like Crocker Fenway (Martin Donovan). Fenway has his own problems, including a missing stash and an errant daughter, Japonica (Sasha Pieterse), who‰Ûªs mixed up with a corrupt dentist, Rudy Blatnoyd (Martin Short, delivering a comic master class in clammy desperation). Fenway appears late in the proceedings, his pale face rising vampirelike from the murk. There‰Ûªs a touch of Brando‰Ûªs Godfather to his entrance, too, except that the old-money Fenway is scarier than any new-immigrant threat. ‰ÛÏPeople like you,‰Ûù Fenway sneers to Doc, ‰ÛÏlose all claim to respect the first time they pay anybody rent.‰Ûù

He‰Ûªs a good fit, in other words, for the site-specific ‰ÛÏInherent Vice,‰Ûù Mr. Pynchon‰Ûªs third novel set in California. Mr. Anderson has condensed the book with surgical precision, ditching certain subplots, characters and locales while retaining the novel‰Ûªs sociopolitical tug, barbed asides and chokingly funny details. In a nice genre twist, he has also added a female narrator, Joanna Newsom as SortilÌ¬ge, who helps offset all the peekaboo miniskirts. Mr. Phoenix‰Ûªs note-perfect performance flows on the story‰Ûªs currents of comedy that occasionally turn into rapids, as the funny ha-ha, funny strange back-and-forth abruptly gives way to Three Stooges slapstick: a bonk on the head, a kick in the rear, a fired gun, a busted-down door. Mr. Anderson‰Ûªs softly lighted close-ups of Doc‰Ûªs face dovetail beautifully with Mr. Phoenix‰Ûªs astonishing gift for heart-heavy vulnerability.
