Showing us the world ‰ÛÓ or at least a swath of old Los Angeles ‰ÛÓ through the eyes of his own children, Lana and Nico, the director Alexandre Rockwell turns ‰ÛÏLittle Feet‰Ûù into a whimsical exploration of loss transformed by magical thinking.

Accompanied by a husky neighborhood kid and perfectly judged musical choices, the siblings set off to find some water and, perhaps, a new mate for their pet. Their picaresque journey, photographed in shimmering black and white by Mr. Rockwell and David Walter Lech, transforms innocence into a cloak against the random dangers of the adult world. So eloquently does Mr. Rockwell evoke the joy of adventure and the solace of imagination that his film would work in virtual silence; the enchantment of the siblings‰Ûª worldview pervades every frame.

Rising above a minuscule budget with ladles of charm and a tender poignancy, ‰ÛÏLittle Feet‰Ûù is a quixotic poem to youthful resourcefulness. Dead and absent parents haunt the movie‰Ûªs margins, but they don‰Ûªt weigh it down; as Nico knows, his mother‰Ûªs spirit is as likely to be found in the flight of a feather as at the bottom of a fishbowl.

Forced to assume responsibilities beyond her seven years, Lana cares for her 4-year-old brother, Nico, and her recently widowed father (Mr. Rockwell), who disappears most nights into a drunken stupor. So when one of the children‰Ûªs two pet fish dies, they process its passing, like that of their mother, without adult mediation; what matters to Lana and Nico is the happiness of its surviving partner.

There are perennial drawbacks to this aestheticized vÌ©ritÌ© approach to capturing history. The speakers aren‰Ûªt formally identified. The songs, which include the Ukrainian national anthem, are heard with mantra-like repetition. Context is missing: At least one of the flags belongs to the Svoboda party, which is mentioned briefly, although the group‰Ûªs history ‰ÛÓ and what critics call its association with neo-Nazi elements ‰ÛÓ is not.

Often, what‰Ûªs said over loudspeakers can be heard only in the background of the primary action; sometimes we see protesters milling about. It‰Ûªs a film of crowds rather than individuals. The masses shown in the opening shot ‰ÛÓ a composition repeated with variations throughout the film ‰ÛÓ are anonymous, extending beyond the edges of the frame.

‰ÛÏMaidan,‰Ûù filmed in and around Independence Square in Kiev during the protests of late 2013 and early 2014, is interested in the physical movement of a movement. This documentary from Sergei Loznitsa, perhaps best known in the United States for the fiction feature ‰ÛÏMy Joy,‰Ûù forgoes explanations. It unfolds almost exclusively in static tableau shots, as concerned with form and beauty as it is with advocacy.

But the point may be that all ideologies have dissolved into a collective, a notion that grows poignant once the government passes restrictions, and a crackdown begins. Suddenly, the fireworks rise above actual fires. There are riot shields, Molotov cocktails and cries for medical help. Camera phones illuminate a vigil. ‰ÛÏMaidan‰Ûù is a film of scale and immediacy, finding artistry, for better or worse, in bearing witness.

This could be rich, if bleak, territory to excavate, but the film, adapted from a novella by Edmond Stevens, doesn‰Ûªt drill down. No role is sketched out beyond brush strokes, and no relationship is meaningfully examined. Casey, a mediocre hockey goalie at the start of the movie, is a better one by the end, but that‰Ûªs about it for character development.
‰ÛÏSkating to New York‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), for hockey violence and tart language. Those Canadians.

In all, something of a squandered opportunity. At least Charles Minsky, a cinematographer (‰ÛÏYou, Me and Dupree,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏNew Year‰Ûªs Eve‰Ûù) directing his first feature, knows his visuals: This movie is distinguished by its long, beautiful shots of the lads on the numbing, trailless expanse, dots marking a vast blank slate.

In ‰ÛÏSkating to New York,‰Ûù four Canadian high school friends and a kid brother spend one of the coldest days of the year trying to skate roughly 25 miles across Lake Ontario, frozen over for the first time in decades. Hoping to become local legends, they meet ice fishermen and smugglers, battle the elements and hypothermia. But it‰Ûªs what they‰Ûªre leaving behind ‰ÛÓ and what they‰Ûªll return to ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs the real story.

For Casey (Connor Jessup), it‰Ûªs parents who are divorced and preoccupied with their own unhappy options; for Rudy (Wesley Morgan), it‰Ûªs a father who is quick to rage and to hit. Living in a working-class town on the edge of the great white open, the teenagers feel a suffocating sense of limits.

Unfolding over eight years, this latest mystery from Atom Egoyan returns us to the snowy setting, secretive characters, looping timeline and endangered-child plot of his 1997 masterpiece, ‰ÛÏThe Sweet Hereafter.‰Ûù This time, however, the infuriatingly vague and downright strange story banishes the haunting delicacy of mood that Mr. Egoyan has conjured so successfully in the past. The girl‰Ûªs abduction is straightforward enough ‰ÛÓ plucked from the truck where her father, Matthew (Ryan Reynolds), has left her while he runs an errand ‰ÛÓ but almost everything after verges on absurd.
‰ÛÏThe Captive‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Not a single unsavory moment, unless you count the bad guy‰Ûªs opera singing.

Filmed in Northern Ontario and Niagara Falls, N.Y., ‰ÛÏThe Captive‰Ûù seems tailor-made to explore the psychological damage that a child can suffer over a lengthy confinement, but instead leans too heavily on the chilly desolation of Paul Sarossy‰Ûªs cinematography. What‰Ûªs going on in the victim‰Ûªs mind, or anyone else‰Ûªs, is as invisible as what lies beneath the snow.

Almost everything in ‰ÛÏThe Captive‰Ûù looks pale and exhausted, not just the flat interiors and the wan women at its center. Even the film‰Ûªs villain ‰ÛÓ a grinning, Mozart-loving skeeve who, when a young girl goes missing, should be the prime suspect on appearance alone ‰ÛÓ moves as if his aberrant behavior were more trouble than it‰Ûªs worth.

There‰Ûªs the cartoonish kidnapper, surveilling his victim‰Ûªs mother (Mireille Enos) in the hotel where she works as a maid and tormenting her with planted tokens from her daughter. There‰Ûªs the twitchy detective (Scott Speedman) whose instant animus toward Matthew is never explained. And then there‰Ûªs the captive, who has evolved over the years into a compliant accomplice to her abductor‰Ûªs perversions.

Excerpts from the poems are murmured in voice-over throughout, and some of the vignettes have a nod-along agreeability, especially those starring Henry Hopper as a young Mr. Williams. The film is too sincere an expression of admiration for this poet‰Ûªs work to feel pretentious, but it‰Ûªs like a music video for the poems, often literal in its biographical readings.

‰ÛÏThe Color of Time‰Ûù was originally titled ‰ÛÏTar,‰Ûù after Mr. Williams‰Ûªs 1983 collection. Arriving in theaters mere weeks before ‰ÛÏThe Interview,‰Ûù Mr. Franco‰Ûªs comedy with Seth Rogen, it is another curious example of Mr. Franco‰Ûªs throwing his clout behind a worthy literary source.
‰ÛÏThe Color of Time‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexuality, drug use and strong language.

As a filmmaker, James Franco seems drawn to literature that poses steep challenges to adaptation, and this latest production, based on the poetry of C. K. Williams, is no exception. Episodic and diffuse, ‰ÛÏThe Color of Time‰Ûù conjures moments of Mr. Williams‰Ûªs life from his writing and comes from a 12-person team of writer-directors who were students of Mr. Franco‰Ûªs at New York University.

This lucky cohort has assembled soft-focus autumnal scenes from Mr. Williams‰Ûªs life, spanning idealized childhood, youthful hedonism and married life with a child and an artist‰Ûªs burden. Mr. Franco plays the elder Mr. Williams, opposite Mila Kunis as his wife; Jessica Chastain, channeling her role in ‰ÛÏThe Tree of Life,‰Ûù plays his mother in the early years; Zach Braff turns up, too, somewhat bafflingly.

Theo‰Ûªs exchanges with Vincent seem too much like a debate in an architecture class, though they certainly make you feel bad for architects, whose misguided creations live for decades or centuries, whereas a boring play or song or novel is simply forgotten. The whole film has an amorphous quality, but maybe that‰Ûªs appropriate; any personal stocktaking late in life is a hazy mixture of real events, misremembered experiences and regret.

It‰Ûªs 1993, and Theo (Hannu-Pekka Bjorkman), an architect, is awash in regret over some ugly buildings that he and his business partner, Vincent (Ville Virtanen), imposed on what had been a pleasant neighborhood in the 1970s. What makes you wonder about Theo‰Ûªs stability is that his late-life self-critique takes the form of a letter to a woman he met only once, when both were young children; now he is designing a dream house where he hopes they will live together.

Not many movies can say they feel alternately like the romantic fantasy of a possibly deluded older man and a discourse on bad architecture, but that describes ‰ÛÏTheo‰Ûªs House,‰Ûù an odd film from the Finnish director Rax Rinnekangas.

The movie‰Ûªs longest segment belongs to the Bahraini sisters Maryam and Zainab al-Khawaja, daughters of a prominent human-rights activist, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja. They spent their formative years in Denmark, where their father went into exile after criticizing the monarchy. He moved back to Bahrain after receiving word of a brewing popular rebellion.

In Syria, Ghassan Yassin and his close friend Motaz Murad join a fledgling nonviolent protest movement against President Bashar al-Assad and are crushed in a military crackdown so severe that what began as a Middle Eastern experiment in flower power morphs into full-scale war. The scenes of slaughter in the streets and of neighborhoods reduced to rubble are undeniably gripping.

The government responded forcefully, and Abdulhadi was arrested, tortured and sentenced to life in prison. Instead of retreating, Zainab endures repeated arrests, while Maryam travels the globe trying to muster support. But because of the strategic military importance of Bahrain to the United States, her pleas are largely ignored by Western diplomats.

‰ÛÏWe Are the Giant‰Ûù builds up quite a rhetorical head of steam, but it doesn‰Ûªt try to analyze the conflicts it observes or to fill in the history, except in the broadest sense of placing these uprisings on a list of rebellions that stretch back through millenniums. ‰ÛÏWe Are the Giant‰Ûù is the movie equivalent of a flashy historical exhibition in which the only text accompanying the gripping photographic collection consists of captions.

In the opening chapter we meet Osama Bensadik, a Libyan businessman and immigrant to the United States, and his American-born son Muhannad. When Muhannad travels to Libya to join the rebellion against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his father follows him. Muhannad, who is killed in the struggle, is sadly remembered as a proud, fearless freedom fighter. And that‰Ûªs that; it‰Ûªs on to the next.

‰ÛÏThe revolution is not an apple that falls when it is ripe. You have to make it fall.‰Ûù That Che Guevara quotation leads off ‰ÛÏWe Are the Giant,‰Ûù Greg Barker‰Ûªs sketchy but spirited documentary polemic about the Arab Spring movement that tries to shake the tree. Che‰Ûªs words define the attitude of this exhortatory film, which encourages viewers to stand up against tyranny using the nonviolent tactics of Gandhi, Nelson Mandela and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It suggests that in the case of the Arab Spring movement, especially in Syria, peaceful protest is not necessarily a good idea.

Seven charismatic activists agitating for change in three countries ‰ÛÓ Libya, Syria and Bahrain ‰ÛÓ are profiled, but the movie‰Ûªs breezy tone makes them sound like cheerleaders at a pep rally. None have enough time to express an idea in language much deeper than sloganeering.

‰ÛÏThe Salt of the Earth,‰Ûù Wim Wenders‰Ûªs new documentary about the life and work of the Brazilian photographer SebastiÌ£o Salgado, elegantly inhabits a moral and aesthetic paradox. Mr. Salgado‰Ûªs photographs illuminate some of the worst horrors of the modern world: starvation, war, poverty, displacement. They are also beautiful, dramatic visual artifacts, and their power has a double effect. We are drawn into the contemplation of terrible realities, but at the same time our attention turns to the person bearing witness.

Leaving her and the young Juliano for months at a time, Mr. Salgado set out to document unexplored aspects of human life, often focusing on remote areas and vulnerable or exploited people. ‰ÛÏThe Salt of the Earth‰Ûù begins with the contemplation of pictures taken in and around an enormous, open gold mine, a crowded, infernal place in which Mr. Salgado‰Ûªs camera discovers humanity in its raw, desperate essence.

The elder Mr. Salgado, for his part, occupies the screen with quiet charisma. Speaking in French and Portuguese ‰ÛÓ he left Brazil during the military dictatorship and lived for many years in Paris ‰ÛÓ he modestly tells the story of an adventurous life. Raised in a rural part of central Brazil, he was trained as an economist before turning to photography, a career change he undertook with the support of his wife, Lelia, a frustratingly peripheral figure in the film until its final section.

Those images were part of ‰ÛÏWorkers: Archaeology of the Industrial Age,‰Ûù a collection published in 1993. Subsequent projects included ‰ÛÏMigrations‰Ûù (2000) and ‰ÛÏSahel: The End of the Road‰Ûù (2004), whose images of famine and war in Africa are made more wrenching by the photographer‰Ûªs calm, heartbroken narration of the circumstances in which they were taken.

To observe and capture on film the death of another person is a disturbing experience, and also an ethically complicated act. Susan Sontag‰Ûªs 2003 book ‰ÛÏRegarding the Pain of Others‰Ûù explores the ways that photographs of atrocities can both awaken and dull the conscience, creating a sense of immediacy that is also, inevitably, a measure of the distance between the sufferer and the observer. ‰ÛÏThe Salt of the Earth,‰Ûù a document of Mr. Wenders‰Ûªs admiration for his subject, largely avoids such complications: a perfectly defensible choice but also something of a lost opportunity. ‰ÛÏThe Salt of the Earth‰Ûù leaves no doubt about Mr. Salgado‰Ûªs talent or decency, and the chance to spend time in his company is a reason for gratitude. And yet his pictures, precisely because they disclose harsh and unwelcome truths, deserve a harder, more robustly critical look.

That is not a fault, either in Mr. Salgado‰Ûªs lifelong project or in Mr. Wenders‰Ûªs consideration of it. It‰Ûªs just a fact of their common vocation. The filmmaker brings his mellow humanism and globe-trotting curiosity into an appreciative, easygoing dialogue with the photographer‰Ûªs single-minded vision. They are a well-matched pair. Though Mr. Wenders does not appear on camera, he is present as a narrator and a sensibility, recounting his early meetings with Mr. Salgado and his collaboration with the photographer‰Ûªs son Juliano, who is the co-director of ‰ÛÏThe Salt of the Earth.‰Ûù

In a more romantic movie, Pomme‰Ûªs adventures would give her a wider perspective on her marriage. But this small, hardheaded film refuses to allow its characters much relief from unhappiness. Even when the ice melts, the Champagne has lost its effervescence.

The film‰Ûªs second half focuses on Pomme‰Ûªs woodland adventures. She doesn‰Ûªt seem to mind when her cellphone runs out of battery power as she is trying to call Romain. She has brushes with a park ranger, with rabbits and a deer, and one night sleeps on a pile of logs, using her backpack as a pillow. She comes upon a road that leads to a town in which a chamber music festival is taking place and spends the night in a hotel, but she doesn‰Ûªt recharge her phone, returning to the forest with a stolen blanket.

Symbolic of their fraught relationship is a moment when they chill a split of warm Champagne by turning the refrigerator setting to ‰ÛÏsuper frost.‰Ûù In a matter of seconds, you hear the bottle cracking. The Champagne has turned into crusty pieces of ice that they rub together in a desultory toast.

Living in a cramped apartment in Lyons, Pomme (Ms. Devos) and Pierre (Mr. Amalric), both in their 40s, are uncomfortably aware of each other‰Ûªs faults and find it next to impossible to stay out of each other‰Ûªs way. They have evolved a style of passive-aggressive communication that never explodes into full-scale rage. The relationship is a pressure cooker: Its little bursts of steam allow them to continue cohabiting without serious bloodshed.

‰ÛÏIf You Don‰Ûªt, I Will‰Ûù is a dour, acutely observed comedy about marital boredom that doesn‰Ûªt glamorize or overdramatize the characters‰Ûª angst. Its lived-in performances evoke an excruciating stalemate that can be ended only by a radical break. But can a weeklong vacation from each other refresh a marriage that has been going sour for years?

There is a turning point in many marriages, after the passion has cooled, when tiny irritants that once were tolerated threaten to turn into toxic infections. In Sophie FilliÌ¬res‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏIf You Don‰Ûªt, I Will,‰Ûù the French stars Emmanuelle Devos and Mathieu Amalric portray such a couple with a subtlety and depth that let you glimpse their rich shared history, as well as their dismal present.

Mr. Amalric‰Ûªs anxious, wide-eyed gaze conveys a lurking sense of alarm, while Ms. Devos‰Ûªs heavy-lidded eyes and drooping mouth suggest a sensual woman with submerged layers of disappointment and despair. When she pressures Pierre to dance with her at a party, he glares at her, throws up his hands and refuses.

In one sign of trouble, Pierre‰Ûªs unconscious desire to escape his wife prompts him to board a bus without checking to see if she is right behind him, and she is nearly left at the curb. Pomme, who suspects that Pierre may be having an affair with a younger TV weather reporter, remarks, ‰ÛÏYou don‰Ûªt love me anymore,‰Ûù in a tone so offhand that he doesn‰Ûªt bother to respond.

Pomme, who is recovering from surgery for a benign brain tumor, makes the first move. The two enjoy hiking in the woods, and on one of their forays into the wild, she impetuously decides to venture off on her own, leaving Pierre looking aghast as she disappears. As the days pass, and she doesn‰Ûªt return, Pierre does nothing until their college-age son, Romain (Nelson Delapalme), suggests that Pierre should deal with a situation that he believes is serious. Although Pierre returns to the woods and begins searching for Pomme, you wonder if he is just going through the motions.

The funniest and most extreme of several caricatures, Debbie (Anna Camp) is a Christian whose predatory behavior alternates with bouts of anguished guilt in which she blames Otto for making her sin. Otto reaches a crossroads when he meets an old girlfriend at a summer camp reunion, and their mutual attraction is deepened by nostalgia for the old days.

In ‰ÛÏGoodbye to All That,‰Ûù Otto Wall (Paul Schneider), a web designer and happy-go-lucky family man in suburban North Carolina, is caught off guard when his wife, Annie (Melanie Lynskey), summons him to her therapist‰Ûªs office. While Annie wipes away tears, the therapist (Celia Weston) brusquely informs him that his 11-year marriage is over.

Like ‰ÛÏJunebug,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGoodbye to All That‰Ûù paints an idyllic vision of the North Carolina landscape of leafy woods and winding roads. The movie isn‰Ûªt as morose as ‰ÛÏJunebug,‰Ûù whose portrait of an unhappy family was steeped in melancholy and a Chekhovian sense of solitude. Here the sadness is balanced by a wry, satirical view of marriage, dating and the social media at a time when romantic fulfillment is supposedly easier to achieve. But is it?

Otto, tall, lean and good-looking in a nerdy way, is devoted to his 9-year-old daughter, Edie (Audrey Scott), and until he is sidelined by a serious foot injury, his world revolves around running, parenting and working. The worst that could be said of Otto is that he is amiably self-centered and complacent. As Annie explains to Edie, who asks why he has so many accidents, ‰ÛÏHe doesn‰Ûªt pay attention.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏGoodbye to All That‰Ûù is very evenhanded in assessing its characters‰Ûª flaws, and it never sentimentalizes. Even after his wife‰Ûªs ambush, Otto is oblivious to Edie‰Ûªs discomfort with her father‰Ûªs escapades.

This poker-faced comedy, the directorial debut of Angus MacLachlan, who wrote the screenplay for the 2005 film ‰ÛÏJunebug,‰Ûù reverses the usual roles in a story that typically focuses on a wife blindsided by her husband‰Ûªs infidelity. So stunned that he is left speechless, Otto might as well have been grazed by a sniper‰Ûªs bullet. He later learns through Facebook that Annie has been having a torrid affair. Although the marriage had been sexless for two years, he was contented with the status quo.

Otto moves to a new house, fixes up a room for Edie, and begins to dabble in Internet dating. He quickly discovers a world he hadn‰Ûªt known existed. The women he meets are aggressors who want commitment-free romance with lots of hot sex. Otto is happy to oblige his voracious partners. Even in the heat of passion, he is never less than courtly.

Ms. Lynskey‰Ûªs Annie is a chilling, at times infuriating portrait of a self-righteous woman seething with bottled-up rage that her husband fails to notice. When she and her therapist ambush Otto, you view their attack through his eyes as an unprovoked skirmish. He is either too nice or too dumb to fight back, and he and Annie never try to resolve their differences. When Otto leaves the office, the divorce is a done deal that needs only their signatures on an agreement to share custody of Edie.

There, the headstrong leader Thorin Oakenshield will install himself in hoarding splendor, a slave to ‰ÛÏthat terrible need‰Ûù for treasure. And so on, and so forth. Mr. Jackson returns to the variably hirsute action figures of Middle-earth for the latest, and presumably last, adventure. Gandalf (Ian McKellen) makes his way back to center stage from imprisonment, with Cate Blanchett and Christopher Lee swooping in to lend supporting gravitas. The Elves and the Orcs converge on Erebor, as seemingly everyone ‰ÛÓ though especially Thorin ‰ÛÓ feels the pull of the dragon‰Ûªs riches, which seem to attract all possible conflicting parties to the Lonely Mountain and neighboring Dale in dire preparation for the film‰Ûªs title.

When the Dwarfs, Elves and Orcs ‰ÛÓ those dumpy, evil forces that appear constantly to need the direction from their rabble-rousing leaders to go forth and ‰ÛÏslay them all‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ finally engage, Mr. Jackson‰Ûªs massed set pieces shift between stirring visual salvos and general panoramic swarming. It‰Ûªs only as individual good guys peel off for death-defying face-offs with Orcs on ledges that the routine violence crackles again with genuine danger and deft showmanship.

Part of the problem with Mr. Jackson‰Ûªs accordion-expanded ‰ÛÏHobbit‰Ûù is just that gravitational pull: At the film‰Ûªs core is not really the engaging Mr. Freeman as Bilbo, ever twitchingly alive, as you might expect. Instead, the story insists upon the hoary sentiment of filthy lucre‰Ûªs overriding all reason and friendship, like an opera without song. Erebor is an imposing castlelike (or cathedral-like) stronghold, containing Thorin like a crazed Macbeth in the labyrinth of his desire, but outside, the gathering of armies feels like a hurry-up-and-wait stage setting by another cast of computer-generated thousands.
‰ÛÏThe Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Extended sequences of intense fantasy action violence, per the title.

What this adaptation of ‰ÛÏThe Hobbit‰Ûù can‰Ûªt avoid by its final installment is its predictability and hollow foundations. It‰Ûªs been said before, but Mr. Jackson himself is still haunted by the past: For all the craft, there‰Ûªs nothing here like the unity and force of ‰ÛÏThe Lord of the Rings,‰Ûù which is positively steeped in mythology and features (wonder of wonders) rounder characterization than the scheduled revelations on display here. At times Mr. Jackson expects too much audience investment, whether in a perfunctory forbidden love between the elf Tauriel (Evangeline Lilly) and the dwarf Kili (Aidan Turner), or in the weak comic relief of a grabby Lake-town deputy who illustrates further venality.

‰ÛÏThe Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies‰Ûù follows hot on the heels of last year‰Ûªs film, with the dragon Smaug giving Lake-town its promised end by fiery devastation. It‰Ûªs a rip-roaring opening spectacle of burning buildings and refugee villagers, with Smaug (voiced by Benedict Cumberbatch with baroque cruelty) thundering over streets like a runaway bomber, until he is felled by Bard the bargeman. Bilbo (Martin Freeman) watches from a distance beside the dwarfs he traveled with to Erebor.

It‰Ûªs especially a shame since Mr. Jackson‰Ûªs original knack for world building (not to mention the sense of humor in his early films) is often missing in the ever-proliferating superhero-franchise worlds that his own vastly successful endeavors no doubt helped encourage. Bilbo may fully learn a sense of friendship and duty, and have quite a story to tell, but somewhere along the way, Mr. Jackson loses much of the magic.

‰ÛÏYou are only quite a little fellow in a wide world, after all,‰Ûù Gandalf reminds his companion at the end of ‰ÛÏThe Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies.‰Ûù The avuncular line has a cozy feel that evokes the bedtime-storytelling of J. R. R. Tolkien‰Ûªs 1937 children‰Ûªs classic ‰ÛÓ now better known as the trilogized prequel to a 21st-century fantasy phenomenon. Gandalf‰Ûªs sentiment is also all too apt for Peter Jackson‰Ûªs vexing conclusion to his oddly apportioned adaptation: Bilbo Baggins is indeed quite a little fellow in Mr. Jackson‰Ûªs wide world here ‰ÛÓ less a central hero on a quest than a supporting player in a film bookended by destruction and war in gray, grim lands.

Employing bursts of Bach and English-language narration, this lulling, informative documentary never fully grapples with its topic‰Ûªs complexity. (No one interviewed speaks disapprovingly of the building‰Ûªs completion.) The movie is ideally viewed while waiting in line to see the church.

Visitors to Barcelona could do worse than watch ‰ÛÏSagrada: The Mystery of Creation,‰Ûù a documentary primer on the Temple Expiatori de la Sagrada FamÌ_lia. The Catalan architect Antoni GaudÌ_ labored over the church for most of his life but never completed it. He died in 1926 after being hit by a tram.

Still under construction more than 130 years after GaudÌ_ was commissioned, the church is a popular destination for tourists, yet it is mired in controversy. Critics have said that continued work on the building distances it from GaudÌ_'s original vision. The question of how to proceed has been confounded over the years by war, lack of money, the destruction of GaudÌ_'s models and Barcelona‰Ûªs urban development.

‰ÛÏGaudÌ_ didn‰Ûªt see it finished and I won‰Ûªt, either,‰Ûù says Jordi Bonet, identified in the film as the church‰Ûªs chief architect (though now emeritus). Others interviewed include Etsuro Sotoo, a Japanese sculptor who converted to Roman Catholicism, which he suggests was a way of getting closer to GaudÌ_'s ideas. The artist Josep Maria Subirachs designed a facade in a style that departs markedly from GaudÌ_'s. The architect David Mackay, who died last month, says that the collaborative nature of the project means that the church should be regarded as ‰ÛÏan after-GaudÌ_.‰Ûù

This routine documentary therefore doubly serves its participants: Illy gets good associations, but Asomobi also becomes better known. Tasty coffee and female entrepreneurship against all odds (in this case, a fire in the tourist bunks, and machismo in the culture) are admittedly part of a different world from Standard Oil‰Ûªs. But there‰Ûªs not a great deal to recommend the documentary as a film, anyway (less than there is, for example, in Patagonia‰Ûªs flawed ‰ÛÏDamNation‰Ûù).

Lesley Chilcott‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏA Small Section of the World‰Ûù follows in the swampy footsteps of Robert Flaherty, who in 1948 made ‰ÛÏLouisiana Story,‰Ûù the tale of a bayou boy and an oil deal, commissioned by the Standard Oil Company. The Italian coffee company Illy financed Ms. Chilcott‰Ûªs film, a celebration of Asomobi ‰ÛÓ a Costa Rican coffee-making concern, run by women, that largely supplies Illy but makes most of its money off tourism.

It‰Ûªs like a gently distressed company film blown up to feature length. Doughty employees explain how Asomobi began and broke into the industry, with cutaways to production. Someone tears up while recounting the fire; the camera abruptly zooms in to make sure we feel it. A final section is taken up with a young woman from Asomobi jazzed to visit a conference where she is introduced by an Illy executive.

Illy, or someone, dutifully assembled the right pedigree: Ms. Chilcott co-produced ‰ÛÏAn Inconvenient Truth‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏWaiting for Superman.‰Ûù It all concludes ‰ÛÓ you can‰Ûªt make this up ‰ÛÓ with Alanis Morissette in a studio session, fervently singing about coffee growers.

Mr. Foxx is the Daddy Warbucks character, here renamed Will Stacks and refashioned as a cellphone billionaire halfheartedly running for mayor of New York. (The legacy of the city‰Ûªs recently departed billionaire mayor, who increased incentives for local film and television production, is visible in the scenes that were shot on actual New York locations rather than somewhere in Canada.) A self-made entrepreneur, he represents both a bootstrap ethic and a fantasy of endless abundance.

The narrative and emotional architecture of a much loved, frequently revived, maybe-not-quite-as-great-as-you-remember-it show has been reduced to a chaotic shambles. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs the Hard-Knock Life‰Ûù can still lodge itself in your head, and ‰ÛÏTomorrow‰Ûù retains the power to dampen your eyes, but the way these and other numbers are arranged, choreographed and edited undermines their effectiveness. A movie musical is more than a bunch of actors lip-syncing on camera, but ‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù is barely even that. The voices sound thin and flat. The mouths don‰Ûªt move in time with the music. The dancing is a chaotic stew of flailing limbs. Numbers that are supposed to lift you out of the story into a realm of giddy wonder and pure feeling have the opposite effect. You just wish they would end.

In Harold Gray‰Ûªs original ‰ÛÏLittle Orphan Annie‰Ûù comic strip, Warbucks was also an avatar of anti-New Deal conservatism, his charity an alternative to the policies of Franklin D. Roosevelt‰Ûªs New Deal. In the recessionary 1970s, the Broadway musical (adapted for the screen by John Huston in 1982) made room for Roosevelt and ended on a note of harmony between government and private enterprise.

I suppose a family entertainment needs to play it safe and avoid inflaming any public sensitivities. But there is a long list of movies, musical and otherwise, that are both engaging and engaged. The new ‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù is neither. Instead of treated, we‰Ûªve been tricked.
‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A little naughty, a little scary.

When the singing stops, a few slightly more amusing things happen. The high point is a movie-within-the-movie, a blissfully silly sendup of the ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù franchise that provides ‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù with its only moment of genuine inspiration. Otherwise, Mr. Foxx and Ms. Wallis seem to have a nice time together, like people making the best of a long flight by playing a few hands of gin rummy.

This ‰ÛÏAnnie,‰Ûù moving the story out of the ‰Ûª30s and into a smoothed-over version of the economically anxious, politically polarized present, gives Roosevelt a brief shout-out and then flees from any implication of historical or social relevance.

QuvenzhanÌ© Wallis is a born movie star, with charisma to burn and a rare ability to magnetize an audience‰Ûªs attention. She showed as much in ‰ÛÏBeasts of the Southern Wild,‰Ûù filmed when she was just 6. In ‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù she is older and taller, less pixieish and closer to the awkwardness of adolescence, but, if anything, her ability to charm has only increased. Unfortunately, it isn‰Ûªt enough.

Ms. Wallis works hard to bring this reboot to life. So do Jamie Foxx, Rose Byrne, Bobby Cannavale and, especially, Cameron Diaz, who flings herself into the role of Miss Hannigan, Annie‰Ûªs boozy, blowzy meanie of a foster mom, with almost frightening abandon. But the cast would have been better served by a middle school production overseen by a creatively frustrated, inappropriately ambitious drama teacher than by this hacky, borderline-incompetent production, which was directed by Will Gluck from a screenplay by Aline Brosh McKenna.

It‰Ûªs tempting to praise ‰ÛÏLife of an Actress: The Musical,‰Ûù a low-budget showbiz melodrama, for its pluck and old-fashioned aims. The director, Paul Chau, a producer on the Daniel Radcliffe revival of ‰ÛÏHow to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,‰Ûù wrote the script, music and lyrics.

The songs bleed into one another. Despite running more than two hours, the film fails to set up its finale, in which an errant cough escalates into a cancer death with absurd speed. Don‰Ûªt fear for the actors: There‰Ûªs a Screen Actors Guild logo toward the end of the credits.

Charlie (Bart Shatto) runs a New York diner where the three lead characters, all actresses, work or have worked while waiting for their big breaks. The 41-year-old Hannah (Orfeh) fears that she‰Ûªs getting too old to be cast. Sandy (Allison Case), who speaks of ‰ÛÏexospiritual‰Ûù vibes, has no sixth sense when it comes to a predatory agent. Jen (Taylor Louderman) has moved to Los Angeles. On a film set, she yearns for union membership in ‰ÛÏI Wish I Was SAG,‰Ûù an infectious number that nevertheless makes you wish for the subjunctive.

Unfortunately, poor execution prevents the movie from achieving an authentic throwback feel. Although the principal cast members are Broadway veterans, here they struggle with technological and tonal issues. While movie musical numbers are typically not recorded live, the pantomiming in ‰ÛÏLife of an Actress‰Ûù lacks energy and diaphragm. The songs sometimes seem a hair out of sync with the stars.
‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Lust for life.

We not only see that work as it might have looked in its moment. We also, thanks to the exquisite, painterly cinematography of Dick Pope, see the world as Turner saw it. And as we do, an almost alchemical transformation takes place, as our various sensory and cognitive impressions merge into a thrilling and powerful form of understanding. By the end, we may not be able to summarize Turner‰Ûªs life, explain his paintings or pass a midterm on British history. But we may find that our knowledge of all those things has deepened, and the compass by which we measure our own experience has grown wider. Only art can do that, and it may be all that art can do.

At the same time, though, we might be reading a novel, a Victorian triple-decker thick with information about the organizing principles and deep contradictions of a complex civilization. We meet Turner in middle age, already successful and living with his cheerful father (Paul Jesson) and Hannah Danby (Dorothy Atkinson), a housekeeper whose patient, masochistic devotion is a source of occasional comedy and more frequent pathos.

Not here, though. ‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù is a mighty work of critical imagination, a loving, unsentimental portrait of a rare creative soul. But even as it celebrates a glorious painter and illuminates the sources of his pictures with startling clarity and insight, the movie patiently and thoroughly demolishes more than a century‰Ûªs worth of mythology about what art is and how artists work. You may have had the good fortune to study Turner‰Ûªs watercolors and martial tableaus up close, to linger over his storms and placid river scenes, but somehow Mr. Leigh makes it all look newly painted, fresh and strange.

It might be risking Ruskinesque folly to take ‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù as a self-portrait of its director, but Turner shares with Mr. Leigh an ability to travel the circuit between the sublime and the ordinary, to bring into view aspects of reality that had been somehow invisible in plain sight. All of Mr. Leigh‰Ûªs films are personal to the extent that they reflect his sensibility, his politics and his ethical concerns, but his methods ‰ÛÓ characters and stories developed over many months of rehearsal, improvisation and research in collaboration with actors and crew members ‰ÛÓ resist the imposition of a singular authorial vision. He is best known for anatomizing the pervasive indignities and saving graces of modern Britain, with particular attention to the low and middle rungs of the class ladder and the stresses and pleasures of family life. Social life for him is what sea air was to Turner: an atmospheric element that becomes a vehicle of meaning and emotion.

‰ÛÏCynicism has no place in the reviewing of art.‰Ûù Words to live by, for sure, and all the more so for being uttered by John Ruskin, one of the giants of 19th-century British art criticism. But nothing is quite so simple. In ‰ÛÏMr. Turner,‰ÛùMike Leigh‰Ûªs revelatory new film, Ruskin (Joshua McGuire) appears as a pretentious carrot-topped nitwit with a voice like a posh Elmer Fudd. In one scene, he offers up ‰ÛÏcontroversial‰Ûù theories about landscapes and seascapes to a roomful of harrumphing artists. It‰Ûªs all very well, one of them says, to opine and interpret, but unless you have braved the elements with brush in hand, you don‰Ûªt really know what you‰Ûªre talking about.

Turner‰Ûªs public life is no less complicated. He basks in the praise of critics and the envy of colleagues, and suffers when his work falls out of fashion, enduring overheard snark from the young Queen Victoria and mockery in a music hall sketch. He welcomes potential buyers and believes that his work should survive him as the property of the British people.

Turner also has an angry, semi-estranged wife (Ruth Sheen) and two grown daughters (Sandy Foster and Amy Dawson), though when asked if he has children, he replies that he has none. On his visits to Margate, where he keeps amorous company with Sophia Booth (Marion Bailey), a kindhearted widow, he sheds his identity altogether, adopting his lady friend‰Ûªs last name. The tenderness he shows her is missing from most of his relations with women, with the exception of Mary Somerville (Leslie Manville), a Scottish scientist who shares his interest in the properties of light.

Mr. Leigh‰Ûªs twin portraits of important 19th-century cultural figures (Gilbert and Sullivan in ‰ÛÏTopsy-Turvy,‰Ûù and now Turner in ‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù) extend the range of his sympathy and curiosity into a past that is neither the mirror of the present nor wholly alien to the world as we know it. Turner, with his lumbering gait and broad, suety face, dominates the picture, seeming to personify his age and all its contradictions. His speech is a symphony of growls, snorts and flights of guttural eloquence. As he traipses from London to the seaside town of Margate and back, paces in his studio and prowls the galleries of the Royal Academy, we witness an act of creation that seems more sculptural than cinematic, as if Mr. Spall and Mr. Leigh were molding Turner in molten bronze.

Fair enough. Though he and his parents are admirers and collectors of good paintings ‰ÛÓ and steadfast champions of the film‰Ûªs hero, J. M. W. Turner ‰ÛÓ the Ruskin of Mr. Leigh‰Ûªs film is a cruelly etched, cautionary figure, a warning that even those people most passionately devoted to the cause of art are likely to get it wrong. A bit of well-placed cynicism might even be in order.

Turner, played with blunt, brutish, grunting delicacy by Timothy Spall, is both a genius and an ordinary man, with the usual emotions and appetites. His art does not arise from any special torment or trauma, though he has his share of unhappiness. Nor is the unhappiness he inflicts on others ‰ÛÓ women in particular ‰ÛÓ excused as the prerogative of talent. The son of a barber, Turner takes a disciplined, businesslike, artisanal approach to his vocation, and even though he often seems gripped by an almost otherworldly inspiration, he and his art belong very much to the everyday world. With other artists, Turner is convivial, collegial and competitive. He is conscious of his celebrity, protective of his reputation and tireless in his labor.

‰ÛÏNight at the Museum 3: Secret of the Tomb‰Ûù signifies closing time for the franchise in which exhibits come alive, and Ben Stiller has to deal with them. The director, Shawn Levy, and the new writers, David Guion and Michael Handelman, throw together enough gags and one-liners to ensure a diverting and, here and there, rather funny journey for the museum stalwart Larry and his menagerie of Teddy Roosevelt, a miniature Roman general, a Neanderthal, a capuchin monkey and others.
It‰Ûªs a chronically underachieving movie, but relatively amusing in its quaint wish fulfillment.
Rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for the wild rumpus to be expected from a museum coming alive.

Now director of nighttime operations, Larry (Mr. Stiller, near left) must visit a pharaoh (Ben Kingsley!) in the British Museum to learn why Roosevelt and friends went bonkers during a dinner show at the American Museum of Natural History. The problems center on an enchanted Egyptian tablet tied to the animation of the exhibits. The trip introduces new blood to the comedy, chiefly a revived Sir Lancelot (a sharp Dan Stevens, far left) and a gabby British nightwatchwoman (Rebel Wilson), and Larry‰Ûªs travails with his college-averse son yield lessons about independence.

The premise shares something with durable silent-era slapstick yarns, even if the material underserves Mr. Stiller, Ricky Gervais, Steve Coogan and the other comedians. (As Roosevelt, Robin Williams serves more as a benevolent fatherly presence.) But the writers turn out amusing riffs on how historical figures might react to the present, nice bits of business (like a tumble into an Escher painting) and a passable Passover joke.

Those words are recited by Peter Capaldi, the Scottish actor known for ‰ÛÏDoctor Who‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIn the Loop.‰Ûù He is not playing a dramatized version of Leonardo; rather, he soliloquizes this artist and inventor‰Ûªs notes against various shaded backdrops. These sequences are rendered in high relief by mostly unnecessary 3-D.

The effect is varied. Segments on flying machines and human dissection testify to Leonardo‰Ûªs astounding foresight. The movie best evokes its subject‰Ûªs intellectual thirst when visualizing his theories on facial proportionality and noses. It superimposes Leonardo-style schematics over the passengers on a streetcar.

The strange biographical essay documentary ‰ÛÏInside the Mind of Leonardo in 3D‰Ûù has the somewhat intriguing, somewhat preposterous idea of trying to illustrate Leonardo da Vinci‰Ûªs way of viewing the world. Near the outset, it shows us Leonardo‰Ûªs private journals, archived in Milan. According to a title card, the words in the movie ‰ÛÏare from Leonardo‰Ûªs own.‰Ûù

The text used ranges from grand summations (‰ÛÏNothing is more fleeting than the years of a man‰Ûªs life. But this is not true of art.‰Ûù) to trivialities. Some of it, including a shopping list (‰ÛÏMust buy mushrooms. Apples. Bread. Cheese.‰Ûù), is spelled out on screen.

But the film can also be tedious and inadvertently comic, as when Mr. Capaldi munches on grapes while delivering his grandiose oratory. The movie starts by noting Leonardo‰Ûªs intent to leave a memory of himself in the minds of others. That‰Ûªs a benchmark ‰ÛÏInside the Mind of Leonardo‰Ûù won‰Ûªt meet.

After his 2010 success with ‰ÛÏThe Secret of Kells,‰Ûù the Irish animator Tomm Moore once again mines Celtic folklore for ‰ÛÏSong of the Sea,‰Ûù a Pied Piper-like fable about the power of music and the magic in the everyday.

Inspired by the myth of the selkie ‰ÛÓ which, as fans of John Sayles‰Ûªs 1994 jewel, ‰ÛÏThe Secret of Roan Inish,‰Ûù know, is a seal-like creature that can shed its skin and live for a time as a human ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏSong of the Sea‰Ûù moves delicately but purposefully from pain to contentment and from anger to love. On land and underwater, the siblings‰Ûª adventures unfold in hand-drawn, painterly frames of misty pastels, sometimes encircled by cobwebby borders that give them the look of pictures in a locket.
‰ÛÏSong of the Sea‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Nature can make you sad, but it can also make you whole.

At the beginning, though, enchantment is hard to find for young Ben and his little sister, Saoirse, a strange child who has never spoken and whose mother disappeared immediately after her birth. Their father (voiced by Brendan Gleeson), a lonely lighthouse keeper, is loving but withdrawn, reluctantly allowing Granny (Fionnula Flanagan) to take the children to live with her in Dublin. But the city sickens Saoirse, and Ben knows that her life depends on their finding their way back home to the sea.

And if there are a few too many mystical beings to help and hinder (without scaring too much), we can forgive their creator: To Mr. Moore, Ireland is a place where stories can be written on strands of hair, and the sigh of a seashell can call you home.

Much like the lost horseshoe nail that leads to the loss of a kingdom, that small thrown rock instigates a series of spiraling crises that set owner against tenant, man against man, paralyzing convictions against destabilizing doubts. Each action begets an inevitable reaction, sometimes in the form of a raised eyebrow or clenched fist, although more often in long, often barbed, impeccably orchestrated conversations that turn intimates into combatants. These words don‰Ûªt merely jab and sting, they drip drip drip into ears like Iago‰Ûªs pestilence, an association that Mr. Ceylon obviously sought to suggest when he named Aydin‰Ûªs high castle, with its servants and stony fortifications, Hotel Othello. ‰ÛÏDangerous conceits are in their natures poisons,‰Ûù Iago asserts, ones that ‰ÛÏburn like the mines of sulfur.‰Ûù

Written by Mr. Ceylan and his wife, Ebru Ceylan, ‰ÛÏWinter Sleep‰Ûù unfolds over more than three hours in three distinct movements, the first involving Aydin and an impoverished family that lives in one of his properties. Its youngest member, Ilyas (Emirhan Doruktutan), a boy of around 11, throws a rock at Aydin‰Ûªs S.U.V. shortly after the story opens, shattering a window. With his driver, Hidayet (Ayberk Pekcan), Aydin brings the boy back to the family‰Ûªs rundown house, which is nestled into an enormous rocky slab. As he scans the jumble scattered outside the home, a look of disgust spreads across his face, a sentiment that turns into a public article of faith when this nonreligious, privileged man writes an editorial linking godliness with cleanliness.

At the start of ‰ÛÏWinter Sleep,‰Ûù a speck of a man can be seen in long shot, dwarfed by the staggering natural beauty that envelops him like an embrace. He runs a hotel carved into a rock face in Cappadocia, a geological astonishment in central Turkey characterized by jutting spires and curvaceous formations that give the region an anthropomorphic sensuality. He spends much of his time in a gloomily lit home office ‰ÛÓ at times alone in near-monastic quiet, at times with bitingly effusive company ‰ÛÓ writing editorials about a world from which he has largely retreated.

Save for a late scene filled with glowering looks and the sputter of a roaring, shrieking fire, there isn‰Ûªt much that burns in ‰ÛÏWinter Sleep,‰Ûù despite some of its first-rate smolderers, including the boy‰Ûªs father, Ismail (Nejat Isler). He has plenty to get worked up about, as does Aydin‰Ûªs wife, Nihal (Melisa Sozen), a beauty with moist lashes and a Modigliani neck who‰Ûªs nursing a grudge against her husband. In one of the movie‰Ûªs missteps, she makes the case against him with the detail of a forensic psychologist testifying against a criminal defendant. Much like a wild horse that‰Ûªs brought to its knees in one scene, Nihal too often serves as a dispensary of obvious meaning, a disappointment given that Mr. Ceylan is a master of ellipses and the quietly devastating moment.

Mr. Ceylan is at his best here when he obliquely circles Aydin and what ails this terminally isolated man. In one dazzling scene, Aydin and his sister, Necla (Demet Akbag), discuss the editorials he writes, a conversation that builds ‰ÛÓ with icy observations, nonchalant cruelty and Aydin‰Ûªs unsettling, punctuating little laughs ‰ÛÓ into a portrait of mutual hostility and contempt. Again and again Aydin laughs at the wrong time, for the wrong reason. He chuckles when he offers his hand to a contrite tenant and again when his wife weeps. You can hear the arrogance in these small, hollow-sounding snickers and chortles, the titanic ignorance and the irony too. Yet despite Mr. Bilginer‰Ûªs dug-in performance and the haunting grandeur of Aydin‰Ûªs world, this is finally a character too small to see.

Former actor, man of leisure, bourgeois conformist, imperious landlord, bad brother, worse husband ‰ÛÓ that speck, Aydin (Haluk Bilginer), takes on a series of overlapping roles in ‰ÛÏWinter Sleep,‰Ûù which was directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan. In genre terms, the movie can be classed as a character study although it often plays more like one of those spiritual autopsies that directors occasionally perform on their protagonists, gutting them with degrees of gravity, glee and precision and extracting flaws like diseased organs. Mr. Ceylan performs this particular operation with rigorous solemnity, technical virtuosity and precision tools ‰ÛÓ his lapidary visual style rises to the challenge of the natural environment ‰ÛÓ yet there‰Ûªs something missing from the very start, namely the spark of breathed-in life.

Guileless, he appeals to God in all his houses: temples, mosques, churches. Sneaking into a maternity ward, he examines an infant from top to bare bottom, looking for a label: is he Christian, Muslim, Hindu?

After some twists and turns ‰ÛÓ including a quick, PK-less detour to Belgium for a Pakistani Romeo and Indian Juliet love story ‰ÛÓ our hero acquires language (Hindi) and finds himself in Delhi in search of his pendant. God alone, he‰Ûªs told, can help him.

But ‰ÛÏPK‰Ûù lacks the redemptive arc of ‰ÛÏLage Raho‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ at least its hero does. PK, played with earnest sexlessness by Mr. Khan, who possesses one of Hindi cinema‰Ûªs most ogled bodies, is another man-boy innocent meant to remind us of our own corruption. He does, but so benignly, that it‰Ûªs hard to feel the sting.

When PK (Aamir Khan) lands in Rajasthan, naked and gym-buff, his first encounter with an earthling is a rude one. A man steals his flashing green pendant (it matches his flashing green eyes), a remote control that allows him to call his ship for pickup.

Mr. Hirani‰Ûªs other films include ‰ÛÏLage Raho Munna Bhai‰Ûù (2006), a comedy about a gangster who becomes a Gandhi-inspired good guy. That movie and its slogan, ‰ÛÏGandhigiri,‰Ûù were so successful that they ushered in a small real-life wave of Gandhian protests.
And this sweet, ambling comedy about an innocent abroad ‰ÛÓ an alien who touches down in the Rajasthan desert ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt offend, even as it pokes gentle fun at religious differences and hypocrisy.

It‰Ûªs hard to imagine that ‰ÛÏPK,‰Ûù with its slogan ‰ÛÏwrong number‰Ûù (when God‰Ûªs interlocutors get their wires crossed), will have a similar impact. Mr. Hirani remains an excellent storyteller, weaving his disparate story strands into a convincing, satisfying whole ‰ÛÓ a rare Bollywood feat.

No religions were harmed in the making of this film. That‰Ûªs the gist of a title card that runs before the credits in the Hindi movie ‰ÛÏPK,‰Ûù directed by Rajkumar Hirani, which states that the film doesn‰Ûªt intend to hurt the feelings of any community, sect or religion.

After a medical leave during which she was treated for depression, Sandra has returned to work, only to discover that her position is in danger of disappearing. The company has offered her co-workers a choice: If she is laid off, all of them will receive the 1,000 euro ($1,200) bonuses they have long been promised; if they agree to give up the bonuses, she can keep her job.

This is a grim and painful reality ‰ÛÓ not only in Belgium ‰ÛÓ but the Dardennes are too committed to the dignity of their characters to set themselves up as merchants of despair. ‰ÛÏTwo Days, One Night‰Ûù does not paint a pretty picture of the world as it is now. Partly for that reason ‰ÛÓ and partly because of the gravity and grace of its star ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs a beautiful movie.
‰ÛÏTwo Days, One Night‰Ûù is rated PG-13. Hard times, hard feelings.

Work, for Sandra and her fellow citizens of the Dardenne Republic, is an irreplaceable source of meaning, identity and happiness. ‰ÛÏTwo Days, One Night‰Ûù is about the erosion of all of those values, and also about the waning of solidarity in the modern economy. In the past, the quality of life that workers like Sandra and Manu enjoy might have been secured through collective struggle. Now, the film suggests, it is maintained through individual competition among the workers themselves.

Sandra and her husband, Manu (Fabrizio Rongione), live with their two young children in a clean, well-appointed townhouse, a big, hard-won step up from the ‰ÛÏsocial housing‰Ûù where they used to live. The thought of going back is especially galling to Manu, who works in the kitchen of a chain restaurant and who pushes his wife to make her case. Anxious, frequently tearful and quick to reach for a Xanax, Sandra would rather curl up in bed than endure the humiliation of begging for the pity of her peers.

The world of Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne ‰ÛÓ a zone of factories, housing projects and modest suburban developments in and around the industrial Belgian cities of Seraing and LiÌ¬ge ‰ÛÓ is no place for a movie star. The Dardenne brothers, twice winners of the top prize at Cannes, practice an austere and democratic style of realism. Their working-class heroes and heroines make their way in stark circumstances, their ethical dilemmas and material challenges presented without glamour, sentimentality or soundtrack music.

A vote has already been held among the 16 members of Sandra‰Ûªs work team, but her boss agrees to a second ballot. This gives Sandra a weekend ‰ÛÓ two days and one night, as the film‰Ûªs title says ‰ÛÓ to persuade a majority of her colleagues to make a painful sacrifice on her behalf.

That the newest member of this select, unhappy company is played by Marion Cotillard, an Oscar winner and glossy-magazine icon, makes very little difference, apart from the fact that Ms. Cotillard‰Ûªs performance is as fine a piece of screen acting as you will ever see. It would be facile to say that in ‰ÛÏTwo Days, One Night,‰Ûù she disappears into the role of Sandra Bya, a working mother fighting to save her job at a small company that makes solar panels, or that she accomplishes a breathtaking transformation. Her shoulders slumped, her eyes weary, her gait heavy, Ms. Cotillard moves past naturalism into something impossible to doubt and hard to describe. Sandra is an ordinary person in mundane circumstances, but her story, plainly and deliberately told, is suspenseful, sobering and, in the original, fear-of-God sense of the word, tremendous.

‰ÛÏTwo Days, One Night‰Ûù consists almost entirely of encounters between Sandra and the people who have, through no choice of their own, been given the power to decide her fate. The key to the movie ‰ÛÓ what makes it moving as well as grueling, thrilling as well as harsh ‰ÛÓ is that the Dardennes refuse to skip or cut away from a single meeting. Like Sandra, the audience must absorb the emotional impact of each conversation. Most begin politely, but after the initial handshakes and greetings, the reactions to Sandra‰Ûªs pleas vary wildly. There are anger, compassion, evasiveness and shame. A man bursts into tears. A fistfight breaks out. A marriage comes undone. A blunt refusal is followed by an offer of orange juice.

A lot more than money is at stake, but the Dardennes never underestimate the importance of money in the lives of their characters. That 1,000 euros will help pay for school tuition, for home repairs, for children‰Ûªs clothes and mortgages. Nobody is rich or greedy, though some people are perhaps more selfish than others. The leisure of a summer weekend is, mostly, a time for more work: fixing the car, coaching soccer, toiling at a second job, looking after the kids.

Impatience was one of Dr. King‰Ûªs great virtues: His ‰ÛÏLetter From Birmingham Jail‰Ûù was published as a pamphlet with the title ‰ÛÏWhy We Can‰Ûªt Wait.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù takes up his history with its eyes very much on the future, reminding us that the voting-rights victory nearly 50 years ago was not inevitable and is not yet complete. The nonviolent fight against white supremacy required not only righteous vision but also strategic insight and tactical discipline. The ideology that would sanction the beating and killing of black Americans who dared to assert their citizenship has not vanished, though its methods, language and partisan affiliations may have changed since 1965.

‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù is not a manifesto, a battle cry or a history lesson. It‰Ûªs a movie: warm, smart, generous and moving in two senses of the word. It will call forth tears of grief, anger, gratitude and hope. And like those pilgrims on the road to Montgomery, it does not rest.

Under constant surveillance ‰ÛÓ F.B.I. field reports typed onto the screen fill the audience in on his whereabouts ‰ÛÓ Dr. King travels a hectic circuit from pulpit to jail cell to the White House and back. There are many piquant moments of behind-the-scenes political theater in Washington and Montgomery: confrontations and colloquies between Dr. King and President Johnson (Tom Wilkinson); between the president and Gov. George C. Wallace (a gleeful Tim Roth); between Gov. Wallace and Al Lingo (Stephen Root), who led Alabama‰Ûªs public safety department. But while ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù acknowledges the importance of men in power, its heart is with the activists on the ground in Selma.

Instead, Ms. DuVernay, working from a screenplay credited to Paul Webb, has stripped away layers of fond memory and retroactively imposed harmony to touch the raw, volatile political reality of the mid-1960s ‰ÛÓ the courage and the cravenness, the idealism and the calculation, the visible and invisible divisions and rivalries. Dr. King, played by David Oyelowo with the requisite grace and dignity and also with streaks of humor, weariness and doubt, occupies a central place in ‰ÛÏSelma,‰Ûù but the film is less interested in affirming his greatness than in understanding its sources and limitations, and in restoring his human dimensions.

On the afternoon of March 7, 1965, Alabama state troopers and members of a Dallas County posse, armed with clubs, cattle prods and tear gas, attacked civil rights demonstrators on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala. The marchers had planned to walk the 50 miles to Montgomery, the state capital, as part of a long-building protest against the denial of basic voting rights to Southern blacks. The procession would have crossed Lowndes County, where not a single African-American voter had been registered in more than 60 years. Efforts to change this had been met with bureaucratic obstruction, intimidation and lethal brutality, including the killing, a week earlier, of Jimmie Lee Jackson, a 26-year-old laborer and protester, by a state trooper.

Narrowing the scope ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù begins with Dr. King‰Ûªs acceptance of the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo in December 1964 and ends in Montgomery a little more than three months later ‰ÛÓ poses its own challenges. How do you capture the chaos, uncertainty and sheer crowdedness of events without sacrificing coherence? How do you suggest what happened before and after? How do you endow a relatively well-known episode from the recent past with the urgency of the present tense?

The above can serve as a partial plot summary of ‰ÛÏSelma,‰ÛùAva DuVernay‰Ûªs bold and bracingly self-assured new movie about the march and the events, in Selma and elsewhere, leading up to it. History does not come with spoilers ‰ÛÓ or spoiler alerts ‰ÛÓ but it does have a habit of setting traps for ambitious filmmakers. The most basic is the lack of clear beginnings and ends. To tell the story of the American civil rights movement properly, a conscientious director would have to plot a course from at least 1619, when the first enslaved Africans arrived, to this week.

While entirely satisfying on its own, ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù seems to contain the seeds of at least a dozen other movies ‰ÛÓ a reminder of how fertile the civil rights era is and how poorly it has been explored by popular culture. Spike Lee and Denzel Washington gave us a fine Malcolm X (who shows up here briefly, played by Nigel Thatch), but how long will we have to wait for a biopic devoted to Bayard Rustin (Ruben Santiago-Hudson), Amelia Boynton (Lorraine Toussaint) or Andrew Young (Andre Holland)? Or for a daring director to tackle the story of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, whose internal tensions and impatience with Dr. King surface here in arguments between James Forman (Trai Byers) and the future Congressman John Lewis (Stephan James)? Where is the premium-cable mini-series about Diane Nash (Ms. Thompson) and James Bevel (Common)? The Martin Luther King-Ralph Abernathy (Colman Domingo) buddy movie? The ‰ÛÏLaw & Order‰Ûù spinoff about the career of the Justice Department lawyer John Doar (Alessandro Nivola)? They are all here, in miniature, but ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù made me impatient for more.

The answers are all up there on the screen. Ms. DuVernay, in her third feature (after ‰ÛÏI Will Follow‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMiddle of Nowhere‰Ûù), writes history with passionate clarity and blazing conviction. (The cinematographer, Bradford Young, captures its shadows and its glow.) Even if you think you know what‰Ûªs coming, ‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù hums with suspense and surprise. Packed with incident and overflowing with fascinating characters, it is a triumph of efficient, emphatic cinematic storytelling. And much more than that, of course: It would be hard to imagine a timelier, more necessary popular entertainment in the year of Ferguson, Mo., a reminder both of progress made and promises unkept. But such relevance is hardly automatic. A timid, pious or dishonest movie about the time-burnished glories of the civil rights era ‰ÛÓ the kind of soothing fable of awakened white conscience that Hollywood has too often favored ‰ÛÓ would not do anyone any good.

A few days later, a second march, led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., turned back rather than risk further violence. By the time the third, ultimately successful effort left Selma on March 21, President Lyndon B. Johnson, pushed by Dr. King and televised images of official brutality as well as by his own political and moral instincts, had introduced the Voting Rights Act in a nationally televised address to Congress.
‰ÛÏSelma‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, bigotry, brief cigarette smoking.

Dr. King‰Ûªs heirs did not grant permission for his speeches to be quoted in ‰ÛÏSelma,‰Ûù and while this may be a blow to the film‰Ûªs authenticity, Ms. DuVernay turns it into an advantage, a chance to see and hear him afresh. Mr. Oyelowo, a British actor of Nigerian background, has mastered the Southern inflections and preacherly cadences that have become part of the permanent soundtrack of our educational system, and the script offers credible paraphrases of his character‰Ûªs unmatched eloquence. But this version of Dr. King is less an orator than an organizer. He is also, in his mid-30s, a man trying to navigate his public role, his private life and the expectations of his allies and friends.

To say that an extraordinary group of actors supports Mr. Oyelowo‰Ûªs performance ‰ÛÓ Oprah Winfrey, Wendell Pierce, Tessa Thompson, Henry G. Sanders and many more ‰ÛÓ is to state the obvious and also, somehow, to get it backward. Dr. King worked in the service of the movement, not the other way around, and Mr. Oyelowo‰Ûªs quiet, attentive, reflective presence upholds this democratic principle by illuminating the contributions of those around him. I have rarely seen a historical film that felt so populous and full of life, so alert to the tendrils of narrative that spread beyond the frame.

Ms. DuVernay‰Ûªs portrait is astonishingly rich and nuanced, and it is very much a group portrait. We see Dr. King at home in Atlanta with his wife, Coretta Scott King (Carmen Ejogo), confronting her worries about his safety and her suspicions of his infidelity. Those suspicions, handled with delicate candor, are fueled by the determination of J. Edgar Hoover (Dylan Baker), the F.B.I. director, to destroy a leader he views as a ‰ÛÏpolitical and moral degenerate.‰Ûù

That blood gushes and splatters, mostly discreetly, at times with misplaced tastefulness, as Louie falls and rises in spirit and body. Ms. Jolie‰Ûªs tendency to go David Lean with this material works against her in the camp sequences, because what you want to know isn‰Ûªt what the prisoners looked like standing in formation in long shot but what they thought and did to survive. What the movie ends up in desperate need of is a sense of life made real and palpable through dreadful, transporting details, not a life embalmed in hagiographic awe. You can find that movie here, at times, tucked amid the crane shots and angelic singing, though mostly in the perverse intimacy that emerges between Louie and the sadistic officer, Watanabe (Miyavi), and shows just how personal war can really be.
‰ÛÏUnbroken‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). War violence and crimes.

That story, in its human reach and cosmic scale, in its different permutations and theaters of war, has been recounted in memoirs, novels, fiction films and all too painfully true documentaries. It emerges again in Laura Hillenbrand‰Ûªs 2010 best seller, ‰ÛÏUnbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience and Redemption,‰Ûù which is the basis for the movie. With some narrative rejigging, a lot of compression and one significant exception, Ms. Jolie follows the lead of the book, which focuses on the first 25 years or so of Mr. Zamperini‰Ûªs life. She also sweeps through his early education as a peewee gangster, truculent son of Italian immigrants and accidental athlete who discovers he can run like the wind, but she gets to the war sooner.

Angelina Jolie opens ‰ÛÏUnbroken‰Ûù with a shot of a celestial blue sky that soon darkens with a battle scene so tense and fluidly choreographed that you quickly sense that, as a director, she leans closer to hell than heaven. She has given herself plenty to work with: The movie takes a slice out of the life of Louis Zamperini, the Olympic runner turned World War II bombardier who, after surviving a plane crash and 47 days adrift on the Pacific, was fished out of the water by a Japanese patrol boat and then imprisoned in camps where he was brutalized for years. His is one of those stories that has come to define the Greatest Generation.

Ms. Jolie is a fast worker. After her inaugural nod at the wide blue yonder, she thrusts you inside the claustrophobic confines of a B-24 bomber that‰Ûªs soon under Japanese attack. There, the adult Louie, as he was called, bounces through the plane while bullets begin shredding its exterior and soon its occupants, the fusillade opening little circles of light in the hull as effortlessly as a pencil punches holes in paper. It‰Ûªs a shrewd opener, because it immediately puts you on notice in regard to the story‰Ûªs life-and-death stakes and draws you close to Louie (the appealing Jack O‰ÛªConnell). Mr. Zamperini was a distance runner, but here he‰Ûªs a sprinter whose quicksilver movements ‰ÛÓ he crouches and scuttles while tending the wounded plane and men ‰ÛÓ suck you in with gravitational force.

That Mr. Zamperini didn‰Ûªt win that day doesn‰Ûªt lessen his accomplishments on or off the track, of course, or make his story any less touching. Being an Olympian is a triumph in and of itself, yet that truism doesn‰Ûªt seem to have been grand enough for Ms. Jolie‰Ûªs purposes. The Olympic interlude is sandwiched between some wartime scenes, right after the plane that Louie‰Ûªs on starts to malfunction and just before it falls into the Pacific. The placement of his Olympic experience suggests that Louie‰Ûªs life is flashing before him or that he‰Ûªs drawing strength from a memory. But the triumphalism of the race is so excessive that it competes with, rather than complements, the war scenes and ends up being another clip in what increasingly will feel like one man‰Ûªs extended highlight reel.

Louie‰Ûªs life moves so rapidly here that about 30 minutes after the movie‰Ûªs start, he‰Ûªs running laps at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. There, he catches a glimpse of Jesse Owens and gawps at the cheering crowds and bloated Nazi spectacle, which Ms. Jolie conveys with digital effects and a touch of Leni Riefenstahl pomp-and-creepiness. Then Louie‰Ûªs off to the races, and we‰Ûªre off to something of a narrative cheat. He scores mightily on the track ‰ÛÓ with a rabbity final sprint ‰ÛÓ but Ms. Jolie pumps the inspirational uplift so high that with all the soaring music, swirling camerawork, excited commentary and slow-motion shots of Louie‰Ûªs straining and gasping you may not realize he didn‰Ûªt win any Olympic medals.

It took four marquee writers ‰ÛÓ Joel Coen, Ethan Coen, Richard LaGravenese and William Nicholson ‰ÛÓ to wrestle Ms. Hillenbrand‰Ûªs many pages into a movie, which clocks in at 2 hours 17 minutes. That‰Ûªs scarcely enough time for any life, but it‰Ûªs impossible when each chapter in that life could itself be a book (including an underplayed epiphany), and the strain shows, especially in the camp sequences. Ms. Jolie does fine work throughout, including on the raft where, after the crash, Louie and two others, Phil (Domhnall Gleeson) and Mac (Finn Wittrock), battle dehydration, starvation and sharks, including one that the men, in a jolting scene, wrestle onboard and devour. Like a lot of actors turned directors, she‰Ûªs good with the performers, even when platitudes gush from their mouths along with the blood.

The real-life merits of this idea are arguable, to say the least. As an ethical touchstone or a political principle, it certainly has its dangers. But a lot of great movies, including several of Mr. Eastwood‰Ûªs, arise from the simple premise of a fight to the death between good guys and bad guys. ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù is not quite among them, but much of its considerable power derives from the clarity and sincerity of its bedrock convictions. Less a war movie than a western ‰ÛÓ the story of a lone gunslinger facing down his nemesis in a dusty, lawless place ‰ÛÓ it is blunt and effective, though also troubling.

The politics of the Iraq war are entirely absent, which is a political statement in its own right. And though George W. Bush‰Ûªs name is never invoked, ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù can be seen as an expression of nostalgia for his Manichaean approach to foreign policy. It can equally ‰ÛÓ and this may amount to the same thing ‰ÛÓ be seen as upholding the Hollywood western tradition of turning complicated historical events and characters into fables and heroes. In other words, it‰Ûªs only a movie.

Or, you might say, its commitment to printing his legend. ‰ÛÏLegend‰Ûù is one of the nicknames Chris earns from his admiring fellow servicemen, who are in awe of his bravery and skill, and Mr. Eastwood engages in his share of mythmaking. This is less a matter of the way he tells the true story than in the way he edits the history in which it is embedded. Terrorist attacks on United States Embassies in 1998 inspired Chris to enlist, and his resolve is fortified when he sees the World Trade Center collapse on Sept. 11, 2001. In Iraq, his foes are identified only and repeatedly as Al Qaeda.

It‰Ûªs a tough, stark view of the order of things, one that guides Chris in his subsequent career as a Navy SEAL sniper and one that has, with some modification, informed much of the work of Clint Eastwood, the director of ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper.‰Ûù Faithful in shape and spirit to the real Chris Kyle‰Ûªs memoir, ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù also reaffirms Mr. Eastwood‰Ûªs commitment to the themes of vengeance and justice in a fallen world. In the universe of his films ‰ÛÓ a universe where the existence of evil is a given ‰ÛÓ violence is a moral necessity, albeit one that often exacts a cost from those who must wield it in the service of good.
‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Intense combat and rough language.

Remorse is out of the question, which is not to say that Chris doesn‰Ûªt suffer. (Mr. Kyle‰Ûªs death in 2013, at the hands of a disturbed fellow veteran, casts a somber shadow over the movie, though Mr. Eastwood avoids the obvious trap of using it as a foreshadowing device.) ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt flinch from portraying the toll of his service on his psyche and his marriage, though it may tidy up the damage a bit too quickly and neatly. But this, too, is part of the film‰Ûªs loyalty to its hero‰Ûªs understanding of himself and his work.

Mostly, though, we are in Iraq, where Chris Kyle served four tours of duty, racking up 160 confirmed kills. He approaches his work with steady nerves and a clear conscience, banishing the doubt and fatalism that afflict some of his comrades and buttressed by the unambiguous depravity of his enemies. These are people who use women and children as suicide bombers, who mutilate and torture anyone who opposes them, who ambush American Marines in the street. Giving them cover is Chris‰Ûªs nemesis and sinister doppelgÌ_nger, a shadowy sharpshooter rumored to be a Syrian Olympic medalist.

As a young boy, which is to say before he grows up into a burly, bearded Bradley Cooper, Chris Kyle receives a lesson in life from his strict Texan father. The world, according to Dad, is divided into sheep, wolves and sheepdogs, those rare, righteous souls called to protect the innocent from the wicked.

Mr. Cooper keeps a lid on his natural, mischievous charm without entirely suppressing it. His Chris Kyle is a loyal friend and a brave warrior, but Mr. Cooper and Mr. Eastwood, working from a script by Jason Hall, decline to make him a saint. Some of the liveliest and most memorable scenes in ‰ÛÏAmerican Sniper‰Ûù are celebrations of the profane, aggressive humor and endless teasing that men in combat deploy to relieve the tension. Chris‰Ûªs courtship and marriage ‰ÛÓ to Taya, played by Sienna Miller ‰ÛÓ are rendered a bit more stiffly, but the warmth and ease that are among Mr. Eastwood‰Ûªs underappreciated virtues make their way into the movie‰Ûªs brief forays into romance and domesticity.

Walter Keane, speaking of creeps, seems at first to be an ebullient, free-spirited charmer. He seems that way to Margaret, anyway. The rest of us, recognizing Christoph Waltz, will suspect other, less amusing dimensions to the character. A Sunday painter who claims to have studied in Paris, Walter, who works in commercial real estate, encourages Margaret‰Ûªs creativity and offers security for her and Jane, whose father is threatening to sue for custody. The new couple exhibit their work in a nightclub (owned by the great scene-stealer Jon Polito), and when Margaret‰Ûªs forlorn children attract more attention than Walter‰Ûªs Parisian street scenes, he starts to claim them as his own.
A horror movie tucked inside a domestic drama wrapped up in a biopic, Tim Burton‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBig Eyes‰Ûù tells the story of Margaret Keane, an artist whose characteristic style is summed up in the title.

Walter is a mediocre artist ‰ÛÓ if that ‰ÛÓ but he does have a genius for self-promotion. Intuiting the Warholian spirit of the times, he pushes the boundary between art and commerce, turning his surname and his wife‰Ûªs talent into a powerful and ubiquitous brand. He is helped by a gullible newspaper columnist played by Danny Huston. Though ‰ÛÏBig Eyes‰Ûù is entirely on Margaret‰Ûªs side, especially as her husband‰Ûªs sadistic, controlling behavior comes to the forefront, it depends on Walter‰Ûªs manic, devilish energy. Ms. Adams‰Ûªs performance is sensitive and subtle, but the film can‰Ûªt quite figure out what to do with her character‰Ûªs passivity. Trying to do Margaret justice, Mr. Burton can‰Ûªt prevent himself (and Mr. Waltz) from upstaging her.

A more intriguing ambiguity has to do with the value of Margaret‰Ûªs work. Terence Stamp shows up briefly as John Canaday, a real-life New York Times critic who attacked the selection of a large-scale Keane painting called ‰ÛÏTomorrow Forever‰Ûù for the 1964 World‰Ûªs Fair. Canaday (a Kansas native here depicted as an imperious patrician with an ascot and a British accent) exposed Walter Keane‰Ûªs hucksterism but also trashed Margaret‰Ûªs art as ‰ÛÏthe very definition of tasteless hack work.‰Ûù

Is that judgment altered by the knowledge that the paintings, rather than emerging from a self-promoting man‰Ûªs supposed encounters with orphans in postwar Berlin, sprung from the unconscious of a self-effacing woman? This is not a simple question, and it is one that Mr. Burton toys with to intriguing effect. In his magnificent ‰ÛÏEd Wood,‰Ûù the director cast a sympathetic eye on a widely reviled filmmaker, exploring the ambition and integrity behind some of the worst movies ever made.

Starting in the 1950s, Ms. Keane ‰ÛÓ who is still alive and who is played by Amy Adams with a whispery Tennessee accent and an air of patient melancholy ‰ÛÓ painted thousands of pictures of waiflike figures with sad faces and oversized peepers. In the 1960s, she was both famous and almost entirely unknown. Her work was everywhere, devoured by the public and scorned by critics. But fans and detractors alike believed that the author of that work was her husband, Walter, who hogged the spotlight while his wife stayed home with the pigments and the canvases.

In ‰ÛÏBig Eyes,‰Ûù the sincerity of the artist trumps the judgment of the critics, and her vision triumphs over fraudulent promotion. It makes a passionate case for her. Whether it vindicates her art is another question entirely.

‰ÛÏBig Eyes,‰Ûù directed in Mr. Burton‰Ûªs coy, heavily pictorial manner, and written by Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, never quite achieves the full measure of psychological intensity promised by the spooky interior lighting, the low camera angles and Danny Elfman‰Ûªs hysterical score. The element of Margaret‰Ûªs personality that allowed her to remain under Walter‰Ûªs spell for so long remains opaque.
