How this arrangement came about ‰ÛÓ and how it fell apart ‰ÛÓ is Mr. Burton‰Ûªs main concern. Margaret arrives in San Francisco in flight from a bad first marriage, accompanied by her daughter, Jane (Delaney Raye as a young child, Madeleine Arthur as a teenager). The world is an unfriendly place for a single mother, and the city, shot in bright, saturated colors (by Bruno Delbonnel), has a lurid creepiness that suggests Alfred Hitchcock‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏVertigo,‰Ûù an impression underlined by Ms. Adams‰Ûªs blond, slightly chilly vulnerability.
‰ÛÏBig Eyes‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Volatile temperaments, uncouth language, bad art.

Directed by Rob Marshall (‰ÛÏChicago,‰Ûù‰ÛÏNine‰Ûù), this witty and touching mash-up of several Grimm fairy tales viewed through a post-Freudian prism reimagines Cinderella (Anna Kendrick), Little Red Riding Hood (Lilla Crawford), Rapunzel (MacKenzie Mauzy), Jack (of ‰ÛÏJack and the Beanstalk,‰Ûù played by Daniel Huttlestone) and other fairy tale figures as complex, self-aware human beings in transition. Mr. Lapine‰Ûªs screenplay follows them to ‰ÛÏhappily ever after,‰Ûù then leaps ahead into territory that turns out to be the scary real world. Here, children weaned on fairy tales must finally abandon magical thinking.
Careful the things you say,

Everyone else is shaded somewhere between good and evil. Even Ms. Streep‰Ûªs vindictive hag is not entirely wicked. When a curse is lifted, and her beauty is restored, she is a dead ringer for Miranda Priestly, Ms. Streep‰Ûªs regal fashion maven in ‰ÛÏThe Devil Wears Prada.‰Ûù Ms. Streep‰Ûªs warm performance gives the witch, even at her most fearsome, a twinkle of good humor that draws you to her. And her climactic meltdown, ‰ÛÏLast Midnight,‰Ûù is a vocal and dramatic tour de force.
Careful the things you do,

Mr. Sondheim and Mr. Lapine, the wizards pulling the strings, are behind-the-scenes Prosperos conjuring magic. Even after the story darkens, Mr. Lapine‰Ûªs book sustains enough humor to prevent the tone from sounding pedantic. Late in the movie, Cinderella‰Ûªs vain, clueless prince apologizes for his dalliance (with the Baker‰Ûªs Wife) by explaining, ‰ÛÏI was raised to be charming, not sincere.‰Ûù
Children will see.
And ‰ÛÏChildren Will Listen‰Ûù distills what might be called the gospel according to Sondheim:

It is a world ravaged by catastrophe. The villain is an angry female giant (Frances de la Tour), who stomps through the land, wreaking random death and destruction. Lost and with no direction home, the survivors turn on one another, but quickly realize they have no choice but to stick together as they fend for themselves.

Rapunzel and the witch are not the movie‰Ûªs only parent and child in conflict. Jack and his strict mother (Tracey Ullman), irate that he traded a cow for some magic beans, are continually at odds. The characters closest to their fairy tale origins are Cinderella‰Ûªs stepmother (Christine Baranski) and stepsisters, Florinda (Tammy Blanchard) and Lucinda (Lucy Punch). With the exception of the giant and a wolf (a sensational Johnny Depp) who stalks and devours Little Red Riding Hood, these mean girls and their avaricious mom are the only genuine baddies.

The Sondheim lyrics do much of the storytelling, with their dense wordplay and ingenious internal rhymes that verge on a Broadway equivalent of rap. The title number, a pastiche of the early-20th-century song ‰ÛÏTeddy Bears‰Ûª Picnic,‰Ûù establishes the innocent, carefree springboard from which everything else leaps. The one major song missing, the heartbreaking ‰ÛÏNo More,‰Ûù alas, is heard only briefly as an instrumental. Gloriously orchestrated by Jonathan Tunick, the gorgeous music has never sounded more eloquent.

The movie gives us two princes, one for Cinderella, the other for Rapunzel. These preening dandies, played by Chris Pine and Billy Magnussen, share the funniest song, ‰ÛÏAgony,‰Ûù in which they bellyache about the pain of the yet-unconsummated romantic chase as they cavort around a waterfall. Mr. Pine‰Ûªs Prince is a direct forerunner of the caddish royal dreamboat in ‰ÛÏFrozen,‰Ûù and it‰Ûªs reasonable to speculate that ‰ÛÏInto the Woods‰Ûù influenced his creation.

Mr. Sondheim‰Ûªs great song ‰ÛÏNo One Is Alone‰Ûù is a double-edged lullaby. It acknowledges that everyone is ultimately alone, although the shared understanding of that isolation makes life bearable.

‰ÛÏInto the Woods,‰Ûù the splendid Disney screen adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for ‰ÛÏchildren of all ages.‰Ûù That usually translates to mean only children and their doting parents. But with ‰ÛÏInto the Woods,‰Ûù you grow up with the characters, young and old, in a lifelong process of self-discovery.

Cinderella, beneath her facade of meek, abused scullery maid, is a schemer who strategically deposits a shoe on the palace steps while fleeing at midnight. With her avid glare and jack-o'-lantern smile, Ms. Kendrick is not a classic Cinderella, but a sly, modern go-getter plotting her future.
We are listening.

‰ÛÏInto the Woods‰Ûù has just enough carefully chosen computer-generated effects to give it the feel of a semi-animated film without going overboard. In Dennis Gassner‰Ûªs production design, the forest in which most of the action takes place is suffused with magic. The witch materializes and vanishes in leafy whirlwinds. The gnarly trees almost have personalities of their own. The shafts of sunlight filtering through the forest lend it a glow of heavenly illumination.
Children will listen.
And learn.

The movie shows remarkably few signs of the sweetening and dumbing down that might have been expected, given the Disney factory‰Ûªs philosophy of gratifying wishes but adding just enough darkness to make the light seem brighter. I suspect that the success of ‰ÛÏFrozen‰Ûù may have persuaded the company to modify its traditional formulas to allow more realism and ambiguity, which is all to the good.

A key player in the drama is a witch (Meryl Streep), who kidnapped Rapunzel, the baby sister of the baker who lives next door, and becomes a fiercely protective mother figure. The chubby, spunky Little Red Riding Hood steals pies from the bakery. There is a complicated history connecting these and other characters who wind up in the nearby forest, pursuing outlandish quests.
‰ÛÏInto the Woods‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Fantasy action and peril, and some suggestive material.

As its imposing title suggests, the Russian drama ‰ÛÏLeviathan‰Ûù is something of a monster movie. It turns on a modern-day Job who endures trials and tribulations in an Arctic town in northern Russia. Some of his miseries are self-inflicted ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs a boozer, not the pious soul of the Bible story ‰ÛÓ but many of his agonies originate with corrupt authorities, including the local mayor, a Hobbesian brute who sits at his desk under a photograph of Vladimir V. Putin. The director, Andrey Zvyagintsev, has a heavenly eye but a leaden hand, and his movie is as heavy as it is transporting, filled with stirring shots of the natural world and deep dives into a human realm flooded with tears and vodka.

Written by Mr. Zvyagintsev and Oleg Negin, who earlier paired up for ‰ÛÏElena,‰Ûù the movie follows Kolya as he tries to hang onto his house, his land, his life. The mayor, Vadim (Roman Madianov, who‰Ûªs great at being horrible), has made a play for Kolya‰Ûªs property, and now the case has reached the appeal stage. Kolya, in turn, has enlisted Dmitri (Vladimir Vdovichenkov, excellent), a Moscow lawyer and old friend who arrives as the story commences. Kolya‰Ûªs appeal is summarily denied (an official speed-talks the verdict like a cattle auctioneer), but Dmitri has dirt on Vadim. The mayor squeals, retreats and plots ‰ÛÓ he has the law, the courts and God, or at least a religious leader, on his side ‰ÛÓ only to come down on Kolya like a hammer.

As the movie‰Ûªs title also suggests, Kolya is a Job in a Hobbesian war of all against all, one he appears to have joined long ago. In Hobbes‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLeviathan,‰Ûù he argues for absolute sovereign power as a defense against the state of nature and a life that is ‰ÛÏsolitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short.‰Ûù This magnificent, exasperating movie is on the longish side, partly so that the devastating cost of absolute power can be announced again and again: in the picture of Mr. Putin; in a nod to the dissident group Pussy Riot; in a Rasputin-like figure; in the misery, sorrow and vodka. Despite flashes of absurdist comedy from some secondary characters, the movie closes around you like the fist it protests and laments. In the Bible, Job rends his mantle; it‰Ûªs no wonder that Kolya takes another drink instead.

Kolya‰Ûªs story starts with his taking a nose-dive and continues with his sinking deeper. Calamity leads to catastrophe, and a smack across a head is followed by thrown fists and brandished guns. As the insults and bruises accumulate, it becomes evident that Kolya‰Ûªs faith isn‰Ûªt being tested, even when he accusatorily asks a priest, ‰ÛÏWhere is your merciful God?‰Ûù It‰Ûªs indicative of Mr. Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs storytelling that when bread that this priest gives away ends up in a muddy pen ‰ÛÓ where pigs soon devour these religiously suggestive loaves ‰ÛÓ the director holds the shot of the guzzling porkers in what can only be described as the needless force-feeding of the viewer. Such bluntness can be maddening, even as Mr. Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs feeling for beauty (every pig ear looks lighted with care) grips you.

The Job here is a middle-aged mechanic, Kolya (Aleksey Serebryakov, all glower and soul), who lives on a majestic, isolated spit of coast with his second wife, Lilya (a fine Elena Liadova), and teenage son, Roma (Sergey Pokhodaev), from an earlier marriage. Kolya works out of a tiny garage next to the house, a heart-skippingly lovely fixer-upper with flaking walls, the usual cozy clutter and enormous picture windows that face the water, visually closing the distance between the interior and the exterior. The austere splendor of this scenery ‰ÛÓ with its craggy mountains, sweeps of treeless land and pools of water ‰ÛÓ makes a fitting stage for the characters, who match the landscape‰Ûªs severity with gruff manners, crude words, brute actions and grave, unsmiling faces.
‰ÛÏLeviathan‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and overdrinking.

Mr. Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs  visual gifts are worthy of the movie‰Ûªs natural landscapes. He opens ‰ÛÏLeviathan‰Ûù with images of the coast, where the brilliant Arctic water doesn‰Ûªt simply ebb and flow, but seems to caress and lash the earth, the waves shimmering with eddies of a midnight hue and glints of pure Yves Klein blue. The rhythms of the water, along with the soft sapphire light and Mr. Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs filmmaking ‰ÛÓ every image is immaculately framed, and every camera move conveys the deliberate thought behind it ‰ÛÓ pull you in with seemingly irresistible power. The overall effect on the viewer is of near-inundation, a feeling that‰Ûªs reinforced by the soundtrack, which features the hypnotic swirling of Philip Glass‰Ûªs 1983 opera, ‰ÛÏAkhnaten,‰Ûù about the rise and fall of that Egyptian pharaoh.

‰ÛÏThe Gambler‰Ûù is based on the terrific lowdown and gritty 1974 movie of the same title starring James Caan. That film was beautifully directed by Karel Reisz from James Toback‰Ûªs script about his experience as a gambler and college lecturer; the new one was directed by Rupert Wyatt from a screenplay by William Monahan, who also wrote Martin Scorsese‰Ûªs Academy Award windfall ‰ÛÏThe Departed.‰Ûù Without a script in hand, it‰Ûªs tough to tell how significant a contribution a writer makes to a movie, what was retained or changed from page to screen. All that‰Ûªs clear in this ‰ÛÏGambler‰Ûù is that almost everything that makes the original so pleasurably idiosyncratic, from its daft ideas to the peekaboo bear rug spread over Mr. Caan‰Ûªs often-bared chest, has been expunged from the remake.
‰ÛÏThe Gambler‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Vice, inherently.

A change in name is the least of it but is symptomatic of the material‰Ûªs bowdlerization. Mr. Caan‰Ûªs gambler is Axel Freed and the scion of a wealthy Jewish New York family. (The name suggests that Mr. Toback was familiar with Dostoyevsky‰Ûªs short autobiographical novel ‰ÛÏThe Gambler,‰Ûù in which the protagonist is named Alexei.) Recast as an ethnically generic poor little rich boy, Mr. Wahlberg‰Ûªs Jim Bennett lives in Los Angeles, mostly after dark in illegal gambling dens where Asian and black habituÌ©s serve as decoration. In one of the remake‰Ûªs better touches, Jim and some other gamblers stroll into these joints with satchels and briefcases stuffed with cash, like salarymen purposefully marching off to work. Gambling isn‰Ûªt his profession, though it is his calling, habit and love.

What‰Ûªs mostly missing from ‰ÛÏThe Gambler‰Ûù is a sense of why Jim is so insistent on squandering his money, privilege and patrimony. In a letter to a friend, Dostoyevsky wrote that the main thing about his gambler ‰ÛÏis that all his vitality, his strength, his impetus, his courage, have gone into roulette.‰Ûù The character ‰ÛÏis a poet in his own way, but ashamed of this poetry because he is profoundly conscious that it is unworthy, although the necessity of risk redeems him in his own eyes.‰Ûù You can understand why Mr. Reisz chose Mr. Caan, who was a sexual beast on-screen back in the day and who makes you feel the intensity of the character‰Ûªs need to gamble, to chance it all so that he can win, a risk that can lead to something like grace. Here, though winning isn‰Ûªt everything ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs hardly anything.

The story mostly involves Jim‰Ûªs consuming passion with gambling and, in a quasi-Freudian move, learning to transfer that libidinous energy to a dubiously healthier object, in this case one of his young students, Amy (an underused Brie Larson). Mr. Monahan may have lifted the teacher-student liaison from Dostoyevsky‰Ûªs biography and novelist‰Ûªs relationship with a much younger woman. That‰Ûªs moderately interesting, but it doesn‰Ûªt mean anything for Amy (or Ms. Larson), who does little more than look intently at Jim when he‰Ûªs jumping around the lecture hall or laying down some heavy thoughts. Ms. Larson holds your eyes and interest, but she‰Ûªs as ornamental as the stick figure played by Lauren Hutton in the 1974 film.

Mr. Wyatt‰Ûªs direction is smooth, although he‰Ûªs more confident, and the movie more convincing, when he goes for baroque with the story‰Ûªs excesses, like cutting loose with the cartoonish villains played by Alvin Ing, Jessica Lange, Michael Kenneth Williams and John Goodman. The problem is that Jim (and Mr. Wahlberg) never joins the fun. A congenitally likable screen presence, Mr. Wahlberg handles the movie‰Ûªs streaming words like the rapper he once was, and he sometimes cocks an eyebrow as if acknowledging the absurdity of it all. Mostly, his character is sad, sincere and heavy, and his performance is, too, even when Jim whips out some eyeglasses the first time he enters his classroom. When Marilyn Monroe pulled that kind of stunt it was comedy gold, but it just makes Jim and Mr. Wahlberg look silly.

In ‰ÛÏThe Gambler,‰Ûù a movie about a guy who‰Ûªs a glutton for criminally high stakes and for punishment, a skeletonized Mark Wahlberg wears a mop of greasy hair and an abject look. In some scenes, he looks crushed and lost, like a wadded scrap of paper that fell short of the garbage bin. It soon becomes clear why. His character, Jim Bennett, hit the literary jackpot years ago with a well-received first and only published novel. Now Jim splits his time between teaching college ‰ÛÓ say hello to Professor Wahlberg ‰ÛÓ and betting and losing at gaming tables, some in underworld parlors around a Los Angeles that‰Ûªs been Michael Mann-ed into a smear of throbbing color and would-be existential dread.

Antoine (Lambert Wilson) is the vain, philandering scion of a family firm who has a heart attack while running in a race with his beautiful wife, a doctor. He faces such annoyances as a garage-mechanic buddy who balks at being his alibi for a one-night-stand, and failing eyesight, which requires him to squint at a restaurant menu. His friends, meanwhile, suffer the indignities of seeing sangria made out of good wine and working out equitable vacation arrangements at a villa.

Eric Lavaine‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBarbecue,‰Ûù a French comedy about a circle of middle-age friends facing mild irritations, is the kind of utterly unremarkable local product that doesn‰Ûªt usually get an American release. But its loosely written story doubles as a smirk-inducing glimpse at what feel like very Gallic life challenges.

There‰Ûªs precious little plot aside from Antoine‰Ûªs tiring of his friends and then liking them again. Mr. Lavaine, who wrote the script with Hector Cabello Reyes, pokes a little fun at the characters‰Ûª circumstances, though it‰Ûªs sometimes hard to tell. The breeziness, like some later-in-life takeoff on the 20-somethings of CÌ©dric Klapisch‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªAuberge Espagnole‰Ûù and its sequels, does help a number of iffy jokes land, and adult sex lives are treated with a refreshing casualness.

But Mr. Wilson‰Ûªs Antoine is too much of a pill to root for, and the voice-over and wispy songs dribbling over scenes only underline the forgettable filmmaking. But hurrah for the use of a game of pÌ©tanque (pronounced pay-TONK, it‰Ûªs a lawn game akin to Italian bocce ball) to illustrate the joie de vivre of a woman separated from her husband.

By a miracle of geopolitical lunacy and media craziness, a typically antisocial, even irresponsible activity ‰ÛÓ did I mention that I had a precocious 10-year-old nephew sitting next to me, getting an earful of wildly age-inappropriate humor? ‰ÛÓ was transformed into a solemn professional duty. But why be modest? It was an act of patriotism. In defiance of a dictator and obeying a diktat from my editor, I fed my credit card information into YouTube (hack that, Mr. Kim!) and did my part for freedom of speech and the Sony Corporation. You‰Ûªre welcome, America.
‰ÛÏThe Interview‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The usual.

What I‰Ûªm saying, just in case you‰Ûªve been distracted by other news, is that I watched ‰ÛÏThe Interview,‰Ûù starring Seth Rogen and James Franco and directed by Mr. Rogen and Evan Goldberg. Was this a happy ending or an anticlimax? My colleague Mike Hale, who saw the movie at an advance screening and wrote about it after Sony‰Ûªs initial decision to pull it from theaters, mused that ‰ÛÏthe only real mystery is how something this ordinary could have caused so much agitation.‰Ûù

What this means is a lot of jokes about the remarkable fact that the male body, so to speak, is equipped with both a car and a garage. In compensation, the women who show up are aggressively reduced to objects of sexual interest. There are two of them: Lizzy Caplan as a C.I.A. operative, and Diana Bang as a North Korean official in charge of managing the logistics of Dave‰Ûªs interview with Kim Jong-un (Randall Park).

So this is how it ends: lining up on Christmas Day, not at a blockbuster-stuffed multiplex but at one of the scrappy independent theaters that have been struggling to stay afloat in a tough marketplace, or hunkering down on the couch at Mom‰Ûªs house (this is how it was for me) with a laptop and a couple of kids while the rest of the family fusses over the tree.

Tweaking a tiny totalitarian state and its dynastic leader is ‰ÛÓ or was probably intended to be ‰ÛÓ a way of striking a provocative and topical pose while still playing it safe. North Korea is not a nation with many sympathizers in the moviegoing world, and the stereotyping of Asians and Asian-Americans flourishes even in supposedly liberal Hollywood. It‰Ûªs unlikely that the filmmakers would have felt as sanguine about holding an African, Latin American or even a Middle Eastern dictator up to the same kind of ridicule.

But that is part of the pathos of the movie. Dave and Aaron are similarly stuck. They seek out a dubious journalistic opportunity in Pyongyang because they‰Ûªre tired ‰ÛÓ Aaron in particular ‰ÛÓ of the endless cycles of gossip and celebrity pseudonews. They want to get out in the world and do something serious, though they aren‰Ûªt entirely sure what that would be. ‰ÛÏThe Interview‰Ûù mirrors their quest, in a touchingly self-defeating way. Its lesson is that American pop culture is inescapable, our great achievement and most popular export, the weapon we wield abroad and the glue trap we struggle with at home. In the mirror the movie holds up, we are at our best when we are funny, stupid, sincere and immature, and that‰Ûªs why everybody loves us. Even if we sometimes have trouble admitting how much we love each other.

Enough scolding. The movie‰Ûªs King Jong-un is really just another dude, although one with nuclear weapons and genocidal inclinations. He worries that drinking margaritas means he‰Ûªs gay and is embarrassed to admit that he likes Katy Perry‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFirework.‰Ûù That song and ‰ÛÏThe Lord of the Rings‰Ûù are the movie‰Ûªs main pop-cultural reference points, by the way ‰ÛÓ oh right, Eminem shows up, too ‰ÛÓ which may be a sign that Mr. Goldberg and Mr. Rogen are slipping toward middle age. They used to get to stuff a beat or two before everyone else did. Now they seem to be slowing down.

Exactly. ‰ÛÏThe Interview‰Ûù is pretty much what everyone thought it would be before all the trouble started: a goofy, strenuously naughty, hit-and-miss farce, propelled not by any particular political ideas but by the usual spectacle of male sexual, emotional and existential confusion. It turned out to be perfect laptop viewing, apart from an occasionally wonky Wi-Fi connection. The bloodshed was less gross on the small screen, and the best jokes ‰ÛÓ loose, absurdist, improvised-sounding riffs ‰ÛÓ landed better in a quiet, half-distracted room than they might have in a crowded theater.

‰ÛÏThis Is the End,‰Ûù the previous Rogen-Goldberg-Franco feature, seemed to leave the raunchy bro-com genre with nowhere new to go. It was funny, for sure, but its apocalyptic high jinks couldn‰Ûªt quite disguise its conceptual exhaustion. ‰ÛÏThe Interview‰Ûù confirms this impression. Mr. Franco plays Dave Skylark, a sleazy, celebrity-hounding journalist, and Mr. Rogen is Aaron Rapaport, his longtime friend and producer. Lovers in all but the technical, physical sense, they sustain an elaborate charade of heterosexual heartiness, Dave‰Ûªs more determined and less convincing than Aaron‰Ûªs.
‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, overt and implicit.

But maybe Abel is not guilty of anything more serious than arrogance. He is named after the Old Testament‰Ûªs first innocent victim, and as his torments increase he might be taken as the latest cinematic incarnation of Job. The intricacy of this movie‰Ûªs plot reflects the complexity of its protagonist, who is a fascinating skein of ambiguities and contradictions brought forcefully to life by Mr. Isaac, an actor who has evolved from being someone to watch into someone you can‰Ûªt take your eyes off. Abel is a man of action, fond of inspirational bromides and self-help business slogans, but Mr. Isaac, with his mournful eyes and slightly predatory smile, provides tantalizing glimpses of the divided soul behind the confident facade.

More brooding than brutal, ‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù finds Abel Morales (Oscar Isaac), the upwardly mobile owner of a heating-oil business, in a time of difficulty. Some of the trouble is atmospheric. It‰Ûªs 1981, and New York City is in a state of decay that looks, in the burnished tints of movie hindsight, almost picturesque. Subway cars blossom with graffiti; the radio news wearily tallies each day‰Ûªs shootings and stabbings; crime and corruption hang in the winter air like smog.

J. C. Chandor, the writer and director of this pulpy, meaty, altogether terrific new film, and Bradford Young, its supremely talented director of photography, succeed in giving this beat-up version of the city both historical credibility and expressive power. The light is harsh, the shadows are dense, and forces of chaos seem to gather just outside the frame, their presence signaled by Alex Ebert‰Ûªs anxious musical score. In the course of ‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year,‰Ûù there is an occasional gunshot, and some blood is shed, but the violence alluded to in the film‰Ûªs title is largely a matter of mood rather than action ‰ÛÓ of whispers, not noise. We can‰Ûªt understand Abel, a quiet, calm man whose good manners seem to sit atop a deep reservoir of fury, without a grasp of his environment, even if its governing logic is mysterious.

‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù is Mr. Chandor‰Ûªs third feature film ‰ÛÓ after ‰ÛÏMargin Call‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAll Is Lost‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and it is larger in scale and wider in range than its predecessors, both of which are studies in confinement and compression. ‰ÛÏMargin Call‰Ûù took place almost entirely inside the offices of an investment firm on a single hectic night. ‰ÛÏAll Is Lost‰Ûù was about a man alone on a boat in the middle of the Indian Ocean. Compared with them, ‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù is busy and crowded, full of incidental pleasures (including at least a half-dozen memorable bits of character acting, notably from Alessandro Nivola, Catalina Sandino Moreno, Peter Gerety and Jerry Adler) and piquant period details.

The New York heating-oil business is depicted as an unglamorous but lucrative trade with its own tribal rules and customs, ruled by a small group of families whose members divide territories and settle disputes according to Mafia-like principles. Abel‰Ûªs company is expanding, but not without significant growing pains. As he prepares to close on a coveted piece of commercial real estate and move his family into a fortresslike suburban mansion, he is menaced from every direction. His trucks are hijacked by armed thugs, and one of his drivers (Elyes Gabel) is in particular danger. Abel‰Ûªs salesmen are not safe as they go from door to door. An assistant district attorney (David Oyelowo) is preparing indictments. ‰ÛÏIt looks very bad,‰Ûù says Abel‰Ûªs lawyer, a skillful worrier played by Albert Brooks, American cinema‰Ûªs greatest fatalist.

But the three movies nonetheless form a rough trilogy, whose subtitle might be ‰ÛÏThe Soul of Man Under Capitalism.‰Ûù Each one is, accordingly, a perfect two-sided coin, a story of heroic resolve that is also a troubling allegory of greed and hubris. ‰ÛÏMargin Call‰Ûù is both a thrilling spectacle of damage control or the anatomy of a grotesque act of free-market savagery. ‰ÛÏAll Is Lost‰Ûù is at once an epic of individual survival and a fable of how the recklessness of the privileged can be mistaken for mastery, with disastrous consequences. ‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù presents an honorable man struggling to stay true to his values in the face of temptation. It is also the portrait of a brilliant hustler working a very long con. It‰Ûªs a terrific movie either way.

Appearances can be deceiving, though. Not that there is any doubting Anna‰Ûªs resolve. It is clear that she can be ruthless in defense of her family‰Ûªs interests, but she is also limited by the patriarchal codes of her milieu. Her role is to offer support and an occasional nudge, but unlike most crime movies, which treat wives as static, marginal figures, ‰ÛÏA Most Violent Year‰Ûù is interested in the dynamic of Abel and Anna‰Ûªs marriage, which unites, sometimes uneasily, the imperatives of business and the demands of love. The movie entwines two old sayings: behind every great man there is a great woman, and behind every great fortune there is a great crime.

Amid all these threats, Abel‰Ûªs wife, Anna (Jessica Chastain), whose father used to own the company, wonders if her husband has the wherewithal to protect her and their three young daughters. Abel, rarely raising his voice or losing his composure, takes ostentatious pride in his honest, reasonable way of doing business. He doesn‰Ûªt like guns or cheating or anything that would make him look like a gangster. Anna, a gangster‰Ûªs daughter, takes a more traditional approach, which can make her appear to be the tougher and more pragmatic half of the couple.
1 hour 13 minutes; not rated
Opens on Friday

Mr. Cheney does get around to explaining the origins of General Tso‰Ûªs chicken, but what‰Ûªs more rewarding than the spoon-fed history ‰ÛÓ which covers the gold rush, the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 and Nixon in China ‰ÛÓ is the film‰Ûªs glimpses of history as lived. Shot around the United States, with surprising stops in New Orleans and elsewhere, the story benefits from the reminiscences of restaurateurs, who are often interviewed in multigenerational pairs. How to cook chicken seems at once a minor detail against backdrops of racism and economic struggle, and a key to finding a foothold among strangers.

General Tso‰Ûªs namesake museum back in China also gets an amusing visit, as does Peng Chang-kuei, a nonagenarian chef with a strong claim to having invented a certain recipe. But Mr. Cheney‰Ûªs movie, while teasing at times, does its celebrating and debunking in mild-mannered fashion, making points without seeming to try to score them. It also lacks any of the zest or cinematic skill of, say, a Les Blank jaunt involving food, but this easily digestible format proves an apt vessel for the mystery dish at its center.
Directed by Ian Cheney

The top-billed star of ‰ÛÏThe Search for General Tso‰Ûù gets its close-up in the opening scene: the staging of that namesake chicken dish for a menu photo shoot. But like so many ‰ÛÏin search of‰Ûù documentary journeys before it, Ian Cheney‰Ûªs roundabout talking-heads film has bigger quarry in mind; it looks at Chinese-American assimilation, the useful adaptability of cuisine and the complicated cultivation of heritage.
Opens on Friday

Still, ‰ÛÏThe Woman in Black 2‰Ûù begins with surprising elegance. The students, escorted by Eve (Phoebe Fox) and Jean (Helen McCrory), arrive in the emptied-out village of Crythin Gifford. Shrouded in what may well be a permanent fog ‰ÛÓ eerily relayed in a near-monochromatic, blue-tinged palette, unpierced by headlights (which might attract bombers) ‰ÛÓ the area looks haunted before the ghost appears.
1 hour 38 minutes
Angel of Death

For the characters, the woman in black may function as a kind of proxy for the war: In her presence, death is unavoidable. But the director, Tom Harper, seems less interested in allegory than in monotonous, conventional goosing, the kind that involves flickering lights and a creaky rocking chair. BEN KENIGSBERG

‰ÛÏThe Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death‰Ûù leaves behind the Edwardian setting of its predecessor for 1941. With the Blitz in progress, a group of children evacuates London for what turns out to be an even more dangerous destination. The building designated as their makeshift school is the Eel Marsh House, which, as in the first film, is haunted by a ghost whose specialty is killing children.
THE WOMAN IN BLACK 2
‰ÛÏThe Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Pervasive gloom.

Word of this specter‰Ûªs vendetta against the young apparently hasn‰Ûªt reached this generation. The original movie‰Ûªs star, Daniel Radcliffe, has likewise vanished, along with much of the promise once heralded by the logo of Hammer Films, a former workhorse of British horror.
Directed by Tom Harper

When Charlotte, her younger sister, travels to Weimar to stay with her godmother, Mrs. von Stein (Maja Maranow), Goethe‰Ûªs mistress, and absorb the rituals of court etiquette, it is hoped she will also find a rich husband. But the pickings are slim. The one candidate offered is an obsequious buffoon.

‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters‰Ûù at least suggests the rigors of transportation by horse and carriage over muddy roads. It follows the development of printing techniques that hastened the mass distribution of literature. But for the most part, the movie stays safely in upscale territory, leaving the cold, cruel world outside the door. There are tourist-ready images of the Rhine Falls and of a river where Schiller, who can‰Ûªt swim, risks his life to save a drowning girl.

Despite its attention to period detail and some flashy set pieces, ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters‰Ûù has the feel of a historical pageant; it is a game of dress-up that never transports you to the past. A film like ‰ÛÏBarry Lyndon,‰Ûù set earlier in the 18th century, conveyed a shivery sense of strangeness. But the aristocrats in ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters‰Ûù have pretty much the same attitudes and manners as those of ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù or those of vintage Merchant Ivory films.

Maps show how the region was divided into duchies. Period etchings portray the atrocities of the French Revolution. But the revolution‰Ûªs impact on the rest of Europe is mentioned in passing. Its barbarism shook Schiller‰Ûªs belief that humanity would evolve ‰ÛÏthrough knowledge and the sight of true beauty.‰Ûù But that is just a remark in a screenplay that barely glosses the intellectual ferment of post-Enlightenment Europe and pays scant attention to his writing or literary influence.

This sprawling 170-minute film, which fits squarely into the ‰ÛÏMasterpiece Theater‰Ûù school of historical melodrama, is pleasing to look at and has earnest performances by Mr. Stetter as the rakish, pretty-boy poet who resembles a younger Hugh Grant, and Henriette Confurius and Hannah Herzsprung as his paramours, Charlotte von Lengefeld and her older sister, Caroline.

Caroline, under Schiller‰Ûªs tutelage, writes the period equivalent of a page turner, and the movie shows her buckling under his stern editorial control. After his death, Caroline wrote Schiller‰Ûªs biography, but destroyed their correspondence and made no mention of their relationship. To some degree, ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters‰Ûù is speculative fiction.

When he meets Caroline, their mutual attraction is instantaneous, and Schiller and the two passionately devoted sisters become a romantic triumvirate. It is Caroline‰Ûªs idea that they vow complete honesty. Pressured by Caroline, Charlotte marries Schiller, who is so self-centered he falls asleep in the next room while Charlotte gives agonizing birth. As played by Ms. Confurius, Charlotte is a radiant screen presence, but her personality is not defined.

Under the noses of the outwardly prim Weimar society, the three carry on a protracted love triangle after swearing a pact of unbreakable loyalty and total honesty; the film makes much of the coded correspondence in letters they exchange. As the story gallops from 1787 to 1802 (three years before Schiller‰Ûªs death), a narrator helps fill in the gaps. But the picturesque film is a long, increasingly bumpy ride as new characters suddenly take center stage and the locations shift.

Like the 1991 movie ‰ÛÏImpromptu,‰Ûù which amusedly observed the romantic furor surrounding the composers Liszt and Chopin, ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters‰Ûù portrays the European culture heroes of yesteryear as the pop stars of their time. Here, they are Schiller and his friend and supporter Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. One of the livelier scenes shows the residents of Rudolstadt gathered at their windows to glimpse Goethe‰Ûªs return from a sojourn in Italy.

Charlotte is the first to meet Schiller when he passes by a window and asks for directions. His play ‰ÛÏThe Robbers‰Ûù has already established his reputation as a promising writer, but he is penniless and reliant on the patronage of his married mistress Charlotte von Kalb (a fiery Anne SchÌ_fer), whom he abruptly dumps.

A frail, handsome artistic genius and the women who fuss and fight over him: That not-so-novel concept powers the German director Dominik Graf‰Ûªs sumptuous, soaked-in-suds costume drama, ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters.‰Ûù The movie, Germany‰Ûªs candidate for the best foreign-language Oscar, imagines a fraught mÌ©nage ÌÊ trois of the German poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller (Florian Stetter) and two sisters.

Caroline is the engine driving the story, and Ms. Herzsprung gives a seething layered performance as this headstrong repressed sensualist, herself a writer. Since the death of the von Lengefeld family paterfamilias, Caroline‰Ûªs propitious but passionless marriage to a stuffy Weimar courtier, Friedrich von Beulwitz (Andreas Pietschmann) has saved the family from ruin.
With its dearth of substance and its wandering focus, this is a middlebrow bodice-ripper posing as an epic that hasn‰Ûªt the foggiest idea of what it wants to say.

The hostage takers are Nigerians who want to free a young activist back home, Ebiere (Mbong Amata, the director‰Ûªs wife). She‰Ûªs in prison facing execution, and the movie is mostly an extended recap showing how she mobilized opposition to an oil company ‰ÛÓ based on Royal Dutch Shell and led by a predictably slimy executive (Mickey Rourke) ‰ÛÓ after a deadly explosion.

Mr. Amata (who reportedly adapted this film from an earlier feature) retains the emphatic Nollywood acting style, which almost becomes a form of agitprop. Every other conversation feels as if conducted at or beyond the pitch of an argument; a crowd is invariably watching. Violence isn‰Ûªt held back: Oil protesters are beaten, even raped. Mr. Amata also reserves some disdain for his compatriots, showing elders divvying up hush money.

There‰Ûªs a go-for-broke vigor to the way Mr. Amata cuts to the conflict in most scenes, but the heavy-handedness across the board imposes some significant limitations. Mr. Amata, though, pulls no punches with his ending.

There are no half-measures in the Nigerian brand of moviemaking called Nollywood: ‰ÛÏBlack November,‰Ûù a blood-for-oil drama directed by Jeta Amata, with a mix of Nigerian and American actors, opens with a hostage crisis in a Los Angeles tunnel. It unfolds in flashbacks to corruption and protests in the oil-rich Niger Delta, where Mr. Amata stages as many face-offs and tirades as he can, bringing a full-on pulp style and speechifying to a fraught subject.

Despite Mr. Stormare‰Ûªs valiant efforts, ‰ÛÏDark Summer‰Ûù (directed by Paul Solet) feels listlessly plotted and insipidly performed. Sustained only by a discordant soundtrack and two equally colorless friends, Daniel responds to disturbing dreams and poltergeist shenanigans with a single bug-eyed expression and twitchy demeanor.

There is gore and there is death, but the flowering of the special effects is countered by the contraction and darkening of the images, until Daniel‰Ûªs house becomes a dungeon, and we all feel as trapped as he does.

There is something profoundly draining and suffocatingly incestuous about watching a film that‰Ûªs dedicated to watching a computer screen. It‰Ûªs as if directors hoped to lure audiences away from their hand-held and desktop devices by focusing on characters who are glued to their own. All they‰Ûªre likely to end up with, however, are movies that hardly ever move.

‰ÛÏDark Summer‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt entirely motionless, but you‰Ûªll have to wait so long for Mike Le‰Ûªs story to get off its backside that you might give up before Daniel (Keir Gilchrist), a 17-year-old hacker under house arrest, becomes the victim of his online obsession. That would be Mona (Grace Phipps), a witchy-looking crush and the unwilling target of Daniel‰Ûªs cyberstalking ‰ÛÓ hence the bracelet on his ankle and the crabby attentions of an unkempt parole officer (Peter Stormare, showing his younger colleagues what acting is supposed to look like).
Interweaving multiple perspectives and three generations of family memories, Yael Reuveny‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFarewell Herr Schwarz‰Ûù traces a Holocaust mystery with stumbling curiosity and endearing sincerity.

In light of that possibility, Uwe‰Ûªs desire to move his father‰Ûªs remains (he died in 1987) to a Jewish cemetery feels presumptuous and even disrespectful, but the film reaches higher and wider than specific events. Employing a businesslike tone and unfussy photography, Ms. Reuveny muses on the way catastrophic events ‰ÛÓ and fractured family stories ‰ÛÓ can change who we are. In the process, she leaves many questions unanswered, but that‰Ûªs partly because there are some that she declines to ask.

‰ÛÏThere are issues you don‰Ûªt touch,‰Ûù Ms. Reuveny‰Ûªs mother says, as her daughter and Peter‰Ûªs son, Uwe, work to reunite the sundered branches of their family. What those issues might be is the film‰Ûªs most tantalizing, and uninvestigated, thread. The more we learn about Peter ‰ÛÓ who celebrated Christmas, played soccer with his former captors and whose brother-in-law had been a Wehrmacht soldier ‰ÛÓ the more we wonder why his political affiliations are never explored. Was his seeming rejection of Judaism, and forgiveness of his persecutors, a consequence of embracing Communism?

At the center is Feiv‰Ûªke Schwarz, Ms. Reuveny‰Ûªs great-uncle, a Pole who survived Buchenwald only to change his name to Peter and settle in Soviet-occupied Germany ‰ÛÓ a stone‰Ûªs throw from the satellite camp where he had been imprisoned. There, he married a German gentile, had two children and never spoke of his former life. His sister, meanwhile, believing him dead, had moved to what would become Israel and raised her own family.
Helmer, the son, is taciturn and defensively brusque, and Ms. Leopold‰Ûªs hushed rural story watches his ever-so-gradual thaw against the lonely, wintry backdrop of Dutch farm country.

‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs All So Quiet‰Ûù ends with a shot appropriately similar to the opening scene of the film ‰ÛÏBoyhood,‰Ûù with its coming-of-age promise: the protagonist lying in a field, wondering what comes next.

Ms. Leopold‰Ûªs previous film, ‰ÛÏBrownian Movement,‰Ûù was a stringent, even off-putting study of a delicate-looking doctor who has secret trysts with various men, and her latest feature feels gentler, shot digitally and suffused with the gray shadows of old houses and dim twilights. But it‰Ûªs just as concerned with the immediacy of desire; much of Helmer‰Ûªs reserve is bound up in longings he hasn‰Ûªt expressed, though an agonizingly shy milk truck driver and then a young farmhand seem open to forging a connection.

In ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs All So Quiet,‰Ûù the Dutch filmmaker Nanouk Leopold brings us close to a middle-aged farmer who‰Ûªs looking after his bedridden father, and looking ahead to the changes that are likely to occur when the old man dies.

Helmer (Jeroen Willems, who has something of Michael Shannon‰Ûªs brooding, minus the crazy) keeps dairy cows and sheep. He‰Ûªs already preparing for change, moving his father upstairs to an emptied-out bedroom (with not-so-passive aggression), and renovating the living room. We feel the weight of the older man‰Ûªs body whenever Helmer has to heave him to or from the bed; it‰Ûªs the burden of an intimacy the son is ready to leave behind.

Amusing as Mr. Perry is, it is Mr. Martin and Mr. Peranson‰Ûªs exuberant, often lyrical imagery that distinguishes ‰ÛÏLa Ì_ltima PelÌ_cula‰Ûù (‰ÛÏThe Last Movie‰Ûù in Spanish). The movie revels in multiple film stocks (with hairs or threads often on the camera lens) and self-conscious ‰ÛÏLast Movie‰Ûù flourishes (long intervals between credits, ‰ÛÏscene missing‰Ûù title cards, a version of ‰ÛÏMe and Bobby McGee‰Ûù) while maintaining its blithe humor. Mr. Hopper, the onetime enfant terrible, would be pleased.

Raya Martin and Mark Peranson‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLa Ì_ltima PelÌ_cula‰Ûù is a goofy, dazzling riff on Hopper‰Ûªs ambitious if flawed picture. Alex Ross Perry, best known as a director (‰ÛÏListen Up Philip‰Ûù), plays Alex, a pretentious filmmaker visiting Mexico to scout locations in the YucatÌÁn. Attired in cowboy wear evoking Mr. Hopper‰Ûªs in ‰ÛÏThe Last Movie,‰Ûù Alex says his movie will herald the death of civilization and celluloid. As he makes fatuous pronouncements to the exasperation of his guide (Gabino RodrÌ_guez), he surveys Mayan ruins, visits a pole-dance joint, disdainfully observes meditating Americans, canoodles with a journalist (Iazua Larios), likens himself to Orson Welles and is tossed into jail.

In 1971, the actor-director Dennis Hopper, flush with success from his directorial debut, ‰ÛÏEasy Rider,‰Ûù made ‰ÛÏThe Last Movie,‰Ûù ostensibly a final, definitive statement about the medium but a notorious box office bomb. About a stuntman (Mr. Hopper) who leaves a film production in Peru to live among the locals, the movie, in its ragged, druggy way, aimed to be both a comment on Hollywood cultural imperialism and an apocalyptic examination of fiction versus reality.

The noir atmospherics seem to have been included largely because the story jumps in and out of 1945, or perhaps because the writer-director brothers Peter and Michael Spierig like tipping their fedoras to film history. Whatever the case, after the bandages come off in one decade, the newly mustachioed temporal agent turns up tending bar in another, pouring shots for a man curiously known only as the Unmarried Mother (Sarah Snook, wearing a sneer and a sack suit). The Unmarried Mother writes confession stories from the women‰Ûªs angle, one he knows intimately. He has a story to tell, which begins with ‰ÛÏWhen I was a little girl‰Ûù and leaps across the years and yawning gaps in logic.

Although he disappears for large stretches, Mr. Hawke serves as both the narrator and the story‰Ûªs ballast amid all the woo-woo interludes and disruptions, the puzzle piece you hold and worry about even as the scenery changes and identities shift. His temporal agent contains sly multitudes and could easily have become a gimmick, but Mr. Hawke brings enough pathos and soul to his performance that the conceit soon becomes a man ‰ÛÓ well, for starters.

The source for all this jumpy action is Robert A. Heinlein‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAll You Zombies,‰Ûù a mind-and-body-bending short-story classic that he wrote in 1958. From its many temporal and sexual kinks, the story suggests that Mr. Heinlein was looking to dust off H. G. Wells‰Ûªs time-travel machinations with some 1950s-style transgender sizzle borrowed from one of the tale‰Ûªs touchstones, Christine Jorgensen. This is a story that doesn‰Ûªt just swallow its tail, it eats itself whole, but Mr. Heinlein‰Ûªs narrative sleights of hand are very much of a piece with his playful take on identity. The Spierigs more or less untangle the proceedings enough so that you grasp how the Unmarried Woman became a he and ‰ÛÓ over time ‰ÛÓ the pivot and whatzit. Peter Spierig also wrote the music, though not the stealthily meaningful song ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm My Own Grandpa.‰Ûù

He is and isn‰Ûªt, as the story‰Ûªs multiple twists gradually, if not altogether too clearly, reveal. The movie opens with a misterioso figure whose face is obscured by a fedora and some clever camera angles and editing. There‰Ûªs a boom, a mess of melting flesh and, shortly thereafter, the temporal agent is in bed with his face wrapped in bandages, much like Humphrey Bogart‰Ûªs in the 1947 noir ‰ÛÏDark Passage.‰Ûù In that film (based on a David Goodis novel), Bogart‰Ûªs character, wrongly accused of murder, undergoes plastic surgery to avoid recapture. ‰ÛÏPredestination‰Ûù similarly plays around with enduring topics like fate and imprisonment, metaphysical and otherwise, and pins them on a character forced to change identities. But it also tosses in a whole lot of time travel.
‰ÛÏPredestination‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Science-fiction violence.

Jumping across time and space is tough, thankless business in ‰ÛÏPredestination,‰Ûù a slab of science-fiction speculation draped in old-fashioned detective story crepe. The story centers on a temporal agent, a futuristic enforcer (he tries to right wrongs before they happen) nicely played by Ethan Hawke with a hungry, hangdog look that suggests that his character has spent long nights howling in the wasteland, often without either a scrap or a prayer. Whether slinking through 1985 or another vintage year (usually while chasing down a bomber), the temporal agent looks like a classic lone wolf.

Ms. Snook looks remarkably like a Leonardo DiCaprio cousin when duded up, but is more persuasive when dolled up in period dresses with a slash of red lipstick. She smoothly maneuvers through the labyrinthine plot and in and out of his-and-her threads, but the character might have worked better, particularly for the would-be shocker ending, with someone with less natural va-va-voom appeal.

A postcard from an old high school acquaintance (Linds Edwards) who has entered a monastery intensifies her spiritual curiosity, but the movie doesn‰Ûªt look to religion for salvation or explanation. Examining a more generalized discontent through the lens of one woman‰Ûªs pain, the writer and director, Paul Harrill, concentrates instead on the ordinary details that constitute a life and the way small choices nudge us toward larger ones.

Modestly presented but emotionally ambitious ‰ÛÓ and with a lovely, low-key performance from Ms. Shelton ‰ÛÓ this immersive first feature gently reveals the void of an adulthood on autopilot. Peggy‰Ûªs transformation isn‰Ûªt earthshaking, just a gradual evolution from quiet desperation to something like hope.

Marked by the changing seasons and delicately shot (by Kunitaro Ohi) over a single year, ‰ÛÏSomething, Anything‰Ûù is about uncoupling ‰ÛÓ conscious or otherwise ‰ÛÓ and recalibrating. As Peggy divests herself of the trappings of fast-track success, her actions alienate her former friends and mystify her recently estranged husband.

The carmine nail polish that Peggy (Ashley Shelton), a young real estate agent in Knoxville, Tenn., applies so carefully at the beginning of ‰ÛÏSomething, Anything‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt the film‰Ûªs only facade. Before the opening credits have faded, Peggy has married a handsome go-getter (Bryce Johnson), become pregnant and settled in an enviable starter home. But there‰Ûªs something adrift in her expression, and when a personal tragedy slaps her into awareness, she suspects that the life she has passively accepted may not be the one she wants.
A Civil War legacy cascades through the backwoods of North Carolina in the 1970s in ‰ÛÏThe World Made Straight,‰Ûù an overcooked adaptation of a novel by Ron Rash.

But while Leonard lives with ‰ÛÓ and enables ‰ÛÓ a sexpot addict (Minka Kelly), he is clearly labeled erudite and softhearted. (He plays a record of Aaron Copland‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAppalachian Spring‰Ûù in his trailer home.) Leonard prompts Travis‰Ûªs interest in nearby Civil War history, in which both men‰Ûªs families played a role.
‰ÛÏThe World Made Straight‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Drugs, guns, rape.

Travis (Jeremy Irvine), who never finished high school, steals marijuana growing on the property of Carlton (Steve Earle), a vicious broker for the area‰Ûªs pill poppers. He sells the pot to Leonard (a disheveled Noah Wyle), a former teacher who deals drugs. Leonard‰Ûªs past is cloudy: A mutual friend (Haley Joel Osment, trying too hard to shed his fresh-faced image from ‰ÛÏThe Sixth Sense‰Ûù) has heard that he shot a man.

The sense of a place frozen in time may be why the period setting must be gleaned more from the florid, twangy dialogue than from production design. But the finale, in which blood rivalries are redressed in an absurdly literal manner, fatally strains credulity.

With a screenplay by Shane Danielsen, who has worked as a journalist covering movies, ‰ÛÏThe World Made Straight‰Ûù sometimes suggests a tidier cousin to ‰ÛÏWinter‰Ûªs Bone,‰Ûù another coming-of-age story in which codes and vendettas loom larger than the outside world.

Mr. Syeed is an American of Kashmiri descent, whose father abandoned his homeland after being imprisoned for participating in the Kashmiri independence movement. His film observes the world through the eyes of Gulzar, who was brought up to believe that Dal Lake was the most perfect place on earth. Although the lake, still beautiful in the movie, is a spoiled paradise, increasingly polluted by trash, its teeming aquatic life threatened.

‰ÛÏValley of Saints‰Ûù finds a poignant humanity in this chaste romance, which awakens in Gulzar a wondrous sense of possibility, along with a new awareness of the world‰Ûªs complexity. As he says in a voice-over at the end of the movie: ‰ÛÏThe world was not meant to be perfect. It‰Ûªs like this lake. It only reflects what‰Ûªs on it.‰Ûù

This movie focuses on Gulzar (Gulzar Bhat), a man in his 20s who lives with his uncle in a tumbledown shack and ekes out a living as a guide. Gulzar dreams of leaving the area to seek a better life with his best friend, Afzal (Afzal Sofi), but their plans are disrupted when a military curfew is imposed in Srinagar, a city of nearly a million and the regional capital.

The only outside view belongs to Asifa (Neelofar Hamid), a prim Kashmiri-American environmental scientist who is studying the water pollution and staying on a houseboat owned by Gulzar‰Ûªs neighbor. When the curfew leaves her stranded, Gulzar is asked to look in on her and make sure she is well fed. Gulzar, accompanied by Afzal, brings her food, and the two begin a rivalry for her affection that threatens their friendship. When she suffers from indigestion, Gulzar finds her medication. Asifa helpfully volunteers to show them how to make a composting toilet, but Afzal lashes out at what he feels is her condescending attitude. Ferrying her around the lake while Afzal seethes with envy, the semiliterate Gulzar regales her with short, heartfelt original poems. There is no suggestion of sex, only a passing shot of their hands brushing.

Dal Lake, the setting of Musa Syeed‰Ûªs small glowing film ‰ÛÏValley of Saints,‰Ûù is a picturesque body of water in the Kashmir region where tourists flock to have boatmen take them to sites with names like Floating Garden and Lotus Lake. The water is dotted with small man-made islands.

This low-key, beautifully photographed movie portrays Gulzar and Afzal as innocents who are stuck in a kind of permanent adolescence born of poverty, lack of education and a puritanical Islamic culture. Some of the loveliest scenes show them affectionately roughhousing.
But there‰Ûªs little story to speak of, beyond Mr. Neeson‰Ûªs racing around fighting for the truth, pursued by a Los Angeles detective (Forest Whitaker).
‰ÛÏTaken 3‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Intense violence and action, and brief strong language.

After ‰ÛÏNon-Stop,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏUnknown‰Ûù and three installments of the ‰ÛÏTaken‰Ûù thrillers, I‰Ûªm not sure that Liam Neeson‰Ûªs signature avengers are actually good people to know. On the plus side, they‰Ûªll use any means necessary to rescue you from kidnappers and killers. But if you‰Ûªve been kidnapped or are facing death, it‰Ûªs probably directly related to knowing Mr. Neeson‰Ûªs character in the first place, or just being nearby.

The logy screenplay, by Luc Besson and Robert Mark Kamen, sags under head-clutchingly banal dramatic scenes. Only Mr. Neeson‰Ûªs appeal somehow survives unscathed, perhaps the most impressive stunt of all.

In ‰ÛÏTaken 3‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Olivier Megaton‰Ûªs embarrassingly flat sequel about the retired government agent Bryan Mills (Mr. Neeson) ‰ÛÓ the agent‰Ûªs daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace), and his former wife, Lenore (Famke Janssen), run into grief yet again. One dies; the other cries; and it all has something to do with a pale Russian gangster (Sam Spruell) and the latest rich-jerk husband (Dougray Scott) to succeed Bryan.
More important, Mr. Megaton‰Ûªs direction of action sequences borders on atrocious. Ragged camerawork and editing ruin freeway car chases and hand-to-hand combat alike.

A running fantasy of wronged divorced-dad nobility, the series here continues its ritualized plot points. Mr. Neeson babies Kimmy with a childish gift and balks at some completely normal step in her adulthood. He has a barbecue with the fellas (also veterans of covert ops). He makes a very serious cellphone call or two, announcing that someone is being taken, or giving very clear directions. He becomes a righteous fugitive whose rampages (up to and including waterboarding) are rationalized through fatherhood.

With its occasional cab rides and street scenes, ‰ÛÏMatch‰Ûù gives the appearance of a play nervously opened up. Every reversal arrives programmatically, as if driven by a mere need for twists, while Stephen Trask‰Ûªs mushy score soothes the blows. The movie pulls the rug out from under the audience several times, but in the end there is not much underneath.

Mr. Stewart applies his deceptively shaded efforts to a contrived confrontation scenario. The writer and director, Stephen Belber, has made one of these before: His play ‰ÛÏTape‰Ûù was filmed in 2001 by Richard Linklater, who used jittery digital video to augment the pressure-cooker atmosphere.
‰ÛÏMatch‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex talk, cannabis.

It may be a tribute to Patrick Stewart‰Ûªs performance in ‰ÛÏMatch‰Ûù that it takes some time to be sure that it‰Ûªs a good performance. As Tobi, a dance instructor at Juilliard, Mr. Stewart offers a study in self-protective vanity. The character ‰ÛÓ flamboyant, forever peppering his chatter with French phrases and far too insistent that his guests eat the party mix ‰ÛÓ is at once extroverted and antisocial, a combination easy to overplay.

In ‰ÛÏMatch,‰Ûù which starred Frank Langella when it appeared on Broadway in 2004, the nature of the confrontation is initially unclear. The couple Lisa (Carla Gugino) and Mike (Matthew Lillard) have come to New York from Seattle, ostensibly to interview Tobi for Lisa‰Ûªs dissertation. But it‰Ûªs obvious, from Mike‰Ûªs hostility and furtive checking of photographs in Tobi‰Ûªs apartment, that something else is at stake.

‰ÛÏPlay‰Ûù makes the barbed implication that the thieves go unchallenged because those who might stop them fear appearing racist. But it is provocative simply in showing how trust is gained and kept, even after the swindled kids have understood their robbers‰Ûª motives. (Given that this is Sweden, perhaps they‰Ûªre experiencing an unusually literal form of Stockholm syndrome.)

These methods come into even fuller view in ‰ÛÏPlay,‰Ûù which screened at the 2011 New York Film Festival. Inspired by news reports in Sweden, the film focuses on a group of black teenagers from immigrant families in Gothenburg. The boys have a recurring scam: Pretending that a sibling has lost a cellphone, they persuade kids from more affluent backgrounds to hand over theirs, getting their marks to comply with the robbery.

Ruben Ostlund achieved a modest breakthrough with his fourth feature, ‰ÛÏForce Majeure,‰Ûù Sweden‰Ûªs submission for the Oscars, but his interest in social expectations and machismo is hardly new. The Film Society of Lincoln Center is holding a retrospective of Mr. Ostlund‰Ûªs movies through Jan. 22. The series, titled In Case of No Emergency: The Films of Ruben Ostlund, includes the three features that preceded ‰ÛÏForce Majeure,‰Ûù all receiving their first runs in New York.

The bitterly funny, multistrand ‰ÛÏInvoluntary,‰Ûù from 2008, is a step forward in the director‰Ûªs ambition. At a birthday party, a patriarch suffers an eye injury but resists leaving for medical help. Discovering a broken curtain rod, a bus driver refuses to proceed until a passenger confesses to having caused the damage. A teacher who has just finished a lesson on influence catches a colleague striking a child. She mentions the offense in a faculty lounge, only to face ostracism. A man won‰Ûªt leave his buddies‰Ûª getaway trip even after he is sexually assaulted.

‰ÛÏThe Guitar Mongoloid,‰Ûù Mr. Ostlund‰Ûªs 2004 debut, begins as a free-floating portrait of mischief and compulsion ‰ÛÓ a cousin to Harmony Korine‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGummo‰Ûù that comments obliquely on fascism and violence. A scene of Russian roulette looks forward to Mr. Ostlund‰Ûªs later studies of peer pressure.
Until the end, any overt brutality is within the group: A black teenager who tries to quit is beaten by his peers. The ambient soundtrack enhances the sense of outsiders‰Ûª indifference.

This filmmaker‰Ûªs chilly, detached style has been compared to that of the Austrian director Michael Haneke, but Mr. Ostlund is a more astute chronicler of behavior. His long takes suggest a psychologist observing group dynamics.

In all of his films, Mr. Ostlund employs vehicles of transit ‰ÛÓ buses, trains, trams ‰ÛÓ as spaces for examining the power (or futility) of public surveillance. Deep focus lets him capture multiple planes at once, showing actions and reactions in the same shot.
GIUSEPPE MAKES A MOVIE
Directed by Adam Rifkin
Opens on Thursday

Shot in motels and borrowed rooms, the dollar-store productions of Giuseppe Andrews make John Waters‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPink Flamingos‰Ûù look like ‰ÛÏGone With the Wind.‰Ûù As we learn in Adam Rifkin‰Ûªs new documentary, ‰ÛÏGiuseppe Makes a Movie,‰Ûù Mr. Andrews‰Ûªs real idols are Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Luis BuÌ±uel, but he shares Mr. Waters‰Ûªs love of filthy dialogue.

Mr. Rifkin follows this wiry young director as he rounds up his neighbors at a trailer park (and assorted transients) to shoot his latest opus. Mr. Andrews casts people from the margins of society (in Ventura, Calif.) as the stars in his colorfully written yarns, which he shoots in as little as three days. (One, ‰ÛÏGarbanzo Gas,‰Ûù is about a cow on an all-expenses-paid vacation from the slaughterhouse.) Mr. Rifkin‰Ûªs own style is rough and ready, and efficient. We quickly grasp Mr. Andrews‰Ûªs casual appeal and how his films resemble community theater productions.

Despite the poverty of his collaborators, Mr. Andrews, who seems to live on sardines and rice, doesn‰Ûªt feel like an exploiter. He calls his friends ‰ÛÏbeautiful eccentrics,‰Ûù which aptly describes him, too. NICOLAS RAPOLD
1 hour 22 minutes; not rated

His actors are not professionals, but they have experience, from drug addiction to homelessness to war. ‰ÛÏVietnam Ron,‰Ûù for example, looks like a wild-haired mountain man, as Mr. Andrews puts it, with ghostly eyes and a rugged energy. Mr. Andrews, an admirer of European art-house films, has in fact acted in Hollywood films, most notably ‰ÛÏDetroit Rock City,‰Ûù which Mr. Rifkin directed, among others.

Capturing the poetry of bodies at rest and a landscape frozen in time (filming was done primarily in the Santa Clarita area of California), Chayse Irvin‰Ûªs exquisite 35-millimeter photography is dreamy and sometimes devastating. In his hands, the vulnerability of a baby‰Ûªs fist and the weary tilt of a sunburned neck are as rich as any monologue.

Rifts and resentments, infidelity and first love are revealed, but what‰Ûªs most striking is Mr. Pallaoro‰Ûªs clear and consistent vision of a home awash in silence and emotional detachment. When the volume turns up ‰ÛÓ during an explosive family dinner, for instance ‰ÛÓ the effect is shockingly primal. In one scene, Christina‰Ûªs baby lies gurgling on a bed as she and her lover copulate noisily a few feet away. And in another, more wrenching moment, the same infant screams pitifully while two siblings sit close by. It never occurs to them to soothe the child with sounds or a lullaby.

Almost from the outset, we can sense the coming storm as Ennis (Brian F. O‰ÛªByrne), a stern dairy farmer plagued by debt and drought, relaxes at a bucolic lake with his wife, Christina (Catalina Sandino Moreno), and their five children. Gradually we learn that Christina is deaf, the children‰Ûªs playful signing with her in stark contrast to their almost flinching obedience to their father.

A slow, mesmeric slide into heartbreak and horror, ‰ÛÏMedeas,‰Ûù the ravishing first feature from the Italian director Andrea Pallaoro, effortlessly conveys a family‰Ûªs disintegration with few words and even fewer miscalculations.

Another, more benign hacker turned prisoner, Hathaway is first seen reading Jean Baudrillard‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe System of Objects,‰Ûù a neo-Marxist critique of the commodification of everyday life. Also adorning Hathaway‰Ûªs shelves is ‰ÛÏDiscipline and Punish,‰Ûù Michel Foucault‰Ûªs inquiry into modern penal systems and disciplinary technologies of power, including surveillance. The nods to these heavyweights happen in an eye blink, and they felt gratuitous and self-conscious the first time I saw ‰ÛÏBlackhat.‰Ûù (Jean-FranÌ_ois Lyotard‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Postmodern Condition‰Ûù is also on the shelf, as is Jacques Derrida.)

The jampacked story, pegged to a shadow hacker stirring up global trouble, could have been gleaned from the latest news. The inspiration for the script, by Morgan Davis Foehl, was an attack on the Natanz uranium enrichment plant in Iran by malware deployed through USB flash drives. The movie opens with an explosion at a nuclear power plant in Hong Kong, where Chinese officials call in Chen Dawai (Wang Leehom), who in turn taps his sister, Lien (Ms. Tang), for help and then an old school friend, Nick Hathaway (Mr. Hemsworth).

A few times, though, notably during a chaotic fight in a crowded Jakarta square that turns multitudes into a streaming network, the locations feel like an directorial extravagance and a mistake. Those bodies are finally too decorative and disposable, and the ease with which they fall undercuts the movie‰Ûªs moral seriousness. Mr. Mann fares better in more intimately scaled scenes, whether inside a restaurant with Hathaway and Lien or out on the street with some joltingly personal shootouts. Whether his characters are making love or war, Mr. Mann often captures them in tight close-ups that thrust their faces into the foreground of the shot. It‰Ûªs a visual choice that briefly isolates these men and women from a world that, like everyone else, they‰Ûªre desperate to comprehend.

Mr. Hemsworth is a brooding Adonis best known for playing Thor in the big-screen cartoons who should be better known for playing a racecar driver in the undersung ‰ÛÏRush.‰Ûù He has a pallor and hard-body physique that don‰Ûªt jibe with the usual mental snapshot of the puny, pasty criminal hacker, even if his bulk makes sense as a jailhouse defense. He isn‰Ûªt a persuasive typist (he was tutored on his keyboard fingerwork), but what he does have is a natural pensiveness bordering on melancholy that creates a nice frisson with his bulging muscles and heartthrob looks. You can see him diving into thought, which works for a role that requires his character to serve as our conduit for a lot of jargon. His strong physicality also works with the movie‰Ûªs sense of hacking and other tech work as labor.

All this face time with blinking screens is in the service of the story‰Ûªs turns, many of which involve following the digital trail left by the hacker who infiltrated the nuclear plant. That initially makes ‰ÛÏBlackhat‰Ûù a cat-and-mouse game, one that shifts into high-action gear with the introduction of the hacker‰Ûªs army of thugs, whose apparatus of choice is a machine gun and whose leader is a dead-eyed enforcer, Elias (an excellent Ritchie Coster). The chase takes Hathaway and company through computer networks, a pursuit that Mr. Mann at times represents by plunging deep into the physical networks, running straight into the guts of the machine, much as he did in ‰ÛÏThief‰Ûù when he pushed his camera in for a peek inside a lock cylinder as it‰Ûªs being picked.

A maximalist, Mr. Mann crams a great deal into the movie‰Ûªs fleet two-hour running time, including the nuclear mishap, a commodities run-up, some cyber-slapstick with the National Security Agency and the specter of 9/11. Once Hathaway has been cut loose from federal lockup with an ankle monitor, he joins a stellar backup team tasked with catching the power-plant hacker that includes Viola Davis on lead. Her character, Carol Barrett, is an agent for the F.B.I. whose reddish wig, plumy lashes and cavalcade of weary sighs and devastating deadpan stares are among the movie‰Ûªs best special effects. Barrett serves as Hathaway‰Ûªs handler and coordinates the American team with the Chinese, while Ms. Davis‰Ûªs fine-grained performance deepens the movie‰Ûªs emotional texture.

Like the safecracker played by James Caan in ‰ÛÏThief,‰Ûù Mr. Mann‰Ûªs 1981 thriller, Hathaway is defined ‰ÛÓ as a man and professional, but also as a friend, lover and target ‰ÛÓ through his job. The characters in ‰ÛÏBlackhat‰Ûù spend a great deal of time staring at screens and making like Rachmaninoff with their keyboards, a familiar image for the increasing numbers of people who are plugged in for work, play or both, even as they‰Ûªre increasingly disconnected from the physical world. This disconnect and its dangers are something of a refrain in the movie and are invoked in Hathaway‰Ûªs prison-house philosophy (when not perusing Baudrillard, he connects mind and body by, um, doing ironman push-ups) and in the conceit of faceless terrorists who, hidden in a virtual world, wreak damage on human beings.
‰ÛÏBlackhat‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Extreme gun and blade violence.

Michael Mann‰Ûªs thriller ‰ÛÏBlackhat,‰Ûù a story about the intersection of bodies and machines, is a spectacular work of unhinged moviemaking. By turns brutal and sentimental, lovely and lurid, as serious as the grave and blissfully preposterous, it combines a truckload of plot with many of the obsessions, tropes, sights and sounds that distinguish his other movies, from kinetic gun battles to cool beauties gazing into the distance in sunglasses. Here those beauties are a pair of improbable computer savants, played by Chris Hemsworth and Tang Wei, who race, jet and furiously bang on keyboards across the globe while chasing villainy, lines of code and millions in loot.

The movie‰Ûªs suppositions ‰ÛÓ namely that the world is now a surveillance penitentiary ‰ÛÓ emerge clearly enough that you don‰Ûªt need these intellectual signposts, even if name-dropping philosophers has long been par for the cinematic course for the likes of, say, Jean-Luc Godard. Yet such allusions are of a piece with Mr. Mann‰Ûªs singular hybrid approach, which exists at the crossroads of the classical Hollywood cinema and the European art film and is evident in his oscillation between action and introspection, transformation and stasis, exterior and interior realms.

That‰Ûªs pretty cool, as are the various Far Eastern locations that add palpable density to the movie‰Ûªs thin-looking, at times near-translucent visuals. The contrast between the richness of the action and the thinness of the (still beautiful) images is just one of many dualities that run through the movie, as when Mr. Mann cuts from a fanlike image spreading across a screen to a huge flame shooting out from under a Hong Kong cook‰Ûªs wok. Time and again, he puts computer and other spaces into play visually, mapping a brave new world with images of kaleidoscopically pulsing screens and the jewel-like glittering of nighttime megacities. The practical locations, with real bodies moving through real spaces, underline the idea that something big is still at stake in the physical world.

Because ‰ÛÏAppropriate Behavior‰Ûù is set in Brooklyn and focuses on the romantic confusion and misadventures of Shirin, a headstrong young Iranian-American woman adrift in hipsterland, this lively romantic comedy starring Desiree Akhavan, who wrote and directed, has inevitably been compared to ‰ÛÏGirls.‰Ûù Shirin‰Ûªs brash, off-kilter attitude is not unlike that of Lena Dunham‰Ûªs Hannah Horvath. Both are self-centered, impulsive and brusque. But there are few signs that Shirin possesses Hannah‰Ûªs driving career ambition. When Shirin takes a job teaching filmmaking to kindergartners, the little tykes run her ragged.

Ms. Akhavan‰Ûªs performance makes it clear that Shirin‰Ûªs attraction to men, though genuine, is less intense than her feelings for women, especially for the casually butch Maxine. A major reason for their discord is Maxine‰Ûªs impatience with Shirin‰Ûªs reluctance to come out to her supportive but strait-laced parents, who dote on their soon-to-be married son (Arian Moayed), a doctor. When she finally musters the nerve to tell her mother that she is bisexual, her mother haughtily retorts, ‰ÛÏNo you‰Ûªre not.‰Ûù

The movie jumps around in time so abruptly that you can easily lose your bearings. Shirin‰Ûªs relationship with Maxine begins almost as a whim on the steps of a Park Slope brownstone on New Year‰Ûªs Eve and breaks off just as suddenly, with an eruption that leads to the throwing of bottles. There are no discussions about their relationship or attempts at reconciliation. Boom. It‰Ûªs over.

Ms. Akhavan, who from certain angles resembles Hilary Swank, has a face so expressive that you can hardly avert your eyes once she appears; every few seconds, a little storm passes across her features. Shirin, who calls herself bisexual, is smarting from her breakup with her first girlfriend, Maxine (Rebecca Henderson), whose apartment she exits toting her luggage and a conspicuous strap-on dildo.

Shirin is much more immature than Hannah. Her default expression is the glowering, willful pout of a child on the verge of a tantrum. She leaps headlong into sexual adventures, including a threesome. What drives her isn‰Ûªt desire so much as a bored curiosity. I have no idea if ‰ÛÏAppropriate Behavior‰Ûù presents an accurate picture of the hookup rites of Brooklyn‰Ûªs hipoisie. But these blasÌ© couplings suggest a climate in which the instinct for emotional self-protection dampens erotic passion.

For all its disorganization and lack of an ending or even a sense of direction, ‰ÛÏAppropriate Behavior‰Ûù is alive. The screenplay is packed with smart remarks, clever and unpredictable turns of phrase that knock you off balance. Little set pieces in which Shirin goes shopping for sexy lingerie and takes part in a gay-rights discussion group give you the flavor of a neighborhood in which everyone has an edge. A stoned, laid-back attitude is not the same thing as relaxation.
Opens on Friday

The first of the film‰Ûªs two parts concerns Shahid‰Ûªs son, Sardar (Manoj Bajpayee), as he cements his kingpin status and challenges Ramadhir. The second half centers on Sardar‰Ûªs son Faizal (portrayed as an adult by Nawazuddin Siddiqui). Unlike Michael Corleone in ‰ÛÏThe Godfather,‰Ûù Faizal, in taking the reins from his father, rules more through fear than through sense.

Although the narrative contains echoes of ‰ÛÏThe Godfather‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Godfather Part II‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and perhaps ‰ÛÏCasino,‰Ûù in that much of it is structured as a flashback from an assassination attempt ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏGangs‰Ûù lacks the poetry and character interest of those films.
Directed by Anurag Kashyap

The Indian mob saga ‰ÛÏGangs of Wasseypur‰Ûù is a frequently spectacular achievement: five hours ‰ÛÓ and then some ‰ÛÓ of gliding camera moves, brutal action and dizzying revenge plotting, often set to a peppy pop music backbeat. The violence is graphic and the innuendo raunchy.
In Hindi, with English subtitles
5 hours 20 minutes; not rated

As the political context shifts, there are assorted alliances and rackets (coal, contract schemes, iron, trains, elections), but ‰ÛÏGangs‰Ûù rarely extends its interest beyond the blood rivalries and romantic intrigues. The slickly stylized gunplay recalls ‰ÛÏCity of God.‰Ûù It is odd when, late in the going, Ramadhir says that a key to a gangster‰Ûªs success is realizing that you can‰Ûªt behave as you would in a movie.

Starting in 1941, ‰ÛÏGangs‰Ûù follows three generations in a family of gangsters. Shahid Khan (Jaideep Ahlawat) initiates an almost biblical cycle of reprisals when he impersonates a feared bandit. After independence, later in the decade, he works as muscle for Ramadhir Singh (Tigmanshu Dhulia).
GANGS OF WASSEYPUR

‰ÛÏSpare Parts‰Ûù should have been a slam dunk. Based on the true story of four remarkable teenage boys ‰ÛÓ all poor, undocumented immigrants from Mexico ‰ÛÓ who surmounted incalculable odds to enter a national underwater robotics competition, the movie‰Ûªs setup has underdog appeal in spades.

Yet we barely get to see the brainstorming, designing and testing of the finished robot, and consequently have no real sense of the mountain its makers had to climb. Failing to build drama from an inherently dramatic premise, the director, Sean McNamara, turns instead to deportation worries and an abusive father (an excellent Esai Morales). High-school movie stereotypes ‰ÛÓ like Jamie Lee Curtis as an impossibly hip principal, and Marisa Tomei as a hot teacher who‰Ûªs all about the kids ‰ÛÓ puncture the tone further, and a suggestion of romance between Ms. Tomei‰Ûªs character and Mr. Lopez‰Ûªs is even less credible than Gene Hackman‰Ûªs 1986 pursuit of Barbara Hershey in ‰ÛÏHoosiers.‰Ûù At least they had the excuse of being turned on by basketball.

But it‰Ûªs all for naught in a screenplay, by Elissa Matsueda (working from Joshua Davis‰Ûªs 2005 article in Wired magazine), that plays down intellect in favor of corn and clichÌ©. Each of the young men, students at Carl Hayden Community High School in Phoenix, is permitted a single, identifying trait: the upstanding straight arrow (Carlos PenaVega); the math whiz (David Del Rio); the mechanical genius (JosÌ© JuliÌÁn); and the muscle (Oscar Gutierrez). We meet them less than three months before the contest, as they and their mentor (a disastrously weak George Lopez, playing a composite of two teachers), scramble to find cheap solutions to expensive problems.
Rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Limp flirting and soggy feminine hygiene products.

At a glance, Mr. CÌ«tÌ© simply appears to be essaying different angles on his subject, through montages of pounding machines or of workers wrangling fabrics or chatting on break. Products vary (metal parts, sheets, organs); gender ratios and ethnic makeup shift.

Mr. CÌ«tÌ© comes closer here to his 2012 study of animals, ‰ÛÏBestiaire,‰Ûù than to his recent drama ‰ÛÏVic + Flo Saw a Bear.‰Ûù As with his other features, brevity ‰ÛÓ in this case, 1 hour 10 minutes ‰ÛÓ has a way of making the film seem minor. It‰Ûªs a little diffuse, but it suggests that Mr. CÌ«tÌ© is trying out a sketch, with more experiments to come.

Factories are a byword for drudgery, but they have a certain inherent drama: the mesmerizing and menacing machines, the vivid subjection of people to their labor, the fact that something (usually) is created at the end of the line. In the ruminative semi-fictional film ‰ÛÏJoy of Man‰Ûªs Desiring,‰Ûù the Canadian director Denis CÌ«tÌ© watches men and women on the factory floor with a documentary eye, before trickling in details and dialogue that seem to express the workers‰Ûª humanity.

But the sense of directorial observation gives way to the workers‰Ûª breaking routines with their words. Their expressions take different forms: musing exchanges, blessings murmured over machines, a long story told out of nowhere, repeated workplace catchphrases. Some of it is staged (Mr. CÌ«tÌ© added actors to the mix), but the sentiments are real: frustration, ambivalence, but also satisfaction. (The title is the same as that of a movement of a Bach cantata played in the film.)
