The mutual obligations of a business relationship might occur to you, too, when you pay to see a movie that is technically a comedy, with all the pointlessly foul language, racial and gender stereotypes, stammering, and canine penis-biting that apparently we‰Ûªre supposed to want to see in raunchy movies about pathetic grooms. Mr. Hart tells wild tales, Mr. Gad is humiliated, and most everyone else gets to dish out or receive abuse. But the laughs are not a sure thing.

Jimmy Callahan, the professional best man of ‰ÛÏThe Wedding Ringer,‰Ûù warns his client more than once that theirs is strictly a business relationship. No actual friendship is intended or implied as Jimmy (Kevin Hart) fills the role of best bud for the self-described yutz Doug Harris (Josh Gad) before and during his wedding, for whom he also assembles a team of degenerate groomsmen.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for crude and sexual content, language throughout, some drug use and brief graphic nudity.

Jimmy‰Ûªs role-playing drives home the theme that people aren‰Ûªt always what they pretend to be, especially when there‰Ûªs money to be made. The point is also made that rubes are only given the hackneyed fantasies they want anyway, even if they‰Ûªre harmful or offensive. That‰Ûªs certainly one perspective, but then, there‰Ûªs no need to buy into it.

The director Jeremy Garelick, who wrote the script with Jay Lavender, takes the shortest route whenever possible, which usually means a gratuitous insult. There‰Ûªs some cynical fun in Mr. Hart‰Ûªs faked wedding speeches, though that‰Ûªs not exactly fresh material. Among the diligently hurried scenes, the gratifyingly ordinary Mr. Gad pipes up with some well-timed mild asides.
LIFE INSIDE OUT

In ‰ÛÏLife Inside Out,‰Ûù Laura (Maggie Baird), a mother of three who earns some money as a baker, picks up the guitar she put down at 19, after her mother‰Ûªs death, and tries open-mike night at a club. At first this surprises her family, but ‰ÛÏLife Inside Out‰Ûù is neither a stealth version of a Douglas Sirk melodrama nor a film about a star in the making. This low-key drama so insistently resists epiphanies that it verges on bland.

Laura stands up to her bossy, artsy sister (Lori Nasso, who wrote the script with Ms. Baird). Laura and her husband (David Cowgill) level with each other about the household‰Ûªs strained economics. She gains a new perspective on her son Shane (Finneas O‰ÛªConnell), the object of scorn from his older twin brothers. He turns out to be a gifted guitarist and a natural songwriting partner, inspired by his adolescent angst.
Directed by Jill D‰ÛªAgnenica
Opens on Friday
1 hour 42 minutes; not rated

During a brief scene of Shane and Laura composing ‰ÛÓ he on guitar, she on piano ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs easy to see how ‰ÛÏLife Inside Out‰Ûù could have left a larger effect, though recalling the songs afterward is almost as difficult as remembering the movie‰Ûªs title. (The stars do their own singing.) Other recent films in which unlikely singing duos find themselves ‰ÛÓ whether it‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏOnce‰Ûù or the little-noticed ‰ÛÏLove Hunter‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ have also avoided ending with a sold-out concert, but ‰ÛÏLife Inside Out‰Ûù is so earnest that Hollywood overkill might have been welcome.

This leaves Owen stranded, which sure doesn‰Ûªt help him but does serve the frustratingly programmatic script, which closes around him like a trap. Its gears grind into place one afternoon in the woods where Owen, trailed by James, meets up with some local boys. It‰Ûªs already been established that the neighborhood spawn are trouble: In an earlier scene, a few grab and break Owen‰Ûªs new MP3 player and it‰Ûªs not entirely clear why he continues to nose around them except that kids make all kinds of stupid mistakes. Mr. Lofland (‰ÛÏMud‰Ûù) has a pretty, wide-open face, which, especially when stilled, can express depths of melancholia and worry. He pulls you in, even when his character errs as grievously as Owen does in those woods.

Among those challenges are Owen‰Ûªs younger brother, James (Beau Wright), a disabled sweetie who insists on tagging after his older sibling, and their emotionally detached mother, Kendra (an underused ChloÌÇ Sevigny), who seems more interested in dyeing her hair than tending to her children. Ms. Sevigny‰Ûªs spiky presence can work like a destabilizing tonic in a movie, and you rarely know where she‰Ûªs going with her characters. Here, though, her emotional reserve or perhaps inability, or refusal to, ingratiate herself with the audience helps stack the deck against Owen. She doesn‰Ûªt have much screen time in ‰ÛÏLittle Accidents,‰Ûù but she only has to cast a chilled look at Owen for it to be clear that he‰Ûªd better not lean on her.

These include a terrible tragedy, an extramarital affair and a new neighborly bond, all of which snuff out the possibility that the personal and the political will go head-to-head here. Ms. Colangelo does some sensitive work with the actors, including in intimate scenes with Amos and Diane, and it‰Ûªs gratifying that Ms. Banks has more to do than play another comic foil. Yet the net effect of the messy bedroom sheets, the marital squabbling and lachrymose, emotional bloodletting is to turn a tragedy into an atmospheric backdrop for three isolated souls, all of whom might have started out considerably less lonely if the movie had a firmer grasp on the world in which they live.

Ms. Colangelo has a feel for the lush, fog-wreathed mountains, which loom somewhat menacingly, and has tapped a fine cast that includes two other valuable performers, Boyd Holbrook and Elizabeth Banks. He plays Amos, a miner and the sole survivor of the accident; she plays Diane, the wife of a mining executive, Bill (Josh Lucas). Amos lives with his father, Basil (James Deforest Parker), a former miner who chases his bad cough with another cigarette and insists that his son stay away from the union representatives. The union wants Amos to testify about the accident, which other miners fear might jeopardize the mine and their livelihood, a promising, politically dynamic conflict that Ms. Colangelo soon submerges under a welter of narrowly personal, melodramatic complications.

The sympathetic young actor Jacob Lofland lights up the American independent movie ‰ÛÏLittle Accidents,‰Ûù an earnest, schematic, pocket-size drama about three people struggling under the weight of a calamity. He plays Owen, the elder of two boys who‰Ûªve recently lost their father in a coal mining accident that has left 10 dead and upended a West Virginia town. Now, amid the region‰Ûªs sweeping green mountains, its ominous mines and traumatized population, Owen tries with lurching uncertainty to ease back into normal, even as the writer and director Sara Colangelo clutters his path with enough obstacles to challenge the most heroically determined traveler.
Directed by Adam Rapp

In 1990s indie terms, ‰ÛÏLoitering With Intent‰Ûù is closer to the navel-gazing of ‰ÛÏMy Life‰Ûªs in Turnaround‰Ûù than to the knowing satire of ‰ÛÏLiving in Oblivion.‰Ûù Dominic and Raphael travel to the country but find it difficult to write. Their distractions include an attractive free spirit (Isabelle McNally), Dominic‰Ûªs flighty sister (Marisa Tomei), her ex-military boyfriend (Sam Rockwell, cast well against type) and his brother (Brian Geraghty), who has blundered into a contract for a reality show produced by Jerry Bruckheimer.
1 hour 20 minutes; not rated
LOITERING WITH INTENT

Watching ‰ÛÏLoitering With Intent,‰Ûù you may briefly feel as though you‰Ûªve been transported back to the 1990s, when independent filmmaking was further from reach ‰ÛÓ it was before the proliferation of cheap digital cameras ‰ÛÓ yet there seemed to be no shortage of movies about making movies.

Amid brainstorming sessions, the characters wax romantic and heal old wounds. The movie has no apparent destination in mind; it ends with a complacent shrug having barely reached feature running time. Ms. Tomei, Mr. Rockwell and Mr. Geraghty get stray laughs, but ‰ÛÏLoitering With Intent‰Ûù mostly plays like an excuse for its makers to hang out.

This film, directed by the playwright Adam Rapp from a screenplay by Ivan Martin and Michael Godere, concerns two struggling New York actors, Raphael (Mr. Martin) and Dominic (Mr. Godere), who persuade a friend (Natasha Lyonne) that her boss, a producer, should invest in their screenplay, a noir. The problem is that no script exists, and they have only 10 days to deliver one.
Opens on Friday

The film, a sluggish adaptation of a novel by Howard Frank Mosher, gives us Bruce Dern and GeneviÌ¬ve Bujold as a long-married couple who barely speak to each other, with Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick as the young grandchild who comes to live with them in Vermont.

It‰Ûªs 1956 and Jay Craven, who directed and wrote the script, is going for coming-of-age wistfulness, but you don‰Ûªt get that simply by making every scene feel as if it takes place in some kind of cosmic slow motion. Mr. Dern is fine in his crotchety-old-man mode, but the rest of the acting is labored, and the story is an unfocused mishmash that includes a not-very-scandalous family secret, the coming of electrification, an old bank robbery and more.

A group of young people learned something about the movie business during the making of ‰ÛÏNorthern Borders.‰Ûù One thing they presumably learned is that good intentions don‰Ûªt guarantee a good movie.

The most interesting thing about the movie is its origin story. Mr. Craven, a professor at Marlboro College in Vermont, turned the low-budget film into a sort of class project: The professional crew was augmented by more than 30 students from 11 colleges, earning academic credit. It may not be a recipe for great filmmaking, perhaps, but almost certainly a premium learning experience.

In stark contrast to their furry, blundering star, the makers of ‰ÛÏPaddington‰Ûù have colored so carefully inside the lines that any possibility of surprise or subversion is effectively throttled. Perhaps burdened by an excess of respect for Paddington Bear‰Ûªs creator, the children‰Ûªs author Michael Bond, or maybe just unwilling to deter the built-in market for the inevitable movie-related merchandising, the filmmakers have settled on safe.

At the same time, what tykes will make of Nicole Kidman, playing an evil taxidermist loaded for bear, is anyone‰Ûªs guess. Squished into a white outfit and stacked on towering heels like a nurse in a bondage video, Ms. Kidman seems more a bone thrown to teenage boys than the antagonist in a children‰Ûªs movie. The little girl sitting next to me at a preview screening was baffled.
‰ÛÏWhy is she wearing those stupid shoes to climb on the roof?‰Ûù she wondered. I could have hugged her.
‰ÛÏPaddington‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Ear wax is eaten, nose hair is plucked and a tranquilizer dart is deployed.

Despite the kid-gloves sensibility, ‰ÛÏPaddington‰Ûù delivers a knockout blend of fluid animation and live action. Erik Wilson‰Ûªs primary-colored photography zings, painting an ultra-British, storybook city with a serenely vintage feel. (All the nonwhites ‰ÛÓ except for some Caribbean musicians ‰ÛÓ seem to be in hiding.) Stringing together a series of mild, bear-in-a-china-shop misadventures, the director, Paul King (who wrote the story with Hamish McColl), honors the books‰Ûª gentle spirit with whimsical humor and a genuine sweetness that little ones should respond to.

While going by the books (more than 20 of them since 1958) might reassure their many fans, it‰Ûªs a disappointingly fainthearted approach to a character who is anything but. Arriving in London as a stowaway from Peru ‰ÛÓ where a long-ago explorer taught his family to love marmalade and the King‰Ûªs English ‰ÛÓ Paddington (voiced by Ben Whishaw) is warily embraced by the Brown family. Mrs. Brown (Sally Hawkins, decked out in amusing hats and old-lady knitwear) looks at him as she might the baby Jesus, but Mr. Brown (Hugh Bonneville, doing his best ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù huffy voice) regards him mainly as an insurance risk. Their two children, like most of the supporting cast, barely register as more than superficial cameos.

But the film‰Ûªs emotions are so carefully calculated that Mr. Brown‰Ûªs transformation from fuddy-duddy to free spirit ‰ÛÓ and his sticky kumbaya speech at the end ‰ÛÓ fail to convince. (Even the lone homoerotic joke feels programmed.) And, as the perfect metaphor for the trials of immigrant assimilation, Paddington could have been given more sophisticated and high-stakes adventures without alienating younger viewers: I doubt that the biggest problem facing British immigrants today is how to negotiate indoor plumbing.

In Uberto Pasolini‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStill Life,‰Ûù the wonderful British character actor Eddie Marsan, barely moving his features, his watery eyes glistening slightly, infuses a remarkable depth of empathy into his character, John May, a dignified, solitary 44-year-old South Londoner. John works in a local council office where his job is to find the next of kin to recently deceased people in his borough whose bodies no one has claimed.
He also organizes their funeral services, where he and a priest are usually the only people attending, and writes eulogies inspired by whatever possessions the dead have left behind.

At exactly this point, a stark portrait of loneliness and stoic solitude rapidly deteriorates into a mawkish, shallow tear-jerker in which John meets Billy‰Ûªs estranged daughter, Kelly (Joanne Froggatt of ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù), and there are stirrings of romantic attraction. As the pace picks up, whatever spell the movie cast is shattered, and ‰ÛÏStill Life‰Ûù melts into a heap of sentimental slush. In its infuriating final scene, when ghosts gather at a grave site, you may scold yourself for investing any emotion at all in hokum that even Mr. Marsan, for all his kindly gravity, can‰Ûªt begin to salvage.

One afternoon, John‰Ûªs boss informs him that after 22 years, he is being terminated in a cost-cutting move. He accepts the news stoically. Then, in a sudden outburst, he pleads to finish his final case: that of a hotheaded alcoholic named Billy Stoke who lived across the street from him. Provided that he pay his own expenses, John is given permission, and he sets out to track down any possible relatives.

The film‰Ûªs early scenes, which observe these rituals, are pervaded by a solemn melancholy that becomes even more acute when John leafs through the scrapbooks he keeps of lives whose complexity he can only guess at from the snapshots that he meticulously pastes onto their pages. He treats each volume as a semi-sacred Book of the Dead, and as he pores over these, you have a premonition that John himself may come to a similarly anonymous end.
‰ÛÏAmericons‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language, drug use and sexuality.

Beau Martin Williams, who wrote the script from personal experience, portrays Jason, a Los Angeles nightclub doorman recruited for a get-rich-quick job in lending. Devin (Matt Funke) is Jason‰Ûªs brash devil‰Ûªs advocate at their office, pushing him to falsify bank statements and join an extravagant lifestyle of clubs, drugs, jets and highly metaphorical gambling binges. The leggy women and lens flares are plentiful, but after conning his best friend from college football days, Jason has doubts.

The subprime mortgage disaster is treated as a muddled morality tale of glitzy corruption in Theo Avgerinos‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAmericons.‰Ûù Mr. Avgerinos‰Ûªs glossy, overripe take on high-flying, unscrupulous lenders ‰ÛÓ the wolves of Main Street ‰ÛÓ deteriorates into a hot mess of montages, trailer-ready one-liners and thudding drama.
The subprime debacle deserves more attention (beyond that already given in documentary), but Mr. Avgerinos‰Ûªs movie, despite an evident passion for sexing up the subject, simply falls apart.

There‰Ûªs an effort to ground the hoopla in facts: The opening is a 2003 clip of President George W. Bush pitching the dream of homeownership, and the deal-making scenes are peppered with plausible jargon. But the writing and plotting have about as much nuance as a house being dropped on your head. Mr. Avgerinos has trouble holding scenes together, and an astonishing number of them are simply slathered in club music, without dialogue, and left to perish on the screen.

‰ÛÏSong One,‰Ûù Kate Barker-Froyland‰Ûªs anemic first feature, offers a wispy meditation on the healing properties of a pretty folk song ‰ÛÓ especially when sung by a shaggy-haired troubadour with bedroom eyes and a sensitive soul.

This particular crooner is James (Johnny Flynn), whose Brooklyn shows leave the local women breathless. But James is sad: His writing has stalled and swooning fans make him uncomfortable. Luckily, along comes Franny (Anne Hathaway), a Ph.D. candidate in anthropology who has abandoned her research in Morocco to attend the bedside of her comatose brother ‰ÛÓ also a musician ‰ÛÓ and process her guilt over belittling his career choice.

Heartfelt but enervated, ‰ÛÏSong One‰Ûù noodles around the Brooklyn music scene without stirring up magic. The original songs (by Jenny Lewis and Johnathan Rice) are pleasant if unmemorable, and Mr. Flynn‰Ûªs performance is too tentative to counter the story‰Ûªs lack of drama. That leaves John Guleserian‰Ûªs lovely hand-held photography and Ms. Hathaway‰Ûªs quiet radiance to pick up the slack, which they might have done had they been allowed more time with Mary Steenburgen. Her zesty turn as Franny‰Ûªs freewheeling mother is as invigorating as a shot of Red Bull to a sleep-deprived student.
‰ÛÏSong One‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Your tween daughter could emerge with the dangerous notion that penniless buskers are sexier than wealthy pop stars.

Commendably, Ms. Barker-Froyland resists the urge to tidy up loose ends. And if her leads remain locked in a romance-novel connection ‰ÛÓ she misty and mopey; he vulnerable and dreamy ‰ÛÓ at least it‰Ûªs one in which the smart girl gets the boy. For a little while, anyway.

The story loses credibility as it goes along, as the body count escalates, and Robinson‰Ûªs solutions to life-and-death crises grow increasingly far-fetched. Well before it ends preposterously, ‰ÛÏBlack Sea‰Ûù has taken leave of its senses. But one consistent element remains: the movie‰Ûªs contempt and hatred for the rich.

Robinson‰Ûªs bottled-up rage surfaces when he is suddenly relieved of his post-Navy job with an ocean salvage corporation and given a meager severance. All at once, this hard-working man‰Ûªs man feels useless. In a bar with other unemployed workers, he fumes about having led a grueling life that has left him nothing to show for it. The scene establishes an ominous undertone of simmering class resentment that never eases up. Robinson seizes the opportunity to lead a speculative exploration for undersea gold based on a rumor and enlists a loutish crew of British and Russian seamen.
‰ÛÏBlack Sea‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and violence.

Robinson (Jude Law, somewhat miscast), the leader of the crew, is a former British Navy captain whose years at sea cost him his marriage to a woman he still dreams about. In the lulls between action sequences, Robinson has misty watercolor memories of his wife and young son before she left him to marry a wealthy man, another thorn in his side.

Because ‰ÛÏBlack Sea,‰Ûù directed by Kevin Macdonald (‰ÛÏThe Last King of Scotland‰Ûù) from a screenplay by Dennis Kelly, begins with pictures of Hitler and Stalin and a World War II montage, you prepare for a story that has some historical resonance. But once the treasure‰Ûªs complicated provenance has been described, it is never mentioned again.

‰ÛÏBlack Sea‰Ûù delivers on the action front, as the usual problems ‰ÛÓ mechanical failure, fire, explosion, leakage and sudden eruptions of violence ‰ÛÓ imperil the voyage. Yet these sequences, while carefully parceled out and adroitly staged, have limited visceral clout.

Disguised as an old-fashioned adventure film, ‰ÛÏBlack Sea‰Ûù is a really a jeremiad for the new gilded age. At the outset Robinson declares that everyone aboard will get an equal portion of the gold, which he estimates will yield each crew member $2 million. That doesn‰Ûªt seem enough to some of the sailors, especially the Russians. Everyone realizes that the fewer men who survive the mission, the greater the individual reward. But since the vessel requires a crew of nine to operate, they can‰Ûªt methodically kill one another off until only one is left standing ‰ÛÓ or can they? Edgy relations between the Britons and the Russians quickly deteriorate into a Cold War waged by Neanderthal tribes.

Except for one bilingual go-between, none of these mercenaries can be described as civilized. Even Mr. Law‰Ûªs Robinson is half-mad with greed and repeatedly risks all the men‰Ûªs lives to keep the operation going when it faces seemingly insurmountable obstacles. As roughed up as he appears, Mr. Law isn‰Ûªt really convincing as a crude, burly seaman with a chip on his shoulder.

The British submarine thriller ‰ÛÏBlack Sea‰Ûù has an insistent political subtext that distinguishes it from earlier films in the undersea action genre. As its waterlogged treasure hunters brave fire and flood to find and bring back a cache of gold ingots from a sunken Nazi U-boat in the Black Sea, they grouse endlessly about paper-pushing rich guys who don‰Ûªt know the meaning of real work.

Robinson‰Ûªs most sympathetic trait is his protective relationship with the crew‰Ûªs youngest member, the 18-year-old Tobin (Bobby Schofield), who is bullied by older shipmates who wrongly assume him to be a virgin. The closest thing to a traditional villain is Daniels (Scoot McNairy), the duplicitous, smooth-talking assistant to the operation‰Ûªs devious private funder (Tobias Menzies).

The spectacle of female suffering has produced a lot of great movies; ‰ÛÏCake‰Ûù is not one of them. It‰Ûªs the sort of well-intentioned independent effort that can make criticism feel like overkill. There‰Ûªs nothing to hate, nothing to love. The movie‰Ûªs greatest virtue is that it gives Ms. Aniston a little room to play against the somewhat sardonic tough-cookie type that she deploys in vulgar comedies, like ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre the Millers,‰Ûù in which she both gets the job done and rises enough above the material to stroll away unscathed. Bad dialogue and roles often seem to just slide off her, sluicing down a slight hardness that (as with the midcareer Ginger Rogers) adds a little brass to the bright, blond picture.

All‰Ûªs fair in love and especially in comedy. There‰Ûªs something strange, though, about a movie that solicits laughter at the expense of its most disposable characters (here mostly played by extras), even as it insists on indulgence for its protagonist (played by the star). In ‰ÛÏCake,‰Ûù that‰Ûªs particularly the case, because it follows a woman weighed down by tragedy on a therapeutic journey from one stage of grief to the next. Claire is facedown in depression at the start of the story, and it gives nothing away to say that she‰Ûªs chin up in acceptance by the end. The movie hits so many familiar beats that it‰Ûªs impossible not to see what‰Ûªs next. It does what you expect at almost every turn, even with some hallucinations that, with one piercing exception, seem calculated to keep real hurt at bay.

Written by Patrick Tobin and directed by Daniel Barnz, ‰ÛÏCake‰Ûù opens with Claire upending her chronic-pain support group. The featured attraction in this circle of despair is a large, mounted photograph of a former group member, Nina (Anna Kendrick), who‰Ûªs recently taken a fatal dive off a freeway ramp. As the attendees sniffle and dab their red eyes, the group facilitator, Annette (Felicity Huffman), encourages the women to process their grief. ‰ÛÏWill you forgive me?‰Ûù Annette asks, pretending to speak for Nina. Claire, understandably, has no interest in playing this game and says something blunt that shocks the room and, also understandably, leads to her being booted out. The scene is played for laughs, most sourly aimed at Annette and the other touchy-feely therapy saps.

Claire‰Ûªs story emerges through a miasma of moans and true and false notes. Just getting out of bed is an agony for her, as Ms. Aniston suggests with a stiff, constricted physical performance to go with the character‰Ûªs clenched face and shuttered, shattered world. The introduction of Nina‰Ûªs husband, Roy (Sam Worthington), gives Ms. Aniston an excuse to warm Claire up. But he‰Ûªs a distraction and an unfortunate one, because Claire‰Ûªs most dynamic relationship is with her Latina housekeeper, Silvana (Adriana Barraza, very good), an exploited saint. Their relationship borders on the embarrassingly unexamined, and Silvana is woefully underwritten, but every so often ‰ÛÓ as when the story follows her home ‰ÛÓ life flickers into view, as does another movie about two mutually dependent equals.

The modestly scaled, sad-funny indie drama ‰ÛÏCake‰Ûù centers on a woman and the kind of grief that‰Ûªs so unbearable this movie can‰Ûªt even handle it. Jennifer Aniston plays Claire, who, having survived a horrific accident, now lives in near isolation in Los Angeles in a midcentury magazine layout of a house. Its clean lines, drawn by an architect and embellished by a period-design obsessive, make a vivid contrast with the scars jaggedly slashed across Claire‰Ûªs face and body. Her wounds have healed, but her grimace and the shadows darkening it announce that she‰Ûªs far from whole.
‰ÛÏCake‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Unsweetened adult language.

‰ÛÏStrange Magic,‰Ûù directed by the Oscar-winning sound designer Gary Rydstrom from a story by George Lucas, is set in a world of fairies, elves and goblins. The fluid digital animation tickles the eye with a sea of periwinkle, pockmarked creatures and diaphanous, detailed wings.

Viewers may relate to the ersatz emotion. At once disarming and calculated, ‰ÛÏStrange Magic‰Ûù is a film of commodified feelings, evoking memories of other experiences ‰ÛÓ whether of Shakespeare, the original songs or authentic enchantment.

When the feisty fairy-princess heroine, Marianne (the voice of Evan Rachel Wood), catches her betrothed, Roland (Sam Palladio), cheating on her, she vows, to the strains of Burt Bacharach, that she will never fall in love again.
‰ÛÏStrange Magic‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Various mean, but really just misunderstood, creatures.

The song choices, which collapse periods and are credited to the ‰ÛÏMoulin Rouge!‰Ûù music director Marius de Vries, are mostly distractions. Marianne‰Ûªs confrontation with Roland merges the Four Seasons‰Ûª ‰ÛÏC‰Ûªmon Marianne‰Ûù with Kelly Clarkson‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStronger (What Doesn‰Ûªt Kill You).‰Ûù Sunny (Elijah Kelley), an elf, obtains a love potion from the Sugar Plum Fairy (Kristin Chenoweth). Doused with the potion, Marianne‰Ûªs sister (Meredith Anne Bull) belts ‰ÛÏI Can‰Ûªt Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch)‰Ûù for the Bog King (Alan Cumming).

Whether the movie dazzles the ear is another matter. ‰ÛÏStrange Magic‰Ûù employs a parade of pop-music covers to do its screenplay‰Ûªs heavy lifting. Said to be inspired by ‰ÛÏA Midsummer Night‰Ûªs Dream,‰Ûù the film plays more like ‰ÛÏAvatar‰Ûù scored to a karaoke competition.

In the director Barry Levinson‰Ûªs movie, adapted for the screen by Buck Henry and Michal Zebede, Simon is a tragicomic figure troubled by agonizing decrepitude, depression, signs of encroaching dementia and diminished libido. Compounding his anxiety is his bemusement at the complexity of a society in which people blithely change gender and sexual orientation.

The other, Pegeen (Greta Gerwig), is the equally headstrong grown-up daughter of a theatrical couple, Asa (Dan Hedaya) and Carol (Dianne Wiest), with whom Simon worked decades earlier. A teacher at a nearby women‰Ûªs college, Pegeen, whom he doesn‰Ûªt recognize, had a crush on him when she was a girl. Now a lesbian, she is the lover of the college‰Ûªs dean, Louise (Kyra Sedgwick), with whom she slept to get her job.

Not long after Simon returns to his spacious Connecticut house in which he has sessions with his therapist (Dylan Baker) via Skype, Sybil, determined that he carry out the murder, shows up on his property and pressures him to do the dirty deed. This tiresome character is one of two women who stalk Simon.

In the opening scene of ‰ÛÏThe Humbling,‰Ûù the screen adaptation of Mr. Roth‰Ûªs 2009 comic novel, its protagonist, Simon Axler (Al Pacino), a revered stage and screen actor who fears he is losing his mojo, is literally staring at his own jowly, weathered visage in a dressing room mirror. Preparing to go onstage in a Broadway production of ‰ÛÏAs You Like It,‰Ûù he tries out various deliveries of Shakespeare‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAll the world‰Ûªs a stage‰Ûù speech.

Simon‰Ûªs extraordinary dressing room soliloquy, during which he makes the first of the film‰Ûªs many references to ‰ÛÏKing Lear,‰Ûù is followed by a sequence eerily similar to a scene in ‰ÛÏBirdman,‰Ûù in which the main character accidentally locks himself out of his dressing room and has to convince disbelieving theater personnel that he is who he says he is. Not long after making it to the stage, Simon makes a suicidal dive into the orchestra pit that lands him a 30-day stay in a psychiatric hospital.

There he meets Sybil (Nina Arianda), a rich young woman who boasts of having had a perfect life until she came home to find her husband molesting their young daughter. Recalling that Simon, in one of his movies, played a man who went berserk and killed his neighbors, she imagines that he is an expert at murder and entreats him to kill her husband. Her confusion of movies and life distills one of the film‰Ûªs themes: the difficulty of distinguishing reality from fantasy, especially for an actor in search of truthfulness while playing roles.

In his later fiction, Philip Roth has addressed the indignities of aging with a squirm-inducing candor. How many readers (or filmgoers) are eager to contemplate the loss of their powers until it is staring them in the face?

It is instructive to know that four of the film‰Ûªs principal creators are over 65, Simon‰Ûªs approximate age. Mr. Roth is 81; Mr. Pacino, 74; Mr. Levinson, 72; and Mr. Henry, 84. All were once young Turks and should know a thing or two about evolving from boy geniuses into lions in winter. That collective knowledge probably accounts for the tone of sardonic fatalism in a film that has the jovial attitude of a higher-brow ‰ÛÏThe Bucket List.‰Ûù

In Mr. Pacino‰Ûªs tempered wild-man performance ‰ÛÓ one of his strongest in over a decade ‰ÛÓ Simon rages at the dying of the light with a zany ferocity, largely avoiding self-pity. A scene in which he picks up a shotgun and prepares to shoot himself like Ernest Hemingway, then bungles it, is played for comedy. Were it made by a different team, the movie might have been conceived as a shrill farce and been much the worse for it.

‰ÛÏThe Humbling‰Ûù metamorphoses from an exploration of a veteran actor‰Ûªs artistic process, and the particular wisdom he has acquired, into a lighter, freewheeling satire of male insecurity in a postfeminist climate where the old rules no longer apply. The movie is too shrewd to qualify as a jeremiad, but underneath the comedy are boiling undercurrents of anger and despair.

Ms. Gerwig is able to make her monstrously selfish character marginally sympathetic, but the role is a hostile caricature of female voracity dreamed up by men frightened of everything Pegeen supposedly represents. Simon‰Ûªs response to her is that of an aging stud throwing up his hands in frustration, trying to keep up with her and blaming women for his troubles. The screenplay‰Ûªs misogyny extends to the vindictive Sybil, who carries out the murder herself and lies to police investigators by naming Simon as a co-conspirator.

This comic femme fatale is pursued by Prince (Billy Porter), a transgender man who, despite his gender reassignment, is still besotted with Pegeen. But Pegeen attaches herself to Simon and, with a suitcase of sex toys, moves in with him, announcing that her 14 years as a lesbian have been a mistake.
‰ÛÏThe Humbling‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sexual material, some strong language and brief violence.

Though hardly immune to clichÌ© (Nomura nibbles on raw meat and listens to classical music like Hannibal Lecter), this squirmy tale of dueling addictions gets points for skillful spikes of humor. In one of these, two cops confer outside a nightclub while, in the background, Nomura wrestles a semiconscious prostitute back into his trunk. The scene has a slapstick energy that leavens the sleaze; just don‰Ûªt expect to leave the theater laughing.

At heart a repulsive slash-and-bash with philosophical pretensions, ‰ÛÏKillers‰Ûù is classed up considerably by strong acting, a multi-strand plot and a tone that‰Ûªs both nihilistic and mournful. Neither the cinematographer, Gunnar Nimpuno, nor the directors seem excited by carnage: Some of the bloodiest moments are also the dreamiest. When things are jacked up ‰ÛÓ in a shootout inside a car, for instance, or when Bayu is chased by a posse of heavies ‰ÛÓ Mr. Nimpuno shoves his camera into the fray with such gusto that he almost certainly has the bruises to prove it.

Playing Nomura, a Tokyo lounge lizard with a well-stocked basement torture chamber, Kazuki Kitamura has a bored loucheness that‰Ûªs darkly magnetic. But dousing women with acid and uploading videos of his ‰ÛÏartworks‰Ûù to the Internet isn‰Ûªt the thrill that it used to be. So when an online encounter with Bayu (Oka Antara), an unhinged Jakarta journalist, suggests a kindred spirit, Nomura wonders if mentoring might be the answer to his ennui.

Two nut cases, one Japanese and the other Indonesian, work out their psychoses on innocent women and despicable men in the aptly named ‰ÛÏKillers,‰Ûù the bludgeon-y sophomore feature from the Mo Brothers, Kimo Stamboel and Timo Tjahjanto.
‰ÛÏManny‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Pummeling.

Mr. Pacquiao is a showman. Mark Wahlberg talks about the joy of watching him enter a ring, while Jimmy Kimmel recalls the time Mr. Pacquiao sang a duet with Will Ferrell on his TV show. Still, Mr. Pacquiao lacks the force of personality of a Muhammad Ali. ‰ÛÏManny‰Ûù can‰Ûªt approach the intrigue of ‰ÛÏWhen We Were Kings,‰Ûù the co-director Leon Gast‰Ûªs Oscar-winning chronicle of Mr. Ali and George Foreman‰Ûªs 1974 bout.

‰ÛÏManny‰Ûù offers an opportunity to ponder the spectacle of a tiny man with impressive speed. Mr. Pacquiao‰Ûªs trainer, Freddie Roach, speaks of the challenge they faced in making his right hand the equal of his powerful left.

Boxing loves an underdog story, and the hagiographic documentary ‰ÛÏManny‰Ûù has a good one in Manny Pacquiao (below). According to the movie, this Filipino fighter grew up in extreme poverty, boxed for small purses to help his family and then became a superstar ‰ÛÓ amassing world titles in eight weight classes ‰ÛÓ after coming to the United States. He is revered in the Philippines, where he sits in Congress.

Instead, it devotes surprising, yet perhaps insufficient time to such bureaucratic matters as fair compensation, contracts and Mr. Pacquiao‰Ûªs handlers. The narrative has been fashioned mostly in Mr. Pacquiao‰Ûªs favor, although there are mentions of overwork, infidelity and gambling. Banal, stentorian narration by Liam Neeson (‰ÛÏOnce victory is stolen from you, what are you left with?‰Ûù) mostly gives the sense that it‰Ûªs the viewer being carried around the ring.

The director, Greg Vander Veer, makes this case through the sheer number of people he interviews. Dancers, choreographers and acquaintances of all kinds testify to the influence of Ms. Hill, who left a strict household in Ohio that was not at all dance-friendly and came east, where she joined Martha Graham‰Ûªs company in 1929. Her real genius, though, proved to be in administration and education. In 1934 she was instrumental in establishing the Bennington School of the Dance in Vermont, and she was founding director of the Juilliard dance division, holding that position for more than 30 years, until 1985. (She died in 1995.)

The film bogs down a bit when it gets to a turf war involving the Juilliard program, George Balanchine, Lincoln Kirstein and the construction of Lincoln Center. But even here the film pays off nicely as Dennis Nahat, former artistic director of Ballet San Jose, tells a sweet, splendid story about how the resourceful Ms. Hill secured her office space.

Making a documentary about a well-known figure from the creative side of the performing arts ‰ÛÓ an actor, a singer, a writer ‰ÛÓ is easy, and common. Making one about any of the countless people who further the arts from behind the scenes is more difficult. ‰ÛÏMiss Hill: Making Dance Matter‰Ûù is such a documentary, advancing the idea that Martha Hill was as important a figure in modern dance in the last century as any of the art form‰Ûªs better-known names.

‰ÛÏMortdecai‰Ûù might as well be called ‰ÛÏThe Johnny Depp Movie,‰Ûù because its preening star, wearing an ascot and a walrus mustache that becomes a tiresome running joke, is the whole show. And what a frantically dull spectacle this vanity project is. ‰ÛÏMortdecai,‰Ûù directed by David Koepp from a screenplay by Eric Aronson, would never have been made without Mr. Depp‰Ûªs enthusiasm for the source material, the first of the 1970s trilogy of farcical novels by the British author Kyril Bonfiglioli, in the P. G. Wodehouse tradition of sophisticated silliness.

Because Charlie owes 8 million pounds in unpaid taxes to the British government, his solution is to find and sell a missing Goya painting, ‰ÛÏThe Duchess of Wellington‰Ûù; it‰Ûªs rumored that the code to a Swiss bank account containing Nazi loot is scrawled on its back. He is joined on his adventures by a British security agent (Ewan McGregor).

About that mustache: Johanna is so revolted by it that a kiss activates her gag reflex. And there you have the movie‰Ûªs only amusing gag (pardon the pun). It‰Ûªs funny the first time, deadly when repeated.

You have to admire Mr. Depp‰Ûªs repertory of tics, which include eyebrows that jump up and down and a comic gait in which his stubby arms swing out from the sides as he lumbers along. Charlie‰Ûªs adventures take him from London to Hong Kong, Moscow and Los Angeles and back.

The momentum is so frenzied that you long for ‰ÛÏMortdecai‰Ûù to ease up just long enough to allow its stars time for some witty banter. But the handful of moments that show Charlie‰Ûªs fondness for pretentious upper-class verbiage are too few and far between and pass too quickly.

The star has cited Peter Sellers and Terry-Thomas as inspirations for his creation, but as I watched the movie, the hybrid coming to mind was Charlie Chaplin and David Niven. Charlie Mortdecai lives in a mansion with his wife, Johanna (Gwyneth Paltrow affecting a barely passable British accent), and his loyal, studly manservant, Jock Strapp (Paul Bettany), whom he keeps shooting by accident and is the butt of many stale, smutty double entendres.

Mr. Depp‰Ûªs wizardly expertise at disappearing into a character is intact. But what if that character isn‰Ûªt funny and hasn‰Ûªt an ounce of charm? Charlie Mortdecai, a bumbling aristocratic bon vivant and sociopath who lives beyond his means and deals in stolen art, is a vehicle for Mr. Depp to turn into a kind of Austin Powers manquÌ©. There is no wink behind the wink because Mr. Depp is so busy showing off.
‰ÛÏMortdecai‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Off-color language and sexual material.

There‰Ûªs not really any deep, substantive connective tissue between ‰ÛÏDead Ringers,‰Ûù a truly great film, and the far lesser ‰ÛÏR100,‰Ûù which, with its flat, presumably intentionally dingy gray look, can be hard on the eyes. What connects the two movies is misogyny, but while ‰ÛÏDead Ringers‰Ûù investigates the contempt for women, ‰ÛÏR100‰Ûù ends up embracing it with a big, goofy smile. In her brilliant review of ‰ÛÏDead Ringers‰Ûù in The Village Voice, the critic Amy Taubin wrote that ‰ÛÏGynecology literalizes the only slightly veiled function of, for example, both psychoanalysis and film direction ‰ÛÓ to investigate, control and objectify women.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏR100,‰Ûù the salaryman, Takafumi Katayama (Nao Omori), only seems to be ceding control when he signs a contract with a sadism emporium that promises regularly delivered pain.

Some of these encounters are absurdly funny and well executed, as one Amazon after another enters, jerking the movie and the sad, dreary Takafumi to life. There are clever touches, including the sadism emporium, where the dominatrixes stare down from their overhead perches, a display that at once brings to mind an old MGM revue and Jeremy Bentham‰Ûªs Panopticon prison. But a little punishment goes a long way, especially for the rest of us, yet on it drags, torturously, slap, kick, slap, kick. Mr. Matsumoto, as if realizing that viewers might need to wake up, stuffs a ball gag in a child‰Ûªs mouth and throws in some reflexive nonsense involving an old director and some critics who seem to be watching the same movie you are. They think it‰Ûªs terrible and finally it‰Ûªs hard to disagree.

Rivers of spit and acres of shiny fetish wear glisten in the Japanese fantasy ‰ÛÏR100,‰Ûù a gleeful gross-out in which a meek salaryman hires an army of dominatrixes to do their cruel worst. The S-&-M gear has been selected with conspicuous care, from the pointy heels (the better to kick bad boys down the stairs) to the suitcase of instruments that look modeled on those in David Cronenberg‰Ûªs gynecological horror show, ‰ÛÏDead Ringers.‰Ûù In that 1988 movie, the sinister tool kit was for ‰ÛÏoperating on mutant women‰Ûù; here, it‰Ûªs hauled out to dig deeper under the viewer‰Ûªs skin.

The writer and director Hitoshi Matsumoto does his best work in the early scenes, starting with the coolly unnerving opening in which a professional punisher, the Violence Queen (an astonishing-looking Ai Tominaga), after prepping in a bathroom (those shoes, those cheekbones!), bursts into a restaurant to pummel Takafumi. The suddenness of the assault, as well as the Violence Queen‰Ûªs impressive scissorslike leg skills ‰ÛÓ in towering heels and fishnets no less ‰ÛÓ pop the movie to abrupt, throbbing life, like a defibrillator. And so it goes as again and again, in the street, in a van, in a sushi bar, some menacing beauty kicks, slaps and scares Takafumi into paroxysms of ecstasy, his eyes darkening weirdly and face cheeks swelling to suggest a full-bodied tumescence.

‰ÛÏSon of a Gun‰Ûù puts on a decent show of scowling brawn with an unusually strong homoerotic subtext. Prime meat for a chicken hawk, JR goes through much of the movie stripped to the waist. Just so we don‰Ûªt get the wrong idea, the story gives him a love interest in Tasha (Alicia Vikander), the steamy, sullen plaything of Brendan‰Ûªs boss, Sam Lennox (Jacek Koman), who refers to her as ‰ÛÏmy little pet.‰Ûù The chemistry between the John-Boy Walton-like JR and Tasha, a glowering tough cookie, is nonexistent.

‰ÛÏSon of a Gun‰Ûù adds to the mystique that Australian crime films are meaner, nastier and more brutish than their American counterparts. But it changes style roughly every half-hour. And behind its macho preening is a preposterous, routinely executed story about the theft of bricks from the Kalgoorlie-Boulder goldfields in Western Australia. The expected betrayals and turnabouts that follow come with the usual excuse: It‰Ûªs just business.

‰ÛÏSome scientist discovered that all people are descended from two kinds of monkey: the chimpanzee and the bonobo,‰Ûù declares Brendan Lynch (Ewan McGregor), a hardened criminal and chess whiz in Julius Avery‰Ûªs grimly silly action-adventure fantasy, ‰ÛÏSon of a Gun.‰Ûù

The reasoning being that chimpanzees will fight, and bonobos won‰Ûªt, he explains to his 19-year-old protÌ©gÌ©, JR (Brenton Thwaites), a fellow chess player whom Brendan saves from imminent rape in an Australian high-security prison. JR has to figure out which species he is.
‰ÛÏSon of a Gun‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For continuous violence, strong language, some sexuality, brief nudity and drug use.

JR comes through for Brendan. After serving six months for a petty crime without incident, he teams up with Brendan‰Ûªs pals on the outside, learns how to handle automatic weapons and returns to the prison by helicopter to airlift his mentor to safety amid a barrage of gunfire.

Rob Cohen‰Ûªs determined movie is basically a stalker story, except that the aggressor bunks 50 feet away. It takes care to counteract the novelty of its gender adjustment to the obsessed-lover formula ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs a dude instead of a temptress! ‰ÛÓ by being utterly routine in other respects. Noah is enraged when Claire‰Ûªs husband (John Corbett) tries to wheedle his way back, so he starts tormenting her and feeding anti-dad bile to her suggestible son, Kevin (Ian Nelson).
‰ÛÏThe Boy Next Door‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For violence, sexual content, nudity and language.

He can fix garage doors, beat up bullies and analyze ‰ÛÏThe Iliad,‰Ûù but don‰Ûªt be fooled: The new almost-20-year-old neighbor, Noah (Ryan Guzman), is a nightmare for an almost divorced schoolteacher, Claire Peterson (Jennifer Lopez), in ‰ÛÏThe Boy Next Door.‰Ûù She succumbs to his flattery and his sculpted body one night, after walking out on a date, and the rest of the movie is devoted to showing how bad an idea that passionate mistake was.

Unflagging in her relaxed appeal, Ms. Lopez never talks down to the often laughably written material, even when the story muzzles her authority-figure character with Claire‰Ûªs dirty little secret and loses its sense of humor. (It takes forever and a murder before she finally calls 911.) Mr. Cohen, no stranger to delivering pulp product, employs visual clichÌ©s as if they were flash cards; no exposed thigh or made-you-jump reveal goes unexploited.

Kristin Chenoweth has a sweetly frank turn as Claire‰Ûªs best friend at work, and her loyalty convinces more than Noah‰Ûªs abruptly vomiting forth his case history. But mostly you wish the desire-punishing story line would let Claire say ‰ÛÏenough‰Ûù sooner.

Cynthia (Sidse Babett Knudsen) and Evelyn (Chiara D‰ÛªAnna) belong to such a mÌ©nage, and Mr. Strickland is principally concerned with the exploration of their sexual practices and domestic routines, which amount more or less to the same thing. There is the hint of a plot ‰ÛÓ involving the waning and waxing of affections and the threats posed to bliss by jealousy and boredom ‰ÛÓ but the film is less a story than a succession of subtly differentiated moods. What gives it momentum is the audience‰Ûªs gradual discovery of the dynamic between the two women, a daily cycle of ritual and release.

Peter Strickland, who seeded and tended this exquisite hothouse flower of high-toned eroticism, is unabashedly fetishistic in his love of old exploitation movies. His previous feature, ‰ÛÏBerberian Sound Studio,‰Ûù was at once a love letter to the Italian horror films of the 1970s and a record of its main character‰Ûªs encounter with the world that spawned them. The characters in ‰ÛÏThe Duke of Burgundy‰Ûù inhabit a carefully imagined alternate reality where film seems not to exist. Bicycles, manual typewriters and slide projectors are the only machines anyone needs. Still, the grainy voluptuousness of the images and the sighing languor and exquisite dÌ©cor in which these characters dwell conjure an atmosphere of pseudo-aristocratic post-‰Ûª60s grind-house Euro-sex.

That is not a precisely technical term. And while it‰Ûªs true that ‰ÛÏThe Duke of Burgundy‰Ûù is designed to appeal to (the following words should be said in a leering, silky, vaguely accented whisper) only the most sophisticated tastes, its pleasures require no special film knowledge. All that is required is a liberated imagination, a sympathetic heart, an eye for luxury and an appreciation for the morphology of winged insects.

Except that, as it turns out, Cynthia is herself acting out Evelyn‰Ûªs instructions, which are neatly written on notecards or whispered like prompts from backstage. Cynthia finds it increasingly lonely at the top, as her complete obedience to Evelyn‰Ûªs demands leaves her weary and frustrated. Evelyn, meanwhile, wants more and more, pushing herself and her partner toward extremes of subjugation and rebelling when her yearnings are unsatisfied. She persuades Cynthia to tie her up and lock her in a chest overnight and then jolts her awake with a keening safe word. (The word is ‰ÛÏpinastri,‰Ûù by the way. Go ahead and Google; all the images are safe for work, though if you‰Ûªre a moth you might feel a little uncomfortable.)

There is exaggeration and a trace of sly humor in the set design, the costumes, the sometimes jarringly jaunty music and the trembling close-ups of leaves, bugs and water. There is also a sense of surrealist sexual comedy in the way Evelyn and Cynthia‰Ûªs exchanges of power are performed. But in the end there is nothing especially campy about ‰ÛÏThe Duke of Burgundy,‰Ûù which neither mocks its heroines nor the breathless, naughty screen tradition to which they belong. It‰Ûªs a love story, and also a perversely sincere (and sincerely perverse) labor of love.

Filming in Hungary, amid crumbling mansions and overgrown forests ‰ÛÓ and including credits for ‰ÛÏdresses and lingerie‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏperfume‰Ûù (perfume!) ‰ÛÓ Mr. Strickland conjures a lush utopia populated entirely by women. The typical household consists of a pair of lovers who are also (or who at least assume the roles of) a gentlewoman scientist and her dutiful, sometimes purposely incompetent maid. The principal profession is entomology, though one woman seems to make a nice living designing and manufacturing bondage beds and ‰ÛÏhuman toilets.‰Ûù (Like much else in ‰ÛÏThe Duke of Burgundy,‰Ûù these apparatuses are frequently spoken of but never seen, discretion being, so often, the better part of kink.)

Here are two somewhat contradictory things I can tell you about ‰ÛÏThe Duke of Burgundy,‰Ûù which takes its name from a species of butterfly. It is, I‰Ûªm fairly certain, quite unlike any other Sapphic S-and-M lepidoptery-themed psychological romance you have ever seen. At the same time, though, its uniqueness rests on a passionate, you might say slavish, devotion to a particular cinematic style of the past.

The rules seem clear enough at first. Evelyn, dark haired and nervous, with trusting eyes and a tremor in her voice, is the servant whose eagerness to please is met with coldness, and whose slightest lapses are severely punished. Cynthia, when her research is interrupted, responds with haughty weariness or outright cruelty to Evelyn‰Ûªs timid attempts at kindness. She is the boss, and Evelyn is happy to be subjected to her whims and her discipline.
‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªll Never Have Paris‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex and smarminess.

If you think the characters played by Woody Allen seem insufficiently self-deprecating, ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªll Never Have Paris‰Ûù offers an even less likely romantic lead in Quinn (Simon Helberg, from ‰ÛÏThe Big Bang Theory‰Ûù), a New York florist with unrealized musical ambitions. Now 28, Quinn plans to propose to Devon (Melanie Lynskey), his girlfriend since high school. But when he reveals his intentions to a co-worker and friend, Kelsey (Maggie Grace, in a ditsy turn), she confesses that she is in love with him.

The film gains some bite in its second half, when Quinn, even more awkward than usual thanks to oversize ultraviolet-protection sunglasses, chases Devon to Paris and encounters a rival suitor (Ebon Moss-Bachrach). A few sharp line readings break through the uncomfortable silence; Devon, protesting a bit of inauspicious timing on Quinn‰Ûªs part, gets the movie‰Ûªs one big laugh. But the film‰Ûªs competition in this genre ‰ÛÓ Elaine May‰Ûªs version of ‰ÛÏThe Heartbreak Kid‰Ûù and Albert Brooks‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏModern Romance‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is fierce.

Quinn begins to wonder what it would be like to see other women, and other women seem eager to help him out. Mr. Helberg and his wife, Jocelyn Towne, directed from Mr. Helberg‰Ûªs script, ostensibly based on their own experiences. Consequently, this derivative comedy, in addition to not being particularly funny, gives off a sense of telling us more than we needed to know.

As such, it courts dismissal, misunderstanding and perhaps even anger. Why does this movie have to be so noisy? So needy? So inconsiderate of the needs of others? Can‰Ûªt it, just for a minute, mind its manners, clean up its room and behave responsibly? But the film‰Ûªs ability to provoke such strong negative sentiments and at the same time ‰ÛÓ even within the same viewer ‰ÛÓ equally strong feelings of sympathy, solidarity and identification is testament to Mr. Dolan‰Ûªs talent. To take ‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù as an undisciplined outpouring of aggression and angst is to underestimate its artistry. He has both advanced beyond the romanticism of ‰ÛÏHeartbeats‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLaurence Anyways‰Ûù and regressed toward a more primal and confrontational mode of storytelling. ‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù may seem out of control, but it knows exactly what it‰Ûªs doing.

The French-Canadian writer, director and actor Xavier Dolan is only 25, but ‰ÛÏMommy,‰Ûù his fifth feature film in five years, seems like the work of an even younger filmmaker. I mean this, mostly, as a compliment. Stories of adolescence ‰ÛÓ young adult novels, coming-of-age movies, teenage-targeted television series ‰ÛÓ are usually the work of adults, and therefore often temper their emotional immediacy with nostalgia, condescension or grown-up wisdom. But ‰ÛÏMommy,‰Ûù the story of a troubled young man and his mother, seethes and howls with unchecked feeling. Shot in the square, narrow dimensions of a cellphone video, it is a pocket opera of grandiose self-pity, a wild and uncompromising demand for attention, a cri de coeur from the selfie generation.

Can the same be said about Steve (Antoine Olivier Pilon), the energetic blond ball of rage and longing who is the film‰Ûªs problem child? Can it be said about his mother, Diane (Anne Dorval), a profane diva of maternal ardor? They are twin volcanoes of love and frustration, but there is also something calculated and manipulative about their eruptions.

It is possible to see ‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù as television-worthy drama about the challenges of living with a difficult child in a world that offers little understanding or support. And it‰Ûªs also possible to speculate on the reasons for Steve‰Ûªs behavior, including the death of his father and Diane‰Ûªs evident instability. But psychological realism is as foreign to Mr. Dolan‰Ûªs concerns as superheroes or car chases. He is a maker of feverish fables, of spectacles that aim for the logic-defying intensity of pop ballads.

Last spring, a Cannes jury led by Jane Campion split one of its prizes between Mr. Dolan and Jean-Luc Godard, the 84-year-old lion of the Nouvelle Vague whose 3-D feature, ‰ÛÏGoodbye to Language,‰Ûù vigorously demonstrates that cinema still has the capacity to surprise, provoke and astonish. ‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù makes the same argument with radically different methods. Love it or hate it, this movie will not leave you alone.

Eventually, she and Steve make room for someone else, another neighbor, named Kyla (Suzanne ClÌ©ment). If Steve and Diane are trapped in their own florid dysfunction, Kyla is a prisoner of domestic normalcy. She lives with her husband and daughter and suffers from a mysterious (and partly metaphorical) speech disorder that makes self-expression almost impossible, a problem that the mother and son across the street decidedly don‰Ûªt share. But she joins their family in a capacity that is at once straightforward ‰ÛÓ she‰Ûªs Diane‰Ûªs friend and Steve‰Ûªs sometime caretaker ‰ÛÓ and fraught with troubling and tantalizing implications.
‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Harsh language, unruly feelings, inappropriate behavior.

Though not a musical, ‰ÛÏMommy‰Ûù often feels like one as it swells and ebbs on the melodramatic currents of love, pain and frustration. It is also, within its very modest means, formally audacious. The cramped images can barely hold two people at once, and restrict our sense of the characters‰Ûª movements, turning each performance into a solo. But then at one point Steve, feeling free and happy for the first time, pushes against the sides of the frame and literally opens the movie up. It‰Ûªs an absurd, naÌøve and beautiful moment, a willful defiance of all the rules of proper filmmaking.

Steve, pretty and pouty with the physicality of a young bull, returns to Diane‰Ûªs care after being thrown out of a group home. She pleads with her son to calm down, but it‰Ûªs also clear that she‰Ûªs afraid of him. And she can be pretty frightening in her own right, even as Ms. Dorval‰Ûªs performance teeters on the edge of camp. She barrels through the film‰Ûªs claustrophobic frames and its drab suburban locations like Anna Magnani auditioning for a role on ‰ÛÏThe Real Housewives of Montreal.‰Ûù A widow, Diane clings to her son, though she craves a measure of freedom. She flirts with a neighbor but hesitates to bring anyone new into the chaos of her household.

When Peter manages to ask CÌ©line her name, she answers, ‰ÛÏHmmm.‰Ûù Along the way he sings Scottish folk songs and buys her items that she signals she needs. During the journey, she cuddles and murmurs to her only confidante, a beloved doll.

Once it turns into a road movie, ‰ÛÏMy Name Is Hmmm ...åÊ,‰Ûù with its focus on the highway landscape of Bordeaux, suggests a child‰Ûªs answer to the Catherine Deneuve film ‰ÛÏOn My Way,‰Ûù much of which takes place on highways. In later scenes, the colors acquire a gorgeous impressionistic glow that conveys a child‰Ûªs wondrous sense of discovery. Peter‰Ûªs character remains a mystery except for one tragic fact; he has recently lost his wife and children. But the movie withholds any details of what happened.

Underneath these experimental flourishes is the tale of CÌ©line, who in a discreet sequence early in the movie is directed by her father to ‰ÛÏcome upstairs.‰Ûù We see just enough of her molestation to know what is happening. This is a very sad household. CÌ©line‰Ûªs father has lost sexual interest in her mother (Sylvie Testud), a hard-working waitress who is fed up with his layabout ways. The father is painfully aware of what he‰Ûªs doing to his daughter and privately weeps with guilt.

CÌ©line, the oldest of three siblings, has a brother and sister. As she embarks on a school outing, she warns her sister not to let their father touch her. Once away from home, she spies a nearby truck, jumps in and hides behind the front seat, where the driver, Peter (Douglas Gordon), a burly Scot, finds her. Because he doesn‰Ûªt speak French and she doesn‰Ûªt speak English, there is little verbal communication between them beyond a deepening mutual fondness and trust.

A story that begins as a naturalistic portrait of a struggling Gallic household whose unemployed, depressed paterfamilias (Jacques BonnaffÌ©) refuses to look for work, becomes increasingly surreal, reaching a point of no return in a scene in which CÌ©line observes a pair of Japanese Butoh dancers performing in a forest.

‰ÛÏMy Name Is Hmmm ...‰Ûù has its magical moments, but they are sabotaged by the director‰Ûªs showy, ham-handed technique applied to a frustratingly threadbare screenplay that leaves you wanting more.

At a certain point, it changes from color to black and white and back, presumably to contrast the French landscape as seen through a child‰Ûªs eyes with the grown-up colorless workaday world. But it is done so abruptly that you are confused and taken aback. As the film shifts from one camera to another, it sometimes changes from clear to grainy, and the aspect ratio also changes. At one point, new scenes are shown on a television monitor.

Especially in its later scenes, this overlong movie loses its focus as the director piles on distracting, pretentious cinematic embellishments underscored by an insistent use on the soundtrack of Vivaldi‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStabat Mater.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs easy for filmmakers and critics alike to confuse artiness with art. As I watched ‰ÛÏMy Name Is Hmmm ...,‰Ûù the feature directing debut of the French fashion designer agnÌ¬s b. (identified here as AgnÌ¬s TroublÌ©), I kept wondering why the story about CÌ©line (Lou-LÌ©lia Demerliac), a glum 11-year-old who escapes her sexually abusive father by hiding out in the back of a truck, insists on changing style and texture every few minutes.

Collectively, these warriors in the name of Allah are a bunch of bullies. They are indifferent to local customs and ignorant of many of the languages spoken by residents of Timbuktu, an ancient trading hub known for its cosmopolitanism. Individually, the fighters are sometimes sadistic, sometimes weak, sometimes kind and frequently confused.

But the way he and his comrades do it is hardly a laughing matter. In the course of the film, a couple accused of adultery are stoned to death. Members of the Islamic Police storm a house where music is being played, and one of the musicians (a woman, of course) is publicly whipped for the crime. When a jihadist‰Ûªs offer of marriage is refused, he vows to take his would-be bride by force. When he does, the commanders inform the local imam that their interpretation of Muslim law is, by definition, the correct one. Might makes right, and the righteousness of the strong is an excuse for all kinds of indulgence.

Their failures to live up to their own rigid notions of Shariah law are evidence of their humanity. Abdelkrim (Abel Jafri), one of the leaders, sneaks off behind a dune to smoke a cigarette, an activity he has forbidden in the city. ‰ÛÏEveryone knows you smoke,‰Ûù says his young driver, who has been trying to teach his boss to drive a stick shift. In the midst of flirting with the wife of a herdsman, Abdelkrim scolds her for immodestly leaving her hair uncovered. He also experiences a frustration common to many filmmakers when he tries to direct a video featuring a young fighter whose diffident, hip-hop-inflected performance style doesn‰Ûªt quite strike the right tone. ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre not doing, ‰Û÷Yo, man,‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù says the would-be auteur, ‰ÛÏwe‰Ûªre doing religion.‰Ûù

The authority of the jihadists in ‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù is cruel, but it is also absurd. Mr. Sissako, who was born in Mauritania and whose films have mainly been set, like this one, in Mali, examines the varieties of this absurdity with an eye that is calm, compassionate and remorseless. The most obvious vice exhibited by members of the militia controlling the desert city of Timbuktu in the name of Allah is hypocrisy.

Mr. Sissako‰Ûªs movie, far from being ‰ÛÏan apology for terrorism,‰Ûù as the mayor (who, of course, had not seen it) supposed, is an unflinching, quietly furious exploration of life under radical Islamist rule. It also makes a point about power that even nonextremist, democratically elected leaders would do well to keep in mind. When you try to restrict the movies people can see, the music they can play or the opinions they can express ‰ÛÓ in the name of whatever theological or secular ideal you claim to represent ‰ÛÓ you may or may not become a monster. That you will make a fool of yourself is, in contrast, a moral certainty.

The narrative of ‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù is a weave of anecdotes and subplots, but it returns frequently to the tent in the dusty hills outside the city where Kidane (Ibrahim Ahmed) lives with his wife, Satima (Toulou Kiki), and their daughter, Toya (Layla Walet Mohamed), tending cows and drinking tea. The presence of the heavily armed fanatics running Timbuktu sends a dispute involving Kidane and one of his neighbors spinning toward tragedy and horror, but Kidane is more than just an innocent victim, in just the way that Mr. Sissako‰Ûªs film is more than a simple polemic. He is a symbol of decency and tolerance, of everything the extremists want to destroy, precisely because he is an intriguing, fully rendered individual. And ‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù is a political film in the way that ‰ÛÏThe Bicycle Thief‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏModern Times‰Ûù is a political film: It feels at once timely and permanent, immediate and essential.
‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Horrific violence, discreetly presented.

Mr. Sissako‰Ûªs previous feature, ‰ÛÏBamako‰Ûù (named for Mali‰Ûªs capital city), similarly embedded a political argument in a rich evocation of daily life. In that film, the main action is a surreal (but entirely earnest) trial of the institutions of neo-liberalism for crimes against Africa. But the story keeps wondering off into the streets of the city, taking refuge from abstraction in the pleasures and travails of everyday life.

This month, Abderrahmane Sissako‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏTimbuktu,‰Ûù an official selection in Cannes last year and a current nominee for the best foreign-language film Oscar, was caught up in the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo murders, when the mayor of a Paris suburb briefly succeeded in banning it from a local cinema. Coming amid an outpouring of public and official support for freedom of speech, this act of censorship was both dismaying and ridiculous.

In that way, it is un peu Charlie Hebdo, though Mr. Sissako‰Ûªs sensibility is gentler, his satirical impulse less scabrous and his imagination more expansive than that shared by most of the magazine‰Ûªs cartoonists. There is a strong current of anger and disgust running through his film, which was inspired by the Islamist takeover of Timbuktu and other parts of northern Mali in 2012. With some adjustments, it could have been set in Syria, Iraq, Nigeria or Pakistan. But the glory of ‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù lies in its devotion to local knowledge, in the way it allows its gaze to wander away from violence toward images of beauty and grace.

Showing them this way is not a matter of ‰ÛÏhumanizing‰Ûù fanaticism, which is the kind of accusation that is often unthinkingly leveled at stories that veer away from presenting political conflict as a simple fight between good and evil. How could the bad guys be anything other than human? Their folly lies in the belief that they can transcend that condition and terrorize their fellow Muslims into holiness. They may be sincere in their devotion to their God and his prophet, but they are still jerks. ‰ÛÏTimbuktu‰Ûù is an act of resistance and revenge because it asserts the power of secularism not as an ideology but rather as a stubborn fact of life.
These fond recollections of derring-do hail from a different era, and the movie‰Ûªs one-sided view of history is bound to start arguments.

Produced by Nancy Spielberg (sister of Steven Spielberg), the documentary ‰ÛÏAbove and Beyond‰Ûù recounts the story of Jewish American pilots who, beginning in 1948, secretly fought for Israel in its war of independence, when the Israeli military was nascent.
The film is best appreciated as a straightforward testimonial: old war buddies‰Ûª hurrah against anti-Semitism.

Drawing on interviews with historians and the surviving pilots, as well as re-enactments and archival footage, ‰ÛÏAbove and Beyond‰Ûù is partly a procedural. It explains how the pilots hopscotched countries to evade detection. (According to the film, Americans who helped Israel‰Ûªs military risked jeopardizing their United States citizenship.) Some of the planes used were manufactured at a factory in Czechoslovakia that only years earlier had served the Germans. The men unabashedly reminisce about how their missions earned them female admirers.

For several of the pilots, defending Israel was their first significant identification with their heritage. At the time, discrimination against Jews was far more prevalent in America than it is now. ‰ÛÏThe idea that Jews were going to fight I found exciting,‰Ûù says Harold Livingston, one of the pilots, who later became a novelist and screenwriter. The actor Paul Reubens, who is known as Pee-wee Herman and whose father was part of this group, describes how his father bailed out of a plane and identified himself to Israelis by shouting what little Yiddish he knew.

‰ÛÏAlien Outpost,‰Ûù the first feature from Jabbar Raisani, should really be called ‰ÛÏAlien Out of Sight,‰Ûù as the few, mostly distant glimpses we‰Ûªre allowed of the movie‰Ûªs extraterrestrials tell us very little. What we do learn ‰ÛÓ from a flurry of opening title cards ‰ÛÓ is that these so-called Heavies invaded Earth in 2021 and were chased off a year later, inexplicably leaving thousands of their kind behind. Probably just to annoy us.

column5: Shaped like a boots-on-the-ground documentary but dying to be a futuristic war movie (if it only had the budget), the story picks up 10 years later at Outpost 37 in Pakistan, one of the few remaining military bases created postwar to clean up the alien stragglers. As two filmmakers conduct softball, ‰ÛÏRestrepo-style interviews with the soldiers
column6: a series of dismaying events ‰ÛÓ alien sightings; a suicide bomber; a missing comrade ‰ÛÓ interrupt the locker-room joshing. But the writing is so poor and the visual embellishments so few that some of the violence
column7: like the frequent attacks on the base by local villagers
column8: make little sense: If otherworldly beings are slaughtering your goats

column5: Plagued by a rickety premise, generic sets and invaders who recall Doctor Who‰Ûªs Cybermen, ‰ÛÏAlien Outpost‰Ûù jabs its finger at the Iraq War with repetitive obviousness. The big reveal won‰Ûªt win any prizes, but things do become more engaging as the squad falls apart, mostly because of actors (Joe Reegan and Rick Ravanello are especially notable) who sweat to rise above band-of-brothers stereotypes. What they can‰Ûªt surmount is a script more confusing than those left-behind invaders.

The movie makes gentle, if too-cute comic hay out of Elliott‰Ûªs fumbling efforts to assume Carol‰Ûªs maternal duties, which include combing out Eloise‰Ûªs hair and driving her to an elite private school. Eloise‰Ûªs black father, Reggie Davis (AndrÌ© Holland of ‰ÛÏThe Knick‰Ûù), is a drifter and crack addict alienated from his family. This back story is parceled out very slowly. In another too-cute touch, Elliott hires Duvan (Mpho Koaho), a young, extremely polite, multilingual West African math tutor, for Eloise.

‰ÛÏBlack or White,‰Ûù Mike Binder‰Ûªs steady, well-intentioned exploration of the racial tensions affecting two branches of a Southern California family, is notable for what it doesn‰Ûªt try to do. It doesn‰Ûªt assess America‰Ûªs racial attitudes based on the headlines of the day or use its story, which revolves around custody of a biracial child, to placate or to inflame.

Buoyed by excellent performances from a cast led by Kevin Costner and Octavia Spencer, it tells a personal story loosely based on events in Mr. Binder‰Ûªs own family history. Its characters, both black and white, want to transcend their differences and do the right thing. As I watched this timid but honorable two-hour film, much of which is set in a courtroom, I feared that its hostilities might resolve in feel-good hugs and teary-eyed apologies. They don‰Ûªt ... quite, in a movie that wants to reassure while avoiding sentimentality.

The movie is so wary of alienating audiences that only at the very end does it explode into violence. That blowup is a contrived, unsatisfying confrontation between Elliott and Reggie that is too calculated to be cathartic.
That‰Ûªs the point at which ‰ÛÏBlack or White‰Ûù surrenders to mawkish Hollywood convention and is much the worse for it. Sad to say, this is a movie that is ultimately afraid of its own shadow.

In a remarkably vanity-free performance, Mr. Costner, 60, plays Elliott as a potbellied alcoholic wreck with a bad dye job who doesn‰Ûªt go anywhere without a drink in his hand. Mr. Costner is entirely convincing as an angry drunk who in trying to drown the pain of his loss only fuels his rage and despair.
‰ÛÏBlack or White‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Strong language, drug use, drinking and a violent fight scene.

Rowena, who operates several small businesses, is the matriarch of a large extended family in the south Los Angeles County city of Compton. The movie jumps between Santa Monica, where Elliott lives in splendor with a full-time housekeeper, and Compton, where Rowena‰Ûªs extended family spills onto the front porch. Except for the absent Reggie, the Jefferses are a happy, productive clan who play jazz together in Rowena‰Ûªs big, homey living room.

The Compton shown in the movie isn‰Ûªt the shoot-‰Ûªem-up Wild West of gangsta rap lore. There is no sound of gunfire or visible police presence. By making the Jeffers household struggling but middle class, ‰ÛÏBlack or White‰Ûù avoids addressing the extremes of poverty that are a root cause of crime and drug addiction. It wants to be a family drama, not a sociopolitical tract, and carefully steers around political potholes.

When Reggie shows up, professing to be drug-free after years of addiction, Rowena and Jeremiah pressure him to join the custody battle. Mr. Holland‰Ûªs fragile, guilt-stricken Reggie is the antithesis of a stereotypical street thug. Lacking the self-protective bravado of a bad boy, he is afraid to meet Eloise, and terrified of testifying in court.

Ms. Spencer turns the strict, truth-telling Rowena into a mighty force. As in ‰ÛÏThe Help,‰Ûù her wide-eyed stare gives her the gravity of an all-seeing sage who doesn‰Ûªt miss a trick and is not afraid to speak her mind. Although Rowena seldom sees Reggie, she hasn‰Ûªt completely given up on him. Rowena may be a clichÌ©d Earth Mother, but Ms. Spencer imbues her with a fierce severity.

Elliott is blindsided when Reggie‰Ûªs mother, Rowena Jeffers (Ms. Spencer), with whom he has a warily cordial relationship, notices his erratic behavior and decides to sue for custody of Eloise. She hires her brother Jeremiah (Anthony Mackie), a hotheaded lawyer who decides they should portray Elliott as a closet racist prone to using offensive epithets.

The focal character, Elliott Anderson (Mr. Costner), is a Santa Monica lawyer devastated by the death of his wife, Carol (Jennifer Ehle, seen in gauzy flashbacks), from a car accident. They were raising their biracial 7-year-old granddaughter, Eloise (Jillian Estell), whose mother died at 17 while giving birth.

This isn‰Ûªt the first time the maverick Mr. German (who died in 2013, leaving his wife and son, a director, to finish this film‰Ûªs postproduction) has delved into the daily ravages of war and oppression. Nor is the richly layered black-and-white film a stylistic departure, for it is the apotheosis of techniques in his films ‰ÛÏKhrustalyov, My Car!‰Ûù (1998) (perhaps its closest rival in seething intensity), ‰ÛÏMy Friend Ivan Lapshin‰Ûù (1984) and even his hard-nosed 1971 war drama, ‰ÛÏTrial on the Road.‰Ûù

If Mr. German isn‰Ûªt keen on explaining his source material, he does look at it with the glint of cynical experience. One crucial bit of dialogue ‰ÛÓ on the problems of paternalism ‰ÛÓ is restaged from a dinner scene in the novel, turned into a conversation with a scholar straining to urinate against a wall. Mr. German was just as stubborn in sticking to his personal vision (and revisions) as he was innovative in his storytelling, and he‰Ûªs left behind a final opus that is hard to shake.

Always an insightfully dynamic framer of images, Mr. German choreographs both important and trivial events in the foreground and background in one big danse macabre. Here he pushes into something like Fellini vÌ©ritÌ©, with faces and swords and buttocks wheeled into and out of view, and people gawking into the camera. He enjoys coming up with effectively discomforting surprises; at one point, chicken legs dangle bafflingly before us.

Our guide is a prankish earthling, Don Rumata (Leonid Yarmolnik, a Russian television personality), although ‰ÛÏguide‰Ûù might be a strong word in the context of Mr. German‰Ûªs nearly documentarylike brand of in-the-fray filmmaking. Rumata is one of several visiting scientists blending in as aristocrats, as the vital (and sparse) voice-over explains. His god‰Ûªs-eye mission of benevolent oversight doesn‰Ûªt shield him from the crackdowns being instigated by a mighty order of monks.

All the planet‰Ûªs his stage, but at the same time, you might wish for an intermission. Mr. German‰Ûªs serpentine takes and dense sound design are relentless, and the tunnel vision of his close-up, cutless prowls can be exhilarating and exasperating over nearly three hours. There‰Ûªs a fine line between immersing and drowning the viewer.

But Mr. German also creates deep panoramas of finely etched beauty, which is part of what has earned the film justifiable comparisons to works by the painters Bruegel and Bosch, not to mention Dante (according to Umberto Eco). Mr. German drops a name or two himself, as when Don Rumata mischievously passes off Boris Pasternak‰Ûªs poem, ‰ÛÏHamlet,‰Ûù as his own. In the film, the poem refers to past Soviet censorship, which the filmmaker himself faced, as well as underscoring Rumata‰Ûªs complex status as a performer with a duty.

The roiling setting alone enforces a medieval mind-set that feels genuine: brutal yet often jovially rambunctious and crude, pre-psychological in its sense of the cheapness of life and yet rich with local custom and detail. Our chaotic journey makes Werner Herzog‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAguirre, Wrath of God‰Ûù look like ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey.‰Ûù But historical power structures are being laid bare too. Mr. German‰Ûªs work evokes the horrors of post-Communist disarray, and purges in any era, while underplaying the Strugatskys‰Ûª more liberating ruminations (and changing the ending).

Yet this isn‰Ûªt a lucid story of moves and countermoves among political forces, and the stranger in a strange land isn‰Ûªt so much Rumata as it is the viewer. ‰ÛÏHard to Be a God‰Ûù is a cinematic plunge into the warp, weft and squelch of another time, thrusting us along with Rumata‰Ûªs wanderings: between his squalid chambers and various manor grounds, among soldiers and peasants and prisoners, amid puddles and flames, half-heard asides and yelps of pain.

The future is mired in the muddy, muddy past in ‰ÛÏHard to Be a God,‰Ûù Aleksei German‰Ûªs full-contact, madly outrÌ© adaptation of the 1964 science-fiction novel by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The film‰Ûªs helter-skelter action takes place on another planet, but not some gleamingly advanced version of our own. On the parallel world of Arkanar, it‰Ûªs still the Middle Ages, and the rabble spend their lives tramping through muck, surviving warring factions (or not), and apparently delighting in the total lack of sanitation.

Then she meets Lady (Assa Sylla), the leader of a clique in need of a fourth member.
