(The film‰Ûªs French title, ‰ÛÏBande de Filles,‰Ûù could be translated as ‰ÛÏGirl Gang,‰Ûù and the English title plays on several meanings of ‰ÛÏhood.‰Ûù) Lady and her lieutenants, Adiatou (Lindsay Karamoh) and Fily (Marietou TourÌ©), accessorize their black leather jackets with gold chains and wear their hair straight and unbraided. They fight, swear, defy authority and talk back to catcallers, shopkeepers and anyone else who annoys them. In their company, Marieme ‰ÛÓ now known as Vic (‰ÛÏas in victory,‰Ûù according to Lady) ‰ÛÓ feels brave, protected and understood. She also has fun, and Ms. Sciamma captures the dizzy sweetness of her first tastes of freedom, as she and her friends dance, drink and lip-sync to Rihanna‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDiamonds.‰Ûù

The camera follows one of these young athletes, Marieme (Karidja TourÌ©), as she makes her way home, and observes the way her boisterous bravado turns into diffidence and timidity as her teammates melt into the night. Marieme is tall and athletic, but her habit of looking down and hunching her shoulders makes her appear slighter and more delicate than she is. She lives with her mother, two younger sisters and an older brother, Djibril (Cyril Mendy), a moody, sometimes frightening would-be patriarch. She has a crush on one of his friends, IsmaÌÇl (Idrissa Diabate), but can barely meet his eyes. By all appearances she is dutiful and self-effacing, resigned to a life of modest expectations and low visibility.

This too is familiar territory, for audiences acquainted with recent French realist cinema or with American television shows like ‰ÛÏThe Wire.‰Ûù Among other things, ‰ÛÏGirlhood‰Ûù is another socially conscious drama about the choices facing a tough, intelligent, basically decent young person in a world that views her with indifference and suspicion. It‰Ûªs worth noting that the state, which usually shows up in French movies in the form of the police, the educational system or the strongly implied ideals of the Republic, is barely present here. And its absence increases the sense that Vic and her friends are alone and vulnerable, safe and valued only in the uneasy cocoon they weave together.

The first shot of the movie is of a football game ‰ÛÓ the American kind, with pads and helmets and hard contact at the line of scrimmage. This may come as a surprise in a French movie. Shouldn‰Ûªt they be playing soccer? Another surprise: All of the players are girls, mostly of African descent and residents of a high-rise housing complex on the outskirts of Paris. So right from the start, before the plot has gotten underway, ‰ÛÏGirlhood‰Ûù insists that the world will not conform to easy categories or lazy expectations.

But while ‰ÛÏGirlhood‰Ûù is sad and wrenching, it doesn‰Ûªt feel like a misery-mongering expression of high-minded (and therefore condescending) concern. This is because Karidja TourÌ©, evolving from the shy Marieme into the assertive Vic, carries herself with the kind of dignity that disarms all pity, and also because Ms. Sciamma, whose previous explorations of female adolescence include ‰ÛÏTomboy‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏWater Lilies,‰Ûù is less interested in what Marieme might represent than in what she experiences. While the movie has a lot to say about the general condition of being a girl, in the Paris banlieues and elsewhere, it never loses sight of the specific girl at its heart.

CÌ©line Sciamma‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGirlhood‰Ûù can be described (like so many movies these days) as a coming-of-age story, and it honors the genre, and its main character, with exemplary sensitivity and sympathy. But even as she stops at familiar stations on the road to maturity ‰ÛÓ problems at home and school, new friendships and first love ‰ÛÓ Ms. Sciamma revels in the risky, reckless exuberance of adolescence and in the sheer joy of filming it.

Vic‰Ûªs liberation is real, but it‰Ûªs hardly complete. Even a girl as defiant and self-possessed as Lady is still subject to male authority, which in this neighborhood rests on a complex set of codes and customs. Some of these are rooted in old religious and cultural traditions, others in the Darwinian realities of poverty, crime and social marginality. Vic must keep her interest in IsmaÌÇl a secret because Djibril‰Ûªs honor and reputation would be compromised if she were known to be sexually active. At the same time, she and her friends, even as they terrorize and dominate rival girl posses, are careful not to antagonize the drug dealers and pimps who run the housing projects.

Stripped of the beard, glasses and unwashed curtain of hair that transform him into Gilfoyle on HBO‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSilicon Valley,‰Ûù the actor Martin Starr is unrecognizable in the prickly love story ‰ÛÏAmira & Sam.‰Ûù His blank-eyed impassivity and deadpan line delivery, though, are exactly the same; and while they work beautifully to play a testy techie on a comedy show, they make him an unpersuasive lover and an unappealing leading man.

Written and directed by Sean Mullin, a comedian and onetime Army officer (he plays a comic in the film), ‰ÛÏAmira & Sam‰Ûù is more successful as a portrait of veteran alienation than as a romance. The script is thoughtful, but its anger is diffuse, with laissez-faire capitalism and the problems of illegal immigrants and returning soldiers jostling for attention. That leaves little room for the character of Amira, who Ms. Shihabi strives to raise beyond the limits of a sharp-tongued hottie ‰ÛÓ hijab above, party below ‰ÛÓ given to heedless lawbreaking. Sam‰Ûªs attraction to her is understandable; her reciprocation is as unfathomable as the expression on Sam‰Ûªs face.

As Sam, an Army veteran and aspiring comedian who has recently returned from the Middle East, Mr. Starr is convincingly troubled by an America that ‰ÛÓ to paraphrase Sam‰Ûªs excruciating stand-up routine ‰ÛÓ has lost its mind. Disheartened by the financial finagling of his cousin, a hedge fund manager (Paul Wesley, taking a break from sucking necks and seducing women on ‰ÛÏThe Vampire Diaries‰Ûù), Sam seems almost relieved when circumstances force him to protect Amira (Dina Shihabi), the niece of his former Iraqi translator.

‰ÛÏProject Almanac,‰Ûù a teenage time-travel fable, begins with its hero delivering a college admissions essay to the camera and continues to pretend that everything we see was filmed by the characters. It‰Ûªs the latest example of the ‰ÛÏfound-footage‰Ûù conceit, which apparently reflects a misperception among screenwriters that the filmmakers have to be part of the story, or else the movie doesn‰Ûªt happen.

There‰Ûªs some insight and humor about how finding a workaround for experience isn‰Ûªt the same thing as living. But nothing here matches the genre‰Ûªs small-scale classic, ‰ÛÏPrimer,‰Ûù or even ‰ÛÏPremature,‰Ûù the recent gonzo ‰ÛÏGroundhog Day.‰Ûù One of David‰Ûªs accomplices also mentions ‰ÛÏLooper,‰Ûù but the self-awareness doesn‰Ûªt save the film from fizzling.

The wish fulfillment of time travel tends to be fun to watch, and the director, Dean Israelite, feeds on the friends‰Ûª giddy escapades for a while, whether it‰Ûªs acing a test or attending a big concert. But the shy David‰Ûªs yen for an outspoken hot girl (Sofia Black-D‰ÛªElia) ends up introducing the ethical quandaries expected in tales of temporal journeys.

That tired trick makes excitement and danger easier to portray through camerawork (and also seems to still appeal to a younger audience). The meat of the action starts when a high school science maven, David (Jonny Weston), happens upon a bizarro home movie of a childhood birthday party. He then finds a time machine left in the basement by his brilliant, and deceased, dad. With his buddies and kid sister, the earnest boy gets the device working; together they secretly use it to finagle better grades, higher social standing and money.
‰ÛÏProject Almanac‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some language and sexual content.

But it is insight-free and clichÌ©-heavy, with the five sharing obvious reminiscences about the thrill of superstardom, visiting haunts from their youth, shooting baskets and occasionally rehearsing. The most interesting bit of Backstreet Boys history ‰ÛÓ the arrest and jailing of a scam artist named Lou Pearlman, who formed the group ‰ÛÓ is brushed over. The behind-the-scenes tensions of preparing a comeback tour are distilled into one shouting match.

The documentary ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏworld‰Ûªs longest promotional video‰Ûù would be a better description ‰ÛÓ gives us more than an hour and 40 minutes of self-aggrandizement by the five Backstreet Boys, who are now in their 30s and 40s. The group was a hit-making machine in the 1990s and early 2000s, and the film is loosely documenting a comeback effort that included a new album in 2013. (The film‰Ûªs subtitle is borrowed from one of that record‰Ûªs tracks.)
‰ÛÏBackstreet Boys: Show ‰Û÷Em What You‰Ûªre Made Of‰Ûù is a film that only fans who are seriously overinvested in that once formidable boy band could love.
The result is a shallow film that perhaps worshipful tweeners would enjoy. But fans who were worshipful tweeners in the group‰Ûªs heyday are older and, presumably, more sophisticated now.

Momentum stalls, however, when we reach the rural farmhouse where Tully and Doreen take cover and plot their next move. The inhabitants, a querulous black family, become hostages and the film becomes a volatile but claustrophobic morality play that the cinematographer, Rodney Taylor, fights valiantly to inject with light and air. But as the family, led by Danny Glover‰Ûªs cautiously wise patriarch, reveals its own fault lines ‰ÛÓ and Tully marks his territory by spraying like an unneutered tomcat ‰ÛÓ the atmosphere becomes increasingly oppressive.

Despite a vein-popping lead performance (and Ms. Olivieri‰Ûªs touching take on the classic broken-down moll), ‰ÛÏSupremacy‰Ûù remains stubbornly uninvolving. Repeated shots of a ticking grandfather clock add weight rather than suspense, and a last-gasp appearance by Anson Mount as Sobecki, the Aryan Brotherhood‰Ûªs big cheese, seems added purely for celebrity value. Tully needs Sobecki to save him; the movie is already beyond help.

Feeding over-the-top language to underdeveloped characters, Deon Taylor‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSupremacy‰Ûù dramatizes racism with an unvarying intensity that quickly becomes wearing. The furnace at its center is Tully (Joe Anderson), a white supremacist newly released from prison after serving 15 years for armed robbery. With a swastika on his cheek and hate in his heart, Tully hits the road with Doreen (Dawn Olivieri), a coked-up Aryan floozy, before robbing a convenience store and shooting a police officer. All this, and we‰Ûªve barely cleared the opening credits.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nasty white folks and odious racial slurs.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong violence, language, some sexuality and nudity.

Even with Hope Davis as a card dealer and Stanley Tucci as a laboriously suave mobster, the Las Vegas setting feels stale. Worst of all is a pasty-faced tech millionaire (Michael Angarano) who hires Nick to ‰ÛÏkill the fear that lives inside of‰Ûù him. The whiz kid is more like the object of a bar rant than an actual person, and ‰ÛÏWild Card‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt really hit the rock bottom that would make it more than a series of sulks and wallops.

Slow-motion knockouts follow, with Mr. Statham as sure-fisted as ever, but the ‰ÛÏExpendables‰Ûù director Simon West can only summon dead air in between. Mr. Goldman‰Ûªs slightly offbeat underworld is not very convincing, and Mr. Statham‰Ûªs thick voice and inexpressive acting suggest brain fog rather than gritty blues.

In this go-round, Nick Wild (Mr. Statham) begins by helping a friend (Dominik GarcÌ_a-Lorido) avenge herself on a sadistic, vain gangster (Milo Ventimiglia) in a luxury hotel. It‰Ûªs a splashily gloating scene of humiliation, and it leaves Nick marked for death. When he goes to gamble away his sorrows ‰ÛÓ in blackjack sequences edited with mechanical pizazz ‰ÛÓ thugs eventually rush in.

Set in the underbelly of Las Vegas and full of dull existential timeouts, ‰ÛÏWild Card‰Ûù is about second chances. For the ‰ÛÏsecurity consultant‰Ûù played by Jason Statham, that would mean finally escaping the (violent) grind. For the film‰Ûªs storied screenwriter, William Goldman, it‰Ûªs the rare privilege of re-adapting his novel ‰ÛÏHeat‰Ûù after its first incarnation in 1986 with Burt Reynolds.

But first Mr. Puri takes a long detour into romance. Our hero, Shivy Talpade (Ayushmann Khurrana), a freethinker and fourth-form dropout, falls in love with an actress, Sitara (Pallavi Sharda). They meet onstage, playing the classic lovers Shakuntala and Dushyanta. (Shivy, drunk and no actor, has been shoved into the scene.) It‰Ûªs love at first you-know-what, but also a mismatch. Sitara harshly sums it up: ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre a blue blood, and I‰Ûªm a harlot.‰Ûù

A real man named Shivkar Talpade is said to have flown an unmanned plane in 1895 ‰ÛÓ fueled by mercury! ‰ÛÓ but ‰ÛÏHawaizaada‰Ûù has no claims on documentary reality. Its storytelling is solidly in the Bollywood tradition, upping the ante everywhere and allowing Shivy some truly remarkable achievements. And the world it places him in is gloriously artificial: steampunk crossed with ‰ÛÏChitty Chitty Bang Bang.‰Ûù Shastry and Shivy‰Ûªs lab is in a beached galleon cluttered with Rube Goldberg-type contraptions. (Science here is a matter of pinging, whizzing balls and steam, and furrowed-brow chitchat about Vedic numbers.)

Mr. Puri‰Ûªs film is so laden with symbols ‰ÛÓ Christian imagery is everywhere ‰ÛÓ and resonances (Hindu myths and scriptures) that it‰Ûªs sometimes hard to read. But an Indian nationalist message comes through clearly, and it‰Ûªs an inclusive one. When Shivy and his mentor, Subbaraya Shastry (Mithun Chakraborty), need money to continue their experiments in flying, which are based on Vedic numbers and principles, Shivy‰Ûªs old pals contribute money they‰Ûªd been saving to go on hajj.

For all that, though, ‰ÛÏHawaizaada‰Ûù often fails to soar. Mr. Puri works hard, but the strain shows and so do the movie‰Ûªs seams. And Mr. Khurrana, who rides the line between ingratiating and annoying, has trouble carrying the movie. He‰Ûªs an actor trying to give a movie-star performance, which is what this fantasy needs: a star with enough power and buoyancy to make it float.

About flying and freedom (and, of course, love), the Bollywood movie ‰ÛÏHawaizaada,‰Ûù directed by Vibhu Virender Puri, spins legend into more legend. The year is 1895, and the setting is Bombay. The story concerns a quest by two Indians to build an airplane and to show the British rulers of India ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏA monkey can‰Ûªt make a machine!‰Ûù one says ‰ÛÓ what their subjects can do.

In lingering over moody night streets and trembling faces, Ms. Josue has brought this film to the verge of becoming a tear-jerker. But, as epitomized in an extraordinary scene with a conflicted priest, it‰Ûªs all part of a shared soul-searching that still continues.

Ms. Josue narrates the film as a personal journey and a kind of grief circle with those who knew and loved the gregarious Mr. Shepard. That means a lot of tearful reminiscences, often of fairly routine bonding among friends, though his sense of belonging is, unusually, rooted abroad in the Swiss boarding school he attended while his father worked an oil job in Saudi Arabia. But practically any details would seem poignant in anticipation of what we know would come.

Ms. Josue pushes back those expectations somewhat in a couple of ways. A heartening undertow comes from Mr. Shepard‰Ûªs parents: a mother ultimately turned activist and a father whose teary adoration is still inspiring. But there‰Ûªs also an awful episode on Mr. Shepard‰Ûªs high school trip to Morocco, where he was raped. Before his nationally reported death, he‰Ûªd suffered hateful violence.

A tender reconstruction of personal loss, ‰ÛÏMatt Shepard Is a Friend of Mine‰Ûù retraces the life of the University of Wyoming student whose 1998 murder put a national spotlight on hate crimes against gay people. Variably effective, this debut feature documentary from Michele Josue seeks to restore the Matt Shepard of his friends‰Ûª and family‰Ûªs memories, and in so doing return a human symbol to a state of ordinary but beloved individuality.

‰ÛÏJupiter Ascending,‰Ûù the latest from Lana and Andy Wachowski, is a big, woozy, spacey fairy tale with a science-fiction exoskeleton and a core of pure mush. With its nods to the original ‰ÛÏStar Trek‰Ûù and David Lynch‰Ûªs proto-steampunk hallucination ‰ÛÏDune,‰Ûù it seduces the eye with filigreed flourishes even as the mind reels from some of the mildewy storytelling. Mila Kunis plays Jupiter Jones, an earthling who turns out to be the reconstituted queen of the universe or some such, which apparently means that she needs to be repeatedly rescued. An uncomfortable-looking Channing Tatum plays her hybrid honey, Caine Wise, a man-wolf with pointy ears and, my, what big, bulging muscles.

Perhaps because Mr. Bean is a veteran of outsize entertainments like ‰ÛÏThe Lord of the Rings,‰Ûù he seems more comfortable inhabiting this fantasia than Mr. Tatum does. Then again Mr. Bean doesn‰Ûªt have to wear pointy ears. The ears are amusing but they‰Ûªre almost all that‰Ûªs memorable about the sketchily conceived Caine. Like Ms. Kunis, Mr. Tatum is a charismatic screen presence who often feels lost amid the clutter and chaos in ‰ÛÏJupiter Ascending.‰Ûù In another movie, these two stars might have been able to add life and layers to their characters; here, they just seem to be trying to keep up with the action. The performances are especially unconvincing in the quieter, intimate scenes because, while the Wachowskis know how to put on a big show and ‰ÛÓ like many other spectacle-minded filmmakers ‰ÛÓ excel at blowing their fantasies to smithereens, they too often fumble something more crucial and more difficult to pull off: ordinary, believable human emotions.

Given their track record it‰Ûªs no surprise that this movie is crammed with plot turns and eye-bulging visuals, including lavishly detailed sets and costumes. After the story really starts churning ‰ÛÓ there are good guys and bad, a spectrum of skin colors, a gallery‰Ûªs worth of body art and some soft, ritualistic jabs against capitalism ‰ÛÓ Jupiter ends up way, way over the rainbow. There she meets overripe villains like Balem Abrasax, one of those decadent aristo-cats with a sneer on his lips and blood on his hands who once would have been played by a camping Jeremy Irons but is now played by a camping Eddie Redmayne. If you‰Ûªre familiar with the fall of Rome you get the big picture more or less, but with spaceships.

The Wachowskis are routinely applauded for their ambitions, yet it‰Ûªs startling how inattentive they can be to certain filmmaking fundamentals, like two shots. They‰Ûªre good at making entire worlds, but, whether distracted by the big stuff or bored by the putatively small, they have a tough time making a conversation between two people come alive. So, once again, they give you loads of fun stuff to look at whether Jupiter is hanging onto Caine‰Ûªs back as he skates across the sky or she‰Ûªs wearing a fab, flowery headdress that would have made Elizabeth Taylor moan. Every square inch of this movie feels so obsessed over that it‰Ûªs startling how rapidly the Wachowskis breeze through all their sets and setups. (It‰Ûªs hard not to think that the original edit ran hours longer.)

At one point, Jupiter has to verify her status as the genetically reborn queen with some paperwork, an amusingly pedestrian errand that finds her briefly entering a bureaucratic spiral as she goes from office to office, including one run by a Dickensian gargoyle nestled in a lair festooned with shadows and old-fashioned machines. It‰Ûªs a pleasantly decrepit, suggestive tableau because, as this extraterrestrial creature punches the keys on one machine and turns the crank on another, you get a sense of all the many histories poured into this science-fiction world. But before you can really take it all in, Jupiter is rushing toward the next plot twist. Part Alice in weirdland, part imperiled Pauline, she periodically hitches a ride in the arms of Mr. Tatum‰Ûªs wolf-man, Caine, and occasionally joins up with another he-man, Stinger Apini, played with relaxed appeal by Sean Bean.

For maximalists like the Wachowskis, the answer to the audience‰Ûªs potential uninterest, or worse, the vaguest tremor of boredom, has always been more: more plot, more special effects, more violence, more coolness, more awesomeness ‰ÛÓ the better to dazzle or bludgeon you, my dear. In the one movie in which it didn‰Ûªt feel as if they were simply piling on ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Matrix,‰Ûù as if there was any doubt ‰ÛÓ they found a story that dovetailed with their will to spectacle and ended up with a tour de force. It‰Ûªs been fairly rough going for them ever since, whether they‰Ûªve taken on someone else‰Ûªs excesses (as in their 2012 adaptation, with Tom Tykwer, of David Mitchell‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCloud Atlas‰Ûù) or have ventured forth with their own original screenplay, as in the case of ‰ÛÏJupiter Ascending.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏJupiter Ascending‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Dystopian fears and violence.

The tale is at once baroque and corny. Ms. Kunis enters with a toilet brush in hand, doing the Cinderella thing with truckloads of pluck and eye makeup. In voice-over, she sketches how she got from her Russian mother‰Ûªs belly to scrubbing commodes in Chicago, a woeful, dreary existence that takes a weird turn when some creepy E. T.-like critters pop into her life. She responds to this surprising close encounter not with screams or dazed smiles but with what feels like typical 21st-century insouciance: She takes a photo of them with her phone. Her apparent indifference seems bizarre at best. (There‰Ûªs more going on because, well, in this movie there always is.) Yet, intentionally or not, it also telegraphs just how tough it is to impress an audience that‰Ûªs inundated and perhaps terminally dulled by images.

‰ÛÏCosta da Morte‰Ûù makes a respectable addition to recent landscape cinema, very nearly quoting Sharon Lockhart‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDouble Tide‰Ûù and James Benning‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCasting a Glance.‰Ûù But in a late shot of outdoor fires at night, the deep infernal reds summon the hand-tinting of some silent-film epic, bringing us full circle from contemporary avant-garde to cinema‰Ûªs earliest spectacles.

Humor is also embedded in these pretty pictures, much as it was in the documentary ‰ÛÏSweetgrass,‰Ûù with its radio-miked cowboys. While the faces of the people in Mr. PatiÌ±o‰Ûªs film are too tiny to make out, their voices are clear as day: a pair of fishermen griping about the government or two beach-going friends trading stories about goodies washing up on shore. Mr. PatiÌ±o also takes us to a carnival and a horse festival, sudden pockets of activity among the monumental vistas.

Mr. PatiÌ±o‰Ûªs subject, the Costa da Morte, or Coast of Death, in Galicia, earned its name from a history of shipwrecks (including the 2002 Prestige oil tanker disaster). But the film‰Ûªs distant imagery makes the turbulent waters and muddy inlands feel incongruously placid. The director‰Ûªs wide frame encompasses vast terrain from a middle vantage point, achieving views and noticing changes over time that a mere passer-by might not.

The Galicia region of Spain may have found a potential filmmaker laureate in Lois PatiÌ±o, who lustrously portrays its extreme coastal environments in ‰ÛÏCosta da Morte.‰Ûù In this high-definition series of cinematic landscape paintings, fishermen, woodcutters and other hardy mortals are often mere matchsticks within improbable panoramas of shimmering blue ocean, rock cascades and towering trees shrouded in mist.

He is also a student of film history and African-American culture, interests that explicitly converge in ‰ÛÏDa Sweet Blood,‰Ûù which is an affectionate remake of Bill Gunn‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGanja and Hess.‰Ûù That movie, first released in 1973 and currently part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center‰Ûªs revelatory series on black independent cinema of the 1970s and ‰Ûª80s, is a horror movie suffused with an experimental spirit, intellectual energy and a sly political sensibility. A product of the blaxploitation era, it is much more of a philosophical love story than an exercise in genre sensationalism.

This is, all in all, one of Mr. Lee‰Ûªs cooler joints, meaning both that it is suavely stylish and feels detached from its own emotions and motivations. It‰Ûªs not especially horrifying, or even very thought-provoking. It is touching, however, because it represents one frequently misunderstood, intermittently great filmmaker‰Ûªs tribute to another.

The weapon is wielded by Lafayette Hightower (Elvis Nolasco), an unstable, suicidal house guest. After being stabbed, Hess awakens with an addiction to blood. He tries at first to feed his new habit nonviolently ‰ÛÓ snatching plasma from a clinic ‰ÛÓ but soon settles into more traditional methods. The fact that he preys on prostitutes and other poor, single women allows Mr. Lee to revisit one of his perennial themes, the class divisions among African-Americans. Hess, with his mansion on the Vineyard and his chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce, is a prince and a demon, a lonely, disconnected man even before he becomes a literal monster.

Mr. Lee, who financed this project partly through a Kickstarter campaign, updates the tale while staying true to its ideas and (mostly) to its plot. Early and late, ‰ÛÏDa Sweet Blood‰Ûù visits a Brooklyn church where the minister (Thomas Jefferson Byrd) seems especially interested in the vampiric subtext of certain New Testament verses. These implications spring to the surface when Hess Green (Stephen Tyrone Williams), an aristocratic scholar and art collector, has a mishap with an Ashanti ritual dagger.

But then he meets Ganja (Zaraah Abrahams), Hightower‰Ûªs former wife, and, before long, Hess‰Ûªs partner in thirst. Their romance doesn‰Ûªt always go smoothly, but ‰ÛÏDa Sweet Blood of Jesus‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt delve too deeply into their emotions. Mr. Williams is a quiet, recessive screen presence, without the brooding charisma that Duane Jones brought to the character in ‰ÛÏGanja and Hess,‰Ûù and while Ms. Abrahams is more theatrical, the passion between them rarely rises above room temperature. Felicia Pearson and Rami Malek, in smaller roles, provide a crackle of humor, and Jeni Perillo shows up near the end to add some extra sexual heat.

‰ÛÏDa Sweet Blood of Jesus,‰Ûù Spike Lee‰Ûªs new film, is a grisly and ghoulish vampire story. It is also an evident labor of love. The opening images ‰ÛÓ a solitary dancer undulating on the Red Hook waterfront, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade and other Kings County spots ‰ÛÓ offer a reminder that no filmmaker has shot this borough as beautifully and fondly as Mr. Lee. Martha‰Ûªs Vineyard, where much of the action takes place, looks pretty good too. And though there are episodes of bloody mayhem and steamy sex, the mood is contemplative, at times almost serene. Mr. Lee has earned a reputation as a polemicist and provocateur, but he has also been, from the beginning, a sensualist and a visual stylist.

One bit on David Cross and Bob Odenkirk‰Ûªs 1990s sketch program, ‰ÛÏMr. Show,‰Ûù featured a yokel who, after the siege in Ruby Ridge, Idaho, declared his house a sovereign nation. That sharp, even impatient strain of satire returns in full force with Mr. Cross‰Ûªs modest, focused directorial debut, ‰ÛÏHits,‰Ûù which also centers on an embattled citizen.

Some of this might ring a bell from any number of media-circus sequences in movies. But Mr. Cross‰Ûªs almost too evenly paced film has a couple of virtues: a grounded realism for Katelyn‰Ûªs dealings with her dad, her co-workers at a bar (headed by Amy Sedaris) and others; and a delightful brief against inane Internet me-tooism. With Dave‰Ûªs fame, the town-meeting audience is flooded with carpetbagging Brooklynites; they‰Ûªre showing support for themselves as much as for Dave, and it feels like Mr. Cross‰Ûªs attempt at a real-life representation of Facebook.

Dave (Matt Walsh) works at the town dump in upstate New York. He attends open-mike town council meetings to rage against potholes, the fact that he can‰Ûªt rage indefinitely, and other injustices. A clip of one rant goes viral and attracts the opportunistic attentions of pampered Brooklyn activists, starting with Donovan (James Adomian), who also makes artisanal packaging materials. Dave‰Ûªs daughter, Katelyn (a note-perfect Meredith Hagner), meanwhile, is hellbent on recording an audition tape for a contest show, and gets jealous of the media circus surrounding the dotty dad she loves.
The gloriously scabrous ending to it all leaves the viewer wishing this talented writer had let it rip earlier.

The hypnotic ‰ÛÏGett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem‰Ûù is the story of a woman wronged by men and God, if finally, in a sense, redeemed by cinema. Under Israeli law, a woman can be divorced only if her husband presents her with a religious bill of divorce called a gett (sometimes spelled get). No gett, no divorce. The long-suffering title character desperately wants to be free of her husband, who refuses to let her go. So year after year, Viviane pleads her case before a rabbinic court, waiting for her divorce as days slip into weeks and then months, her pacific face glazed with tears and her body occasionally rocked by a laugh tinged with knowing and madness.

Viviane ‰ÛÓ brought to powerful life by Ronit Elkabetz with currents of humility and hauteur ‰ÛÓ is at once a fleshed-out character, a political metaphor, a shout to heaven and earth. The movie‰Ûªs title brings to mind all those novels named after their protagonists, especially women with tribulations (Jane Eyre, Madame Bovary, Anna Karenina), but the word trial also almost predictably suggests Franz Kafka. It soon becomes clear why. In Israel, all divorces and marriages, even secular ones, are under the power of rabbinic courts and therefore Orthodox Jewish law. A wife who doesn‰Ûªt receive a gett from her husband becomes an ‰ÛÏagunah‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ chained or anchored woman. A husband can be chained, too, although this is apparently rarer.

This makes for gripping cinema from start to finish, almost implausibly so. ‰ÛÏGett‰Ûù is the third movie featuring Viviane that Ms. Elkabetz has written and directed with her brother Shlomi Elkabetz, after ‰ÛÏTo Take a Wife‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏShiva‰Ûù a.k.a. ‰ÛÏSeven Days,‰Ûù and their work here is assured, streamlined and bold. As if to underscore the highly subjective quality of the storytelling in ‰ÛÏGett‰Ûù (he said, she said, they said), the Elkabetzes use only point-of-view shots throughout, which tethers every image ‰ÛÓ of the judges, of Viviane‰Ûªs legs, of Elisha‰Ûªs profile ‰ÛÓ to the perspective of one of the characters. This concentrated focus underscores the personal stakes and torques the tension so that even the image of Viviane letting down her hair ‰ÛÓ and incurring the wrath of the court ‰ÛÓ becomes a tremulous action scene.

With her dramatically pale face framed by a voluptuous dark cloud of hair, Ms. Elkabetz is never more effective than when she‰Ûªs holding still, her face so drained of emotion that it transforms into a screen within the screen on which another, indelibly private movie is playing. This stillness can be transfixing in close-up because the human face remains one of cinema‰Ûªs great landscapes even if our screens are cluttered with banally framed head-and-shoulder shots. There‰Ûªs nothing indifferent about the human face here, especially Viviane‰Ûªs. That‰Ûªs why every so often the filmmakers fill the screen with her face, allowing you to traverse its planes and trace its lines and, in the process, discover a woman who ‰ÛÓ even as she has been denied her freedom ‰ÛÓ retains a stubborn, transcendent humanity.

Although Viviane and Elisha both periodically speak ‰ÛÓ mostly to their representation and to the judges, sometimes to each other, quietly slipping between Hebrew and French ‰ÛÓ much of the talking is done for them. ‰ÛÏGett‰Ûù is a trial narrative complete with witness testimonies and periodic admonitions from the judge, but with little of the courtroom dramatics that characterize mainstream legal stories. Nothing if not dialectical, ‰ÛÏGett‰Ûù instead unfolds as a debate about love, marriage and human rights that turns on personal stories and philosophical asides, arguments and counterarguments. As one witness after another testifies about Viviane and Elisha‰Ûªs marriage, her virtue, his rectitude, it becomes clear that divorce here isn‰Ûªt a personal choice, but a matter for God and a people.

Set in the present, ‰ÛÏGett‰Ûù focuses on Viviane‰Ûªs determined efforts to divorce her longtime husband, Elisha (Simon Abkarian), a pious man with whom she has had several children and an apparently unhappy life. As radical in its narrative conceit as it is in its secular politics, the movie takes place almost entirely inside a rabbinic court presided over by a nameless judge (Eli Gorstein) who is flanked by two others on a raised podium embellished only with an emblem of a menorah. These three bearded men in black suits and kipas stare down upon Viviane and her lawyer, Carmel (Menashe Noy), who are usually seated at a small, plain table next to a similarly humble table where Elisha is dourly parked, sometimes with his brother and advocate, Shimon (Sasson Gabay).

That‰Ûªs too bad, because someone here has assembled a fine cast led by Colin Firth, who plays a spy in an agency hidden behind (and beneath) a Savile Row tailor shop where he swaps tradecraft secrets with Michael Caine, Mark Strong and the charming newcomer Taron Egerton. A lisping Samuel L. Jackson plays the villain, an American zillionaire with a henchwoman (Sofia Boutella) who, like Oscar Pistorius, uses leg prosthetics, though ones that are sharp enough to slice a man in half as cleanly as if he were an overcooked Easter ham. Nothing excites Mr. Vaughn as a director more than turning this chick loose, especially in slow motion with a gun in her pretty hand.

The problem is that Mr. Vaughn has no interest in, or perhaps understanding of, violence as a cinematic tool. He doesn‰Ûªt use violence; he squanders it. Some directors overdo it with crane shots, close-ups and dissolves, but Mr. Vaughn gorges on splatter, splashing rooms with red until it‰Ûªs the only color and emotional note left. His love for guns and guts at least made sense in the ‰ÛÏKick-Ass‰Ûù movies, mondo fairy tales about a child killer who locks and loads on the run. But his lack of modulation ruins ‰ÛÏKingsman,‰Ûù which is based on a comic book by Mark Millar and Dave Gibbons, and was written by Mr. Vaughn with his frequent collaborator Jane Goldman.
‰ÛÏKingsman: The Secret Service‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Splat.

The British director Matthew Vaughn first came to attention as a producer on ‰ÛÏLock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels,‰Ûù Mr. Ritchie‰Ûªs jokey, blunt-force gangster caper. Mr. Vaughn then went on to direct a Ritchie-esque gangster flick of his own, ‰ÛÏLayer Cake,‰Ûù now best remembered for Daniel Craig‰Ûªs star-making turn. Since then, Mr. Vaughn has directed the ultraviolent ‰ÛÏKick-Ass‰Ûù movies and a franchise reboot (‰ÛÏX-Men: First Class‰Ûù), both of which have raked in enough cash to assure that he‰Ûªll be running amok for a while. He‰Ûªs developed into an adequate if often generic manager of action and bodies, but his real talent is for delivering extreme violence with a shrug and a smile.

If you don‰Ûªt mind the church full of parishioners who are slaughtered to the sounds of Lynyrd Skynyrd‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFree Bird‰Ûù or the ‰ÛÏArab terrorists‰Ûù who are blown to smithereens or the guns that are pointed at pet dogs or the human heads that explode like firebombed melons as ‰ÛÏPomp and Circumstance‰Ûù plays, it may be possible to enjoy ‰ÛÏKingsman: The Secret Service.‰Ûù That said, as this bludgeoning movie grinds to a halt, its gears clogged by viscera and narrative overkill, even those who enjoy go-go gore may end up yearning for the soft touch and subtleties of Guy Ritchie.

At the outset, Keith, divorced and alienated from his college-age son, is a really bad guy. That Mr. Grant can bring Keith back from the edge more or less persuasively is a testament to his ability to convey genuine humility without mawkishness, once he sees the light.

‰ÛÏThe Rewrite‰Ûù has a relaxed, easygoing performance by J. K. Simmons as Keith‰Ûªs department head, Harold Lerner, who is married with four daughters. Marisa Tomei as Holly Carpenter, one of Keith‰Ûªs students ‰ÛÓ a single mother who has two jobs and becomes a possible love interest ‰ÛÓ is solidly likable. To its credit, ‰ÛÏThe Rewrite‰Ûù resists the temptation to fling them into each other‰Ûªs arms at the first opportunity. By the time they acknowledge their mutual attraction, they have a shared history on which to build.

But Mr. Grant, now 54, is facing the expiration date of his twinkly boyish act. And in ‰ÛÏThe Rewrite,‰Ûù as he plays a spoiled screenwriter and one-hit Hollywood wonder on the skids, you can feel the strain as he goes through the routine one more time.

Desperate for work, Keith agrees to teach screenwriting at Binghamton University, near the New York-Pennsylvania border. Breezing into Binghamton, N.Y., a town he loathes on sight, Keith blithely proclaims to anyone within earshot: ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt believe that writing can be taught. You can‰Ûªt teach talent.‰Ûù Without a second thought, he beds Karen (Bella Heathcote), who ends up in his class.

‰ÛÏThe Rewrite,‰Ûù the fourth screen collaboration of Hugh Grant and the director and screenwriter Marc Lawrence, is a return to form for the long-running team after the debacle six years ago of ‰ÛÏDid You Hear About the Morgans?‰Ûù By ‰ÛÏreturn to form,‰Ûù I don‰Ûªt mean to suggest that their pre-‰ÛÏMorgans‰Ûù films ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏTwo Weeks Notice‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMusic and Lyrics‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ were more than reasonably intelligent romantic comedies buoyed by Mr. Grant‰Ûªs appeal as a bumbling, sheepish charmer.

Binghamton, nicknamed the Carousel Capital of the World, is also the childhood home of Rod Serling, whose ‰ÛÏWalking Distance‰Ûù episode of ‰ÛÏThe Twilight Zone‰Ûù embodies the movie‰Ûªs message in a father‰Ûªs advice to his son: ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªve been looking behind you. ... Try looking ahead.‰Ûù

The smart, needling dialogue in these opening scenes has a satirical bite almost equal to that of the Showtime series ‰ÛÏEpisodes.‰Ûù It sets a high standard that the rest of the movie can‰Ûªt maintain, as the story settles into a formulaic tale about a scoundrel‰Ûªs redemption.

Keith also meets his nemesis, Mary Weldon (Allison Janney), a severe, scowling Jane Austen scholar, tenured professor and head of the college ethics committee, and an imperious type Ms. Janney has down cold. When they‰Ûªre introduced, Keith, straining to be witty, remarks, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm just a little bit tired of female empowerment.‰Ûù From that moment, she regards him with suspicion and contempt.

Instead of choosing his students based on their writing samples, Keith researches their Facebook profiles and stacks his course with the prettiest women who applied. On his first day on the job, he dismisses the class for a month, but not before falsely claiming that Matt Damon is interested in starring in his latest project.

His character, Keith Michaels, won an Oscar for best original screenplay in 1999 for something called ‰ÛÏParadise Misplaced,‰Ûù but hasn‰Ûªt had a hit since, and his A-list status has plummeted. The squirm-inducing opening scene shows Keith desperately pitching a concept in which Jack Nicholson fakes his death and stages his own funeral to see what people really think of him. This idea is nixed by producers in pursuit of the latest trend: ‰ÛÏedgy comedies with a kick-ass type woman.‰Ûù

Spooked at a young age by a bunny-hunting trip, Harlon (Nick Krause) is harangued by his hard-drinking father and bullied at school, where he‰Ûªs failing the 11th grade. Wounded but caring, he lumbers within sight of normalcy when a shoplifting newcomer (Britt Robertson) starts joining him on jaunts in an abandoned factory. But addicted to a scourge straight out of a 1950s congressional hearing ‰ÛÓ comic books! ‰ÛÓ Harlon begins to hear voices more and more often.

But Anthony Di Pietro‰Ûªs screenplay keeps dropping the ball, eventually falling back on hallucinations, a narrative dead end. While ‰ÛÏWhite Rabbit‰Ûù is not a lost cause, its difficult story of mistreatment and lashing out proves too much of a challenge to tell well.

Mr. McCann, who dived into mental illness with 2002‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRevolution #9,‰Ûù has a number of factors in his favor: the cinematographer Alan McIntyre Smith working overtime at conveying a woozy beauty; evocative country locations (from Dad‰Ûªs tool shed to an otherwise throwaway shot with a cherry picker); and superb casting of children. The dramatically featured Mr. Krause has plunging, expressive eyebrows, recalling Ezra Miller‰Ûªs in ‰ÛÏWe Need to Talk About Kevin.‰Ûù

The opening of ‰ÛÏWhite Rabbit‰Ûù leaves little doubt that a storm is brewing: A teenager named Harlon broods in a car, then turns to the camera with the heavy slowness of a reptile. Like the thickly atmospheric photography, the shot sets a foreboding tone. But all too much of Tim McCann‰Ûªs drama about this disturbed loner comes to feel like a checklist of warning signs.

In Mr. Jordan‰Ûªs portrayal of Jamie, this handsome talented musical theater performer (‰ÛÏNewsies‰Ûù) goes for the jugular in taking down his character and making him insufferable. Jamie doesn‰Ûªt court Cathy so much as lunge at her in a flurry of self-congratulatory egoism. He says all the right loving words to Cathy, but you never sense that to him she is anything more than just a trophy: a shiksa goddess.

Soon enough Cathy tires of being an attractive appendage to her husband at literary parties at which we see him being mobbed while she patiently waits for the event to end. Unable to find employment in New York, she goes to Ohio year after year to work in a summer stock company. One of the best songs is her wistful, amusing ‰ÛÏA Summer in Ohio.‰Ûù In one painful scene, Jamie pays her a weekend visit in which he announces upon arrival that he can‰Ûªt even stay one night.

‰ÛÏThe Last Five Years,‰Ûù the composer Jason Robert Brown‰Ûªs emotionally fraught musical about a passionate relationship that crashes and burns, almost requires some familiarity with its rarefied milieu: the New York City hothouse of ravenously ambitious performers and writers. Over the years, the show, which had its premiere in Chicago in 2001 and opened Off Broadway the next year, has gained traction as a regional theater staple. It is now a movie adapted and directed by Richard LaGravenese. Its lovers, Cathy Hiatt, an aspiring actress played by a winsome Anna Kendrick, and Jamie Wellerstein, by a fire-breathing Jeremy Jordan, fall in love and marry in a whirlwind of romantic hyperbole.
‰ÛÏThe Last Five Years‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). For sexual material, brief strong language and a drug image.

The five-year relationship comes apart after Jamie‰Ûªs first novel is published and becomes an overnight sensation reminiscent of the young Jay McInerney, or of Mr. Brown himself, whose first Off Broadway show was produced when he was 25. While Jamie‰Ûªs career soars, Cathy‰Ûªs never achieves liftoff. Songs that tell their story from both their points of view are among the smartest show tunes this side of Stephen Sondheim.

Much is made of Jamie‰Ûªs Jewishness and his worship of Cathy in the song ‰ÛÏShiksa Goddess.‰Ûù Later in the story when Cathy is depressed, he tries to cheer her up with ‰ÛÏThe Schmuel Song,‰Ûù a sprawling comic yarn about a tailor in Eastern Europe, that for all its cleverness nearly stops the movie dead in its tracks as Jamie performs it in their living room.

Ms. Kendrick‰Ûªs Cathy is dazed by Jamie‰Ûªs forceful charm as he spins out fantasies of them as a creative power couple about to conquer the world. He won‰Ûªt even allow the possibility that either of them might fail. But as the movie follows her from audition to audition and she doesn‰Ûªt get called back, her spirits sink and her self-esteem withers.

In both the show and in the movie, the timelines of Cathy and Jamie run in opposite directions. Her songs begin at the end of the relationship, while Jamie‰Ûªs start at the beginning. They meet in the middle with Jamie‰Ûªs marriage proposal in Central Park. It can be a little confusing.

The turning point comes during his anguished song, ‰ÛÏIf I Didn‰Ûªt Believe in You,‰Ûù in which he gives himself away with his declaration: ‰ÛÏI will not fail so you can be comfortable, Cathy/I will not lose because you can‰Ûªt win.‰Ûù
And there you have his dirty little secret: His personal ambition trumps love.

At heart a dotty look at oldsters struggling to adapt to an unwelcoming modernity, ‰ÛÏShadows‰Ûù has the bones of an anarchic sitcom. The jokes don‰Ûªt always land, but the group‰Ûªs determination to befriend a bewildered techie ‰ÛÓ without eating him ‰ÛÓ is strangely touching. Once they‰Ûªve learned how to Google pictures of virgins for themselves, though, he‰Ûªd better watch his back.

It‰Ûªs what they‰Ûªre not doing that irritates Viago (Mr. Waititi), an 18th-century dandy who‰Ûªs had enough of blood splatters on the couch and stray spinal columns littering the floor. But while Vlad (Mr. Clement), over 800 years old and ‰ÛÏa bit of a pervert,‰Ûù is happy to pick up the vacuum, Deacon (Jonathan Brugh) ‰ÛÓ a spry 183 ‰ÛÓ would rather be out on the town. As for the Nosferatu-like Petyr (Ben Fransham), well, no one really expects an 8,000-year-old to do dishes.

A daring film crew, armed with crucifixes and guarantees of safety, sets out to record the daily lives of four vampire housemates in ‰ÛÏWhat We Do in the Shadows,‰Ûù a goofily amusing mockumentary from the New Zealand comedians and actors Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.

Set in modern-day Wellington, New Zealand (the exterior of the vamps‰Ûª house is the headquarters of Peter Jackson‰Ûªs production company), this weird and witty spoof filters the routines of the living through the lens of the long dead. For our gang of ghouls, encounters with passing werewolves ‰ÛÓ whose full-moon preparations are ingeniously telescoped into a hilarious aside ‰ÛÓ are ultimately less problematic than figuring out how to look good when you have no reflection. Or getting into a hot club without a direct invitation.

Like greyhounds after the hare, ‰ÛÏWyrmwood: Road of the Dead‰Ûù bursts out of the gate panting and doesn‰Ûªt let up. The hare in this case is a mysterious zombie plague that follows a meteor shower in the Australian outback, and the greyhounds are a pair of siblings whose particular talents ‰ÛÓ one artisanal, the other supernormal ‰ÛÓ prove especially useful in battling the undead.

Filming mostly on weekends over three and a half years, the director, Kiah Roache-Turner (who wrote the script with his brother Tristan), exhibits a blithe, go-for-broke style that doesn‰Ûªt hang about to commiserate over the infected or ingested. So when Barry (Jay Gallagher), a studly car mechanic, is forced to shoot his wife and child with a nail gun, there‰Ûªs barely a beat before he tightens his tool belt and heads out to rescue his sister, Brooke (Bianca Bradey), from a sadistic doctor with a soft spot for KC and the Sunshine Band. There‰Ûªs no crying in the apocalypse.

Ambulant corpses may be tramping all over our movie and television screens these days, but ‰ÛÏWyrmwood‰Ûù has enough novelty ‰ÛÓ and more than enough energy ‰ÛÓ to best its minuscule budget. Tim Nagle‰Ûªs photography is sharp and frisky, whether capturing the black-and-green miasma of zombie breath (which, don‰Ûªt you know, is a fine substitute for petrol) or the priceless comic reactions of Leon Burchill as Benny, Barry‰Ûªs unflappable sidekick. Benny doesn‰Ûªt know much about zombies, but he does know that few weapons are more powerful than a man in a tool belt and a woman in a rage.

There‰Ûªs also another room where he keeps his collection of canes, cuffs and other specialized equipment. Early in their relationship, he gives a tour to Anastasia Steele, his young inamorata, played with captivating sensitivity by Dakota Johnson. ‰ÛÏThat‰Ûªs a flogger,‰Ûù he explains, in one of several moments in Kelly Marcel‰Ûªs script that sound a little redundant, and more than a little silly, when uttered on screen.

Christian has a lot of psychic baggage, but for most of this installment in the ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù trilogy, it‰Ûªs obscured by his physical stuff. In the tradition of Leonardo DiCaprio‰Ûªs Jay Gatsby, James Franco‰Ûªs Alien (from ‰ÛÏSpring Breakers‰Ûù) and Kanye West‰Ûªs Kanye West, this young mogul (played by Jamie Dornan) treats luxury consumption as an erotic passion and a spiritual calling. He has his own helicopter, which he pilots himself; an underground garage full of cars with a chauffeur to drive them; a penthouse apartment with a grand piano; and a walk-in closet so big that his suits hang without even touching.

W.H. Auden once wrote that ‰ÛÏthe proof that pornography has no literary value is that, if one attempts to read it in any other way than as a sexual stimulus, to read it, say, as a psychological case-history of the author‰Ûªs sexual fantasies, one is bored to tears.‰Ûù In defiance of this irrefutable good sense, the ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù phenomenon has spawned innumerable kink-themed think pieces, though the analysis has dwelt less on Ms. James‰Ûªs psyche than on the fantasies of the tens of millions of women who have bought her books. The writers transform their boredom into mockery and judgment as they circle around a tantalizing, perhaps frustrating question. Why do so many women read these novels, even though they have no literary value?

The movie is neither one of those things. It dabbles in romantic comedy and splashes around in melodrama, but the one thing it can‰Ûªt be ‰ÛÓ the thing the novel so trashily and triumphantly is ‰ÛÓ is pornography. Ms. Taylor-Johnson‰Ûªs sex scenes are not that much different from other R-rated sex scenes, though there are more of them and more hardware is involved. You know the routine: an arched neck, some curled toes, a buttock here, a breast there, a wisp of pubic hair, a muffled moan, another BeyoncÌ© song. Maybe a riding crop for variety.

At the end of a recent New York sneak preview of ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ in the blackout between the final lines of dialogue (‰ÛÏAnastasia!‰Ûù ‰ÛÏChristian!‰Ûù) and the first breathy notes of the last BeyoncÌ© song ‰ÛÓ a lot of the audience burst out laughing. The source of that laughter continues to puzzle and intrigue me, perhaps more than the actual movie did. Was it delight? Derision? Embarrassment? Surprise? All of the above?

I‰Ûªm no expert, but I can venture a guess: for fun. They seem to be the kind of books you can simultaneously have fun with, make fun of, trash and cherish and adapt to the pursuit of your own pleasures. Which brings me back to the laughter at the end of the sneak preview. ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù might not be a good movie ‰ÛÓ O.K., it‰Ûªs a terrible movie ‰ÛÓ but it might nonetheless be a movie that feels good to see, whether you squirm or giggle or roll your eyes or just sit still and take your punishment.

In the book, this hardly matters. In fact, it‰Ûªs something of an asset. Anastasia‰Ûªs inner life exists to fill the space between sex scenes, and her zigzagging responses to Christian‰Ûªs proposals make the fantasy more inclusive while also providing an escape clause. ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù is both daring and conventional, falling back into traditional gender roles even as it plays with transgressive desires. Christian‰Ûªs sexual tastes are intriguing to Anastasia, but they are also the result of emotional wounds that she sets herself the task of healing. He wants to take charge of her, and she wants to take care of him. She tolerates the kind of sex he wants, and even enjoys some of it, but what she really wants is something more, and she wants to make him want that, too. She loves him, but love in these tales functions less as an emotional ideal than as a literary safe word, a return ticket to the land of romance.

Reviewers have complained about Ms. James‰Ûªs pedestrian prose, but the bad writing serves an important purpose. ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù not only destigmatizes kink, bringing bondage and spanking to airport bookstores and reading groups across the land. But it also, so to speak, de-sophisticates certain sexual practices, taking them out of the chateau and the boudoir and other fancy French places and planting them in the soil of Anglo-American banality. If E. L. James were a better writer, her books would be more ‰ÛÓ to use one of Anastasia‰Ûªs favorite words ‰ÛÓ intimidating. And much less useful.

Not that professional ambition plays much of a role in Anastasia‰Ûªs life. Or, for that matter, in Christian‰Ûªs. He runs a big, vague company but doesn‰Ûªt really seem to do much work. Ana is an English major who works part time in a hardware store, which is one of the places Christian shows up to surprise her. He‰Ûªs always doing that ‰ÛÓ at a nightclub, at her apartment, at a hotel bar in Savannah, Ga., where she‰Ûªs having a drink with her mom. It‰Ûªs a little unnerving.
‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Different strokes.

These are kind of a mess. The problem isn‰Ûªt that she‰Ûªs indecisive or conflicted or capricious, or that she reacts to Christian‰Ûªs proposal of a formal, contractually established dominant-submissive relationship with ambivalence. Who wouldn‰Ûªt? (And I‰Ûªm not passing judgment on his lifestyle. It‰Ûªs just that I have a strong bias against having sex with anyone who would use the word ‰ÛÏincentivize‰Ûù in conversation, as Christian does the very first time he and Anastasia lock eyes.) The problem is that as a character, Anastasia makes no sense. Her behavior has no logic, no pattern, no coherent set of causes or boundaries.

Anastasia‰Ûªs portion of the dialogue is more likely to be funny on purpose. Critics of Ms. James‰Ûªs books have called attention to Ana‰Ûªs habit of exclaiming ‰ÛÏWow!‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏHoly crap!‰Ûù when a more heightened vocabulary (or no words at all) might seem to be called for. But the energy that brings her and Christian together is comic as well as sexual. She‰Ûªs an ordinary, guileless, somewhat clueless young woman ‰ÛÓ kind of basic, as they say nowadays ‰ÛÓ pulled into the orbit of an enigmatic aristocrat with peculiar tastes and dark secrets. Their first meeting takes place in his office, where Anastasia, with her messy bangs and shapeless blue cardigan, looks absurdly out of place amid the sleek corporate Valkyries. ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù may have begun as ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù fan fiction, but Ms. Taylor-Johnson wittily notes its kinship with ‰ÛÏThe Devil Wears Prada.‰Ûù

Mr. Dornan, given the job of inspiring lust, fascination and also maybe a tiny, thrilling frisson of fear, succeeds mainly in eliciting pity. In print, Christian is a blur and a blank ‰ÛÓ a screen onto which any given reader can project a customized masculine ideal. On the screen, he risks becoming just some guy, which is how Mr. Dornan plays him, without mischief or mystery. There are actors who might have given Christian a jolt of naughty, bossy life, most of them creatures of an earlier movie era. Cary Grant. William Powell. Paul Newman. Sean Connery if you wanted the roughness a little closer to the surface. Jamie Bell was a convincing dominant in Lars von Trier‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNymphomaniac: Volume II,‰Ûù though his character was more artisan than aristocrat.

Mr. Dornan has the bland affect of a model, by which I mean a figure made of balsa wood or Lego. What vitality ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù possesses belongs to Ms. Johnson, who is a champion lip-biter and no slouch at blushing, eye-rolling and trembling on the verge of tears. She‰Ûªs a good actress, in other words, and Ms. Taylor-Johnson matches the colors and the visual texture ‰ÛÓ the chilly blues and pulsing reds, the drab daylight and the velvety dusk ‰ÛÓ to Anastasia‰Ûªs moods and desires.

The last answer seems the most likely, since Sam Taylor-Johnson‰Ûªs screen adaptation of E. L. James‰Ûªs best seller is, like the book itself, a wildly confused treatment of a perennial confusing subject. Sex is a knotty business, perhaps all the more so when actual knots are involved, as they tend to be in the world of Christian Grey, the kinky billionaire bachelor who lends his name and his impressive collection of neckties to this Seattle-set tale of seduction, submission and commodity fetishism.

Playing the director‰Ûªs alter ego, Mr. Turner is a sly, agreeable presence. Bill as a child (Sebastian Rice Edwards in ‰ÛÏHope and Glory‰Ûù) was watchful in a manner befitting a future director, and in this chapter, he sometimes seems more observer than participant. But that is at least partly a self-protective ruse. Percy is a passionate rebel who eagerly courts trouble, for laughs and for revenge.

Another private, Redmond (Pat Shortt), is a seasoned skiver. This wonderful bit of slang connotes a special blend of scheming and laziness, a commitment to do as little as possible without getting caught. Bill is somewhere in between Percy and Redmond, wielding a quietly subversive irony as his weapon against the absurdities of army life.

To appreciate ‰ÛÏQueen and Country,‰Ûù John Boorman‰Ûªs gently nostalgic, quasi-autobiographical film about Britain in the early 1950s, it isn‰Ûªt entirely necessary to have seen his earlier ‰ÛÏHope and Glory.‰Ûù You should, of course, see it, if you haven‰Ûªt already: One of a handful of great movies that look at World War II through the eyes of a child, ‰ÛÏHope and Glory‰Ûù is distinguished by mischievous good humor and by the unashamed acknowledgment that war can be fun as well as horrible.

‰ÛÏQueen and Country‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt quite have the bittersweet intensity of its precursor. The terrible magic of the war is missing, and so is the heightened, wide-eyed perceptiveness of the child protagonist. A young man is a more pedestrian creature, and the ‰Ûª50s a quieter decade. Bill‰Ûªs family, the focus of much of the drama in ‰ÛÏHope and Glory,‰Ûù is glimpsed here in a few lovely scenes. The update is welcome.

Much as the war did in ‰ÛÏHope and Glory,‰Ûù the army provides a loose frame around the action here. But Mr. Boorman approaches his story in the relaxed and generous manner of a raconteur, charming the audience rather than pushing us through the machinery of a plot. Our attention wanders into Bill‰Ûªs romantic life, where his own attention is divided between Sophie (Aimee-Ffion Edwards) a warm, good-humored nurse, and a chilly, melancholy college student he knows as Ophelia (Tamsin Egerton). Each has other suitors, which is awkward, farcical and painful, like much of what happens in the movie.

At least that‰Ûªs how it was for 9-year-old Bill Rohan. ‰ÛÏQueen and Country,‰Ûù which catches up with Bill (Callum Turner) at the age of 18, begins with a flashback to a memorable scene of childish jubilation during the Blitz, as the boy and his classmates respond with cries of ‰ÛÏThanks, Adolf!‰Ûù to the news that a German bomb has smashed their school. A similar irreverence pervades this new chapter in Bill‰Ûªs adventures. When he is conscripted into the army, his natural resistance to authority is both tested and given fresh opportunities to express itself. The military, with its endless protocols and musty hierarchies, is a nonconformist‰Ûªs purgatory and a prankster‰Ûªs paradise.

And so is the portrait, fleeting yet precisely detailed, of Britain at a time of change. The overt manifestation of that change is the arrival of the sovereign who gives ‰ÛÏQueen and Country‰Ûù its title, and who inspires cynicism and patriotism in its characters. But as the young Elizabeth IItakes the throne, you can feel the ground shifting, and a different Britain coming into view: the one that would give the world angry young playwrights, rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll bands and resourceful, iconoclastic filmmakers like John Boorman.

Rather than being sent to fight in the Korean War, Bill and his best pal, Percy Hapgood (the Cagneyesque Caleb Landry Jones), are put in charge of a typing class. Their supervisor is a humorless martinet, always eager to report the tiniest infraction to his commander (Richard E. Grant). There is a stark, contentious generational split between the older officers who served in the earlier war and the young men who are a bit sick of hearing about it and also eager to taste some of the freedom the elders fought to preserve. And Mr. Boorman, now 82, is steadfastly on the side of youth.

Wesley will help Bianca conquer boy phobia; Bianca will help him pass science (speaking of stereotypes). Cue a makeover, the spread of an embarrassing viral video at the behest of the class mean girl (Bella Thorne) and the most awkward sushi date since, well, ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe DUFF‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). #Language.

Bianca (Mae Whitman) learns that her peers regard her as the DUFF, or designated ugly fat friend, of Casey (Bianca Santos) and Jess (Skyler Samuels). ‰ÛÏYou can‰Ûªt take it literally,‰Ûù says her neighbor Wesley (Robbie Amell), a self-identified jock. Of course, the effervescent Ms. Whitman (TV‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏParenthood‰Ûù) is not ugly or fat by the standards of any era or dictionary.

Even in this would-be subversive comedy, success means getting the guy. Getting good grades (as Bianca does) is not enough, nor is writing the front-page article in the school paper. (Bianca‰Ûªs assignment is ‰ÛÏWhat homecoming means to me.‰Ûù It must be a slow news day, even with the principal‰Ûªs crackdown on cyberbullying.) On-screen hashtags, references to social media and closing credits with Twitter handles serve as inscribed marketing.

Adapted from a novel by Kody Keplinger, whose website says that she wrote the book as a senior in high school, ‰ÛÏThe DUFF‰Ûù begins, in an apparent nod to ‰ÛÏThe Breakfast Club,‰Ûù by informing us that teenage stereotypes have changed: ‰ÛÏJocks play video games, princesses are on antidepressants.‰Ûù You could have fooled these characters, who ruthlessly enforce the traditional pecking order.

Who knows what the world will look like in 2025? The goofballs from the smart-dumb 2010 guy comedy ‰ÛÏHot Tub Time Machine‰Ûù are accidentally given an advance peek in the frenzied, chaotic sequel. As could have been predicted, ‰ÛÏHot Tub Time Machine 2‰Ûù is vastly inferior to the first ‰ÛÏHot Tub,‰Ûù but it‰Ûªs not stupid so much as desperately frantic.

The future, a decade hence, is no great shakes. Some amenities, like telephone holograms, are clichÌ©s. The wittiest is a self-driving, emotionally volatile smart car that can turn on you if you‰Ûªre not polite when giving it directions. It can also hold a grudge.

Because these and other acts take place in the future, the screenplay (by Josh Heald) suggests they didn‰Ûªt really happen. And if they did, it might have been in an alternative universe. Whether something did or didn‰Ûªt happen, and the comic confusion as the future bumps into the past: those are the smart parts of a movie that is not as idiotic as it pretends to be.

That tub, which when given the right chemical infusion can open a portal to the past, is an infernal contraption that at full steamy bubble suggests a cauldron of boiling urine with an attached tornado.

The original film‰Ûªs flurry of joking pop-cultural references has become a white-out blizzard of allusions. Both movies are directed by Steve Pink, whose strategy is to keep the momentum so breathless that the story outpaces the mental agility of an audience with a presumed attention span of zero.

Lou, now a bewigged, superannuated party animal with the wardrobe of an ‰Ûª80s hair-band god, resembles a caricature from ‰ÛÏRock of Ages.‰Ûù While hosting a bacchanalian corporate bash, he is shot in the groin. Desperate to retrieve his manhood, he jumps into the same magical hot tub to take him back far enough in time to anticipate the incident and emerge with his genitalia intact. Instead, he is blasted forward 10 years.

‰ÛÏHot Tub Time Machine 2‰Ûù is clever, but the absence of Adam (John Cusack), one of the original time travelers, is keenly felt. Mr. Cusack gave the first ‰ÛÏHot Tub‰Ûù a poignant emotional core that is missing in the sequel. In both movies, the voice of caution and common sense belongs to Lou‰Ûªs nerdy son, Jacob (Clark Duke), who has become his butler. Instead of Mr. Cusack, the film substitutes Adam Scott playing his son, Adam Jr.
‰ÛÏHot Tub Time Machine 2‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For crude sexual content and language throughout, graphic nudity, drug use and some violence.

In the years since their trip back to 1986 ‰ÛÓ during which they encountered their younger selves, along with ex-girlfriends ‰ÛÓ Lou Dorchen (Rob Corddry), once a depressed loser, has used his foreknowledge of the future to become the chief honcho of the tech giant Lougle (think Google, relocated to New Orleans), and is nicknamed ‰ÛÏthe father of the Internet.‰Ûù His best buddy and fellow time traveler Nick Webber (Craig Robinson) has also done well, forging a music career by stealing songs like Lisa Loeb‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStay (I Missed You)‰Ûù and making them hits for himself.

Both ‰ÛÏHot Tub‰Ûù movies have the genre‰Ûªs requisite nods to homophobia with scenes in which Lou and Nick are forced to have sex with each other in front of an audience. In ‰ÛÏHot Tub 2,‰Ûù the deed is required when the men appear on the future‰Ûªs most popular television program, a sadistic game show called ‰ÛÏCelebrity Choozy Doozy.‰Ûù But the gay panic that is a guy-movie staple is treated so lightly that such antics are almost immediately forgotten.

Ms. Wilder gradually focuses on a self-proclaimed ‰ÛÏbossy‰Ûù rascal named Jiovanni ‰ÛÓ diplomatically described as having great leadership potential ‰ÛÓ and the articulate, younger Lucy, who likes some roughhousing but believes in reasonable limits. Together with Alex, the enthusiastic but eventually exasperated head teacher, they represent the range of qualities we might expect to see.

At the recently opened Teddy McArdle Free School, students ranging from age 6 to 11 choose what to learn and can call meetings to write new rules or to mediate disagreements. (‰ÛÏSo we don‰Ûªt have to do math?‰Ûù is one boy‰Ûªs reaction.) You might feel like it‰Ûªs your own first day there, as the observational black-and-white documentary whirls through glimpses of elementary-school-age children at play and in conference; stronger personalities bubble to the surface, and a year of schooling melds into something like a single, claustrophobic eternal day.

In ‰ÛÏApproaching the Elephant,‰Ûù the director Amanda Rose Wilder embeds herself in a tiny New Jersey ‰ÛÏfree school‰Ûù that practices a style of self-directed learning, an idea originated by anarchists in Barcelona in the 1900s. Her film invites questions about what makes good schooling, or a strong documentary, but she seems most enamored by what children do, period.

There‰Ûªs still something exhilarating about the school‰Ûªs experiment and the children‰Ûªs ability to apply democratic principles without clobbering one another (much). Frederick Wiseman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHigh School II,‰Ûù about an alternative school in Spanish Harlem, is one clear optimistic precedent, but Ms. Wilder, in her debut feature, riskily opts to leave much of the children‰Ûªs educational activity fairly vague. Which gives it one more thing in common with school: You need to pay attention.

She and the screenwriters (Christopher Cleveland, Bettina Gilois and Grant Thompson) also have a social awareness that blunts and complicates some of the clichÌ©s lurking in the story. ‰ÛÏMcFarland‰Ûù is very much a heroic-teacher melodrama about a white coach leading a team of poor, nonwhite strivers toward glory, but for the most part it avoids the traps of condescension and self-congratulation that so often ensnare well-meaning examples of this durable genre. It also helps that the white coach in question ‰ÛÓ a real-life character whose actual surname is White ‰ÛÓ is played by Kevin Costner, for whom gruff compassion is by now second nature.

The sport is dominated by mostly white, wealthy schools in places like Palo Alto, with fancy uniforms and lavish facilities. McFarland‰Ûªs high school, which mostly educates the children of Mexican farmworkers, is across the street from a prison, and the surrounding area is flat and dusty, except for the orchards and fields where the students and their parents work. For hill training, there are mounds of almond hulls covered in tarps. Running shoes are a luxury none of the athletes‰Ûª families can afford.

Jim White and his family ‰ÛÓ two daughters (Morgan Saylor and Elsie Fisher) and a wife (Maria Bello) ‰ÛÓ move to McFarland after he has been fired just about everywhere else. The first scene shows him losing his temper in a locker room in Boise, Idaho, and accidentally injuring an obnoxious player. Jim is less than fulfilled in his new job as a physical education teacher and assistant football coach until he spots a talented runner among his students and decides to organize a cross-country team.
‰ÛÏMcFarland, USA‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Mild violence and brutal labor conditions.

There are some familiar characters: the beleaguered principal (Valente Rodriguez); the wise, all-seeing local shopkeeper (Danny Mora); the no-nonsense mother (Diana Maria Riva), dispensing tough love and homemade enchiladas.

‰ÛÏMcFarland, USA‰Ûù might recall the season of ‰ÛÏFriday Night Lights‰Ûù when Coach Taylor went to work in hardscrabble East Dillon. And like that series, the movie organizes its picture of the team and the town around a portrait of the coach. (His family plays less of a role, however. Cheryl White is no Tami Taylor, and Mr. Costner remains one of the last of the old-school movie patriarchs.)

A different kind of movie would have explored Thomas‰Ûªs life more deeply, and dug into his relationship with his coach. But this one ‰ÛÓ a slick and safe Disney version of a fascinating and complicated reality ‰ÛÓ aims to be rousing rather than revelatory, and it mostly succeeds.

The plot tracks the team‰Ûªs rise and Jim‰Ûªs awakening. He starts out uncomfortable in his new surroundings but learns to love and respect the runners and their families. And also, of course, to earn their trust. They start out calling him ‰ÛÏWhite‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏBlanco,‰Ûù and one of the big emotional moments arrives when they start calling him ‰ÛÏCoach‰Ûù for the first time. While some of the seven racers are lightly sketched ‰ÛÓ the chubby kid (Ramiro Rodriguez), the ladies‰Ûª man (Sergio Avelar), the coach‰Ûªs pet (Hector Duran) ‰ÛÓ stereotypes are generally avoided. And though there is a brief episode involving gang violence, McFarland is depicted as a place of hard-working, loving families struggling with poverty and prejudice rather than a nightmare of crime and dysfunction.

It‰Ûªs perhaps dispiriting that such a point even needs to be made, though ‰ÛÏMcFarland, USA‰Ûù deserves credit for making it sensitively and well. Mr. Costner, with his knack for grumpy understatement, manages both to dominate the film and to deflect attention from himself. One of his best traits as an actor is his generosity: He is a great scene-sharer, adept at using his charisma to illuminate the gifts of his fellow performers. Here he does that most notably with Carlos Pratts, a quiet actor with interesting, sad eyes who plays Thomas Valles, the reluctant star of the McFarland squad.

An entirely predictable, mostly honorable movie, ‰ÛÏMcFarland, USA‰Ûù tells the story of a washed-up coach who turns a bunch of misfits into a team of champions. It‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHoosiers,‰Ûù more or less, relocated to a poor agricultural town in California‰Ûªs Central Valley in 1987. The sport is not basketball, football or baseball ‰ÛÓ the usual athletic pursuits in this genre ‰ÛÓ but cross-country running. The director, Niki Caro, who is originally from New Zealand and whose earlier films include ‰ÛÏWhale Rider‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏNorth Country,‰Ûù has an eye for dramatic landscapes, which lends some visual grandeur to the training and racing scenes.

Mr. Szifron is banking that his movie will stir up strong emotions, which at times makes ‰ÛÏWild Tales‰Ûù feel like an experiment in human psychology, both his and yours. A few of the stories have a modest political undertow that, however sincere, largely exists to give the other characters permission to behave badly and you the go-ahead to laugh when they do. In ‰ÛÏThe Rats,‰Ûù Moza tells the diner cook (a peerless Rita Cortese), that Cuenca ruined her family and is now running for office. In response, the cook suggests that they poison him. And why not? Cuenca isn‰Ûªt just a political menace, he‰Ûªs also a bad customer ‰ÛÓ his fate is sealed. It‰Ûªs no wonder that you snicker when the cook slams down some rat poison, her cheeks shaking and her eyes flashing conspiratorially with the edits and camera moves.

Comedy both leads and bleeds in ‰ÛÏWild Tales,‰Ûù which starts with a slinky number, Isabel (MarÌ_a Marull), roller-boarding onto a plane and into an unexpected reunion. It turns out that the unctuous guy across the aisle, Salgado (Dario Grandinetti), knows her former (never seen) boyfriend. A music critic, Salgado once sat in judgment of the boyfriend, to whom the critic had happily delivered a soul-crushing critique. An older woman seated nearby, overhearing their conversation, pipes in that she too ‰ÛÓ wouldn‰Ûªt you know it? ‰ÛÓ was acquainted with the boyfriend and so it goes as one passenger after another echoes the same refrain. Just as each realizes that they know the same man, the plane banks and a queasy mix of dread and understanding begins ricocheting from face to face and then ....

Not that you necessarily notice, at least not often. The best stories, like ‰ÛÏRoad to Hell‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a cautionary tale about untrammeled road rage ‰ÛÓ are so well executed (pun sort of intended) and as narratively stripped down as a Road Runner cartoon that they make worrying over ethics seem somehow self-indulgent. The cartoonish quality of Mr. Szifron‰Ûªs violence has age-old appeal, of course, which is itself a moral to ponder. Notably, he is on shakier ground when he tries to complicate the stakes, as he does in ‰ÛÏThe Deal,‰Ûù about a wealthy family that pins a crime on a gardener who‰Ûªs willing to take the fall for a price. He recovers nicely with ‰ÛÏåÊ‰ÛªTil Death Do Us Part‰Ûù a brutally, gloriously streamlined story of love and jealousy that blows up a wedding, filling the screen with tumult and kisses.
‰ÛÏWild Tales‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Anarchy unbound.

As high-spirited as its title suggests, ‰ÛÏWild Tales‰Ûù opens on a savage note and ends, well, that‰Ûªs for you to find out. In between its shocker start and equally startling windup, this Argentine anthology offers up a scabrous, often unsettlingly funny look at human behavior in extremis. It‰Ûªs a mad, mad social Darwinian world, churning with men and women who, whether pushed a lot or just a little, are all eager to do the worst to one another. They pounce and then they pummel, engaging in drag-down fights that leave them black and blue and sometimes stone-cold dead.

The writer and directoråÊDamiÌÁn Szifron hasn‰Ûªt made it especially easy to write about ‰ÛÏWild Tales.‰Ûù All of its six distinct stories turn on someone‰Ûªs overheated, sometimes murderous reaction to a grievance, real or perceived, major or absurdly minor. In the second story, ‰ÛÏThe Rats,‰Ûù a greasy-spoon waitress, Moza (Julieta Zylberberg), realizes that her only customer, Cuenca (CÌ©sar BordÌ_n), once did her family a profound injustice. Mr. Szifron sets the scene skillfully, starting with a dark and stormy night that inaugurates an equally foreboding initial exchange between waitress and customer. ‰ÛÏParty of one?,‰Ûù Moza asks with a smile. ‰ÛÏI see you‰Ûªre good at math,‰Ûù Cuenca says, by way of hello. You don‰Ûªt need to have worked in the service industry to feel the fury creeping into your heart.

Mr. Szifron‰Ûªs use of humor and steel-trap coincidence at times evokes O. Henry, if in a minor key. There‰Ûªs nothing so stirring here as, say, in the O. Henry story ‰ÛÏThe Furnished Room‰Ûù (1904), about a poor young man who rents a furnished room in which ‰ÛÓ after catching a whiff of his old lover‰Ûªs perfume ‰ÛÓ he commits suicide, never knowing that she had done the exact same a week earlier in the very same room. Here, for O. Henry, coincidence is a means to an ending that‰Ûªs haunted by the lives of its desperate, impoverished characters. Mr. Szifron creates inhabited worlds with comic timing and visual flair, but you can hear him chortling as he shovels his people into the grinder.

Mr. Corra eventually became involved in Ms. Nicholson‰Ûªs medical care. There are passages ‰ÛÓ especially the finale ‰ÛÓ that suggest he lacked perspective in editing. The movie continues through several possible closing moments.

But ‰ÛÏFarewell to Hollywood‰Ûù grows more troubling as it progresses. Ms. Nicholson‰Ûªs parents fight with each other instead of comforting the coughing teenager in the room. When Ms. Nicholson moves from Long Beach, Calif., to South Pasadena (less than 30 miles away) to live on her own, she reveals that her parents have threatened to cut off insurance and demanded that she choose between her family and the film. We are told that her father suspected that she and Mr. Corra were having an affair.

Rendering a verdict on the cinematic merits of ‰ÛÏFarewell to Hollywood‰Ûù seems beside the point or even inappropriate; the movie‰Ûªs key attribute is that it exists. The co-director, Regina Nicholson, died of cancer at 19 in 2012. She is shown expressing a wish that the documentary about this period in her life ‰ÛÏsurvive and be fantastic.‰Ûù

According to a title card, Ms. Nicholson‰Ûªs co-director, Henry Corra, met her at a film festival. Together they created this impressionistic portrait from her two final years. Ms. Nicholson handles her illness with more serenity than the adults around her. She is a cinephile ‰ÛÓ something illustrated with clips from ‰ÛÏThe Silence of the Lambs,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏPulp Fiction‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and shows a burgeoning filmmaker‰Ûªs instinct.

‰ÛÏFarewell to Hollywood‰Ûù is moving yet queasily unsettling, even if Ms. Nicholson‰Ûªs enthusiasm mitigates the veneer of exploitation. Watching it feels like judging a last will and testament. The movie is an intimate dialogue from which viewers may prefer to recuse themselves.

A bickering young couple suspect the worst when an elderly neighbor named Sylvia dies in Lawrence Michael Levine‰Ûªs Brooklyn comedy, ‰ÛÏWild Canaries.‰Ûù Setting this pair of squirrelly, suspicious minds loose on matters of love and death, Mr. Levine spins a caper that wins you over more through tenacity than through originality.
