‰ÛÏMerchants of Doubt‰Ûù links cigarettes and climate ‰ÛÓ with a fascinating and troubling detour into an investigation by The Chicago Tribune of the flame-retardant industry ‰ÛÓ by noting that both the playbook and many of the players are the same. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm not a scientist,‰Ûù a recently adopted catchphrase among Republican politicians, echoes earlier evocations of complication and confusion. In both cases the science could hardly be clearer, but pseudo-experts can be brought before the cameras to peddle the idea that no real consensus exists. False information need not be coherent to be effective, and the specters of vanished liberty and tyrannical government regulation are easy enough to conjure.

And those who promote it ‰ÛÓ in the news media, in political discourse, in serious-looking reports published by dubious think tanks ‰ÛÓ are anything but fools. ‰ÛÏMerchants of Doubt,‰Ûù based on Naomi Oreskes and Erik M. Conway‰Ûªs book of the same title, examines the history of corporate-financed public relations efforts to sow confusion and skepticism about scientific research. The filmmakers interview scientists, activists and whistle-blowers who have tried to expose such activities, as well as some of its perpetrators, repentant and otherwise.

That fuse has another function: it‰Ûªs for some exterior lights that Helen will soon wish were working. Ms. Clarkson always raises her characters‰Ûª I.Q., but that Helen doesn‰Ûªt realize she should swap out the fuse for another is as maddening as her relatively cool reaction to the blood smeared on her open door. Leaving that door ajar registers as a human error; walking past it when it‰Ûªs newly decorated with blood comes across as a storytelling contrivance, a way to trap Helen in the house even if it also makes her look reckless or dumb. That she quickly eases into a cozy rapport with the stranger also makes her conveniently trusting (and available).

The title refers to the nearing storm that‰Ûªs at once a narrative device and enveloping metaphor. Here, clouds don‰Ûªt just threaten, they also suggest the difficulties Helen has weathered since the death of her husband, James (Callum Keith Rennie). She‰Ûªs come to open the house, prettily situated alone on an island several hours north of Toronto, mostly so the writer and director, Ruba Nadda, can point up Helen‰Ûªs past dependence on James and her current autonomy. Ms. Clarkson tries to imbue feeling into the house opening, but is hampered by Ms. Nadda underplaying some moments (Helen packing James‰Ûªs clothes) and overstating others (her fussing about a fuse).

A woman alone in the movies is rarely alone for long. In ‰ÛÏOctober Gale,‰Ûù a low-key character study gives way to increasingly clamorous melodrama when a widowed doctor, Helen (Patricia Clarkson), finds a bleeding man making a mess on the floor of her lakeside vacation home. Having gone out to inspect a noise (and left her front door open), she‰Ûªs returned to find William (Scott Speedman), a handsome stranger ‰ÛÓ good looks being a prerequisite for gigs like this ‰ÛÓ with a bullet in his shoulder. While some women might run for a kitchen knife, this good doctor starts dressing his wound.

Ms. Nadda spends considerable time laying out what Helen lost, mostly through copious fragmented flashbacks. They‰Ûªre pretty, as are the landscapes that may have you thinking about Canada for your next vacation, yet Helen remains more of a generic type than a credible woman, despite her periodic tugs on your sympathies. Ms. Clarkson and Mr. Speedman do what they can with their underwritten and overly contrived roles, including when the story lurches into romance. (A single woman in the movies is rarely single for long.) Late in the game, Tim Roth boats in as Tom, a local with a grudge, and shocks the movie to life by throwing some lightning bolts of his own.

The best that can be said for the Italian television host Pierfrancesco Diliberto ‰ÛÓ as far as his comic, feature-film debut is concerned ‰ÛÓ is that he‰Ûªs not nearly as annoying as Roberto Benigni. Granted, that‰Ûªs a very low bar to clear.

But as the director, star, narrator and one writer of ‰ÛÏThe Mafia Kills Only in Summer,‰Ûù Mr. Diliberto (known as Pif) must bear most of the responsibility for the movie‰Ûªs clashing tones and penciled-in characters. Filming in his native Palermo, Sicily (and without paying a Mafia protection fee), he plays Arturo, a virginal klutz whose lifelong brushes with mob misbehavior parallel his ceaseless yearning for the beautiful Flora (Cristiana Capotondi). Conceived during a 1970s massacre in his parents‰Ûª building, young Arturo (Alex Bisconti) finds that almost every adult he admires ‰ÛÓ or shares a pastry with ‰ÛÓ winds up whacked. Politicians, judges and crime bosses litter the streets while the citizens of Palermo refuse to acknowledge the wiseguy killers in their midst.

The flesh of the story is fiction, but its bones are real. Cleverly folded-in archival footage (some of it fabricated) underscores a time when the wholesale murder of prominent figures forced the Cosa Nostra into the light. (A sequence at the end honoring well-known anti-Mafia crusaders probably left many Italians soggily nostalgic.) But the swings from goofy to gory and jokey to tragic cancel one another out, and Mr. Diliberto‰Ûªs near-constant voice-over is irksome. As is the pivotal romance: Arturo is a dolt and Flora a cipher. They may be the only two people in town who aren‰Ûªt connected.

Now gray-haired, Mr. DeFriest is still a likable son of a gun in interviews, snapping out of his funk with wisecracks. But Mr. London‰Ûªs story about the team mounting his defense ‰ÛÓ including a wife he married while in prison and a psychologist who changed his mind about his case ‰ÛÓ tilts the documentary toward advocacy. (Mr. DeFriest‰Ûªs parole date, in 2085, was eventually moved to this month, although he still has more time to serve.)

The film uses comic-book-like animated re-enactments, spiked with hard rock, to convey experiences that Mr. DeFriest has described in letters, but the results feel a bit misbegotten. Although the film may play down Mr. DeFriest‰Ûªs his offenses during incarceration and questions of morality, there‰Ûªs a spark to the man that reliably raises a smile.

Mr. DeFriest appears to be a mechanical genius, capable of making radios and guns from loose parts, but he has also been too smart for his own good. Arrested at the age of 19 in 1980 after a dispute over his beloved dead father‰Ûªs tools, he remained in prison for decades because of an ill-advised plea deal and repeated disciplinary infractions. Mr. London suggests that Mr. DeFriest‰Ûªs escape attempts were both a reaction to abuse in prison and a natural expression of a mind that just can‰Ûªt stop tinkering.

The indomitable personality and talents of the serial prison escapee Mark DeFriest outshine the weaknesses of this documentary that bears his name. Gabriel London‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Mind of Mark DeFriest‰Ûù recounts how this Florida man landed in prison and kept breaking out through illegal (and often outlandish) means.

But be warned: If you haven‰Ûªt seen the first ‰ÛÏMarigold,‰Ûù adapted from a novel by Deborah Moggach, you may find it difficult to figure out who‰Ûªs who and what‰Ûªs what in the seriously overpopulated ‰ÛÏThe Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.‰Ûù

Meanwhile, the fledgling friendship of Evelyn (Ms. Dench) and the shy, bumbling Douglas (Bill Nighy) moves a step closer to true romance. For in the second ‰ÛÏMarigold,‰Ûù atmosphere is so overheated with senior desire that you begin to wonder what might be in the water. A stay at the Marigold Hotel looks as rejuvenating as a dive into the magically restorative swimming pool in ‰ÛÏCocoon.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). For language and suggestive comments.

In aggressively sunny picker-uppers like the Marigold movies, there is a thin line between adorable and insufferable. And in the second ‰ÛÏMarigold,‰Ûù Mr. Patel has succumbed to his tendency toward cuteness. His performance is an increasingly tiresome display of sentimental slapstick and attempted scene stealing in which he evokes uncomfortable memories of Roberto Benigni running wild in ‰ÛÏLife Is Beautiful.‰Ûù

Because there‰Ûªs no explanatory prelude in the sequel, you wouldn‰Ûªt know, for instance, that most of the characters are financially stressed Britons, recruited to spend their sunset years in Jaipur, India, at a residential hotel that is much less splendid than advertised. After much grumbling and backbiting, they become a semi-happy extended family embarked on improbable romantic adventures.

Beyond its blindingly colorful palette, the pleasures to be gleaned from the sequel to the 2012 hit ‰ÛÏThe Best Exotic Marigold Hotel‰Ûù derive from watching its eminent, mostly British cast ham it up while trying to inflate dramatic molehills into mountains. To get away with pretending that less is more, strenuous overacting is required.

It all culminates in a grand, pseudo-Bollywood-style wedding sequence. The song-and-dance extravaganza celebrating Sonny‰Ûªs marriage is the first of several endings that unnecessarily pad the movie. For the last half-hour, I felt like a party pooper as I waited impatiently for it to end.

The second ‰ÛÏMarigold‰Ûù begins in San Diego, where the hotel‰Ûªs hyperkinetic co-owner and manager, Sonny Kapoor (Dev Patel), has gone to seek the backing of an international chain in the hopes of opening a second hostelry near the original Marigold; he gets cautious nibbles of interest. Shortly after his return to India, a suave American, Guy Chambers (Mr. Gere), claiming to be a novelist, shows up. Sonny assumes he must be a hotel inspector masquerading as a guest and smothers him with obsequious attention. Complicating matters, and adding another unnecessary romantic subplot, Guy makes a beeline for Sonny‰Ûªs proper, widowed mother (Lillete Dubey).

By hyping the pageantry and adding more stars, the director, John Madden, and the screenwriter, Ol Parker, who created the first film, try to compensate for the new movie‰Ûªs lack of coherence and narrative momentum. But with no real story to tell, only so much can be done. The newcomers include Richard Gere at his most courtly, David Strathairn and Tamsin Greig (of the Showtime series ‰ÛÏEpisodes‰Ûù).

But for die-hard Anglophiles whose hearts go pitter-pat over actresses awarded the title Dame, it won‰Ûªt really matter what the film‰Ûªs most famous returnees say or do, as long as they chew the scenery. Leading the list are Maggie Smith and Judi Dench, peddling their irresistible brands of British hauteur.
‰ÛÏThe only hope we have for change is spectacle, and yet somehow spectacle kills hope,‰Ûù he says, a line that suggests that Mr. Nikolic might feel similarly about film itself.

These drifting, unresolved stories may lack dramatic punch, but Mr. Nikolic, who teaches film at the New School, draws lovely performances from his cosmopolitan cast and oodles of atmosphere from a spare piano-and-strings soundtrack. In the movie‰Ûªs most direct scene, an animated professor (played by the filmmaker Caveh Zahedi) comments on the cultural impact of the Occupy demonstrations.

The complicated lives of four immigrant women casually intersect in ‰ÛÏAllure,‰Ûù a title that accurately reflects the seductive quality of its black-and-white images. The Serbian-born director, Vladan Nikolic, seems to have a knack for choosing dexterous cinematographers. (He has twice used his wildly gifted countryman Vladimir Subotic.) Here he passes the reins to Aleksandar Kostic, who turns New York City into a dreamy melting pot of conflict and yearning.

Playing out in 2011 against the backdrop of the Occupy movement, this largely improvised drama mixes professional and nonprofessional actors in a loosely constructed portrait of immigrant uncertainty. A willowy Estonian escort (Diana Lotus) fights her American husband for custody of their daughter; a waitress from Mexico City (Julia Konrad Viezzer) works two jobs to support her sick mother; a middle-aged French journalist (Madeleine Assas) deals with an unreasonable new boss and a bored husband; and a Chinese student (Ying Ying Li) daily resists the nagging of her mother to return home. Like the protesters in the streets, they‰Ûªre fighting for futures they might never attain.

A crystal-clear close-up of a horse‰Ûªs eye opens each of the film‰Ûªs beaded vignettes, which take place in an old-fashioned but comfortable community. A gallant horseman, Kolbeinn (Ingvar E. Sigurdsson), suffers the gross public indignity of being astride a mare when a randy stallion approaches; a tippler swims out to a Russian ship to get drunk on 96-proof alcohol; a grinning Spanish-speaking tourist gets lost and faces death by freezing.

The spirited turnover of the stories can‰Ûªt conceal that the animals bear the brunt of their masters‰Ûª troubles (to the point of being killed out of pure vanity). But Mr. Erlingsson‰Ûªs upbeat outlook suggests that generations of horses and men have coexisted and will continue to do so for centuries more.

Mr. Erlingsson, an actor directing a brisk debut feature, doesn‰Ûªt use these and other characters for deadpan jokes or lessons (except maybe that the horsewomen are the real go-getters of the bunch). He pushes ahead with efficient visuals, snappy transitions and a driving score split between cantering rhythms and choral hymns. All the same, it‰Ûªs not quite apparent what these characters do besides go on roundups, get into quandaries and spy on one another.

Set among hearty horse owners in ever-photogenic Iceland, Benedikt Erlingsson‰Ûªs dryly witty ‰ÛÏOf Horses and Men‰Ûù is like an animal documentary, but about people. Life revolves around mares and stallions in the film‰Ûªs windswept terrain, but the animals‰Ûª orblike eyes direct us to the many follies of their owners, who are driven by petty desires and, occasionally, courage.

Because the movie doesn‰Ûªt give us enough time to get to know this newly besotted couple, vicarious identification is difficult. Sylvie, although married to a man whose work is taking him to the United States, shows up for the rendezvous. But on the way, the anxiety-prone Marc suffers a mild heart attack and arrives late, by which time Sylvie has returned home and decided to accompany her husband to Minneapolis.

Ms. Gainsbourg, a lean, fearless adventurer who has survived several films by the Danish provocateur Lars von Trier, plays Sylvie, and Ms. Mastroianni, whose screen characters tend to be insecure, supersensitive women, is Sophie. These devoted siblings of opposite temperament, unknowingly fall in love with the same man, and the heart of the drama is a guessing game of how and when the truth will come out. Ms. Deneuve, as imperturbable as the Statue of Liberty, sails through the movie with her customary composure in the role of their mother.

This deliberately old-fashioned movie from a director who has acknowledged such Hollywood chestnuts as ‰ÛÏBack Street,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏLove Affair‰Ûù and Douglas Sirk films as influences, plays standard Hollywood tricks to prevent Sophie from discovering Marc‰Ûªs secret past or Marc from learning that his ex is Sophie‰Ûªs sister. And as Marc avoids telling Sophie the truth, his cowardice diminishes his character.

The screenplay, written by the director with Julien Boivent, has to pull a lot of strings to keep the sisters in the dark about their shared inamorato, Marc (BenoÌ¨t Poelvoorde), a fussy Parisian tax inspector. Marc is not the dashing prince you might expect these glamorous siblings to fall in love with. Although reasonably presentable, he ranks far below Cary Grant, leading man of ‰ÛÏAn Affair to Remember,‰Ûù in suavity and charm, and he lacks the boyish radiance of Florian Stetter, who plays the poet and philosopher Schiller in ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters.‰Ûù Marc‰Ûªs relative absence of magnetism leaves a hole in the movie‰Ûªs center.

The story begins when Marc, during a visit to Valence, the provincial town where the sisters live, misses his train back to Paris and by chance meets Sylvie in a bar. Their attraction is instantaneous, and they spend much of the rest of the evening wandering the streets and eventually agreeing to meet at a designated time at the Tuileries Gardens in Paris.
Even when Sylvie returns for Sophie‰Ûªs wedding, the secret isn‰Ûªt revealed until the very last minute.

This being the age of the cellphone, you inevitably wonder why neither Sylvie nor Marc carried one. The obvious answer is that if they had had them, there wouldn‰Ûªt be a movie. And because their missed connection doesn‰Ûªt seem fateful so much as sloppy, your heart doesn‰Ûªt sink.
‰ÛÏ3 Hearts‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). For sexual content, brief nudity and smoking throughout.

The French filmmaker BenoÌ¨t Jacquot‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏ3 Hearts‰Ûù has the incalculable advantage of teaming three of Europe‰Ûªs most revered actresses, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve, in a proudly old-fashioned romantic melodrama. Those names alone make it sound delectable, and in its outlines, this quintessential Gallic bodice-ripper might be described as a hybrid of ‰ÛÏAn Affair to Remember‰Ûù and the German filmmaker Dominik Graf‰Ûªs recent ‰ÛÏBeloved Sisters.‰Ûù

Marc, returning later to Valence, soon meets Sophie, an antiques dealer who needs help with an audit. Unaware that he has met Sylvie‰Ûªs sister, he pursues Sophie and they marry. The film makes it very clear that the quality of his passion for Sophie has little of the erotic intensity of his connection to Sylvie. In the meantime, the sisters communicate via Skype.

But its internal clock is askew and the premise of the movie, which is set in the present, feels musty. The screenplay relies on so many mechanical contrivances to make the story gripping that you can hear the rusty machinery clanking.

These stories are already familiar to fans, and, more to the point, they‰Ûªre presented here in a way that makes boxing sound like a solution to urban poverty and the lure of drugs and gangs. That the sport helped a handful of men does nothing for countless thousands; it‰Ûªs no more a viable escape route than rap or basketball is.

The film does, to its credit, eventually mention that even those few who can box their way off the street rarely make a decent living. And the occasional boxing phenomenon who earns millions doesn‰Ûªt know how to handle it or loses much of it to bad advisers. ‰ÛÏThey did take advantage of what I didn‰Ûªt know,‰Ûù Holyfield says.

The film‰Ûªs intent is thus unclear. It also needs a trip through a clichÌ©-removing machine. But now and then this documentary by Bert Marcus rises above mere promotion, leaving you wishing it had tackled the sport‰Ûªs difficult questions in more depth.

‰ÛÏChamps‰Ûù spends about a third of its time perpetuating the myth of boxing as a path out of poverty, a third of it taking a cursory look at what‰Ûªs wrong with the sport and a third being a greatest-hits compilation.
Footage of these men, especially Tyson and Holyfield, in their prime is thrilling, but what ‰ÛÏChamps‰Ûù envisions for the future is unclear.

The film assesses boxing through the stories of three champions, Mike Tyson (who is also an executive producer), Evander Holyfield and Bernard Hopkins. It begins by describing how each man used the sport to escape difficult circumstances. For Hopkins, boxing was a skill he honed in prison.

In traditional iteration after iteration, the story of Cinderella is also that of mothers ‰ÛÓ dead, cruel and magical ‰ÛÓ who loom over this quintessential dutiful daughter far more than any man. One mother abandons Cinderella, leading the way for a second mother to torment her, who in turn opens the door for a third mother to come to the rescue with a wave of her wand. The prince may eventually find and marry Cinderella, but it‰Ûªs a mother who truly saves her. It‰Ûªs a strange matriarchal world, after all, if one still rived with complexities. Here, the screenwriter Chris Weitz adds some dimensionality to the standard conception of the Stepmother (as she‰Ûªs only known), mostly by referencing the dire prospects for a widow with two children and no income of her own.

Poor Cinderella ‰ÛÓ she still can‰Ûªt catch a break. In the 1950 Disney animated musical, her friendly neighborhood mice know the score and give it song: ‰ÛÏNight and day, it‰Ûªs Cinderelly! ‰Û÷Make the fire, fix-a breakfast, wash the dishes, do the mopping, and the sweeping and the dusting.‰Ûª They always keep her hopping!‰Ûù In Disney‰Ûªs latest version, directed by Kenneth Branagh, the mice stick to squeaking and look about as real as most computer-generated rodents. And, fascinatingly, much remains the same, including a fairy tale that opens with clear skies but soon plays the poor-little-girl blues before you-know-who comes along. ‰ÛÏMaleficent‰Ûù and its revisionism are so last year.

And here she is again, pretty as a picture, with flowing blond hair, a flashing smile, a fabulous gown ‰ÛÓ a bewitchingly blue number from the costume wizard Sandy Powell ‰ÛÓ and that go-good-girl triumphalism. First, though, here‰Ûªs the once upon a time: ‰ÛÏCinderella‰Ûù opens in an indeterminate past with long frocks, horse-drawn carriages and no cellphones, in one of those lavish soundstage countries. (The movie was partly shot in the Pinewood Studios in Britain.) There, 10-year-old Ella (Eloise Webb) safely nests in a pocket paradise alongside her homemaker mother (Hayley Atwell) and merchant father (Ben Chaplin), a small menagerie and a clutch of smiling servants. This being a fairy tale, heaven soon gives way to woe so the story can get down to business.

You know the rest, bibbidi-bobbidi-boo and all that jazz. Helena Bonham Carter toddles in as the Fairy Godmother and Richard Madden (‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù) gallops in as the Prince. Mildly charming and orthodontically dazzling, the Prince first sees Ella taking a very unmaidenly bareback horse ride, a scene that conveys that she remains free despite the home-front misery. Try as the filmmakers might to obscure her victimization, there‰Ûªs no getting around that this Cinderella has to do time as the classic persecuted woman even if the Disney imperative means that she must also dust herself off, go to the ball and waltz into a happy ending. As tabloids, reality television, countless novels and sometimes the movies suggest, you cannot keep a good woman down, even if it‰Ûªs fun trying.

Ms. Blanchett, eyes widening and narrowing, and teeth all but gnashing, plays the role at full Cruella de Vil tilt. It‰Ûªs a divertingly oversize, near-vaudevillian performance ornamented with frozen looks, boogieing brows and rubber-band-like mouth contortions. Mr. Branagh‰Ûªs ascension into big-budget studio directing largely remains a mystery, and there‰Ûªs little in ‰ÛÏCinderella‰Ûù beyond its faces and gowns that captures the eye or the imagination. His one interesting directorial choice is to fold in different performance styles, which tend to fall into exaggerated, almost-burlesque mode or a more familiar naturalistic expressiveness. This suggests that, at least in the case of the Stepmother (if not her nitwit daughters), cruelty sometimes may be more a mask than a question of being.

Why Cinderella, why now? If you‰Ûªre the Walt Disney Company the answer can only be: Why not? She may not be a princess (yet!) and the story may have been told innumerable times, but there‰Ûªs gold in those glass slippers no matter how many miles they have on them. The cinema pioneer Georges MÌ©liÌ¬s told her story in 1899, perhaps for the first time on screen, and she recently popped up in Disney‰Ûªs live-action adaptation of Stephen Sondheim‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏInto the Woods.‰Ûù Disney has further helped stoke the demand for this new movie with two direct-to-video sequels to its 1950 film, ‰ÛÏCinderella II: Dreams Do Come True‰Ûù (2002) and ‰ÛÏCinderella III: A Twist in Time‰Ûù (2007).

Less genuinely wicked than seriously mercenary, this Stepmother can‰Ûªt help but steal the show. Ms. Blanchett takes some of the credit (or blame), as does the visual design for the character which, from her soignÌ©e updos to a leopard-skin dressing gown, suggests a 1940s femme fatale. There certainly is a touch of Joan Crawford‰Ûªs Mildred Pierce to the Stepmother and her sob-worthy back story (as well as her blood-red lipstick and power shoulders). And when Ms. Blanchett‰Ûªs pale face emerges from behind a hat, the entrance evokes the likes of Jane Greer ‰ÛÏcoming out of the sun‰Ûù in the noir ‰ÛÏOut of the Past‰Ûù so she can destroy Robert Mitchum. Even so, the Stepmother isn‰Ûªt really evil ‰ÛÓ she just proves, from her smoky eyes to her enviable green frocks, that bad always sizzles more than good.

Bruno Bettelheim claimed that ‰ÛÏCinderella‰Ûù was the most popular fairy tale, so pardon my spoiler: Ella‰Ûªs mother dies after some discreet coughing, time passes and Lily James takes over the role of the older Ella. A regular on the television series ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey,‰Ûù Ms. James effortlessly holds the big screen, less because of her beauty than the life that both animates and demystifies that beauty, making it seem less other (even a touch aspirational) and her character feel approachable and likable. It‰Ûªs smart casting because that likability and the smiles it solicits help take the edge off Cinderella‰Ûªs victimization and because the minute Ella‰Ûªs father brings home a new wife, Ms. James becomes a wee planet in the orbit of a very bright star known as Cate Blanchett ‰ÛÓ the Stepmother, of course.
‰ÛÏCinderella‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A mother dies and animals and vegetables are bewitched.

‰ÛÏCymbeline‰Ûù has been branded a tragedy, a tragicomedy and a romance, and Mr. Almereyda embraces all three categories. The movie is by turns grim, grimly amusing and romantic, sometimes at once. As character pose and declaim ‰ÛÓ Mr. Almereyda uses a lot of frontal staging, giving some scenes a near-hieroglyphic quality ‰ÛÓ violence erupts and kisses fly as does a head and questions of nation. (Scholars have read the play allegorically through James I, who saw himself as ‰ÛÏking of Great Britain.‰Ûù) Mr. Almereyda nods to all this, as in Cymbeline‰Ûªs exchanges with a Roman cop, Caius Lucius (Vondie Curtis-Hall), who, at one point, is showered with Hershey‰Ûªs Kisses instead of tribute gold. Cymbeline, caught between lands and loyalties, seems impotent to act.

Cymbeline‰Ûªs relationship with Rome holds up a mirror to that of Imogen and Posthumus. Having been cast out by Cymbeline, Posthumus ends up hanging out with Iachimo (Mr. Hawke), a sly fox who wagers that he can compromise Imogen‰Ûªs honor. The bet doesn‰Ûªt make much narrative sense, at least in this telling, but instead registers as one in a series of predetermined, somewhat (or entirely!) inexplicable turns on an exceedingly crooked path. What matters more are the consequences, including the casual cruelty with which Posthumus gambles with his and Imogen‰Ûªs love. The wager reaps various dividends, plotwise and otherwise, including the playfully silly sight of Iachimo sneaking into Imogen‰Ûªs bedroom while she sleeps and taking cellphone selfies with her body.

Confusion is right, although Mr. Almereyda adeptly unkinks the complications. Set in the untrammeled, boutique-free wilds of New York (standing in for ancient Britain), the story runs on two parallel tracks. One involves Cymbeline (Ed Harris), the overlord, or rather drug kingpin, of the Britons, a motorcycle gang. He‰Ûªs tough, but he‰Ûªs also burdened by a feckless, fashion-forward queen (Milla Jovovich) who has encouraged him to withhold tribute to Rome. She has her reasons, namely her son from a previous union, Cloten (Anton Yelchin), whom she wants to wed to the king‰Ûªs daughter, Imogen (Dakota Johnson, lovely). Imogen, meanwhile, has married Posthumus (Penn Badgley), a former favorite of the king who has little going for him beyond his looks and a skateboard he hasn‰Ûªt mastered.
‰ÛÏCymbeline‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Firing guns and one rolling head.

Whatever Mr. Almereyda‰Ûªs inspiration, his version of ‰ÛÏCymbeline‰Ûù (which for a while was actually titled ‰ÛÏAnarchy‰Ûù) reaffirms that Shakespeare can always survive every interpretive trick, with or without choppers and chrome. As soon becomes evident in this appealing eccentric divertissement, the loudest, flashiest of contemporary appurtenances, from blazing machine guns to gleaming leather jackets, are inevitably outshone by Shakespeare‰Ûªs words, even in a lesser-known, lesser-loved late play like this. And ‰ÛÏCymbeline‰Ûù has not always felt the love, as witnessed by Samuel Johnson‰Ûªs spittled outrage at ‰ÛÏthe folly of the fiction, the absurdity of the conduct, the confusion of the names and manners of different times, and the impossibility of the events in any system of life.‰Ûù

Despite the raised and fired guns, the machismo and the mayhem, Mr. Almereyda is transparently more interested in Imogen than all the scheming, warring men who surround her. Soon after Iachimo‰Ûªs bedroom raid, Imogen‰Ûªs fate takes a dramatic turn. Aided by Posthumus‰Ûªs servant, Pisanio (John Leguizamo), she chops her hair, ditches her shorts and goes on the run, becoming one of Shakespeare‰Ûªs undercover women by transforming into a man. In her journey she finds lost brothers, waylaid honor and herself. The fate of a people hangs in the balance in Cymbeline‰Ûªs contentious dealings with Rome. But, as Mr. Almereyda underscores with a rapturously beautiful close-up of Imogen‰Ûªs face ‰ÛÓ itself a battlefield of a type ‰ÛÓ there are other lives and truths at stake as well.

Was the director Michael Almereyda watching an episode of ‰ÛÏSons of Anarchy‰Ûù when he decided to tackle ‰ÛÏCymbeline‰Ûù? For an overextended seven seasons (2008-14), that FX show retold ‰ÛÏHamlet‰Ûù through the trials and tribulations of a violent motorcycle gang and its circle. Back in 2000, Mr. Almereyda, an independent American filmmaker, wittily conceptualized his own ‰ÛÏHamlet‰Ûù to suit the indie-movie times, casting Ethan Hawke as a film student who wonders whether to be or not while strolling in a Blockbuster video store near a sign labeled ‰ÛÏaction.‰Ûù

Alex, a prodigy in the robot design field, has returned to his hometown after a 10-year absence to try to program emotional life into an advanced robot intended to be as much like a human child as possible. This reunites him with his brother (Alberto Ammann) and his sister-in-law (Marta Etura), and we slowly come to realize that Alex‰Ûªs long absence has something to do with a youthful triangle.

This plotline becomes entwined with one involving Alex‰Ûªs search for a human child on which to base his robotic child. Eva, the girl he picks, is deliciously played by Claudia Vega, a real find by the director, Kike MaÌ_llo. The story has several well-disguised twists, and although it‰Ûªs a drama, it is sprinkled with touches of whimsy, thanks to a colorful collection of robots. If the ending feels a little dismaying somehow, that‰Ûªs only because the film has done a good job of making you care about its characters, human and otherwise.

Robots haven‰Ûªt become an integral part of the everyday world as quickly as some people had predicted, but in the not-too-distant future of ‰ÛÏEva,‰Ûù an appealing film from Spain, they‰Ûªre very much a factor. We learn this early on, when the central character, Alex (Daniel BrÌ_hl), steps off a plane trailed by his robotic cat.
The real drama comes not from Dusty‰Ûªs con but from Mona‰Ûªs reaction to the situation. In this, ‰ÛÏHome Sweet Hell‰Ûù deserves a shred of credit for its escalating nastiness.

But as a marital satire, this cartoonish movie is a blunt instrument, lacking the elegance and ambiguity of perspective seen just recently in ‰ÛÏGone Girl.‰Ûù While the oafish men come off poorly, the treatment of women as nothing more than schemers and monstrous Martha Stewart clones seems woefully past its expiration date.

Mona (Katherine Heigl), the chief villain of the shrill comedy ‰ÛÏHome Sweet Hell,‰Ûù is the sort of terrifying suburban status seeker who might inspire fond memories of the 1994 John Waters film ‰ÛÏSerial Mom.‰Ûù She insists that her children ‰ÛÏargue constructively‰Ûù and requires nothing less than perfect hedges. She indulges in casual bigotry and refuses to mingle with the employees of the furniture company she runs with her husband, Don (Patrick Wilson). She lists 15 precise minutes of sex with him on her calendar. She keeps an album of goals for her perfect family.

Those goals are threatened when Don begins an affair with a new saleswoman, Dusty (Jordana Brewster). Their relationship grows so steamy so soon after her hiring that all but the most dense of observers ‰ÛÓ these include Don ‰ÛÓ will suspect that Dusty has ulterior motives. ‰ÛÏHome Sweet Hell‰Ûù clumsily tips its hand anyway, cutting to Dusty‰Ûªs accomplices.
‰ÛÏHome Sweet Hell‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, violence, dismemberment, crystal meth.

‰ÛÏIt Follows‰Ûù opens nearly a year after winning the Next Wave award at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival. Its acclaim derives from its masterly manipulation of mood by its cinematographer, Michael Gioulakis. The deadly menace, which seems to emerge from your peripheral vision, is initially hard to discern, but as it draws closer, never quickening its step, you sense its grim intention.

The explanations for almost everything that happens are intentionally enigmatic and sometimes completely mystifying. In the most elaborate set piece, Jay dives into an indoor swimming pool, which her friends encircle with electrical appliances. But why? For protection?

It takes a while for Jay to convince her friends that the danger isn‰Ûªt just a figment of her imagination. But as the ominous portents accumulate, the group, which includes Kelly (Lili Sepe), Yara (Olivia Luccardi), Paul (Keir Gilchrist), and Greg (Daniel Zovatto), stands by her. Unlike the daredevils and vixens of slick Hollywood horror thrillers, these are everyday teenagers. The shy, pensive Paul, who has had a crush on Jay ever since they shared a kiss many years earlier, is the most memorable.

‰ÛÏIt Follows‰Ûù abides by a principle that few horror movies have the courage to embrace: The unknown is the unknown. Clues to the source and motives of this menace are dropped, but they don‰Ûªt add up. Like the evil in a David Lynch horror film, it is out there in the night, waiting to get you.

The second feature film by Mr. Mitchell, the director of the 2011 cult film ‰ÛÏThe Myth of the American Sleepover,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏIt Follows‰Ûù is set during autumn in a Detroit suburb. The place is so depopulated that the empty streets and darkened houses evoke a ghost town evacuated in an emergency. Except for a few scattered people, Jay and her teenage friends are the only remaining local residents. There are no parents in sight.

Jay‰Ûªs troubles begin after she sleeps with her new boyfriend, Hugh (Jake Weary), who, after their lovemaking in his car, ties her to a chair under a bridge, and explains her predicament. From him, she has caught a supernatural version of a venereal disease. Having sex with someone else is the only cure, if cure is the right word.
‰ÛÏIt Follows‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Disturbing violent and sexual content, including graphic nudity, and language.

The nameless, shape-shifting horror that stalks the blond, 19-year-old Jay (Maika Monroe) in David Robert Mitchell‰Ûªs cool, controlled horror film, ‰ÛÏIt Follows,‰Ûù might be described as the very incarnation of paranoia. The menace, which only she can see, takes any number of forms, from a naked man standing on the roof of a house to an unsmiling old lady heading purposefully in her direction. When it appears, it is usually first glimpsed from a distance, walking slowly toward her like an expressionless zombie. Although Jay repeatedly flees, she can never shake the sense that it is out there somewhere and knows her precise location.

Rather than breaking new ground, ‰ÛÏIt Follows‰Ûù recycles familiar teenage horror tropes ‰ÛÓ a girl alone in a house, evil forces banging on a door ‰ÛÓ but its mood is dreamy. Seldom do you feel manipulated by exploitative formulas. The violence, when it comes, is sudden, and the camera doesn‰Ûªt linger over the gore.
‰ÛÏRun All Night‰Ûù is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bloody urban mayhem. Great performances.

Yes, ‰ÛÏRun All Night‰Ûù is another action film starring Liam Neeson, with a title as generic as you might expect. But the movie, directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, who directed Mr. Neeson in the efficient airborne thriller ‰ÛÏNon-Stop,‰Ûù has two saving graces: a tight script and terrific acting.

But amid the brawls, shootouts and chases, the exquisitely matched Mr. Neeson and Mr. Harris share a layered, nuanced relationship. Also on point are Nick Nolte as Jimmy‰Ûªs brother; Vincent D‰ÛªOnofrio as a sympathetic detective; and Common as a high-tech hit man. Towering over all is Mr. Neeson, who combines a rough-hewed authority with a blazing emotional core. I won‰Ûªt defend ‰ÛÏTaken 2,‰Ûù but let‰Ûªs face facts: Mr. Neeson is the best actor the action genre has had in decades.

Mr. Neeson plays Jimmy Conlon, a longtime enforcer for the underworld boss Shawn Maguire (Ed Harris). Jimmy ‰ÛÓ alcoholic and estranged from his son, Mike (Joel Kinnaman), a father of two who is determined to avoid his father‰Ûªs career path ‰ÛÓ feels pangs of remorse after a life of violence. But when Shawn‰Ûªs hotheaded son, Danny (Boyd Holbrook), tries to kill Mike, Jimmy bumps him off, as well as two crooked cops, and suddenly the New York Police Department and seemingly every hoodlum in the city, including his former friend and employer, are combing Manhattan and its environs on a manhunt.
‰ÛÏLike Sunday, Like Rain‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), needlessly. It has a little cursing.

The film was written and directed by Frank Whaley, who is in no hurry as he lets these two characters get to know each other and ever so gently crack each other‰Ûªs shells. It‰Ûªs a well-played character study whose subtlety is marred by a grating caricature of a role for Debra Messing as Reggie‰Ûªs entitled, brusque, inattentive mother.

Leighton Meester of ‰ÛÏGossip Girl‰Ûù acquits herself quite well in ‰ÛÏLike Sunday, Like Rain,‰Ûù and so does a young newcomer named Julian Shatkin. It‰Ûªs a bittersweet story that thins out toward the end as it turns too obviously sentimental, but it‰Ûªs still a nicely etched tale of the intersection of two unrelated lives.

Ms. Meester plays Eleanor, a 23-year-old New Yorker who has just jettisoned a boyfriend (Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day) and is in need of a job. She ends up as a nanny to a 13-year-old cello prodigy, Reggie (Mr. Shatkin), whose precociousness and family wealth give him a sort of detached melancholy.

Fans of Mr. Armstrong might also be disappointed that he‰Ûªs not around much. But Ms. Meester and Mr. Shatkin mesh beautifully, so much so that you might feel a little cheated at the end. Mr. Whaley goes for a hard tug on the heartstrings, but there was more to be done with these two appealing characters.

The movie shares a title with the J. D. Salinger‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSeymour: An Introduction,‰Ûù a 1959 Glass family story in which Buddy Glass streams out thoughts about his older brother, Seymour, who has killed himself. It‰Ûªs not a universally loved story; in a review, Norman Mailer wrote that Mr. Salinger ‰ÛÏdisappoints because he is always practicing.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs a dig, and off the mark. Practice doesn‰Ûªt always make perfect, but, as Mr. Bernstein shows, practice, struggle and running your fingers up and down the scales year after year is what we must do. As Seymour asks Buddy, what will you be asked when you die? ‰ÛÏåÊ‰Û÷Were most of your stars out? Were you busy writing your heart out?‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù Seymour assures Buddy, ‰ÛÏIf only you knew how easy it would be for you to say yes to both questions.‰Ûù

And, if you gave up playing an instrument (oh, let‰Ûªs say, the violin), you will surely regret that folly. Among the lessons, musical and otherwise, that Mr. Bernstein offers is that surrender isn‰Ûªt an option. ‰ÛÏThe struggle is what makes the art form,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏI had to go to war for my art form.‰Ûù Many of us may not have felt equipped for war when we were trying to coax grace, beauty, something, from our sheet music, but that‰Ûªs scarcely the point. What Mr. Bernstein reveals through both the example of his life and the many recollections and conversations threaded throughout this documentary, is that struggle ‰ÛÓ long, brutal, enervating, interminable ‰ÛÓ must have its due.

If you don‰Ûªt necessarily notice their absence it‰Ûªs because there‰Ûªs so much else here, so much music, poetry, philosophy and communion as well as memorable visits to the piano bank in the basement of the old Steinway Hall. Mr. Hawke incorporates a fair amount of interviews with Mr. Bernstein, but much of the movie takes the form of dialogues, including between the filmmaker and his subject, a dynamic that, over time, begins to resemble some of the other teacher-student encounters in the movie. Some of these students are familiar, others less so. (Among the guests is The New York Times critic Michael Kimmelman.) None dazzle as brightly as Mr. Bernstein whether he‰Ûªs talking, teaching or playing. That the three blur together is evident whether he‰Ûªs alone at the piano, teaching students in his cozily appointed one-room apartment or holding a master class.

That this is as much a movie about life as about art is clear from the first few minutes, as is the sense that the terms are inseparable for him. Life for Mr. Bernstein began in Newark in 1927; music entered not long after. At 6, he begged his mother for a piano, though music was entirely absent from his family‰Ûªs home. He began teaching piano when he was 15, started winning prizes shortly thereafter, studied with the likes of Clifford Curzon and, in 1969, made his debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Bernstein played at the front in the Korean War and in concert halls afterward, winning praise and admirers, only to give up his public career when he was 50.
‰ÛÏSeymour: An Introduction‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Refined adult discussions.

As its title suggests, ‰ÛÏSeymour: An Introduction‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt try to offer the final word on its subject, Seymour Bernstein, the pianist, composer, teacher, philosopher and ultimate New Yorker. Instead, in 81 transporting minutes, this intimate, big-hearted documentary draws you so completely into his world that you feel as if you know all there is to know, even as questions linger. So effectively does it close the distance between you and Mr. Bernstein that afterward you may find yourself scanning the streets, hoping to catch sight of him, as if for an old friend.

Ethan Hawke, who directed and occasionally appears on camera, provides a generous amount of biographical details about his subject while omitting others. Mr. Bernstein doesn‰Ûªt seem terribly interested in oversharing. He sketches in his early years, but doesn‰Ûªt often voluntarily return to the subject of his family. Sometimes, he is pulled back to it, as when Mr. Hawke asks if it bothered Mr. Bernstein that his father said he had two daughters and a pianist. (Yes, it did.) You can learn more facts from Mr. Bernstein‰Ûªs website than from this movie and still more from his suggestively titled 2002 memoir, ‰ÛÏMonsters and Angels: Surviving a Career in Music.‰Ûù There‰Ûªs nothing about his love life in the movie, no questions about partners or whether he longed for children.
‰ÛÏThe Cobbler‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, profanity, nudity, all mild.

The good news is that ‰ÛÏThe Cobbler‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt another ‰ÛÏGrown-Ups‰Ûù sequel. Adam Sandler, as he did with Jason Reitman‰Ûªs little-seen ‰ÛÏMen, Women & Children,‰Ûù works outside his sophomoric-humor comfort zone in this urban fairy tale directed by Tom McCarthy (‰ÛÏThe Station Agent‰Ûù). The bad news is that he is not very well served. ‰ÛÏThe Cobbler,‰Ûù which Mr. McCarthy wrote with Paul Sado, speaks to the fabulist side of Mr. Sandler, the one that appeared in ‰ÛÏClick‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBedtime Stories.‰Ûù But it‰Ûªs an uneasy fit, in a trite story.

And how does Max employ his chameleonic powers? Helping a housing activist (Melonie Diaz) save a tenement resident threatened with eviction by a criminal slumlord (Ellen Barkin). Sentimental and fantastical plot twists follow. The sophomoric humor may be absent, but in its place is only a soufflÌ© of whimsy, seasoned with soot, that fails to rise.

Mr. Sandler plays Max Simkin, a schlumpy shoe repairman living in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, tending to his dying mother. Max, who inherited a shop on the Lower East Side from his long-vanished father, finds an enchanted machine in the basement that lets him assume the appearance of his customers by donning their footwear ‰ÛÓ yes, walk in their shoes. (That allows co-stars like Cliff Smith, a.k.a. Method Man, and Dan Stevens an opportunity to vocally impersonate Mr. Sandler; Mr. Stevens is more successful.)

As in Darren Aronofsky‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Fountain,‰Ûù romance lost is romance regained across years and continents. Time may bring good things to light, but the 2010 copyright suggests that delays have worked no such wonders for this film.

The crosscutting then stops for an hour as the movie bogs down in colonial history. Mr. JoffÌ© ‰ÛÓ three decades from his Oscar-nominated direction on ‰ÛÏThe Killing Fields‰Ûù (1984) and ‰ÛÏThe Mission‰Ûù (1986) ‰ÛÓ has lost his knack for visual poetry but retained a taste for turgid exposition.

The title of ‰ÛÏThe Lovers‰Ûù refers not just to characters but also to two rings that join together. In this inert, exasperatingly proportioned phantasmagoria from Roland JoffÌ©, who wrote the screenplay and directed, the jewels‰Ûª fortunes in 1778 India have a ripple effect on a futuristic diving mission hundreds of years later. Or perhaps it‰Ûªs the other way around.
‰ÛÏThe Lovers‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Swashbuckling.

The movie initially cuts between the time frames, interspersing a prophecy from the 18th century with sequences more suited to ‰ÛÏThe Abyss.‰Ûù On a dive, Jay (Josh Hartnett) discovers one half of the ring. But Jay is gravely injured rescuing his wife, Laura (Tamsin Egerton), after she unaccountably tries to retrieve it during a storm.

Mr. Hartnett appears again as James Stewart, a Scottish soldier reluctantly serving the English crown during a ‰ÛÏMacbeth‰Ûù-like power struggle on the subcontinent. Ambivalent about his mandate, he falls for Tulaja (Bipasha Basu), who is destined to betray the man she loves.
Opens on Friday
Directed by Denny Tedesco

This sentimental documentary is directed by Denny Tedesco, whose father, Tommy, was a lauded guitar player of that era. (He died in 1997.) Mostly, it‰Ûªs hagiography, with stars like Cher and Brian Wilson used as character witnesses to the players‰Ûª greatness. The musicians themselves speak most eloquently when joking about the people whose parts they were playing or, in some places, when speaking through their instruments. (The bassist Carol Kaye shines in these moments.)

For a stretch in the 1960s, those faces beaming from album covers were lying to you: The music inside was often played by others. Those others were usually members of the Wrecking Crew, a loose cabal of versatile Los Angeles session musicians fluent in rock, soul, country and getting out of the way.
THE WRECKING CREW
‰ÛÏThe Wrecking Crew‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Salty musician talk.

‰ÛÏThe Wrecking Crew‰Ûù arrives in the wake of the success of the 2013 documentary ‰ÛÏ20 Feet From Stardom,‰Ûù about underappreciated backup singers. (This film has been in the making for much longer, though, with interviews dating back to the 1990s ‰ÛÓ licensing the music took significant time and money).
1 hour 41 minutes

‰ÛÏ20 Feet‰Ûù was about music, but really about how gender and, especially, race were used to hold artists back, often privileging white men on the backs of black women. ‰ÛÏWrecking Crew‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt have as fertile a struggle at its core, but it does raise the question of why players of this caliber ‰ÛÓ often, they didn‰Ûªt even want their names printed in the credits of the records they worked on, but some have since been voted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame ‰ÛÓ were so content in the shadows. JON CARAMANICA

The narrative is effectively constructed and the cinematography is crisp. Even so, in touching lightly on themes without committing to any of them, the movie falls flat. What should be sweet is saccharine, what might be profound seems trite. Supernatural comedy, psychological mystery, modern-day parable, ‰ÛÏWalter‰Ûù is a little of all of these ‰ÛÓ another way of saying it can‰Ûªt decide what it is or what story it wants to tell.

Written by Paul Shoulberg and directed by Anna Mastro, ‰ÛÏWalter‰Ûù weaves plot threads from other, better films: ‰ÛÏThe Sixth Sense,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏAmerican Beauty,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Graduate,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏOrdinary People.‰Ûù In supporting roles Virginia Madsen plays Walter‰Ûªs equally bent mother, Jim Gaffigan his reality check of a boss and William H. Macy his rumpled psychiatrist.

In ‰ÛÏWalter,‰Ûù the title character is a ticket taker at a multiplex, a good gig for someone who enjoys fantasy. Walter, an obsessive-compulsive in his early 20s, believes himself to be a son of God, required to decide the final destination ‰ÛÓ heaven or hell ‰ÛÓ of every individual he sees. Folks lining up to get into the theater just make his true calling easier.

Flashbacks indicate that the disorders plaguing Walter (Andrew J. West) stem from the death of his father when he was a boy. Still, Walter is at ease with his role ‰ÛÓ until a ghost visits, saying he was never designated and asking Walter‰Ûªs help in determining his fate. This disturbance in Walter‰Ûªs field pushes him out of his comfort zone and into the rest of the movie.

A sharp, light look into the abyss, ‰ÛÏAmour Fou‰Ûù takes as its inspiration a terrible bloodletting: In 1811, Kleist fired a bullet into the heart of a friend, Henriette Vogel, and then shot himself in the mouth. Vogel may have been terminally ill, one of the few details about her that tends to make it into great-man accounts. Kleist seems to have held his own narrow views of her as suggested in a letter to his cousin Marie (who had declined his offer), writing of Vogel: ‰ÛÏShe has grasped on a higher plane that my sadness was incurable and deeply rooted, and therefore, although she has enough means at hand to make me happy here on earth, she will die with me.‰Ûù

Still, as in her earlier movies like ‰ÛÏLourdes,‰Ûù Ms. Hausner draws you in with the oddness of the material, exacting compositions and the kind of narrative ellipses that force your engagement (and risk your irritation). She‰Ûªs working within a recognizable art-film idiom but bending it to her own ends. The physically restrained, at times borderline somnolent, performances in ‰ÛÏAmour Fou‰Ûù will be familiar to habituÌ©s of European art cinema, as if the characters were in the grip of some destabilizing ennui. Here, the restrained physicality thematically serves as proof of the prison that Henriette will soon be liberated from by her suitor. It also works for the subtly escalating comedy that Ms. Hausner, with finesse and fine timing, sneaks into her story with dogs, sidelong looks and deadpan.

The Austrian writer and director Jessica Hausner makes the most of the vanity embedded in that letter, notably by turning her gaze and ours from the man who wrote of ‰ÛÏmy sadness‰Ûù to the woman willing to ‰ÛÏdie with me.‰Ûù Much of the movie centers on Henriette, who, before Heinrich seizes on her, seems perfectly content being a wife and mother. With a maid, DÌ_rte (Alissa Wilms), Henriette keeps house; serves her husband, Friedrich (Stephan Grossmann); and cares for the couple‰Ûªs only child, Pauline (Paraschiva Dragus). It‰Ûªs an orderly, tastefully sterile and, you soon sense, palpably suffocating world with a place for everything and a thing for every place, one that Ms. Hausner appears ‰ÛÓ from bedroom to dining table ‰ÛÓ to have mapped out using a compass and a straightedge.

In this, she receives great help from Mr. Friedel, whose portrayal of Kleist ‰ÛÓ with his already-dead eyes, hunched shoulders and uncomfortably stiff formality ‰ÛÓ can bring to mind a Beatrix Potter illustration of a gentleman toad. It may be an uncharitable creation, more absurd than tragic, but this isn‰Ûªt a biographical study of the doomed poet and his times or anything that literary or high-minded. It is, rather, a teasingly dry gloss on the notion of romantic love and its costs. To that end, it can be a strategically off-putting movie yet one that also steals under your skin scene by scene and through Ms. Schnoeink‰Ûªs slowly revealing performance as an ill-fated heroine turned future biographical footnote. Her Henriette enters ‰ÛÏAmour Fou‰Ûù as much a mystery to herself as us, only to figure it out a little too late.

Heinrich has some renown but yearns for more in life, specifically a woman to die for and with him. He has both the weapons and the romantic bona fides, having been modeled on none other than the poet and playwright Heinrich von Kleist, who once wrote, ‰ÛÏIt was hell that gave me this half-talent of mine: Heaven grants a whole one or none at all.‰Ûù

Romantic longing takes a beating in ‰ÛÏAmour Fou,‰Ûù an eccentric, coolly deadpan story of love, including that of the self. Set in Germany in the early 19th century, it tells of a middle-class woman, Henriette (Birte Schnoeink), who, to her great surprise, catches the eye of an insistently gloomy young poet, Heinrich (Christian Friedel).

There are traces of life here and there in this well-appointed family mausoleum, like the big bouquet that nearly bursts out of one early shot, partly and instructively obscuring Henriette from view. Of course the blooms are already dead and therefore more funerary than life-affirming, which seems very much to be the point, much like the beautiful flowers that ornament Douglas Sirk‰Ûªs Hollywood melodramas. Ms. Hausner‰Ûªs approach to her material is considerably more restrained than that of Mr. Sirk, who deployed his Brechtian distancing devices in lushly emotional, fantastically hyperbolic sob stories that simultaneously pulled you in. Ms. Hausner clearly wants to create some distance between her characters and the audience; she initially seems less interested in full-on seduction.

Ms. Kikuchi has already made your heart ache by the time Kumiko embarks on her trip, especially with scenes in which her character puzzles over what to do with her pet rabbit. Speaking no English, Kumiko struggles once she reaches the Minneapolis airport and ventures into the frigid outdoors.

In any case, Kumiko gets addicted to watching a battered, grainy videotape of ‰ÛÏFargo‰Ûù that she finds buried in a mysterious opening scene, and she becomes convinced that her destiny is to go to North Dakota and dig up the case full of cash that Steve Buscemi‰Ûªs character buries near the film‰Ûªs end.

The tale is drawn from a story that began circulating after a Japanese woman was found dead in Minnesota in 2001. The idea that she was searching for the ‰ÛÏFargo‰Ûù money turned out to be an urban legend ‰ÛÓ suicide fueled by a romantic disappointment is suspected ‰ÛÓ but the Zellners decided to stick with the yarn. They end it with a sort of magical-realism flourish well suited to the closing weeks of what in much of the United States has been an unforgiving winter.

‰ÛÏKumiko,‰Ûù written by another pair of sibling filmmakers, David and Nathan Zellner (with David directing), follows this journey in all its frozen, aching misguidedness. But a strength of the film is that, before Kumiko ever gets on a plane for the United States, we see a significant slice of her life in Tokyo, enough to realize that this is a woman who is slowly losing her grip on reality.

Rinko Kikuchi, nominated for a supporting-actress Oscar for ‰ÛÏBabel,‰Ûù does lovely work as the title character, a Japanese woman who gets the disastrously incorrect idea that the Coen brothers‰Ûª movie ‰ÛÏFargo‰Ûù depicts a true story. It‰Ûªs an easy mistake to make for those not acquainted with the Coens‰Ûª wit; after all, that movie starts out with the words ‰ÛÏThis is a true story.‰Ûù

The real-life story that inspired ‰ÛÏKumiko, the Treasure Hunter‰Ûù was too good to be completely true, but that doesn‰Ûªt diminish the film, a delicate, haunting study of a woman who has in several senses lost her way.
Kumiko, who is 29, works an impersonal job where her boss treats her dismissively, but in her fantasies she is beginning to see herself as a treasure hunter.

‰ÛÏThis is not the right time of year to go sightseeing,‰Ûù a well-meaning woman tells her, one of several strangers who extend courtesies to the obviously confused woman. Most memorable of these is a sheriff‰Ûªs deputy (played by David Zellner) who goes out of his way to try to help her, albeit clumsily. These kindnesses of strangers contrast with the landscape, which is beautiful but vast and inhospitable.
‰ÛÏI am like a Spanish conquistador,‰Ûù she tells the security guard at a library where she tries to learn more about North Dakota.

All too conveniently, we learn that Tom has been silently fighting a grave illness. His vulnerability gives Danny the chance to ‰ÛÏbe there‰Ûù for his stoic, manly son. Meanwhile Samantha is pregnant with their second child.

Isn‰Ûªt 70 supposed to be the new 50? In the age of Viagra and testosterone supplements, grumpy old men shuffling into senescence are a vanishing species. Or so Hollywood would like to imagine. Thrice married and divorced, Danny, who lives with a much younger babe, is the second lion in winter that Mr. Pacino has played this year, after his aging actor in ‰ÛÏThe Humbling.‰Ûù For all the quirks he brings to the role, Danny is less a character than a type. He could have been just as comfortable a fit for Jack Nicholson, Robert De Niro or Michael Douglas.

What was the name of that Beatles song ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏCan‰Ûªt Buy Me Love‰Ûù? That was a hit in 1964, when decent schooling and health care were more affordable and the song‰Ûªs title seemed like a proud declaration of resistance to materialism. Once Danny turns into Santa Claus and smothers Tom‰Ûªs family with his largess, the only protest you hear from Tom is a whimper of gratitude.

Flash forward from 1971 to the present. Danny, his hair dyed and his nose full of cocaine, has turned into a Neil Diamond-like entertainer serenading hordes of swaying middle-aged women who sing along with him on his signature hit, ‰ÛÏHey, Baby Doll,‰Ûù at the Greek Theater in Los Angeles. The song is identical in feel to ‰ÛÏSweet Caroline.‰Ûù And Mr. Pacino does a nifty job of portraying a jaded, drink- and drug-addled pop star exhibiting a palpable self-disgust as he cynically goes through the motions.

The movie throws in a half-baked screwball plot about Danny‰Ûªs flirtation with Mary Sinclair (Annette Bening), the ever-chipper manager of the Hilton hotel in New Jersey where he stays. What authenticity Mr. Cannavale and Ms. Bening bring to their roles is the sense of groundedness and integrity for one-note characters in a movie whose screenplay is little more than an efficiently executed outline.

In ‰ÛÏDanny Collins,‰Ûù Al Pacino injects a zany charge of adrenaline into the title role of a rich, dissolute pop star belatedly seeking redemption for four decades of excess and wasted talent. This bogus character, introduced in a prologue set in 1971 as an intense, hungry young folk singer with a resemblance to the young Bob Dylan, is the latest in a lengthening Hollywood roster of rambunctious old goats.

The directorial debut of the screenwriter Dan Fogelman (‰ÛÏLast Vegas,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Guilt Trip,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏCrazy, Stupid, Love‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏDanny Collins‰Ûù embraces the sentimental notion that Danny is a good guy at heart whose buried songwriting gift is waiting to be excavated. Danny sets about using his money and connections to make amends and buy his son‰Ûªs love. He secures Hope an interview at an elite Manhattan school for children with learning disabilities and showers her with toys.

It prompts Danny to wonder how it might have changed his life had he received it 40 years earlier. In the throes of an existential crisis, Danny suspends his tour and flies to New Jersey in search of his estranged grown-up son, Tom (Bobby Cannavale). A 40-year-old construction worker with a wife, Samantha (Jennifer Garner), and a young daughter, Hope (Giselle Eisenberg), who has A.D.H.D. Tom despises his father. In the first of several father-son skirmishes, Tom bitterly declares he grew up wanting to be ‰ÛÏeverything you‰Ûªre not.‰Ûù

Danny is jolted by a birthday present from his longtime manager, Frank Grubman (a gravely miscast Christopher Plummer), who presents him with a framed personal letter written in 1971 by John Lennon, Danny‰Ûªs original idol. The hand-scrawled missive, which offers sage advice about avoiding the pitfalls of fame and wealth and staying true to his art, was never received and wound up in the hands of a private collector. (Danny is fictional, but the letter and the incident really happened ‰ÛÓ to another singer.)

‰ÛÏDanny Collins‰Ûù gets a nostalgic boost from regular infusions to the soundtrack of John Lennon songs, including ‰ÛÏImagine‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏWorking Class Hero.‰Ûù Its reverence for St. John no doubt adds to the appeal of this shameless piece of boomer bait, which peddles the highly questionable notion that it‰Ûªs never too late to get back to where you once belonged.
‰ÛÏDanny Collins‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For language, drug use and some nudity.

For most of its 91 tense, uneven minutes, ‰ÛÏBackcountry‰Ûù plays on your nerves like a kid flicking you with a rubber band. You feel the sting (thwack, thwack), but it doesn‰Ûªt bother you. Over time, though, the kid grows meaner, and the flicks grow harder, faster, too, and you realize that they‰Ûªre keeping time with the thudding of your heart (thump, thump). The writer and director Adam MacDonald was born in 1977, two years after ‰ÛÏJaws‰Ûù (chomp, chomp) forced everyone out of the water. He‰Ûªs set out to have you now steer clear of the lovely, dark and deep woods, too.

It‰Ûªs diverting, unnerving fun watching their descent, at least for a while. Making the most of the beautiful surroundings, the camera sweeping over the quiet grandeur of the crystalline lake and dense forest, Mr. MacDonald and his nimble-footed director of photography, Christian Bielz, make a convincing visual case for why Alex and Jenn (who has little camping experience) have made the trip. During the couple‰Ûªs short canoe ride to the trailhead, the pristine park looks vast yet inviting, and as deceptively manageable as the boat itself. Once they hit the trail in earnest, though, that initial sense of expansiveness (and manageability) begins to disappear along with the friendly faces of other hikers. The forest begins to progressively close in around them like a hand ‰ÛÓ a giant, furry, clawed one.

Tales of man against nature tend to be more exciting than those about man with nature, and so it is here. ‰ÛÏBackcountry‰Ûù includes a brief notice that it‰Ûªs based on a true story, and Mr. MacDonald has said he was partly inspired by an Ontario couple‰Ûªs real-life wilderness nightmare. He teases out the exact nature of the attack with insinuating cracks and creaks, a foreboding dead bird, a lot of neck-swiveling double takes and a sly, amusingly testy encounter with another hiker, Brad (Eric Balfour). Something wicked this way comes ‰ÛÓ or maybe not. When the worst finally does arrive, Mr. MacDonald trades in his timing and discretion to go full-bore gore, gleefully painting the screen red with blood and guts in an ugly scene that proves, yet again, man really is the most dangerous animal.

Mr. MacDonald‰Ûªs ability to notch up dread moment by moment ‰ÛÓ with a rustle of leaves, the snap of a twig ‰ÛÓ is all the more impressive given that it takes a while to warm up to the two souls he cuts loose in those woods. You first meet Jenn (a good Missy Peregrym) and Alex (Jeff Roop) en route to a backpacking trip in the Canadian wilds. They‰Ûªre attractive if bland and, it becomes clear when they check in with a ranger (Nicholas Campbell), terribly ill equipped for their adventure. They may have the gear, including water purification (if not enough water!), but when Alex, a self-professed park expert, tells the ranger they don‰Ûªt need a map, the couple‰Ûªs fate is as good as sealed.

Watching characters make stupid choices can be pleasurable and useful, as countless Farrelly brothers chuckleheads show. Too many dumb decisions by a good-guy stiff like Alex, a Dudley Do-Right whom Mr. MacDonald tries to make sympathetic, tends to mean that a filmmaker hasn‰Ûªt done the necessary hard work. In ‰ÛÏWild,‰Ûù when Cheryl Strayed sets off on her trek with too much gear and ill-fitting boots, it makes sense for her personality and becomes part of her journey. By contrast, Alex‰Ûªs mistakes ‰ÛÓ and he makes several forehead-slapping doozies ‰ÛÓ don‰Ûªt register as expressions of character but rather as specific narrative strategies because, without a map or a compass (never mind G.P.S.) and nowhere near enough water, he and Jenn have nowhere to go but down, down, down.

This is Mr. Summers‰Ûªs show all the way: his memories (eating magic-mushroom omelets with John Belushi in Bali); his tour photographs (naked groupies draped enticingly across hotel-room furniture); and his face dominating footage of the band‰Ûªs 2007-8 reunion tour. But as the movie plods repetitively from Britain to America, past to present, it‰Ûªs his pre-Police career that begs for more than a flyover ‰ÛÓ the years in the 1960s when he cycled through magnificently protean bands like Eric Burdon and the Animals. The talented Lancashire lad who began life in a Gypsy wagon seems now, at 72, to be finally claiming the limelight for himself.

The most exciting moment in Andy Grieve‰Ûªs rather dull documentary, ‰ÛÏCan‰Ûªt Stand Losing You: Surviving the Police,‰Ûù comes when we learn that Sting‰Ûªs can of hair spray exploded in his face right before a 1978 television appearance. Had the actual detonation been recorded, it would have livened up a movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.

Recounted in droning voice-over by the band‰Ûªs guitarist, Andy Summers (working from his 2006 memoir, ‰ÛÏOne Train Later‰Ûù), the Police‰Ûªs stuttering attempts in the late 1970s to find a London audience and a signature sound ‰ÛÓ finally settling on a smooth fusion of jazz, pop and reggae ‰ÛÓ also suggest the artistic fissures that would do in the band. Yet the personal frictions that placed the Police on Rolling Stone‰Ûªs list of the 10 Messiest Band Breakups are barely evident here. Neither Sting nor the drummer Stewart Copeland contributed to the film, and no former managers or crew are around to comment. Passing references to Sting‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏmoody arrogance‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏdictatorship‰Ûù drop into the film like appetizers for a meal we never get to eat.

It has been seven years since the directors‰Ûª small and promising debut feature film, ‰ÛÏHumboldt County,‰Ûù a group portrait of marijuana farmers living off the grid in Northern California. That movie immersed you in a bohemian culture that the filmmakers seemed to know inside out, and you feel the same here. For all their differences, the characters and their joshing camaraderie feel believable. Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Grodsky have an extraordinary ear for the rhythms and nuances of everyday speech, as voices overlap, conversations take random directions, and casual remarks carry loaded subtexts.

Although Jake has decided to forsake New York City to live in Ohio and work for his ailing father, he holds out the possibility that he will change his mind at the last minute. It brings up the prickly issue of a grown-up child‰Ûªs responsibility for his aging parents, one of many themes that percolate through the film. Throughout the day, Jake behaves like an overgrown brat whose rowdy behavior camouflages terror and despair.
The trip itself, a tour of Manhattan on a bright and beautiful autumn day, is the movie‰Ûªs organizing principle; blocks are counted off on a map, and sights identified.

‰ÛÏGrowing Up and Other Lies,‰Ûù the story of four friends in their 30s who walk from the northern tip of Manhattan to the Battery (with detours), is nominally a buddy comedy. But the movie, written and directed by Danny Jacobs and Darren Grodsky, is so steeped in angst that you share its characters‰Ûª deep-seated dread of a future that looks anything but rosy. The prospect of parenthood is especially daunting.

Jake and his companions, Rocks (Adam Brody), Gunderson (Wyatt Cenac) and Billy (Danny Jacobs), make a somewhat unlikely foursome. Their defensive, competitive roughhousing suggests that their bonds are shallow; they act more like fraternity brothers than lifelong friends, and they have few common interests. As they make their way downtown, they pass an apartment they once shared in which a fire broke out and foam from an extinguisher caused damage, leaving some hard feelings.

‰ÛÏGrowing Up and Other Lies‰Ûù may not have been intended as a generational portrait, but it feels like a slightly older, male version of ‰ÛÏGirls.‰Ûù Because the costumes at that children‰Ûªs birthday party have a pirate theme, you are reminded of ‰ÛÏPeter Pan.‰Ûù The portrayal of rampaging, screeching children at the picnic is a nightmarish premonition of their future as stressed-out parents unable to control the little savages they have spawned. The movie subscribes to the notion that attaining maturity is synonymous with learning to survive in hell.

Rocks, the most soulful of the four, has been engaged to his girlfriend Emma (Lauren Miller) since she unexpectedly became pregnant. He is determined to do the right thing, but his earnestness can‰Ûªt cover up his notable lack of enthusiasm. She senses his ambivalence and doesn‰Ûªt want him to witness the baby‰Ûªs birth lest it repel him sexually.

Their jaunt is a ceremonial farewell for their unofficial ringleader, Jake (Josh Lawson), a painter whose dreams of artistic glory haven‰Ûªt panned out. Not only is Jake devastated by accusations by another, more successful artist that Jake stole his ideas, he is reeling from the loss of an ex-girlfriend, Tabatha (Amber Tamblyn), for whom he stills pines. The pair briefly reconnect at a children‰Ûªs birthday party in Central Park and meet again at a dinner at her parents‰Ûª Gramercy Park apartment.

Billy, nerdy and paranoid about keeping his job as a law partner, is the only one of the four who has prospered. Gunderson, the least developed character, is a hipster contrarian who exudes a sour, reflexive sarcasm.

Emotions are held in check: Voices are never raised, and passions are described from a distance rather than expressed overtly. Most of the conversations are about art, history, literature and of course architecture, but there are inklings of more volatile and intimate matters. Mr. Green, who shows up briefly on a park bench to dispense wisdom (in syntactically impeccable, heavily accented French), has more on his mind than old churches. The story he has to tell, at times barely perceptible but moving all the same, is about a marriage in crisis. It is also about the fate of the idea clumsily translated into English as ‰ÛÏsapience‰Ûù and embodied by artists and craftsmen like Borromini. Where, in the 21st-century West, are the sources of enlightenment and wisdom?

The characters in ‰ÛÏLa Sapienza,‰Ûù EugÌ¬ne Green‰Ûªs new film, tend to look directly into the camera when they speak, to speak clearly and grammatically, and to refrain from interrupting one another. The rhythm of the editing is similarly deliberate: The camera looks at one person, then another, and patiently surveys a landscape or the interior of an old and magnificent building. This graceful, unhurried style, with its blend of austerity and artifice and its roots in classical French theatrical traditions, is Mr. Green‰Ûªs signature. American by birth and ardently European by residence and vocation, he elevates formal decorum to a moral principle. ‰ÛÏLa Sapienza,‰Ûù quiet and conversational as it seems, is a passionate defense of ‰ÛÓ and perhaps also an elegy for ‰ÛÓ an old and dignified ideal of civilization.

Mr. Green‰Ûªs response is quietly but unmistakably polemical. His conservatism ‰ÛÓ rarely articulated outright but implicit in every meticulous frame and carefully wrought sentence ‰ÛÓ is intriguing and provocative. His films amount to a protest against the vulgarity and velocity of 21st-century life, from which he, like Alexandre, seeks refuge in the symmetries and harmonies of Borromini and his contemporaries.

The chance to contemplate Borromini‰Ûªs arches, ornaments and elliptical forms is both an incidental pleasure of ‰ÛÏLa Sapienza‰Ûù and the whole point. The movie is an unapologetically rarefied undertaking and at the same time a gracious and inviting film. And it embodies an elegant and melancholy paradox: What looks like tourism is really the pursuit of truth and beauty, and vice versa.

And also, as such, an escape from the modern world. Though set in the present, ‰ÛÏLa Sapienza,‰Ûù which takes its name from a venerable university in Rome, finds inspiration and sustenance in the past, specifically in the 17th century. Alexandre Schmidt (Fabrizio Rongione), a coldly rational Swiss-born architect living in France, finds himself in a state of professional and emotional malaise. He and his wife, AliÌ©nor (Christelle Prot Landman), a social scientist, retreat to the Piedmontese town of Stresa, where Alexandre plans to begin researching and writing a long-deferred book on the Baroque architect Francesco Borromini. During a stroll along the shore of Lake Maggiore, Alexandre and AliÌ©nor meet Lavinia (Arianna Nastro) and Goffredo (Ludovico Succio), teenage siblings who become their protÌ©gÌ©s. Goffredo, who wants to study architecture, accompanies Alexandre to Turin and Rome, while AliÌ©nor remains in Stresa with Lavinia, who suffers from a mysterious nervous disorder.

Its central character, Ronah (Brooke Bloom), is a graduate student in New York City whose clients, referred to her by a therapist (Dennis Boutsikaris), have serious intimacy issues. Patients visit her drab New York apartment, which has persistent plumbing problems, in a building whose walls are so thin that there is no shutting out neighbors‰Ûª racket. Her uncomfortable living situation is not conducive to therapy. And Ronah, although articulate and professionally welcoming, is not a warm and fuzzy person like Cheryl Cohen Greene (Helen Hunt), the empathic surrogate who helps a survivor of polio lose his virginity in the 2012 movie ‰ÛÏThe Sessions.‰Ûù

It also becomes increasingly apparent that Ronah, who is freezing her eggs in case she decides one day to have a child, is an isolated single woman whose only nonprofessional contact is her brother in upstate New York. They converse via Skype, and he cares for their mentally unstable mother.

‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Lost Control,‰Ûù Anja Marquardt‰Ûªs chilly portrait of a behavioral psychologist who works as a sexual surrogate, is so studiedly bleak it will pour ice water on anyone‰Ûªs fantasies of earning a living as an erotic healer.
Ronah, against her will, begins developing romantic feelings for Johnny, and surreptitiously visits the hospital where he works to check up on him. Eventually, he responds violently.

The movie observes Ronah working with several clients, who, after a test for sexually transmitted diseases, must sign an agreement asserting that their sessions are ‰ÛÏnot for sexual gratification or for entertainment.‰Ûù It focuses on a new case in which the boundaries between her feelings and professional detachment are tested and begin to blur. Johnny (Marc Menchaca) is a handsome, red-bearded anesthesiologist whose aversion to intimate physical contact coincides with a drinking problem. His trust in Ronah is slow to develop, but as they go through the exercises involving eye contact and delicate, gentle touch, he begins to warm up and shed his defenses, although each advance is followed by a backlash.

Before this outburst, the camera follows Ronah around the streets of Manhattan, whose architecture reflects her loneliness. ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Lost Control‰Ûù sustains a mood of deepening alienation, but the attitude of the movie is too detached for it to be emotionally gripping, and its ending is botched.
Because Ronah is evasive about her occupation outside the office, there is plenty of reason to suspect she harbors deep ambivalence and perhaps even some shame about it.

‰ÛÏSpring‰Ûù tells the story of Evan (Lou Taylor Pucci), a young American who after some personal troubles takes a trip to Italy to find himself and instead finds much more than he bargained for. He becomes involved with Louise (Nadia Hilker), a beautiful woman except when she‰Ûªs transforming into a hideous monster.

Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead don‰Ûªt yet have many movies to their credit, but with ‰ÛÏSpring,‰Ûù which they directed, they show that they already possess something that many makers of horror films never develop: patience.

Mr. Benson, who wrote the script, has invented an intriguing mythology for this ancient, indescribably ugly beast that involves pregnancy, rebirth and genetics. And the best thing about ‰ÛÏSpring‰Ûù is that it doesn‰Ûªt lead to an obvious devoured-by-my-girlfriend ending. Evan and Louise have a good long time to talk about their situation once he discovers her secret. The actors get a chance to create a real relationship, and they make the most of the opportunity.

Filmmakers working the trashier side of the genre often can‰Ûªt wait to unleash a big effect, as if they‰Ûªre worried viewers will bail if they‰Ûªre not grossed out in the first 10 minutes. It is well past the one-hour mark before ‰ÛÏSpring‰Ûù really causes you to recoil, and the wait makes that shot all the more jolting.
‰ÛÏThe Gunman‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Killing and cursing.

At the start of the movie Annie (Ms. Trinca) is Jim‰Ûªs girl, and he is an American sniper pretending to provide security to humanitarian relief workers in the Democratic Republic of Congo. While Annie tries to do good amid the atrocities of that country‰Ûªs long civil war, Jim and his colleagues conspire to assassinate a government minister who is inconveniently trying to renegotiate contracts with multinational mining companies. The guy running the conspiracy is Felix (Mr. Bardem), who uses the operation as a pretext to steal Annie from Jim.
