The director, Pierre Morel, is not too bad at this sort of thing, having directed Liam Neeson in the first ‰ÛÏTaken‰Ûù movie, a touchstone of modern angry-dad cinema, and John Travolta in ‰ÛÏTo Paris With Love.‰Ûù He runs away pretty quickly from the topical pretensions of the script (written by Don MacPherson, Pete Travis and Mr. Penn and based on a Jean-Patrick Manchette novel), and concentrates on set pieces ‰ÛÓ chases, shootouts, a climactic showdown at a bullfighting ring ‰ÛÓ that are effective without being all that original.

Mr. Penn, aiming for weary, battered intensity, settles into a zone somewhere between fatigue and indigestion. Jim‰Ûªs bouts of forgetfulness, blurred vision and vertigo ‰ÛÓ results of a career of international headbanging ‰ÛÓ are meant to add some vulnerability to the character but really add only a layer of contrivance to the plot, which runs out of steam long before the loose ends are tied up. Mr. Bardem at least seems to be having fun, playing a big, silly drunk scene and exiting the movie before things get completely stupid. The poor gunman has to stick around until the end. No wonder he‰Ûªs jealous.

All of which could be worthy and interesting. Sean Penn, who plays Jim Terrier, the titular shooter, afflicted by conscience and a head injury, has done some indisputably great things. And among the guys he pistol whips and pals around with here are Javier Bardem, Mark Rylance, Ray Winstone and Idris Elba, all fine actors not above a bit of genre showboating. The atmosphere is leathery and masculine, redolent of stale cologne and weary bravado, with a token woman (the Italian actress Jasmine Trinca) whose job is to be menaced, protected and partially undressed. She is allowed to drive a car, but the fighting and shooting ‰ÛÓ the bad things that are also, in a movie like this, the cool things and the important things ‰ÛÓ are left to the men.

Eight years later, Jim is back in Congo digging wells, surfing and condescending to the locals ‰ÛÓ in other words, doing penance for his earlier misdeeds and trying to forget about his lost love. But a bunch of men with machetes and assault rifles show up (shouting ‰ÛÏWhere‰Ûªs the white man?‰Ûù) to drag him back into the old life. Jim is chased from London to Barcelona to Gibraltar, and Mr. Penn, grimacing and flexing his impressive brows and well-veined biceps, is put through the paces of the midlife-crisis action thriller. Minions are slaughtered. Cellphones are dialed. Interpol is invoked.

It‰Ûªs not a hard and fast rule, but in general when the main character, sometime in the third act, says, ‰ÛÏI did some bad things ... ‰Ûù and stares off into the middle distance, the implied end of the sentence is ‰ÛÏincluding this movie.‰Ûù I take no particular pleasure in reporting that this is the case in ‰ÛÏThe Gunman,‰Ûù a globe-trotting action thriller and also, in passing, a melodrama of male sexual jealousy, an indictment of Western meddling in Africa and a concussion-awareness public service announcement.

Fallen from the peak of the ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù phenomenon, Mr. Lautner is game here for playing a well-meaning joe who‰Ûªs deep in debt to a Chinese loan shark. Cam tracks down the parkour whiz, Nikki (Marie Avgeropoulos), and, after proving himself, joins her in a group of thieves for hire. But she and her fellow street ninjas have a Fagin of sorts ‰ÛÓ a slick leader named Miller (Adam Rayner) who sends them on increasingly risky jobs and has Nikki in his clutches.
The story feels cut-rate, but Mr. Benmayor, a Spaniard, brings eager eyes to the city, and a lot of crane shots to the endeavor.

A dry-docked ship, construction sites and rooftops are the terrain for their exploits, rather than the ritzy face-lifted side of New York. Cam and Nikki are good at their jobs ‰ÛÓ leaping and pilfering ‰ÛÓ but they‰Ûªre corruptible innocents, unlike the professionals of another notable parkour entry, ‰ÛÏDistrict B13,‰Ûù by Pierre Morel. These action sequences are more an underdog celebration of physical freedom than brash showing off.
Rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some intense violence, sexual content and gravity-defying methods of getting crosstown.

Part urban crime film, part romantic fantasy, ‰ÛÏTracers‰Ûù begins by zipping along with the street-level symbol of heedless New York motion, a bike messenger. When this particular speed demon, Cam (Taylor Lautner), has an accident, he slams into a young woman practicing another kind of perpetual motion, parkour, an equipment-free sport that treats urban spaces as obstacle courses. Corny twists and exchanges ensue in the wobbly story, but, delightfully, Daniel Benmayor‰Ûªs film shows love not just for stunts but for the dynamic surfaces of the city.

Great careers have begun with flesh-eating creatures. Take the writer-director John Sayles (‰ÛÏLone Star‰Ûù), who got his start in movies writing trash classics like ‰ÛÏPiranha‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAlligator.‰Ûù Now the director Jordan Rubin, a former writer for Comedy Central‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCrank Yankers,‰Ûù and Evan Astrowsky, a producer of Eli Roth‰Ûªs horror film ‰ÛÏCabin Fever,‰Ûù pool their talents for ‰ÛÏZombeavers,‰Ûù an intermittently diverting stew of low-budget effects and potty-mouth humor. Unsurprisingly, its writers and soundtrack composers, the brothers Jon and Al Kaplan, wrote the music for Syfy‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPiranhaconda‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏDinocroc vs. Supergator.‰Ûù (More intriguingly, they also created ‰ÛÏSilence!,‰Ûù the stage parody of ‰ÛÏThe Silence of the Lambs.‰Ûù)

Also unsurprising is the premise: Six young, attractive archetypes ‰ÛÓ sensitive Sam (Hutch Dano); brainy Mary (Rachel Melvin); randy Zoe (Cortney Palm); goofy Buck (Peter Gilroy); sexy Jenn (Lexi Atkins); and alpha male Tommy (Jake Weary) ‰ÛÓ take up residence in (not again!) a cabin in the woods. A nearby chemical spill from a truck has seeped into the local ecosystem, resulting in a legion of white-eyed, bucktoothed, flat-tailed undead. These ravenous critters chew through everything: walls, floorboards and body limbs, this last giving birth to human variations on the same.
Abundant but cheesy gore, a frenetic pace and a self-amused air from the filmmakers pervade the proceedings. As for the actors, are they superstars of tomorrow? Let‰Ûªs just say it‰Ûªs early yet.
‰ÛÏZombeavers‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Profanity, nudity, viscera, gnawing.

There‰Ûªs a little smooching in ‰ÛÏInsurgent,‰Ûù most conspicuously when Tris unzips to get down and tastefully dirty with her boyfriend, Four (Theo James). Like Tris, Four is a renegade with a secret that‰Ûªs revealed in this installment and leads to the introduction of a new character, Evelyn, played by the always welcome Naomi Watts. Like most big-ticket screen franchises, this one comes with some actual acting talent that gives the movie tang and legitimacy and may also help broaden its appeal along with its marketing and publicity opportunities. Performers like Ms. Watts and her co-star, Kate Winslet, who plays Jeanine, one of the baddies in the series, also provide a much-needed counterweight for the interchangeable young lovelies floating in the background.

The story takes place in a post-apocalypse walled Chicago largely peopled by five multiracial factions. At 16, its citizens partake in an initiation ritual, the Choosing Ceremony, in which, like Harry Potter and his wizardly kin, they choose their group for life. Born into Abnegation, which values selflessness, Tris signed up with Team Dauntless in the inaugural movie. As their names suggest, the remaining factions ‰ÛÓ Amity, Candor and Erudite ‰ÛÓ serve specific needs. They were also created by shortsighted ancestors who believed that human personality was the root of a ‰ÛÏwarring world,‰Ûù instead of ‰ÛÏpolitical ideology, religious belief, race or nationalism,‰Ûù as Ms. Roth puts it in the first book. The last time, the know-it-alls in Erudite were looking to take over; they‰Ûªre still trying.

Tighter, tougher and every bit as witless as its predecessor, ‰ÛÏThe Divergent Series: Insurgent‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the second segment in the cycle ‰ÛÓ arrives with a yawn and ends with a bang. In between, bodies run, leap and fall amid nuzzling lips, blasting bullets and periodic story turns that make the movie a modest cultural artifact if one largely devoid of aesthetic interest. At this point, the heroine, Tris Prior (Shailene Woodley), can easily lock and load, having been trained by a thuggishly stylish faction, Dauntless, whose members wear the usual blah-blah black, tats and piercings and guard this dystopian world. ‰ÛÏThey‰Ûªre our protectors, our soldiers, our police,‰Ûù Tris says of them in the first movie, if also ‰ÛÏcrazy.‰Ûù

For Tris, the filmmakers and those who have embraced this franchise, that‰Ûªs probably, you know, cool. As the Wachowskis proved in the ‰ÛÏMatrix‰Ûù trilogy and as copycat moviemakers have been affirming since, jackboot fashion and heroic hyperviolence go together in movies like guns and ammunition. And while guns may be a hot-button topic off-screen, they remain blandly par for the action-movie course, including in PG-13-rated movies like this. So much so that ‰ÛÏInsurgent,‰Ûù based on the young-adult series by Veronica Roth, features not one but two scenes in which a nominal villain is executed point blank with a bullet to the head by a nominally righteous character.

The standout among the younger performers is Miles Teller, whose to-the-screen-born poise and controlled nervous energy make a jolting contrast to the pouts and droopiness of some of the other secondary male leads. Mr. Teller plays Peter, a Dauntless member who turns up every so often to help push the story forward and throw some barbs at Tris. Mr. James has obvious charms, but together he and Ms. Woodley work like a palliative on the movie. A somewhat appealingly diffident presence, Ms. Woodley has a talent for carving out a little pocket of intimacy on-screen, which is why she‰Ûªs good at bringing you into a character‰Ûªs head space. She too has appeal, though it‰Ûªs clear that, even after two movies, she isn‰Ûªt as much driving this franchise as catching a ride.

That said, Tris still isn‰Ûªt all that engaging, even if she remains an effective empathy generator despite her occasional need to shoot to kill. She feels bad about that, mind you, shedding tears now and then amid the mayhem and exegesis. In broad strokes, Tris is the classic odd girl out and compulsory self-reliant heroine who leads with her brains instead of her inevitable good looks, the protagonist who struggles to feel she belongs even though she was born to lead. Sometimes she‰Ûªs called Joan as in Arc; in ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games,‰Ûù the obvious model for the ‰ÛÏDivergent‰Ûù book series, she‰Ûªs called Katniss Everdeen. Although Tris isn‰Ûªt Katniss, not exactly, the characters face similar hurdles, including securing the future of their people and negotiating the attention of their romantic foils.

The director Robert Schwentke, whose credits include ‰ÛÏFlightplan‰Ûù and junkier diversions like ‰ÛÏR.I.P.D.,‰Ûù takes on this franchise with generic competence. If you didn‰Ûªt know that the first movie‰Ûªs director, Neil Burger, had bowed out of the sequels, you might not even notice the change in personnel. True, Ms. Woodley looks more comfortable with her action-heroine duties than she did in ‰ÛÏDivergent,‰Ûù though this may have more to do with her rising stardom than anything else, including her new director. She looks at ease running and gunning now, and also shows off some impressive upper-body strength along with some feeling. Like Mr. Schwentke, she hits all the requisite marks in a story that, like so many middle chapters, feels distinctly interstitial.

The idea that life comes down to personality is a reassuring fantasy, perhaps especially for readers struggling to find their own paths and selves amid the confusions of adolescence. Ms. Roth‰Ûªs stated interest in psychology may partly account for why her factions evoke the five-factor model of personality, a.k.a. the Big Five: agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, neuroticism and openness. Tris, who is actually an outlier type called Divergent, transcends these classifications, which makes her a danger to power and assures her the widest possible audience appeal. She doesn‰Ûªt fit in, not really, except as a distinctly familiar narrative figure whose radical innocence (to borrow a term from the literary theorist Ihab Hassan) will help redeem a fallen world step by anguished step.
‰ÛÏThe Divergent Series: Insurgent‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Extreme if generally bloodless, gutless violence.

The situation carries echoes of Joseph Conrad and John Ford. In addition to a mostly unseen, presumably hostile indigenous population, the dangers facing Dinesen include a former soldier known as Zuluaga, who seems to have descended into Kurtzian madness. Dinesen, with his European manners, books and scientific principles, is at once noble and ridiculous, a civilized man adrift in the wilderness and the embodiment of blind, imperial arrogance. A doting father and a bit of a snob, he seems to absorb the wildness of his surroundings, becoming desperate and almost feral as he wanders the wasteland howling his daughter‰Ûªs name.

The films of the Argentine director Lisandro Alonso often feel longer than they are. That isn‰Ûªt a bad thing, necessarily. Too many movies hurtle forward on fast editing and breathless plotting, and too much of life goes by in a blur. The characters in four of Mr. Alonso‰Ûªs features ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏLa Libertad,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏLos Muertos,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏLiverpool‰Ûù and now ‰ÛÏJauja‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ undertake difficult journeys, at least partly on foot, across hostile terrain. Following them through long takes and static shots accompanied by abundant silence and sparse dialogue and music, the viewer feels the weight of time. This can be uncomfortable, but the risk of tedium can deliver a special kind of intensity, a slowing of the metabolism and an awakening of the senses.

In ‰ÛÏJauja‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the title refers to a mythical city akin to Xanadu or El Dorado ‰ÛÓ the traveler is Gunnar Dinesen, a Danish engineer played by Viggo Mortensen, the first actual movie star to appear in an Alonso film (and also one of the composers of the film‰Ûªs curiously and also purposely anachronistic-sounding score). Sometime in the late 19th century, somewhere along the rocky and desolate Patagonian coast, Dinesen and his 15-year-old daughter, Ingeborg (Viilbjork Mallin Agger), are camped out with a small group of soldiers and surveyors. A middle-aged officer expresses polite but unmistakably predatory interest in the girl, who instead runs off with his assistant, a skinny dreamboat named Corto. Her father sets off in pursuit.

For a while, his search follows the trail of a classic western ‰ÛÓ of ‰ÛÏThe Searchers,‰Ûù to be precise. We assume that it will end either in a reunion or in disaster, and as Dinesen encounters bloody corpses and bloodcurdling screams, the second possibility seems much more likely. But Mr. Alonso, it turns out, has an entirely different destination in mind.

I hesitate to spell it out. Frankly, I doubt if I could. Suffice it to say that this filmmaker, who has until now specialized in earthbound, emphatically linear stories that nonetheless resonate with intimations of spiritual mystery, has gone in a new direction, toward a more overtly poetic and frankly anti-realist kind of cinema. ‰ÛÏJauja‰Ûù is more stylized and shapely than his earlier films. The rounded-off corners of the almost-square frames evoke early movies and antique photographs, and there is wit and mischief in the way Mr. Alonso plays with the relationship between what we see, what we don‰Ûªt see and what we expect to see.

The setting is vast and empty, yet nobody experiences true solitude. Whenever characters might think themselves alone and unobserved, the camera will pivot to reveal that someone else is nearby, watching or scheming or just taking up space. The wilderness, a barren and silent entity in ‰ÛÏLa Libertad‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLiverpool,‰Ûù now feels haunted, full of inscrutable meanings and intentions. These may be signs of a cosmic or metaphysical presence, or they may be figments of Dinesen‰Ûªs increasingly desperate and fevered imagination. It‰Ûªs possible that we end up in his mind or his dreams, or in a hitherto uncharted dimension, or maybe the film guides us to the magical city of Jauja. It may take a few more trips to figure it out.

But this is unhappy sightseeing: Ms. Peng‰Ûªs film centers on a man on a decade-plus search for his lost son, a victim of the scourge of child trafficking in China. What results is ample fodder for a stop-and-go tear-jerker featuring the Hong Kong star Andy Lau, suitably rumpled like a piece of distressed clothing, as the poor, bereft father, Lei.

‰ÛÏLost and Love‰Ûù (‰ÛÏLost Orphan‰Ûù in the original Chinese title) confronts serious problems but is too busy reaching for epic sweep and soaring moments to nail the fine detail of main characters‰Ûª fraught give-and-take.

Their bond feels awkwardly developed, as typified by a shouting match over the bike and a playful car-washing scene. Ms. Peng, a novelist and screenwriter, keeps lurching into wide shot to show off the landscape (especially the bridges that tap into Zeng‰Ûªs vague memories of childhood) and cutting away to wispy stories about a baby trafficker and a distraught mother.

On a mountain leg of his province-by-province dragnet, Lei is joined by a young mechanic, Zeng (Boran Jing), after repairs on his bike, which flies a flag of his missing child. When the younger, well-coiffed man reveals he was kidnapped as a child, the film begins a potentially poignant drama of two people in need, both clinging to grief.

Peng Sanyuan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLost and Love‰Ûù could ably serve as a travelogue of China: glowingly verdant trees, winding roads, fishing shacks, ribbonlike bridges, cafes and grubby city intersections, all shot by Mark Lee Ping Bin, the cinematographer who has helped the great director Hou Hsiao-hsien sculpt time in images.

It takes courage to ask your partner ‰ÛÏAre we happy?‰Ûù‰ÛÓ especially if, like Mary (Elisabeth Waterston), you‰Ûªre pregnant and your boyfriend, Victor (played by Ms. Waterston‰Ûªs husband, Louis Cancelmi), seems increasingly detached from his imminent fatherhood. That detachment, its cause and consequence, forms the shrouded heart of ‰ÛÏPlease Be Normal,‰Ûù a tiny, piercing study of dawning desperation that‰Ûªs all the more remarkable for being virtually silent.

Bearing up under this brutal scrutiny, the actors remain miraculously natural as their director (who also photographed the film with Ori Lahav) creates a curiously magnetic drama from restraint and repression. Stabs of eerie music (by the duo Stars of the Lid) punctuate the narrative, most effectively in a dreamy sequence that follows Victor and a grieving young woman (Dana Eskelson) on a nighttime journey. Their connection is transient but profound, just one of the film‰Ûªs several kinds of love. But happiness? That‰Ûªs something else entirely.

Working confidently within the quiet, the writer and director, Haik Kocharian, lets us see the prison that love can become when responsibility smothers dreams. A playwright with an Off Broadway work in rehearsal, Victor does odd jobs and endures the disapproval and controlling largess of Mary‰Ûªs wealthy father (Sam Waterston, playing a rather scary version of his real-life relationship to Mr. Cancelmi). As the couple prepare to move from their cozy New York City apartment to a new suburban home, their rising tension is conveyed through fragments of dialogue and a camera that catches every twitching cheekbone and uncertain glance.

The heaviness of the real world isn‰Ûªt evident on screen; it just swirls around ‰ÛÏThe Kidnapping,‰Ûù seeping through the cracks and into your consciousness. It opens unceremoniously with Michel, as our protagonist is known, speaking with another middle-aged man about an apartment renovation. Seated at a table, sipping coffee and smoking cigarettes, the men chat idly and to no evident narrative end. And so it goes for a while as Michel wanders here and there, speaks with other intimates and keeps things entertainingly hopping with his observations about J.G. Ballard, so-called Swedish fascism and Le Corbusier‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏconcentration camp‰Ûù architecture. And then three kidnappers corner Michel and ‰ÛÓ after pausing to see what he‰Ûªs reading (Tocqueville) ‰ÛÓ sweep him off to the countryside.

Mr. Houellebecq‰Ûªs readers may note that Ginette and Dede‰Ûªs homey ministrations offer a piercing contrast with the parents in both his books and his biographical accounts. Ginette is such a warm bosom that she even asks Michel if he would like some pornography. At that point, Michel, who wanders the garden, wrestles a bit and smokes a lot, more or less has free rein of the house, a slyly horrifying kitsch-topia with display cases filled with beer steins and ornamental plates, and crammed with bric-a-brac and peach-colored accents. Michel says no to the porn but asks for a woman (Marie Bourjala as Fatima), who arrives to warm his bed and reassure us that this is Michel Houellebecq‰Ûªs world, after all: preposterous, assaultive and tender.

The apparent genesis for ‰ÛÏKidnapping‰Ûù can be traced to 2011, when Mr. Houellebecq briefly went missing without explanation while promoting his novel ‰ÛÏThe Map and the Territory.‰Ûù Rumors swirled, including one that he had been snatched by Al Qaeda. This proved false: ‰ÛÏMichel Houellebecq has not been captured by Al Qaeda,‰Ûù one  news outfit  assured anxious readers. Enter the French filmmaker Guillaume Nicloux, who, casually blurring nonfiction with fiction and shooting in remarkably ugly digital, has created a distinct, insistently light version of that disappearance. This lightness is especially strange, as is the movie‰Ûªs comedy, which together make a dissonant counterpart to the now-familiar, deadly kidnappings by the likes of the Islamic State.

The crumpled, ashen-faced man on screen stands on a corner in Paris alone and seemingly ignored. The world is not paying attention to Michel Houellebecq, save for the off-screen movie crew and us, of course. This probably doesn‰Ûªt happen often to Mr. Houellebecq (pronounced WELL-beck), the French novelist whose putatively scandalous work touches on subjects ‰ÛÓ despair, sex tourism, cloning, Islamic political power, despair again ‰ÛÓ that seem calculated to provoke, especially, the humorless. A typically vulgar caricature of him was on the cover of the magazine Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, the day that two jihadists entered its Paris offices and set about slaughtering 12 people.

A fictional movie or perhaps not exactly, ‰ÛÏThe Kidnapping of Michel Houellebecq‰Ûù had its premiere at the 2014 Berlin International Film Festival, a year before the Charlie Hebdo killings. There‰Ûªs no direct connection between the movie and the murders, but both are part of that contested terrain known as Michel Houellebecq. By this, I mean less the real Mr. Houellebecq (whoever he is) than that site in which writerly production meets intellectual validation or condemnation, vociferous public debate and political denunciation. It is this site, this authorial marker that is presumably on view in ‰ÛÏThe Kidnapping,‰Ûù a divertingly eccentric, often comically absurd movie about a novelist, also named Michel Houellebecq, who finds something like happiness after being abducted.

He lands in a modest house plunked down next to what looks to be a car junkyard and cordoned off by barbed wire. There, he becomes intimately, humorously and fraternally acquainted with his French-speaking kidnappers ‰ÛÓ played by Luc Schwarz, Mathieu Nicourt and Maxime LefranÌ_ois, all called by their real first names ‰ÛÓ who pour him drinks, ask about his writing process and demonstrate their various bodybuilding and fight skills. Michel proves to be a demanding kidnapping victim: he asks for wine, food, cigarettes, a lighter, books. These he receives and more, including the warm company of the home‰Ûªs owners, an old couple, Ginette (Ginette Suchotzky) and Dede (Andre Suchotzky). In time, Michel transforms into something of a guest ‰ÛÓ a contented, genially indulged one.

Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence will probably get a lot of grief and negative reviews for ‰ÛÏSerena,‰Ûù but this isn‰Ûªt the kind of fiasco you can entirely pin on its stars. Miscast and misdirected from first ridiculous scene to last, they play George and Serena Pemberton, 1929 glamour-pusses who, soon after the story opens, marry and move to his timber camp. There, he plans to build an empire or dominate nature or something ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs telling that it is never wholly clear what he has in mind beyond felling trees ‰ÛÓ while Serena, well, she intends to dominate poor George.

The Danish director Susanne Bier, whose credits include ‰ÛÏOpen Hearts‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThings We Lost in the Fire,‰Ûù has done good work with actors before, so it‰Ûªs hard to know what happened here or why. Whatever the case, she seems as unsteady as her two stars although, given how overedited the movie is, it can be difficult to tell if the scenes ever had any integrity before they were put in a Cuisinart. (Ms. Bier apparently spent more than a year in postproduction trying to get the movie in shape.) That said, all the deep-fried performances, including from Rhys Ifans as a weird mountain man with a gun, strongly suggest that no amount of post magic could have saved this picture from its makers.

Based on a well-regarded 2008 novel by the American author Ron Rash, the story takes place in the North Carolina mountains and finds George and Serena first battling those who want to turn the area into a park and then fighting each other. Blood spills and drama erupts, but none of it registers. What does register is that this is another recent bid from a Danish director to recreate not simply the American past but also a Hollywood-style version of that past. In ‰ÛÏThe Salvation,‰Ûù the Danish director Kristian Levring reimagines the old American West in a movie shot in South Africa; here, Ms. Bier has tried to recreate 1920s Appalachia in the Czech Republic. The German filmmaker Wim Wenders once observed that the Americans have ‰ÛÏcolonized our subconscious,‰Ûù so I guess we have only ourselves to blame.

Serena does just that largely through a lot of awkward love scenes that turn the characters into tangles of disembodied body parts and find Ms. Lawrence‰Ûªs head pinwheeling in painful, at times comically so, pantomimes of ecstasy. It‰Ûªs embarrassing watching a likable, supremely capable actor like Ms. Lawrence deliver a performance more suited to a Mel Brooks burlesque, though her vamping and eye-popping are really no worse than Mr. Cooper‰Ûªs maladroit Boston accent and palpable, at times visible, discomfort. The actors don‰Ûªt just look uncomfortable in their period duds, they also look uneasy in their own skins, which is a feat for two such natural, physically confident screen performers.
‰ÛÏSerena‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, violence, logging.

The comic premise of ‰ÛÏGet Hard‰Ûù could hardly be simpler. Will Ferrell is white. Kevin Hart, in contrast, is black. But you don‰Ûªt have to consult a Starbucks barista to know that race is a very complicated matter. It‰Ûªs been a source of humor for a very long time, but which jokes are acceptable to whom is never an easy matter to determine. Somebody is likely to be offended. The trick in a movie like this one is to appear daring while playing it safe, to act provocative while not actually provoking anyone.

That can be done a few ways. You can carefully select and hone the material, loading up the barbs and ironies so as to disarm bigotry and short-circuit the hot buttons of sensitivity. Key and Peele are the current masters of that approach. Or you can choose quantity over quality, opening up a spigot of gags and riffs and hoping that the good ones will wash away the bad. That is pretty much what the makers of ‰ÛÏGet Hard‰Ûù have done (Etan Cohen is the director. He, Ian Roberts and Jay Martel are the screenwriters. All white guys, in case you were wondering.) It‰Ûªs more or less how a lot of R-rated big-studio comedies are put together these days, with or without racial themes. Let a couple of funny guys do a lot of funny things and don‰Ûªt worry too much about whether it makes sense.

Anyway: Mr. Ferrell‰Ûªs character, a superrich financier named James, faces 10 years in the penitentiary after being convicted of fraud and embezzlement, and he‰Ûªs terrified of sexual assault. He hires Darnell, the upwardly striving carwash owner played by Mr. Hart, to teach him how to protect himself. Why? Because James assumes that, as a black man, Darnell must know all about prison. Let us pause here to marvel at the challenge the filmmakers have set for themselves, which is to say at the many different ways this conceit isn‰Ûªt funny. It‰Ûªs hard to know where to begin.

A few other performers show up when needed: Edwina Findley as Darnell‰Ûªs wife; Alison Brie as James‰Ûªs materialistic fiancÌ©e; Craig T. Nelson as her father, who is also James‰Ûªs boss; John Mayer as himself. The only one who makes much of an impression is the rapper T.I., who takes what might be the most egregiously stereotyped role in the whole movie and infuses it with sly menace and charismatic wit. There is a plot of sorts ‰ÛÓ James, who insists he‰Ûªs innocent, will need to find out who set him up ‰ÛÓ but it‰Ûªs pretty much abandoned until the very end, when the need for an action sequence or two asserts itself, and the rape jokes have run low.
‰ÛÏGet Hard‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). One guy uses bad words wrong. The other guy uses them correctly.

You can‰Ûªt go to a water park and not get wet. Similarly, you can‰Ûªt watch ‰ÛÏGet Hard‰Ûù without laughing a few times, whether you like it or not. What makes you laugh will, of course, depend on your taste, or lack thereof. It may be the sight of Mr. Ferrell‰Ûªs buttocks. (Did I mention that he‰Ûªs white?) It may be his goofy swear words. It may be when Mr. Hart impersonates the whole population of a prison exercise yard. Or when Mr. Ferrell bench-presses him. (Mr. Ferrell, it should be noted, is fairly tall. Mr. Hart is quite short.)

The highest praise I can give ‰ÛÏGet Hard‰Ûù is that it is not quite as awful as it could have been. Mr. Hart, as usual, is jumpy and silly, maniacally mugging his way through every scene. Mr. Ferrell, as usual, is lumbering and silly, using his big body and his adaptable voice to explore new varieties of embarrassment. Neither is exactly bad, though both have been better doing other things.

Or maybe you will be tickled by one of the hundreds of rape jokes that seem to be the movie‰Ûªs main source of inspiration. I kind of hope not. There are no taboos in comedy, of course, but even among comedians there‰Ûªs some reluctance to mine sexual assault for easy laughs. The exception seems to be when men in prison are involved, but why should that be the case? (No need to answer.)

The short, squat creatures that turn up in animated movies may all be starting to run together in your mind, which makes finding a distinctive voice for such characters all the more important. The creators of ‰ÛÏHome‰Ûù made an inspired choice in that regard for their little hero, recruiting Jim Parsons of ‰ÛÏThe Big Bang Theory‰Ûù for the job, and they made another by pairing him with the pop star Rihanna.

Yeah, this is another extraterrestrial-plus-human-child movie, and the Boov are yet another brightly colored runty people. But Oh‰Ûªs imperfect grasp of English and the good will Mr. Parsons engenders make the character adorable, and Rihanna (who also provides some music, as does Ms. Lopez) gives Tip a likable edge. Grown-ups, meanwhile, can ponder whether the movie, based on a children‰Ûªs book by Adam Rex, contains a veiled pro-immigration message. Or perhaps it‰Ûªs a statement about overreliance on material goods. When the Boov arrive on Earth, they get rid of any human things they have no use for by bundling them in antigravity balls so they float away. Seeing what they deem useless makes you realize that we humans do accumulate a lot of stuff.
‰ÛÏHome‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). For occasional scary moments.

The result is a charming concoction with positive messages for younger children about conquering fears, understanding outsiders and knowing yourself. Mr. Parsons is Oh, an extraterrestrial of the Boov species, which is highly skilled at running away from danger and at taking over other species‰Ûª planets. The Boov decide to inhabit Earth, gently relocating its humans to Australia, thereby inadvertently separating Rihanna‰Ûªs character, Tip, from her mother, Lucy (Jennifer Lopez). Oh and Tip join forces to try to reunite mother and daughter and ‰ÛÓ oops ‰ÛÓ save the planet from annihilation, a threat seemingly brought on by a blunder any grown-up will relate to: an email Oh mistakenly sent to ‰ÛÏreply all.‰Ûù

The result of these and other constraints is a frustratingly fragmented yet warmly intimate portrait of an evolving bond that frays but doesn‰Ûªt sever. Drawing on experiences with her own parents, the director Sophie Hyde (who wrote the story with Matthew Cormack) neither lectures nor elides, addressing the stresses of hormone treatments and sexual reassignment surgery with simple directness. This candor ‰ÛÓ echoed in Bryan Mason‰Ûªs straightforward if bland photography ‰ÛÓ seems to relax and embolden her inexperienced cast, especially Del Herbert-Jane, who originally joined the project as a gender diversity consultant before accepting the pivotal role of the mother.

There‰Ûªs very little about the Australian drama ‰ÛÏ52 Tuesdays‰Ûù that could be considered conventional. Not the characters, all of whom are played by nonprofessional actors. Not the story, which concerns the effects of a mother‰Ûªs gender transition on her teenage daughter. And not the filmmaking, whose rigid structure ‰ÛÓ once a week for a year, only on Tuesdays ‰ÛÓ was decided before any other element.
In James‰Ûªs quiet bravery, however, the physical and psychological pain of transformation are front and center. His is the journey that resonates, and his the happiness we hope for.

Less emotionally compelling is Tilda Cobham-Hervey as Billie, a carefree 16-year-old who responds to her mother‰Ûªs decision to live as a man by embarking on her own metamorphosis, videotaping herself and two school friends in exploratory make-out sessions. A circus performer in real life, Ms. Cobham-Hervey never fully conveys Billie‰Ûªs fluctuating feelings, and the decision to prioritize her experience over that of her mother ‰ÛÓ now called James ‰ÛÓ is to the detriment of the film. (As are the director‰Ûªs too-pointed signifiers of gender nonconformity.)

The gaudy excesses of the annual Eurovision contest have inspired filmmakers before (Farah Khan‰Ûªs 2014 Bollywood extravaganza, ‰ÛÏHappy New Year,‰Ûù comes to mind), but rarely have they been employed as sure-footedly as in Eytan Fox‰Ûªs dramedy ‰ÛÏCupcakes.‰Ûù This candy-coated confection is so irresistible that you‰Ûªre captivated by its sentiment even as you acknowledge its manipulations.

Five women in Tel Aviv ‰ÛÓ a mother and bakery owner (Anat Waxman); a lonely, introverted blogger (Keren Berger); a struggling musician (Efrat Dor); a former beauty queen (Yael Bar-Zohar); and a cabinet minister‰Ûªs overworked assistant (Dana Ivgy) ‰ÛÓ and a gay nursery-school teacher (Ofer Shechter) stuck with a closeted boyfriend assemble every year to watch the UniverSong contest on TV. When they spontaneously record a tune sympathizing with the marital misfortunes of Ms. Waxman‰Ûªs character, that cellphone video finds its way to the contest‰Ûªs judges, and the group is off to Paris for the big competition.

In addition to the skilled cast, Arad Sawat‰Ûªs production design is awash in playful purples and pinks. Throw in a soundtrack offering an infectious ditty composed by Scissor Sisters and 1970s pop-cheese classics (‰ÛÏLove Will Keep Us Together‰Ûù; a rendition of ‰ÛÏYou Light Up My Life‰Ûù) and affirmations about heeding your aspirations, and the elements coalesce into a thoughtful yet bubbly cocktail. And one not blind to political realities: ‰ÛÏI think this is a fascinating human blend that reflects a varied, fresh take on modern Israel,‰Ûù a publicist says to the group. ‰ÛÏToo bad we don‰Ûªt have an Arab.‰Ûù

The film includes other stories of heroism. We learn of a doctor who shielded Jews in a hospital ward by claiming they had a nonexistent illness, and of nuns and monks who provided protection. Survivors and their descendants revisit their hiding places and reunite with the families of those who sheltered them.

The movie periodically returns to the deeds of Gino Bartali (given a voice-over by the actor Robert Loggia), a Tour de France champion regarded as an inspiration by the Fascist government. As his son Andrea explains, Mr. Bartali also secretly helped to save lives by transporting fake identification papers in his bicycle frame.

Yet the director, Oren Jacoby, who made the Oscar-nominated short ‰ÛÏSister Rose‰Ûªs Passion‰Ûù and the feature ‰ÛÏConstantine‰Ûªs Sword,‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt give ‰ÛÏMy Italian Secret‰Ûù much structural or chronological organization. The anecdotal presentation sometimes seems more suited for museum browsing than for viewing in a theater.

Narrated by Isabella Rossellini, the movie unfolds in a somewhat standard testimonial documentary format, mixing old photographs, re-enactments and a heavy-handed soundtrack. It provides a reasonable primer on Italy‰Ûªs complicated history with the Holocaust and the Italian resistance. Maps illustrate geographic complexities; subjects speak of identity and assimilation.

‰ÛÏMy Italian Secret: The Forgotten Heroes‰Ûù compiles the stories of Jews who lived or sought refuge in Italy during World War II and the gentiles who helped them, particularly after German troops occupied the northern half of the country in 1943.
Nightlight is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for profanity and talk about sex.

The movie‰Ûªs title suggests the movie‰Ûªs principal visual motif: The concentric circles cast by flashlights appear in almost every shot, an approach that grows wearisome. Familiar items in the horror tool chest ‰ÛÓ distant noises; snakes; creaking stairs; dank interiors; a barking, sometimes whimpering dog; inverted crosses ‰ÛÓ parade by, with breathless play-by-play coming from Ms. Young, who, with Mr. Fain, ably performs most of the emotional heavy lifting. The rest of the actors barely have distinct roles, Ms. Murphy‰Ûªs being the most cruelly underwritten. ‰ÛÏWhen does this end?‰Ûù a terrified Robin asks. It‰Ûªs a valid question.

Into the pantheon of found-footage horror cinema comes ‰ÛÏNightlight,‰Ûù a spare trifle carried largely by its leading actress. The film begins with a videotaped message from the teenage Ethan (an affecting Kyle Fain) to his parents, talking about his struggles with suicide and his hopes to see Robin (Shelby Young) at a dance. Cut to weeks later, and Robin is joining Nia (Chloe Bridges), Ben (Mitch Hewer), Amelia (Taylor Murphy) and Chris (Carter Jenkins) for a night of fun and games in a forest enclosed by barbed wire.

A variation on hide-and-seek is played, with blindfolds and counting and searching for friends in the dark. Cue encounters with a malevolent spirit. These woods, it seems, have a history of ensnaring teenagers; Ethan took his own life within them.

The story is the standard allegory of an innocent golden boy tempted by the devil and handed a ringside seat to a circle of hell. Before induction, Miles acquires a ‰ÛÏbootstrappy‰Ûù Welsh girlfriend, Lauren (Holliday Grainger). ‰ÛÏBeing at Oxford is like being invited to a hundred parties all at once, and I want to go to all of them,‰Ûù he gushes.

Not all Riot Club members are British blue bloods. Dimitri (Ben Schnetzer), scion of a Greek shipping family, may be filthy rich, but the others never cease reminding him that being Greek, he is not really one of them. The others are more of a blur, although the sour, dyspeptic Alistair (Sam Claflin), a first-year student whose older brother was a member, stands out.

Lone Scherfig (‰ÛÏAn Education‰Ûù), the Danish filmmaker who directed the movie from a screenplay by Ms. Wade, has coaxed wonderfully nasty performances from a young cast led by Max Irons (son of Jeremy), whose character, Miles, is a handsome first-year student dazzled by the club‰Ûªs mystique. Seeking to join the invitation-only organization, he attracts the sponsorship of the suave, supercilious Hugo (Sam Reid), a gay senior member who describes himself as descended from ‰ÛÏthe ragged end of the gentry.‰Ûù

Why such excess? As one member of this group, the Riot Club, explains in dulcet Oxonian cadences, ‰ÛÏIt is the last time we get to disport ourselves without everybody watching,‰Ûù since many of the members will one day occupy ‰ÛÏvery important desks‰Ûù in politics and business.

Enter the serpent. It isn‰Ûªt very long before Miles, as part of his initiation, finds his room trashed and is blindfolded and forced to drink a cup of wine that contains wriggly bugs, spittle and a cigarette butt. He takes it in stride.

‰ÛÏThe Riot Club,‰Ûù a poisonous satire of Britain‰Ûªs upper class, adapted from Laura Wade‰Ûªs play ‰ÛÏPosh,‰Ûù may puncture any lingering fantasies that good breeding is synonymous with noblesse oblige. The small group of rich young men on whom it focuses belong to an Oxford University dining club that has a fabled history of drunken mischief making. As they exercise their privilege at the club‰Ûªs annual bacchanal, an alternate title for the movie comes to mind: ‰ÛÏBoozing and Vomiting.‰Ûù

Their attitude when they lose control recalls the reports of a meltdown by the 20-year-old Conrad Hilton III aboard a recent British Airways flight. According to witnesses, he denounced members of the crew and his fellow passengers using the dreaded p-word (‰ÛÏpeasants‰Ûù). For the majority of us who can‰Ûªt afford to buy ourselves out of a mess, the movie delivers a crude warning: The loathing and contempt by the entitled rich for hoi polloi is far more dangerous than we imagined.

The core of the movie is the club‰Ûªs celebratory annual dinner in the banquet room of a rural pub. The boys tear into a ‰ÛÏ10-bird chicken‰Ûù (a fowl stuffed with other fowl) and consume gallons of booze and wine as rowdiness and chaos take over and the party devolves into a scary Dionysian free-for-all that curdles into collective rage. Women, including a reluctant escort hired to service the boys, and finally Lauren, who appears unexpectedly, enter the banquet room at their peril.

When they‰Ûªre in their cups, these upper-class twits devoted to ‰ÛÏdebauchery raised to an art form ‰ÛÓ an almost spiritual release,‰Ûù in the words of one, also carry snobbery and class hatred to savage extremes. The official response to their misbehavior and the damage it causes seems to be a weary, ‰ÛÏOh well, boys will be boys,‰Ûù accompanied if necessary, by the writing of checks and the assurance, ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªll pay for it.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe Riot Club‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For language, disturbing and violent behavior, sexual content, nudity and drug use.

An ensuing brawl is both a horror show and a guilty pleasure you can‰Ûªt take your eyes off of. Once it‰Ûªs over, ‰ÛÏThe Riot Club‰Ûù tries to stir up drama surrounding the aftermath. By this point, I was drained and quivering with fury and disgust.

But is it? Reading up on the Bullingdon Club, on which the fictional Riot Club is loosely based (the British prime minister, David Cameron, was a member), the cruelty fictionalized in the movie wasn‰Ûªt as hateful as the film suggests, and the group didn‰Ûªt assault a pub owner; the members turned against one another.

Mr. Baumbach, who is 45, does not pretend to be neutral, and neither can I. ‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young‰Ûù opens with some darkly funny lines from Henrik Ibsen‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Master Builder‰Ûù that show the hostility directed against the rising generation by the middle-aged to be very old news. Of course it is. How could we not be terrified and resentful? Their evolutionary job is to correct our mistakes, to ignore our hard-won wisdom and to replace us, whether or not we‰Ûªre ready. They need less sleep and look better in their clothes, and they‰Ûªre so damn confident. Don‰Ûªt get me started.

Or maybe not quite. I have some problems with this movie, not all of which can be ascribed to the usual narcissism of small differences. But first it‰Ûªs important to acknowledge the acuity of Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs insight and his overall generosity of spirit. Generosity, as it happens, is the film‰Ûªs key ethical principle. It‰Ûªs the quality Josh most admires in Jamie and Darby and finds most lacking in himself. A documentary filmmaker who has spent most of a decade working on a sprawling, incomplete project on ‰ÛÏpower in America,‰Ûù Josh marvels at his young friends‰Ûª apparent indifference to success, at their open, eager embrace of experience. He and Cornelia seem crabbed and cautious by comparison.

Of course. And this film, Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs movie, mostly brings a light touch and a forgiving gloss to its own self-consciousness. It is not afraid to be implicated in the confusion ‰ÛÓ in the self-involvement, the anxiety, the pettiness ‰ÛÓ it depicts. But there are also areas where it feels soft and compromised, where the subtlety and clarity of Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs vision seem to desert him. The last section, while it has a few fine, farcical moments, goes astray in trying to recapture flagging comic momentum and slides toward chaotic Greenbergian hostility. The inevitable complications in what had seemed to be a perfect friendship are not quite credible, and the movie seems uncertain how to handle them.

Ambition in this movie, as in Judd Apatow‰Ûªs somewhat similar ‰ÛÏThis Is 40,‰Ûù is a guy thing. Men make movies. Women make ice cream or babies, or help the men make their movies. The frustrations and identity crises that plague poor Josh ‰ÛÓ his rivalries with older and younger men, his failure to live up to his early promise ‰ÛÓ are large and central. Whatever analogous problems Cornelia might have are circumscribed and peripheral, and exist entirely in terms of her relationships with the men in her life.

Is that wisdom or willful ignorance? Either way, Mr. Baumbach is, as usual, a piquant observer of the manners and morals of the various demographic subsets of the white, urban lower-upper-middle class. He is without peer among screenwriters as a composer of incisive, non-punchline-driven comic dialogue, and unrivaled among directors as a choreographer of fraught social encounters.

If you‰Ûªve seen Noah Baumbach‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGreenberg‰Ûù you may remember a scene in which the title character, played by Ben Stiller, unleashes a tirade against a roomful of 20-year-olds whom he believes have been ruined by sensitive parenting, among other things. (If you haven‰Ûªt seen ‰ÛÏGreenberg,‰Ûù we need to talk). ‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young,‰Ûù Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs buoyant, vinegar-laced new film, is not a sequel ‰ÛÓ Mr. Stiller plays Josh, a reasonably pleasant and well-adjusted guy for a Ben Stiller character in a Noah Baumbach picture ‰ÛÓ but it does pick up where the earlier movie left off in its exploration of the fraught relations between ascendant millennials and the rapidly aging members of Generation X.

Besotted with their new companions, Josh and Cornelia neglect their old friends Fletcher (Adam Horovitz) and Marina (Maria Dizzia), who seem preoccupied with their new baby. Josh and Cornelia, who decided not to have children after a series of miscarriages, seem to have more in common with Jamie and Darby in any case. And also more to learn from them. These youngsters take an impressive interest in the past: They collect vinyl records, VHS cassettes and manual typewriters, and have a healthy ability to take or leave the latest technology. When no one can remember the word ‰ÛÏmarzipan,‰Ûù Josh pulls out his phone to Google it, but Jamie and Darby stop him. ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs just not know,‰Ûù Jamie says.

The most brilliant example of this lies not in the plot or the dÌ©cor but the casting. In addition to Mr. Horovitz ‰ÛÓ some of us know him better as Ad-Rock ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young‰Ûù features Peter Yarrow as a curmudgeonly left-wing intellectual. Think about that: Peter, Paul and Mary and the Beastie Boys represented, however subliminally, in the same movie. If you were born during the Johnson or Nixon administrations and drifted from a progressive nursery school toward a liberal arts college, that‰Ûªs pretty much the story of your life right there.

He is also, like many a child of his era, obsessed with the finer points of pop-cultural taste. ‰ÛÏI remember when this song was just supposed to be bad,‰Ûù Josh marvels when Jamie, with apparent sincerity, plays ‰ÛÏEye of the Tiger‰Ûù for inspiration. Josh‰Ûªs relationship with music and movies is based on sorting and rating, whereas his new bro seems to take everything as equivalent, without regard for categories like high and low, or even good and bad. Josh and Jamie are equally objects of gentle satire (which sharpens as the movie goes on), but Mr. Baumbach also honors both of their sensibilities, compulsively combining and repurposing the detritus of the recent past in the hope that some kind of meaning will emerge from it.

For about two-thirds of its fleet and mostly pleasant running time, however, ‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young‰Ûù presents a sun-dappled vision of intergenerational harmony. Josh and his wife, Cornelia (Naomi Watts), befriend Jamie and Darby, a 25-year-old married couple who open a portal into a new, cool parallel universe. It‰Ûªs still New York, but it‰Ûªs totally different. There are ‰ÛÏstreet beach‰Ûù parties and ayahuasca ceremonies, artisanal restaurants and thrift shops. Cornelia accompanies Darby (Amanda Seyfried) to a hip-hop exercise class. Josh goes bike riding with Jamie (Adam Driver) and buys himself a narrow-brimmed fedora.

At times the movie seems aware of the limitations of its own perspective, and struggles against them. Fletcher is a stay-at-home dad; Darby experiences a feminist awakening, though nobody quite calls it that. But in spite of those moments, and in spite of the happy, good-humored companionship that exists between Josh and Cornelia, Mr. Baumbach never quite grants the women in the movie equal access to their own lives, or to the audience‰Ûªs empathy. His title turns out to be doubly ironic: We‰Ûªre not really young, and we‰Ûªre not really ‰ÛÏwe.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It‰Ûªs just how people of a certain age talk.

There is another generational specter haunting them, Josh in particular. He finds himself squeezed on one side by Jamie, an aspiring documentarian guilelessly seeking a mentor, and on the other by Cornelia‰Ûªs father, Leslie (Charles Grodin), a beloved old lion of the heroic cinÌ©ma vÌ©ritÌ© era. Leslie‰Ûªs name is invoked alongside those of Frederick Wiseman, D. A. Pennebaker and the Maysles brothers, and he stands for an honest, rugged, socially conscious brand of filmmaking that both Jamie and Josh admire. But while Leslie could believe in an ideal of truth in cinema and Jamie can just go out and shoot great stuff, Josh finds himself tangled up in overthinking and qualification. Pitching his unfinished masterpiece to a hedge-fund friend of Jamie‰Ûªs, Josh is unable to say exactly what it‰Ûªs about. It‰Ûªs about so many complicated things, including ‰ÛÏthe very possibility of making this film.‰Ûù

These tonal and procedural fumblings expose a more serious blind spot. Josh, Jamie and Leslie are all vividly drawn and intricately shaded characters, but Darby and Cornelia, in spite of Ms. Seyfried‰Ûªs quickness and Ms. Watts‰Ûªs incomparable emotional range, are blurry and sketchy in comparison. They have a lesser share in the story.

Unblinkingly gory, this evisceration foreshadows other violence to come. It‰Ûªs a tough but critical scene because, while Mr. Mundruczo has a sharp sense of humor, evident especially in his use of horror-movie tropes, ‰ÛÏWhite God‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt a comedy or a Disney-like anthropomorphized romp. The camera gets down on all fours, metaphorically, and shares Hagen‰Ûªs point of view, showing you what the world looks like around our knees. Yet Hagen isn‰Ûªt a wee human in a fuzzy costume; he doesn‰Ûªt have a digital mouth, talk to other animals or share his thoughts. The radicalness of the movie is that it asserts he doesn‰Ûªt need to be like a person for you to be on his side. He is a dog, and that‰Ûªs all he needs to be.

The brutality of the training, which culminates with an ugly fight that‰Ûªs a frenzy of slamming bodies, ominous growls and bloodied muzzles, isn‰Ûªt for the weak of heart. But these scenes represent movie sleight of hand at its finest, as do the sequences of Hagen making like Jason Bourne while escaping pound workers, hurtling down alleys, darting around corners, racing across terraces and even bursting through an apartment window into the lap of its understandably surprised inhabitant. In time, Hagen stops running from his oppressors and instead ‰ÛÓ flanked by a glorious mutt army in a series of soaring, astonishingly choreographed scenes ‰ÛÓ heads straight at the humans who have done him and his friends lethally, morally, wrong. After years of domination, nature is biting back.

The hand that feeds ‰ÛÓ and also brutalizes ‰ÛÓ is righteously bitten in ‰ÛÏWhite God,‰Ûù a Hungarian revenge fantasy that‰Ûªs like nothing you‰Ûªve seen on screen before. The story is as simple as a parable, a campfire story, a children‰Ûªs book: A faithful animal, separated from its loving owner, endures, suffers, struggles and resists while trying to transcend its brutal fate. The director, Kornel Mundruczo, has said that he was partly inspired by J. M. Coetzee‰Ûªs devastating novel ‰ÛÏDisgrace,‰Ûù but the movie also invokes haunting animal classics like ‰ÛÏBlack Beauty‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Call of the Wild.‰Ûù

Like Buck, the four-legged hero of ‰ÛÏThe Call of the Wild,‰Ûù the dog protagonist in ‰ÛÏWhite God,‰Ûù Hagen ‰ÛÓ played with full-bodied expressivity by the canine siblings Bodie and Luke ‰ÛÓ is a mixed breed. For his closest companion, a solemn-faced 13-year-old named Lili (Zsofia Psotta), Hagen‰Ûªs ancestry isn‰Ûªt an issue, but it is one for those state officials who tax dogs that aren‰Ûªt purebreds. Lili‰Ûªs father, Daniel (Sandor Zsoter), who has custody of her for a few months, has no interest in paying the tax or keeping the dog, which is how Hagen ends up on the streets of Budapest, initially alone, then in the hands of a cruel master and then with a pack.

Hagen and Lili are separated not long after moving in with Daniel. Once they‰Ûªre divided, the story divides too, forming parallel narrative tracks. For much of the movie, Mr. Mundruczo switches back and forth between Hagen and Lili as they look for each other, underlining their similarities, friendships, close calls, minor triumphs and anxious, searching, long runs down unfriendly streets. Hagen finds a pal (a scene-nibbling Jack Russell terrier named Marlene); Lili flirts with a boy who plays in her orchestra. Both Hagen and Lili are soon forced on a tight leash. She has to deal with her tyrannical father and a similarly patriarchal orchestra leader; Hagen, meanwhile faces far worse after he‰Ûªs sold by a vagrant first to a dealer (Mr. Mundruczo) and then a vicious trainer (Szabolcs Thuroczy).

That pack in all its barking, panting, tail-wagging glory is the big payoff in ‰ÛÏWhite God,‰Ûù which features 250 or so dogs that were trained for the movie, not a computer-generated pooch among them. Mr. Mundruczo has said that his movie was shot using the American film industry‰Ûªs guidelines on the use of animal performers. That‰Ûªs not entirely reassuring given the abuses that nonetheless occur during productions, as a ghastly 2013 exposÌ© in The Hollywood Reporter affirmed. Still, viewers concerned about the welfare of the dogs, especially in some of the tougher scenes, should pay close attention to the cunning editing and camera angles as well as all those happy tails. Mr. Mundruczo has also produced, smartly, a reassuring behind-the-scenes video that‰Ûªs available on YouTube.

In classic narrative fashion, Mr. Mundruczo works the setup like a burlesque fan dancer, teasing out the reveal bit by bit. He introduces Lili and Hagen together while they‰Ûªre sharing the frame and playing a quietly portentous game of tug-of-war. Lili‰Ûªs mother has gone off on a lengthy trip with her husband, leaving the girl with her father, who Lili demonstrably doesn‰Ûªt much like. Mr. Mundruczo at first seems to share Lili‰Ûªs aversion; at the very least, he knows how to stack the story decks: Daniel isn‰Ûªt just a dour, unsmiling sad sack, he‰Ûªs also a fallen man who now works as a slaughterhouse inspector. You first meet him in an antiseptic room in which, after workers gut and skin a dead cow, he plunges a gauge in the innards, declaring it fit for consumption.

All this won‰Ûªt make viewers out of people who believe that animals should never be used, period. Those who don‰Ûªt care how we treat animals may wonder what any of this has to do with a movie, much less a review. Yet it is our bonds with other animals, our obligations and our sympathies, that make ‰ÛÏWhite God‰Ûù more than a gimmick movie. These are questions, Mr. Mundruczo suggests, that also extend to creatures that we, godlike, designate as meat, not pets, to borrow a formulation from Michael Moore‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRoger & Me.‰Ûù What are nonhuman animals to us? In Mr. Coetzee‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDisgrace,‰Ûù a character who helps out at a shelter in which animals are euthanized says of dogs, ‰ÛÏThey do us the honor of treating us like gods, and we respond by treating them like things.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏWhite God,‰Ûù the dogs respond with their own kill policy.
‰ÛÏWhite God‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Dog-day afternoons, mornings and nights.

One person her character doesn‰Ûªt sleep with is Adam (Adam Mediano), who has just turned 16. (She promises him that she will once he‰Ûªs had a year to ‰ÛÏmaster the clitoris,‰Ûù which may mean that Mr. Clark is planning a sequel.) Not that Adam is condemned to a life of abstinence. This is Marfa ‰ÛÓ this is a Larry Clark movie, at any rate ‰ÛÓ which means that action is easy to find, with his girlfriend, Inez (Mercedes Maxwell), and with a young mother whose husband is conveniently out of town. Adam‰Ûªs pregnant social studies teacher doesn‰Ûªt take him to bed, preferring to spank him with a paddle on dubiously disciplinary grounds.

‰ÛÏMarfa Girl‰Ûù takes place in the West Texas town of the title, a place best known to outsiders as a pilgrimage spot for admirers of the sculptor Donald Judd, whose large pieces are scattered across the surrounding high desert. One of the main characters is an artist (Drake Burnette) with a fellowship at Judd‰Ûªs Chinati Foundation. We don‰Ûªt learn her name or much about her work, and she seems to spend most of her time having sex with local residents or engaging them in awkward conversations about race, culture and, of course, sex. Ms. Burnette, may not have much craft as an actress, but she does have a sense of humor about what she‰Ûªs doing that complements the lack of inhibition that seems to have been the main criterion for getting the job.

The third panel in this naughty triptych of dysfunction and desire belongs to Tom (Jeremy St. James), a Border Patrol agent with a foul mouth and a big crush on Adam‰Ûªs mother. He brings general bad vibes into the easygoing atmosphere of pot-smoking and bed-hopping, and is responsible for the climactic burst of violence and ugliness that belatedly supplies ‰ÛÏMarfa Girl‰Ûù with something like a plot and a flimsy excuse for a point beyond the display of naked bodies and picturesque landscapes.

‰ÛÏMarfa Girl‰Ûù is the latest exploration ‰ÛÓ and exploitation ‰ÛÓ of teenage sexuality from Larry Clark, the photographer and filmmaker who has been splitting the difference between fearless honesty and leering prurience for more than four decades. ‰ÛÏTulsa,‰Ûù the 1971 book of portraits that made his reputation, still has the power to shock and unsettle with its blunt portrayal of drug use and promiscuity among the provincial American young. But the scandal of Mr. Clark‰Ûªs more recent movies, including ‰ÛÏWassup Rockers‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏKen Park‰Ûù and this new one, resides more in its tedium and lack of insight than its strenuously provocative content.

The two main characters in Dave Boyle‰Ûªs labyrinthine neo-noir, ‰ÛÏMan From Reno,‰Ûù make an oddball pair of sleuths. Aki Akahori (Ayako Fujitani) is a renowned Japanese mystery writer, nicknamed ‰ÛÏthe J. D. Salinger of Japan,‰Ûù hiding out from the paparazzi in San Francisco. Paul Del Moral (Pepe Serna) is the sheriff of the fictional San Marco County, south of the city. The depressed, enigmatic Aki and the grizzled, avuncular Paul don‰Ûªt meet until an hour into the movie, when he knocks on her hotel door while investigating a murder.

Because they met only that night, Aki is of little help. The morning after their rendezvous, Akira vanished, leaving behind his luggage. Examining the contents, one item she finds is a head of lettuce. Being a mystery writer, her curiosity is piqued.

These disappearances initially seem unrelated. But Paul‰Ûªs investigation leads him to San Francisco, and he and Aki encounter a world of smugglers with multiple identities, mobsters, drawers filled with passports and a priceless shipment of rare turtles stored in a toilet tank in Aki‰Ûªs hotel room.

Paul is on the trail of another disappearance. In the movie‰Ûªs opening scene, while driving through a thick fog, he notices an abandoned vehicle, but before he is able to stop to inspect it the driver accidentally stumbles into his path. The victim survives the collision and is taken to a hospital but flees, leaving behind his clothes.

Aki, who has every reason to be wary, is understandably reluctant to let him in, having abruptly left a book tour in a state of nervous exhaustion. Ever since her one-night stand with a dashing charmer calling himself Akira Suzuki (Kazuki Kitamura), whom she met in the hotel bar, she has been pestered by ominous, inquisitive strangers looking for Akira or someone impersonating him.

The film by Mr. Boyle, who also directed ‰ÛÏDaylight Savings‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSurrogate Valentine,‰Ûù has an undercurrent of dark comedy. The mere existence of those turtles, who turn out to be pet shop substitutes for smuggled reptiles, is a joke in itself. In one scene, the ever-paranoid Aki, while pressing her ear against a hotel wall to overhear a conversation, notices a hand reaching through the doorway of her chain-locked suite, rushes to slam the door on it and produces a howl of pain.

‰ÛÏMan From Reno,‰Ûù which nods to noirs from ‰ÛÏChinatown‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏVertigo,‰Ûù neither of which it matches in stylistic elegance, self-consciously deploys the cinematic tricks of the noir trade, from camera angles to shadows. But it refrains from emotionally drawing you into its impenetrable scheme. Once Aki begins assisting Paul, you expect a jovial camaraderie to develop between them, but it doesn‰Ûªt. Even so, ‰ÛÏMan From Reno‰Ûù fascinates. It invites you to go back, decipher its clues and discern a grand design, if there is one.

‰ÛÏMan From Reno‰Ûù belongs to the subgenre of noirs that gather new characters and subplots as they advance into the fog. You can never be sure if its Japanese characters are who they say they are, and many of the principals‰Ûª uncertain identities, compounded by the English-Japanese language barrier, lend ‰ÛÏMan From Reno‰Ûù an extra layer of mystery. As in a Patricia Highsmith novel, deception rules. Aki herself has a history of secrecy and duplicity, her first mystery novel having been written by someone else who died before it was published.
‰ÛÏThe Barber‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), because being buried alive is terrifying.

Scott Glenn handles the balancing act required of him in ‰ÛÏThe Barber‰Ûù with his usual skill, playing a guy who might be just a harmless haircutter or might be a serial murderer with a habit of burying young women alive. The film, though, delivers its plot twists muddily and doesn‰Ûªt really distinguish itself from the countless other creepy-killer tales out there.

Chris Coy plays John, the son of a Chicago police officer who years earlier thought he had a suspect in a string of ugly murders but couldn‰Ûªt make the charges stick. Now John takes up the case, materializing in a small town where a harmless-seeming fellow named Eugene (Mr. Glenn) has been living invisibly for years.

John thinks Eugene is the man his father was pursuing, and he worms his way into the old man‰Ûªs life by asking him for lessons on how to murder. Several guessing games ensue. Is Eugene who John thinks he is? Does John perhaps really want to become a serial killer? It‰Ûªs moderately intriguing, but John‰Ûªs noisy pursuit is less than credible, and the film‰Ûªs revelations could be clearer. Mr. Glenn‰Ûªs performance is the main attraction, though you may never look at your barber or stylist the same way again.

An off-kilter look at friendship and generosity, ‰ÛÏHenry Fool‰Ûù got a very different kind of sequel, the espionage-film parody ‰ÛÏFay Grim‰Ûù (2007), in which Henry‰Ûªs wife, Fay (Parker Posey), learns that Henry has secretly been involved in various international intrigues. Now the trilogy concludes with the Kickstarter-backed ‰ÛÏNed Rifle.‰Ûù If the new film looks and sounds much cheaper than Mr. Hartley‰Ûªs earlier work, the writer and director‰Ûªs wit remains intact.

Since the last movie, Fay has been imprisoned for treason. Her son, Ned (Liam Aiken), has found religion while in witness protection. Leaving after his 18th birthday, he announces a plan to kill Henry, his father. ‰ÛÏI was going to say, ‰Û÷Go in peace,‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù says the dismayed minister (Martin Donovan) who helped raise the boy.

‰ÛÏNed Rifle‰Ûù is unabashedly a fans‰Ûª movie. Its jokes assume fluency with ‰ÛÏHenry Fool,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFay Grim‰Ûù and even early details from Mr. Hartley‰Ûªs films. (The name Ned Rifle has appeared throughout his career, often as a credit for the lilting scores he composes.) But even if this minor coda plays to an increasingly closed circle of admirers, it gives the trilogy a pleasing, moving symmetry.

Hal Hartley is no longer as dominant a figure in independent cinema as he was in the 1990s, when his deadpan humor was a mainstay in art-house theaters. His magnum opus remains ‰ÛÏHenry Fool‰Ûù (1998), whose title character (Thomas Jay Ryan), a rogue with a criminal past, inspires Simon Grim (James Urbaniak), a garbage man in Woodside, Queens, to write poetry. As a poet, Simon finds worldwide success.

Ned‰Ûªs odyssey reunites him with Simon, still wearing his garbage collector‰Ûªs uniform as a Nobel laureate and now aspiring comedian. He also encounters Susan (Aubrey Plaza, whose sourness complements Mr. Hartley‰Ûªs pseudo-academic dialogue), who has written a thesis on Simon‰Ûªs poetry.
Maria changes and softens as the story advances. In Vienna, she is bombarded with memories of her childhood and the 1938 Anschluss, the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany.

The film‰Ûªs most gripping scenes are flashbacks portraying the Nazis‰Ûª triumphant entrance into Vienna, where welcoming throngs line the streets. One especially upsetting scene shows Jews forced to scrub sidewalks to the delight of contemptuous onlookers. As unsettling as they are, such moments in a dramatically undernourished film make the viewer acutely aware of being emotionally manipulated. When the young Maria (Tatiana Maslany) flees Vienna, her parents‰Ûª final words, ‰ÛÏremember us,‰Ûù strike a tone of mawkish nobility that characterize the heavy-handedness of the screenplay and of the score, by Martin Phipps and Hans Zimmer.

In this drama based on real life, the artwork, Gustav Klimt‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPortrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I,‰Ûù is a regal painting encrusted with gold leaf of Maria‰Ûªs beloved Aunt Adele. Many consider it the Mona Lisa of Austria, and to some Austrians, keeping this magnificent work in the country is a matter of national honor.

The story begins with the death of Maria‰Ûªs sister, in whose belongings are records of her unsuccessful effort to recover five Klimt paintings displayed in the Belvedere in Vienna. Maria engages Randy Schoenberg (Ryan Reynolds), grandson of the composer Arnold Schoenberg and an inexperienced young lawyer, who persuades her to accompany him to Vienna, a city to which she vowed she would never return after fleeing the Nazis.

As directed by Simon Curtis (‰ÛÏMy Week With Marilyn‰Ûù) from a screenplay by Alexi Kaye Campbell, ‰ÛÏWoman in Gold‰Ûù turns a complicated story with many debatable questions about artistic provenance and ownership into a standard historical drama about good guys versus bad guys.

‰ÛÏWoman in Gold‰Ûù rests heavily on the squared shoulders of Helen Mirren, whose character, Maria Altmann, is a proud, elderly Austrian Jewish woman who fled the Nazi scourge to settle in California. Reawakened to the past by the death of her sister, at whose 1998 funeral she is first observed, Maria wages a protracted legal battle to regain possession of a priceless canvas stolen from her family by the Nazis 60 years earlier.

Although Maria lives modestly, as embodied by Ms. Mirren, she is a woman of enormous cultural refinement and as formidable a personage in her way as Ms. Mirren‰Ûªs sometime stage and screen alter ego, Queen Elizabeth II. Assuming a clipped Viennese accent and maintaining a rigid posture, she exudes a keen-eyed patrician composure.

The bad guys are modern-day Austrians, portrayed as cold, arrogant enemies of truth and justice. Their legal battle to keep the work in Austria is subtly used as evidence of a residual nostalgia for the Nazi occupation, tinged with anti-Semitism, although none is voiced outright. The good guys are Holocaust refugees and their American descendants, who take Maria‰Ûªs case all the way to the United States Supreme Court.

The casting of Mr. Reynolds as Randy is especially unfortunate. Playing a lawyer, this Hollywood lightweight, given glasses to make him look serious, delivers a bland, colorless performance. As Randy‰Ûªs deepening involvement in the case becomes an obsession, causing him to quit his job and devote everything to Maria‰Ûªs cause, Mr. Reynolds works hard and even breaks down in tears, but his performance is shallow and unconvincing.
It remains for Ms. Mirren to salvage a film that without her would be a laborious slog down a well-trodden path.

A legal fight over the struggle for ownership of an artwork is hardly the stuff of high drama. And the screenplay can‰Ûªt find a way to make that conflict, or the ethical and moral issues involved, compelling beyond the obvious guessing game of who will win.

Ms. Mirren‰Ûªs portrayal of this sometimes fearsome woman who doesn‰Ûªt suffer fools is ultimately sympathetic; her chilly reserve and aristocratic manners camouflage a reservoir of feeling. Her dry-eyed performance is the more impressive because the role could so easily have been milked for weepy sentimentality. For apart from Ms. Mirren‰Ûªs performance, ‰ÛÏWoman in Gold‰Ûù smugly and shamelessly pushes familiar buttons.
‰ÛÏWoman in Gold‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some disturbing thematic elements and brief strong language.

Maria‰Ûªs ambivalence about continuing to pursue what sometimes seems to be a hopeless quest is the dramatic core of the film. Once she and Randy arrive in Vienna, the paperwork concerning the painting‰Ûªs history is withheld from them. Only with the help of a local journalist (Daniel BrÌ_hl) can they penetrate the wall of secrecy and evasion and learn that the painting, commissioned by Adele‰Ûªs husband, and later acquired by the Belvedere‰Ûªs duplicitous curator, belonged not to Adele, but to her husband, who willed it to his heirs.

The dream of the big city, with its bright lights and seductions, is irresistible, yet even Gene Kelly winked at the fantasy in ‰ÛÏSingin‰Ûª in the Rain‰Ûù with his character of the wide-eyed young Broadway hoofer. Brian isn‰Ûªt all singing, all dancing, but rather an all pecking struggling novelist (a calling perfumed with its own romance), who papers his Manhattan apartment with copious rejection letters ‰ÛÓ real ones! The letters speak both to an earlier, more robust publishing age and to Mr. Levin‰Ûªs nostalgia: The prominently featured New Yorker, for instance, has been emailing rejections since at least 2008. The image of Brian scrolling through his emails, though, wouldn‰Ûªt jibe with the dewy romanticism that clings to this movie, softening every edge and attenuating its bids at emotional honesty.

The city doesn‰Ûªt need to be real in a romantic movie, but the feelings must be. Although Mr. Levin tends to embrace clichÌ©s and overstatement (Brian‰Ûªs parents, Arlene and Sam, played by Glenn Close and Frank Langella, are straight out of Yiddish vaudeville), he can also surprise you with delicate touches, a pained look, a wince of recognition. Together he and Mr. Yelchin manage to occasionally tap into something true, including in some scenes with Olivia Thirlby that hint at a movie that might have been. Ms. Thirlby plays Jane, a striver who works in publishing who‰Ûªs also having an affair with Arielle‰Ûªs husband, ValÌ©ry (Lambert Wilson). As her name suggests, Jane isn‰Ûªt as exotic as Arielle, but Ms. Thirlby easily makes the case that beautiful reality trumps dream girl any day.

Set in the indeterminate, immediate past, before smart devices became our greatest objects of desire, ‰ÛÏ5 to 7‰Ûù takes place in a New York that looks, sounds and feels like a borrowed memory. Some of that memory may have originated with the writer and director Victor Levin, but the characters, their actions and exchanges are so familiar that they can‰Ûªt help but feel secondhand. Woody Allen‰Ûªs New York romances (‰ÛÏManhattan,‰Ûù included) are the most obvious touchstone here, as is sometimes the case with films that take on love in the city. Mr. Levin, a television veteran making his feature directing debut, doesn‰Ûªt so much quote directly from Mr. Allen; rather, like Nora Ephron in ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªve Got Mail,‰Ûù he turns the city into a glittering backdrop as drained of authenticity as a studio backlot.
‰ÛÏ5 to 7‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sexy French people.

Thus starts an affair if not to remember then at least to try to understand as Brian and Arielle walk and talk, laugh and flirt, pausing every so often for a discreet interlude beneath the St. Regis‰Ûªs crisply laundered sheets. As days stretch into weeks, life sneaks into the bubble ‰ÛÓ family intrudes, somewhat ‰ÛÓ and these two attractive characters grow at once more intimate and unpersuasive. Casting is one reason, because while Mr. Yelchin does a fine job of playing a man discovering new feelings, he largely has to explore Brian‰Ûªs emotional and psychological transformations alone. The opaque, physically stiff Ms. Marlohe doesn‰Ûªt have as much to do with her character as Mr. Yelchin, which may be why she smiles a great deal, revealing little more than some lovely teeth.

Boy meets woman in ‰ÛÏ5 to 7,‰Ûù a New York romance set at the intersection of nostalgia and wishful thinking that takes off near the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street. It‰Ûªs there that Brian (Anton Yelchin) first sees Arielle (BÌ©rÌ©nice Marlohe) across a crowded street, smoking outside the St. Regis Hotel. He heads straight toward her, lights up his own cigarette and somehow charms her enough so that the two are soon sharing laughs. He‰Ûªs 24, single and American; she‰Ûªs 33, married and French. It‰Ûªs chemistry at first blush and, because neither character works for a pay check, they run off to begin the 5 to 7 p.m. assignations that give the movie its title.

Bursting with sound but devoid of intelligible dialogue, ‰ÛÏCheatin‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù chronicles a couple, Jake and Ella, from first meeting to marital crisis. The opening sequence, which in some ways the movie never tops, follows Ella through a crowded carnival. Her lissome gait and bright yellow hat attract admiring attention that turns to mockery and hostility when she ignores it, preferring to read a book. Ella‰Ûªs humiliation is one of the film‰Ûªs motifs. She is a blameless soul brought down repeatedly by the reflexive aggression of others.

She has eyes only for her husband, who is drawn with a massive rib cage, a skeletal waist and a face like a Brancusi sculpture. Plenty of other women like his looks too, though, including an exhibitionist neighbor and a slinky-hipped customer. He ignores them all, until ...

But see for yourself. After a graceful, wonderfully simple beginning, the story grows a bit tangled. There are a retired stage magician, a killer for hire, a series of sordid encounters in a motel room, an incriminating photograph, a wayward chicken. There is also a rawness and intensity of emotion unusual in a cartoon. The music (an urgent, passionate score by Nicole Renaud, supplemented by snippets of Verdi, Ravel and others) creates a sustained melodramatic swoon that is enhanced rather than undermined by the exaggerated designs.

‰ÛÏCheatin,‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù the latest feature from the feverishly crosshatched imagination of the animator Bill Plympton, is a pulpy, sex-addled opera rendered in fleet penciled lines and watercolor washes. Mr. Plympton‰Ûªs unmistakable style ‰ÛÓ the scrunched-up faces and elongated bodies, the figures that mutate as well as move, the volatile blending of the sensual and the grotesque ‰ÛÓ is pressed into the service of a lurid, lusty story that takes place in a colorful film-noir dreamscape.

As always with Mr. Plympton, the plot serves as a scaffolding for the visual inventions. Like every other great animator, from Chuck Jones to Hayao Miyazaki, Mr. Plympton rewrites the laws of physics at will, but within a rigorous and coherent logic. He conjures a world of absolute improbability that, somehow, makes perfect sense.

At first these others are mostly men, the exception being Jake. While on a date with someone else, he rescues Ella from a bumper-car mishap, and at first touch both are smitten. There follows a period of hot-and-heavy marital bliss (the soundtrack fills with moans and sighs and creaking bedsprings) and an old-fashioned household arrangement. Jake goes off to work at a gas station, while Ella stays home with the laundry, the dishes and her libido.
‰ÛÏCut Bank‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and language.

Cut Bank is a small Montana town of around 3,000 residents that welcomes visitors with an oversize plaster penguin announcing it is the coldest spot in the United States.
