‰ÛÏHave you ever wondered about the person you should have been?‰Ûù Floyd, who recently turned 30, says during one of the myriad interior monologues he delivers while driving back and forth on weekends to an unidentified city, two hours from his current home.

His plan is to reinvent himself by experiencing his old hometown from other angles ‰ÛÓ hanging out in bars different from the ones he used to frequent; evading his parents and his sister, who live nearby; and sleeping with prostitutes rather than pursuing a relationship with any of the willing women he meets while drinking.

Still, the fragmented and existential atmosphere, reminiscent of a Paul Auster novel, is an interesting reward for sticking with the tale. Edward Deraney, as Floyd, is credible enough as a man vexed by the path his life is taking. His frustration is neatly summed up at the end: ‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs no way to ever fully break from your family and your past,‰Ûù he says in a voice-over, then adds, ‰ÛÏBut that doesn‰Ûªt mean you shouldn‰Ûªt.‰Ûù
The idea is a bit better than the execution of ‰ÛÏReset,‰Ûù an opaque and offbeat story of a man who repeatedly returns to his hometown with the intention of avoiding anyone he once knew.

Written and directed by Paul Bojack, ‰ÛÏReset‰Ûù is primarily a collection of side stories and elliptical sketches broken up by chapter titles and sporadic bursts of anxiety and humor. There‰Ûªs no overriding plot here, and there‰Ûªs so much talk on cellphones that the devices should get top billing for all the time they spend onscreen.
‰ÛÏThe Living‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and profanity.

As Teddy, the husband who wakes one morning with a blinding hangover, blood on his hands and a missing wedding ring, Fran Kranz (‰ÛÏThe Cabin in the Woods‰Ûù) projects moist-eyed contrition but not the interior violence that erupts when he is soused. As Teddy‰Ûªs wife, Molly, Jocelin Donahue fails to adequately suggest the terror and anger to be expected in light of her character‰Ûªs torment. (Similarly, Ms. Donahue‰Ûªs makeup, for all its bruises and scars, seems like a sanitized approximation of domestic brutality‰Ûªs aftermath.) And though we are not given a back story to Teddy and Molly‰Ûªs fight, Molly‰Ûªs eventual forgiveness of Teddy does not feel earned.
The emotional dynamics in domestic violence, for the abuser and the abused, are often too disturbing and complex to be treated as superficially as ‰ÛÏThe Living‰Ûù does.

The neo-noir ‰ÛÏThe Living,‰Ûù while bearing an impressive sheen for its modest budget, sells short its own potential. The story of a working-class man in rural Pennsylvania who in a drunken fever physically abuses his wife one night ‰ÛÓ setting into motion events involving a hit man hired by the wife‰Ûªs brother to avenge her injuries ‰ÛÓ flirts with a loaded topic but settles for mere genre exercise.
At least Chris Mulkey, as a homicidal sociopath, and Kenny Wormald, as Molly‰Ûªs timid, self-hating brother, find many nuances to explore in the fraught relationship between their characters.

Soon a mania grips the town, fueled by rumors of sexual abuse and satanic rituals. Rational voices are ignored and personal vendettas come into play, leading to a conclusion that twists as it reveals bits of scenes that had been withheld.

The plot begins at a high school in Kingston, N.Y., where three students, Mary (Georgie Henley), Catherine (Willa Cuthrell) and Lavinia (Olivia De Jonge), form an invitation-only clique that meets in the woods after dark.

Early on, ‰ÛÏThe Sisterhood of Night‰Ûù feels so familiar that it‰Ûªs quite a feat when the film turns out to be this tense. Even with sections recalling both ‰ÛÏThe Crucible‰Ûù and an ‰ÛÏAfterschool Special,‰Ûù it still fashions a story that‰Ûªs fairly fresh and often absorbing.
‰ÛÏThe Sisterhood of Night‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). These teenagers test out adult-size issues, including sex and suicide.

Emily (Kara Hayward), a classmate, is denied membership, and her jealousy, combined with questions about the group ‰ÛÓ What exactly are those girls doing when they go into the forest? ‰ÛÓ incite gossip that spreads with a vengeance when social media and cellphone photos are added to the mix.

Though the script, by Marilyn Fu from a story by Steven Millhauser, might have benefited by closing on a darker note (one sadly beautiful late scene with Ms. Cuthrell seems ideal for that), ‰ÛÏThe Sisterhood of Night‰Ûù remains a considerably taut tale. Yes, you‰Ûªve seen some of this before. And here, they‰Ûªve made it worth seeing again.

Caryn Waechter, the director, is impressive here in her first feature. She and her young cast practice understatement rather than exaggeration, often choosing sideways glances over screaming matches, and are more effective for it. Kal Penn, as a guidance counselor, supplies the welcome levity.

Another, a patchwork chronicle of a woman (Leann Miller) with four children who wants to be an actress, never quite recovers from an especially clunky scene with her own mother in a car. There‰Ûªs also an idler from New York, played by a professional actor (Elliott Ehlers), but he amounts to little more than a wisp of a character.

The best among the film‰Ûªs three alternating strands involves an earnest father (Jamaine Johnson) trying to land a job despite a felony conviction. His interview at a coffee shop shows the disconnect between those truly in need, like him, and his apparently oblivious would-be employers. But there‰Ûªs not much more to the story than these efforts at securing employment and the advice he hears along the way.
Ms. Bradley‰Ûªs debut feature flutters along with inoffensive lyricism and a kindly eye, but it‰Ûªs not enough to bring off a full-fledged portrayal that holds together.

Garrett Bradley‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBelow Dreams‰Ûù hovers around three people in their 20s striving separately in New Orleans. With an impressionistic style and mostly nonprofessional actors, what emerges is a handful of adequate scenes that constitute an assortment of notes toward a film rather than a final draft.

As for ‰ÛÏChild 44‰Ûù: Znot too terrible, but znothing great, either. The movie, running more than two hours and feeling a bit shorter than the Battle of Stalingrad, charges through a hectic, sometimes confusing plot imported from Tom Rob Smith‰Ûªs 2008 novel. Mr. Hardy‰Ûªs character, Leo Demidov, starts out as a gaunt, big-eyed Ukrainian orphan during the famine of 1933 and grows into a sensitive brute ‰ÛÓ into Tom Hardy, in other words ‰ÛÓ in time for the Red Army‰Ûªs liberation of Berlin. Leo‰Ûªs heroism earns him a place in Stalin‰Ûªs secret police force, and by 1953 he is enjoying the perks that come with membership in the Soviet elite. He and his wife, Raisa (Ms. Rapace), are seen at the Moscow opera and in a fancy restaurant, drinking Champagne as the rest of the population quakes in terror.

Meanwhile, a serial killer of boys is on the loose, plying his grisly trade along the country‰Ûªs railroad lines and exploiting the willful blindness of Communist ideology. Since there are, as a matter of precept and policy, no murderers in the workers‰Ûª paradise, his crimes are officially designated accidents, or blamed on scapegoats. Leo and Raisa, exiled to a remote factory town, must simultaneously evade the long reach of Vasili‰Ûªs treachery and try to track down the killer.

That‰Ûªs a big job, and a heavy burden on viewers, who must swallow potato-size lumps of exposition swimming in a visual gravy of browns, grays and muddy tans. It‰Ûªs only when people start punching and stabbing one another that Mr. Espinosa ‰ÛÓ whose earlier films include the action thrillers ‰ÛÏSafe House‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏEasy Money‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ finds any kind of rhythm. Some of the actors are able to locate psychological nuances amid the big murky themes and heavy-handed plot twists. The relationship between Leo and Raisa is the film‰Ûªs only zone of real human complexity, and in a few quiet moments the two of them muster poignant duets of desire, confusion and fear.
‰ÛÏChild 44‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Grim violence and heavy swearing.

‰ÛÏChild 44,‰Ûù directed by Daniel Espinosa from a screenplay by Richard Price, is an English-language movie set in Russia, which means that it is above all a festival of accents. Gary Oldman, Paddy Considine and Vincent Cassel measure their vowels and consonants carefully, but the most floridly enjoyable voices belong to Tom Hardy and Noomi Rapace, last seen together speaking Brooklynese in ‰ÛÏThe Drop.‰Ûù In that film, Mr. Hardy dropped his r‰Ûªs like a champ. Here he lands heavily on the aitches and contracts the words ‰ÛÏit is‰Ûù into the letter Z. ‰ÛÏZimpossible,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏZdifficult.‰Ûù

What ‰ÛÏChild 44‰Ûù most resembles is a rushed and crowded pilot for a television drama. Mr. Smith‰Ûªs book was the first in a series featuring Leo Demidov, and as such functioned as a kind of origin story, establishing the tangled roots and ambiguous temperament of a hard-boiled, tenderhearted Soviet detective. In a ‰ÛÏBack in the U.S.S.R.‰Ûù version of ‰ÛÏCSI‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏCriminal Minds,‰Ûù Mr. Hardy, Ms. Rapace and Mr. Oldman could be pretty cool, accents and all.

Leo and his comrades in the M.G.B. (a precursor to the K.G.B.), some of whom are his old army buddies, are among the primary sources of that terror, but they can just as easily become its targets. To be accused of disloyalty is to be guilty, which means disgrace, torture and death. Leo takes part in the brutality, but he seems more scrupulous than others, trying to spare the life of a suspected traitor (Jason Clarke) and reacting with outrage when a fellow officer summarily executes a peasant couple. That officer, Vasili (Joel Kinnaman), a notorious coward during the war, is Leo‰Ûªs nemesis. Before long the shadow of suspicion falls on Raisa, a teacher, and Leo must decide whether to denounce her or risk his life and those of his adoptive parents by protecting her.

Mr. Caranfil never manages to negotiate the thickets of ambiguity, tragedy and bleak comedy, although the problem may be that someone behind the scenes just didn‰Ûªt see the profit in a no-exit narrative. Mostly, though, by stressing personal tears and woes over the larger political picture, ‰ÛÏCloser to the Moon‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the title comes from a savagely comic suggested punishment ‰ÛÓ downplays how apparatchiks hijacked reality for a carefully staged, serial fiction called the Socialist Republic of Romania that starred Nicolae Ceausescu as the benevolent leader of a cast of smiling, happy millions. In this putative paradise ‰ÛÏthere was no crime and no opposition,‰Ûù as ‰ÛÏThe Great Communist Bank Robbery‰Ûù puts it with memorable, ferocious cool. ‰ÛÏOnly the terror imposed by the government on the people.‰Ûù

Written and directed by Nae Caranfil, ‰ÛÏCloser to the Moon‰Ûù draws on many of the same facts that appear in ‰ÛÏThe Great Communist Bank Robbery,‰Ûù but in the service of a less adventurous movie with familiar Western actors, English-language dialogue and badly strained uplift. In a narrative move that further obscures the interesting if clouded truth, Mr. Caranfil also frames his version with a needless contrivance. In ‰ÛÏCloser,‰Ûù the robbers pull off the heist using a diversionary tactic: They pretend that they‰Ûªre shooting a film. With overblown gestures, they fire up a movie camera and overplay to the audience of ordinary looky-loos, creating a pantomime that will be echoed when, after their arrest, they must recreate the crime in the official propaganda picture.

This history has inspired a couple of documentaries, including one also called ‰ÛÏReconstruction‰Ûù (2001), by Irene Lusztig, whose grandmother, Monica Alfandary Sevianu, and grandmother‰Ûªs husband, Igor Sevianu, were part of the bank-robbing gang. It isn‰Ûªt widely available, but ‰ÛÏThe Great Communist Bank Robbery‰Ûù (2004), by Alexandru Solomon, a smart, bitingly sardonic chronicle of the same incident, can be rented online. It‰Ûªs worth a look because the robbers offer a fascinating entree into crazy Communist Romania and because Mr. Solomon doesn‰Ûªt pretend he knows why they did what they did. Rather, he shuffles through the possible motivations ‰ÛÓ Zionism, despair, nihilism ‰ÛÓ deconstructing an event that from mysterious start to grim finish looked a lot like a suicide mission.

‰ÛÏCloser to the Moon,‰Ûù a fictionalized tale about a weird chapter in Romanian history, tries hard to slap a smiley face on a calamity. In 1959, a group of formerly true-believing Romanian Communists, all Jewish, did the unthinkable when they robbed a branch of the state (and only) bank. They were soon caught, but the story went from curious to crackpot when officials decided that the robbers would portray themselves in a state-produced film titled ‰ÛÏReconstruction,‰Ûù recreating their gangsta roles with secret meetings, gats and getaway cars. Apparently believing that the state might go easier on them if they cooperated, the robbers played along, all the way through the show-trial end.

Like Mr. Solomon, Mr. Caranfil divides ‰ÛÏCloser‰Ûù into chapters, each meant to throw new light on the tale. Vera Farmiga stars as Alice, who not long after the story opens, returns to Bucharest. She soon takes up with her old comrades, including her unhappily married ex-lover, Max (Mark Strong). (Max seems to be a conflation of Mr. Sevianu and another conspirator, Alexandru Ioanid; the crew was nicknamed theIoanid Gang.) Mr. Strong and Ms. Farmiga can be predictably, cartoonishly fun, like a Romanian Boris and Natasha, but even they can‰Ûªt always make clunky dialogue sing or navigate slippery tone shifts without showing the strain, and neither is especially convincing here, whether playing it heavy or light. (Some warring accents and Mr. Strong‰Ûªs two-bit rug do some scene-stealing.)

Yet this tenderly observed love story (by the director, Maxime Giroux) isn‰Ûªt about religion ‰ÛÓ or its lack ‰ÛÓ but about the attraction of difference and the undeniable need to feel alive. That‰Ûªs something that Meira (Hadas Yaron) clearly longs for; chafing against the restrictions imposed by her Orthodox community, and weary of being scolded by her bewildered husband, Shulem (Luzer Twersky), Meira hides her birth-control pills and the phonograph records she plays when alone. She‰Ûªs a time bomb in an unflattering wig and frumpy dresses, and when she meets Felix (Martin Dubreuil), a flirtatious prodigal son who has just lost his father, explosion seems inevitable.

Set in the Mile End district of Montreal, ‰ÛÏFelix and Meira‰Ûù presents the pair‰Ûªs slow, circling courtship as a dance of incremental intimacy. Tiny advances in seduction ‰ÛÓ like a direct gaze, or the eventual removal of that wig ‰ÛÓ assume the power of full-on sexual collisions, and Ms. Yaron, with her restlessly darting eyes, easily conveys Meira‰Ûªs sensual deprivation. Felix‰Ûªs flaky charisma brings color into her world, and it‰Ûªs to the film‰Ûªs credit that Shulem is drawn not as an unfeeling counterpoint but as a loving, observant husband who‰Ûªs simply bemused by his wife‰Ûªs small rebellions.
Unfolding on snowy sidewalks and beneath overcast skies, ‰ÛÏFelix and Meira‰Ûù watches ever so closely as a young Hasidic wife and mother is tempted by the quirky charms of a wayward older man.

In one of the film‰Ûªs most moving scenes, Shulem and Felix reach an uneasy dÌ©tente, a foreshadowing of an ending that ‰ÛÓ like the final scene in Noah Baumbach‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWhile We‰Ûªre Young‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ vibrates with shadowy disquiet. It‰Ûªs that awful moment when ‰ÛÏWe did it!‰Ûù tips over into ‰ÛÏWhat have we done?‰Ûù

The other ‰ÛÏnew‰Ûù film being screened, ‰ÛÏMuddy Track,‰Ûù is a documentary chronicling Mr. Young‰Ûªs 1986-87 European tour with Crazy Horse. Some of Mr. Young‰Ûªs footage can be glimpsed in Jim Jarmusch‰Ûªs 1997 tour documentary ‰ÛÏYear of the Horse,‰Ûù although ‰ÛÏMuddy Track‰Ûù is ragged enough to make that film look like a PBS program.

Throughout his protean music career, Neil Young has tried his hand at filmmaking. The movies of Neil Young, auteur, include the rarely seen ‰ÛÏJourney Through the Past‰Ûù (1974), which Paul Thomas Anderson (‰ÛÏInherent Vice‰Ûù) has cited as an influence, and ‰ÛÏGreendale‰Ûù (2004), an earnest and political rock opera.

The movie‰Ûªs in-jokes are probably of most interest to fans. (Mr. Young told The New York Times that the script was written down after the film was shot.) As self-destructing star vehicles go, it isn‰Ûªt as radical or inventive as Mr. Hopper‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Last Movie‰Ûù from 1971.

‰ÛÏHuman Highway,‰Ûù which Mr. Young made with his co-star Dean Stockwell, is set at a highway gas station and diner shortly before the end of the world. (Given a brief premiere in 1983, it is now being screened as a director‰Ûªs cut.) Mr. Young plays Lionel, a mechanic with big glasses, mouth agape and an unrequited crush. Nuclear-plant operators (members of the band Devo, dressed in radiation suits that glow with ‰ÛÏTron‰Ûù-like auras) bring waste to the town. A radio announces that war looms. The diner‰Ûªs cook (Dennis Hopper) feeds an egg to a raccoon.

Mr. Young shot much of the footage himself. The haphazard visuals are matched by distorted sound. Rain and rioting fans contribute to the chaotic atmosphere. Hotel jam sessions sound far mellower than the concerts. In an interview with a journalist, Mr. Young complains of computerized drumbeats and laments that ‰ÛÏpeople are dancing to machines now.‰Ûù Say this for ‰ÛÏMuddy Track‰Ûù: There‰Ûªs nothing inorganic about this outsize home movie.

Opening on Friday, the IFC Center‰Ûªs Bernard Shakey Film Retrospective: Neil Young on Screen ‰ÛÓ Bernard Shakey is Mr. Young‰Ûªs directorial pseudonym ‰ÛÓ will feature two movies from the 1980s that never received proper runs. Neither is an unearthed classic, but each is a supremely odd artifact that reveals a different aspect of Mr. Young‰Ûªs persona.

Mr. Young‰Ûªs slapdash style, which suggests a Roger Corman movie crossed with dinner theater, extends to the clanking sound effects and flagrantly fake backdrops. The film is also a musical: In a dream sequence, Mr. Young accompanies Devo on ‰ÛÏHey Hey, My My (Into the Black).‰Ûù

Mr. Messina, an actor making his directing debut, tends to soften edges. The movie opens with a whoosh on Alex, an environmental lawyer who has become careless about handing off her family life to her husband, George (Mr. Messina), including the care of their 10-year-old son, Dakota (Skylar Gaertner), and of her father, Roger (Don Johnson). You see the exasperation in George‰Ûªs face before Alex does, so it‰Ûªs not especially surprising when he announces that he‰Ûªs leaving. Much like the runaway wife in ‰ÛÏKramer vs. Kramer,‰Ûù George needs to figure things out, which shocks Alex and forces her, like Dustin Hoffman‰Ûªs Kramer, to learn how to juggle her personal life and her professional commitments, though without the upper-middle-class income and antifeminist finger-wagging.

In standard movie terms little happens. Alex‰Ûªs marriage has fallen apart, but the filmmakers know enough about human beings to know she doesn‰Ûªt have to. Instead, she makes mistakes, works long hours and serves her family takeout pizza for dinner without regret or recrimination. Meanwhile, Roger, a former television star, goes out on an audition and discovers his mortality when he lands a supporting role rather than a lead. The filmmakers (the script was written by Jessica Goldberg, Katie Nehra and Justin Shilton) initially seem to have erred badly by making ‰ÛÏThe Cherry Orchard‰Ûù the framework for Roger‰Ûªs turmoil both onstage and off, but Mr. Johnson‰Ûªs sensitive, lived-in performance, with its layers of vanity and humiliation, makes the best argument for bringing in Chekhov.
‰ÛÏAlex of Venice‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult language). Grown-up talk and recreation.

An appealing portrait miniature of a woman who loses and finds her bearings, ‰ÛÏAlex of Venice‰Ûù takes place against that messy Los Angeles backdrop of beachside attractions and boardwalk crowds, millionaire mansions and homeless encampments known as Venice. That‰Ûªs the neighborhood in which the heroine, Alex (Mary Elizabeth Winstead), grew up and that, with her family, she still calls home. She may not notice the carnival anymore, but the director, Chris Messina, takes time to gently point out some of the more picturesque sites, like the Venice sign that serves as a gateway to the Pacific and the arched walkways that Orson Welles immortalized in ‰ÛÏTouch of Evil.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏAlex of Venice‰Ûù can be skittishly under-ambitious, particularly in respect to its title character. The narrative routinely splits to separately track Roger and Dakota, who nurses his feelings of abandonment while hanging with Alex‰Ûªs adult sister, Lily (Ms. Nehra), a tamed rebel returned to the fold. These scenes dilute Alex‰Ûªs story, and the family dynamics they gesture to are blandly familiar: Roger is a stoner, Lily a former druggie, Alex an unhealthy overachiever. In American movies, it sometimes seems, every unhappy family is unhappy in exactly the same dysfunctional way. What‰Ûªs missing here is the sting of revelation, something less comforting than the story‰Ûªs melodramatic turns and more worthy of Ms. Winstead‰Ûªs performance, which is as natural as life.

The cast also includes Derek Luke as Frank, a developer whom Alex battles in court, only to bed; Jennifer Jason Leigh as Maureen, Alex‰Ûªs prickly, arrogantly crusading boss; and a parade of performers whose faces may be more familiar than their names, among them Reg E. Cathey, Timm Sharp, Matthew Del Negro, Will McCormack and Beth Grant. This lineup can be somewhat distracting (you may find yourself trying to place each actor with a television show) and it‰Ûªs hard not to wonder if the movie was cast by scrolling through someone‰Ûªs iPhone contacts. At the same time, these familiar faces feel welcoming and make the movie seem like a shared effort, as if Mr. Messina had rounded up his friends for a production as modest and sincere as the one Roger appears in onstage.

The movie, a collaboration between marine science and film divisions at Rutgers University, takes a dry, educational-documentary approach to its material. But if talk of sampling krill and phytoplankton populations conjures memories of biology class, ‰ÛÏAntarctic Edge‰Ûù illustrates its points effectively, providing vivid evidence of how shrinking ice at the South Pole affects climates across the globe.

We watch as the scientists explore an area that, according to the film, is the size of Oklahoma. Passing through ice and at times in danger of running aground, their ship travels to Charcot Island, at 70 degrees south latitude. One subject likens the voyage to traveling back in time to a period less affected by global warming.

‰ÛÏAntarctic Edge‰Ûù includes its share of animal footage. The team compiles measurements on the declining population of AdÌ©lie penguins. At one point a seabird crashes into the camera. But the movie also looks at the sheer labor involved in the trip and the difficulty of procuring even a small amount of data. We see the consequences when equipment won‰Ûªt cooperate on the precise schedule required.

There aren‰Ûªt many uncharted areas left on the globe, but ‰ÛÏAntarctic Edge: 70å¡ South‰Ûù takes viewers to a spot where surveying is so scarce that the destinations may diverge from their locations on a map. Exploring that terrain could mean getting caught in ice for a month, as one scientist in the film recounts experiencing.

Why Madec doesn‰Ûªt just do away with Ben when he has the chance is unclear, but when Mr. Douglas is playing this type of snarling, greed-driven ogre, rational decision-making is always in short supply.

Mr. Douglas does his unhinged thing again in ‰ÛÏBeyond the Reach,‰Ûù a sun-baked suspense tale that doesn‰Ûªt add anything to the human-hunts-a-human genre but is effectively served. He plays Madec, a wheeling-and-dealing businessman who takes a hunting excursion to the Mojave Desert. Jeremy Irvine ends up with the world‰Ûªs worst sunburn in the role of Ben, the young guide he hires to help him bag a bighorn for his trophy wall.
‰ÛÏBeyond the Reach‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and sun exposure.

Any wilderness ordeal has to help some character clarify something, and for Ben it‰Ûªs his relationship with his girlfriend (Hanna Mangan-Lawrence), which gives the film a modest side interest. But mostly this one is for fans of desert scenery and of Mr. Douglas in cranky, crazy mode.
How many times can a guy lose his marbles? If the guy is Michael Douglas, apparently as many times as he wants.

Madec is a man in a hurry, in his business dealings and in his hunting, which is why he pulls the trigger too soon, mistaking an old prospector for a sheep. Ben is unwilling to help him cover up the accident and so himself becomes the hunted, with Madec chasing him all over the desert in a monstrous vehicle that looks as if it has the fuel efficiency of a tank.
‰ÛÏThe Dead Lands‰Ûù is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Brutal bloody violence.

These involve toned-up warriors thrashing away with paddlelike weapons in fights that at times respect a certain ceremony of honorable combat and at others turn merely bloodthirsty. Honor and shame are frequently announced concerns in the story, and the staginess recalls Mr. Fraser‰Ûªs experience as a theater director. The action often turns into a hash of glimpses from hand-held cameras, messily cut together; a ubiquitous electronic score pulverizes the setting‰Ûªs mood.

The son, Hongi (James Rolleston), teams up with a legendary lone fighter (Lawrence Makoare) who trains him, while the smugly ruthless leader (Te Kohe Tuhaka) of his family‰Ûªs killers wanders through hallowed lands. Mr. Fraser seems to have directed his cast to declaim their lines as if every moment is a fraught ritual. Spirituality does palpably course through the waking (and dreaming) lives of these characters, but the actors almost seem most comfortable (and convincing) in the combat scenes.

The burdens of tribal responsibility weigh heavily on Toa Fraser‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Dead Lands‰Ûù and its Maori warriors, but, inconveniently, so does some ponderous and cluttered filmmaking. Set deep in New Zealand forests long before colonization and performed in the Maori language, Mr. Fraser‰Ûªs full-dress action drama follows a chieftain‰Ûªs son surviving after his family is slaughtered by merciless enemies.

Some of the stronger moments are the quieter ones: Hongi communing with his dead grandmother against a handmade-looking starry backdrop, or a soliloquy in which the warrior rages helplessly against his inner demons. But as it dives into this infrequently depicted culture, Mr. Fraser‰Ûªs film is caught shuttling uneasily between speeches and action.

Luckily, there‰Ûªs common sense, and the directors, Don Hardy and Dana Nachman, do a fine job convincing us that, even if a tiny amount of a single known carcinogen is considered safe, the cumulative load on our bodies over time is reason for concern. By the time they get to our country‰Ûªs appalling lack of safety regulations ‰ÛÓ and, in particular, the scurrilous lobbying tactics of the chemical industry to forestall new regulation ‰ÛÓ the film has really hit its stride. It may leave many bases uncovered (a section on groundbreaking European legislation is inadequately explained), but it will also leave you looking a lot more closely at what you put on your skin, in your mouth and underneath your sink.

Not long into ‰ÛÏThe Human Experiment,‰Ûù a scary if scientifically lightweight documentary about our daily exposure to thousands of synthetic chemicals, you realize that its main targets are women. Proceeding through breast cancer statistics, cosmetics ingredients and the toxic horrors that lurk in our household cleaners, the movie focuses primarily on the ladies. Even its poster ‰ÛÓ an infant surrounded by cleaning products ‰ÛÓ seems designed to catch a woman‰Ûªs eye.

‰ÛÏBabies are being born all over the world pre-polluted,‰Ûù Sean Penn‰Ûªs creamy narration tells us, joining the men who show up now and then to lend authority to the wealth of moving anecdotal evidence. An infertile environmental health worker with polycystic ovary syndrome; a Latina maid devoted to green products after a painful skin condition; a young woman with an autistic brother ‰ÛÓ all are engaging and informative. None advance proof of a causal link between the chemicals they fear and the alarming rise in certain human ailments.

Tina Fey narrates, wringing every available ounce of treacle out of the script. It‰Ûªs hard to imagine what message children will take away from this film other than that monkeys are just like characters in a fictional Disney movie, which they are not.

The film looks at a troop of toque macaque monkeys in Sri Lanka, and of course it‰Ûªs attractively filmed. But it doesn‰Ûªt convey as much information as it might because it is primarily interested in peddling a girl-power story about one of the monkeys, which it names Maya.
‰ÛÏMonkey Kingdom‰Ûù is rated G (General audiences).

Imposing human motives, emotions and story lines on wild animals is probably never a good idea for a nature documentary, but it‰Ûªs done to especially annoying effect in ‰ÛÏMonkey Kingdom,‰Ûù a new feature from Disneynature aimed at younger children.

The troop is organized in a caste system, and Maya is near the bottom rung of the ladder. But this, we‰Ûªre told, is one monkey who is determined to better her lot in life. A suitor from outside the troop changes her situation substantially, though not before an attack by a rival troop temporarily rousts Maya‰Ûªs group of monkeys from their preferred rock.

Screen time is given to groups like Government Issue, Dag Nasty and Bad Brains, while thoughtful interviewees include Henry Rollins formerly of the band Black Flag and previously a singer in the Dischord band State of Alert; Foo Fighters‰Ûª Dave Grohl, another alumnus of the D.C. demimonde; and Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth.

Yes, Washington is a company town, its labor force often revolving in and out with each presidential administration. But a vigorous underground musical scene has long existed there, and ‰ÛÏSalad Days,‰Ûù an enlightening documentary by the rock journalist Scott Crawford, details its origins.

Anchoring the film is the singer, guitarist and record-label entrepreneur Ian MacKaye, now 53, who fronted the hard-core punk band Minor Threat in the early ‰Ûª80s and later the more tempered but still muscular group Fugazi. With his band mate Jeff Nelson, he also founded the independent label Dischord Records, first housed in Mr. MacKaye‰Ûªs parents‰Ûª house. The pragmatic, eloquent and close-cropped Mr. MacKaye bears a demeanor that only hints at a life that has witnessed a thousand stage dives and mosh pits. (A Minor Threat anthem was ‰ÛÏStraight Edge,‰Ûù a one-minute-45-second blast of aggression describing the drug- and alcohol-free ethos that some in this milieu lived by; the film‰Ûªs title comes from another Minor Threat song.)
For all his influence, Mr. MacKaye makes no claims to having craved local dominance. ‰ÛÏI didn‰Ûªt want to own the scene,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏI just wanted there to be one.‰Ûù

There are two survivors, one from each side, both wounded and both reluctant beneficiaries of Ivo‰Ûªs hospitality. Ahmed (Giorgi Nakhashidze), the Chechen, has the milder injury and the hotter temper. He swears that he will kill Niko (Mikheil Meskhi), the Georgian, as soon as he can, but promises Ivo that he won‰Ûªt do it under the old man‰Ûªs roof. A tense period of convalescence follows, during which Niko and Ahmed glare at each other over cups of tea, Margus frets about the state of his fruit and Ivo sternly tells everyone to calm down.

The audience, meanwhile, has time to meditate on the stupidity of war and the nature of honor. The film, beautifully shot and cleanly edited, has the economy of a short story, unfolding in a mood of slightly sentimental masculine stoicism. There are no women to be seen ‰ÛÓ a photograph of Ivo‰Ûªs granddaughter is the only female presence ‰ÛÓ and occasionally some more fighting men show up, to increase the tension and underscore the themes.

That remote conflict ‰ÛÓ part of a flurry of ethnic and regional wars in the immediate post-Soviet era ‰ÛÓ is the setting of Zaza Urushadze‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏTangerines,‰Ûù a humanist fable that was among this year‰Ûªs nominees for the best foreign-language film Oscar. The mountain valley where Ivo (Lembit Ulfsak) and Margus (Elmo NÌ_ganen) live seems quiet enough, a place of rural rhythms and ancient routines. (Their families returned to Estonia when the fighting started). But the tranquillity is disrupted by a skirmish between Georgian soldiers and Chechen mercenaries fighting for the Russian-backed Abkhazian separatists.

Ivo, a taciturn grandfather with a straight back and a silver beard, makes wooden crates in his workshop. He hopes to make enough to contain the harvest from his neighbor Margus‰Ûªs tangerine grove. The two men are among the last Estonians remaining in the former Soviet Republic of Georgia during the 1992 war in the Abkhazia region.

‰ÛÏTangerines‰Ûù is a modest film, sure of its proportions and clear about its intentions. The key to its effectiveness lies with the actors, in particular Mr. Ulfsak, who radiates wry, weary wisdom and Mr. Nakhashidze, who is as charismatic and menacing as a mastiff at rest. The friendship that develops between Ivo and Ahmed is touching and credible, and seems like a small mercy in the midst of cruelty and hatred.

Mr. Finkel, played in the movie by Jonah Hill, was a young magazine writer of great ambition and impressive achievement when he was caught fabricating part of an article in The New York Times Magazine. Unlike other well-known writerly miscreants like Jayson Blair, Jonah Lehrer and Stephen Glass, whose careers trace a pattern of fraud, Mr. Finkel does not seem to have been a serial offender. But his single lapse was grave enough to warrant an editors‰Ûª note in this newspaper and banishment from its pages.
‰ÛÏTrue Story‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A horrible crime and its aftermath, more implied than shown.

Except that the movie, written by Mr. Goold and David Kajganich, is fuzzy, lazy and thoroughly declawed. Mr. Franco, it turns out, is also a natural sidekick. His quiet voice and sorrowful eyes don‰Ûªt convey enigma, torment or danger. They convey nothing much at all. Two stars giving recessive, wary, passive-aggressive performances ‰ÛÓ with Ms. Jones assigned the thankless task of providing some emotional color ‰ÛÓ leave the movie hollow and inert. The echoing emptiness should not be mistaken for resonance.

Since ‰ÛÏTrue Story‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the movie, not the book ‰ÛÓ is a fictionalized rendering of real events, we can buy this version of the character. Or we could, if Mr. Hill‰Ûªs performance provided a window into Finkel‰Ûªs inner life and hidden motives. But while Mr. Hill is a quick-witted actor, he is also an essentially reactive performer, a born sidekick who plays best with a complicated, charismatic foil, like Brad Pitt in ‰ÛÏMoneyball‰Ûù or Leonardo DiCaprio in ‰ÛÏThe Wolf of Wall Street.‰Ûù James Franco, slotted into that role here, doesn‰Ûªt quite cut it.

Mr. Goold, the cinematographer Masanobu Takayanagi and especially Marco Beltrami, who composed the minor-key, anxiety-inflected score, manage to create a mood of menace and mystery. Could Longo possibly be innocent? If not, why did he kill his family? What is at stake in the intimacy between him and Finkel? Are the two men as similar as they sometimes seem to think? Is one using the other? Which one?

‰ÛÏThe Journalist and the Murderer‰Ûù is the title of a book by Janet Malcolm, but it could just as well be the name of a genre. A small library of searching and sensational stories attests to the strong, often uncomfortable affinity between reporters and killers. Truman Capote‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏIn Cold Blood‰Ûù is perhaps the supreme example, and one that has inspired several movies over the years. Neither Michael Finkel‰Ûªs book ‰ÛÏTrue Story‰Ûù nor Rupert Goold‰Ûªs film adaptation is anywhere near as accomplished as Capote‰Ûªs book or Bennett Miller‰Ûªs movie ‰ÛÏCapote.‰Ûù The new film is of interest mainly because it demonstrates just how difficult it can be to map the queasy moral territory where crime and journalism intersect.

The film deals with this episode, which took place in 2001-2, in a few quick scenes, and leaves the impression that what happened wasn‰Ûªt entirely the writer‰Ûªs fault. Gretchen Mol appears as a fictitious editor who seems to be both accomplice and hanging judge. Like the book (which is subtitled ‰ÛÏMurder, Memoir, Mea Culpa‰Ûù), the movie has a tendency to conflate shame and self-congratulations. Mr. Finkel‰Ûªs admitted sins of arrogance and sloppiness turn out to be virtues in disguise, side effects of a professional temperament defined by passion, courage and a fierce work ethic. The more he beats himself up, the more sympathetic he becomes.

The problem with ‰ÛÏTrue Story‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt that it fails to answer these questions, but that it never poses them with sufficient moral gravity or dramatic force. The real story of Christian Longo and Michael Finkel might be a fascinating and disturbing tale of crime, curiosity and journalistic ethics, but that‰Ûªs not what this movie is.

In disgrace, Finkel retreats to the wilds of Montana, where he mopes around while his girlfriend, Jill Barker (Felicity Jones), works with rare books at a university library and furrows her brow in concern. His malaise is broken by a weird piece of news: An Oregon man named Christian Longo has been arrested and charged with murdering his wife and three children. While on the lam in Mexico, he pretended to be Michael Finkel, a writer for The New York Times. Alerted to this imposture by a reporter (Ethan Suplee), the real Michael Finkel arranges to meet Longo, and they begin a wary friendship that is also a psychological cat-and-mouse game.

‰ÛÏUnfriended‰Ûù seems ready-made to watch on a computer, where its windows upon windows will take on more resonance. (It probably has a future as an academic thumb-sucker on generation selfie, gender roles and fragmented spectatorship.) Mostly, though, it reminds you that today‰Ûªs horror movies still owe a great debt to Val Lewton, the producer of cheapie classics like ‰ÛÏCat People‰Ûù (1942) and a virtuoso of shadows who realized that audiences could be entertained if the characters they watched looked like them. ‰ÛÏUnfriended‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt have Lewton‰Ûªs poetry. Yet the filmmakers understand that one way into an audience‰Ûªs head and nervous system is to fill the screen with the kind of ‰ÛÏinsipidly normal characters‰Ûù (as the critic Manny Farber described Lewton‰Ûªs) you‰Ûªre happy to see shiver and scream.

Much of the live-action material was shot by the actors, using GoPro cameras. As in Skype exchanges, their faces tend to loom in their respective displays, which Mr. Gabriadze arranges and rearranges like a blackjack dealer dealing assorted hands. Mr. Gabriadze and his postproduction team also play around with the image (and sound) because, as is often the case these days, much of what you‰Ûªre watching is animation. They pixelate, smear and split the visuals, and interrupt and punctuate the dialogue with ominous crackles and static. These manipulations torque the tension and at times forecast other, more substantive violence to come. Time and again, the characters break apart aurally and visually, becoming near-ghosts in their own machine world.

The best thing about ‰ÛÏUnfriended,‰Ûù beyond its funny-nasty title, is that it doesn‰Ûªt play as remotely dull as it sounds even if most of the drama takes place inside shifting, overlapping windows. In other words, most of what you‰Ûªre watching looks a lot like your computer, especially if, like Blaire (Shelley Hennig), you‰Ûªre a multitasking teen who likes chatting with besties on Skype while simultaneously instant messaging (and sexting) your BF, Mitch (a good Moses Storm); checking out YouTube (for videos like ‰ÛÏLaura Barns Kill Urself‰Ûù); listening to tunes; and scrolling through horror-show websites that feature dubious demon-extraction tips even as you fight your possible DOA BFF who ‰ÛÓ OMG, LOL ‰ÛÓ may actually be alive or just your gas-lighting BF.
‰ÛÏUnfriended‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun, knife and blender violence.

A skinflint‰Ûªs dream, ‰ÛÏUnfriended‰Ûù either raises or lowers the bar for low-budget, big-studio synergy. More provocative sizzle than bloody-disgusting steak, it features a small cast of whozat young actors and was directed by another question mark, Leo Gabriadze. The most recognizable name is Timur Bekmambetov, the cult filmmaker (‰ÛÏNight Watch‰Ûù) turned Hollywood name (‰ÛÏAbraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter‰Ûù), who cooked up the idea of making a movie that unfolds almost entirely on computer windows. One of Mr. Bekmambetov‰Ûªs former employees, Nelson Greaves, wrote the script, and they both also helped produce.

The story is basically Agatha Christie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAnd Then There Were None‰Ûù retooled for the social-media age. Six blank-slate teenage friends convene one evening on Skype for some idle yammering only to be interrupted by a troll or perhaps a poltergeist now virtual-squatting in their screened-in world. The intruder may be Laura Barns (Heather Sossaman), a friend of the six who killed herself after being bullied online. The intruder-troll-dead girl doesn‰Ûªt have much of a sense of humor, and, after baiting the jittery Skypers, it gets down to progressively violent business. It cannily uses an arsenal of classic scare tactics (loud bangs, dim lights) but is never creepier than when deploying the kinds of cruel taunts, gleeful insults and ugly threats that are the Internet bully‰Ûªs stock-in-trade.
‰ÛÏPaul Blart: Mall Cop 2‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for reasons I cannot fathom.

You won‰Ûªt find much offensive in Kevin James‰Ûªs slick, innocuous vehicle ‰ÛÏPaul Blart: Mall Cop 2.‰Ûù You won‰Ûªt find much prompting an emotional reaction in general, so familiar are the jokes and situations. If Mr. James‰Ûªs character thinks of safety first, so does this movie, to its extreme detriment.

The pride of the West Orange Pavilion Mall in New Jersey, Blart, returning from the 2009 original, is a mustachioed, huffy-puffy bundle of ego and sanctimony who, at the start of ‰ÛÏMall Cop 2,‰Ûù has had bad luck: His wife left him after six days of marriage, and his mother has been killed by a milk truck. Only an invitation to a security guard convention in Las Vegas, for which he mistakenly believes he will give the keynote speech, lifts his spirits. In tow is his daughter, Maya (Raini Rodriguez, back from the first), who meets a quasi-love interest, Lane (David Henrie), at the hotel and casino where she and her father are staying.

At the convention Blart is introduced, James Bond-style, to nonlethal gadgets he will use later: one that spits marbles; another that fires beanbags; a glue gun. There are also Segways, Blart‰Ûªs preferred mode of travel, that he activates, ‰ÛÏMacGyver‰Ûù-style, with improvised materials.

But first he must wrestle with a cantankerous exotic bird and have his face spattered with pink ice cream droppings as he seeks to remedy his hypoglycemia. Blart‰Ûªs efforts earn him a medal, and again his colleagues, if not viewers in the movie theater, burst into applause.

After the scheduled convention speaker gets too drunk to do the job, Blart steps in, and his colleagues erupt with cheers at his oratory. (The script was written by Mr. James and Nick Bakay). Even the comely Divina Martinez (Daniella Alonso), the hotel-casino‰Ûªs manager, grows starry-eyed. And when high-tech criminals (led by Neal McDonough, the villain of ‰ÛÏRed 2‰Ûù) plot to steal artwork from the place, they inevitably take Maya and Lane hostage, and Blart, in pursuit, must employ his novelty arsenal.

The film, by Douglas Kass and Roger Kass, introduces us to migrating songbirds that funnel through the Mediterranean, and to people who hunt them illegally in places like Cyprus. The birds are considered a culinary delicacy in some cultures, so they are captured by the thousands as they fly by, snared in nets that are strung up in trees, stuck on branches covered in a gooey substance, crushed under rocks precariously balanced on sticks, and so on.
That‰Ûªs when you realize that ‰ÛÏEmptying the Skies‰Ûù is about the commitment to living out your beliefs, no matter how quixotic. Their example is stirring somehow, no matter what your passion.

Two types of people will be tempted to ignore ‰ÛÏEmptying the Skies,‰Ûù a documentary about bird poaching based on a Jonathan Franzen article: people who don‰Ûªt care about birding, and people who care passionately about birding. Both groups would be missing out on a thoughtful bit of filmmaking, one that at heart is not really about birds at all.
‰ÛÏYou save thousands of birds,‰Ûù one says, ‰ÛÏbut they kill millions.‰Ûù

They call themselves the Committee Against Bird Slaughter, and Mr. Franzen wrote about them in The New Yorker in 2010. He appears in the film as well, and he has become a prominent advocate for birds. At the moment, he is immersed in controversy over a New Yorker article he wrote this month questioning part of the National Audubon Society‰Ûªs emphasis, and certain bird lovers no doubt hate him for it.

But his detractors would still find much to admire in this film, and so would people who are indifferent to birds and don‰Ûªt enjoy seeing close-ups of suffering animals. That‰Ûªs because while, yes, this documentary is chronicling a problem for the animal kingdom, it‰Ûªs really a heartening study of humans.

For the first 45 minutes or so, you think the anti-poaching guerrillas are insane, risking a hostile reaction from landowners for the sake of freeing a small fraction of the birds being captured. But the film turns when they admit their own limitations.

It‰Ûªs unpleasant to watch, and it has roused a small group of bird lovers to guerrilla-style action. The film follows them as they steal into hunting grounds, destroying traps and painstakingly freeing the captives, one bird at a time.

‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Think I‰Ûªve Forgotten‰Ûù is not exactly suspenseful: we know from the start that the American bombs and the Communist killing fields are just over the horizon. But the filmmakers‰Ûª deft interweaving of old videos with recent interviews casts an unusual spell, inducing a poignant kind of magical thinking. The pop stars are so vivid ‰ÛÓ Sinn Sisamouth, with his dapper clothes and neatly combed hair, Ros Serey Sothea with her keening, passionate voice, the rebellious guitar hero Yol Aularong ‰ÛÓ that you almost believe they will somehow be spared, as if the ebullience and freedom they represent could keep the monsters of history at bay.

And even as you revel in the sounds of newly rediscovered artists, you are aware that their careers were cut brutally short, and that the further flowering of Cambodian rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll was sacrificed on the altar of fanaticism.

In 1970, after the United States began bombing suspected North Vietnamese positions in northern and eastern Cambodia, Sihanouk, who opposed the American intervention, was deposed in a military coup led by Gen. Lon Nol, a former prime minister. His government demanded nationalistic songs and repressed some of the more countercultural kinds of music. But this repression was minor compared with the blood bath that would follow.

The Khmer Rouge, which entered Phnom Penh almost exactly 40 years ago (in April 1975), emptied the cities and singled out artists, intellectuals and ‰ÛÏpro-Western‰Ûù Cambodians for harsh treatment. Wearing long hair or owning a musical instrument could lead to torture, confinement or death ‰ÛÓ not that the Khmer Rouge was especially discriminating in its brutality. While Mr. Pirozzi does not dwell on the misery of the mid-‰Ûª70s, he does not minimize it either, or suggest that reconciliation and recovery have been easy.

And Cambodia from the late 1950s to the mid-‰Ûª60s looks very pleasant indeed ‰ÛÓ a land of flowering trees and blossoming cultural possibilities. Prince Sihanouk, while not exactly a democrat, was a patron of the arts and a music lover with a decent singing voice. After his country peacefully negotiated its independence from France, he tried to keep it on a neutral and independent path, something that proved increasingly difficult and ultimately impossible as the Cold War heated up in neighboring Vietnam.

Because it concentrates on the music ‰ÛÓ interviewing surviving fans and artists, generously sampling old 45s and video clips ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Think I‰Ûªve Forgotten‰Ûù offers a fresh and powerful account of Cambodia‰Ûªs painful history. Like Rithy Panh‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMissing Picture,‰Ûù a family chronicle of almost unimaginable suffering and loss at the hands of the Khmer Rouge, Mr. Pirozzi‰Ûªs film is an unsparing and meticulous reckoning of the effects of tyranny on ordinary Cambodians. It is also a rich and defiant effort at recovery, showing that even the most murderous totalitarianism cannot fully erase the human drive for pleasure and self-expression.

Popular songs are both ephemeral and durable. They have their brief season of radio airplay and then linger in memory as permanent tokens of generational identity. The Cambodian musical culture that spawned the soundtrack of Mr. Pirozzi‰Ûªs film was marvelously fertile, absorbing a wide range of Western influences and infusing them with traditional Khmer themes and singing styles. There were go-go bands and girl groups, crooners and bubble-gum divas, skinny suits and big hairdos, funk and psychedelia. But all of it ‰ÛÓ the record stores and discothÌ¬ques, the atmosphere of youthful exuberance and romantic longing ‰ÛÓ proved tragically fragile, unable to withstand the forces of war and political fanaticism.

‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Think I‰Ûªve Forgotten,‰Ûù a moving and informative documentary by John Pirozzi, takes its name from a hit song of the 1960s. The title may not ring a bell among Western audiences, though the tune itself might carry a sonic reminder of that era. Like almost all the music heard in the film, it was a product of the vibrant pop music scene that flourished in Cambodia during the ill-fated reign of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

Those musicians and their fans ‰ÛÓ who can still recall listening parties and record-store excursions 50 years after the fact ‰ÛÓ reclaim their long-forgotten place in the global youth culture of their era. The kids in Phnom Penh resemble their counterparts in Prague, Paris, Berkeley or Mexico City, some of whom were also caught up in the political storms of the era, though few quite as lethally. It‰Ûªs the closeness of that Cambodian generation, the familiarity of their tastes and attitudes, that makes their fate seem especially horrific.

A dramatized account of the 2006 abduction and torture of a young Jewish cellphone vendor in Paris, ‰ÛÏ24 Days‰Ûù arrives freighted with so much sociopolitical baggage that you can almost feel the weight. Contributing to a growing disquiet among French Jews, the horrifying ordeal of Ilan Halimi, 23 ‰ÛÓ who was held for roughly three weeks in a suburban housing project by a multiethnic gang known as the Barbarians ‰ÛÓ fueled a national debate about anti-Semitism that the movie‰Ûªs French release invigorated.

That discussion could easily eclipse the fact that, sadly, ‰ÛÏ24 Days‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt nearly as involving as it should be. Based on a 2009 memoir by Mr. Halimi‰Ûªs mother, Ruth Halimi, and Emilie FrÌ¬che, the story begins on the day of the kidnapping as Ilan (Syrus Shahidi) leaves a family dinner to meet a woman who would be revealed to be a lure deployed by thugs targeting wealthy Jewish professionals. As the ransom calls begin and the movie settles into the familiar rhythms of the police procedural, the director, Alexandre Arcady, effectively conveys the emotional discord between the family‰Ûªs increasing despair and the calm methodology of law enforcement.

Yet Mr. Arcady‰Ûªs reliance on heavy-handed melodrama, on screaming women and on worried-looking men, winds everything so tightly that the anguish plateaus and the characters begin to seem like chess pieces in an argument. It doesn‰Ûªt help that we are told almost nothing about Ilan ‰ÛÓ or anyone else ‰ÛÓ before the kidnapping. Why is his father (a beautifully modulated performance by Pascal ElbÌ©) estranged from the family? Why does the gang‰Ûªs terrifyingly unhinged leader (Tony Harrisson) make two trips to the Ivory Coast? Even Ilan‰Ûªs mother (Zabou Breitman), whose viewpoint we are sharing and who directly addresses the camera, emerges as little more than a tireless advocate for exposing the anti-Semitic motivations of the crime.

Denied the flashbacks that would have varied the film‰Ûªs tone and allowed us to bond with the family, we are moved less by the sight of Ilan‰Ûªs considerable suffering than by the patient diplomacy of Delcour (a marvelous Jacques Gamblin), the police commander in charge of the case. Caught between a mother‰Ûªs demands and the ideology of a republic that resists viewing citizens as members of separate communities, Delcour is the embodiment of a predicament that shows no signs of resolution.

Meanwhile Hahou helps the stone-faced detective Luk Yuen-sum (Charlie Young) catch up to Fung, and worries about his sword-fighting girl (Michelle Bai) back home. Mr. Yen brings a turn-on-a-dime efficiency to the melees, but he‰Ûªs nearly upstaged by the boiling insanity of Mr. Wang, a star of the blockbuster comedy ‰ÛÏLost in Thailand.‰Ûù

Mr. Chen, who teamed with Mr. Yen for the superior ‰ÛÏBodyguards and Assassins,‰Ûù scatters references to Hong Kong martial arts classics. But while he has impressive fists of fury in both Mr. Yen and Mr. Wang, ‰ÛÏKung Fu Killer‰Ûù lacks the brio and spice of its ancestors.

In Teddy Chen‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKung Fu Killer,‰Ûù the Hong Kong action star Donnie Yen faces a foe who didn‰Ûªt get the memo about martial arts: you don‰Ûªt have to murder the other guy; you just have to win. Mr. Yen plays Hahou Mo, a jailed champion who is released by the police to stop a killer who is going after former fighters. That orderly premise results in a buffet of fights of one variety or another ‰ÛÓ boxing, grappling, a bamboo-pole duel ‰ÛÓ leading to the inevitable showdown.

There‰Ûªs no mystery, really, since a constant stream of flashbacks and crosscutting identifies Hahou‰Ûªs nemesis as the furious Fung Yu-sau (Wang Baoqiang). Mr. Chen grabs our eyes early with a skittering battle between Fung and a victim that takes place on a gargantuan artwork that resembles King Kong‰Ûªs skeleton. Later Fung fights a stunt man on a (swiftly evacuated) movie set.

His is one of many voices heard in ‰ÛÏBecause I Was a Painter,‰Ûù Christophe Cognet‰Ûªs somber, rambling documentary study of art surreptitiously created by prisoners at Buchenwald, Auschwitz-Birkenau, Dachau, Treblinka and other Nazi camps. The majority of the works shown in the movie are drawings on whatever scraps of paper were available, which had to be hidden. Other works were drawn or painted from memory after World War II by former prisoners.

Throughout the film, a debate simmers about the possibility of finding beauty in such horror. The artist Zoran Music, a survivor of Dachau, is quoted as declaring: ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt dare say it. I shouldn‰Ûªt say it. But for a painter, it was incredibly beautiful.‰Ûù

That observation is the film‰Ûªs most extreme expression of how making art helped momentarily distract some artists from the horrors surrounding them. Others vehemently argue that there was no possibility of finding beauty in such a situation. The film, which opens with shots of a graveyard, ends with a searing picture by LÌ©on Delarbre, ‰ÛÏA Dead Buddy by the Roadside.‰Ûù The eyes are closed, the mouth open in a scream.

One of the most cohesive bodies of work is a meticulously assembled gallery of small identically sized portraits of 114 prisoners from four camps, drawn by Franciszek Jazviechi. Another scene is devoted to Dinah Gottliebova‰Ûªs detailed portraits of Roma people, drawn hours before their deaths under orders from Josef Mengele, who was using the prisoners in demonic medical experiments on ethnicity and physical attributes. In return for Ms. Gottliebova‰Ûªs work, she was allowed to live.

‰ÛÏAll these dead bodies totally drained of color: a symphony of grays.‰Ûù Those words, spoken by the Belgian artist JosÌ© Fosty, describe his impression of a wagon filled with dead bodies in the Buchenwald concentration camp, where he was held for more than two years until its liberation in 1945.

As crude as many of these works are, they exert an eerie cumulative power. The only pieces that seem out of place are deliberately so. Two or three depict voluptuous naked women, crammed together in a gas chamber. These are included to suggest the short distance between sober documentary remembrance and exploitative Holocaust kitsch.

‰ÛÏBecause I Was a Painter‰Ûù maintains a funereal rhythm, alternating images of artworks with long-distance views of camp barracks as they are today, the camera moving slowly and stealthily. The film makes eloquent use of near-silence. As the camera pans slowly in 360-degree shots to capture what one talking head calls a ‰ÛÏlandscape of death,‰Ûù the only sounds are the rustling of trees and birdsong, and the quiet evokes a gaping emptiness.

Presumably Ms. Greenfield sees no point in giving a soapbox to anti-Zionists. A pity: To refute something, you must first identify it. In its campaign to educate, and win hearts and minds, ‰ÛÏBody and Soul‰Ûù does itself no favors by getting fuzzy.

‰ÛÏBody and Soul: The State of the Jewish Nation‰Ûù is a concise, skillful recounting of the story of the Jewish people and their connection to the land of Israel. While it tends to conflate Judaism with Zionism ‰ÛÓ a position not all Jews agree with ‰ÛÓ the film is straightforward in presenting the historical record.

In publicity materials, Ms. Greenfield, whose earlier films include ‰ÛÏUnmasked Judeophobia,‰Ûù says she made this documentary as pushback against efforts to ‰ÛÏdelegitimize Israel‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏpropaganda, myths and misinformation that have been accepted by so many.‰Ûù Yet in a departure from its otherwise rigorous scholarship, ‰ÛÏBody and Soul‰Ûù opts not to deeply analyze denialist claims beyond contending that a current wave of revisionism started with Yasir Arafat and showing two short clips of Arab historians denying Jews‰Ûª legacy in the land.

The director, Gloria Z. Greenfield, keeps a swift pace: In 64 minutes, archaeologists, historians, diplomats, lawyers and religious leaders ‰ÛÓ among them, Jonathan Sacks, the former chief rabbi of Britain; the historian Benny Morris; and the author and law professor Alan Dershowitz ‰ÛÓ narrate a 3,000-year saga of residency, exile and return. Featuring contemporaneous documents and artifacts from ancient days through the Middle Ages to modern times, the film is as cogent as it is inspiring.

At one point the film interviews a local poacher who bemoans his lack of employment, underscoring the link between poverty and poaching in Africa. He explains how his reward is dwarfed by the profits of the smugglers in China (and, presumably,åÊthe United States) who resell his ivory. Weeks after the interview, he is arrested again.
And why are these noble creatures being killed wholesale? ForåÊtrinketsåÊ‰ÛÓ mantelpiece knickknacks. The sheer needlessness is appalling.

The images are stark and grisly at the start of the short but bluntly powerful documentary ‰ÛÏGardeners of Eden‰Ûù: Television news footage presents the bloody carcasses of elephants, shorn of their tusks, that are sold in theåÊillegal ivory trade. And soon we are taken to Tsavo National ParkåÊin Kenya, the front line of the elephant slaughter in Africa, which is losing its population of these majestic mammals at an alarming rate. The film follows the efforts of Daphne Sheldrick, 80, of theåÊDavid Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, which raises orphaned elephant calves and reintroduces them into the wild. And it accompanies members of the trust and armedåÊKenya Wildlife ServiceåÊofficers as they search for poachers and treat elephants wounded by wires planted to cripple herds.

We probably don‰Ûªt need to see the actress Kristin Davis (‰ÛÏSex and the City‰Ûù), a patron of the Sheldrick trust and an executive producer of this film, on camera as much as we do, certainly not as much as we need to know the extent of this scourge throughout Africa and the steps being taken in America and Europe to stem the slaughter. But Ms. Davis does promote the trust and theåÊUnited States Fish and Wildlife Service, and sounds the alert. And that is very much to her credit.

There‰Ûªs not much to say about this movie save that it features a troika of likable performers ‰ÛÓ the comedian Nick Kroll, Rose Byrne and that reliable most valuable player Bobby Cannavale ‰ÛÓ who pretend to have emotions during over-the-shoulder talks and while moving in and out of flatly lit, blandly shot sets. Mr. Kroll plays Jake, a would-be entrepreneur who, after his big idea tanks, moves in with his sister, Justine (Ms. Byrne), and brother-in-law, Danny (Mr. Cannavale). Jake has to get back on his feet, etc., which he does amid generic invocations of parental fatigue, marital stress, financial uncertainty, having it all or not. There‰Ûªs also a swimming metaphor.

The influence of television only partly explains all the medium shots and close-ups that are crammed into a movie like ‰ÛÏAdult Beginners,‰Ûù an overreliance that‰Ûªs most evident in its drearily written, monotonously staged and edited conversations. The director Ross Katz, making his feature directing debut, does occasionally move the camera around, but for the most part he just points and shoots his performers talking, joking, whining, sharing and caring. The three leads remain watchable, but only the sourness in Jake‰Ûªs face when he moves into Justine‰Ûªs house hints at the kind of true and complex emotions that, bromide by bromide, this movie insistently denies.
‰ÛÏAdult Beginners‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Growing pains.

The only downside to living in (yet another) golden age of television is that film critics can no longer summarily dismiss bad movies as, you know, television. When Matthew Weiner takes cues from Wong Kar-wai for ‰ÛÏMad Men,‰Ûù and one of the best action movies last year was an episode of the HBO show ‰ÛÏTrue Detective,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs clear that the lazy hierarchy that once judged movies good and television bad needs a serious rethink. And while a movie like ‰ÛÏAdult Beginners‰Ûù may play like an extended sitcom, the truth is that it probably would never get picked up.

‰ÛÏJust Before I Go,‰Ûù the directorial debut of Courteney Cox, lurches along a wobbly line between salacious comic nastiness and nauseating sentimentality. The two strains are so poorly integrated that the screenplay (by David Flebotte) feels like pieces from two different projects mashed together with little oversight. In the middle of a mawkish confession, a crude zinger from out of the blue is liable to shatter the mood, presumably for the sake of levity in a movie that isn‰Ûªt funny, merely bizarre.

Before ending it all, Ted has a bucket list of vengeful tirades to deliver to people who hurt him while he was growing up, including a seventh-grade math teacher and a high school bully. Returning to his hometown, he stays with his brother, Lucky (Garret Dillahunt), a policeman with a closeted, tormented gay son (Kyle Gallner, giving the movie‰Ûªs only grounded performance) and a bitter wife (Kate Walsh), who puts the moves on Ted while feigning sleepwalking.
‰ÛÏJust Before I Go‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual content, language and some drug use.
On the critical scoreboard, ‰ÛÏJust Before I Go‰Ûù earns two resounding thuds.
Zaniness without purpose or comic imagination invariably lands with a thud. So does unearned by-the-numbers sentiment with no real heart behind it.

In the opening scene, Ted (Seann William Scott), a mild-mannered 41-year-old pet store manager who appears to be in perfectly good health, cheerfully announces that he plans to commit suicide. Why? His long-dead father brought him up to believe that the world was a safe and decent place, and he found out it wasn‰Ûªt. ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt feel bad for me,‰Ûù he chirps. And Mr. Scott‰Ûªs tepid, colorless performance ensures that we don‰Ûªt.

It opens with Connor wandering a prettily dusty landscape with a divining rod and, like some Aussie Moses, soon hitting a gusher. This inundation foretells a tragic one that leaves him a widower and before long leads him to Turkey, where he meets a mercilessly cute boy, Orhan (the blameless Dylan Georgiades), who takes him to a hotel run by his mother, Ayshe (Olga Kurylenko). As director and actor, Mr. Crowe fares better once he splits this ludicrously false scene and switches into action mode, which gathers force as he cuts between Connor‰Ûªs travels and flashbacks to Gallipoli. Some of these scenes are generic; others hit hard, including a trench fight that turns into an intimate frenzy of death and a harrowing vision of a man holding his guts while dying, breath by whimpered breath.

If Connor and Ayshe‰Ûªs romance is embarrassing, filled with Andy Hardy-style eye darting and virginal vibrations, Mr. Crowe finds his rhythm and apparent purpose in Connor‰Ûªs relationship with the Turkish officer, Major Hasan (the very fine Yilmaz Erdogan). After a testosterone flare-up, they seal their bonds first over drinks and then in battle where Hasan‰Ûªs men fight Greek invaders, represented as dirty-faced brutes in black. Here again, crude narrative hieroglyphics ‰ÛÓ Grieving Father, Beautiful Widow, Noble Warrior, Evil Invaders ‰ÛÓ stand in for history, including all the horrors of World War I and not just at Gallipoli; the postwar partitioning of the Ottoman Empire; and the slaughter that followed in the Greco-Turkish War of 1919 to 1922. Connor manages to conquer the hard Australian land and some crusty Turks, even as Mr. Crowe‰Ûªs own directorial campaign goes down in defeat.

The movie wants to take you back to Gallipoli and honor its soldiers, both Australian and Turkish, but it never coherently establishes the specifics of Connor‰Ûªs character or his context. It darts from mood to self-canceling mood ‰ÛÓ from upbeat to down, from sun to shadow ‰ÛÓ as Connor dowses water, mourns his dead, sails a boat, hops a train, rides a horse, romances a beauty and hotfoots it in and out of battle. In turn, Mr. Crowe disjointedly cycles through genres as if trying to decide which one fits: a father-son saga, a combat movie, a gauzy romance and a cross-cultural bromance. It‰Ûªs never clear what drives Connor beyond his dead wife‰Ûªs bitter recriminations that he lost their sons; mostly he serves as a totem of the supremely capable, ruggedly individualistic Australian white male.

These characters ‰ÛÓ the indomitable Australian man of the earth, the unfeeling British soldiers and the upright Turkish warrior ‰ÛÓ all signify. There‰Ûªs meaning too in the movie‰Ûªs American release on Friday, April 24, the day before the centenary of the Allied landing at Gallipoli. April 24 is also the start of another centenary: the Armenian genocide, during which an estimated 1.5 million Armenians were killed between 1915 and 1923. You don‰Ûªt have to be a historian to wonder about the timing of the opening or a critic to regret that Mr. Crowe has signed onto a preposterous, would-be sweeping historical romance that‰Ûªs far too slight and silly to carry the weight of real history.

For ‰ÛÏThe Water Diviner,‰Ûù his muddled directorial debut about love in the time of war and dissemblance, Russell Crowe wanted to go full David Lean while nodding at Peter Weir‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGallipoli.‰Ûù Like many filmmakers, Mr. Crowe also wanted to tidy up history to suit his dramatic needs. He plays Joshua Connor, a widowed Australian farmer who four years after the Gallipoli campaign of 1915-16 goes to Turkey to find his three missing sons. In Istanbul, he meets an insensitive British officer who orders him home and a lovely Turkish widow whose eyes tell him to stay. In Gallipoli, Connor meets another cloddish British officer and forms a manly friendship with a wise Turkish army officer.
‰ÛÏThe Water Diviner‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). War carnage.

Cobain‰Ûªs and Nirvana‰Ûªs music is heard throughout, and there are unusual bonuses, like a shot of Cobain fiercely running through ‰ÛÏDrain You‰Ûù at a sound check or a poignant tape of him singing the Beatles‰Ûª ‰ÛÏAnd I Love Her.‰Ûù Oddly, we don‰Ûªt really see Cobain‰Ûªs development as a musician ‰ÛÓ he seems to appear fully formed, while the film concentrates on Cobain the writer, draftsman and personality. You‰Ûªre not likely to mind, though, for the duration of Mr. Morgen‰Ûªs seamless mystery ride.

‰ÛÏMontage of Heck‰Ûù is really a series of montages, both visual (Mr. Morgen and Joe Beshenkovsky were the editors) and aural (Cameron Frankley did the sound design). Swirls of images flash by ‰ÛÓ childhood family movies, journal and notebook entries, Cobain‰Ûªs drawings and paintings, scenes of life on the road, concert footage, magazine articles, the home movies of Cobain and his wife, Courtney Love ‰ÛÓ set to an intricately layered soundtrack of Nirvana songs, archival interviews and the semiconfessional audiotapes he made as part of his diverse, constant artistic output.

Mr. Morgen‰Ûªs reliance on Cobain‰Ûªs personal material goes along with an unusual sparseness of interview subjects for a biographical documentary ‰ÛÓ just seven, including his mother, father and sister, his bandmate Krist Novoselic and Ms. Love. (The Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl was interviewed but not included in the film.) You can speculate about how complete a picture we‰Ûªre getting, given that Ms. Love‰Ûªs and Cobain‰Ûªs daughter, Frances Bean Cobain, was an executive producer of the film, but that‰Ûªs all you can do.

‰ÛÏKurt Cobain: Montage of Heck,‰Ûù Brett Morgen‰Ûªs family-approved documentary about the prodigiously talented and troubled leader of Nirvana, opens with a credit for its source material. Mr. Morgen was given access to Cobain‰Ûªs archives ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏart, music, journals, Super 8 films and audio montages‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and his exhilarating, exhausting, two-hour-plus film, both an artful mosaic and a hammering barrage, reflects years of rummaging through that trove.

Ultimate answers about the suicide, or about the nature of Cobain‰Ûªs relationship with Ms. Love, are still elusive, though. When it comes down to it, Mr. Morgen is faced with the opacity and the nondramatic, self-fulfilling nature of the drug addiction story. This is partly why the first hour, with its home-movie footage of an angelic, hyperactive Cobain as a child and its animated sequences of his adolescence, set to his own taped narration, is the best part of the film. (Though the later scenes of Cobain and Ms. Love living in comfortable, generally cheerful rock-star squalor have their own fascination.)

You‰Ûªre never unaware of this virtuosity ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMontage‰Ûù is, more than anything, an editing tour de force ‰ÛÓ or of the highly constructed nature of Mr. Morgen‰Ûªs narrative. The film stops short of Cobain‰Ûªs suicide in 1994, which is recounted in a one-sentence title card. But a portrait is assembled of Cobain as relentlessly self-aware and self-critical, and a theory is advanced involving insecurity and shame. And Mr. Morgen ‰ÛÓ able to choose from the archives ‰ÛÓ finds abundant clues and premonitions in Cobain‰Ûªs writings and uses a full bag of film tricks to make them tell the story he wants told.

In an awkwardly edited device, he is haunted by the abusive headmaster (Tom Sizemore) of the orphanage where he was raised. It doesn‰Ûªt help that Mr. Sizemore, mumbling dialogue about animal skin as he readies a belt for a beating, is barely intelligible.

The film serves as an acting exercise for Mr. Forsythe, less recognizable than usual thanks to a ridiculous Klaus Kinski mane. But the movie‰Ûªs main joke seems to be on viewers seeking anything more than tough-guy posturing.

Frank Stone (William Forsythe), the steely, taciturn protagonist of ‰ÛÏLaugh Killer Laugh,‰Ûù is the sort of hard-boiled murderer that screenwriters love. He drives a vintage car and owns a typewriter. When not pulling heists for a mob boss (Victor Colicchio), he is sharpening knives or stoically watching a Max Fleischer cartoon.

Written and directed by Kamal Ahmed, formerly of the Jerky Boys ‰ÛÓ the comedy duo whose prank-call routines enjoyed inexplicable popularity in the 1990s ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏLaugh Killer Laugh‰Ûù is a tired parody that seems to have been constructed from received notions of noir and mob movies. Even the jazzy score sounds like an affectation.

After an encounter with Jackie (Bianca Hunter), Frank impulsively enrolls in a creative-writing class in Queens. He churns out pages of terse Mickey Spillane-like prose that only he knows is more fact than fiction. Jackie, his classmate, tries to lure him out of his shell, inviting him over for a sandwich. Still, Frank doesn‰Ûªt display a sense of humor until his life is in jeopardy.

The steady performances of Tom Wilkinson, playing a kindly priest, and Emily Watson, an angelic mother, in Alejandro Monteverde‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLittle Boy‰Ûù do little to offset the cloying sweetness of a movie that has the haranguing inspirational tone of a marathon Sunday-school lesson. This tear-stained lump of hokum, drenched in oversaturated color, is a World War II fable about faith versus magical thinking.
‰ÛÏLittle Boy‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has one grisly battle scene.

Pepper finds hope at a children‰Ûªs magic show when his participation in an onstage stunt leaves him believing he possesses telekinetic powers. He is fortified by memories of his father‰Ûªs giving him courage when facing physical challenges with the words ‰ÛÏDo you believe you can do this?‰Ûù

The unseen narrator is Pepper, looking back at his anguished California childhood, when his beloved father, James (Michael Rapaport), a car mechanic, left home to fight the Japanese and was reported missing in action. Once Daddy is gone, 8-year-old Pepper (Jakob Salvati) is taunted by his peers who call him ‰ÛÏlittle boy‰Ûù because he is short.
The story compares Pepper‰Ûªs persecution to the harassment of Hashimoto (Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa), a gentle Japanese-American who is considered a pariah on the home front.

In the most preposterous scene, Pepper‰Ûªs desperate arm-waving attempt to prove that faith can move mountains coincides with an earthquake, earning him the awe of the bigoted, credulous townspeople, who cheer when news arrives of the bombing of Hiroshima. The queasiest moment of this crass, manipulative claptrap is the mention that the bomb was named Little Boy.

Pepper, encouraged to make amends after he and his teenage brother, London (David Henrie), throw stones at Hashimoto‰Ûªs house, develops a student-teacher bond with Hashimoto that is reminiscent of ‰ÛÏThe Karate Kid.‰Ûù With Hashimoto‰Ûªs help, Pepper sets about carrying out the Roman Catholic Church‰Ûªs Seven Corporal Works of Mercy.

All of that applies equally to documentary filmmaking. Comedians don‰Ûªt get points for trying, and documentaries should not be judged on their intentions. ‰ÛÏMisery Loves Comedy,‰Ûù Kevin Pollak‰Ûªs survey of the opinions of a bunch of professionally funny people, is an evident labor of love and also a work of grating amateurism. Mr. Pollak is an accomplished actor with ample comic gifts ‰ÛÓ he had a memorable moment in ‰ÛÏThe Aristocrats,‰Ûù Penn Jillette and Paul Provenza‰Ûªs 2005 documentary about a notoriously filthy joke ‰ÛÓ and impressive access to the famous and the talented, including Mr. Jillette.

Mr. Pollak, never seen and occasionally heard on screen, invites his interlocutors to reflect on the meaning of the stand-up life. Not all of them are best known as comedians. Tom Hanks shares some thoughts, as do James L. Brooks, Christopher Guest, the guys from the Opie and Anthony radio program and Jason Alexander, forever George Costanza to ‰ÛÏSeinfeld‰Ûù fans. Judd Apatow is also on hand to talk about, among other things, his early encounters with Jerry Seinfeld (who is not in the movie, though Larry David is) and other titans in the field. The roster of interviewees also includes Freddie Prinze Jr., who reflects on the legacy of his father, a brilliant young performer who took his own life in 1977.

The elder Prinze and Richard Pryor are invoked, along with Lenny Bruce and George Carlin, as formative influences on many of the assembled jokesters, though it is striking that nearly all of those jokesters are white. Whoopi Goldberg is the only African-American, which is astonishing when you consider just how many talented black performers are part of the current comedy boom. There are a handful of women, including Ms. Goldberg, Lisa Kudrow, Amy Schumer and Janeane Garofalo. But the overwhelming impression that the movie leaves behind ‰ÛÓ or maybe the assumption with which it started ‰ÛÓ is that white guys are funnier.

It‰Ûªs a truism that stand-up comedy is harder than it looks. Though it may seem like something anyone can do, telling jokes in a room full of strangers is something best left to professionals. It‰Ûªs a demanding craft, and also, when approached with the proper mix of discipline and inspiration, an art.

Instead, he invites his guests to traffic in abstraction. They wax philosophical on the nature of the job, but rarely tell stories about what it‰Ûªs like for them. We learn something about what it feels like to bomb on stage ‰ÛÓ and to kill ‰ÛÓ but very little about the creative process or about the professional landscape. ‰ÛÏMisery Loves Comedy‰Ûù is organized into haphazard chapters that keep us perpetually on the surface, protecting the secret lore of a guild supposedly devoted to truth-telling and self-exposure.

Some fans will find the movie irresistible, but even a die-hard comedy geek, eager to hang out with Jimmy Fallon or Richard Lewis or Bob Saget, is likely to grow bored over the course of 95 minutes. There is better comedy, deeper misery and greater wisdom to be found on YouTube.

I‰Ûªm not pointing this out to be politically correct ‰ÛÓ some of my best friends are funny white guys ‰ÛÓ but rather to note one of several ways the film falls short in exploring its chosen topic. The ‰ÛÏmisery‰Ûù that is proposed as a source of comic inspiration ‰ÛÓ and that not all of the comedians admit to ‰ÛÓ is fairly circumscribed. You felt insecure as a kid, misunderstood by your family or mistreated by your peers, and you compensated by making people laugh. This may be a universal experience, but specific varieties of it, collective as well as individual, have been the great sources of American humor.
