Scarcely a word is breathed about religion, sex, race or money, as though Mr. Pollak were convening a prim dinner party at which such matters could not be mentioned.

Best known for the television show ‰ÛÏGossip Girl‰Ûù and her red-carpet appearances, Ms. Lively has done some fine work elsewhere, including in ‰ÛÏThe Town‰Ûù and especially ‰ÛÏSavages.‰Ûù Here, though, she delivers a muted, largely opaque performance, an unfortunate choice given that Adaline shows few signs of having lived through two world wars, the space age, the Beatles, the invention of the pill, the civil rights movement, second-wave feminism, punk rock or, really, anything at all.

Best of all, though, is the underused Ms. Burstyn, who makes her every scene pop. Flemming is brought in after a newsreel-style recap of Adaline‰Ûªs life in one of the movie‰Ûªs smartest, most effective and meaningful interludes. Adaline, for reasons that never really make sense, is on the verge of moving out of San Francisco, something she does every 10 years. The two women meet at a restaurant where, facing off in a booth, they rapidly assume their respective roles after Adaline maternally chides Flemming for using too much salt on her food. It‰Ûªs a familiar routine, and lovely. All at once, Ms. Burstyn, with just a few bobs of her head, a whine creeping into her voice and not an iota of digital help, transforms into a petulant adolescent. It‰Ûªs the most magical scene in the movie.
‰ÛÏThe Age of Adaline‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). There‰Ûªs a sad visit to a vet.

Movie people have been lapping at the fountain of youth since cinema‰Ûªs creation, both on-screen and off. That‰Ûªs no surprise given that cinema confers a kind of immortality on performers even if, as parades of tragically frozen faces attest, it can get confusing for the real people on camera. In Billy Wilder‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSunset Boulevard,‰Ûù Norma Desmond so deeply embodies this confusion that she punctuates a banal observation with a pitiful question: ‰ÛÏStars are ageless ‰ÛÓ aren‰Ûªt they?‰Ûù Norma may be a Hollywood tragedy, but the movie brilliantly proves that she‰Ûªs got the ageless part right.

What comes around goes around ‰ÛÓ gods, people, intimations of immortality. Adaline, alas, isn‰Ûªt resurrected with any special talents (not aging is more burden than gift for her, and certainly not an aptitude); the problem with this movie is that she isn‰Ûªt resurrected with much of a personality, either.

In ‰ÛÏThe Age of Adaline,‰Ûù Blake Lively plays the title character, a woefully under-conceptualized gimmick who, after a strange car accident ‰ÛÓ lightning flash, a cold bath, some narrated mumbo-jumbo ‰ÛÓ stops aging. Adaline becomes forever 29, but, like a few vampires, knows that immortality isn‰Ûªt all it‰Ûªs cracked up to be. Because while her clock stopped ticking in 1937, time kept on marching, of course, taking with it various loved ones, including a line of Cavalier dogs. By the time the present rolls around, Adaline has become an emotional shut-in. Her closest companion, outside the latest Cavalier, is her daughter, Flemming, who‰Ûªs played by Ellen Burstyn, who in turn played a woman who rises as a Christ-like healer after a car accident in ‰ÛÏResurrection‰Ûù (1980).

The filmmakers try to insist that time weighs heavily on Adaline, but there‰Ûªs little in J. Mills Goodloe and Salvador Paskowitz‰Ûªs script that suggests that the years have left her with much more than an expansive wardrobe and a knack for both languages and Trivial Pursuit. Far too often here, Adaline‰Ûªs parade of period dresses, coats and handbags stand in for the richness of human experience. The director Lee Toland Krieger is good with actors, especially in the expression of a low-key, unforced intimacy. And the movie features some very nice performances, including from Michiel Huisman, who plays Ellis, the equivalent of the modern prince charming (a.k.a. a tech millionaire), and a touching Harrison Ford as William, a mystery man who gives the story tears and heft.

A late entry in the weary Boston crime subgenre, ‰ÛÏThe Forger‰Ûù finds a morose John Travolta as a silver-maned convict named Ray Cutter. Less than a year away from the end of his sentence, Ray expedites his release by racking up a debt to a powerful bad guy. The reason for Ray‰Ûªs haste is that his teenage son, Will (Tye Sheridan), has a brain tumor and may not have long to live. But the payback is a dangerous job painting a fake Monet for the Museum of Fine Arts.
‰ÛÏThe Forger‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bad language, worse accents.

Mr. Travolta teeters between tough-guy menace and soulful, artistic intensity, but you don‰Ûªt ever believe that he can paint or that he can beat up a whole squad of younger, bigger, meaner dudes. He does both, of course, and whatever else the script (by Richard D‰ÛªOvidio) calls for. Toward the end, when ‰ÛÏThe Forger‰Ûù turns into a jaunty, silly caper, it shows a bit of energy, but otherwise it‰Ûªs by the numbers and an obvious fake.

Preposterousness is not necessarily a vice, and plausibility is a weak virtue. Just ask Alfred Hitchcock. So to say that the conceits of ‰ÛÏThe Forger‰Ûù (directed by Philip Martin) are ridiculous isn‰Ûªt really saying much. It‰Ûªs also dull, incoherent and drab to look at. There may be a glimmer of interest when Christopher Plummer shows up as Ray‰Ûªs con-man dad, and another when Will‰Ûªs drug-addict mother turns out to be Jennifer Ehle, but hope is quickly replaced by frustration that they had to waste their talents on a piece of straight-to-video hack work.

That‰Ûªs not necessarily a knock on ‰ÛÏThe Great Museum.‰Ûù There is still a fascination in seeing the care that goes into the placement of paintings and the upkeep of floors and walls. (Even the moth traps have an elaborate numbering system.) The camera whips through the hallways. The art itself is discussed mainly in regard to restoration, as when conservators analyze the layers of composition in a possible Rubens painting.

The director, Johannes Holzhausen, shot ‰ÛÏThe Great Museum‰Ûù during the preparations for the reopening of the Kunstkammer Wien, galleries that house extensive Hapsburg collections. Hovering over the movie ‰ÛÓ and its scenes of bureaucracy and budget discussions ‰ÛÓ is the question of how centuries-old art should be presented to a modern audience. One of the boardroom meetings dwells on the phrasing and font of two advertisements.

That question is also central to Mr. Wiseman‰Ûªs film, which had a knottier structure and a richer subtext. (You sense that Mr. Wiseman is commenting obliquely on his own body of work.) ‰ÛÏThe Great Museum,‰Ûù in comparison, feels like a cursory guided tour.

‰ÛÏThe Great Museum,‰Ûù filmed in 2012 and early 2013 in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, has the misfortune of arriving soon after Frederick Wiseman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNational Gallery,‰Ûù shot at roughly the same time at that museum in London. Each documentary observes the operations of a museum, and each has a nonintrusive style: no questions, no visible interruptions from the filmmakers and no identifications or title cards (at least until the end).

The film begins with a discussion of kaiseki, a centuries-old approach to the multicourse supper, before moving into fleeting and flattering profiles of prominent chefs, notably Nobu Matsuhisa, executive chef and owner of the Nobu chain of restaurants, who introduced Peruvian influences into Japanese food. Others on-screen include Katsuya Uechi, the man behind the Izaka-ya restaurants in Los Angeles, and Tyson Cole of the restaurant Uchi and its offshoots in Austin, Tex., and Houston.
But then ‰ÛÏWa-shoku‰Ûù gets back to its main concern: extolling the considerable rewards of ramen and sake, and the value of a good sharp knife in the kitchen.

Mouth-watering imagery abounds in Junichi Suzuki‰Ûªs diffuse documentary ‰ÛÏWa-shoku: Beyond Sushi,‰Ûù a study of the advent and popularity of Japanese cuisine in the United States. (The title comes from the term for traditional Japanese food.) But the film may leave you hungry for deeper insight into some its most renowned purveyors.

But the principal focus of ‰ÛÏWa-shoku‰Ûù is Noritoshi Kanai, now 92, chairman of the Mutual Trading Company, a food importing and distribution business in Los Angeles, who is widely credited with introducing sushi to the United States. Only in the film‰Ûªs portrait of Mr. Kanai do we glimpse the sacrifices and costs of success: his grief over a friend who died in wartime; his regret over not having spent enough time in the past with his children.
‰ÛÏBlackbird‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strongly suggested if not graphic sexual situations.
The earnest, laudable and heartfelt intentions of ‰ÛÏBlackbird‰Ûù carry it far ‰ÛÓ just not far enough.

Transplanting the book‰Ûªs setting from Los Angeles to Hattiesburg, Miss., ‰ÛÏBlackbird‰Ûù tells the story of Randy Rousseau (the newcomer Julian Walker), the star of his church choir and a creative force in his school‰Ûªs theater department. His friends Efrem (Gary L. Gray) and Crystal (Nikki Jane) joke with him about his possibly being gay, but despite his feverish homoerotic dreams and moony stares at the hunk Todd (Torrey Laamar), Randy denies it and resists his impulses. His religious, erratic mother (an overwrought Mo‰ÛªNique, from ‰ÛÏPrecious: Based on the Novel ‰Û÷Push‰Ûª by Sapphire‰Ûù) has been half-addled since her daughter went missing long ago, and Randy has been drilled with notions about sin.

There are wonderful actors here: Mr. Allesee has an unforced naturalism, and Mr. Gray has a winning affability. In a brief but vivid role as Randy‰Ûªs estranged father, Isaiah Washington is a paragon of paternal concern and understanding. But plot threads keep wandering astray: An intriguing high school production of ‰ÛÏRomeo and Julian‰Ûù is cut short; the subplot about Randy‰Ûªs sister has a cursory and unconvincing conclusion; and Randy and Marshall‰Ûªs film about sexual violence has changed into a gauzy valentine to Randy, directed by Marshall, that has him on a swing set and features a close-up of his clothed rear end. As for Mr. Walker, he may be heavy-lidded and attractive, but more acting experience would do him good.

At an audition for a student film about gay rape, Randy meets another actor, Marshall (Kevin Allesee), a gay 21-year-old who lives in a trailer park with his accepting parents. Marshall teaches Randy to embrace his longings, and Randy is off on a voyage of sexual discovery that includes visits to a cruising spot, a gay-friendly bar and Marshall‰Ûªs bed. It‰Ûªs not long before Randy‰Ûªs mother and a local minister (Terrell Tilford) discover his leanings and try to force him to renounce his identity.

There‰Ûªs impressive, palpable conviction in Patrik-Ian Polk‰Ûªs drama ‰ÛÏBlackbird,‰Ûù an adaptation ‰ÛÓ written by Mr. Polk and Rikki Beadle Blair ‰ÛÓ of Larry Duplechan‰Ûªs 1986 novel about a young black man‰Ûªs coming out. But despite its sense of mission, the film suffers from soapy excesses and narrative disjunctures.
‰ÛÏIris‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Shopping.

She prefers the descriptor ‰ÛÏgeriatric starlet‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ her turns of phrase are as vibrantly ornamented as her body ‰ÛÓ a celebrity that led to swarming fans, interviews, magazine spreads and of course this documentary. She clearly enjoys the attention, even if it sometimes seems to carry the sour whiff of condescension. Every so often in the documentary, you can hear someone who isn‰Ûªt part of the movie team talk to Ms. Apfel in the patronizing tones that some reserve for old folks, children, foreigners and ‰ÛÏthe help,‰Ûù as if they were speaking to someone stupid when it‰Ûªs the reverse. Mr. Maysles, working with a small crew, doesn‰Ûªt comment on these moments, but his point of view is evident in every camera angle and edit in this exactingly constructed documentary.

There are few better ways right now to spend 80 movie minutes than to see ‰ÛÏIris,‰Ûù a delightful eye-opener about life, love, statement eyeglasses, bracelets the size of tricycle tires and the art of making the grandest of entrances. Directed by Albert Maysles ‰ÛÓ one half of the legendary documentary team that made ‰ÛÏGrey Gardens‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ this is a documentary about a very different kind of woman who holds your imagination from the moment she appears. You can‰Ûªt take your eyes off Iris Apfel (she wouldn‰Ûªt have it any other way), but, then, why would you want to?

You may have seen her before, peering out of a luxury magazine in a gaudy fur cloud in a jewelry advertisement or, in another campaign, cozily perched on a park bench alongside the model Karlie Kloss. Ms. Kloss wears all white; Ms. Apfel, her customary bold palette muted, wears blue socks with white polka dots, tee-ready green slacks and a dusky rose coat, a large white bow tied around her neck. The bow makes her look like a gift, which, in a way, she is. As you discover, she would prefer you look at the bow than try to untie it to see what lies beneath. You get the bullet-point versions of her life both in talking-head interviews and while she‰Ûªs on the somewhat slow, but persistent run: She was born in Queens, in 1921, and married a charmer named Carl Apfel, with whom she ran a textile company and engaged in extreme globe-trotting. They never had children; they had each other. They also had the obvious means to collect an astonishment of luxury items and cut-rate stuff, some of which she wears, some of which she lives with, like the oversized replica of the RCA dog, plush toys, statuary, ornate vases and gilt mirrors.

A few years ago, Architectural Digest described Ms. Apfel‰Ûªs Park Avenue apartment as looking ‰ÛÏa little as if the Collyer brothers had moved in with Madame de Pompadour.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs a clever bit of journalistic acid, but the documentary paints a vividly contrary picture. A radical individualist, Ms. Apfel embodies a profoundly alternative reality and another kind of truth, one that may be threatening to some. Writers tend to deploy words like kooky, eccentric and so forth when describing her style, when, mostly, I think, they mean ‰ÛÏdoes not compute.‰Ûù There‰Ûªs an uneasiness to even some of this praise, a disquiet that, in the movie, you see and hear in certain words and looks. Are these people admiring or threatened? It‰Ûªs hard to know, just as it‰Ûªs tough to tell if the patronizing tones are because of her age, looks or both. What is clear is that while there are several stories folded into ‰ÛÏIris‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a marriage tale, an ode to multiculturalism and a fashion spectacular ‰ÛÓ it is also about the insistent rejection of monocultural conformity.

‰ÛÏIris‰Ûù is the second-to-last documentary from Mr. Maysles, who died on March 5. (His final is ‰ÛÏIn Transit.‰Ûù) Mr. Maysles, with his brother, David (who died in 1987), directed a number of genre-defining documentaries, including ‰ÛÏSalesman,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGimme Shelter‰Ûù and, of course, ‰ÛÏGrey Gardens.‰Ûù In that film, the brothers defy direct-cinema conventions by inserting themselves into the picture, a potential transgression that personalizes the movie all the more. In some documentaries, the director prefers to stay out of sight and perhaps out of mind. Here, though, Mr. Maysles pops up again, both on camera and as an out-of-frame presence that Ms. Apfel addresses. These moments pierce the heart because he‰Ûªs now gone and because, you sense, that this portrait of a glorious rebel is also and unmistakably a self-portrait.

You could furnish a couple of flats with all the furniture and tchotchkes that adorn the Apfels‰Ûª homes, including one apartment on Park Avenue and another in Palm Beach. (She appears to be the family shopper, at least these days.) You could fill an exhibition with all of her outfits, which is, on a modest level, what the Metropolitan Museum of Art did with ‰ÛÏRara Avis: Selections From the Iris Apfel Collection,‰Ûù which opened in September 2005. In the movie, Harold Koda, the curator in charge of the museum‰Ûªs Costume Institute, discusses the pragmatic reasons and artistic rationale for highlighting objects from Ms. Apfel‰Ûªs voluminous holdings. A smash, the exhibition dazzled fashion insiders and traveled to other museums. It also turned Ms. Apfel into a star.

The film‰Ûªs most glaring omission, however, is independent musical commentary. Without it, you won‰Ûªt be convinced that Spandau Ballet was the best band of the 1980s. Even if they did have the best bums.

The film agrees, celebrating tailoring over Tony Hadley‰Ûªs killer pop voice or Gary Kemp‰Ûªs smart, tight lyrics. Maintaining a sunny, scrubbed-clean tone, Ms. Hencken allows no possibility of dazed groupies or drunken meltdowns ‰ÛÓ and only the briefest whiff of cocaine ‰ÛÓ to darken her portrait. And when Mr. Kemp and his brother, Martin Kemp, take a 1990 detour into acting with the rather terrific gangster movie, ‰ÛÏThe Krays,‰Ûù we don‰Ûªt even get a clip of their wonderfully cool performances.

And who‰Ûªs to argue, when the five band members dominate the film‰Ûªs commentary? Chattering over vintage film of council-house living rooms and London clubs, the men discuss early musical influences with a relaxed charm that softens the often harsh economic realities of the time. As we slide nostalgically through the 1978-79 garbage collectors‰Ûª strike (the so-called winter of discontent that ushered in Margaret Thatcher) and the Falklands War, the band‰Ûªs danceable beats discourage depression. As do their extravagant outfits: Sporting clobber more suited to a medieval minstrel or a Bedouin, the members knew that peacocking was at least as important as playing.

Perfectly timed to coincide with Spandau Ballet‰Ûªs current reunion tour, ‰ÛÏSoul Boys of the Western World‰Ûù is a cheekily self-serving account of the English group‰Ûªs rise to glory in the 1980s and its later dissolution. Working with only pre-existing footage, the director, George Hencken, constructs an unabashedly promotional tale of working-class aspiration and worldwide acclaim.

There are also details and characters that link the parts of the film, though the main continuities are stylistic. Mr. Gout favors restless camerawork and syncopated editing, which is both engaging and somewhat superficial. And not every panel in the triptych is equally persuasive. The 2010 kidnapping of a wealthy businessman whose wife (Dolores Heredia) uncovers his secrets as she tries to save his life feels a bit thin. The relationship, in 2006, between a kidnapping victim (Carlos Bardem) and one of his young captors (Kristyan Ferrer) teeters on the edge of sentimentality.

But ‰ÛÏDays of Grace‰Ûù is a potent and vigorous film. It may not illuminate the depths or explore the causes of Mexico‰Ûªs crisis, but it mines that crisis for memorable images and dramatic scenes. And while Mr. Gout seems pessimistic about his country, he is not entirely cynical about human nature, or for that matter about movies.

In 2002, with the soccer taking place in South Korea and Japan, the protagonist is Lupe (Tenoch Huerta), a young, ambitious cop who insists on believing in right and wrong. He‰Ûªs a hothead and a bit of a bully, but his devotion to the memory of the great peasant revolutionary Emiliano Zapata, whose photograph hangs from his rearview mirror, identifies Lupe as an idealist and a patriot. He is also a new father, and the vulnerability that family brings is a thread that connects his story with the others.

‰ÛÏDays of Grace,‰Ûù the debut feature from Everardo Gout, a Mexican filmmaker with a background in music videos and television commercials, weaves together three stories of violence and corruption in Mexico City. Braided narratives are a way for directors both to show off their chops and to illuminate social issues and complex themes. Mr. Gout combines a slick, kinetic style with a somber ethical sense. His movie is flashy and entertaining, but also earnestly concerned with the collapse of trust and integrity at every level of society.

Though it may take a while to figure out what‰Ûªs going on, the three plot lines take place during successive World Cups, in 2002, 2006 and 2010. At the center of each is a kidnapping, which produces opportunities for clever sleight-of-hand editing. Mr. Gout and his tremendously talented cinematographer, Luis David Sansans (whose credits include Alfonso CuarÌ_n‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏY Tu Mama Tambien‰Ûù and Baz Luhrmann‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRomeo+Juliet‰Ûù), use different color schemes and aspect ratios to signal where we are in time. The music (by Nick Cave and Atticus Ross, among others) also changes, and soccer fans will be able to identify which high-stakes match is distracting the attention of various criminals, police officers and ordinary citizens.

Not that such distinctions are easy to make. There are no clear boundaries between victims and perpetrators, or between the authorities and the outlaws. ‰ÛÏPeople think we‰Ûªre referees,‰Ûù a police commander says to one of his underlings. ‰ÛÏBut we‰Ûªre players. And we have to win.‰Ûù Winning turns out to mean acquiring power rather than dispensing justice.

These too-short interludes of the Black Widow grappling with a difficult love interest modestly humanize the movie, which helps a bit with both its rhythm and scale, making it less of a monotonous special-effects blowout. Repeatedly, Mr. Whedon injects something alive into the mix, be it a woman‰Ûªs fingers tenderly caressing a computer-generated wrist or children leaping into a father‰Ûªs embrace. This assertion of flesh-and-blood vulnerability extends to several narrative points, including a nod at the military industrial complex that is almost touchingly pointless given how much of this movie has been dedicated to ensuring obliterating violence looks cool. Even the villainous alien, Ultron, playfully voiced with mellifluous menace by James Spader, philosophically chews the cud about humankind.

Another summer season, another superhero spectacular ‰ÛÓ these are the days (and nights) of our moviegoing lives. The one under review today, Marvel‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAvengers: Age of Ultron,‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt half-bad, largely because of its director, Joss Whedon. Here‰Ûªs a guess: Some viewers will love it, others will hate it, and still others will yawn at its very existence. None of this matters because the most relevant thing about a movie like this is that its quality is almost entirely irrelevant. It was created to crush the box office, entertainment media and audience resistance, and mission, you know, already accomplished. In an age of lock-step entertainment, pushback isn‰Ûªt just immaterial; it is also suspect.

This is a familiar lament, especially from those of us who didn‰Ûªt grow up worshiping at the altar of Stan Lee et al. or don‰Ûªt watch movies based on brand affiliation. (Guilty!) It‰Ûªs a good question whether the big studios‰Ûª dependence on comic books is hurting American mainstream cinema and whether they can figure out how to survive without suckling at Marvel‰Ûªs great multiplatform teat. For a Marvel agnostic like me, the single most interesting thing about ‰ÛÏAge of Ultron‰Ûù is that you can sense that Mr. Whedon, having helped build a universal earnings machine with the first ‰ÛÏAvengers,‰Ûù has now struggled mightily, touchingly, to invest this behemoth with some life.
‰ÛÏAvengers: Age of Ultron‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The usual bloodless mayhem and massacre.

If you‰Ûªre not acquainted with the intricacies of the Marvel universe, it can be hard to keep track of who‰Ûªs doing what to whom and especially why. In story terms, the movie ‰ÛÓ Mr. Whedon wrote ‰ÛÏAge of Ultron‰Ûù as well as directed ‰ÛÓ is outlandishly overpacked, taking place on multiple fronts against various foes both terrestrial and galactic. Mr. Whedon opens with one of those Bond-style blowouts that‰Ûªs so old-fashioned it even includes a Nazi-type villain, Strucker, whom the German actor Thomas Kretschmann plays all too briefly with a sneer and a monocle. Strucker evokes the continental cads ÌÊ la Erich von Stroheim and is meant to be a Mengele type whose work has produced a special set of twins: the Scarlet Witch (Elizabeth Olsen) and Quicksilver (Aaron Taylor-Johnson).

Mr. Whedon chews over the same in ‰ÛÏAge of Ultron‰Ûù (war and people, what are they good for?) in his efforts to personalize the material while dutifully hitting all the genre notes. This ‰ÛÏAvengers‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt always pop the way that the first one sometimes did, partly because its villain isn‰Ûªt as memorable, despite Mr. Spader‰Ûªs silky threat. And, as is often the case in these comic-book movies, most of the fights are interminable and fatiguing, though Mr. Whedon does fold in moments of beauty, including when the image slows down with each Avenger centered in the frame both together and individually. This centering crystallizes the dynamic that is paramount to the Avengers story and also suggests the behind-the-scenes push-and-pull battle that Mr. Whedon has waged over two movies.

The upshot here is a movie that lumbers along like a front-line tank, hauling the enormous weight of the entire Marvel enterprise along with it, only to routinely work itself into a frenzy of action and then (shades of the Buffyverse) chill out with scenes of relaxed camaraderie, challenging romance and domestic intimacy. A lot of effort has been expended so that the Hulk can make like a big baby with tantrum issues, tossing cars and whatnot around like toys, including in a disastrously protracted street brawl that stops the movie dead. Once the character reverts to ordinary form as Bruce Banner, though, Mr. Ruffalo lifts his every scene, as does Ms. Johansson, even if she doesn‰Ûªt have much to do but strut in her form-fitting costume and exchange meaningful looks with a romantic foil.

He has and he hasn‰Ûªt ‰ÛÓ in a movie that is by turns a diverting and dreary blur of babbling and fighting that translates into faces in close-ups or bodies in longer shots. The gang‰Ûªs all here, of course, including the billionaire egoist Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.); the straightedge hero, Captain America (Chris Evans); the E.T. Viking with the hammer and hair, Thor (Chris Hemsworth); the token chick, Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson); some dude with arrows, Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner); and that computer-assisted leviathan, the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo). Rounding out the A-listers is Samuel L. Jackson, who as Nick Fury brings a beautiful bald skull along with an Old Testament vibe and a black leather coat straight out of Shaft‰Ûªs closet. Mr. Jackson has a nine-movie deal with Marvel; he has two more to go.

Like much of the rest of the main cast, Ms. Olsen and Mr. Taylor-Johnson are appealing, attractive performers who usually show up in independent productions that probably cost less to make than this one‰Ûªs craft-services bill. Their newness to this world distinguishes them when the screen becomes too crowded; so do the intensity of their contrapuntal performances and the pathos of their characters‰Ûª back story as refugees turned lab rats. Mr. Whedon is a sensitive director of actors, as he showed for years while shepherding ‰ÛÏBuffy the Vampire Slayer.‰Ûù His characters banter and quip like screwball loons while parading their cultural literacy (here, someone name-drops Eugene O‰ÛªNeill), but these are linguistic fig leaves for men and women who feel and hurt deeply.

Sparks from the friction between a cranky old man and a mouthy spitfire who suggests a downscale Ellen Page drive the rest of the movie. Dylan, who initially claims her parents are circus performers working in Europe but eventually admits that they are ‰ÛÏlosers,‰Ûù is a manipulative liar and petty thief who boasts that she has invented a literary genre, the ‰ÛÏaction romanture.‰Ûù A sample of her fiction reveals her to be utterly devoid of basic writing skills. Somehow she has wangled a meeting with a West Coast publisher.

Why another road movie about bickering mismatched travelers warily making friends on a cross-country journey? That clichÌ© weighs heavily on ‰ÛÏCas & Dylan,‰Ûù the feature film directorial debut of Jason Priestley (known mostly from his acting role on ‰ÛÏBeverly Hills 90210‰Ûù), even after you queasily succumb to the sentimentality of this formulaic two-hander.

Cas, who plans to kill himself, is working on his suicide note but can‰Ûªt seem to come up with a final farewell. There is a sweet little moment when they have dinner with an aged married couple who are still deeply in love after 54 years together. Afterward, Dylan gets the movie‰Ûªs sharpest remark when she comments, ‰ÛÏThey‰Ûªre like the Cleavers on ketamine.‰Ûù

Cas and Dylan meet by chance outside the hospital where Cas works. An inveterate hitchhiker, Dylan pressures Cas to give her a lift to the shack she shares with her abusive boyfriend, Bobby (Christopher Cordell). Cas drops her off, but before he can escape, Bobby chases Dylan out of the house with a gun, she jumps back into the car, and in his haste to leave, Cas accidentally hits Bobby. Mortified by the possibility that Bobby might be dead, the two flee. For the rest of the movie, Cas and Dylan are stuck with each other.

This Canadian movie, from a screenplay by Jessie Gabe, begins in Winnipeg and ends in Vancouver and jounces along on the crackle of smart-aleck dialogue mouthed by its stars, Richard Dreyfuss and Tatiana Maslany (of ‰ÛÏOrphan Black‰Ûù). When the banter sputters, there is always the glorious scenery along the Trans-Canada Highway to divert you.
Ms. Maslany portrays his unwelcome passenger, Dylan Morgan, a scruffy young woman who fancies herself a writer and needs a ride to Vancouver to see a publisher.

Mr. Dreyfuss‰Ûªs character, Dr. Cas Pepper (the last name is good for half a chuckle), is an alternately glum and blustery physician dying from a malignant, inoperable brain tumor. Cas is bound for the Pacific Coast and a resting place not only for himself but for his dead dog, whose corpse he keeps in a cooler in the back of his car.

Bachelor No. 3 is a military officer named Francis Troy (Tom Sturridge), who in a scene with no Freudian implications whatsoever impresses Bathsheba with his skilled swordsmanship. He has a former sweetheart (Juno Temple) and a fondness for vice that alarms Oak and intimidates Boldwood.

At that point, Gabriel (though for obvious reasons everybody prefers his last name) is relatively prosperous and Bathsheba is penniless. After he loses his small farm and she inherits a much bigger one from her uncle, an awkward gulf opens between them. She hires him to tend her sheep, and he watches as she toys with the affections of William Boldwood (Michael Sheen), a neighbor with an even bigger farm and an even manlier last name. (When it comes to the evocative christening of his characters, Hardy rivals Dickens and Shakespeare himself.)

When Thomas Hardy first brought her to life in 1874 in his novel ‰ÛÏFar From the Madding Crowd,‰Ûù Bathsheba was both a bracingly modern character and part of a lively literary sorority going back at least to the novels of Jane Austen. When the book was brought to the screen in 1967, in a slower-moving, sexier version directed by John Schlesinger, Bathsheba was played by Julie Christie, one of that era‰Ûªs great incarnations of youthful glamour and freedom. The latest adaptation, probably not the last, is a swifter and more superficial movie, directed by Thomas Vinterberg and starring Carey Mulligan. Her Bathsheba is brisk and practical, frank and friendly, and a little impatient with the trio of suitors who admire her moxie even as they compete for the honor of suppressing it.

Through it all, Ms. Mulligan smirks, sighs and sniffles, Mr. Schoenaerts smolders, Mr. Sheen scowls and Mr. Sturridge enjoys his mustache. They are all fun to watch, though only Mr. Schoenaerts seems interested in testing the deeper currents of longing, shame and pride that course beneath the surface. The most obvious thing to say about ‰ÛÏFar From the Madding Crowd‰Ûù is also the most bizarre, given the source material. It‰Ûªs buoyant, pleasant and easygoing. That‰Ûªs a recommendation of sorts, and also an expression of disappointment.
‰ÛÏFar From the Madding Crowd‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Sighs, smirks, sexy swordplay.
Not because she doesn‰Ûªt like him ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs clear that she likes him best ‰ÛÓ but because the prospect of marrying makes no sense to her.

They are not bad guys. Well, one of them may be, but he‰Ûªs also the only one who appeals to Bathsheba‰Ûªs less rational side. All three, however, are satellites orbiting the planet of her will, which makes ‰ÛÏFar From the Madding Crowd‰Ûù feel like an unusually fresh and surprising romantic comedy. That‰Ûªs not quite what Hardy or the filmmakers (David Nicholls wrote the script) intended: The story calls for two fatal gunshots and two more tragic and untimely deaths, and the musical score (by Craig Armstrong) swells with melodramatic portent. But for all that ‰ÛÓ and for the requisite lingering over landscapes and livestock; the scenes of peasant heartiness and genteel reserve; the frocks and hats and Victorian facial hair ‰ÛÓ there is some fun to be had on this carefully decorated merry-go-round.

‰ÛÏFar From the Madding Crowd‰Ûù passes a kind of reverse Bechdel test: Nearly every time two or more men converse, they are talking about a woman. When they talk to her, she often responds like one of the women in Mallory Ortberg‰Ûªs hilariously captioned online surveys of Western art history, who generally have better things to do than listen to men. When Gabriel Oak, a farmer played with understated but unmistakable virility by Matthias Schoenaerts, proposes to Bathsheba shortly after they have exchanged glances over a rustic fence, she brusquely refuses.

The narrative conspires to make Bathsheba choose and choose again until she gets it right, and her mistakes and spells of indecision are engaging without feeling terribly consequential. The mood of the film is less Hardy-esque than vaguely Hardy-ish. He rooted his chronicles of desire and its thwarting in a closely observed world of agricultural labor and ancient custom, an earthiness conveyed here by the occasional shot of a toad or a snail and a few bouts of hearty off-key singing. Hardy‰Ûªs interest in the operations of accident and caprice ‰ÛÓ in the ‰ÛÏpurblind Doomsters‰Ûù who governed human fate ‰ÛÓ is reduced to a few plot points. A feckless dog chases a flock of sheep over a cliff. A bride goes to the wrong church on her wedding day. It all feels a little flimsy.

Bathsheba Everdene ‰ÛÓ if the last name sounds familiar, that‰Ûªs because she‰Ûªs an acknowledged feminist foremother of the ‰ÛÏHunger Games‰Ûù heroine ‰ÛÓ is faced with a series of complicated choices. Really, though, her predicament is simple: She wants to live on her own terms in a society where a woman‰Ûªs freedom is tightly circumscribed by custom and expectation. As she tries to figure out what she wants to do and who she wants to be, the world keeps pushing her to answer a different question: Which man will she marry?

A second Scandinavian structure, the Oslo Opera House, and the Centre Pompidou in Paris get differently lackluster entries, but all six are lighter works than, say, the kind of movies about architecture that Heinz Emigholz has made. Still, with a film running in two parts, at a combined length of 168 minutes, you might wish you could walk on by certain stretches instead of staying seated.

As houses of God, Europe‰Ûªs cathedrals were built to be something more than mere stone, something that could transport and transform. In the omnibus film ‰ÛÏCathedrals of Culture,‰Ûù subtitled ‰ÛÏA 3D Film Project About the Soul of Buildings,‰Ûù the secular structures on display are scarcely less ambitious, and the strongest of the film‰Ûªs six chapters reflect filmmakers searching to express higher states of being.

Michael Glawogger‰Ûªs homey ramble through the century-old National Library of Russia features a pastiche of quotations from literature (spoken in a nearly disastrous mix of Russian and English voice-overs). Michael Madsen‰Ûªs ethereal view of the new Halden Prison in Norway shows a kind of enlightened institution probably unrecognizable to most Americans, given added frisson by its fey voice-over. (The talented Wolfgang Thaler shot both entries.)

Wim Wenders establishes the film‰Ûªs approach of gliding tours and anthropomorphic voice-over with his maternally proud look at the Berlin Philharmonic. Mr. Wenders lets us breathe in the airy, democratic spaces of Hans Scharoun‰Ûªs postwar panoptic concert hall. Robert Redford, aided by the light-tripping cinematographer Ed Lachman, tries a similar tribute to the mind-clearing geometries of the Salk Institute in San Diego, but the tunes by Moby and koans by the architect Louis Kahn give it a promotional flow.

Before long, the men are tramping through the desert, where step by step, over one and then another crest, they walk and periodically speak, sharing meals and assorted dangers. With the director of photography Guillaume Deffontaines, Mr. Oelhoffen conveys the striking, multicolored glories of this rough landscape, with all its sun-shot gradations of red and brown, without descending into picture-postcard banality. (The movie was shot in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco.) Many of the movie‰Ûªs most effective scenes involve the men just walking through this extraordinary landscape, the warring splendor and harshness of their surroundings ‰ÛÓ equally inviting and foreboding ‰ÛÓ as seemingly at odds as the attraction-repulsion that initially defines Daru and Mohamed‰Ûªs relationship.

In ‰ÛÏFar From Men,‰Ûù Viggo Mortensen, his sharply planed face weathered and solemn, plays a man who looks as if he were quarried right out of the hard red-rock earth. He plays Daru, a teacher who imparts the names of French rivers to eager Algerian children in a small white schoolhouse that‰Ûªs nestled in a valley and ringed by jagged desert mountains. There‰Ûªs something haunted about this wildly beautiful place with its thirsty ground and sparse vegetation, though only partly because the story takes place in 1954, the year the fight for Algerian independence ignited.

One day, a gendarme, Balducci (Vincent Martin), rides up on horseback to Daru‰Ûªs schoolhouse with an Arab prisoner, Mohamed (Reda Kateb), on foot. Balducci explains that the prisoner, who‰Ûªs never named in the Camus story, has cut the throat of a cousin (‰ÛÏlike a sheep‰Ûù) and now Daru needs to take Mohamed to another town for some French justice and certain death. Daru refuses, but when Balducci rides off, the teacher is left with Mohamed and a quandary. After giving Mohamed dinner and a bed, and after a restive night with a gun by his side, Daru wakes to tell Mohamed that he can leave of his own accord. This seems as if it should be an easy call, but Daru‰Ûªs assumptions about free will don‰Ûªt pan out. Mohamed refuses to flee.

Although astringent by mainstream movie standards, ‰ÛÏFar From Men‰Ûù is shored up with increasingly personalized conversations between Daru and Mohamed that explain the men, their lives and times. At one point, they come across a small detachment of Algerian guerrillas that includes Slimane (Djemel Barek), a former army compatriot of Daru‰Ûªs, and which for a short, eventful interlude swallows the travelers up. Mr. Oelhoffen sometimes explains too much, but his work with the actors is precise and delicate. Both Mr. Kateb and Mr. Mortensen, who deliver their dialogue in Arabic and French (Mr. Mortensen also speaks a little Spanish), are generous performers and they share the screen easily. They‰Ûªre playing nomads from separate histories and cultures who, in their radical isolation, turn out to be right at home.

A tale of two rootless strangers, ‰ÛÏFar From Men‰Ûù takes its inspiration from an Albert Camus short story that was first published in his collection ‰ÛÏExile and the Kingdom‰Ûù (1957). The movie is considerably more sentimental than the Camus, which is as arid as its stark milieu and absent a ray of hope. The French writer-director David Oelhoffen fills in some of the narrative‰Ûªs meaningful blanks with extra characters, back histories, low-key action scenes and a central relationship that feels, by turns, true and like wishful thinking. Camus sets the movie‰Ûªs initial course, but Mr. Oelhoffen resolutely steers it home with political context, historical hindsight, an unambiguous moral imperative and a pair of well-matched performances; put another way, he makes the story his own.

Coming from the director of ‰ÛÏNo Skin Off My Ass‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Raspberry Reich,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGerontophilia‰Ûù might sound like just another gleefully raunchy provocation: An 18-year-old man is uncontrollably attracted to old men, despite being involved with a spirited, radical-minded young woman. But the mild style that the filmmaker Bruce LaBruce slips on for his new feature is that of tastefully observed indie romance, flavored with a sweetly droll sense of humor but never to the point of undermining the sincerity of its intentions.

Sex is often a life-giving force in Mr. LaBruce‰Ûªs films (quite literally, in ‰ÛÏL.A. Zombie‰Ûù), and Lake, besides ringing his own bell, gives Melvyn a libidinal lift and an escape from a pill-fueled slide into decrepitude. But while the director and his editor, Glenn Berman, elegantly and musically usher scenes along, and segue from self-discovery tale into May-December road trip, Mr. Lajoie doesn‰Ûªt stir up much feeling beyond admiration of his dewily pretty looks.

Lake (the model Pier-Gabriel Lajoie) is the teenager with a yen for those of retirement age and up. He fixates on Melvyn Peabody (Walter Borden), a witty 81-year-old patient at the assisted-living facility where he works. Lake spends hours drunkenly playing cards with Mr. Peabody ‰ÛÓ later, just ‰ÛÏMelvyn‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and his make-out buddy, DÌ©sirÌ©e (Katie Boland), panics upon discovering his sketchbook of octogenarian nudes.

Mr. Borden, an acclaimed Canadian stage actor and playwright, turns in a slyly entertaining performance. But the relationship between Lake and Melvyn feels a bit more one-sided than perhaps was intended.
Warning: ‰ÛÏHyena,‰Ûù like that cocaine, is bad for you.

Like Al Pacino‰Ûªs Tony Montana in ‰ÛÏScarface,‰Ûù Mr. Ferdinando‰Ûªs Michael fortifies his failing courage by snorting coke as his fateful rendezvous with the Albanians approaches. The anesthetic effects of that white powder are his only protection.

‰ÛÏHyena,‰Ûù Gerard Johnson‰Ûªs corrupt-cop drama, is the kind of gory British policier from which you come away with the queasy feeling that the world is essentially a butcher shop ruled by greed, murder, cruelty and lust. American equivalents like ‰ÛÏBad Lieutenant‰Ûù at least have a moral compass, however twisted. British crime films in a similar mode (I‰Ûªm thinking particularly of ‰ÛÏFilth‰Ûù) begin from the Hobbesian presumption that, as Mick Jagger sings in ‰ÛÏSympathy for the Devil,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏevery cop is a criminal.‰Ûù

Human trafficking is another of the Albanians‰Ûª pursuits. In an especially ugly scene, Ariana (Elisa Lasowski), one of the two women in this ultramacho caper, is injected with heroin and raped while unconscious by an Albanian thug after Michael is seen stealing into the office where she is guarding the brothers‰Ûª financial accounts. Michael, who is not entirely evil, finds her a place to stay, and his girlfriend, Lisa (MyAnna Buring), watches over her. But he is no match for the new kingpins with whom he strikes a tentative bargain that will net him one-third of their business.

This film‰Ûªs baddies are persuasively embodied by a crew of actors, many of whom have thick, often impenetrable accents, playing the tainted louts on a narcotics task force in West London. Their leader, Michael Logan (Peter Ferdinando), is a coke-addicted rogue cop in league with a Turkish drug-smuggling ring. In the sickening opening scene, two Albanian brothers, muscling in on the Turks‰Ûª territory, storm into the basement of a nightclub and pulverize a rival in an orgy of hacking and sawing, as Michael watches from a hiding place. In a later scene, the cutting up and disposal of freshly chopped corpses leaves the Albanians drenched in viscera like a pair of Sweeney Todds.

The strongest elements of this film, which adds nothing new to the subgenre, are its atmospheric, smeared-lipstick cinematography and Mr. Ferdinando‰Ûªs portrayal of an arrogant, double-dealing crook who meets his match not only in the Albanians but in a former adversary (Stephen Graham), whom he unwisely brings to the scheme.

The film‰Ûªs messages about friendship, acceptance and being yourself are clear enough for the young, and grown-ups can read the story as a warning about conformity and about going to war on false pretenses.

Maya (voiced by Coco Jack Gillies) is a young bee who hears nothing but ‰ÛÏdon‰Ûªts‰Ûù from grown-ups: ‰ÛÏBees don‰Ûªt dream‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBees don‰Ûªt sing‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBees don‰Ûªt have fun.‰Ûù But her curiosity and spirit are not to be stifled, and soon she finds herself outside the hive and on a wide-ranging adventure where she learns that the things we‰Ûªre taught to fear sometimes aren‰Ûªt all that fearsome.
‰ÛÏMaya the Bee Movie‰Ûù is a sweet, colorful animated story aimed at young children. Let‰Ûªs just hope no actual bees watch it.

Honeybees have been mysteriously dying in recent years, raising concerns that there won‰Ûªt be enough of them to do the pollinating job bees are supposed to do. So we don‰Ûªt need any of the remaining bees hearing the message of this film‰Ûªs title character, who thinks her kind should not be content merely to perform their assigned roles.
That includes hornets, the bees‰Ûª sworn enemies. Maya becomes instrumental in heading off a bee-hornet confrontation, as well as in thwarting an internal plot against the beloved queen bee.

Jackie takes many spills but refuses to give up. With each dousing you silently applaud her humiliation. Even when she is finally able to stand up on a surfboard and ride the waves beside her son, you hope to heaven that he can somehow escape her toxic clutches.

Even so, she decides to give it a try. The moment Jackie wades into the Pacific determined to prove that any reasonably fit person can surf without help is the point at which ‰ÛÏRide‰Ûù takes leave of its senses and becomes fatally waterlogged. Realizing she can‰Ûªt learn the sport without a teacher, she takes lessons with Ian (Luke Wilson), a convenient love interest who reacquaints her with marijuana and with her libido.

A more accurate title for ‰ÛÏRide,‰Ûù a wobbly underdeveloped comedy starring Helen Hunt, who directed and wrote the screenplay, would be ‰ÛÏHow I Learned to Surf.‰Ûù As an instructional movie on the sport, ‰ÛÏRide‰Ûù offers some useful tips, but beyond that, it feels like a slightly bizarre vanity project.

Ms. Hunt‰Ûªs character, Jackie, is a high-strung New Yorker editor who is never at a loss for a stridently voiced opinion. Divorced and in her 40s, this micromanaging harridan is a repellent caricature of a familiar East Coast type. Convinced of her own invincibility and rightness, she seems to have no relationships other than with her college-bound 18-year-old son, Angelo (Brenton Thwaites), an aspiring author. With him, she is an arrogant, intrusive bully who evaluates his writing with a crushing insensitivity.

Not long after Angelo leaves the nest, Jackie learns that he has dropped out of college and is staying in Santa Monica, Calif., with his father‰Ûªs family. Playing detective, she heads to the West Coast, hires a driver and tracks her son to the beach, where she finds him surfing, an activity she views with towering contempt.
‰ÛÏRide‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language and some drug use.

The movie refuses to condescend to Alice or to her chosen medium. The less prestigious kinds of television ‰ÛÓ shopping shows, daytime self-help series, off-brand reality spectacles ‰ÛÓ have a way of simultaneously inviting and defeating irony.

Based on that description, you might be tempted to say the same about ‰ÛÏWelcome to Me,‰Ûù which is the name of a new movie directed by Shira Piven from a screenplay by Eliot Laurence and starring Kristen Wiig as Alice. Just describing the film is equivalent to listing the many ways it could have gone wrong. To build a comedy around the predicament of a mentally ill main character is to risk either gross insensitivity or a maudlin romanticism that is just as offensive. To take up the subject of subprime television is to court banality and bad faith. But ‰ÛÏWelcome to Me,‰Ûù while not perfect, is the opposite of a disaster. By turns touching, amusing and genuinely disturbing, it defies expectations and easy categorization, forgoing obvious laughs and cheap emotional payoffs in favor of something much odder and more interesting.

That ‰ÛÏsomething‰Ûù has a lot to do with Ms. Wiig, who embraces Alice‰Ûªs outlandish notions and cross-wired emotions with compassion and integrity. As a sketch-comedy performer and a supporting player in movies like ‰ÛÏDate Night‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAnchorman 2,‰Ûù Ms. Wiig has proved herself to be a resourceful and disciplined goofball. She is also a subtle and serious actress, a fact that has manifested itself, in very different ways, in ‰ÛÏBridesmaids,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏHateship Loveship‰Ûù and the Sundance favorite ‰ÛÏThe Diary of a Teenage Girl,‰Ûù opening in August.

In exchange for attention, however distracted or derisive, they offer therapy. The spirit-affirming gobbledygook that Alice spouts is not all that different from what is dispensed by her saner real-life counterparts, who collect rather than pay out millions of dollars for the chance to share their wisdom with the rest of us. But like them, she provides what the people on the other side of the screen really want ‰ÛÓ a human face, a flicker of recognition, a bit of company in our misery.

And as you watch the movie, you may experience similar confusion. Ms. Piven favors bright colors and tonal understatement, creating a fascinating, occasionally dizzying discrepancy between what the movie looks as if it‰Ûªs doing and what it‰Ûªs actually doing. At times it seems as if the director herself isn‰Ûªt quite sure, but more often she succeeds in controlling the ambiguity. Outrageous and improbable situations ‰ÛÓ like the news conference at which Alice accepts her lottery winnings ‰ÛÓ are presented matter-of-factly. Jokes are whispered or implied, rather than telegraphed and punched up. Are we even supposed to be laughing?
‰ÛÏWelcome to Me‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Stuff you‰Ûªd never see or hear on basic cable.

‰ÛÏWelcome to Me‰Ûù is the name of a television show created by Alice Klieg, a California woman ‰ÛÓ divorced, unemployed, coping with borderline personality disorder, off her medication ‰ÛÓ who financed it with money she won in the state lottery. Alice is the program‰Ûªs guiding creative spirit and also its star, so the content reflects her interests: low-‰ÛÏcarbohydrant‰Ûù cooking, swan figurines, the neutering of dogs, re-enacted episodes of childhood humiliation and, above all, herself. She is both unstable and self-absorbed, and though she has spent years studying the broadcast work of Oprah Winfrey on VHS, Alice‰Ûªs on-air gestures and intonations can be as awkward as her self-help pronouncements are bizarre. From the start, ‰ÛÏWelcome to Me,‰Ûù shot in front of a sparse audience in the studios of a struggling infomercial outfit, seems to be headed for disaster.

‰ÛÏWelcome to Me,‰Ûù though it may at times look like a case study in quirk, is really the portrait of an artist. Alice‰Ûªs pain, like everyone else‰Ûªs, is ordinary and specific. Her way of experiencing it is what defines her condition as a disorder, and without minimizing or making light of pathology, the film suggest that it can also be a source of meaning, and not only for Alice. The brothers who own the studio ‰ÛÓ Gabe (Wes Bentley), a sensitive infomercial host, and Rich (James Marsden), a sunny, practical businessman ‰ÛÓ come to appreciate what she does, even as they are frequently alarmed by her on-air behavior. So does the producer (Joan Cusack), who knows effective television when she sees it.

In ‰ÛÏWelcome to Me,‰Ûù Ms. Wiig is to some extent having it both ways, using her natural silliness to draw us into a complicated psychological reality. In the studio audience for a demonstration of the power of algae-based smoothies ‰ÛÓ her first foray into television ‰ÛÓ Alice stares into the camera with unnerving directness, looking like a freshly plucked owl. In private and in public, she says wildly inappropriate things in a glassy, self-satisfied monotone. Once her own show is underway, she veers between studied, Oprahesque radiance and tearful hysteria. Audience members (including a curious graduate student played by Thomas Mann) don‰Ûªt know whether they‰Ûªre witnessing sly performance art or a slow-motion trainwreck. They may giggle or cringe, but they can‰Ûªt look away.

Alice may be ridiculous, but the point of Ms. Wiig‰Ûªs performance is not to hold her up to ridicule. It‰Ûªs to make sense of her suffering and find the logic in her experience of herself and the world around her. The people in Alice‰Ûªs life ‰ÛÓ including the producers and crew members who cash her checks and help realize her peculiar media vision ‰ÛÓ don‰Ûªt treat her like a freak or an object of pity. She has a best friend (Linda Cardellini) and an ex-husband (Alan Tudyk) who care about her and a therapist (Tim Robbins) who does his best to help her. All of them try to map the fluid boundaries of her personality. Is she potentially dangerous to herself and others ‰ÛÓ or merely eccentric? Is she a sad oddball or a kind of genius?

Though based on a remarkable true story, this clichÌ©d tear-jerker is barely interested in Marguerite‰Ûªs revolutionary teaching methods, focusing instead on the intensity of her connection to Marie. It‰Ûªs that very bond, however, that could have engendered an edgier movie, one that openly acknowledged the tension between the nun‰Ûªs spiritual vows and her earthly passion for her charge. Marguerite‰Ûªs love for her God is invisible, but her adoration of Marie is as clear as day.
A deaf and blind girl is saved by a consumptive nun in ‰ÛÏMarie‰Ûªs Story,‰Ûù a saccharine sister to Arthur Penn‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Miracle Worker‰Ûù (1962) from the French director Jean-Pierre AmÌ©ris.

Taken in hand, quite literally, by Sister Marguerite (Isabelle CarrÌ©), Marie flails from one mushy eureka moment to another, eventually mastering a hairbrush and ‰ÛÓ moments later, it seems ‰ÛÓ complex sign language. That‰Ûªs the cue for her teacher‰Ûªs lung problems to worsen and for Marie to grapple with abstract concepts like abandonment, but she‰Ûªll have plenty of time: Not even our favorite doctor on ‰ÛÏGrey‰Ûªs Anatomy‰Ûù was afforded the attenuated decline that Sister Marguerite enjoys.

Instead of Helen Keller, we have Marie Heurtin (impressively played by the deaf actress Ariana Rivoire), 14, who arrives at a rural French convent near Poitiers at the turn of the 20th century. Barely more than a savage, Marie thrashes wildly as her exhausted parents drop her off, her hands secured by leather handcuffs attached to a leash. Her lunatic demeanor teases a livelier, more jagged story, but it‰Ûªs not to be: Intent on delivering a three-hankie weepie, Mr. AmÌ©ris slathers on the sentiment with the proficiency that Marie brings to scaling trees ‰ÛÓ a talent that would impress even if she were sighted.

The indecipherability of ‰ÛÏReality,‰Ûù the latest absurdist deathtrap from Quentin Dupieux (‰ÛÏRubber,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏWrong‰Ûù), begins with its title: ‰ÛÏReality‰Ûù is actually the name of a girl (Kyla Kenedy) who spots a blue VHS tape inside the guts of the hog her father has shot. A hog ingesting a videotape ‰ÛÓ or even the continued use of tapes ‰ÛÓ makes as much sense as anything else in this sardonic, self-devouring comedy, in which dreams, movies within movies and reality (such as it is) mix.

Jason Tantra (Alain Chabat), a cameraman on a cooking show with a rat-costume-wearing host (Jon Heder), is given a provisional green light to make a horror film, if he can devise a death-groan sound that will win the producer (Jonathan Lambert) an Oscar. Reality ‰ÛÓ the girl ‰ÛÓ stars in a film being made by the same producer. And around and around Mr. Dupieux‰Ûªs exercise goes.

Each narrative fissure further thwarts meaning. The most you can ask from a movie as nullifying as this one is that it offer wit and visual panache, which it does. Unlike the leaden killer-tire comedy ‰ÛÏRubber,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏReality‰Ûù ekes out a few laughs that aren‰Ûªt purely theoretical.

The funniest material involves Jason, who is haunted by visions of winning the nonexistent award. (The actress Roxane Mesquida and Michel Hazanavicius, the director of ‰ÛÏThe Artist,‰Ûù appear as the Oscar presenters.) At one point, Jason, discovering that his unfilmed movie has already been made, begs a theater audience to stop watching: ‰ÛÏThis film doesn‰Ûªt exist yet!‰Ûù

The film finds Mr. Spinney in a reflective mood as he looks back over the path that got him to where he is today. A generous overture from Jim Henson brought him into the world of television puppetry just as it was about to break big, but he didn‰Ûªt immediately feel comfortable there. He tells of being on his way to see Mr. Henson to quit when Kermit Love, who built the Big Bird puppet, wisely advised him to give it a little more time. Soon he found the persona that made Big Bird click.

These anecdotes and more constitute ‰ÛÏI Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story,‰Ûù a documentary about the man who has been making Big Bird walk, talk, sing and be generally lovable for some 45 years. Mr. Spinney, now 81, is still doing much of the bird work, which is all the more impressive when you see, at one point in the film, just how physically demanding the job is. Oh, and Mr. Spinney is also Big Bird‰Ûªs fellow ‰ÛÏSesame Street‰Ûù resident, Oscar the Grouch.

Mr. Spinney made Big Bird so famous that he was invited to fly on the space shuttle, part of an effort to interest children in science. He relates that he had accepted the invitation for the 1986 flight but then was told there was no room for the large costume. It was the Challenger mission that exploded moments after launching.

The world‰Ûªs most famous giant bird has a human performer inside it, and it turns out that this nearly anonymous fellow has interesting stories to tell. There‰Ûªs the one about the puppeteer who was almost part of a space-travel disaster. There‰Ûªs the one about the guy who wanted to quit the job he was born to do practically before he had started it.

The film gets a little syrupy at times, but Mr. Spinney is forthright and engaging throughout. It seems as if Big Bird has been around forever. This film, by Dave LaMattina and Chad Walker, reminds us that even the most omnipresent cultural phenomena were created by someone, usually through a combination of hard work and happenstance.

‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs something about Caroll,‰Ûù Michael Davis, author of ‰ÛÏStreet Gang: The Complete History of Sesame Street,‰Ûù says, describing Mr. Spinney‰Ûªs talent. ‰ÛÏNot many people have it. He can go back in time almost, and re-create the feelings and the thoughts and the questions and the fears of a youngster.‰Ûù

The Norwegian filmmaker Bent Hamer is notable for his deadpan visual wit and his interest in odd jobs. ‰ÛÏFactotum,‰Ûù his 2005 English-language feature starring Matt Dillon, followed its down-and-out protagonist (drawn from the writing of Charles Bukowski) through a series of unlikely employments. None were quite as peculiar as the work undertaken by the researchers in ‰ÛÏKitchen Stories,‰Ûù who perched in lifeguard chairs in middle-class kitchens in the 1950s to observe the habits of housewives. The title character in ‰ÛÏO‰ÛªHorten‰Ûù had the relatively conventional profession of railway conductor but compensated with personal eccentricity.

In France, she meets Pi (Laurent Stocker), a former scientist who works as a groundskeeper at the Institute for Weights and Measures and who records bird songs in his spare time. Cheerful and a little disheveled, he seems in some ways like Marie‰Ûªs opposite, and we all know what happens to opposites, at least according to the romantic-comedy understanding of the laws of physics.

The movie is about her grief and disappointment, emotions that Ms. Torp, with her clear eyes, smooth skin and ruler-straight posture, expresses through gestures so subtle they almost escape detection by the camera. Marie is professional and temperamentally committed to balance, to careful measurement and precise, dispassionate calibrations of cause and effect. Mr. Hamer shares this commitment. His frames are meticulously composed, his camera movements minimal and surgical, his pacing decorous and deliberate.

In ‰ÛÏ1001 Grams,‰Ûù Marie Ernst (Ane Dahl Torp) follows, deliberately and dutifully, in the footsteps of previous Hamer heroes. She‰Ûªs a researcher at a pristine, orderly factory that manufactures weights ‰ÛÓ not the rough iron plates you might lift at a gym, but the shiny metal cylinders that balance grocers‰Ûª and pharmacists‰Ûª scales. Her workplace also houses the Norwegian prototype kilogram, an object so precious that it can be transported only inside two glass bell jars and a specially designed case.

But the point of all of this restraint and control ‰ÛÓ which is both pleasing and confining, for the audience as it is for the characters ‰ÛÓ is to allow small eruptions of chaos to become visible. Marie‰Ûªs life is upended by a series of accidents and surprises. Some them are physically and emotionally painful, but to the extent that they undermine her composure they also offer a way out of her rut.

Marie is assigned to travel with her country‰Ûªs prize kilo to an international conference on weights and measures in France, which sets up an amusing airport-security sequence. Mr. Hamer shows off his poker-faced, borderline-invisible comic style from time to time, but the dominant mood in ‰ÛÏ1001 Grams‰Ûù is one of stoical, melancholy resignation. Marie sits in her tiny electric car watching her former husband remove paintings and furniture from the boxy little Modernist house they once shared. She takes cigarette breaks with her father at work and visits him on the family farm, worrying about his health until she discovers his dead body in the hay barn.

‰ÛÏ1001 Grams‰Ûù achieves a charming equipoise of levity and gravity, of formal rigor and soulful sentiment. It‰Ûªs a quiet movie, sometimes to the point of near inaudibility, and a small one, so unassuming that, like Marie herself, it seems to want at times to disappear altogether. But here it is, sure of its proportions and also much bigger and messier than it looks.

The movie‰Ûªs gaping flaw is a bogus subplot in which the hunt for a suspected terrorist who might be carrying a bomb creates gridlock on the Williamsburg Bridge, possibly scaring away potential buyers and lowering real estate values on the Brooklyn side. The news coverage of the trumped-up crisis is sloppy, unconvincing and gratingly out of tune with the rest of the film.

In his prime, the playwright Neil Simon could have built a bright, caustic comedy around the competition for decent, affordable housing in New York. In ‰ÛÏ5 Flights Up,‰Ûù the British director Richard Loncraine, who directed from Charlie Peters‰Ûªs screen adaptation of Jill Ciment‰Ûªs novel ‰ÛÏHeroic Measures,‰Ûù has made something less abrasive than Mr. Simon might have written and carefully tailored it to its stars‰Ûª likable screen personalities.

The Carvers have weathered their share of conflicts and disappointments with remarkable equanimity. We learn that Ruth‰Ûªs mother was dead set against her daughter‰Ûªs marrying a black man and that Ruth‰Ûªs subsequent discovery of her infertility was a severe blow to the couple, who expected to have children and probably would have made excellent parents. Instead of a child, the Carvers have a beloved dog, Dorothy, who becomes sick and undergoes expensive tests followed by even more expensive surgery. We are repeatedly reminded that the day has long passed since a million dollars ensured a lifetime free from financial anxiety in New York City.
‰ÛÏFive Flights Up‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has some strong language and nude images.

When they gaze at each other, they convey the palpable pride and joy of sane adults who after four decades together remain deeply in love. I can‰Ûªt remember the last time in an American movie that an older couple so thoroughly embodied the promise of Robert Browning‰Ûªs invitation: ‰ÛÏGrow old along with me!/The best is yet to be.‰Ûù The light in their eyes says it all.

‰ÛÏ5 Flights Up‰Ûù would be nothing without its stars, whose humanity warms up a movie that otherwise portrays New Yorkers as coldblooded, slightly crazy, hypercompetitive sharks. Mr. Freeman‰Ûªs Alex is a variation of the avuncular wise man he so often portrays, his voice calm and soothing, until moments of stubborn impatience or indecision interrupt his composure. Ms. Keaton‰Ûªs Ruth is a softer, matured version of the charming, occasionally exasperating eccentric we know and treasure.

Their unidentified neighborhood has become a hipster destination. Real estate prices are astronomical, and the value of their home is now around $1 million. The temptation to cash in is almost irresistible. Enter Lily Portman (Cynthia Nixon), an indefatigably perky real estate agent whom the Carvers choose to show the apartment.

Married for 40 years, Alex Carver (Mr. Freeman), a moderately successful painter, and his wife, Ruth (Ms. Keaton), a retired schoolteacher, have lived in the same Brooklyn apartment ‰ÛÓ a comfortable fifth-floor walk-up with one of the two bedrooms serving as Alex‰Ûªs studio ‰ÛÓ since the 1970s. Negotiating five flights isn‰Ûªt as easy as it used to be, especially for Alex, and they come to the realization that they will eventually have to move to a building with an elevator.

The lead performances are so perfectly in sync that Alex and Ruth really feel like an old married couple who know each other‰Ûªs foibles and cherish every tic. In flashbacks to their younger selves (Korey Jackson and Claire van der Boom), the resemblances between older and more youthful are so close they don‰Ûªt strain credibility.

If every longtime couple were as contentedly happy and healthy as the pair played by Morgan Freeman and Diane Keaton in ‰ÛÏ5 Flights Up,‰Ûù aging side-by-side with a devoted partner would be something to look forward to.

A series of open houses during which various high-strung couples sniff around the premises offers a knowing cross-section of various New York types, among whom the unnervingly upbeat, avaricious agent tries to spur a bidding war.

‰ÛÏBravetown,‰Ûù directed by Daniel Duran from a screenplay by Oscar Orlando Torres, can sometimes drown in its own tears. At one point, its bad boy, who suggests a sour and much younger Matt Damon, whines: ‰ÛÏNobody has ever been there for me. Why would I be there for anybody else?‰Ûù

‰ÛÏThis town is good for nothing but turning out future soldiers,‰Ûù says Mary (Kherington Payne), the glum captain of a North Dakota high school dance team in the excruciating ‰ÛÏBravetown,‰Ûù an unwieldy hybrid of high school dance competition movie and shameless flag-waver.

Overnight, the team advances to compete in the state championship finals. The atrocious spectacle they contrive is a morbid battlefield production number inspired by the movie ‰ÛÏPlatoon,‰Ûù whose soundtrack scrambles Samuel Barber‰Ûªs Adagio for Strings with electronica in what only could be described as a grotesque act of desecration.

Josh gets support from a court-ordered counselor, Alex (an ill-used Josh Duhamel), who is a veteran recovering from post-traumatic stress disorder. With Alex‰Ûªs help, Josh sheds his antisocial attitude and acquires some self-esteem when his techno remixes spark the dance team to new heights of terpsichorean inspiration.
‰ÛÏBravetown‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language, brief drug use and sexuality.

Mary lives with her perky younger brother and her delusional mother (Laura Dern), who has been clinically depressed since Mary‰Ûªs older brother was killed at war. The drab small town is also where Josh (Lucas Till), a 17-year-old nightclub D. J. from New York, has landed after an on-the-job drug overdose. His lengthening list of misdeeds has earned him a warning from a judge: face jail time or go live with his divorced father. His mother (Maria Bello), an embittered wreck who declares that she wishes he had never been born, is more than happy to be rid of him.

So maybe I expected too much. But while a movie that fails to catch fire is disappointing, there is something even more dispiriting about a movie that doesn‰Ûªt even bother to try, that tosses its stars a soggy book of matches and expects them to generate a spark.

‰ÛÏHot Pursuit‰Ûù is an on-the-run buddy comedy starring Sofia Vergara as the wife of a criminal and Reese Witherspoon (also credited among the film‰Ûªs producers) as a San Antonio police officer. Thrown together by improbable (though entirely conventional) circumstances, the two women head across Texas, mocking and humiliating each other on the way to mutual appreciation.

How you respond to the movie may depend on whether that description raises or lowers your expectations. I‰Ûªll admit that mine were perhaps unreasonably high. Ms. Witherspoon, though she has been doing other things lately, has a long track record as a resourceful comic performer, going back at least to ‰ÛÏElection‰Ûù and the sometimes delightful ‰ÛÏLegally Blonde‰Ûù movies. Ms. Vergara has for a while seemed more than ready to leap beyond her narrow, frequently hilarious, occasionally offensive role on ‰ÛÏModern Family.‰Ûù

Before long, Cooper and Mrs. Riva ‰ÛÓ last names suffice until the blossoming of their final-act friendship ‰ÛÓ are being chased by two sets of gunman and forced into various slapstick- and insult-generating situations. Ms. Vergara teeters on high heels, threatens to burst the seams of her dress and mangles common English idioms. Ms. Witherspoon rattles off sections of the penal code and figures out what‰Ûªs really going on just in the nick of time. They climb out a bathroom window. They pretend to be lovers for the benefit of a suspicious homeowner played by Jim Gaffigan. Some people are shot and even killed, but only for laughs.
‰ÛÏHot Pursuit‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Anatomical humor.

Ms. Witherspoon plays Cooper, the daughter of a cop who is killed in the line of duty in an ill-judged opening sequence. Her dream of following in his footsteps has gotten her as far as the precinct evidence room, where she endures the condescension of hotshot detectives. A mishap with a Taser ‰ÛÓ less than hilarious in the context of certain recent episodes of police violence ‰ÛÓ has made Cooper‰Ûªs name a punch line, and she‰Ûªs desperate to redeem herself with some real police work. Sure enough, her captain (John Carroll Lynch) gives her the job of watching over Daniella Riva (Ms. Vergara), whose husband is preparing to testify against his narco-stereotype boss.

But while ‰ÛÏHot Pursuit‰Ûù makes much of the vocal, temperamental and physical contrasts between its stars ‰ÛÓ not since Frodo and Gandalf has a difference in height been so carefully emphasized on screen ‰ÛÓ it doesn‰Ûªt give them anything especially fresh or interesting to do together. We are in the midst of a comedy boom, and within it an explosion of feminist and woman-driven humor, but the news has apparently not reached Warner Bros. headquarters. Directed by Anne Fletcher (‰ÛÏ27 Dresses,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Proposal‰Ûù) from a screenplay by David Feeney and John Quaintance, ‰ÛÏHot Pursuit‰Ûù is cautious and tentative in its pursuit of laughs, and almost entirely unsure of how to go about being funny.

Alas, not nearly enough. Despite its horror-film backdrop and chomp-chomp flashbacks, ‰ÛÏMaggie‰Ûù turns out to be a deliberately paced and played drama about a family coping with a fatal disease. It‰Ûªs a sad story, or would be if the zombie apocalypse backdrop ‰ÛÓ and the inky splotches creeping across Maggie‰Ûªs body ‰ÛÓ didn‰Ûªt wreak such havoc with the movie‰Ûªs unsmiling sincerity. The director, Henry Hobson, a graphic artist making his feature debut, largely steers clear of the usual horror-film shocks and instead delivers quiet, unhurried scenes of people struggling to cope with one another and their pain, sometimes because, well, they‰Ûªre molting like sick reptiles.

It‰Ûªs entirely possible that another filmmaker could make a Malickian zombie movie that works, and some wags may believe that a few of Mr. Malick‰Ûªs more somnolent characters have already traipsed and twirled down that road already. Wade doesn‰Ûªt twirl but at one point he walks into a field of waving crops, one of his hands skimming across the stalks. It‰Ûªs a classic Malick moment, one that‰Ûªs been recycled endlessly and that in ‰ÛÏMaggie‰Ûù becomes an emblem of the longing of those who yearn to tap into all the beauty, solemnity, grandeur and deeply considered thought that reverberates through this quintessential image. But, you know, with zombies.
‰ÛÏMaggie‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Family drama and death.

Zombies, Arnold Schwarzenegger and a certain Terrence Malick je ne sais quoi ‰ÛÓ what could go wrong? More or less everything in this low-budget head-scratcher and periodic knee-slapper. A bearded Mr. Schwarzenegger plays Wade Vogel, a strenuously humble American farmer who, not long after the movie opens, retrieves his 16-year-old daughter, Maggie (Abigail Breslin), from a world crammed with artfully uglified, zomboid victims of a ghastly virus. Cars burn, fields burn and every so often ‰ÛÓ as when Wade gasses up his truck ‰ÛÓ one of these hungry zombies goes on the attack.

Come again? Bhashkor is not your typical Bollywood papa, and ‰ÛÏPiku,‰Ûù directed by Shoojit Sircar from a script by Juhi Chaturvedi, isn‰Ûªt a typical Hindi movie. It lopes along, following no formula beyond the roughest outlines of a romantic comedy. In its middle section, it detours into road movie territory, with Rana (Irrfan Khan, brooding and wonderful), behind the wheel; the owner of a taxi company, Rana drives Piku and Bhashkor to Kolkata from Delhi. Even on the road, the film‰Ûªs concerns remain domestic, more about getting along inside the cramped car than about the wide-open spaces.

‰ÛÏPiku,‰Ûù an offbeat Hindi comedy, would have you contemplate the intestines and mortality of one Bhashkor Banerji and the actor who plays him, Amitabh Bachchan. Bhashkor‰Ûªs life and conversation may revolve around his constipation and fussy hypochondria, but there‰Ûªs no mistaking the scene-stealing energy that Mr. Bachchan, India‰Ûªs erstwhile Angry Young Man, musters for his new role of Cranky Old Man.

And so pity Bhashkor‰Ûªs poor daughter, Piku (Deepika Padukone). She may be the very picture of a modern career girl, but she can‰Ûªt escape the father who has turned her into an ill-tempered scold. His chiding, hectoring voice fills the home they share, and even follows her to the office, where he sends her much-too-public updates on his bowel movements. And Bhashkor, who derides the very idea of marriage, waylays Piku‰Ûªs suitors to let them know that she is no virgin.

This movie, as the title suggests, is set up to be Piku‰Ûªs story: How will she make a life? But the filmmakers let Mr. Bachchan overwhelm the story. Ms. Padukone, an always likable performer, remains in his shadow, just as Piku remains in Bhashkor‰Ûªs, liberated but without real agency. Ms. Padukone keeps Piku from being a one-note shrew. But she can‰Ûªt quite make her a heroine.

For long stretches, ‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù serves as a commodious vehicle for Mr. Black, who, like the best comic performers, never seems remotely concerned about going too big or risking the audience‰Ûªs love. He‰Ûªs a showboat if every so often, more of a steamroller, capable of flattening everyone and everything in his way. Yet he is also adept at conveying emotional and psychological fragility, and there are some nice moments here when you see Dan as confused by his feelings for Oliver as a crushed-out 12-year-old, which the filmmakers smartly don‰Ûªt try to explain. Instead, they show you what Dan sees and in the process upend the old formulation (often attributed to Raymond Chandler about James Bond) that while men want to be the handsome hero, it‰Ûªs only the women who want to be with him.

Dan dreams, as you see in an amusing Walter Mitty-like fantasy, that landing Oliver will turn him into the conquering reunion hero. The writer-directors Jarrad Paul and Andrew Mogel don‰Ûªt make Dan a full-blown fantasist and, crucially, unlike Mitty, Dan isn‰Ûªt victimized by one of those classic pecking hens. His issues are largely of his own grandiose design but also fairly picayune. He‰Ûªs carved out his own version of the American dream and appears happily married with a supportive wife, Stacey (Kathryn Hahn), and two children, as well as contentedly employed. (Jeffrey Tambor plays his boss.) It‰Ûªs perfectly ordinary if also not enough for Dan who, with can-do resolve, flies to Los Angeles, where he finds Oliver. There, over several days and feverish nights, they bond big time, including in bed.

A genial movie about how we live now or like to think that we do, ‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù stars Jack Black as Dan Landsman, an outwardly ordinary Joe who‰Ûªs helping to plan his 20th high school reunion. His testy dealings with the other reunion committee members suggest that he was as unpopular in high school as he is now. He‰Ûªs not a bad guy, but more of a fussbudgety blowhard who‰Ûªs always trying too hard to be the big man, often through trivial means like scatting slang and being keeper of a reunion password. When he sees one of the school‰Ûªs former golden boys, Oliver Lawless (a nimble, perfect James Marsden), in a television commercial, Dan decides to try to persuade him to come to the reunion.

‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt the first comedy to coax laughs out of two ostensibly straight guys having sex, a situation more typically found in seriously unfunny prison movies. The 2009 indie movie ‰ÛÏHumpday,‰Ûù a sendup of the genre, circled the issue with two straight male friends who decide to make a pornographic movie with each other only to keep their penises in lockdown. That‰Ûªs invariably the case in the typical bromances, of course, which feature delineated straight guys who engage in stereotypically, even hyperbolically coded male behavior: They play air guitar, drink to excess, become involved in street altercations and so forth. One of the best, ‰ÛÏI Love You, Man,‰Ûù even mimics the classic heterosexual romantic coupling: Boy meets boy; boy loses boy; boy gets boy, kind of.
‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Boys will be naughty boys.

In most movie bromances, sexual desire skitters at the edge of the story, quivering like a man-child in a cathouse.
