The dudes in these movies tend to observe a ritualistic narrative proximity (they get close, but not too close) that‰Ûªs echoed in the physical protocols of the typical bro-hug. In these familiar ceremonial interactions, the bros lean in toward each other for some upper-body contact even as they simultaneously maintain scrupulous, observable genital distance. Once contact is made, the bro-huggers exchange two or three hearty back slaps and then uncouple. In the comedy ‰ÛÏThe D Train,‰Ûù there‰Ûªs no such retreat ‰ÛÓ only sweet, sweaty surrender.

With light and moderately dark comic flourishes, a skipping, sometimes thudding heart and some careful lighting, ‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù takes the bromance to its logical conclusion. Even so, it plays it sweet rather than tough, including narratively, and there are instances ‰ÛÓ as in a close-up of Dan, his face knotted up in jealousy as he watches Oliver across a dance floor ‰ÛÓ when you see hints of a more dangerous, less comfortable movie. ‰ÛÏThe D Train‰Ûù acknowledges there can be more to all the usual sharing, caring and relentless joking than the reproduction of male power, but it isn‰Ûªt going to upturn the status quo. The truth is that it‰Ûªs pretty straight, including in its revelation that sometimes when a guy says ‰ÛÏI love you, man,‰Ûù he really, really means it.

At a time of high unemployment in Italy, there is something unmistakably political about a comic figure who professes to like any kind of work, expressing only mild concern about payment. But ‰ÛÏIntrepido,‰Ûù directed by Gianni Amelio (‰ÛÏLamerica‰Ûù), never coheres: Does Antonio‰Ûªs flexibility reflect the diversity of Italy‰Ûªs economy or its lack of steadiness? Perhaps the satire hasn‰Ûªt traveled well, though reviews from Italy also indicate narrative shortcomings.
Digressions involving suicide, child abuse, immigration and unions muddy the film‰Ûªs meaning rather than illuminate it.

‰ÛÏIntrepido: A Lonely Hero,‰Ûù set in ‰ÛÏMilan, in these times,‰Ûù opens on a day when rain falls on old snow. The protagonist, Antonio Pane (Antonio Albanese), takes short-term jobs, filling in for different people. He works at a construction site, in costume at a mall, in a kitchen and as a tram driver. No occupation holds his interest for long: When he delivers pizzas to a sewing factory, he shows off his facility with one of the machines.

When Antonio sits for an exam for a public job (the large, anonymous crowd may evoke Ermanno Olmi‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏIl Posto‰Ûù), he sneaks answers to Lucia (Livia Rossi), a young woman paralyzed by the test. (Unemployment has hit young Italians especially hard.) She tells him that as a girl, she imagined staying in bed instead of working. Antonio‰Ûªs son (Gabriele Rendina), a saxophonist, appears more responsible than his father ‰ÛÓ until, abruptly, he isn‰Ûªt.

The movie rather confusedly jumps around in time with flashbacks to this or that turning point. The seemingly random time-scrambling at least lends Christina‰Ûªs story some consistency by reminding you of the hardships she overcame.

High-spirited and rebellious from a young age, she dreamed of a singing career like her idol Doris Day. She also had conversations with God. When her alcoholic father couldn‰Ûªt keep the family together, the children were distributed to various institutions. Christina landed in a school run by nuns where she was treated harshly. Even after she was viciously raped and the son she bore sent away, her spirit was not broken.

A feisty, passionate performance by the Irish actress Deirdre O‰ÛªKane gives the inspirational biopic ‰ÛÏNoble‰Ûù a serrated edge of defiance and gumption. Its subject, Christina Noble, is an Irish children‰Ûªs rights activist and writer, who traveled to Ho Chi Minh City in 1989 and established a foundation that has set up more than 100 projects in Vietnam and Mongolia that provide protection, education and health care for more than 700,000 children and their families.

Christina overcomes misfortune by fighting back. When she marries, you imagine she has found deliverance. But no; her husband is violently abusive. As the movie tells it, everything she achieves is accomplished almost single-handedly. She had to browbeat most of her allies, including one played by Brendan Coyle of ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù fame, into embracing her cause.

As the movie tells it, television coverage of the Vietnam War inspired visionary nightmares that led Christina to Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, where the plight of orphaned, homeless children squatting in abandoned buildings drove her to take action. Her efforts to help them were repeatedly thwarted by indifferent officials. Threatened with deportation, she was given three months to secure sponsorship for a program to help the children.
‰ÛÏNoble‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for violence and sexual situations.

In many ways, ‰ÛÏNoble‰Ûù is a standard tale of one tenacious individual‰Ûªs determination to make a difference. And in bluntly connecting Christina‰Ûªs campaign with her own nightmarish childhood in late-1940s and ‰Ûª50s Dublin, the movie partly avoids the sticky sentimentality of the typical do-gooder film portrait.

Ms. O‰ÛªKane‰Ûªs brusque performance portrays Christina as a woman who acts on her principles and has little time for making nice. She is a compelling embodiment of the adage ‰ÛÏWhat doesn‰Ûªt kill you makes you stronger.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs a rare thing when a script comes across your desk that truly knocks the wind out of you,‰Ûù McG, one of the film‰Ûªs many producers, confides in the publicity notes. It certainly knocked something out of me.

Cut loose from the flash-bang-wallop of the ‰ÛÏCaptain America‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAvengers‰Ûù franchises, Mr. Evans seems lost. But it‰Ûªs Chris Shafer and Paul Vicknair‰Ûªs hackneyed writing that really does him in.

Proceeding with a strained quirkiness that infects much more than the names of its main characters, this first feature by Justin Reardon is a paean to the kind of narcissism that sucks the air out of every scene. Me, a writer whose rom-com screenplay is hindered by his never having been in love, suffers from abandonment issues and the conviction that it‰Ûªs fine to stalk the lovely Her (Michelle Monaghan), a young woman with a boyfriend and a natural warmth that jarringly illuminates her pursuer‰Ûªs slick superficiality.

A series of monotonous ‰ÛÏfriend dates‰Ûù follows, as does a flash mob of clichÌ©s, some of which recall exponentially better movies like ‰ÛÏSay Anything‰Ûù (1989) and ‰ÛÏThe Graduate‰Ûù (1967). Insipid fantasy vignettes allow the cast to dress up in old-timey costumes, and a clutch of generically oddball sidekicks ‰ÛÓ almost all of whom (especially the wonderfully subtle Topher Grace) would have made more convincing romantic leads ‰ÛÓ facilitates the delivery of off-color jokes.

‰ÛÏPlaying It Cool‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Malaysian women are maligned, a child‰Ûªs doll is abused, and a famous Colombian author is used as a punch line.

You know how awkward it is when you date a man and he won‰Ûªt stop talking in voice-over? Allow me to introduce the hero of ‰ÛÏPlaying It Cool,‰Ûù a struggling writer named Me (Chris Evans, insufferable) whose incessant narration ‰ÛÓ for audiences, if not for his luckless love interest ‰ÛÓ is inescapable.

Ruth, single and childless and irresponsible, hangs out with old pals who have all begun to have children. She is increasingly unwelcome among them, and she feels like an outcast in her family as well, since her father (James Caan) is eager for grandchildren.
Ms. Bennett‰Ûªs own character, at least, is believable enough for a lighthearted farce. There are a few decent laughs before the plot spins out of control.

A mistaken assumption leads Ruth to pretend that she is pregnant, and suddenly she finds herself pampered by her pals, at home, at work, even on public transit. The movie makes some good comedy out of the ever-evolving lie and Ruth‰Ûªs angst over how to undo it. Danny Trejo is especially amusing as Ruth‰Ûªs co-worker, who learns her secret and forms a collaborative bond with her.

‰ÛÏPreggoland,‰Ûù a mild comedy about a fake pregnancy, has some rewards, though you have to be prepared to give it a chance. The central character, Ruth, initially comes across as irritating. By the end, though, the actress who plays her, Sonja Bennett, has made her likably irritating.

The movie‰Ûªs flaw is that it mixes tones. Ruth, her relatives and her fellow workers are realistically played, but her gal-pal buddies are caricatures. It‰Ûªs as if Ms. Bennett, who also wrote the script, didn‰Ûªt trust her own idea or comic sensibility, and the director, Jacob Tierney, doesn‰Ûªt find a way to synthesize things.

He is the rarest orchid in a hothouse full of exotic blooms, as well as a few more ordinary horticultural specimens. YSL‰Ûªs most loyal friend, his lover and business partner, is Pierre BergÌ© (JÌ©rÌ©mie Renier), whose patience and pragmatism seem to guarantee that his heart will be broken. As the ‰Ûª60s wane, Saint Laurent takes up with Jacques de Bascher (Louis Garrel, even dreamier and hunkier than usual), who introduces him to harder drugs and kinkier sex. Saint Laurent‰Ûªs other companions and enablers include de la Falaise (LÌ©a Seydoux) and the tall, blond model Betty Catroux (Aymeline Valade). Hanging out with them has its pleasures, its appalling moments and also its tiresome and confusing stretches. Mr. Bonello‰Ûªs rigorous indifference to the usual matters of plot is admirable, but it can sometimes test a viewer‰Ûªs patience. His films, shown in a recently concluded retrospective at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, are held together more by color, sensuality and atmosphere than by narrative or psychology. You could call them superficial, but only in the sense that Oscar Wilde might have understood the word: The surfaces are rich, complex and saturated with meaning. And this aesthetic, here as in earlier features like ‰ÛÏThe Pornographer‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏHouse of Pleasures,‰Ûù can be suffocating as well as seductive.

You are transported into the workshops where Yves Saint Laurent designed his couture collections of the late 1960s and early ‰Ûª70s, and into the business meetings where his brand-extension strategies were hatched. After-hours you follow the designer, in the company of friends, lovers and hangers-on, to Paris nightclubs and cruising areas, to Morocco and to bed. A few names are dropped ‰ÛÓ Andy Warhol, Loulou de la Falaise ‰ÛÓ but mostly you sweep through the parties and runway shows without stopping for introductions, as if you already knew everyone who mattered.

But for just this reason, ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù may represent a perfect match of filmmaker and subject. YSL‰Ûªs commitment to elegance was all-consuming, and also represented a kind of transcendental consumerism. His life, or at least this movie‰Ûªs idea of it, was both sumptuous and empty, hedonistic and sad. He was a creator and, even more, a collector, of attractive people, intense experiences and beautiful things. To visit him in old age, surrounded by servants, memories, occasional hallucinations and abundant objets d‰Ûªart, is to sit with a pharaoh in a tomb furnished for the afterlife. You‰Ûªre not sure if you‰Ûªve witnessed a tragedy in the guise of a fashion show, or the reverse.

It‰Ûªs a giddy, intoxicating, decidedly decadent feeling, but ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù is more than merely seductive. In dispensing with the usual plodding routines of the biopic, Mr. Bonello offers a perspective on his subject ‰ÛÓ played in his prime by the epicene, hollow-cheeked Gaspard Ulliel ‰ÛÓ that is at once intimate and detached. Beginning at a low moment in 1974, flashing back to the glory days of 1967 and later jumping ahead to Saint Laurent‰Ûªs final years (when he‰Ûªs played by Helmut Berger), the film is a compulsively detailed swirl of moods and impressions, intent on capturing the contradictions of the man and his times. Observations of Saint Laurent at work and in love give way to panoramic, intricate surveys of the world of commerce and culture in which he suffered and flourished.

What we can and do witness, though, is his absolute aesthetic confidence. He knows what is beautiful, and he believes, correctly, that the rest of the world will eventually see things his way. His fanatical, at times dictatorial will ensures that outcome. Mr. Ulliel‰Ûªs Saint Laurent endures pain ‰ÛÓ and brings pain to others ‰ÛÓ but he never experiences a moment of doubt. He smokes, draws, drinks and watches the unfolding of history through his signature oversized glasses, conveying a haunting, quietly charismatic mixture of sensitivity and coldness. YSL, as he is often called, is equally capable of casual, aristocratic cruelty and earthy, spontaneous tenderness, and when you study his face it can be hard to distinguish boredom from rapture.

The recent film that ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù most closely resembles may be Mike Leigh‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù and not only by virtue of its two-and-a-half-hour length, its episodic structure and the gorgeousness of its production design. Though their respective heroes could hardly be more different as physical or temperamental types, both movies confront the challenge of depicting an original creative spirit at work, and the paradoxical inability of one visual form to do justice to another. Though its products can be displayed, artistic talent is invisible: There is no way for Mr. Ulliel (or Timothy Spall in ‰ÛÏMr. Turner‰Ûù) to dramatize the inner workings of genius, or for Mr. Leigh or Mr. Bonello to show their work from the inside out. The sketches and dresses that Saint Laurent produces are beautiful, of course, but we can‰Ûªt quite see where they came from.
‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Beautiful people, often on drugs and frequently out of their (also beautiful) clothes.

Like an E! channel reality show or an Instagram feed from the Met Gala, Bertrand Bonello‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù beckons with the promise of an inside look at the hectic and mysterious world of fashion. Shepherding you past security with a flash of a V.I.P. all-access pass, it confers instant insider status made even more alluring by the element of time travel.

Allan (Robert Gustafsson) is about to be honored with a 100th birthday party when, for no particular reason, he decides to climb out the window of the retirement home where he lives and do some aimless traveling. How aimless? ‰ÛÏCan you travel somewhere from here?‰Ûù he asks the ticket clerk at the local bus station.
‰ÛÏOlder people don‰Ûªt smell like we do,‰Ûù the official explains to a colleague. ‰ÛÏA sweeter smell, sort of ‰ÛÓ a bit cadaverish.‰Ûù

As Allan ambles on, he picks up some friends and an elephant, and we also learn about his rather eventful life through flashbacks. Turns out the fellow was a catalytic force in some major historical events. Who knew?

A customer with an urgent restroom issue leaves his suitcase with Allan, who promptly boards a bus with it, not realizing it is stuffed with cash. That sets off an adventure in which he is pursued by various nefarious types, most of whom come to unfortunate ends. It is one of these whose body draws the attention of the cadaver dog, but the police official investigating the increasingly odd string of events Allan is leaving in his wake is inclined to discount the dog‰Ûªs report, thinking that perhaps Allan is causing a false reading.

The film genre that might be called Old People Behaving Hilariously gets an appealing new entry with ‰ÛÏThe 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared,‰Ûù a sometimes daffy, often droll Swedish movie. Among other things, this film dares to ask the controversial question: Can a cadaver dog distinguish between a body that‰Ûªs dead and one that is merely triple-digit old?

When asked by the Mollen Commission whether his loyalties were with ‰ÛÏthe community he was supposed to be policing‰Ûù or the drug traffickers he protected, Mr. Dowd said, ‰ÛÏI guess I‰Ûªd have to say the drug traffickers.‰Ûù Again and again, you see him before the commission, but his testimony tends to get lost amid the hyperventilated crime stories. That‰Ûªs too bad. He was a font of information, as when he testified hat the police officers who ‰ÛÏare taking money will more typically be the ones that are giving beatings.‰Ûù As the commission found, ‰ÛÏDowd, like other officers, reported that brutality strengthened the bonds of loyalty and silence among officers and thus fostered corruption tolerance.‰Ûù This documentary could have a whole lot more Mollen and a whole lot less of Mr. Dowd.

A movie like ‰ÛÏThe Seven Five‰Ûù has only minor use as a historical document; its principal function is to package gonzo tales of bad behavior into commercial entertainment that plays down the real suffering behind those stories. Mr. Dowd‰Ûªs vehement narration does have, at times, a vague Joe-Pesci-in-‰ÛÏGoodFellas‰Ûù feel, which is amusing only if you ignore the historical record. In 1988, when Mr. Dowd was still on the force, an estimated 100 people were murdered in East New York. Those dead should haunt ‰ÛÏThe Seven Five,‰Ûù which instead breezes through its crimes while tossing out grim images of unidentified black and brown bodies. I wonder if these will show up in the fictional version that as Variety reported, Sony won the rights to after a winning bid of ‰ÛÏaround the seven-figure range.‰Ûù

The documentary ‰ÛÏThe Seven Five‰Ûù giddily revisits the true-crime deeds of Michael Dowd, a former New York police officer who was arrested in 1992 with a stash of cocaine on him. As the ringleader of a crew of dirty cops stationed at the 75th Precinct in East New York, he padded his income by stealing money, guns and drugs from dealers. He eventually graduated to working for drug rings, one of which put him on retainer so he could provide information about narcotic operations. ‰ÛÏThe Seven Five‰Ûù has been called ‰ÛÏthe cop version of ‰Û÷GoodFellas,‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù which may explain why Sony has plans to produce a fictional remake. Here‰Ûªs hoping that version uses a better moral compass.
‰ÛÏThe Seven Five‰Ûù is rated R (No one under 17 admitted without parent or adult guardian). Crimes against humanity.

You learn a lot in ‰ÛÏThe Seven Five‰Ûù about Mr. Dowd‰Ûªs criminal exploits, which emerge in original interviews with him and some of his former associates, in re-creations of their exploits and, valuably, in clips from his testimony before the Mollen Commission. It was formed after Mr. Dowd and a handful of other dirty cops were arrested on narcotic charges, and its mission was spelled out in its title: ‰ÛÏCommission to Investigate Allegations of Police Corruption and the Anti-Corruption Procedures of the Police Department.‰Ûù Among its many bleak findings was that Mr. Dowd‰Ûªs underworld activities were so lucrative that from 1987 to 1988 he reaped $4,000 a week from drug organizations in his precinct. Sometimes he even forgot to pick up his paycheck.

And now Mr. Dowd, having served time in a federal prison, is making a comeback as the star of this breathless, ethically challenged documentary, which the director Tiller Russell has pulled together as slickly as an episode of ‰ÛÏLaw & Order‰Ûù (without, you know, much of either). The main source here is Mr. Dowd, who, mouth gunning, excitedly recounts how he stole drugs and money, stories that are interlaced with talking-head accounts from some of his past associates, including former cops and drug dealers who are thanked in the credits. Every so often if not nearly enough, you also hear from some of the good guys who helped bring Mr. Dowd down, including one who soberly invokes what bad guys like Mr. Dowd meant for neighborhoods under his watch.

‰ÛÏOne ticket for ‰Û÷Jud SÌ_ss,‰Ûª please‰Ûù are not words one expects to hear decades after the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. But there they are, spoken by a moviegoer shown in ‰ÛÏForbidden Films: The Hidden Legacy of Nazi Film,‰Ûù an unnerving documentary that considers the legacy of the Third Reich‰Ûªs propaganda films. Moments later in the same sequence chronicling a rare public screening of the anti-Semitic movie, we glimpse a box-office sign, ‰ÛÏåÊ‰Û÷Jud SÌ_ss‰Ûª sold out,‰Ûù like some vision from an awful alternate universe.

It‰Ûªs a sober treatment of sobering material. If the Nazis have been viewed as especially horrific because they arose within a highly developed Western culture, their propaganda films in turn offer the shock of seeing a popular modern form of art and entertainment being employed to incite and justify hatred and violence. Mr. Moeller, who also directed a film about the director of ‰ÛÏJud SÌ_ss,‰Ûù seems to lean toward not suppressing these films, but even their nuance-free scenes of chest-thumping Nazi pilots and homeland-loving hausfraus remain uncomfortable to watch.

‰ÛÏJud SÌ_ss‰Ûù is among 40-odd Nazi productions that cannot be exhibited in Germany without the presence of scholarly context. The director of ‰ÛÏForbidden Films,‰Ûù Felix Moeller, provides that context with this survey of the Nazis‰Ûª film output, which was pro-German and anti everyone else ‰ÛÓ Jews, French, British, Polish. He layers clips from the films with reactions from German professionals (a historian, a filmmaker), audiences today (German and Israeli) and, shrouded in shadow, neo-Nazis.
This is a documentary fascinated with and fearful of cinema‰Ûªs potency, but it‰Ûªs also devoted to the idea of open discourse, a stance that underlines the urgency of thinking about film critically.

The scant, digressive story begins when a teenager, Mariano (Rafael Federman), discovers a revolver and nonchalantly shoots himself in the head and stomach. He survives ‰ÛÓ Mr. Rejtman earns this bit of license with a shrewd use of off-screen space ‰ÛÓ and seems unfazed. Perhaps Mariano‰Ûªs motive was the sweltering heat. ‰ÛÏIt was an impulse,‰Ûù he says during a psychological exam. ‰ÛÏIt was very hot.‰Ûù

His brother (BenjamÌ_n Coehlo) flirts with a fast-food worker (Camila Fabbri) ambiguously committed to her boyfriend. In an abrupt change of focus that expands the film‰Ûªs shaggy-dog vision while suggesting that Mr. Rejtman (who wrote the screenplay) may lack interest in his own story, the movie ditches the brothers to follow Susana on a beach vacation from hell.

The droll, shape-shifting ‰ÛÏTwo Shots Fired,‰Ûù the newest movie from the Argentine filmmaker MartÌ_n Rejtman (the subject of a current retrospective at the Film Society of Lincoln Center), accomplishes the strange feat of constantly thwarting expectations without ever varying its tone or moving the needle of excitement.
Even the mystery of a lost dog is a red herring. A French New Wave-style voice-over holds the narrative together, but ‰ÛÏTwo Shots Fired‰Ûù is somewhere between deadpan and coy.

Mariano‰Ûªs mother, Susana (Susana Pampin), becomes paranoid, hiding knives and other potential weapons. The bullet lodged in Mariano‰Ûªs body causes him to play two notes at once with the recorder he plays in a quartet. (The group specializes in ancient music. In one of the funniest moments, a new recruit asks about payment.)

On the most obvious level, it is a scrambled three-panel portrait of Mr. Pincus, who died in November 2013; Ms. Small, who is many years his junior; and Mr. Pincus‰Ûªs wife, Jane, an author and painter. The film, which follows Mr. Pincus into doctors‰Ûª offices and hospitals, observes a patient faced with complicated, uncertain choices about his treatment. If there‰Ûªs the tiniest chance of survival, he wants to take it.

Throughout the movie, the conflict between the feminist principles of the two women and their unruly emotions complicates the relationship. And the issue of Mr. Pincus‰Ûªs male prerogative in an equal collaboration with a woman remains unresolved.

Mr. Pincus ‰ÛÓ who pioneered an unprecedentedly intimate style of personal documentary with ‰ÛÏDiaries (1971-1976),‰Ûù from 1982, a three-and-a-half-hour chronicle of his family life ‰ÛÓ is first seen wearing a surgical mask on a New York subway. He is introduced by Ms. Small, who reflects that New York City is a place where ‰ÛÏyou can turn a corner, and everything will change.‰Ûù Two of her closest friends, the artist Susan Woolf and the film editor Karen Schmeer, died violently within seven weeks, she says. Ms. Woolf was murdered, and Ms. Schmeer was killed in a hit-and-run accident. These shocks contribute to Ms. Small‰Ûªs heightened awareness that anything can happen at any moment.
This rich, sprawling film bears out the words in the unascribed epigraph that prefaces the film: ‰ÛÏThere could be a novel by Tolstoy in everyone‰Ûªs life.‰Ûù

Mr. Pincus was 75 when he died of leukemia, which had stemmed from a myelodysplastic syndrome, a bone marrow ailment. On top of that, he had Parkinson‰Ûªs disease. The medical question that haunts him in the film is whether to undergo a bone-marrow transplant that might prolong his life or shorten it, depending on the timing. No one can be sure. Throughout his ordeal, Mr. Pincus remains stoic, but his strength is visibly diminishing.

As much as the film is shadowed by a keen awareness of mortality, ‰ÛÏOne Cut, One Life‰Ûù often pulses with an almost ecstatic vitality. In its vision of human existence, life is as messy and unpredictable as it is precious. Beginning in the 1980s, Mr. Pincus took a 30-year sabbatical from filmmaking to run a successful flower farm in Roxbury, Vt. The documentary is punctuated by shots of flowers, trees and nature that are so ravishingly beautiful they make you want to turn your face to the sky, breathe deeply and embrace the moment like an ardent lover. Mr. Pincus will do anything for more time.

‰ÛÏOne Cut, One Life‰Ûù is also a valedictory to Mr. Pincus that touches on the milestones of his filmmaking career, including the 1967 documentary ‰ÛÏBlack Natchez‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Axe in the Attic,‰Ûù from 2007, his first collaboration with Ms. Small, which explored the impact of Hurricane Katrina. ‰ÛÏMy Father, the Genius,‰Ûù Ms. Small‰Ûªs 2002 documentary profile of her father, Glen Small, an eccentric, egotistic architect, is also noted.

The intensity of life lived in the shadow of a terminal illness is the subject of ‰ÛÏOne Cut, One Life,‰Ûù a portrait of the seminal documentarian Ed Pincus in his final years. Filmed by Mr. Pincus and his longtime collaborator Lucia Small, this extremely personal and moving documentary has several layers.

On another level, ‰ÛÏOne Cut, One Life‰Ûù is a quietly fraught domestic drama in which Ms. Small and Mrs. Pincus, an author of the classic women‰Ûªs health book ‰ÛÏOur Bodies, Our Selves,‰Ûù reluctantly find themselves engaged in a power struggle. Ms. Small and Mr. Pincus‰Ûªs platonic relationship is as passionate as any love affair, and Mrs. Pincus understandably can‰Ûªt help but feel threatened and marginalized. Mrs. Pincus initially disapproves of the film‰Ûªs being made and calls it ‰ÛÏrape,‰Ûù a term she quickly takes back. Because Ms. Small is much younger, Mrs. Pincus is embarrassed to find herself prone to bouts of insecurity and jealousy.
‰ÛÏEvery Secret Thing‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and disturbing themes.

The director, Amy Berg, is known for documentaries about unsettling things, including ‰ÛÏDeliver Us From Evil,‰Ûù which involved a pedophilic priest. Her instincts about how to pace a true story serve her well with this imaginary one, and so do the performances by Ms. Fanning and especially Ms. Macdonald. As Alice, she plays the plain, overweight half of the pair, resentful of never fitting in yet seemingly the more harmless of the two. For the movie to work she has to make both versions of Alice convincing, and she does.

Nothing is creepier than creepy children and teenagers, and the ones in ‰ÛÏEvery Secret Thing‰Ûù are first-rate examples. The story may be fictional ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs based on a Laura Lippman novel ‰ÛÓ but by the end of this movie you‰Ûªll be warier than ever of the local youngsters.

Diane Lane also has a tough assignment, playing Alice‰Ûªs mother, Helen, who appears unflustered by the swirl of events but may know more than she is telling. The script doesn‰Ûªt give her enough to work with; Helen is supposed to be an enigma but ends up being more of a vacuum, which isn‰Ûªt the same thing.

Ronnie (Dakota Fanning) and Alice (Danielle Macdonald) enter the juvenile prison system as young girls after kidnapping and somewhat inadvertently killing a baby. They are released at 18 and return to their hometown, and soon another baby disappears. The authorities (Elizabeth Banks and Nate Parker play the lead detectives) don‰Ûªt have to look too hard for suspects, but determining just who, if anyone, is guilty, and of what crime, is a tangle not easily unraveled.

The most persuasive character, barely seen, is Edith (Jordan Baker), Richard‰Ûªs ex-wife and Katherine‰Ûªs mother. Her anguished grief, conveyed with lacerating intensity by Ms. Baker, lays bare the self-obsession of the others and reveals the kind of beating heart the movie could use more of.

The movie, written and directed by Charlie Levi, is a deftly shot and edited succession of monologues, primarily from four aging, affluent Angelenos. Natalie (Barbara Hershey) is a real estate agent trying to rekindle her marriage despite an affair she has had; Harvey (James Naughton), Natalie‰Ûªs husband, is a diplomat and fancier of women whose job has kept him from Natalie for long stretches; Mary (Diane Venora) is an acerbic, pot-smoking, creatively stifled painter; and Richard (Joe Mantegna), Natalie‰Ûªs brother and Mary‰Ûªs ex-boyfriend, is a businessman whose daughter from a past marriage, Katherine, has died in a possible suicide. In a magical-realism flourish, Katherine herself (Natalie Dreyfuss, in her feature debut), a blithe spirit, addresses the camera from her coffin.
There‰Ûªs solid acting in ‰ÛÏChildless,‰Ûù but mostly there are words ‰ÛÓ torrents of them.
‰ÛÏChildless‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for profanity.

In extended passages perhaps better suited to the stage, the four adults talk about their petty conceits, resentments and regrets as they prepare for Katherine‰Ûªs funeral. Eventually their unwittingly selfish reactions come across as inappropriate under the circumstances. Even Richard seems so preoccupied that his reaction to the death of his own daughter is understated.

That would be Mr. Giger‰Ûªs home in Zurich, a murky warren of buckling bookshelves and crammed corridors. Disturbing paintings plaster the walls, endless iterations of his childhood terrors and lifelong obsessions. In them, metallic tentacles penetrate or sprout from soft female flesh, the tussle between birth and death replayed in erotic duels that the camera is reluctant to leave. When it does, it‰Ûªs to linger on skulls and other artifacts ‰ÛÓ the spooky detritus of a darkly creative life.

Nestled in this chaos, Mr. Giger is a benign, Yoda-like presence in declining health. (He died in 2014, at 74.) Gentle and modest, he shuffles in repetitive loops through his tangled yard, a child‰Ûªs wonderland of miniature railway cars and oversized sculptures. Partners past and current, romantic and professional, cycle through his front door bearing food and commentary that the director, Belinda Sallin, assembles in a free-form style that‰Ûªs carefully curated to flatter. It‰Ûªs disappointing: A man with this many skeletons on display must have a few in his closet.

For consolation, we must make do with the occasional juicy anecdote, like when the producers of ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù nixed the original design for the creature‰Ûªs eggs because their openings were ‰ÛÏtoo vaginalike.‰Ûù That its head was essentially a phallus with teeth must have escaped their notice.

If you crossed ‰ÛÏThe Addams Family‰Ûù with an episode of ‰ÛÏHoarders,‰Ûù you might come up with something like the documentary ‰ÛÏDark Star: H. R. Giger‰Ûªs World.‰Ûù A deferentially admiring visit with the Swiss surrealist artist whose beastie design for Ridley Scott‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù (1979) earned him Hollywood renown, this disordered portrait seems heavily influenced by its equally jumbled setting.

The scriptwriters, Kane Senes (who also directed) and John Chriss, keep the family secrets too bottled up, but the actors, who include William Forsythe as the McCluskey patriarch, play it with dark vigor.

James Badge Dale, whose rÌ©sumÌ© includes the mini-series ‰ÛÏThe Pacific‰Ûù and one of the better seasons of ‰ÛÏ24,‰Ûù is Wade, who as the movie opens is returning home after fighting for the Confederacy. ‰ÛÏHome‰Ûù is a remote place indeed ‰ÛÓ the story revolves around two families living on the edge of nowhere, with no sign of civilization nearby.

One of the families, the McCluskeys, had a robust cattle business before the war but lost all its livestock to the conflict. Wade‰Ûªs clan, the Rileys, traps animals for a living, a meager existence to begin with but one made more so because the McCluskeys are stealing from the snares.

Wade figures this out and moves to put a stop to it, but he is blundering into a situation he doesn‰Ûªt understand. Some kind of odd, symbiotic relationship between the families has developed while he has been gone, and what makes sense to him with the perspective his military service provided doesn‰Ûªt make sense in the cloistered world to which he has returned.
‰ÛÏEchoes of War‰Ûù is rated R (No one under 17 admitted without parent or adult guardian). Nudity and violence.

If you haven‰Ûªt had your dose of dourness for the day, ‰ÛÏEchoes of War‰Ûù will provide it in well-acted abundance. It‰Ûªs a gloomy, somewhat underwritten story of two families just after the Civil War, an exploration of the kind of disruption that lingers after fighting on the battlefield is over.

Mr. Hawke‰Ûªs anguished performance gives ‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù a hot emotional center. Tom is painfully aware that innocents will die from missiles dispatched from a great distance. In battle, of course, there is always the likelihood of collateral damage, but there‰Ûªs a difference between pulling a joystick while thousands of miles from a theater of war and risking your life in an aircraft. Tom observes in horror when civilians wander into a targeted site and are blown up.

Disregard the arguments for and against drone warfare advanced in ‰ÛÏGood Kill,‰Ûù and the movie still makes a persuasive case that our blind infatuation with all-powerful technology is stripping us of our humanity.
‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù is really a contemporary horror movie about humans seduced and hypnotized by machines into surrendering their souls: ‰ÛÏInvasion of the Body Snatchers‰Ûù for techies.

The movie makes you feel the confinement of the trailer in which Tom works, wearing headphones and sitting in front of a computer. He belongs to a group of technicians awaiting orders, including the most sympathetic fellow officer, Vera (ZoÌÇ Kravitz), the only woman in the unit. She and Tom conduct a discreet flirtation.

Scenes of Tom and his fellow officers out on the town suggest that the drinking and lap-dancing pleasures in Las Vegas ‰ÛÓ what Colonel Johns calls I&I (for ‰ÛÏintoxication and intercourse‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ are as mechanical as drone strikes. Viewed from above, the treeless suburban housing development in which Tom and other officers live is an ugly, sterile wasteland baking in the heat that resembles the arid Afghan villages that the drone strikes reduce to dust.

Early in the story, the operation is taken over by the C.I.A. (facetiously nicknamed Christians in Action), whose rules of engagement are much looser than those of the military. Even the hard-nosed Colonel Johns is abashed by the wider license to kill.

‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù at least makes a halfhearted attempt to justify drone warfare and its collateral damage. Most of those arguments are put in the mouth of Zimmer (Jake Abel), a gung-ho technician who reminds Tom that most of the casualties of the 9/11 terrorist attacks were American civilians. Zimmer‰Ûªs motto: ‰ÛÏFly and fry.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs no longer necessary to identify a specific target as the enemy to be eliminated. All that‰Ûªs required is for a ‰ÛÏpattern of behavior‰Ûù to be discerned. And Tom finds himself bombing a funeral for the victims of a strike. When rescue workers flock to the site of another explosion, he is instructed to kill them.
Tom blunts his guilt and boredom with booze swigged straight from the bottle. And his marriage to Molly (January Jones), a former dancer with whom he has two children, is in the deep freeze.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, including a rape; sexuality; and some strong language.

The film‰Ûªs conscience, Maj. Tom Egan (Ethan Hawke), is an embittered Air Force pilot who after six tours of duty flying F-16s, is now a drone operator in a cramped trailer at a base outside Las Vegas. Acutely nostalgic for the flashy heroics of aviation, Tom pleads to return to the sky, but drones have superseded aerial combat.

As you watch the smoke billow from a drone strike, it offers the cheap thrill felt by a child operating an Xbox, which the movie‰Ûªs resident expert, Lt. Col. Johns (Bruce Greenwood) explains was a model for drones. ‰ÛÏThe brass don‰Ûªt want to admit it,‰Ûù he tells underlings, ‰ÛÏbut half of you were recruited in malls precisely because you‰Ûªre a bunch of gamers.‰Ûù

As Tom‰Ûªs drinking worsens, and his inner turmoil reaches a boil, Mr. Hawke recalls Harrison Ford in his haunted, paranoid mode. At any second, you expect him to vomit up his bilious rage, but he resists.

Written and directed by Andrew Niccol (‰ÛÏGattaca‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù is a blunt, outspoken critique of remote-control warfare, which is transforming the ugly reality of battlefield carnage into a video game whose casualties are pixels on a screen. The killing is real, and yet it isn‰Ûªt. The title is the congratulatory jargon following an explosion that wipes out a terrorist cell or a Taliban hide-out in Afghanistan, Pakistan or Yemen.

The blocky exposition, although highly informative, lends ‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù a heavy-handed didacticism that undercuts the still shocking vision of the direction of modern warfare. Increasingly, it is a video game played by grown-ups who describe their dirty work in techno-speak that obscures what they are actually doing. Although the story is set back in 2010, when the use of drones was dramatically expanded, ‰ÛÏGood Kill‰Ûù still feels like science fiction.

Every so often, an image in ‰ÛÏAnimals‰Ûù will underline the implication of the title: that Jude and Bobbie, the drug addicts whose lives occupy the film‰Ûªs attention, lead a primal, almost bestial existence. Looking at predatory cats or beluga whales (on television and at the zoos and aquariums of Chicago, where ‰ÛÏAnimals‰Ûù was shot), you are invited to notice parallels to the couple‰Ûªs behavior: their moments of rest and tenderness, their fights and flights, their raw, ferocious need.

But that equivocation is also part of what makes the film, within its modest scope, affecting and interesting. Mr. Schiffli shoots in a fluid style, tweaking colors and focus to register changes in perception and feeling. Anxiety dissolves in sunshine and dreamy music, gathers up again in darker colors and more dissonant sounds and then winds up to a pitch of panic. It‰Ûªs awful and appealing, and much as you worry about Jude and Bobbie, you might envy them a little bit too.

The movie‰Ûªs evident sympathy for them at times shades toward sentimentality, and the story that emerges from their hustling and scoring is dealt from a stacked deck. When Jude and Bobbie run their scams, the marks are doughy, greedy hypocrites. When things go wrong, there are brutal policemen and unfriendly dealers to contend with. Only near the end, when the luck and the dope run out and the grifting turns desperate, do they encounter kindness or compassion. Otherwise, ‰ÛÏAnimals‰Ûù walks the fine line between acknowledging the romance of narcotics ‰ÛÓ something any honest movie about addiction must do ‰ÛÓ and actively romanticizing its sweet, basically harmless protagonists and their way of life.

But Jude (David Dastmalchian) and Bobbie (Kim Shaw) ‰ÛÓ young, attractive and described by Jude as college-educated and middle class ‰ÛÓ don‰Ûªt simply dwell in a state of nature. (Literally, they dwell in a beat-up car.) They see themselves less as instinct-driven creatures than as the only members of a self-contained civilization, with rules and rituals and a strong sense of standing together against the rest of the world. They are in love with each other and with heroin, and while this mÌ©nage ultimately turns into a tragic and tawdry love triangle, it also supplies Jude and Bobbie with a sense of common purpose.

‰ÛÏAnimals,‰Ûù directed by Collin Schiffli and written by Mr. Dastmalchian, doesn‰Ûªt break new ground in depicting the jagged rhythms of addiction. From ‰ÛÏThe Panic in Needle Park‰Ûù (an obvious precursor), to ‰ÛÏNurse Jackie,‰Ûù and through countless novels and memoirs, the daily routines of getting high offer an inexhaustible reservoir of narrative incident and a smeary, gritty palette of moods. For Bobbie and Jude, each day is a series of problems to solve, and when things work as planned ‰ÛÓ when they can snatch a wallet, sell a bunch of stolen CDs or rip off a would-be john and then use the proceeds to buy drugs from a familiar dealer ‰ÛÓ they bask in a smug feeling of triumph. It‰Ûªs more than just a chemical high; it‰Ûªs a kind of moral victory over the cruelties and compromises of the square world.

Its real subject is time and how people old enough to know the end is in sight deal with looming finality. Carol certainly has everything one could want at her age. With her cornflower blue eyes and Cheshire cat smile, she is still beautiful. She suffers from no discernible physical ailments, and she seems to have enough money (from life insurance, she explains) to be free of financial worries.

Decades earlier, Carol performed with a band in New York City but gave up singing to become a teacher. Coaxed to a karaoke bar by her glum, poker-faced pool cleaner, Lloyd (Martin Starr), with whom she strikes up an oddball friendship, she delivers a respectable version of ‰ÛÏCry Me a River,‰Ûù while he drones an excruciating, out of-tune ‰ÛÏI Think We‰Ûªre Alone Now.‰Ûù

To the lengthening list of well-mannered films aimed at moviegoers who have reached an age when, to quote Shakespeare, ‰ÛÏthe heyday in the blood is tame,‰Ûù add ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll See You in My Dreams,‰Ûù a modest, quietly touching portrait of an older woman radiantly embodied by Blythe Danner. Her character, Carol, widowed for two decades, is a nice, sensible woman who lives alone in a comfortable Southern California house with her ailing dog, Hazel. When, near the beginning of the movie, she has to have the animal put down, she is briefly grief-stricken.

The friends are played rather broadly, and each has her signature foibles. But the screenplay gives them no setups or punch lines. Except for one scene in which the four get goofy on marijuana, the movie doesn‰Ûªt strain for laughter.

A potential Mr. Right appears in the person of Bill (Sam Elliott), a snowy-haired widower and retiree with no family ties who lives on a boat conveniently docked nearby. The unlit cigar between his teeth, the glint in his eye and his deep cowboy voice signal virility. This aging dreamboat pursues Carol with a courtly machismo, and a spark is struck. But the movie bravely resists following the obvious route.
‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll See You in My Dreams‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for sexual material, drug use and brief strong language.

Carol, who lives near a retirement community, whiles away her afternoons playing bridge and sipping chardonnay with three of its residents, Georgina (June Squibb), Sally (Rhea Perlman) and Rona (Mary Kay Place), who pressure her to move there. As you watch the movie, directed by Brett Haley from a screenplay he wrote with Marc Basch, you half-expect it to turn into a 21st-century ‰ÛÏGolden Girls.‰Ûù And during its longueurs you wish it had.
But when most of your life is behind you, what does having everything really mean? That‰Ûªs the question this timid, wistful film addresses as it tiptoes around the subject of mortality.

Carol, a retired schoolteacher who married happily and had a daughter (Malin Akerman), who is now grown and living back East, scoffs at the possibility of remarrying or of even pursuing romance. Strictly as a lark, she experiments with speed-dating and is propositioned by a voracious eager beaver who volunteers that he doesn‰Ûªt mind if she has herpes.

Aside from a parting pitch for an increase in mentors and money, though, few ideas are offered on how to improve the system. Lacking that, ‰ÛÏKnow How‰Ûù is a robust, youthful call to be seen, heard and appreciated ‰ÛÓ to be a little less invisible.

Written and acted by young men and women who grew up in New York City‰Ûªs foster care system, ‰ÛÏKnow How‰Ûù tours the mean streets of a rough urban adolescence rarely acknowledged. Originally a musical presented by the nonprofit Possibility Project, the film weaves together tales of five teenagers striving for stability in turbulent settings.

The film is respectful of the adult professionals working with these hardened youngsters. Teachers, Legal Aid Society lawyers, judges, Children‰Ûªs Services administrators ‰ÛÓ all are doing tough jobs, and none are villains. (Oddly enough in a film about foster care, there are no scenes with foster parents.)

In the grimmest story, Megan (Claribelle Pagan) is taken from her abusive family, separated from her younger sister and put into a treatment center where she is bullied by other residents and heavily medicated. In others, teenagers lose loving relatives, turn to crime, sleep on the subway, have little hope.

The director, Juan Carlos Pineiro Escoriaza, coaxes mostly credible performances from his raw cast, especially Niquana Clark as Addie, a mouthy know-it-all who improves her grades in a bid to earn her high school diploma. The film‰Ûªs hip-hop interludes beat out a quickened tempo, and there is a polish to many scenes that does not undermine their authenticity.

Yes, I know. And also: Shut up. This fellow, whose daily routine is a circuit from screening room to laptop screen, with occasional stops at the newsroom and the cafe where his scruffy tribe gathers, is named Victor. (He‰Ûªs played by Rafael Spregelburd.) That‰Ûªs ironic because he‰Ûªs so obviously a loser: divorced, dissatisfied, trapped in the cage of his own snobbery, scratching out a marginal and largely pointless living. His interior monologue is in French because he thinks Spanish is too pompous in voice-overs, though the idea that anything would be too pompous for Victor is hard to believe. His editor wishes he would write something positive every now and then. His rich brother-in-law wants him to write a screenplay. His niece proclaims her love for the Hollywood romantic comedies that are understood to be the bane of a serious critic‰Ûªs existence.

The joke is on Victor: He learns the value of the kind of emotionally uplifting, optimistic story he had disdained for so long. Mr. Guerschuny can meanwhile have the satisfaction of both parodying and upholding the rules of the genre, putting us all in Victor‰Ûªs position. We get to feel knowing and sensitive at the same time.

Reviewing a pretentious little movie can be like shooting fish in a barrel. Sometimes all you can do is start with a clichÌ©. But sometimes the target in the water looks familiar, as if you were staring at your own glassy-eyed reflection. That is more or less the case with ‰ÛÏThe Film Critic,‰Ûù a movie from the Argentine director HernÌÁn Guerschuny whose protagonist is a grumpy middle-aged guy in less than perfect physical condition who writes dyspeptic notices for a big-city newspaper and hates just about everything that isn‰Ûªt Godard.

But ‰ÛÏThe Film Critic‰Ûù is at once too clever by half and not as smart as it pretends to be. If Victor were less of a clichÌ© to begin with ‰ÛÓ if anyone in the movie, for that matter, were a credible character with an interesting inner life ‰ÛÓ his predicament might have some weight. Or, if the movie had a more daring sense of style, it might take off into a dizzy meta-adventure. Instead, it‰Ûªs just another day at the office.

And then his life turns into one. Looking for a new apartment, he cute-meets Sofia (Dolores Fonzi), a young woman with a pink bicycle helmet, yellow tights, a vaguely exotic background and all the other signs of manic-pixie-dream-girl status. Soon Victor finds himself inhabiting the moments of a conventional romance plot. When he and Sofia first kiss, fireworks erupt in the sky. There is a shopping montage, a series of misunderstandings that threatens their bliss, a climactic race to the airport, a timely ‰ÛÏJerry Maguire‰Ûù quotation.

AgnÌ¬s (AdÌ¬le Haenel) is the most compelling part of Mr. TÌ©chinÌ©‰Ûªs zippy and drifty interpretation of the events, even with the director‰Ûªs longtime star Catherine Deneuve playing her mother and an opaque Guillaume Canet as Maurice. Ms. Haenel, who‰Ûªs an amusing tomboy in the coming ‰ÛÏLove at First Fight,‰Ûù poignantly portrays how her character‰Ûªs youthful defiance crumples into painful withdrawal in the face of Maurice‰Ûªs manipulation and indifference.
‰ÛÏIn the Name of My Daughter‰Ûù is rated R (No one under 17 admitted without parent or adult guardian). Sexuality, nudity, some foul language.

Set in sun-kissed Nice, France, ‰ÛÏIn the Name of My Daughter‰Ûù adapts the so-called Affaire Le Roux, a choice sample of family intrigue ready-made for a TV movie. In the 1970s, AgnÌ¬s Le Roux fell for her casino-running mother‰Ûªs lawyer, Maurice, who then connived to unseat them from management by pitting daughter against parent. AgnÌ¬s disappeared in 1977, and a court has ruled that Maurice was responsible.

AndrÌ© TÌ©chinÌ©‰Ûªs latest film, ‰ÛÏIn the Name of My Daughter,‰Ûù a bit like his ‰ÛÏThe Girl on the Train,‰Ûù centers on a young woman who hurls herself into an obsessive pursuit, heedless of the consequences as she fulfills a deeper need. Both are also dramas based on true stories, yet Mr. TÌ©chinÌ© uses this fodder not as a fount of titillating scandal but as a chance to portray mysterious urges and passions, which come to feel slightly less mysterious the closer we get.

But Mr. TÌ©chinÌ© ‰Ûªs methodical storytelling covers more narrative ground than the drama requires, sapping the film‰Ûªs energy. A concluding return to the present, when Maurice is brought to trial, feels unnecessary and clunky. While by no means misfiring, Mr. TÌ©chinÌ© is definitely capable of finer orchestrations.

But that description makes this experimental comedy, from Lev Kalman and Whitney Horn, sound more conventional than it is. Shot piecemeal, the film seems to see virtue in its slapdash qualities. The performances are stiff and amateurish, and exchanges of dialogue have the structure of jokes but don‰Ûªt quite pay off (unless mere mentions of Snapple and Marky Mark count).

One problem with this mode of filmmaking is that it is essentially unfalsifiable: No element, however random (say, a dog on a body board), can be deemed out of place. It is possible to admire Mr. Kalman and Ms. Horn‰Ûªs ambition and at the same time have no idea what they were trying to achieve.

Divided into segments with postcard-ready titles (‰ÛÏThanksgiving, 1992, Beaumont, TX‰Ûù; ‰ÛÏSummer Break, 1993, Baja, Mexico‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏL for Leisure,‰Ûù set in the early 1990s, follows graduate students on vacations around the world. The vignettes offer ample opportunities to watch ostensibly smart people behaving stupidly. The conceit, to paraphrase one character, is that grad school is for people who never moved on from high school.

There are occasional flashes of the sort of humor you associate with Whit Stillman, an acknowledged influence of the directors, as when a student (Benjamin Crotty) in Aix-en-Provence tries to explain in French that he and his friend are earning terminal degrees. (‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre both dying?‰Ûù their waiter replies.) It‰Ûªs a rare scene in ‰ÛÏL for Leisure‰Ûù that plays like something other than a private joke.

Let‰Ûªs back up for a moment. This ‰ÛÏMad Max‰Ûù unfolds in fast, hectic, relentlessly linear motion. It starts quietly, with Max standing on a dusty outcropping, casually snacking on a two-headed gecko as he sketches the relevant background in voice-over. When things started going bad ‰ÛÓ when the world collapsed in a welter of greed, violence and stupidity ‰ÛÓ he failed to protect his wife and daughter. Their memory both haunts and grounds him, making him able, even in the worst circumstances, to recognize decency in himself and others.

There is also enormous pleasure in watching those consequences play out, and in encountering surprises along the way. Not twists ‰ÛÓ the plot moves from Point A to Point B and back again, ending up pretty much where you knew it would ‰ÛÓ but kinks and swerves, tricks of perspective and playful reversals of expectation. A sweet, almost wordless romance blossoms between a hapless war boy (Nicholas Hoult) and one of Joe‰Ûªs brides, as she and her comrades evolve from eye candy into a feminist guerrilla force. They are joined by a band of older women called the Vuvalini, who along with Furiosa, decide to give Immortan Joe‰Ûªs patriarchy a taste of its own medicine.

Like Mr. Jones‰Ûªs universe, Mr. Miller‰Ûªs world has its rules. Viewers raised on the more baroque, digitally enabled forms of blockbuster spectacle are likely to admire the relative simplicity of ‰ÛÏFury Road,‰Ûù while aficionados of the traditional slam-bang methods will revel in its coherence. Even in the most chaotic fights and collisions, everything makes sense. This is not a matter of realism ‰ÛÓ come on, now ‰ÛÓ but of imaginative discipline. And Mr. Miller demonstrates that great action filmmaking is not only a matter of physics but of ethics as well. There is cause and effect; there are choices and consequences.

‰ÛÏFury Road,‰Ûù directed, like the others, by George Miller, is sort of a sequel, and also what we‰Ûªre now supposed to call a reboot. In any case, it doesn‰Ûªt traffic in the kind of half-jokey, half-sentimental self-consciousness that characterizes so much franchise entertainment these days. Unlike, say, ‰ÛÏAvengers: Age of Ultron,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFury Road‰Ûù does not usher you into a bright corporate universe where everything has been branded to within an inch of its life. The branding you witness here reminds you of the cruel etymology of the word, as a death‰Ûªs-head insignia ‰ÛÓ the mark of a tyrannical C.E.O. known as Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne) ‰ÛÓ is scorched into the flesh of people destined to live as property.

It‰Ûªs all great fun, and quite rousing as well ‰ÛÓ a large-scale genre movie that is at once unpretentious and unafraid to bring home a message. Way back in the ‰ÛÏThunderdome‰Ûù days, Tina Turner sang, ‰ÛÏWe don‰Ûªt need another hero.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs more true than ever, especially during summer movie season. And ‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road,‰Ûù like its namesake both humble and indomitable, isn‰Ûªt about heroism in the conventional, superpowered sense. It‰Ûªs about revolution.

And then the fights and chases commence. The whine and chug of souped-up engines, the whoosh of flames and the squeal of twisting metal ‰ÛÓ all the tried-and-true idioms of action filmmaking to make your heart beat faster. Speed and efficiency are of the essence, leavened with nasty biker wit and a blunt distaste for authority.
‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A ruthless critique of everything existing.

One of these, a designated ‰ÛÏblood bag‰Ûù kept alive to transfuse one of Joe‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏwar boys,‰Ûù is Max himself, played without a wasted word or gesture but with plenty of expressive grunts and snorts by Tom Hardy. Max, a Bogartian loner impelled by conscience to stick his (admirably thick) neck out for somebody, is really more sidekick than hero. The chief warrior on this road is Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron), a rebel with a buzz cut, a prosthetic arm, a thousand-mile stare and a supremely righteous cause. Joe, whose empire runs on slave labor, keeps a harem of women for breeding. Furiosa has five of them (Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, ZoÌÇ Kravitz, Riley Keough, Courtney Eaton and Abbey Lee) hidden in her tanker truck, and she‰Ûªs running a kind of underground railroad operation in the guise of a trading mission. Joe wants his property back, and sets out in pursuit with a battalion of war boys, a heavy-metal guitarist and a fleet of customized retro-futuristic vehicles.

The first ‰ÛÏMad Max,‰Ûù released in the United States in 1980 (with a soundtrack that dubbed the thick Australian accents), was a no-money Down Under cult-exploitation movie. ‰ÛÏThe Road Warrior‰Ûù (1981) was a little fancier, but it still had the snarl and velocity of a punk-rock club show. ‰ÛÏBeyond Thunderdome‰Ûù (1985) was arena rock by comparison, but Mr. Miller ‰ÛÓ whose rÌ©sumÌ© also includes ‰ÛÏThe Witches of Eastwick,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBabe: Pig in the City‰Ûù and both ‰ÛÏHappy Feet‰Ûù cartoon-penguin movies ‰ÛÓ has always stayed true to his scrappy, pragmatic roots. At 70, he has a master craftsman‰Ûªs intuitive sense of proportion and a visual artisan‰Ûªs mistrust of extraneous verbiage.

The script, which Mr. Miller wrote with Brendan McCarthy and Nico Lathouris, has been whittled almost clean of expository dialogue and touchy-feely bushwa. A cut or a pan can explain or express much more than words. When ‰ÛÏFury Road‰Ûù reaches for emotional grandeur it relies on the faces of its cast ‰ÛÓ Ms. Theron could be a silent-movie heroine, despite the noise that surrounds her ‰ÛÓ and on Junkie XL‰Ûªs superb, full-throated score. When it wants to crack jokes, the movie reaches for quick, profane sight gags or elaborate feats of Newtonian improbability.

Desolate, post-apocalyptic landscapes, zombie-ridden or not, are perennial popular tourist destinations for 21st-century moviegoers and couch potatoes. ‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road‰Ûù is like a visit to a World Heritage site. Some of us ‰ÛÓ old enough to remember when nuclear Armageddon had not yet given way to climate change as the main source of existential anxiety ‰ÛÓ harbor a special fondness for the young Mel Gibson as Max Rockatansky, the grieving, aggrieved former cop who motored across the Australian desert in ‰ÛÏMad Max,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Road Warrior‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBeyond Thunderdome.‰Ûù

Nearly all of which unfold in real physical space. It‰Ûªs worth paying a few more dollars for 3-D: That newfangled format brings out the virtuosity of Mr. Miller‰Ûªs old-school approach. The themes of vengeance and solidarity, the wide-open spaces and the kinetic, ground-level movement mark ‰ÛÏFury Road‰Ûù as a western, and the filmmakers pay tribute to such masters of the genre as John Ford, Budd Boetticher and, not least, Chuck Jones, whose Road Runner cartoons are models of ingenuity and rigor.

It made a darn good Hollywood movie, and the story of how the Canadian ambassador and others helped six American Embassy workers escape Iran in 1980 also makes a pretty watchable documentary. It‰Ûªs called ‰ÛÏOur Man in Tehran,‰Ûù and if it doesn‰Ûªt have the slickness of Ben Affleck‰Ûªs Oscar-winning version of events, ‰ÛÏArgo,‰Ûù it can claim authenticity. There‰Ûªs nothing like hearing a harrowing tale from the people who lived it.

The film, by Drew Taylor and Larry Weinstein, smoothly weaves together the accounts of Kenneth D. Taylor, the Canadian ambassador to Iran during the uprising that deposed the Shah; others in the Canadian and American Embassies; C.I.A. operatives, including the real Tony Mendez (the character played by Mr. Affleck); and journalists.

The directors sketch the growing revolution and the takeover of the American Embassy, during which more than 50 hostages were seized but six employees slipped away and into the protection of the Canadians. ‰ÛÏArgo‰Ûù was criticized for not giving the Canadians enough credit for helping to spirit the six out of Irandisguised as a film crew, but ‰ÛÏOur Man in Tehran‰Ûù certainly does, and it reminds us that this was not a movie, but scary real life.

‰ÛÏI‰Ûªve been through Mehrabad Airport several times,‰Ûù Carole Jerome, a Canadian journalist who covered the revolution, says of the pivotal moment when the fake film crew made it through airport checkpoints in Tehran. ‰ÛÏYou do not want to tangle with those people. If they get suspicious at the slightest little thing, you‰Ûªre gone into the back room. They ran a terrible risk there. It‰Ûªs almost cowboyism.‰Ûù

If the 100-odd minutes of ‰ÛÏPitch Perfect 2,‰Ûù briskly directed by Elizabeth Banks from a jam-packed script by Kay Cannon, consisted only of that scene, I wouldn‰Ûªt be disappointed. And if this is what musical comedy looks like on film today, that‰Ûªs O.K., too: the music is catchy and the jokes connect, even when they‰Ûªre easy. You can tell this is a sequel by the occasionally frantic mood and a sense of scale that feels a little off sometimes. ‰ÛÏPitch Perfect‰Ûù was a charming campus comedy with humor that was naughty and sweet and had a sharp sense of the pop-culture moment. Its success has allowed (or perhaps forced) this installment to be bigger, louder and wilder, with new, sometimes redundant characters, celebrity cameos ‰ÛÓ Snoop Dogg! Jake Tapper! The Green Bay Packers! ‰ÛÓ and artificially elevated dramatic stakes. Some of the underdog appeal is gone, but a victory lap can be its own kind of fun, and more is not necessarily something to complain about, especially when what there is more of is Fat Amy.

Maybe they will blossom in ‰ÛÏPitch Perfect 3.‰Ûù Meanwhile, this installment has improbable, inspired musical numbers and frequent occasions when everyone else wisely stands back and lets Ms. Wilson riff, gesticulate and manage to be utterly crude and impossibly graceful at the same time, as if she were the solution to a complicated math problem involving Divine, Dame Edna and Doris Day. Forget what I said before about the Green Bay Packers and songs about butts: If the whole movie were just Fat Amy singing in a rowboat ‰ÛÓ you‰Ûªll see what I‰Ûªm talking about ‰ÛÓ I would not go away mad.

New Bella blood arrives in the person of Emily (Hailee Steinfeld), who enrolls at Barden with the sole ambition of following in the footsteps of her mother (Katey Sagal) and becoming a Bella. Not to spoil anything, but she does and also gets a romantic subplot of her own, with a tongue-tied crooner played by Ben Platt.

Plot is kind of beside the point, though. It‰Ûªs there to give the characters something to do when they‰Ûªre not singing or acting silly. In the case of Fat Amy (Rebel Wilson), that is exactly never, but she and Bumper (Adam Devine) her friend-with-benefits, nonetheless contrive to encounter a bit of love trouble. That‰Ûªs one story. Another involves Beca (Anna Kendrick), whose commitment to the Bellas is tested by her internship at a record label, a situation that allows Keegan-Michael Key to steal a bunch of scenes as her boss.

‰ÛÏPitch Perfect 2‰Ûù is not as barbed as ‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù or as anarchic as ‰ÛÏBroad City‰Ûù (it‰Ûªs also studiously PG-13), but it lives in their neighborhood ‰ÛÓ or maybe a nearby suburb. And its arrival is another sign of the extent to which feminism is reshaping the landscape of American comedy, and not a moment too soon. Not every joke is in the best taste, and there are some failures of imagination, especially in the way the nonwhite Bellas (Ester Dean, Hana Mae Lee and Chrissie Fit) are confined to the margins and to the kind of stereotyping that tries to subvert itself with knowingness.

After an onstage wardrobe malfunction makes the Bellas pariahs in the a cappella world ‰ÛÓ the mishap, in front of an audience including President and Mrs. Obama, becomes an international news story ‰ÛÓ they set out to sing their way back to the top. They must overcome the skepticism of powerful podcasters (John Michael Higgins and Ms. Banks, playing a variation on her ‰ÛÏHunger Games‰Ûù smiley-underminer role), dissension in their own ranks and of course those Germans, whose leader is an icily charismatic Valkyrie (Birgitte Hjort Sorensen).
‰ÛÏPitch Perfect‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Campus life is probably not quite this wholesome. Neither is popular music, for that matter.

At one point in ‰ÛÏPitch Perfect 2,‰Ûù for no especially compelling narrative reason, the Barden Bellas, an all-girl a cappella group at a fictional Georgia college, find their way to an underground sing-off hosted by a pajama-clad harmony geek played by David Cross. The other contestants include the Treblemakers, the Bellas‰Ûª male counterparts; a highly disciplined German vocal ensemble and some Green Bay Packers. It‰Ûªs a single-elimination contest with strict rules, and the first category is Songs About Butts.

It‰Ûªs all very cute, and kind of beside the point. The glory of ‰ÛÏPitch Perfect‰Ûù is that it‰Ûªs devoted, above all, to the friendship and shared ambition of young women, and that it finds plenty of room within that premise for raunchiness, ridiculousness and warmth. The casual busyness of the plots does not distract from the essence of the movie, which is the pleasure and occasional stress of hanging out with like-minded girlfriends as you ease your way toward adulthood. Dudes are nice to have around, but the pursuit of them is a whole lot less than the meaning of life.

That lone researcher in his covered wagon who feeds Jay and gives him a blanket before disappearing into the night embodies the film‰Ûªs dreamlike perspective when he calmly observes, ‰ÛÏIn a short time, this will be a long time ago.‰Ûù

This episodic movie is really a series of visionary flashes of the New World being born, set to twangy old-time music. Silas reflects that in Jay‰Ûªs innocent eyes, they are ‰ÛÏin the land of hope and good weather.‰Ûù Silas sees it otherwise.

The beautifully choreographed scene in which the gang approaches the cottage from the field, heads bobbing in and out of view, is as witty as it is ominous. Once the gang takes over the house, Payne, wearing a twisted smile, aims his gun and jovially remarks: ‰ÛÏTurn around folks. It‰Ûªs over. It doesn‰Ûªt hurt.‰Ûù

A son of aristocrats, Jay has traveled all the way to America in pursuit of his sweetheart, Rose (Caren Pistorius), a girl from a humbler background who has settled on the Plains in a cabin with her father, John (Rory McCann). Jay doesn‰Ûªt know it, but the father and daughter are the targets of bounty hunters responding to wanted posters, and Silas hopes the boy will lead him to their door. A flashback reveals that Rose thinks of Jay as a younger brother and not as a lover, a possibility that the besotted Jay refuses to entertain.

Once Silas and Jay team up, they have a series of eerie encounters with various wanderers, dreamers and crooks. They come upon three affable Congolese musicians to whom Jay speaks French. At a general store, a desperate shotgun-wielding Swede and his wife demand money and pay with their lives as their two children wait patiently outside. Jay, briefly separated from Silas, encounters a friendly anthropologist in a covered wagon who says he is ‰ÛÏrecounting the decline of the aboriginal tribes in the hope of preventing their extinction by their conversion to Christianity.‰Ûù

The Scottish flashbacks raise more questions than they answer about why and how the father and daughter fled their homeland to end up on the edge of a wheat field in the middle of nowhere. As played by Mr. Smit-McPhee (Viggo Mortensen‰Ûªs son in ‰ÛÏThe Road‰Ûù) Jay is so dewy and naÌøve he suggests a mannequin freshly plucked out of clear plastic casing.
‰ÛÏKick over any rock, and most likely a desperado would crawl out and knife you in the heart if there was a dollar in it,‰Ûù he muses.

Set in Colorado in 1870 and filmed in New Zealand, ‰ÛÏSlow West‰Ûù follows as unlikely a pair of traveling companions as you‰Ûªll find in a movie posing as a western. Its laconic narrator, Silas (Michael Fassbender), who speaks in clipped poetic phrases, is an experienced frontiersman and cynical bounty hunter who appoints himself the paid chaperone of Jay (Kodi Smit-McPhee), a 16-year-old innocent from the Scottish Highlands. They meet by chance when the boy, who has miraculously survived his arrival in the Wild West without a scratch, is being menaced by a stray Union soldier hunting Indians for sport.
‰ÛÏSlow West‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence and strong language.

The glorious cinematography, by Robbie Ryan, sharply illustrates the disparity between the rugged majesty of the landscape and the savagery of its outlaws and adventurers, who resemble vermin scuttling through the underbrush of a perilous no man‰Ûªs land.

The surreal frontier fable ‰ÛÏSlow West,‰Ûù written and directed by John Maclean (‰ÛÏMan on a Motorcycle‰Ûù), is an absurdist deconstruction of classic Hollywood westerns whose 21st-century view of frontier mythology is as sardonic as that of the Coen brothers.

Reunited, the travelers encounter a gang of outlaws whose sinister leader, Payne (Ben Mendelsohn), an acquaintance of Silas in an enormous fur coat, is a fellow bounty hunter. The first time they cross paths, Payne is alone, and the three get drunk on absinthe, pass out and wake up in a drenching rain. Mr. Mendelsohn, who steals the Netflix series ‰ÛÏBloodline,‰Ûù nearly does the same in ‰ÛÏSlow West.‰Ûù

The characters who haven‰Ûªt already been dispatched converge in a shootout at the weirdly spick-and-span little house on the prairie occupied by Rose and her father. If you tallied up the number of shots fired by the characters, Rose would win hands down. She seems far too ferocious for the likes of Jay.
‰ÛÏWhere Hope Grows‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). An attempted assault and a few other unpleasant moments.

Here the movie has a chance to be something, especially with the appealing performance turned in by David DeSanctis, a young man with Down syndrome in his first acting role. His Produce is amusing and likable and exactly what Calvin needs to shake off his self-absorption. But just when their friendship catches your interest, Mr. Dowling reveals that he isn‰Ûªt really interested in exploring its possibilities at all; he‰Ûªs just using it to sell Christianity.
Not to be flip, but ‰ÛÏWhere Hope Grows‰Ûù has the potential to be a decent inspirational film until God shows up.

Produce, you see, carries a Bible and goes to church and, what do you know, so does the good-looking woman Calvin met while chatting with Produce at the grocery. This is a common and loathsome element in these types of films: If a fallen man will only embrace Jesus, a luscious romantic reward could be his.

The movie, written and directed by Chris Dowling, begins with a clichÌ©d character, the failed athlete with a drinking problem. He is Calvin (Kristoffer Polaha), who is brooding about his lost baseball career so much that all his personal relationships are in jeopardy, including the one with his teenage daughter (McKaley Miller). But he begins to change when he strikes up a relationship with a stock boy at the grocery who has Down syndrome and whom everyone calls Produce.
Once the proselytizing takes over, so does the predictability.

If Mr. Kashyap‰Ûªs previous films, like ‰ÛÏUgly‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThat Girl in Yellow Boots,‰Ûù have had an indie, sometimes arty sensibility, here, and in the ambitious ‰ÛÏGangs of Wasseypur,‰Ûù he paints on a bigger canvas, or perhaps a bigger screen, wedding indie impulses and Bollywood storytelling. For much of its first half, ‰ÛÏBombay Velvet‰Ûù hums with the kind of energy found in movies by the 1970s American directors Mr. Kashyap seems to admire. (Martin Scorsese is thanked in the head credits.)

The director Anurag Kashyap‰Ûªs cinematic touchstones don‰Ûªt end with Raj Kapoor. He also has a thing for American gangster movies. There are echoes here of ‰ÛÏThe Godfather‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏScarface‰Ûù (Brian De Palma‰Ûªs). James Cagney shows up, too; Johnny watches ‰ÛÏThe Roaring Twenties,‰Ûù with Cagney dying on snowy steps as a blonde intones, ‰ÛÏHe used to be a big shot.‰Ûù

Which is to say that ‰ÛÏBombay Velvet‰Ûù (great title) is more about movies than it is about gangsters. Mr. Kashyap‰Ûªs restless camera likes the look of rain on windshields and tommy guns, Art Deco nightclubs and girl singers with beehive ‰Ûªdos.
Still, as one fast operator tells our hero, ‰ÛÏThe map of Bombay is being redrawn, Johnny.‰Ûù Even with its faults, Mr. Kashyap‰Ûªs film is more evidence that the map of Bollywood is, too.

In the period world of ‰ÛÏBombay Velvet,‰Ûù Ranbir Kapoor ‰ÛÓ with his pencil mustache, crop of flyaway hair and broad-shouldered jacket ‰ÛÓ looks more than a bit like his grandfather Raj Kapoor. And he has some of his raffish, leading-man charm.

Mr. Kashyap is perhaps too faithful to his Bollywood imperatives, though. In the grand tradition, his film is overlong (149 minutes) and overplotted. (It‰Ûªs hard to keep track of all the dirty deals and dirty dealers carving up Bombay.) And just when you expect it to explode some of the clichÌ©s it reinvigorates, it embraces them instead.

Like the elder Kapoor in such films as ‰ÛÏAwaara‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏShree 420,‰Ûù Ranbir plays an underdog battling the system. He‰Ûªs Johnny Balraj, a petty gangster who doesn‰Ûªt mind taking a pounding or doling one out. Johnny runs a nightclub and longs for a piece of the real-estate pie that is Bombay in 1969, a city on the cusp of (over)development.

Mr. Ruizpalacios is chasing his own, somewhat different ‰Ûª60s shadows. With its sudden cuts, its fleet, ground-level camera work, its abrupt changes in tone, its blend of earnestness and insouciance, ‰ÛÏGÌ_eros‰Ûù is an unabashed hommage not only to the Nouvelle Vague but also to a more general international new wave-ism. The story pops and swerves; the images are by turns comical, banal and ravishing; and the result is a briskly shaken cocktail made of equal parts provocation and comfort. You come away with a buzz that is invigorating and pleasantly familiar.

In the Godardian spirit of ‰ÛÏMasculine Feminine‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBand of Outsiders‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ artifacts of a time when to be young and French was both the coolest and most ridiculous thing you could dream of being ‰ÛÓ Mr. Ruizpalacios mocks his characters with unstinting affection. Through TomÌÁs‰Ûªs eyes, Sombra is a charismatic mystery and an emotional wreck ‰ÛÓ a child more thoroughly and poignantly lost than his younger brother, who serves as the director‰Ûªs watchful alter ego. The relationship between them is the quiet heart of the film, which takes note of physical differences between them and hints at what those might mean.

Shot in black-and-white, in the boxy, old-fashioned aspect ratio that seems to be the latest thing in art-cinema retro fashion, Alonso Ruizpalacios‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGÌ_eros‰Ûù manages to feel both sweetly nostalgic and exuberantly now. It takes place in 1999, during a period of student unrest in Mexico, and many of the young people on screen, militants and slackers alike, live consciously in the shadow of 1968, when campus uprisings shook the country and were murderously suppressed by the military.

TomÌÁs (SebastiÌÁn Aguirre) is a teenager living in the coastal city of Veracruz whose exasperated mother exiles him to the capital after a water-balloon-throwing incident. That event is cleverly shown mainly from the point of view of the victim, a misdirection that sets the tone of frantic mischief that Mr. Ruizpalacios works hard to sustain. In Mexico City, TomÌÁs finds his older brother, Federico (nicknamed Sombra and played by the witty and soulful Tenoch Huerta), who lives in a filthy high-rise apartment with his roommate, Santos (Leonardo Ortizgris). A strike has disrupted their classes, but rather than join the other students who are occupying university buildings, Sombra and Santos declare themselves ‰ÛÏon strike from the strike.‰Ûù Sombra drinks, smokes, suffers through panic attacks and tries to master a card trick. His only connection to the outside world is Ana (Ilse Salas), a radical whose voice drifts in from a pirate radio station.

Sombra is in love with her, but she may be involved with another guy, a serious activist briefly glimpsed in full revolutionary pomposity at a chaotic meeting. When Santos, Sombra and TomÌÁs finally get it together to leave their pad ‰ÛÓ in flight from the very angry neighbor whose electricity they were borrowing ‰ÛÓ they eventually find Ana, and ‰ÛÏGÌ_eros‰Ûù becomes a ragged and romantic road movie. The young people zig and zag, quarrel and smoke, blithely confusing their own chaotic passions with the movements of history. There is a mission of sorts behind this wandering: to track down Epigmenio Cruz, a reclusive singer from the ‰Ûª60s whose music was so exquisite that he was rumored to have made Bob Dylan cry. (In one of the film‰Ûªs formal jokes, the soundtrack goes silent whenever someone puts on headphones to listen to one of his tunes.)

The movie‰Ûªs title is Mexican slang, derogatory but also at least sometimes affectionate, for people with light skin, a description that fits TomÌÁs (and Sebastian and Ana), but not Sombra, whose nickname means shade or shadow in Spanish. As they meander through poor neighborhoods and fancy parties, sampling hedonism, idealism and cruel cynicism, the viewer catches glimpses of a society seething with contradictions and half-buried class conflict. ‰ÛÏGÌ_eros‰Ûù is like a flip-book history lesson, one that evokes the pain and comedy ‰ÛÓ the pop, the politics, the tedium and the momentousness ‰ÛÓ of a particular moment in the endless, cyclical chronicles of youth and disillusionment.

‰ÛÏThe Japanese Dog,‰Ûù the first feature from Tudor Cristian Jurgiu, is an hommage to Ozu, down to the way Mr. Jurgiu often isolates different generations within the frame. The protagonist, Costache (Victor Rebengiuc), is a curmudgeon reeling from his wife‰Ûªs death and his house‰Ûªs destruction in a flood. When the movie opens, he is reluctant to accept help from others and is under pressure to sell his land.

His son, Ticu (Serban Pavlu), an engineer living in Japan, returns home, bringing his wife and their son. The visit gives Costache a chance to act as a grandparent and to discuss unresolved matters, like the romance Ticu left behind and what Ticu sees as his father‰Ûªs chronic failure to communicate.

While it lacks the richness of some of Ozu‰Ûªs masterworks, ‰ÛÏThe Japanese Dog‰Ûù steers clear of sentimentality ‰ÛÓ an impressive feat, given that the title somewhat preciously refers to a toy dog. The movie depicts a hopeful side of Romania, peeking through even Costache‰Ûªs lonely world.

On the surface, the brooding, cynical dramas that have come to represent the standard of Romanian cinema ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Death of Mr. Lazarescu,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days‰Ûù‰ÛÓ have little in common with the humane family portraits of the great Japanese filmmaker Yasujiro Ozu (‰ÛÏTokyo Story‰Ûù).
