Newton‰Ûªs nautical journey has sequences evoking a stage musical (notably with spirituals sung by the baritone Jubilant Sykes) and an ocean tempest that induces a religious epiphany in Newton. The plot strands, of course, eventually intersect; faith plays a part in both, but not to a belabored degree.

‰ÛÏFreedom‰Ûù does not remotely approach, say, ‰ÛÏ12 Years a Slave‰Ûù in its production values or dramatic impact. But it does offer Mr. Gooding, whose weathered countenance is no longer the exuberantly cherubic face featured in ‰ÛÏJerry Maguire.‰Ûù In its place is something more interesting: a quiet, rugged and arresting conviction.

‰ÛÏFreedom‰Ûù takes a compelling chapter in American history ‰ÛÓ the flight of slaves from Southern bondage to Canada via the Underground Railroad ‰ÛÓ and flattens its drama. The film pursues twin narratives: one, starting in 1856, presents the trek of a slave, Samuel Woodward (Cuba Gooding Jr.), and his family from the Richmond, Va., area to points north; the other, beginning in 1748, follows the fact-based story of John Newton (Bernhard Forcher), an English slave trader voyaging from Gambia to Charleston, S.C.
‰ÛÏFreedom‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A few shootings, a brief whipping scene.

Saverio Costanzo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHungry Hearts‰Ûù begins promisingly with a meet-cute scene that compresses the progress of relationship intimacy into just a few minutes. Jude (Adam Driver) and Mina (Alba Rohrwacher) find themselves locked in the bathroom of a Chinese restaurant, where they are forced to share close quarters, endure unpleasant odors and get to know each other.

Mr. Costanzo and the cinematographer Fabio Cianchetti do bring a picturesque long view to the Upper West Side setting (though the orchestral music by Nicola Piovani feels annoyingly on point). Mr. Costanzo‰Ûªs attempt at rendering the fraying of minds and marital bonds draws on notions of hysteria that only shortchange his characters.

Baby and marriage are soon endangered, and the film‰Ûªs initial naturalism is warped by overheated film technique and a dead-ending screenplay (adapted by Mr. Costanzo from a novel). Ms. Rohrwacher‰Ûªs gentle expressiveness is flattened by a role requiring a monotonous strain of suspicion and mental imbalance. At one point, an extreme camera lens turns her into an apparition from those 1990s Steve Madden commercials. Mr. Driver applies his flair for picking through scenes and injecting sincere exasperation, but he, too, is boxed in by the child-in-peril plotting. So is Roberta Maxwell, as his abrasive, protective mother.

A few cuts later, the young New York couple ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs an American engineer, she‰Ûªs an Italian diplomat ‰ÛÓ pair up and experience a career conflict, a wedding and the birth of a baby. From there, it‰Ûªs unfortunately a hop, skip and a fisheye-lens away to a bafflingly misjudged drama about Mina‰Ûªs obsession with vegan diets and isolationist parenting.

Unlike those in many art-house releases, this wilderness is not an abstract arena for playing out alienation but a living, breathing land with deep, abiding significance for Charlie and his fellow Aborigines cast adrift. Mr. de Heer resists the impulse to give the character an unrealistic ability to rebel without consequences, and instead features the attrition of alcoholism and malnutrition.

In Australian cinema, the wilderness has long served as a rebuke to the primacy of Western civilization. With ‰ÛÏTwelve Canoes‰ÛÏ and now ‰ÛÏCharlie‰Ûªs Country,‰Ûù the Dutch-Australian director Rolf de Heer has portrayed the lived experience of Aboriginals that are often treated as part of an exotic landscape. Using a combination of bleak realism, fatalistic humor and a healthy dose of sentimentality, Mr. de Heer traces the downward spiral of a man who has become a refugee in his own homeland.

At the same time, however, an obligatory feel creeps into Charlie‰Ûªs successive travails, as if Mr. De Heer is putting the character through his paces and surrounding him with a dutifully representative spectrum of sympathetic-to-condescending whites. The simplistic piano score doesn‰Ûªt help.

The star David Gulpilil, an Aborigine, plays Charlie, who lives in a shack provided by the government and fitfully feels the pangs of injustice. He leads an easy-come-easy-go existence that results partly from temperament and partly from destitution; the plot lurches along according to his clashes with the police.
But Mr. de Heer‰Ûªs relentless treatment may well suit the background history of Western land appropriation, which isn‰Ûªt necessarily one of elegance or subtlety.

This Canadian feature, expanded by its director, Craig Goodwill, from a short, suggests a discount version of the kind of topsy-turvy dystopia associated with Tim Burton, Terry Gilliam or, circa ‰ÛÏWho Framed Roger Rabbit,‰Ûù Robert Zemeckis. While the results are more creepy than charming ‰ÛÓ too childish for adults, though not necessarily too dark for children ‰ÛÓ it is hard to fault Mr. Goodwill for trying.

In Patch Enterprises‰Ûª company town, workers extract babies from cabbages to be turned into dolls. Show tunes are forbidden during work hours ‰ÛÓ a real drag for Jon (Rob Ramsay), a bushy-haired former doll with unflagging good cheer. Helped by a driver, Sly (Suresh John), he escapes to the real world with his wife, Mary (Stephanie Pitsiladis), and their baby. If the Muppets could take Manhattan, then cabbage dolls can take Toronto (indicated by a neighborhood but not formally named).

Mr. Goodwill has fun with the fish-out-of-water comedy, introducing Jon and Mary to the concept of rent and later putting Jon and Sly in police custody. But the heart of the movie is in the visually under-realized Patch Town, where Jon and the others foil the kidnapping plot of an evil tycoon (Julian Richings, hitting just the right note of cartoonishness). In toy terms, ‰ÛÏPatch Town‰Ûù is a specialty item.

Give ‰ÛÏPatch Town‰Ûù credit for seeking a fresh niche: It‰Ûªs not as though we have a glut of musical fairy tales inspired by Eastern European folklore in which vivified toys revolt against an unscrupulous corporate overlord.

Susan is anxious, awkward and eager to please, her intelligence and competence in perpetual struggle with her low self-esteem. Once in the field, though, she undergoes a transformation that is all the more entertaining because it doesn‰Ûªt quite make sense. Rebelling against the typecasting of her undercover identities ‰ÛÓ a Midwestern cat enthusiast, a bedraggled single mom ‰ÛÓ Susan reinvents herself as an elegant espionage artiste. Instructed to observe and report on the doings of a Bulgarian arms dealer (Ms. Byrne), she goes rogue in every imaginable way and proves herself adept at fighting second-string femmes fatales and random dark-suited minions, as well as flying planes and conducting high-speed chases through European cities.

But this movie, written and directed by Paul Feig, is very much Ms. McCarthy‰Ûªs show, a potential franchise built around her talents and her proven audience appeal. When ‰ÛÏThe Heat‰Ûù (also directed by Mr. Feig) was released a few years ago, I complained that its threadbare genre elements made it a less-than-perfect vehicle for its newly fledged star. That film‰Ûªs box-office mileage suggests that I may have been wrong, and even though ‰ÛÏSpy‰Ûù is similarly engineered to be easy, forgettable fun, it is likely to be a big hit.

Along the way she tangles with Mr. Statham‰Ûªs character, an arrogant peacock who brags about exploits that sound like outtakes from Jason Statham movies. She also attracts the attention of Aldo (Mr. Serafinowicz), an amorous Italian who shows up every time ‰ÛÏSpy‰Ûù threatens to tilt too far toward the action end of the action-comedy spectrum.

Even better is the blithe feminism that makes ‰ÛÏSpy‰Ûù feel at once revolutionary and like no big deal. It‰Ûªs not just that the movie aces the Bechdel test. It didn‰Ûªt even need to study. The movie isn‰Ûªt uplifting; it‰Ûªs buoyant. While Susan at first clearly has a lot to prove ‰ÛÓ that she‰Ûªs a skilled professional and a ruthless adversary, everyone else‰Ûªs doubts to the contrary ‰ÛÓ Mr. Feig doesn‰Ûªt make her proving it the central arc of the narrative. Instead, he highlights Ms. McCarthy‰Ûªs quickness and unpredictability, her genius for defying logic and decorum. She can be ridiculous and heroic, needy and scary, clueless and clever ‰ÛÓ in quick succession and sometimes all at once.

This movie is fancier than ‰ÛÏThe Heat‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏBridesmaids‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ flush with high-end visual effects purchased on the strength of their success. And the big, hectic set pieces aren‰Ûªt bad, as long as the gunfire doesn‰Ûªt drown out Ms. McCarthy‰Ûªs floridly inventive insults and non sequiturs. There‰Ûªs an undercurrent of cheeky surrealism that sometimes pops to the surface: For some reason C.I.A. headquarters are infested with bats and mice; for some reason the rapper 50 Cent is in Budapest; for some reason Ms. Byrne is Bulgarian.

And why not? The busy, silly script allows Ms. McCarthy to be her own best sidekick, in effect an entire sketch-comedy troupe unto herself. She starts out as Susan Cooper, a mousy, cheerful desk jockey at C.I.A. headquarters where, despite her training and her status as a full-fledged officer, she is ignored and belittled. Her job is to be the eyes and ears of Bradley Fine (Mr. Law), a glamorous would-be 007 who relies on Susan‰Ûªs expertise and toys with her feelings.

In ‰ÛÏSpy,‰Ûù a wild, profane, surprisingly bloody caper-comedy, Melissa McCarthy appears on screen with various sidekicks, nemeses, foils, straight men (and women) and human punching bags. Among them are Jason Statham, Jude Law, Allison Janney, Bobby Cannavale and Rose Byrne, who are accomplished and by now fairly well-established banterers and counterpunchers in their own right. Even better ‰ÛÓ and less familiar ‰ÛÓ are Peter Serafinowicz and the marvelous Miranda Hart (Chummy to all you ‰ÛÏCall the Midwife‰Ûù fans out there) as two of the unlikelier C.I.A. employees in recent cinema.
‰ÛÏSpy‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Salty and bloody.

Other lines seem scripted by a legal defense team: One staffer tells Mr. Blatter, ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªve been betrayed by the people you‰Ûªve put in power.‰Ûù Another asks, ‰ÛÏWhen are you going to do something to defend yourself?‰Ûù Mr. Auburtin and some of the actors, who surely knew better, have made noises about being hamstrung by FIFA‰Ûªs financing. Not so fast. If cynicism were a crime, they‰Ûªd be taking a sheet-covered perp walk of their own.
It turns out there is such a thing as bad publicity after all. Just ask Sepp Blatter.
While he waits for other shoes to drop, he might want to curl up with ‰ÛÏUnited Passions,‰Ûù the dramatized history of FIFA that the association mostly financed and in which he figures prominently.

As you may have heard, Mr. Blatter, the head of soccer‰Ûªs governing body, the FÌ©dÌ©ration Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), has had a busy couple of weeks ‰ÛÓ avoiding arrest while 14 colleagues and associates were indicted on fraud and corruption charges; winning re-election to a fifth term as FIFA president; deciding to resign.

Yet there is barely a nod to the corruption scandals that have plagued FIFA for decades. Instead, what passes for drama comes when Mr. Blatter assumes command in 1998. He is shocked, shocked, to find affairs in disarray and tells his executive committee there‰Ûªs a new sheriff in town: ‰ÛÏSome of you feel this is an opportunity to close lucrative deals. Think again.‰Ûù And, ‰ÛÏThe slightest breach of ethics will be punished.‰Ûù

The stories are of deals made ‰ÛÓ with Uruguay, to host the first Cup in 1930; with African soccer representatives for political support; with Coca-Cola and Adidas for exclusive marketing agreements ‰ÛÓ not games played. At least not soccer. (Indeed, surprisingly little soccer is shown.)

Or, maybe not. ‰ÛÏUnited Passions‰Ûù is one of the most unwatchable films in recent memory, a dishonest bit of corporate-suite sanitizing that‰Ûªs no good even for laughs. Directed by FrÌ©dÌ©ric Auburtin from a script he wrote with Jean-Paul Delfino, ‰ÛÏUnited Passions‰Ûù tracks the rise of the World Cup through three FIFA presidents: Jules Rimet (GÌ©rard Depardieu), who thought up the tournament in the 1920s; JoÌ£o Havelange (Sam Neill), who expanded its reach in the ‰Ûª70s and ‰Ûª80s; and particularly Mr. Blatter (Tim Roth), who came aboard in the ‰Ûª70s and succeeded Mr. Havelange in the ‰Ûª90s.

Trying to make a fresh start after their college-age son, Bobby, dies, Anne and Paul Sacchetti (Barbara Crampton, ‰ÛÏRe-Animator‰Ûù and Andrew Sensenig, ‰ÛÏUpstream Color‰Ûù) make a move in bleakest winter. Like many judgment-impaired horror movie couples, they leave ‰ÛÏthe city,‰Ûù presumably Boston, where they must have friends and perhaps livelihoods, for creepy Aylesbury, Mass., a village of strangers. Their new home? A charmless, isolated, hideously decorated handyman special built in 1859 for the short-lived town undertaker.

Ted Geoghegan, in his feature film debut as a director, also wrote the screenplay. His inspiration is as retro as the antique lenses selected to capture the movie in dusty, faded tones, but his sketchy plot will make you appreciate the newspaper headlines rolling past at the close that fill in enough exposition to make sense of the rickety story line and make clear what‰Ûªs really haunting the house. Sort of.

Some of the scariest and funniest bits come from May‰Ûªs husband, Jacob, the veteran horror actor Larry Fessenden (director of ‰ÛÏWendigo‰Ûù), who reaches back to ‰ÛÏThe Shining‰Ûù and Jack Nicholson‰Ûªs crazy eyes, and draws on the archetypal genre battle for a human soul, ‰ÛÏThe Exorcist,‰Ûù as he wrestles with a demon. (He loses and has to swallow a nasty-looking gym sock.)

Set in a vague era before cellphones, ‰ÛÏWe Are Still Here‰Ûù will make you scream and make you laugh, and possibly leave you speechlessly gesticulating at a charred zombielike ghost in the background. But the peak moments are too few, considering those incendiary, cinder-fingered ghosts who can sear with a touch, the bloodthirsty small-town mob and the steak-knife-versus-sickle combat.
The Sacchettis‰Ûª friend May (Lisa Marie, of ‰ÛÏEd Wood‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMars Attacks‰Ûù), who dabbles in the paranormal, comes to investigate Anne‰Ûªs hopeful sense that Bobby‰Ûªs spirit is in the house.

Most likely, ‰ÛÏInsidious: Chapter 3,‰Ûù directed by Leigh Whannell (who wrote the first two). A prequel to the original, ‰ÛÏChapter 3‰Ûù concerns Quinn Brenner (Stefanie Scott), a teenager trying to connect with her dead mother. To that end she enlists the spirit wrangler Elise Rainier (Lin Shaye), who aided the family in need in Chapters 1 and 2. Quinn‰Ûªs brother suggests Spectral Sightings ‰ÛÓ a ghost-hunting operation comprising two bickering nerds (Angus Sampson and Mr. Whannell) ‰ÛÓ to help Elise, and lo! Three franchise regulars are born! Needless to say, evil entities crash the party.

About the importance of actors: Mr. Whannell wisely retains the series‰Ûª secret weapon, Ms. Shaye, a seasoned performer of range, moxie and limitless charm. The third chapter finally gives her character a romantic back story and a chance to clobber a demon. And Ms. Shaye gives ‰ÛÏInsidious‰Ûù more than sufficient reason for a Chapter 4.

In 2011, James Wan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏInsidious,‰Ûù the tale of a family terrorized by malign spirits, was the little horror movie that could: On a budget of $1.5 million, it made almost $100 million worldwide. Its sequel, in 2013, cost about $5 million and took in around $162 million. How did these modest pictures, virtually devoid of gore, nudity and cursing, prove so profitable? With decent actors, for one thing. And with simple but cohesive plots, tidy production values, effective ‰ÛÏBoo!‰Ûù moments and a sense of humor. What more could a 14-year-old at the mall on a Friday night ask for?
‰ÛÏInsidious: Chapter 3‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Harmless jolts.

Working together ‰ÛÓ but also in isolation from each other, like musicians in separate recording booths ‰ÛÓ Mr. Cusack and Mr. Dano create a remarkable composite performance, a set of before-and-after pictures that is also a perfectly unified, hauntingly complex portrait. Mr. Dano, gentle and inscrutable as a panda bear, conveys the pathos of a young man‰Ûªs unraveling. The Beach Boys were a family business, including Brian‰Ûªs brothers Carl (Brett Davern) and Dennis (Kenny Wormald) and their cousin Mike Love (Jake Abel). Their rise, chronicled in a lively montage of early hits, was overseen by Murry Wilson (Bill Camp), an abusive patriarch who hung around to undermine and humiliate his sons, Brian in particular, even after being fired as the group‰Ûªs manager.

The first thing you see in ‰ÛÏLove & Mercy‰Ûù is an extreme close-up of Brian Wilson‰Ûªs ear. It‰Ûªs a startling image, and it holds out a twofold promise: that the film will take viewers inside its protagonist‰Ûªs head and that it will pay particular attention to the role that sound played in his life.

This film deepens that appreciation and illuminates its sources. Mr. Pohlad‰Ûªs deft narrative sense and careful visual style are complemented by the work of Atticus Ross, whose sonic collages ‰ÛÓ‰ÛÏscore‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt quite do justice to his achievement ‰ÛÓ take us deeper inside a musical mind than we might have thought possible. ‰ÛÏLove & Mercy‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt claim to solve the mystery of Brian Wilson, but it succeeds beyond all expectation in making you hear where he was coming from.

The movie is careful not to push too far into Freudian psychodrama. Brian‰Ûªs mental collapse is not directly attributed to his abusive father or to the pressures of fame. At a certain point, the sounds in his head take on a sinister cast, and his odd behavior and paranoid ramblings frighten his bandmates and his first wife, Marilyn (Erin Darke). LSD doesn‰Ûªt help. By the time he meets Melinda, though, his breakdown is in the past. He strikes her as a sweet, soft-spoken eccentric, a pampered rich guy who is also kind and vulnerable. He shocks her sometimes by referring almost casually to the trauma and abuse in his past and gradually reveals the terror that governs his present-day life.

For the most part, this movie, a smart, compassionate, refreshingly unconventional biopic directed by Bill Pohlad, makes good on both promises, exploring the mental world and the artistic method of a great artist. It‰Ûªs a loving tribute to the Beach Boys and the man responsible for their distinctive sound, but it goes to deeper and stranger places than most movies of its kind. On screen, the lives of musicians tend to follow a tried-and-true outline: A rise to fame is followed by a personal and professional crisis, often involving drugs, which is followed by a redemptive third act. What is often missing from the formula is any real insight into the reason we might be interested in the first place, which is the music. We might see our idol, more or less persuasively impersonated by a hard-working actor, strumming a guitar or noodling at a piano, but the complicated labor of creativity is notoriously hard to show on screen.

The making of ‰ÛÏPet Sounds‰Ûù is the centerpiece of ‰ÛÏLove & Mercy.‰Ûù It also represents a plateau of calm and control in the midst of a life full of chaos and pain. Instead of telling the story in full, the film shifts back and forth ‰ÛÓ fluidly and seamlessly ‰ÛÓ from the ‰Ûª60s to the ‰Ûª80s, when Brian, now played by John Cusack, first meets Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks), in a Cadillac showroom in Los Angeles. Their courtship is complicated by the presence of Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti), a psychologist who serves as Brian‰Ûªs guru, dietitian and legal guardian.

Mr. Pohlad, an accomplished producer who had the cooperation of Mr. Wilson and his wife, Melinda, doesn‰Ûªt just overcome this challenge; he makes witnessing the creation of a record as exciting as hearing a classic song for the first time. One of the best things about ‰ÛÏLove & Mercy,‰Ûù which was written by Oren Moverman and Michael Alan Lerner, is how long it lingers in the recording studio, observing as Brian, played in his 20s by Paul Dano, is putting together ‰ÛÏPet Sounds,‰Ûù by consensus one of the great albums of its era.

The attention to detail in these scenes provides a feast for geeks of all kinds, as the camera lovingly ogles microphones, amplifiers and consoles that were state of the art in the mid-1960s. Watching Brian, with his boyish face and eager puppy-dog manner, adjusting the knobs and directing the session players, is like watching a kid in a toy store. He is freer and more confident than ever before, layering and sculpting improbable instruments and bewitching harmonies into songs that are at once exquisitely simple and astonishingly sophisticated.

If the ‰Ûª60s half of ‰ÛÏLove & Mercy‰Ûù is, in part, a trippy excursion into a golden piece of the California past, the ‰Ûª80s section is a spooky Los Angeles noir. Told almost entirely from Melinda‰Ûªs perspective, it follows her discovery of the hidden, sinister dimensions of Dr. Landy‰Ûªs apparent benevolence. A jolly, friendly fellow on the surface, Landy is both a one-of-a-kind creep (Mr. Giamatti‰Ûªs smile will give you nightmares, as will his hair) and a recognizable type of villain. Melinda, whose sunny disposition masks a steely, icy resolve, makes a very satisfying foil, and Ms. Banks‰Ûªs astute performance, in a series of eye-catching period-appropriate outfits, is what binds the film together. Melinda is the only person who can love and appreciate Brian for who he is, and as such she is the stand-in for the rest of us, who admire what he accomplished.
‰ÛÏLove & Mercy‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Not all the vibrations are good.

‰ÛÏTestament of Youth,‰Ûù James Kent‰Ûªs stately screen adaptation of the British author Vera Brittain‰Ûªs 1933 World War I memoir, evokes the march of history with a balance and restraint exhibited by few movies with such grand ambitions. Most similar films strain at the seams with bombast and sentimentality. This one, with a screenplay by Juliette Towhidi (‰ÛÏCalendar Girls‰Ûù), is consciously old-fashioned ‰ÛÓ or should I say traditional? ‰ÛÓ while maintaining a sober perspective.

The movie unashamedly invokes two famous scenes in Hollywood movies films set during wartime. A tearful farewell at a train station strongly echoes Jennifer Jones and Robert Walker‰Ûªs parting as he goes off to fight and die in the 1944 tearjerker ‰ÛÏSince You Went Away.‰Ûù

Soon Vera leaves Oxford for grueling training as a nurse. The movie never asks us to regard her as a swoon-worthy angel of mercy but as a tough, smart woman of action who chokes back her fear and revulsion to do what must be done. At no point does ‰ÛÏTestament of Youth‰Ûù coddle her with misty soft-focus photography.

Vera chafes at her parents‰Ûª efforts to groom her into a model future wife. Determined to go to Oxford, she rejects the piano her father (Dominic West) gives her and reminds him that it cost the same as a year in college. Contrary to the wishes of her severe, eagle-eyed mother (Emily Watson), Vera is not a flower waiting to be picked by a wealthy suitor, and her parents are aghast when she announces she will never marry. A wary attraction develops between Vera and Roland, both of whom write poetry, but they can meet only with a chaperone present. Nevertheless, they fall in love.

‰ÛÏTestament of Youth,‰Ûù however, is not fiction; Vera and the other major characters are real-life figures who faced the horrors of the First World War. The movie is also the stronger for having no battle sequences or scenes depicting acts of courage, though you hear about such heroics after the fact. There are just enough shots of life in the trenches to give a glimpse of a hell, peopled by exhausted, mud-covered soldiers who are almost unrecognizable from the vital young men who left Britain thinking they were bound for glory. Other scenes in army hospitals in England and behind the lines in France are unrelievedly grim tableaus.

The absence of battlefield heroics fortifies the movie‰Ûªs staunchly antiwar perspective. The more Vera sees, the more she internalizes the grim reality she absorbs. In one of the saddest scenes, Roland returns on leave with symptoms of what is now called post-traumatic stress disorder. When she asks if he has written any poems while at the front, he contemptuously scoffs: ‰ÛÏPoetry! Oh, for God‰Ûªs sake!‰Ûù

An even more conspicuous allusion is a crane shot at a French field hospital where countless wounded and dying soldiers are surveyed from above as the widening focus takes in almost unimaginable suffering in a sea of mud. This powerful moment isn‰Ûªt spoiled by its resemblance to a similar overhead shot of the streets of Atlanta packed with wounded Confederate soldiers in ‰ÛÏGone With the Wind.‰Ûù Quite the contrary, it reminds you of the degree to which Hollywood molded our ideas of conflict and places ‰ÛÏTestament of Youth‰Ûù in a continuum of commercial high-minded war movies.

While hardly cold, ‰ÛÏTestament of Youth‰Ûù avoids the temptation to elicit tears, although a reading in the film of Roland Leighton‰Ûªs poem ‰ÛÏVillanelle‰Ûù cuts to the bone. As for the bright, handsome eager beavers who excitedly troop off to a war they believe will end in a matter of weeks, they haven‰Ûªt an inkling of the fate that awaits them.

No sooner is war declared than first Roland, then Edward, then Victor ‰ÛÓ who pines after Vera ‰ÛÓ succumb to war fever and heed the call to fight. Vera‰Ûªs father relents and sends her to Oxford, where she has a stern but sympathetic adviser in Miss Lorimer (Miranda Richardson).

The film begins on Armistice Day 1918, then flashes back four years to a scene of Vera, her younger brother Edward (Taron Egerton) and his prep school friends Victor Richardson (Colin Morgan) and Roland Leighton (Kit Harington from ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù) frolicking in the countryside.
‰ÛÏTestament of Youth‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Bloody and disturbing war images.

All this is viewed through the eyes of Vera, portrayed by the Swedish actress Alicia Vikander (‰ÛÏAnna Karenina,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏEx Machina‰Ûù), who gives her character a purposeful edge of impatience and bitterness. ‰ÛÏTestament of Youth‰Ûù might be described as a feminist war film, because it is saturated with Vera‰Ûªs frustration at her parents‰Ûª limited ambitions for her and later with her contempt for war. It isn‰Ûªt until the end that she delivers a scathing antiwar diatribe.

In ‰ÛÏRoom 237,‰Ûù the director Rodney Ascher invited armchair experts to share their theories about secret meanings in Stanley Kubrick‰Ûªs movie version of ‰ÛÏThe Shining.‰Ûù Annotated clips allowed viewers to play along.

Yet as an analytical exercise, ‰ÛÏThe Nightmare‰Ûù pales in comparison to ‰ÛÏRoom 237.‰Ûù Examining art is different from exploring a scientific phenomenon, and here the absence of medical experts seems evasive. Pesky neuroscientific theories could only dampen the atmosphere of terror that Mr. Ascher works so hard to establish. While ‰ÛÏRoom 237‰Ûù sought evidence for its most outlandish conceits, ‰ÛÏThe Nightmare‰Ûù declines to delve. As the testimonies grow repetitive, the strategy suggests willful ignorance.

It would be difficult to find a subject that is as much of a potential rabbit hole, and ‰ÛÏThe Nightmare,‰Ûù Mr. Ascher‰Ûªs new essay documentary, is not nearly as engrossing or hands-on as its predecessor. This time, the topic is sleep paralysis. Eight people with that disorder share their stories, augmented with slick re-enactments and a rumbling soundtrack. The movie conveys the horror of the experience, which can involve waking up motionless and seeing a ‰ÛÏshadow man.‰Ûù

To cope, one interviewee says he filled his room with TV sets. Another says she became a Christian. By the time the first speaks of a shared hallucination with a woman in his bed (both saw figures with red eyes), you may begin to believe in these boogeymen yourself ‰ÛÓ perhaps influenced by such movies as ‰ÛÏA Nightmare on Elm Street‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏInsidious,‰Ûù which dramatize elements of sleep paralysis.

When Samantha interviews Scott and wonders out loud whether Jimmy might have been murdered, Scott throws her out of the house and enlists a sheriff‰Ûªs deputy to intimidate her with a gang of thugs. No sooner has this subplot been introduced than it is abruptly, inexplicably abandoned, in a screenplay written by Mr. Duvall.

Could Robert Duvall‰Ûªs incoherent melodrama ‰ÛÏWild Horses‰Ûù have been salvaged by a skillful editor? Probably not. Mr. Duvall‰Ûªs first directorial effort since ‰ÛÏAssassination Tango‰Ûù in 2003, this film is the story of Scott Briggs (Mr. Duvall, now 84), a hard-bitten Texan rancher deep into his twilight years. It has majestic man-on-horse-under-the-Southwestern-sky cinematography, and in its best scene, Scott‰Ûªs three grown sons get drunk in a roughneck bar and stumble into a brawl with some cowboys. But such moments are too scattered to make this jumble of a film come together.
‰ÛÏWild Horses‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Some violence and strong language.

Mr. Duvall‰Ûªs character is an imperious, gun-toting rancher who summons those sons ‰ÛÓ Johnny (Devon Abner), K C (Josh Hartnett) and Ben (James Franco) ‰ÛÓ to a meeting at which he announces his plans to dispose of his 40,000-acre estate. In an unwelcome surprise, the property is to be divided into fourths instead of thirds. It would be giving away too much to explain why.

Ben, the black sheep, has returned after a 15-year absence that began the night his father caught him having sex with another boy in a barn and went ballistic. Ben‰Ûªs boyfriend, Jimmy (Darien Willardson, barely glimpsed), has been missing ever since. Mr. Franco, who makes nothing of his role, reverts to his standard default pose of smirking hipster. Coincidentally, out of the blue, Jimmy‰Ûªs mother (Adriana Barraza) pressures a lean, severe Texas Ranger, Samantha Payne (Luciana Pedraza Duvall, Mr. Duvall‰Ûªs wife), to investigate Jimmy‰Ûªs disappearance.

The one solid element in ‰ÛÏWild Horses‰Ûù is Mr. Duvall‰Ûªs squinting, stone-faced portrayal of a gruff, crusty patriarch beginning to crumble. For decades, Scott has ruled his prairie fiefdom like a dictator. Racked with regrets, sensing the end is near, he belatedly feels compelled to atone for his mistakes before it‰Ûªs too late. The symbol of his fading power is his near inability to mount a horse.

It‰Ûªs cheering, though, to see that four of the six shorts represented here were written and directed by women, including the lone documentary, ‰ÛÏThe Face of Ukraine: Casting Oksana Baiul,‰Ûù by the Australian filmmaker Kitty Green. Capturing a handful of glowing, sequined young beauties as they audition for the role of the champion figure skater, Ms. Green, who has personal and artistic roots in Ukraine, gently reveals the emotional rubble of war and displacement.

These days, no mini-movie compilation feels complete without the animator Don Hertzfeldt, whose dreamy ‰ÛÏWorld of Tomorrow‰Ûù sends us into a future where deteriorating copies of humanity seek answers that only their original selves can provide. A trippy meditation on the significance of memory, the film turns a meeting between a toddler and her third-generation clone into a sad song of innocence and experience.

Anthologies offer short films an escape from the festival circuit and a chance to show regular moviegoers the rewards of discipline and constraint ‰ÛÓ even when their titles, like ‰ÛÏ2015 Sundance Film Festival Award-Winning Shorts,‰Ûù  reveal neither attribute.

Mental turmoil of a different sort drives the compendium‰Ûªs strongest narrative entries. In Frankie Shaw‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSMILF‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ currently being developed as a cable television comedy ‰ÛÓ a young single mother tries to use a booty call with an old flame (the charmingly gauche Thomas Middleditch of ‰ÛÏSilicon Valley‰Ûù) to reconnect with her former freedoms and self-esteem. And in the strangely moving ‰ÛÏOh Lucy!,‰Ûù a middle-aged office worker in Tokyo is startled when her English teacher‰Ûªs unconventional tutelage stirs up unfamiliar longings. Touching lightly on the dehumanizing drills of cubicle life, this endearing story (by the director Atsuko Hirayanagi) reminds us that the answer to ‰ÛÏWhat‰Ûªs in a name?‰Ûù can be ‰ÛÏAnything we want.‰Ûù

Ms. Berg connects that manager, Martin Weiss, who pleaded no contest to two counts of child molestation in 2012, to a string of other men in Hollywood who have also been accused or convicted of similar crimes. Except for a secretly taped conversation and some menacing music, she resists the urge to sensationalize. Such composure is admirable, but further aggressive reporting is needed. This topic deserves a tenacious call for answers.

You may miss a few moments of ‰ÛÏAn Open Secret,‰Ûù either while looking away during its unsettling stories or closing your eyes in frustration. This potent documentary elicits those kinds of reactions.

Still, ‰ÛÏAn Open Secret‰Ûù is affecting, particularly when the victims recount their experiences in voices that crack with emotion or pause with pain. Even if you do look away, hearing them speak is enough.

Directed by Amy Berg (‰ÛÏDeliver Us From Evil‰Ûù), the film centers on a handful of young men who say that as child actors they were sexually assaulted by older men in the entertainment industry. Manipulations, cover-ups and exploitations are recounted, and in several cases accountability was weak; some of the culprits, we‰Ûªre told, still work in Hollywood.

The victims and their parents defy the stereotype of hard-driving dream-seekers. They come across as merely trusting, which led them to rely on those who promised successful careers. Such faith was exploited by men who later turned out to be predators.
‰ÛÏAn Open Secret‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Explicit stories of sexual abuse.

‰ÛÏHe just told me it‰Ûªs normal, like, this goes on all the time, this is what you have to do,‰Ûù one young man says he was told after being molested by his manager. ‰ÛÏEverybody does this.‰Ûù Shame and fear of reprisals initially led him to stay silent, and may be keeping more victims from speaking out.

The notion of superpowered beings as bearers of disease has been explored in films like ‰ÛÏ28 Days Later‰Ûù; Mr. Roth himself demonstrated his penchant for illness as metaphor in ‰ÛÏCabin Fever.‰Ûù And the abundant violence in ‰ÛÏThe Stranger‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ beatings, shootings, immolations, the killing of small creatures ‰ÛÓ is certainly nothing new. But the movie benefits greatly from Mr. Amoedo‰Ûªs largely steady direction and the uniform acting skills of its Chilean cast (performing in English).

Everyone soon discovers that the dour Martin has an illness with an upside: His blood, applied to wounds, has healing powers. The downside: He must consume the blood of animals, including humans, to survive. Only fire or daylight, it seems, can kill him.

Though the full title of Guillermo Amoedo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Stranger‰Ûù bears the name of one of the film‰Ûªs producers, the horror specialist Eli Roth (‰ÛÏHostel‰Ûù), it has its own singular, and gruesome, distinctions.

The film begins with the arrival of Martin (CristÌ_bal Tapia Montt) in a small town (in Chile, standing in for Canada). He seeks his wife, Ana, who he learns has died, and instead meets a young graffiti artist, Peter (NicolÌÁs DurÌÁn), who had a connection to her and comes to Martin‰Ûªs aid. Martin also meets the town thug, Caleb (Ariel Levy), the son of a corrupt police officer (Luis Gnecco), in a brutal encounter that Caleb instigates.
Is there any philosophical takeaway to be found amid the carnage? Only the value of good deeds, perhaps, and the cost of being a bad parent. And those verities can never be overstated.

When the Suprematism pioneer Kazimir Malevich (Anatoly Beliy) arrives to teach at Chagall‰Ûªs school, Mr. Mitta even sends animated bars of color streaming through shots. But Malevich‰Ûªs dogmatism about abstract art also confirms that Mr. Mitta‰Ûªs actors will primarily function as didactic representatives of certain viewpoints.

That‰Ûªs a shame because Mr. Mitta stages some nifty fantasias, like a shadowy bathhouse brawl that amusingly doubles as a physical debate over Western portrayals of the human body. And Mr. Mitta‰Ûªs scenes of Chagall fancifully in flight (in imitation of the artist‰Ûªs paintings) above the earth make for a summer-appropriate portrayal: the artist as superhero.

Wartime upheaval leads Chagall (Leonid Bichevin) to return to his hometown, Vitebsk, with his sweetheart, Bella (Kristina Schneidermann). There he starts a government-sanctioned art school under the watch of a military commissar, Naum (Semyon Shkalikov), an old friend who pines for Bella.

Set primarily in revolutionary-era Russia, Alexander Mitta‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏChagall-Malevich‰Ûù centers on the painter Marc Chagall and fictionalizes his real-life efforts to establish an artistic bulwark amid war and ideological ferment. It‰Ûªs a literally colorful and playful attempt to portray battlefields of artistic ambition and political struggle. But its dialogue and characters are also written as subtly as a radical manifesto.

Instead of the international ambassador that Chagall would become in later years, Mr. Mitta gives us something like a Jewish folk hero who takes the risk of forging a distinct artistic and personal identity during the throes of the Bolshevik Revolution. Among the to-and-fro of school and town intrigue, the film‰Ûªs color filters and canted camera angles create shallow, crowded spaces that echo Chagall‰Ûªs roiling canvases.

Mr. Spielberg may not have directed ‰ÛÏJurassic World,‰Ûù but his fingerprints ‰ÛÓ and anxiety over his influence ‰ÛÓ are all over it. He‰Ûªs one of its executive producers and gave his blessing to the director Colin Trevorrow, who has just one other feature on his rÌ©sumÌ©, the indie ‰ÛÏSafety Not Guaranteed.‰Ûù As is the case with every filmmaker hired to lead an industrial brand to box-office domination, Mr. Trevorrow was principally tasked with delivering ‰ÛÏJurassic World‰Ûù in salable shape, which he has done. Actors repeat their bad lines without smirking, and digital dinosaurs stomp, scatter and gulp amid product placements for Triumph motorcycles and Jimmy Buffett‰Ûªs Margaritaville chain. There are so many plugs for Mercedes that you may wonder if the targeted viewers are studio executives.

That would be par for the course in an entertainment that‰Ûªs as relentlessly reflexive as this one. Cinema is an insistently self-referential art (movies about movies being just one example), and filmmakers have long enjoyed drawing attention to the fact that, hey, you‰Ûªre watching the big screen. Given Mr. Spielberg‰Ûªs heavy shadow, it‰Ûªs no surprise that ‰ÛÏJurassic World‰Ûù almost immediately if obliquely nods at antecedents, including the first two he directed, with a character in the new one stating that ‰ÛÏevery time we‰Ûªve unveiled a new attraction attendance has spiked.‰Ûù She‰Ûªs talking about the movie‰Ûªs dinosaur theme park, but she might as well be referring to all the special effects and other blockbuster add-ons that moviemakers use to try to blow the audience‰Ûªs collective mind.

Blowing minds rather than, you know, telling a good story is the driving imperative in ‰ÛÏJurassic World,‰Ûù which takes place on an island turned luxury resort where thousands enjoy a very special kind of eco-tourism. There, the usual suspects convene, including a pair of bland young brothers (Nick Robinson, Ty Simpkins), avatars for the sought-after demographic; the usual odd-couple cuties (Bryce Dallas Howard and Chris Pratt); and some standard-issue villainy that exists to feed the dinosaurs and our bloodlust. It‰Ûªs a measure of how dumbed-down this movie is that while the three heroes in ‰ÛÏJurassic Park‰Ûù were scientists, Mr. Pratt plays Owen, an indeterminate animal expert, and Ms. Howard plays Claire, a corporate stooge whose idiocy is partly telegraphed by her towering heels.
‰ÛÏJurassic World‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Product placements and other violence.

Clomp, clomp, clomp ‰ÛÓ here it comes, another new blockbuster ready for its shock-and-awe ch-ching close-up. With its global brand recognition, ‰ÛÏJurassic World‰Ûù comes with more muscle than the average big-ticket behemoth, one that‰Ûªs been built on best-selling novels, three earlier flicks, theme-park attractions and the usual marketing tie-ins. Once again, dinosaurs are on the roam, an unpeaceable kingdom that is an index of the folly of man trying to play God. In reality, there‰Ûªs more flab than muscle packed on this galumphing franchise reboot, which, as it lumbers from scene to scene, reminds you of what a great action god Steven Spielberg is. Too bad he didn‰Ûªt take the reins on this.

Dolling Claire up so preposterously is a glib tactic, although it‰Ûªs unclear if the filmmakers were trying to tweak politically correct sensibilities or thought they were being clever, or maybe both. Whatever the case, the heels are just silly and a distraction given that they‰Ûªre nowhere near as insulting as the rest of her. Owen may be a parody of a hunk, what with his greasy workingman hands, shirt-busting arm muscles and nicely coiffed chin hair, but at least he does cool stuff like wrangle raptors and, spoiler alert, Claire. She mostly just schemes and screams, before Owen melts her like an ice cube on a hot griddle, proving that, yes, she‰Ûªs every bit as bad as Joss Whedon thought when on Twitter he called out ‰ÛÏJurassic World‰Ûù as sexist: ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs a stiff, he‰Ûªs a life-force ‰ÛÓ really? Still?‰Ûù Yes, still.

Winking self-consciousness and movie love are Spielberg signatures and they suffuse ‰ÛÏJurassic Park,‰Ûù which pivots on an entrepreneur cum carny, Hammond (Richard Attenborough, who directed ‰ÛÏGandhi‰Ûù), who could be a stand-in for any Big Man of cinema. It‰Ûªs Hammond who‰Ûªs brought dinosaurs back to dangerous life, and while he has the vision thing down, he also likes to mention the money he‰Ûªs spent on his spectacle, cementing the Hollywood analogy. By the end, his hubris nearly does him in and his plans flop, a cautionary fictional failure that spawned a real-life smash. Oh, the irony or, as one of the writers, David Koepp, said, ‰ÛÏI was really chasing my tail there for a while trying to find out what was virtuous in this whole scenario ‰ÛÓ and eventually gave up.‰Ûù

Part of the pleasure of ‰ÛÏJurassic Park‰Ûù is how seamlessly Mr. Spielberg‰Ûªs deep love of movies worked with what was, back in 1993, bleeding-edge computer-generated imagery: the dinosaurs were cool, and the filmmaking fluid and vigorous. It‰Ûªs a resolutely old-fashioned Hollywood adventure movie in many ways, but one that felt (feels) paradoxically alive because of Mr. Spielberg‰Ûªs filmmaking talents and his absolute faith in movies. ‰ÛÏJurassic World,‰Ûù by contrast, isn‰Ûªt in dialogue with its cinematic reference points; it‰Ûªs fossilized by them. From the first shot of a dinosaur hatching (signaling new beginnings, etc.) to one of a massive aquatic creature chowing down on a great white shark (get it?), it is clear that the only colossus that‰Ûªs making the ground shake here is Steven Spielberg.

The heels come across as a joke, or at least that‰Ûªs how the filmmakers attempt to skew them, with Owen telling Claire that they‰Ûªre ‰ÛÏridiculous.‰Ûù That Claire can actually run from dinosaurs, over cement and through mud, without breaking a heel off or twisting her ankle like a film-noir dame, is played as a kind of triumph. Of course it‰Ûªs a hollow one and it‰Ûªs representative of how the filmmakers like to point out the very clichÌ©s (genre, gender, whatever) they embrace, as if merely acknowledging them were a critical move. By the time Claire is shooting a gun, still in heels, you may find yourself humming that old fake-feminist jingle: ‰ÛÏI can bring home the bacon/ Fry it up in a pan/ And never let you forget you‰Ûªre a man.‰Ûù That Owen is the hero ensures that you‰Ûªll never forget, either.

Rachel is not a close friend of Earl‰Ûªs or Greg‰Ûªs ‰ÛÓ just a classmate with cancer ‰ÛÓ until Greg‰Ûªs mother (Connie Britton) insists that he start spending time with her. That awkward parental intrusion and the even more awkward greeting Greg receives from Rachel‰Ûªs mother (Molly Shannon) are handled with humor and graceful realism. Other adults in the film ‰ÛÓ notably Greg‰Ûªs dad (Nick Offerman) and Earl and Greg‰Ûªs favorite teacher (Jon Bernthal) ‰ÛÓ are recognizable types from the world of teenage literature. And so, for that matter, are the young people, Rachel in particular. Her kinship with the heroines played by Shailene Woodley and ChloÌÇ-Grace Moretz in last summer‰Ûªs dying-girl dramas ‰ÛÏThe Fault in Our Stars‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIf I Stay‰Ûù is obvious. A similar morbid romanticism floats around her, an aura of tragic mystery deepened by her wry, impatient resistance to sentimentality.

Their do-it-yourself hobby is a technologically updated, highbrow variation on the ‰ÛÏSweding‰Ûù practiced by Jack Black and Yasiin Bey (then known as Mos Def) in Michel Gondry‰Ûªs 2008 film ‰ÛÏBe Kind Rewind.‰Ûù But ‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl,‰Ûù directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon and adapted by Jesse Andrews from his own young-adult novel, doesn‰Ûªt dabble in trippy Gondryesque surrealism. It has its quirks and improbabilities, but its sensibility is earnest and earthbound. Nor does it have much in common with the Criterion Collection canon that inspires Earl and Greg‰Ûªs acts of homage. The kind of movie they inhabit ‰ÛÓ a terminal teen melodrama, a bittersweet coming-of-age story, a wishful tale of interracial friendship ‰ÛÓ is not the kind of movie they‰Ûªd be likely to imitate.

While the filmmakers are not above trying to wring a few tears, they don‰Ûªt wage an all-out assault on your feelings. There is a notable absence of aggression and of the kind of manipulation that yanks adjectives like ‰ÛÏdevastating‰Ûù from the laptops of unwitting reviewers. The film is touching and small, but also thoughtful and assured in a way that lingers after the inevitable tears have been shed and the obvious lessons learned.

As I said, potentially awful stuff. But Mr. Gomez-Rejon turns down the melodramatic volume and slows the plot almost to the point of stasis. (The music, by Brian Eno with contributions from Nico Muhly, is also wielded gently and judiciously). ‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl‰Ûù is about growing up, facing death, making and losing friends and other rites of passage, but it‰Ûªs also, and more immediately, about drifting, hanging out, wasting time and succumbing to confusion. And it provides three young people in whose company it is a pleasure to drift and wonder and loaf.

Speaking as one such cinephile, I will confess to experiencing some irritation at the start. But I found that my resistance slowly but decisively crumbled, thanks to Mr. Gomez-Rejon‰Ûªs warm, low-key direction and the perceptive, lived-in performances of Mr. Mann, Mr. Cyler and Olivia Cooke as Rachel, the film‰Ûªs third title character and its riskiest proposition.

On paper, ‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl‰Ûù should be dreadful. That‰Ûªs not quite fair. On paper, Mr. Andrews‰Ûªs book is lovely: sensitive and rueful and attuned to both the solipsism and the ethical seriousness of adolescence. But it‰Ûªs also full of the sort of themes, emotions and situations that can turn maudlin and embarrassing on the way from page to screen. The self-conscious narrator, the kooky parents and above all the dying girl ‰ÛÓ these elements are likely to raise alarms among grown-up admirers of the auteurs whom Earl and Greg mock and revere.
‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Tactful but truthful teenage language and behavior.

The ‰ÛÏme‰Ûù in ‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl‰Ûù is a Pittsburgh teenager named Greg, a gangly, sarcastic young man ‰ÛÓ not quite a misfit, but also not a member of any recognizable high school social grouping ‰ÛÓ with a special fondness for movies. Greg (Thomas Mann) and Earl (RJ Cyler), his best friend since childhood, spend their spare time remaking classic films on video, using stop-motion animation and silly costumes and giving the results groan-inducing punny titles. (Samples from their extensive catalog include ‰ÛÏThe 400 Bros,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏMonorash‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏEyes Wide Butt.‰Ûù)
An unborn baby and a ticking biological clock make the scariest sounds in ‰ÛÏThe 11th Hour,‰Ûù a troubling example of what can only be called a fertility thriller.

Cleanly photographed and infused with strong religious undertones, ‰ÛÏThe 11th Hour‰Ûù (not to be confused with the 2007 documentary of the same name) is, like its heroine, more than a little barmy. Then again, if you awoke to a ghost baby praying on your quilt, you might be too.

‰ÛÏI am still here,‰Ûù the baby insists in whispery voice-over. ‰ÛÏCome find me, Mommy!‰Ûù The maternal stars align when Maria learns of Eastern European prostitutes who sell their offspring to human traffickers. Assisted by a hitchhiking, heroin-addicted dwarf named Christian (an admirable Jordan Prentice), she embarks on a delusional rescue mission marked by escalating violence and twisted morality.

Icily chic and scarily composed, Ms. Basinger commits to her disturbed character. But the script (by the director, Anders Morgenthaler) makes Maria‰Ûªs behavior so reckless ‰ÛÓ at times, she‰Ûªs practically begging to be mugged or worse ‰ÛÓ that we have no chance of sympathizing with her. The character‰Ûªs debasement adds a concerning pulse of masochism that harks back to the punishment of those prior miscarriages.

Maria (Kim Basinger) is a high-powered shipping executive in Denmark with a yearning womb. After a decade of marriage and eight miscarriages, Maria refuses to accept a childless future, ignoring her doctors and her exhausted husband (Sebastian Schipper) in favor of the urgings of what she believes is her future child.

The action that causes them the most trouble in the new film is a 2009 prank designed to make fools of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the vast lobbying agency that the Yes Men contend is overwhelmingly controlled by the oil industry. The Yes Men rent a space in the National Press Club in Washington and hold a briefing at which Mr. Bichlbaum impersonates the communications director for the Chamber of Commerce and reverses its position, voicing support for climate change legislation pending in Congress. So irate were the chamber‰Ûªs leaders that the group sued the Yes Men for ‰ÛÏcommercial identity theft masquerading as social activism.‰Ûù Four years later, the lawsuit was dropped.
‰ÛÏThe Yes Men Are Revolting‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language.

‰ÛÏThe Yes Men Are Revolting,‰Ûù their third film, has a personal poignancy that is missing in the forerunners, ‰ÛÏThe Yes Men‰Ûù (2003) and ‰ÛÏThe Yes Men Fix the World‰Ûù (2009). It‰Ûªs easier to thumb your nose at authority when you are young and carefree than when you‰Ûªre middle-aged and trying to settle down.

At an international climate-change conference in 2009 in Copenhagen, they collaborate with Benadette Chandia Kodili, a Ugandan activist, in announcing that Canada has agreed to pay off billions of dollars in ‰ÛÏclimate debts‰Ûù to third world countries that contribute less to carbon dioxide emissions than industrialized ones. Canada is cornered into denying that any such plans exist.

A favorite prank is to call a news conference at which they impersonate corporate and government officials and announce a radical shift of agenda, then watch the fallout when their hoaxes are accepted as genuine and their opponents scramble to set the record straight.

During the making of the new movie, Mr. Bonanno‰Ûªs wife gives birth to the couple‰Ûªs third child and they move to Scotland. Mr. Bichlbaum, who is gay, meets a boyfriend with whom he wants to spend the rest of his life. But that relationship breaks up when the Yes Men‰Ûªs partnership interferes. The Yes Men describe themselves as each other‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏperfect enablers.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs one thing for political pranksters to play dirty tricks on corporations whose agendas they oppose, but it‰Ûªs quite another for their shenanigans to be carried out with the ingenuity and humor of comic performance art. Take the Yes Men, Mike Bonanno and Andy Bichlbaum (not their real names), subversive political satirists who dream up elaborate stunts to embarrass climate-change deniers.

In the silliest prank, they pose as officials with the Energy Department the Bureau of Indian Affairs at a Homeland Security conference and declare their intention to have the United States rely on renewable energy sources for 100 percent of its needs by 2030. Power plants would be turned over to Native Americans as partial reparation for ‰ÛÏgenocide.‰Ûù Then the attendees, who include defense contractors, are asked to form a circle and do an Indian dance. The compliant guests obey instructions, and the ritual that follows is a delectable moment of pure farce.
‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù deserves much better than the documentary equivalent of what a book editor would surely dismiss as a rushed, careless clip job.

This 82-minute film goes out of its way to address ticklish issues like the cast‰Ûªs relative lack of racial diversity and its boys‰Ûª-club sexism. At one point, it suggests that ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù unintentionally influenced the outcome of the 2000 presidential election because Mr. Ferrell‰Ûªs impersonation of George W. Bush was more likable than Darrell Hammond‰Ûªs Al Gore.

Controversies mentioned but not dissected include Andrew Dice Clay as a host, Sinead O‰ÛªConnor‰Ûªs ripping up a picture of the pope, and the sexually provocative 2006 skit with Andy Samberg and Justin Timberlake that became an instant YouTube sensation. We see political candidates confront their ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù doppelgÌ_ngers (Tina Fey as Sarah Palin and Amy Poehler as Hillary Rodham Clinton). In the most squirm-inducing moment, the movie awkwardly approaches 9/11 in a sequence with Rudolph W. Giuliani that is made all the more creepy by the conspicuous presence of his disgraced right-hand man, Bernard B. Kerik.

Hyperbole abounds. Will Ferrell calls ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù ‰ÛÏa living, breathing time capsule.‰Ûù Others describe it as tracing ‰ÛÏthe arc of America‰Ûù and of being a cross between ‰ÛÏ60 Minutes‰Ûù and Monty Python. All true, I suppose. But why is any time given to tangential commentators like Bill O‰ÛªReilly, Fran Lebowitz and others who have nothing useful or amusing to say, while the show‰Ûªs inner workings are left unexplored? As you watch its parade of stars spoof current events, you still wonder what direction American comedy might have taken had ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù not been created. The documentary stresses the importance of the show‰Ûªs nature as a live broadcast, which lent it a special immediacy. Bizarrely, no mention is made of the Hollywood franchises the show has spawned, and many famous ‰ÛÏS.N.L.‰Ûù alumni, like Eddie Murphy and Adam Sandler, are missing or barely seen.

There are scattered moments of interest, such as an opening sequence of what are apparently excerpts from original cast members‰Ûª auditions. In its scruffy early years, the show was an impudent, mildly subversive reflection of post-countercultural euphoria. Then, a fallow half-decade followed the 1980 departure of that cast along with the show‰Ûªs creator and producer, Lorne Michaels. In 1985, Mr. Michaels returned to rebuild ‰ÛÏS.N.L.‰Ûù into a mainstream show-business institution.

‰ÛÏLive From New York!,‰Ûù Bao Nguyen‰Ûªs unfocused, skimpy history of ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live,‰Ûù resembles a smiley-faced Sunday morning infomercial for a vintage pop music collection. Stumbling upon such an ad, chances are you might linger long enough to feel a nostalgic tug upon hearing a fragment of a favorite oldie but goodie before changing channels. You are also reminded of how much time has passed and how quickly the years have flown. The show‰Ûªs 40-year existence, after all, is roughly half a lifetime.

The movie goes through the motions, tracking Emma‰Ûªs growing boredom, her reckless flights of passion and her eventual undoing. It might be spoiling Flaubert‰Ûªs novel to note she dies at the end, but Ms. Barthes uses the familiar movie device of signaling the end in the very first scene and rendering nearly everything else that happens as a flashback. This is a shortcut to emotions that the film does little to earn, and it also warps the implacable, deliberate linearity of Flaubert‰Ûªs narrative.

‰ÛÏMadame Bovary, c‰Ûªest moi,‰Ûù Gustave Flaubert said of his most famous fictional creation. Impulsive, vain and sometimes cruel, she is hardly the most sympathetic character in 19th-century literature, but she is among the most vivid and complicated. Flaubert illuminated her inner life and outward circumstances with a clarity that set a new standard for the novel, one that continues to beguile, and often to frustrate, his followers.
‰ÛÏMadame Bovary‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Amorous doings.

The film is nothing great: It‰Ûªs a B+ term paper that dutifully checks off the costume-drama boxes of the post-Merchant Ivory era. The men in Emma Bovary‰Ûªs life are reduced to their caricatural essences, and played with respectable craft by actors whose participation has a way of making any movie look a little better than it is. Henry Lloyd-Hughes is Charles Bovary, the dull, decent country physician who marries Emma Rouault not long after she leaves a convent school. Paul Giamatti is Monsieur Homais, the arrogant pharmacist whose grandiose ideas about progress cause all kinds of trouble. Rhys Ifans is Monsieur Lheureux, the merchant whose flattery of Emma‰Ûªs tastes and social ambitions leads her and Charles into ruinous debt. Ezra Miller and Logan Marshall-Green represent her extramarital interests, one a romantic quasi-intellectual, the other a moody, hunky aristocrat.

And also filmmakers. ‰ÛÏMadame Bovary‰Ûù can be cited as evidence of the fundamental mismatch between movies and books. The novel‰Ûªs style and structure elude cinematic capture. Not that ambitious directors and actresses have been scared away. There have been at least a half-dozen renditions in various languages and formats since the beginning of the sound era. Jennifer Jones and Vincente Minnelli took a turn during the golden age of Hollywood prestige mongering. Isabelle Huppert and Claude Chabrol tried in the early ‰Ûª90s. Now the French director Sophie Barthes has made a relatively compact, lavishly decorated English-language version, with Mia Wasikowska as the most notorious adulteress in Normandy.

Otherwise, the film is doggedly, dutifully faithful to its source, which is a little odd given the importance of infidelity in the story. What wildness there is in this ‰ÛÏMadame Bovary‰Ûù belongs to Ms. Wasikowska, an actress who is frequently more interesting than her material. She was terrific as Jane Eyre in 2011, and among young actresses with a habit of playing 19th-century literary heroines ‰ÛÓ Keira Knightley and Carey Mulligan, for example ‰ÛÓ she has a special gift for making her characters feel at once bracingly modern and entirely of their own time, determined to act freely in circumstances that constrain them.

Ms. Barthes‰Ûªs film, unfortunately, is to its star what Charles‰Ûªs household is to Emma: a stifling closet of propriety and good intentions. It is not hard to believe that Ms. Wasikowska is Madame Bovary ‰ÛÓ she is at once serious and shallow, willful and indecisive, powerful and helpless ‰ÛÓ but this ‰ÛÏMadame Bovary‰Ûù is unfortunately not quite itself.

While riding in a rowboat, Thomas and Brinnin are spotted from the shore by an academic couple, Stanley (Kevin Eldon) and Shirley (Shirley Henderson), whom Thomas invites to a dinner party without first asking Brinnin‰Ûªs permission. At this bacchanal, ghost stories are exchanged, wine appears, and Stanley overindulges and passes out.

What suspense there is concerns an overseas letter to Thomas from his wife, Caitlin, that Thomas is terrified to open. As his dissipation intensifies, Brinnin has to drag Thomas out of bed and into a car. Near the end, the movie becomes a surreal depiction of his precarious mental state. Coerced by Brinnin, Thomas eventually reads the letter and hallucinates the presence of the beautiful, fiery Caitlin.
‰ÛÏLittle man, half man, crumbled boy,‰Ûù she sneers, as he cowers like a beaten dog.

‰ÛÏSet Fire to the Stars‰Ûù barely skims the surface of characters you wish had been given more dimension, but as a snapshot of postwar academia and its pretensions, it exerts a creepy fascination. If the movie were a comedy, it might be called ‰ÛÏFrodo and Caliban Go to College.‰Ûù

As played by Mr. Wood, Brinnin is a nervous worrywart and dandified academic, impeccably attired in suspenders and bow tie, who seems always to be on the brink of tears. Thomas is finally delivered to Yale, where he empties a faculty dinner party by reciting dirty limericks. The screenplay captures the stuffiness of the era, but contains anachronistic slips like the terms ‰ÛÏin the loop‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏwhatever.‰Ûù

Celyn Jones, the Welsh actor who plays Thomas in ‰ÛÏSet Fire to the Stars,‰Ûù is scruffier and more rotund than the cherubic writer as seen in vintage photographs. Although a physical wreck at the end of his life, Thomas still had a baby face and wavy hair that conveyed a raffish glamour. In the film, only fragments of his most famous poetry are heard, delivered by Mr. Jones in a voice that is far less musical than Thomas‰Ûªs seductive caroling.

The movie gets the period details right: the tiny television sets, the bizarre pop music (‰ÛÏMule Train‰Ûù) and the attitude of grave propriety that pervaded academia. After Thomas tears up a New York hotel room while on a drunken rampage, Brinnin spirits him to a woodland house in Connecticut, where he is out of reach of booze and besotted young women.

Time was when the lilting incantations of the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas were viewed as visionary outpourings of a holy bohemian by audiences entranced by his mellifluous voice. Thomas was one of the first modern poets who understood that poetry readings were as much show business as they were art. Those were the days ‰ÛÓ the late 1940s and early 1950s ‰ÛÓ when the romantic notion that drunkenness was a shortcut to enlightenment held sway, and a buttoned-up society allowed bad boys like Thomas, who died in 1953 at 39, relatively free rein to misbehave.

In this handsomely photographed black-and-white film, directed by Andy Goddard, Thomas comes across as a pitiful, bullying lout who makes life miserable for John Malcolm Brinnin (Elijah Wood), the prim teacher and poet who arranges a multicity American tour for Thomas in 1950.

A gifted editor helps, and ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù has one in Enat Sidi, a veteran who aided Ms. Moselle in shaping years of material into a streamlined 84-minute chronicle of love and resilience. The family‰Ûªs story emerges elliptically as the boys grow up on screen, largely in intimate moments in which one or another ‰ÛÓ the four eldest boys do much of the talking ‰ÛÓ open up about their lives with indoor voices colored with hints of Steve Buscemi (of ‰ÛÏReservoir Dogs,‰Ûù another favorite). Their mother, Susanne Angulo (she now uses her maiden name, Reisenbichler, as do two of her sons), met their father, Oscar Angulo, on the trail to Machu Picchu. She was from the Midwest, he was from Peru, and together they traveled the United States and had seven children (including Visnu, a disabled daughter) to whom they gave Sanskrit names

‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù has the virtue of an unfamiliar tale, one that‰Ûªs further distinguished by the persuasive intimacy that comes from the Angulo brothers‰Ûª sincerity and openness, and their obvious love for their family. Ms. Moselle‰Ûªs affable informality adds to the intimacy ‰ÛÓ the brothers tend to come across more like friends than subjects ‰ÛÓ as does the claustrophobia of their apartment, a warren of rooms with a long hall that seems to grow shorter as the movie unfolds. In one arresting video snippet, a few brothers zip down that hall on scooters, followed by another wearing in-line skates. For years, this narrow corridor, you realize, was their playground, their skate park, too. And their great outdoors? That was the world that they watched from their windows as it indifferently passed them by.
‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Quentin Tarantino is one of their favorite directors.

That makes this warm, disarmingly optimistic documentary sound desperately sad when it‰Ûªs anything but. Much of the back story for ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù could have gone full-bore Dickensian, as suggested by the family‰Ûªs unusual history and rundown apartment, with its sad, shabby carpeting and cracked windows. It‰Ûªs easy to imagine what an exploitative director, using artful editing and a sinister score, could have done to darken this material. At the same time, it‰Ûªs hard to imagine a more sensitive director for this story than Crystal Moselle, a 34-year-old who five years ago discovered the brothers soon after they began making unaccompanied excursions outside. Sometimes, all you need is a great subject to make a great documentary ‰ÛÓ or a willingness to chase after total strangers.

Given how much the brothers share, candidly and obliquely, and given their ages, it never feels as if Ms. Moselle is exploiting them; she never prods them, at least on camera, to reveal more than they seem to want to. Documentary has a tradition of trafficking in the misery of other people‰Ûªs lives, so it‰Ûªs a relief that ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt drag you down or offer packaged uplift, but instead tells a strange tale with heart and generosity. You‰Ûªre left with the sense that something went wrong for this family, but that whatever did (no laws seem to have been broken) is none of our business. ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù is a reminder that documentary cinema isn‰Ûªt a license to snoop into other lives (sometimes, all you need is a cordial visit) and that while movies can save lives, that works only if there is also as much love as there is here.

The Angulo brothers ‰ÛÓ originally named Bhagavan, Govinda, Narayana, Mukunda, Krsna and Jagadisa, now ages 23 to 16 ‰ÛÓ made their escapes the way many people do, by watching movies at home on VHS and DVD. But they also recreated, on camera and off, favorites like ‰ÛÏThe Dark Knight‰Ûù using handmade costumes, face paint and scripts they transcribed line by line without a computer. To replicate Batman‰Ûªs signature Gotham-gone-Goth look, Mukunda explains, they repurposed yoga mats and cereal-box cardboard, displaying the kind of tape-and-spit creativity that‰Ûªs a hallmark of movie-crazed youngsters and real independent filmmakers everywhere. The home-schooled Angulos weren‰Ûªt goofing around in between play dates and Little League practices, neither of which they apparently experienced: For them, movies were a form of self-expression as well as a kind of survival.

In its intense personal quality and complex family dynamics as well as in Ms. Moselle‰Ûªs disregard for (or lack of interest in) the questions that some of her methods raise, ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù can bring to mind Albert and David Maysles‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGrey Gardens.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs important to underscore that there‰Ûªs never any question as to the mental health of the Angulo brothers, unlike with the mother-daughter duo in ‰ÛÏGrey Gardens,‰Ûù another documentary that benefits from closing the traditional divide between filmmaker and subject. The Angulo brothers come off as smart, well-adjusted and charmingly eccentric; in other words, they‰Ûªre New Yorkers. And while they‰Ûªre movie mad, they belong to the same great tribe that many of us do, a tribe that finds joy and sustenance being transported into other worlds.

Ms. Moselle tends to omit the kind of information that might have made it into another documentary, including outside testimonials, supporting evidence and even establishing identifiers. There is no introductory text to set the scene and no voice-over to fill in the gaps; the movie just opens on a bleak New York cityscape, the camera skittishly poking around outside a brick high rise. The only people who speak in the movie are the Angulos and, presumably, Ms. Moselle, so you have to take it on faith that everything in it is true. (Ms. Moselle doesn‰Ûªt identify herself, but I assume that‰Ûªs her tossing out periodic off-camera remarks.) Yet what might elsewhere register as problematic, including a restricted focus and borderline naÌøve approach, actually strengthens the movie.

Movies can change your life, but can they save it? For most people that probably sounds foolish, but the six brothers featured in the astonishing documentary ‰ÛÏThe Wolfpack‰Ûù aren‰Ûªt most people. For much of their lives, these six ingenious young men used the movies to imaginatively if not physically break out of their Lower Manhattan apartment in a building run by the New York City Housing Authority. Even as their father all but imprisoned them (one year they never left the apartment), they made great metaphoric escapes by immersing themselves in the fictional realms created by directors like Francis Ford Coppola and Quentin Tarantino.

Her husband, who has been mysteriously absent for five years and is the father of her son, returns, brooding and violently livid at Vasudha‰Ûªs romance. We discover that Vasudha‰Ûªs father compelled her to marry Hari, who later forced her to have his name tattooed on her arm. (Mr. Rao‰Ûªs disturbing portrait of Hari is the most resonant in the movie.) Hari appears to have been brainwashed by an unidentifiedåÊterrorist group in a land-mine-laden jungle and is arrested by the police. Events then grow muddled: Aarav has divorce papers drawn up for Vasudha; Vasudha waffles, flip-flopping between sympathy and revulsion toward Hari; to please Vasudha, Aarav heads to the perilous jungle to find evidence to clear Hari‰Ûªs name. Vasudha and Aarav reunite, but not as you might expect.

Hari (Rajkumar Rao) is undergoing psychiatric treatment because of his addled state and persistent obsession with his wife, who left him over 20 years ago. From the present day, the film then flashes back to the story of his wife, Vasudha (Vidya Balan), and her one true love (it‰Ûªs not Hari). Vasudha, who is raising a son by herself, works as a hotel florist. When she sets out to rescue a dashing hotel magnate, Aarav (Emraan Hashmi), from what appears to be a fire, the two enter into a passionate flirtation that takes them to the glittering high-rise landscape of Dubai; a luxurious resort in Abu Dhabi; and an opulent residence in Shimla, India.

‰ÛÏA true love story has no end,‰Ûù Aarav says to his assistant. This one does, but by that point ‰ÛÓ despite its laudable warnings about brutally controlling husbands ‰ÛÓ it has shed much credibility.

For a romance, marriage ‰ÛÓ especially arranged marriage ‰ÛÓ does not get a good name in Mohit Suri‰Ûªs florid melodrama ‰ÛÏHamari Adhuri Kahani‰Ûù (‰ÛÏOur Incomplete Story‰Ûù). The movie may suffer from a surfeit of excesses, but it does have arresting, if overwrought, things to say about domestic abuse in India.

If the details of the plot are sometimes unclear, the action is always vivid and engaging. Mr. Slaboshpytskiy alternates between long, fixed takes and jostling hand-held following shots. He pays close attention to body language ‰ÛÓ reflexive gestures as well as formal signs ‰ÛÓ creating an atmosphere of tension and dread. There are moments of physical comedy and quiet feeling, but mostly there is raw, brutal exuberance.

What Mr. Slaboshpytskiy finds behind the walls of his drab and dreary school is greed, deceit and brutality. There is no idealism in his depiction of youth, but rather, endless cynicism. After a few opening scenes showing the pomp of an assembly and the tedium of a classroom, adult supervision all but vanishes. The only teacher regularly present is a wood shop instructor who also serves as a driver, co-conspirator and consigliere for the organized crime syndicate run by some of the older students.

Younger children are sent onto trains to sell toys and rifle through unattended bags. Packs of boys steal liquor and groceries from citizens walking home at night. Two girls work as prostitutes, riding out each night in the wood shop teacher‰Ûªs van to visit truck drivers parked on the edge of town, with male classmates as their pimps.

Our guide to this underworld is a new student, Sergey (Grigoriy Fesenko, who resembles a more filled-out Michael Cera). After suffering through a few hazing rituals, he is inducted into the upper level of the gang. His rise is disrupted when his lust for one of the girls, Anya (Yana Novikova), turns into something else ‰ÛÓ if not love, at least jealousy and protectiveness. Anya and her friend are planning to go to Italy, possibly as part of a sex-trafficking scheme enabled by the shop teacher and a cooperative bureaucrat.

Things turn very nasty at the end, as petty criminality gives way to rape and murder and the camera starts to feel like an instrument of exploitation. Having provoked the audience‰Ûªs curiosity, the film punishes us, using the bodies of its young performers, the women in particular, as tokens in a prurient, punitive spectacle. ‰ÛÏThe Tribe‰Ûù deploys an elaborate, rigorously executed conceit in support of a weary, dreary hypothesis: People are awful. That might well be true, but there‰Ûªs no need to shout.

‰ÛÏThe Tribe,‰Ûù set at a Ukrainian boarding school for the deaf, unfolds without spoken dialogue or subtitles. The members of the nonprofessional, mostly deaf cast communicate in sign language, and while much of the audience will remain ignorant of the nuances, and even the basic sense, of their interactions ‰ÛÓ we learn the characters‰Ûª names only in the final credits ‰ÛÓ the film isn‰Ûªt obscure or especially confusing. Written and directed by Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, it‰Ûªs something of a formal tour de force, a triumphant overcoming of self-imposed cinematic challenges.

Whether ‰ÛÏThe Tribe‰Ûù is more than that is another question. There is a long tradition, most recently upheld in the ‰ÛÏHarry Potter‰Ûù movies, of treating boarding schools as backdrops for coming-of-age adventures. But such institutions, with their volatile mix of regimentation and youthful energy, have also provided fertile ground for allegorical, sometimes fantastical investigations of power, rebellion and human depravity. The great movies in this line include Jean Vigo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏZero de Conduite‰Ûù (1933) and Lindsay Anderson‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏIf ... ‰Ûù (1968), both of which find a political dimension in schoolboy rebellion.

‰ÛÏTentacle 8‰Ûù proves to be a convoluted shell game, packed with high-tech espionage jargon about servers, data breaches and black sites, but hobbled by a muddy plot. But Mr. Chi, who wrote the screenplay, is generous with the many supporting characters (almost uniformly well played): a detention center guard (Courtney DeCosky), a high-level executive (Bruce Gray), a master of disguise (John Henry Whitaker), a microchip designer (Matthew Borlenghi) ‰ÛÓ each receiving an extended moment. As for Mr. Rickaby, he may not be glamorous, but he is a compelling performer.

Mr. Chi, making his feature debut with ‰ÛÏTentacle 8,‰Ûù lavishes attention on his characters at the expense of the through line binding them. Fortunately his cinematographer, Danny Grunes, lends a cool veneer to the proceedings. But next time, the promising Mr. Chi might bring a similar polish to his narrative.

Sprawling and intricate, John Chi‰Ûªs labyrinthine conspiracy thriller ‰ÛÏTentacle 8‰Ûù is nothing if not ambitious (and in the wake of the Edward J. Snowden affair, somewhat timely). When Ray (Brett Rickaby), a National Security Agency analyst, is suspected of having a hand in a huge loss of data at the organization, he is thrown into a secret detention center and viciously beaten. A Pentagon consultant (Joshua Morrow) is determined to interrogate him, but before he can, Ray has escaped, aided by a nameless man in a town car. Ray learns of a covert group known as Tentacle 8, and soon he is on the run, determined to unearth information about it. His girlfriend, Tabitha (Amy Motta), a C.I.A. employee, may or may not be on his side.

Malcolm, who lives with his mother (Kimberly Elise), a bus driver, is bullied in school and harassed on the street by the drug dealers who control the local corners. He, Jib and Diggy respond in the usual way, with cunning, sarcasm and, when those tactics fail, desperate flight. But they are caught up in a caper when Malcolm does a favor for a midlevel gangster named Dom (ASAP Rocky) and accepts an invitation to his birthday party. After an eventful evening, Malcolm ends up with a backpack full of drugs, a handgun and a lot of confusing instructions from various dangerous characters.
‰ÛÏDope‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). N.W.A. 2 Live Crew.

Propelled by an expertly selected soundtrack reflective of Malcolm‰Ûªs interests, ‰ÛÏDope‰Ûù zigs and zags and occasionally spins its wheels. Malcolm is smitten with Nakia (ZoÌÇ Kravitz), which makes him Dom‰Ûªs rival. She is charmed by Malcolm‰Ûªs virginal, brainy charisma ‰ÛÓ Mr. Moore, a master of sly deadpan, is almost too good-looking for the role ‰ÛÓ and so is Lily (Chanel Iman), the wayward daughter of a drug kingpin. The movie isn‰Ûªt heavily invested in its female characters, sticking to a basic template: There are a good bad girl, a bad bad girl, a buddy and a mom.

Otherwise, it‰Ûªs boys in the ‰Ûªhood all the way, with Blake Anderson (as a hippie hacker) and Quincy Brown (as a rich kid desperately striking outlaw poses) popping up when extra comedy or extra mayhem seems to be in order. Mr. Famuyiwa may be interested in mocking and subverting stereotypes, but he‰Ûªs unwilling to go beyond them entirely, to populate his sunny Southern California mean streets with fully rounded human beings. He also leans too heavily on the audience‰Ûªs presumed prejudices, or maybe on prejudices that some members of the audience will be eager to attribute to somebody else.

Does ‰ÛÏDope‰Ûù treat Malcolm ‰ÛÓ an ambitious, intelligent, nonviolent black adolescent ‰ÛÓ like a freak, or does it depict a world in which he‰Ûªs viewed that way? Does the film engage its precursors (movies like ‰ÛÏBoyz N the Hood‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMenace II Society‰Ûù) as update, pastiche or critique, or as some combination? These are complicated questions, but your answers are likely to determine your response to this amiable, energetic, scrambled movie. It‰Ûªs easy to root for Malcolm, to admire his pluck and share in his enthusiasm. It may be a little harder to buy what he and ‰ÛÏDope‰Ûù are selling.
