While Maria is studying in her school library one afternoon, Christian (Moritz Knapp), a boy her age from another class, strikes up a conversation and invites her to his choir practice. But because the repertory includes gospel and soul, which her mother considers Satan‰Ûªs tools, Maria reluctantly turns down the invitation.

Father Weber‰Ûªs severity is reinforced by Maria‰Ûªs mother (Franziska Weisz), who rules her family with a tyrannical fervor. The intensity of her tirades about Satan‰Ûªs wiles bring to mind Faye Dunaway as Joan Crawford fulminating against the use of wire hangers in the movie ‰ÛÏMommie Dearest‰Ûù or Piper Laurie in ‰ÛÏCarrie.‰Ûù Father Weber and Maria‰Ûªs family insist that their church, which disdains other forms of Catholicism, is the one true way.

When she tells her mother about her new acquaintance, she lies and says it is a girl. Even the tiniest white lie, when suspected, is enough to make her mother fly into a rage. She is so fanatically vigilant and withholding of approval that Maria becomes convinced her mother doesn‰Ûªt love her anymore.

These humiliations only increase Maria‰Ûªs determination to be purer and more self-sacrificing. Refusing to eat or to dress warmly, she begins to waste away, believing that if she sacrifices her life, Johannes will be able to speak.

It is also possible, although extremely far-fetched, to see ‰ÛÏStations of the Cross‰Ûù as a genuinely religious work exalting self-deprivation in pursuit of eternal life. Each of the film‰Ûªs 14 scenes was filmed in a single take and illustrates a different station in a traditional Roman Catholic sequence of images depicting Jesus on the day of his Crucifixion. The movie throws a crumb to true believers in what appears to be a miracle wrought by Maria near the end of the movie. Or is it just a sarcastic tease?

That much is obvious the moment the movie opens on Sin-Dee Rella (Kitana Kiki Rodriguez) and Alexandra (Mya Taylor), face to face in a doughnut shop, a single sprinkled confection grandly set before them. Tight friends, Sin-Dee and Alexandra share much in common, including a taste for sweets, a weakness for men and absolute faith in the transformational power of a luxurious wig. Given the girl talk and high-pitched shrieks of laughter, you may not immediately notice that the women are transgender, with identities that speak to the cultural moment. ‰ÛÏTangerine‰Ûù encompasses dizzying multitudes ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs a neo-screwball chase flick with a dash of Rainer Werner Fassbinder ‰ÛÓ but mostly, movingly, it is a female-friendship movie about two people who each started life with an XY chromosome set.

Little is as it seems in ‰ÛÏTangerine,‰Ûù a fast, raucously funny comedy about love and other misadventures. That‰Ûªs true of its main attractions, a pair of transgender lookers with motormouths and killer gams, as well as the nominally straight men occupying their hearts and minds. Appearances both deceive and delight in this tough yet tender, gritty yet gorgeous movie, which was made with ingenious skill and what would count as chump change at the big studios. Shot along a grubby stretch of Los Angeles, it takes place in the looming shadow of the Hollywood sign, but as far from industrial cinema as another galaxy.

Step by humorous, occasionally hurting step, Sin-Dee‰Ûªs quest takes her across Hollywood, which may be a state of mind to some but is a real neighborhood to others. Rarely since Michael Mann directed ‰ÛÏCollateral‰Ûù has a filmmaker mapped Los Angeles as lovingly and, with such open eyes, as Mr. Baker has. This isn‰Ûªt the usual movie-made city of fallen, monotonously stereotypical angels, with its suburban mega-fortresses, oceanside views, clogged freeways and Joan Didion anomie. It is, instead, a viscerally, vibrantly lived-in metropolis filled with people of different hues who walk (in Los Angeles!), ride the subway (yes, the subway), hop buses and occasionally jump into the cab of a frisky Armenian, Razmik (Karren Karagulian), whose home life and passengers all add layers to the diversified picture.

Mr. Baker has justifiably received a lot of attention for shooting ‰ÛÏTangerine‰Ûù with a few tricked out iPhones and some special lenses. His low-budget triumphalism and mother-of-invention ingenuity hews to a familiar heroic indie-film arc, though more remarkable still is Mr. Baker‰Ûªs casting of Ms. Rodriquez and Ms. Taylor, both fluid, forceful screen presences. He met Ms. Taylor at the Los Angeles L.G.B.T. Center, the 21st-century version of Lana Turner‰Ûªs apocryphal discovery at Schwab‰Ûªs; Ms. Taylor introduced him to Ms. Rodriguez. Like Turner, an old-fashioned Hollywood invention, the women embody an on-screen ideal of sexualized, glamorized femininity that means radically different things depending on the bodies expressing it. For Turner, femininity could look like a bad performance, like tawdry drag, even prison. Here, it looks like liberation.
‰ÛÏTangerine‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Drinking, drugging, swearing, whoring ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs Hollywood, honey.

Maybe it is, maybe it isn‰Ûªt. ‰ÛÏTangerine‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt dive deep into transgender identity; the movie is a dizzy, often exuberant down-and-dirty romp, not a lesson. It casually reminds you that femininity is a mask that can be slipped on and off, as when Sin-Dee‰Ûªs voice mischievously drops an octave or when Alexandra reminds a foolish client (Scott Krinsky as the parsimonious John) that she‰Ûªs easily his physical match. What‰Ûªs radical about ‰ÛÏTangerine‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt identity ‰ÛÓ which enters directly and obliquely, playfully and powerfully ‰ÛÓ but that Sin-Dee and Alexandra aren‰Ûªt limited by it. There‰Ûªs something blissfully freeing about that, just as there‰Ûªs something shocking when you remember that, not long ago, characters like these would have often been called on to decorate the story‰Ûªs edges or just laid out on a slab.

This mix feels bracing, honest and unforced. It‰Ûªs also political (as is the focus, however narratively expedient, on public transportation), which is sometimes the case when black and brown bodies take up this much time and space on an American movie screen and so beautifully, too. Unlike a lot of white directors, putatively independent and not, Mr. Baker hasn‰Ûªt simply looked in a mirror for his inspiration, but into that infinite world of possibility that is other people. When he bathes Sin-Dee and Alexandra in the luscious orange of another smoggy Los Angeles sunset, you may note the warm, radiant palette and, almost in passing, admire how the harmonious performances fit with the gracefulness of the filmmaking ‰ÛÓ but what you see, really see, are two women shimmering in the sun.

The story, from a script by the director Sean Baker and Chris Bergoch, is largely an excuse to chase after Sin-Dee and Alexandra as they navigate the frayed, less-familiar margins of Los Angeles. It‰Ûªs Christmas Eve, and Sin-Dee, having been released from jail, is looking to reconnect with her boyfriend and pimp, Chester (James Ransone), when she learns that he‰Ûªs stepped out on her. That cheating is an occupational prerogative for a pimp doesn‰Ûªt much concern Sin-Dee, who soon is hot in search of Chester and his mystery woman (Mickey O‰ÛªHagan as Dinah). Alexandra, the more pacific of the friends, vainly tries to calm Sin-Dee, a fast-talker and -walker whose bodily rhythms create a time signature that‰Ûªs answered by the editing, camera swoops and pumping musical beats.

There‰Ûªs a naÌøvetÌ© to some of this, especially when people who teach the discipline imply that tap dancing could solve all the problems of the world‰Ûªs wayward youths, a claim also made by proponents of soccer, spelling bees, bridge, poetry slams and a zillion other things. There‰Ûªs a repetitiveness as well; everyone here loves tap and eagerly tells us so. Yet we‰Ûªre left wondering about the details, like the physical demands and the time commitment necessary. And the film alludes only briefly to the economics of making a living with fast-moving feet.

The many varieties of tap dancing on display, though, are a treat to watch. And one particular story, of a dancer who overcame a seemingly insurmountable obstacle to continue pursuing the art form, is downright humbling.

‰ÛÏTap World‰Ûù is a pleasant documentary full of tap dancers proclaiming their love of the form and showing off their skills. It would be better if it had a bit less proclaiming and a bit more nuts-and-bolts information, but still, it‰Ûªs refreshing to see people bubbling over with enthusiasm for an art that is somewhat out of the mainstream.

The film‰Ûªs genesis, we‰Ûªre told, included an open invitation to professional and amateur tap dancers to submit clips of themselves in action. The movie focuses on an assortment of dancers from all over the world, some tapping for their own enjoyment, others trying to make a living at it.
The horror movie ‰ÛÏThe Gallows‰Ûù starts with a decent if improbable premise, and it ends with a pretty good jolt. But in between, the film sure wears out the already tired found-footage device.

Back in 1993, the theater department at Beatrice High School was staging a play called ‰ÛÏThe Gallows‰Ûù that went disastrously wrong when the pivotal set piece malfunctioned and left the male lead dead. Twenty years later, the department (this is the improbable part; no school would allow such a thing) decides to restage the same play, apparently as some kind of anniversary tribute.
‰ÛÏThe Gallows‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for frights and language.

We see practically all of this through hand-held video shot by one of the trapped students (Ryan Shoos), a boorish jock with a gorgeous girlfriend (Cassidy Gifford, daughter of Frank and Kathie Lee). Rickety camerawork has been almost mandatory in horror movies for the last few decades, and it has long since ceased to add to the scariness. Mostly it‰Ûªs just annoying, and that‰Ûªs certainly the case in this bothersome film, directed by Chris Lofing and Travis Cluff.

The night before the opening, four students, including the play‰Ûªs male and female stars (Reese Mishler and Pfeifer Brown), find themselves trapped in the auditorium by sinister forces. Is it the ghost of the student killed years earlier on the same stage? The creepy janitor? The socially spurned theater techie?

Transferring their successful sitcom formula ‰ÛÓ scene-stealing kids plus frazzled parents ‰ÛÓ to the Scottish Highlands, the writing and directing team of Andy Hamilton and Guy Jenkin (‰ÛÏOutnumbered‰Ûù) piles on the contrivances. These include a heart-tugging hook (provided by Billy Connolly as the croaking codger), a painful secret (kept by David Tennant and Rosamund Pike as divorcing parents), and a liberal dollop of quirky relatives and eccentric locals.

A family of bickering, broken adults has its priorities realigned by three children and a terminally ill grandpa in ‰ÛÏWhat We Did on Our Holiday,‰Ûù a damp-eyed comedy whose banal title isn‰Ûªt the only thing needing improvement.

Framed by placid ocean and heathered hillsides, this unexpectedly poignant sequence draws on fantasy and history ‰ÛÓ and the subtext of Mr. Connolly‰Ûªs real-life health concerns ‰ÛÓ to construct a touching commentary on end-of-life decisions. Rather than use this melancholy to deepen the narrative, the filmmakers soon yank us back to the buffoonery. Which suggests that taking the writers out of the sitcom might be easier than taking the sitcom rhythms out of their prose.
‰ÛÏWhat We Did on Our Holiday‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Quarreling adults, rioting hormones and an ostrich-breeding lesbian.

Stirring furiously, the directors ensure that most of the jokes and emotional beats land on cue. But Ms. Pike and Mr. Tennant are wasted in roles that demand little more than pecking at each other like angry gulls, and the excellent dramatic actress Amelia Bullmore is reduced to an offensive caricature as a menopausal sister-in-law. Yet as the adults squabble and pout, the movie is almost saved by a visit to a blessedly peaceful beach where the plot turns dark and Mr. Connolly coaxes a lovely performance from young Emilia Jones as his anxious grandchild.

Narayan is first seen teaching children Indian geography in a crowded Mumbai classroom, then hurrying to board a bus that takes him to an outdoor theater where he is introduced to a small crowd as ‰ÛÏthe people‰Ûªs poet.‰Ûù Backed by a troupe of musicians, he sings a forceful song urging everyone to rise up against ‰ÛÏreligious, racist, casteist and nationalist jungles.‰Ûù Midway through, Narayan is arrested.

For the public prosecutor, Nutan (Geetanjali Kulkarni), a smug middle-aged woman obsessed with obsolete judicial rules, the trial is just a formality to silence a gadfly. The sole witness she produces who recalls hearing the song has testified in similar cases and obviously been coached.

In a public arena, Narayan is a forceful, charismatic advocate for social change. As a Dalit, he belongs to a caste once considered ‰ÛÏuntouchable,‰Ûù and is treated by the judge and the prosecutor as an eccentric rabble-rouser and public nuisance. His young defense lawyer, Vinay Vora (Vivek Gomber), seems to be the only person interested in doing more than going through the motions of courtroom etiquette.

Time and again, the camera draws back to offer panoramic shots of Indian life in the streets or in the courtroom. Scenes are drawn out longer than they need to be, the better to evoke a complex social mosaic and convey a stately overview of Indian society. Late in the film, the courtroom is emptied, the lights are turned off, and the camera lingers in near-total darkness to contemplate another day of legal injustice.

The lack of evidence doesn‰Ûªt prevent the trial from dragging on for weeks, many of them spent going over laws that date to the 19th century. The judge, Sadavarte (Pradeep Joshi), puts on a studiously neutral face but voices no opinion. His primary goal is to keep the trial moving.

The wheels of justice grind slowly and mercilessly in ‰ÛÏCourt,‰Ûù Chaitanya Tamhane‰Ûªs quiet, devastating critique of the antiquated Indian legal system. As it follows the case of Narayan Kamble (Vira Sathidar), a 65-year-old folk singer and social activist accused of inciting what is presumed to be the suicide of a sewer worker in Mumbai, the film conjures an absurdist nightmare of bureaucratic incompetence, indifference and social inequity.

The remainder of the movie observes his protracted trial. A travesty of justice that another filmmaker might have directed as a farce, the work has a gravity, a measured pace and a detachment reminiscent of a Frederick Wiseman documentary ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏCourt,‰Ûù however, is fictional.

The movie follows the prosecutor and defense attorney out of the courtroom to observe them with their families. Nutan, the prosecutor, is a harried mother who is just trying to get through the day and sees Narayan‰Ûªs case as unworthy of serious scrutiny. Narayan‰Ûªs lawyer is a public defender from a prosperous family, who has a social conscience and cosmopolitan tastes in music and food. The movie doesn‰Ûªt specify what drew him to the case but implies that it was his belief in social justice. His continually nagging mother is obsessed with his finding a wife and producing grandchildren.

Because Narayan has long been seen as a political troublemaker, his guilt is presumed, and the movie gives you a queasy sense of how easy it is for rebellious public figures in India to find themselves on the wrong side of the law.

Defense witnesses testify that the manhole worker, who died from inhaling fumes, had no history of suicidal tendencies. His widow (Usha Bane) recalls that he found his job so noxious that he got drunk every morning before leaving home, but that he was not depressed. We learn that nobody supplied him masks or other protection of any kind from the hydrogen sulfide gas to which he succumbed while underground. To determine where the air was too toxic each morning, he would look for signs of life crawling out of the pipes. If a cockroach appeared, it was safe to go underground.

The heart of the trumped-up case is an allegation that Narayan performed an original song in a Mumbai slum, urging sewer workers to commit suicide, a ‰ÛÏseditious‰Ûù act. But, as the trial drags on, it becomes increasingly clear that no such song exists.

The Mumbai courtroom, in which the white-bearded Narayan dispassionately listens to charges that could land him a 20-year prison sentence, is a social microcosm of a country mired in hidebound colonial traditions, class prejudice and corruption.

It‰Ûªs no surprise that the Japanese artist-impresario Takashi Murakami has directed a feature-length film that combines human actors and animated characters. After all, Mr. Murakami is a polymath trained in anime as well as in Nihonga, Japan‰Ûªs rigorous traditional painting style, and has been moving between high and low art for over two decades. He is known for multipurpose cartoon creatures, among them petal-rimmed smiley faces and mushrooms dotted with wide, baby-doll peepers that he calls jellyfish eyes. These and other signature motifs have appeared in labor-intensive paintings, in large polychrome sculptures evoking a highbrow Disneyland and on skateboards and limited-edition Louis Vuitton handbags.

When the black-cloaked four discover that Masashi‰Ûªs energy is especially strong, things start heating up in a confusing way. Lightning flashes, toxic clouds swirl, Kurage-bo turns out to have jet engines, and eventually evil is vanquished or at least subdued. The black-cloaked four slink away, suggesting that a sequel is on the way. This grim prospect is confirmed by the trailer that follows the credits.

Masashi and his widowed mother (Mayu Tsuruta) have just arrived in town to be near his uncle, Naoto (Takumi Saito), who works in the lab. It has been all but hijacked by the black-cloaked four, whose mission immediately seems suspicious: to cleanse the world by channeling the powerful emotions of children.

Masashi is befriended by Kurage-bo, who likes Chee-Kama, a real cheese-and-fish-stick snack that ‰ÛÓ in a rare bit of product placement ‰ÛÓ is almost intrinsic to the plot. In the film, it is supposedly made by the company that employed Masashi‰Ûªs father, who is revealed in one of the boy‰Ûªs dreams to have died in the 2011 tsunami. Masashi discovers that his new schoolmates have similar companions and that they are called F.R.I.E.N.D.s, which breaks down into the not so catchy ‰ÛÏlife-Form Resonance Inner Energy Negative emotion and Disaster prevention.‰Ûù

Whatever you might think of Mr. Murakami‰Ûªs paintings and sculptures, they are invariably polished and eerily perfect, but his movie seems thrown together. It is poorly shot and afflicted by tedious sound (lots of screaming and saccharine music) and inept special effects. It moves with either incomprehensible abruptness or tedious slowness, especially at supposedly suspenseful moments. It seems aimed primarily at die-hard Murakami fans or children under 7 who will be taken with the animation (the best part). Those who fit neither demographic may watch ‰ÛÏJellyfish Eyes‰Ûù with growing perplexity; its obviousness might almost be ironic, but the laughs never come.

What‰Ûªs surprising is that ‰ÛÏJellyfish Eyes‰Ûù is very bad. A coming-of-age story with philosophical trappings, it centers on a tween named Masashi (the appealing Takuto Sueoka), and unfolds against a battle between good and evil that seems to be a fable about post-Fukushima Japan. With a lovable, jellyfish-like sprite named Kurage-bo (Jellyfish Boy) as its lead animated character, a laboratory of unspecified function that frightens its surrounding suburb, and a shapeless gray monster named Oval that towers above the land, the movie blends aspects of ‰ÛÏClose Encounters of the Third Kind,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFrankenstein‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGodzilla.‰Ûù Other familiar devices include a brainwashed religious cult and four young villains in black capes who lack only big black mustaches to twirl.

These vivid animated creatures, conjured by Mr. Murakami and his studio for the movie, are irresistible and, as might be expected, have already spawned a line of small rubber charms. The best scenes come early, when Kurage-bo fights off the other F.R.I.E.N.D.s, with the aid of Luxor, the F.R.I.E.N.D. of a peace-loving girl, Saki (Himeka Asami), who bonds with Masashi. The giant Luxor is played by an actor in furry costume.

The expression ‰ÛÏamour fou‰Ûù barely begins to describe the unhinged passions that boil in ‰ÛÏAlleluia,‰Ûù the Belgian director Fabrice Du Welz‰Ûªs reimagining of the 1970 crime classic ‰ÛÏThe Honeymoon Killers.‰Ûù That docudrama was inspired by the murderous real-life exploits of Raymond Fernandez and Martha Beck, lovers who achieved tabloid notoriety as the Lonely Hearts Killers in the late 1940s.

A movie that begins as a kinky erotic thriller morphs into an increasingly gory horror film, divided into four acts, each focused on a conquest. Posing as brother and sister, the two go on the road in search of vulnerable widows. While traveling, Gloria leaves her young daughter in the care of a friend.

‰ÛÏAlleluia,‰Ûù which is set in the present, begins the afternoon that Gloria (Lola DueÌ±as), a middle-aged single mother with a resemblance to Anna Magnani, connects with Michel (Laurent Lucas), a suave, handsome shoe salesman with an avaricious smile, on an Internet dating site.

He also has a foot fetish, which Gloria gratifies, and an obsession with Humphrey Bogart. The movie incorporates a scene from ‰ÛÏThe African Queen‰Ûù in which Bogart makes goofy faces at Katharine Hepburn. His parodies of those expressions become a running joke that calms Gloria when she seems about to explode.

From the beginning, the relationship is threatened by Gloria‰Ûªs scary, insane jealousy. When Gloria, who made Michel vow to sleep only with her, catches him in flagrante delicto with another woman, she becomes murderously unhinged. To accomplish his seductions undetected, Michel begins drugging Gloria with sleeping pills before working his wiles.

What lifts ‰ÛÏAlleluia‰Ûù far above run-of-the-mill Grand Guignol is a screenplay written by the director with Vincent Tavier that treats each conquest as discrete. The homely, warmhearted Marguerite (Edith Le Merdy), whom Michel marries, recalls that her first husband didn‰Ûªt ‰ÛÏsee‰Ûù her. Gabriella, an older, proper Roman Catholic devoted to the church, believes that Michel and Gloria are charity workers who have spent years in central Africa doing good works. Solange (Helena Noguerra) is a beautiful young widow with a high-strung young daughter. Throughout the movie, the eerily blasÌ© Michel loses his temper only once.

At their first meeting, Michel, who looks a bit like the young Martin Landau, sweeps Gloria off her feet and into bed. Afterward, he asks her for money, which she gladly gives him, then disappears. Gloria, hopelessly besotted, tracks him down to a nightclub where she finds him surrounded by fawning women. When he confesses that he is really a gigolo who specializes in swindling lonely, mostly older, women, she pressures him to make her his business partner, and they become a team.

Driven by lust that racks her with uncontrollable seizures, Gloria is bewitched. Even when she announces that she will live only for him, Michel ignores ominous warning signs. And he is riddled with quirks. A practitioner of eerie candlelit rituals in preparation for his seductions and prone to acute migraines, he confesses that he learned his sexual skills from his mother, who slept with him when there were no other men available and taught him how to give pleasure. As an adult, he began to seek compensation for his services.

The film takes place almost entirely inside the heated bubble of their demented relationship. How they meet the women Michel seduces is left to the imagination. The noirish cinematography of Manu Dacosse sustains a mood of shadowy ambiguity and menace, and there are creepy close-ups that seem to get under their skin.
In this version of the story, the bubble never bursts. ‰ÛÏAlleluia‰Ûù is a fever dream of sex, jealousy and murder whose intensity leaves you spellbound.

The ants who are regular summer visitors to my kitchen have lately been sending scouts into the study. One just crawled across my laptop screen, and as I crushed its tiny body between my thumb and forefinger, an alarming thought crossed my mind: They know what I‰Ûªm up to. Ants are highly intelligent creatures (at least collectively), and are famous for their determination and commitment. Here I was, about to pass judgment on one of their rare forays into popular culture, and here they were, checking up on me.

The most ingenious sequence comes near the end, during a climactic battle between two miniaturized dudes, which toggles between their perspective and that of normal-size people. What appears to the combatants to be a noisy, screen-filling, no-holds-barred struggle looks, at human scale, like a minor disturbance in a room full of toys. Perhaps this is a metaphor: Trapped inside this big movie is a small one, trying to get out.

But look at the time! Spoiler alert. OMG and LOL ‰ÛÓ not so much of the first (unless you are still astonished by the sight of guys in mechanical suits punching each other), but a decent dose of the second. This is mostly thanks to David Dastmalchian, Michael PeÌ±a and the rapper T.I., who play Scott‰Ûªs buddies with cantankerous Three Stooges energy. Judy Greer and Bobby Cannavale show up as Scott‰Ûªs former wife and her new husband ‰ÛÓ stepfather to Scott‰Ûªs adorable daughter (Abby Ryder Fortson) ‰ÛÓ but for fans of these wonderful actors, the main satisfaction will come from the knowledge that they earned some money. (The continued marginalization of the brilliant Ms. Greer in expensive studio movies, however, has become a national scandal. Someone needs to convene a task force.)
I wish I could assure you that no insects were harmed in the writing of this review, but that would be a lie.

It‰Ûªs an origin story, which is too bad, but at least relieves a reviewer of tedious explanatory duties. The background is that a brilliant scientist, Dr. Hank Pym (Michael Douglas, a fine goateed curmudgeon), has developed a secret particle that makes objects shrink. His onetime protÌ©gÌ©, Darren Cross (Corey Stoll, a fine bald villain) wants to perfect the invention and put it to nefarious use. A hapless ex-con named Scott Lang (Mr. Rudd) gets mixed up with the scientist and his daughter, Hope (Evangeline Lilly), and the next thing you know ...

Ants are not known for individualism, which makes them, in some ways, a less promising platform for superheroism than spiders or bats. When Scott summons swarms of six-legged allies, the effect is underwhelming. But Mr. Reed does exploit two important (if obvious) ant characteristics: strength and tininess. Scott‰Ûªs Ant-Man suit allows him to change size instantly, which adds novelty to some of the fight scenes (notably one with Falcon, an Avenger played by Anthony Mackie).

And Mr. Rudd? Well, it‰Ûªs funny. What I mean is that he isn‰Ûªt very funny, which is strange, given his track record in ensemble comedies. He‰Ûªs a pleasant enough hero, registering confusion, amazement and irritation when circumstances require them, but his special charisma gets lost in the suit and drowned out in the hectic noise of the plot.

So someone else will have to tackle the hot topic of ‰ÛÏWhat ‰Û÷Ant-Man‰Ûª Gets Wrong About Ants.‰Ûù Directed by the comedy specialist Peyton Reed (‰ÛÏBring It On,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Break-Up,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏYes Man‰Ûù) from a script credited to Edgar Wright, Adam McKay, Joe Cornish and Paul Rudd (who stars), this film is a passable piece of drone work from the ever-expanding Marvel-Disney colony. It provides obligatory, intermittently amusing links to other corporate properties, serving essentially as a sidebar to the ‰ÛÏAvengers‰Ûù franchise. Like ‰ÛÏGuardians of the Galaxy,‰Ûù last year‰Ûªs off-brand Marvel hit, ‰ÛÏAnt-Man‰Ûù dabbles in the bright, playful colors of the superhero spectrum, reveling in moments of cartoonish whimsy and smirky humor.

But to what end? Were they sniffing out bad press in advance, or trying to warn an honest journalist that their species was terribly misrepresented by ‰ÛÏAnt-Man‰Ûù? In my thoughtless, murderous haste, I hadn‰Ûªt bothered to ask, or to check my victim for a Marvel logo tattooed on its thorax.
‰ÛÏAnt-Man‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Squish.
In one nice twist, though, the film ends with a nod to the truth. The land grab, one character notes, is not going to end: ‰ÛÏThe people who sent them will send more.‰Ûù

In this contemporary frontier tale, Gael GarcÌ_a Bernal (‰ÛÏRosewater‰Ûù) plays a Man With No Name ‰ÛÓ though the credits call him KaÌ_ ‰ÛÓ who emerges from a river to arrive at the subsistence-level tobacco farm that JoÌ£o (Chico DÌ_az); his daughter, VÌ¢nia (Alice Braga); and a handyman are trying to protect from mercenaries sent to steal the land for a lumber company.

This slow-paced, cut-to-the-bone drama ought to be gripping, especially as the jungle and its beasts make their presence felt. But curiously, ‰ÛÏArdor‰Ûù lacks tension, maybe because the actors are playing archetypes: Little is said, and there are few surprises.

The Argentine director Pablo Fendrik presents ‰ÛÏArdor‰Ûù as a ‰ÛÏmachete western‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ that is, a western transplanted to the thick rain forests of South America ‰ÛÓ but its plot draws just as much from Tarzan as from Sergio Leone, with a dusting of magical realism.

JoÌ£o tells KaÌ_ that he is the answer to prayers the old farmer offered to the jungle spirits. If so, he‰Ûªs a kind of mixed blessing: That night, the hired guns shoot the handyman and force JoÌ£o to sign a bill of sale before killing him and kidnapping VÌ¢nia. After burying JoÌ£o, KaÌ_ stalks the murderers in the rain forest, hoping to rescue VÌ¢nia and avenge JoÌ£o by using the ways of the jungle.

Employees, many of whom stayed for decades, loved the business and working for the old man. For family members, it was a different story. Sol, Nathan‰Ûªs younger son (and Lloyd‰Ûªs father) left to start his own hot-dog restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. As Nathan reluctantly ceded more responsibility to his older son, Murray, they clashed over Murray‰Ûªs decision to expand. Nathan officially retired in 1971, then died in 1974 in his early 80s. A group of investors bought the business in 1987.

The movie is choppy and rushed ‰ÛÓ a bumper-car ride that somehow fits the rough-and-tumble era it recalls. Nathan remains a distant figure, summoned best in a thickly accented interview he gave in 1973 to Lloyd‰Ûªs cousin.

‰ÛÏFamous Nathan‰Ûù is a home movie of a tribute by a grandson, Lloyd Handwerker, who really didn‰Ûªt know his forebear. Off and on since the 1980s, he has compiled archival footage and interviewed family, friends and longtime Nathan‰Ûªs staff members, sketching a portrait of a classic rags-to-riches success, and a tough boss who was fanatical about the quality of his fare and the speed of its delivery.

But ‰ÛÏFamous Nathan‰Ûù is also a respectful account of an immigrant family dynamic many Brooklynites of a certain age might recognize, and of the heyday of a fast-food landmark that still draws multitudes.

Back when Coney Island was America‰Ûªs playground, Nathan Handwerker was royalty. An immigrant from Poland of little education and lesser means, Handwerker built a hot-dog stand into an eatery that became an institution, then a sensation. No one who was anyone didn‰Ûªt stop by and have a frank at Nathan‰Ûªs Famous.

Directed by Bill Condon and based on a novel by Mitch Cullin, ‰ÛÏMr. Holmes‰Ûù tells a few overlapping stories. From the cottage where Holmes (Ian McKellen) spends time with his housekeeper, Mrs. Munro (Laura Linney), a war widow, and her young son, Roger (Milo Parker), the film occasionally ventures backward and eastward, revisiting a 30-year-old case and a more recent sojourn in Japan. In London just after World War I, Holmes trails a married woman (Hattie Morahan) whose husband (Patrick Kennedy) suspects her of taking illicit music lessons. In Japan, he meets with an amateur herbalist (Hiroyuki Sanada) with a family secret. Back home, Holmes struggles with his growing forgetfulness, tends his hives and encourages Roger‰Ûªs dreams and ambitions, which are thwarted by Mrs. Munro‰Ûªs narrow, anxious mind-set.

The film suggests that there is much about Sherlock Holmes that his fans don‰Ûªt know. Its most ingenious conceit is that the real man has grown old alongside his legend, slipping into theaters to watch movies made about his exaggerated exploits and gently correcting some of Watson‰Ûªs fabrications. A long retirement has humanized him, and the specific longings and regrets chronicled in ‰ÛÏMr. Holmes‰Ûù might constitute only a partial list.

That at least, is the tantalizing possibility implicit in Mr. McKellen‰Ûªs whispered reminiscences and slow, graceful movements: that beyond the potted vignettes we are witnessing lies the untold story of a great, complex soul, a man more mysterious than any of the crimes he is supposed to have solved.

‰ÛÏMr. Holmes,‰Ûù a mild and minor bit of revisionist Sherlockiana, imagines the world‰Ûªs greatest detective in his dotage, retired to a picturesque rural spot on the English coast where he tends to bees and fading memories. It‰Ûªs 1947, and Holmes is in his 90s. Dr. Watson is long gone, and it turns out that the pipe and the deerstalker cap were fictitious embellishments. The keen ratiocinative powers that made Holmes an early hero of modern popular culture are still in evidence, though the cases he has left to solve are of a decidedly intimate, melancholy nature. No spectacular murders or intricate conspiracies: just quiet enigmas of memory and remorse.
‰ÛÏMr. Holmes‰Ûù is rated PG (Parents strongly cautioned). Hints of violence.

You might also detect some kinship between Holmes and Magneto, Mr. McKellen‰Ûªs mutant in the ‰ÛÏX-Men‰Ûù movies, whose genius is filtered through rage and resentment. Not that Holmes is angry, though he does now and then betray a flicker of impatience. He is, however, very much a man of feeling as well as a creature of reason, and the suggestions of buried emotion that can sometimes be detected between the coolly logical lines of Arthur Conan Doyle‰Ûªs stories are brought to rich life here.

The film‰Ûªs plots are soft and flimsy, and they don‰Ûªt mesh as gracefully as they might, but they do serve as an adequate trellis for Mr. McKellen‰Ûªs performance, which is gratifyingly but unsurprisingly wonderful. With his craggy visage and papery diction, his Holmes is a study in wry, intellectual charisma. Anachronistic as it might be, it isn‰Ûªt hard to imagine Benedict Cumberbatch, the kinetic, intensely focused Sherlock of the BBC series, aging into this mellow codger. (The same can‰Ûªt be said for the smirky action-hero version played by Robert Downey Jr. in Guy Ritchie‰Ûªs tedious franchise.)

One of cinema‰Ûªs untold running, stumbling men (it‰Ûªs a crowded field), Gun-soo has plenty to flee: his grief over his mother; the money worries of his hectoring sister and her inept husband; his colleagues, an ominous gang; his moral turpitude. As a director, Mr. Kim devotes much of his energy to keeping Gun-soo preoccupied, and with increased freneticism, to moving the character relentlessly forward in the face of an obstacle course filled with pop-up hurdles and an occasional kick in the gut. As the screenwriter, Mr. Kim is a quick-sketch artist when it comes to character motivation. He doesn‰Ûªt fill in Gun-soo and the rest with psychological insight and anguished speeches; rather, with pointed asides ‰ÛÓ about failing businesses, corrupt cops and Korea ‰ÛÓ Mr. Kim paints a world.

Mr. Kim sets a tireless pace that never gets exhausting, at least not for the viewer. Shot in thin-looking digital, the movie has next to no visual density, which isn‰Ûªt always nice on the eyes but suits this whooshing story. The editing, as is common in commercial action cinema, can be very fast, with some shots shorter, seemingly, than the blink of an eye. In a lot of action movies, quick cutting is mostly an attempt to create a sense of urgency that‰Ûªs otherwise absent. You can get lost in the ensuing chaos, as the image splinters and scatters. Here, though, the editing initially prevents your having a coherent, unified image of Gun-soo ‰ÛÓ in moments, he looks as shattered as a reflection in a broken mirror ‰ÛÓ which visually suggests just what kind of man he is, what kind of stakes he faces.

Just about the time that it seems Mr. Kim should soon be running on empty, he introduces a new threat: another detective, Park Chang-min. Played by a spectacular Cho Jin-woong with a John Wayne swagger, an oily scoop of velvet Elvis hair and a billowing black coat that adds a bespoke dash to the villainous picture, Park slides into the story and soon very nearly engulfs it. Mr. Cho has a large face that can appear deceptively inviting (he often enters winking, underscoring his resemblance to the Man in the Moon), that can freeze into a stone-cold slab of pure malice. Park‰Ûªs ominous charisma could have been its own hurdle for Mr. Kim, but he skillfully marshals the character to the story‰Ûªs good and just lets that big moon glow into a long night that you‰Ûªre sorry to see end.

Not long after the panicky protagonist of ‰ÛÏA Hard Day‰Ûù avoids hitting a dog with his car on a dark highway ‰ÛÓ only to run over some guy, stuff the guy‰Ûªs corpse into the trunk and be comically waylaid at a sobriety checkpoint by some Keystone clowns ‰ÛÓ you may wonder how long the writer-director, Kim Seong-hun, can keep this Rube Goldberg machine going. By the time the dupe-hero is sliding that cadaver through an air duct at the funeral parlor where his dead mother is laid out, it‰Ûªs clear that Mr. Kim is just going to keep the gears greased and happily purring.

A kinetically visceral, enjoyable nasty joy ride, ‰ÛÏA Hard Day‰Ûù is pretty much as advertised. Its long day opens at night, with Gun-soo (Lee Sun-kyun), a South Korean detective, speeding on a highway while chattering on the phone with his sister. Their mother has recently died, and Sis wants to know why Gun-soo isn‰Ûªt there with her and playing the dutiful, grieving son. Their exchange slips by quickly and is soon lost amid the horrible thudding of Gun-soo running over a body and the sound of so many falling dominoes, but their conversation introduces the idea that keeping up appearances is crucial. Gun-soo, who keeps a photo of his daughter on the dashboard (like a talisman or maybe a threat), is constantly looking over his shoulder, and that gets tricky when you‰Ûªre racing from trouble.

Lila meets Eve (Jennifer Lopez), her partner in payback, at a meeting of Mothers of Angels, a 12-step support group for women with murdered children. Eve, who agrees to be Lila‰Ûªs sponsor, goads her to find Stephon‰Ûªs killer when the police drop the case after a cursory investigation.

The main, and perhaps the only, reason to see the revenge thriller ‰ÛÏLila and Eve,‰Ûù a shallow, cut-rate ‰ÛÏThelma and Louise,‰Ûù is for the thunderous lead performance of Viola Davis. Her character, Lila, is an aggrieved mother of two sons in an Atlanta suburb who is responding to the drive-by shooting death of the older, the 18-year-old Stephon (Aml Ameen), who was college bound. Whether on the large or small screen, Ms. Davis projects an ominous gravity. Even when smiling, she always means business.
‰ÛÏLila and Eve‰Ûù is rated R for violence and language.

Eve is a throwback to Ms. Lopez‰Ûªs abused wife in the preposterous 2002 thriller ‰ÛÏEnough,‰Ûù in which her character, Slim, the imperiled wife of a rich, vengeful psychopath, took the law into her own hands. Both characters are shrill one-note creations. Eve‰Ûªs back story (she lost a daughter) is barely mentioned.

Eve persuades Lila to visit the street corner where Stephon was shot. There they confront a low-level dealer, who pulls a gun. Eve promptly shoots him. As the body count escalates, and the pair stake out a drug kingpin‰Ûªs lair, ‰ÛÏLila and Eve‰Ûù deteriorates into a tawdry shoot-‰Ûªem-up whose screenplay takes an ill-advised surreal twist that propels the movie deep into the ozone.

As you watch the movie, directed by Charles Stone III (‰ÛÏDrumline‰Ûù) from a screenplay by Patrick Gilfillan, you marvel that Ms. Davis makes any dramatic headway in this sloppily written movie, which loses its center and feels like an exploitative made-for-TV quickie. ‰ÛÏLila and Eve‰Ûù glosses over issues facing African-American families, not the least of which is police indifference to drug-related urban crime and its collateral damage. Its treatment of the subject is incidental compared with its fixation on gun-toting female vigilantes seeking street justice.

South Koreans voted with their feet to give ‰ÛÏNorthern Limit Line‰Ûù the box-office edge over ‰ÛÏTerminator Genisys‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏInside Out,‰Ûù but I wouldn‰Ûªt get too excited. This jingoistic war-at-sea movie, redeemed by neither narrative momentum nor fully formed characters, will test the patience of the most ardent military fanatic.

A critical World Cup match between South Korea and Turkey unfolds in the background but fails to prevent what should have been a rousing naval adventure from becoming a 130-minute slog. Though if you have a tipple every time someone says, ‰ÛÏSalute!,‰Ûù you‰Ûªll soon be too plastered to care.

Striving to dramatize a real-life battle that occurred in 2002 near Yeonpyeong Island in the Yellow Sea, the writer and director, Kim Hak-soon, stirs corn and clichÌ© into a paean to patriotism. But while jogging the national memory and wringing the national heart might work at home, it‰Ûªs unlikely to captivate foreign audiences who desire more than inert staging and ineptly executed conflict. Thus, when a North Korean ship crosses the so-called Northern Limit Line ‰ÛÓ the hotly disputed maritime boundary between the two Koreas ‰ÛÓ and opens fire on a South Korean patrol vessel, the ensuing bloodshed is more confusing than distressing.

Powered by the banal interactions of a humorless lieutenant commander (Kim Mu-yeol), a boyish officer (Jin Goo) and a friendly medic (Lee Hyun-woo), the movie layers melodramatic moments onto Hans Zimmer-ish musical phrases. (At times, the ghostly strains of the ‰ÛÏPearl Harbor‰Ûù soundtrack seem to be trying to break through.)

The second half is less focused. There is a trip to South Korea for a gathering of adoptees, a reunion with the foster mothers who cared for the two briefly after they were born and a bittersweet search for their biological mother. The film has too many fits of uncontrolled laughter and other awkwardness that suggest an unedited home movie, but, in general, ‰ÛÏTwinsters‰Ûù makes for a heartfelt alternative to a traditional documentary approach.

Samantha Futerman and AnaÌøs Bordier, identical twins born in South Korea in 1987, were adopted by different families shortly after birth and raised on different continents. Each was unaware that she was a twin until a friend of Ms. Bordier‰Ûªs saw a video of Ms. Futerman, an actress, on YouTube in 2013. What‰Ûªs unusual about ‰ÛÏTwinsters‰Ûù is that the women (mostly Ms. Futerman, a director of the film) tell the story of their eventual reunion themselves while it unfolds, with the help of Skype, Facebook and some friends with video cameras.

They document the process, which included a trip by Ms. Futerman, who was raised in the United States, to England to meet Ms. Bordier, and DNA testing to confirm their suspicions. That all takes place in the first half of the film, which is engaging.

The real-life story told in ‰ÛÏTwinsters‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ separated-at-birth twins find each other and reunite ‰ÛÓ is less unusual than it once was, thanks to the Internet. But the way this particular tale is told has some DIY charm.

The film has a farm-to-table sensibility, proclaiming the culinary superiority of beef that isn‰Ûªt raised agribusiness-style and shipped halfway around the world. But within that mind-set is a range of philosophies about what to feed the animals, when to slaughter them, how to age the meat, how to cook it. Selecting the animals can go beyond breed to ‰ÛÓ yes ‰ÛÓ personality.

In his documentary ‰ÛÏSteak (R)evolution,‰Ûù Franck RibiÌ¬re goes in search of the world‰Ûªs best steak. But this informative foodie film is more than just footage of assorted chefs cooking delicious-looking cuts of meat. The tour encompasses breeders, butchers, grazing practices and genetics. Mr. RibiÌ¬re uses a Top 10 countdown structure familiar from other searching-for-the-best documentaries, but the rankings are beside the point. This film is all about the meat and the animals it comes from.
The search takes Mr. RibiÌ¬re to Japan, Italy, South America, Britain, Brooklyn (where the Peter Luger Steak House makes his list) and more. We meet assorted breeds, each with advocates among chefs.

Backyard barbecuers may never eat at any of the restaurants seen here, but they‰Ûªll come away enlightened about things like what ‰ÛÏAngus‰Ûù really means on their grocery-store cut and whether, when it comes to steaks, bigger is really better.
‰ÛÏWe look for docile animals with a noble character,‰Ûù says JosÌ© Gordon, a breeder and chef in Spain. ‰ÛÏThis kind of character facilitates a specific marbling.‰Ûù

With a single exception ‰ÛÓ an old NBC news report from the mid-1960s ‰ÛÓ Mr. Oppenheimer avoids the archival footage and explanatory material that usually fill out historical documentaries. His approach is more like Claude Lanzmann‰Ûªs in ‰ÛÏShoah,‰Ûù which surveyed the Holocaust by rigorously focusing on the faces and words of witnesses, survivors and participants.

Mr. Rukun sets out, along with Mr. Oppenheimer and a film crew, to confront his brother‰Ûªs killers. Sometimes he conducts eye exams while asking questions, his professional bearing blending with his gentle, insistent manner of interrogation.

Mr. Oppenheimer, filming in Indonesia over more than a decade, found that this ideology was still very much in place. ‰ÛÏThe Look of Silence‰Ûù visits a classroom where young children are taught that the killings were justified. Elsewhere, they are celebrated. Early in the film, two elderly men stroll down an overgrown path to the banks of the Snake River, gleefully demonstrating how they beat their captives, dragged them by the feet and then hacked them to death with knives and machetes. Their laughter is all the more horrifying for seeming free and un-self-conscious, as if they were recalling incidents of youthful mischief.

Amid the laughter, the boasting and the superstition, there are some of the expected evasions and excuses. The killers were only following orders, or targeting bad people, or caught up in the chaos of the times. It was so long ago, Mr. Rukun is told. Why stir up bad memories?

The mood of ‰ÛÏThe Look of Silence‰Ûù is tranquil. Its settings ‰ÛÓ modest houses and sun-dappled gardens, far from the urban bustle of ‰ÛÏThe Act of Killing‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ are peaceful, and Mr. Rukun is a quiet man, contemplating his family‰Ûªs tragedy more in sorrow than in anger. But this atmosphere has the effect of making the violence at the film‰Ûªs heart all the more shocking. Movies have helped make even extreme brutality seem banal (that was part of the message of ‰ÛÏThe Act of Killing‰Ûù), but hearing a simple, factual account of an atrocity can be almost unbearable.

We watch video of the two men, around 10 years after it was shot, in the company of Adi Rukun, a soft-spoken ophthalmologist whose brother Ramli was killed by the Komando Aksi, a paramilitary organization in the Aceh Province of Indonesia. Mr. Rukun was born in 1968, and he is haunted less by traumatic memories than by their terrible absence. His mother recalls the day of Ramli‰Ûªs disappearance with unbearable clarity and undiluted sorrow, while his father, who is frail, mostly blind and over 100, drifts in and out of awareness.

‰ÛÏThe Look of Silence,‰Ûù a documentary directed by the American filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer and an anonymous Indonesian collaborator, is a painful, profoundly empathetic work of moral reckoning. Like its companion film, ‰ÛÏThe Act of Killing,‰Ûù released in 2013, it examines the mass killings that began in Indonesia in 1965, when at least a million people were slaughtered in the aftermath of a military coup.

‰ÛÏAfter such knowledge, what forgiveness?‰Ûù T. S. Eliot asked that question, in his poem ‰ÛÏGerontion,‰Ûù almost a century ago, and it has hovered over much subsequent history. Mr. Oppenheimer and his collaborators pose it with renewed urgency and poignancy, and also suggest the ways that, in Indonesia, forgiveness is still premature. The silence they discover is not a failure of acknowledgment, but the refusal of apology.

In the earlier movie, perpetrators of the massacres eagerly re-enact their crimes, borrowing costumes and attitudes from American genre movies, as if they were western or film noir heroes. In ‰ÛÏThe Look of Silence,‰Ûù it is clear that many of the killers, whose political sponsors are still in power, feel little or no regret for their actions. On the contrary, they bask in a glow of righteous vindication. A death squad commander matter-of-factly talks about ‰ÛÏexterminating Communists‰Ûù for several months and concludes that ‰ÛÏbecause this was an international matter, we should be given a gift. We should be rewarded with a trip to America.‰Ûù Recalling the Cold War context of the atrocities, he notes that ‰ÛÏAmerica taught us to hate Communists.‰Ûù

Even when specific atrocities are admitted ‰ÛÓ or bragged about ‰ÛÓ ultimate responsibility is pushed away. Death squad members say they were fulfilling the mandates of the military, while politicians insist that the slaughter was the spontaneous expression of popular will. It‰Ûªs suggested at one point that the ‰ÛÏCommunists‰Ûù offered themselves up, asking to be killed as punishment for their transgressions.

The encounters are, for the most part, unnervingly calm and decorous. For half a century, survivors have lived among those responsible for the deaths of their loved ones. Political authorities, neighbors, even relatives and friends have blood on their hands, and acknowledge as much. A few go further, telling of how they drank their victims‰Ûª blood, a practice they credit with saving them from the madness that afflicted some of their colleagues.
‰ÛÏThe Look of Silence‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Extreme acts of violence, rendered in words rather than images.

Billy Crudup, playing Dr. Zimbardo, is the most recognizable name in the cast, and he does nice work portraying a man who, as the experiment spirals out of control, is torn between protecting the students and protecting his research. But it‰Ûªs the young actors playing the students who really make an impression.

The film is about a 1971 study done by a Stanford University professor, Philip Zimbardo, in which students were recruited to play either guards or inmates in a make-believe prison. Guess what? People put in positions of authority, like prison guards, sometimes abuse that authority, and in startlingly cruel ways.

Fine ensemble acting brings a notorious psychological study to life in ‰ÛÏThe Stanford Prison Experiment.‰Ûù The research, now 44 years old, may today seem as if it merely confirmed the obvious, but the film, by Kyle Patrick Alvarez, certainly makes you feel the claustrophobic intensity of what went on.

Michael Angarano is downright terrifying as a guard who patterns his behavior after a particularly nasty character in the prison movie ‰ÛÏCool Hand Luke,‰Ûù which had come out in 1967. The students playing prisoners adopt attitudes ranging from rebellious to meek, but none are immune to the brutal treatment of their overseers.

The experiment‰Ûªs methodologies and meanings have been analyzed endlessly over the years, and the film doesn‰Ûªt delve deeply into these interpretations and critiques. It doesn‰Ûªt need to; this stark and riveting version of events speaks for itself.
‰ÛÏThe Stanford Prison Experiment‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language and intensity.

Amy does have issues, which give the movie a fuzzy focal point, namely that she needs to believe she‰Ûªs worthy of a man‰Ûªs love or something. The movie suggests that this has to do with her adored father, Gordon (Colin Quinn), who‰Ûªs introduced in the opener delivering uncommon words of advice to the 9-year-old Amy and her younger sister, Kim. ‰ÛÏMonogamy isn‰Ûªt realistic,‰Ûù Gordon declares, instructing his daughters to repeat after him. Fast forward 23 years, and Amy has done just that, seemingly taking those words to heart by freely taking men to bed. She‰Ûªs breezily accepting of her choices, though falters when she receives a one-two punch: She falls for a monogamous-minded surgeon, Aaron (Bill Hader, sweetly vulnerable), and her father‰Ûªs bad health dramatically worsens.

‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù is pretty straight stuff: Amy likes to have sex with men and isn‰Ûªt interested in monogamy. That makes her like a lot of women (studies show!), if not like those who generally flounder through the average dippy romantic comedy, where gender norms are rigorously enforced and the only things contemporary about the characters are their designer threads and gadgets. What‰Ûªs energizing and exciting about Amy, especially when compared with the sexless cuties populating rom-coms, in which female pleasure is often expressed through shopping, is that her erotic appetites aren‰Ûªt problems that she needs to narratively solve and vanquish. She likes sex, thanks, as an early montage of her shuffling through various men nicely illustrates.

Ms. Schumer fares better when she‰Ûªs slaying symbolic fathers, as in a brutally funny short scene, tucked in a montage sequence, in which Amy and Aaron have sex on a bench in front of a bridge. Much like the flourish from George Gershwin‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRhapsody in Blue‰Ûù that slips onto the ‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù soundtrack, this image initially sneaks in like yet another homage to Woody Allen‰Ûªs 1979 film, ‰ÛÏManhattan,‰Ûù and the most famous image in his work. The allusion quickly turns into an evisceration of that movie‰Ûªs gauzy romanticism when Amy jokes that she thinks this is where ‰ÛÏWoody Allen met Soon-Yi.‰Ûù It sounds cheap only if you forget that the other romantic couple in ‰ÛÏManhattan,‰Ûù the one not immortalized on the bridge, was played by Mr. Allen and a teenage Mariel Hemingway.

The movie‰Ûªs giddy first half zips along more smoothly than the second, which sputters when the story takes a short, awkwardly managed detour into tragedy. Ms. Schumer trained as an actress, and her tears in ‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù are fairly persuasive, if not as contagious as her laughs. Yet while they‰Ûªre narrative necessities, they‰Ûªre also tonally at odds with the movie‰Ûªs overall buoyancy. (Mr. Apatow‰Ûªs sentimental side is crystallized by a close-up of a weeping Amy, a shot that underscores the obvious.) As with a lot of debuts, there are a few different stories crammed into ‰ÛÏTrainwreck,‰Ûù which is Ms. Schumer‰Ûªs first produced film script, and the least satisfying one is the melodrama about the daughter struggling to come to terms with her feelings for an aggressively unlovable father who begot, bred and loved her.

Ms. Schumer drew on her own life for the story, which she turned into something of a sexual bildungsroman cum romantic comedy jumping with pop-cultural references and edged with razored social cultural critique. Her on-screen doppelgÌ_nger works as a writer for a men‰Ûªs magazine, S‰ÛªNuff, a blistering, jokey title that sums up the idiocy of lad mags and their annihilating views on women. That the editor running it is a woman, Dianna (a peerless Tilda Swinton, in a swingy shag and gloomy spray tan), isn‰Ûªt surprising. Ms. Schumer can be a merciless equal-opportunity takedown artist. If she doesn‰Ûªt let women off the hook, it‰Ûªs because she knows that sexism isn‰Ûªt exclusively a guy thing; like stupidity, it is a people thing.

In ‰ÛÏTrainwreck,‰Ûù Ms. Schumer plays, well, Amy, a more vanilla version of one of her comically flawed women, who aren‰Ûªt as remotely together as they think or may appear to be. The movie, which was directed by Judd Apatow from her script, is often extremely funny, even if it never approaches the radicalness of her greatest, most dangerous work. Mr. Apatow‰Ûªs talent as a movie director is opening up a space on screen in which comic performers (and some total stiffs) can be effortlessly funny together. In ‰ÛÏTrainwreck,‰Ûù he creates a roomy, comfortable vehicle stuffed with second bananas (both professional zanies and guest-starring squares), who support Ms. Schumer as she tosses out jokes, pops her eyes, deploys her deadpan and shows off her gift for old-school physical high jinks, often in heels and minis.

Amy wiggles through that embarrassment, as she does repeatedly. That could be seen as having your cake and eating it too, but mostly it adds another ding to an often ridiculous, imperfect, recognizable character. (This is, after all, a woman who, when she cuts back on her drinking, donates her booze to a derelict played by Dave Attell.) At times in some of her bits, Ms. Schumer has, like other comics, used fakey apologies as get-out-of- jail cards, as a way to both toss out insults and smilingly refuse responsibility for them. In ‰ÛÏTrainwreck,‰Ûù as in her best work elsewhere, Ms. Schumer is at her strongest when she insists that women aren‰Ûªt distressed damsels but ‰ÛÓ as they toddle, walk and race in the highest of heels, the tightest of skirts, the sexiest, mightiest of poses ‰ÛÓ the absolute agents of their lives and desires.

Ms. Schumer doesn‰Ûªt worry too hard about what Amy wants and why, preferring to go with the story flow and use the passage from swinging singleton to cuddling coupledom to cover the joke spectrum, from the comedy of erections to the trouble with spooning. The postcoital nuzzling bit echoes some laughs that the standup comic Elayne Boosler generated about men, women and intimacy (‰ÛÏI think you should make love and go to your corners‰Ûù) in her landmark, self-financed 1985 comedy special, ‰ÛÏParty of One.‰Ûù A pioneering figure in the 1970s New York standup scene, Ms. Boosler is one of those female pop-cultural warriors (like Clara Bow, Mae West, BeyoncÌ©, etc.) who insist on claiming their sexuality as, you know, their own.

It‰Ûªs gratifying to see Mr. Apatow, who in recent years has worked with the likes of Kristen Wiig and Lena Dunham, continue to put his show-business power to good by joining forces with a smart woman. For too long, the bromances (a subgenre that he popularized) and its corollary, the wedding comedy, have segregated heterosexual men and women into seemingly irreconcilable camps. After ‰ÛÏBridesmaids‰Ûù blew up, my colleague A. O. Scott astutely suggested that perhaps what it revealed wasn‰Ûªt that women can be funny but that, as he wrote, ‰ÛÏmen and women can‰Ûªt be funny at the same time, or direct their humor at one another.‰Ûù Similarly to Ms. Dunham, who in her show ‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù brilliantly grapples with what heterosexual romance means today, Ms. Schumer may be helping change that dynamic.

Amy Schumer is my kind of superhero ‰ÛÓ she stops haters dead. As fans of her Comedy Central show, ‰ÛÏInside Amy Schumer,‰Ûù know, there‰Ûªs almost nothing that anyone can say about women, her included, that she hasn‰Ûªt already said herself. Her powers of deflection are the perfect approach in a neofeminist moment in which women are calling out sexists, sometimes against vicious pushback. Think that she‰Ûªs not thin enough or pretty enough? She intercepts hateful slurs like those and turns them into ferocious comedy gold that exposes chauvinism as the absurdity it is. She can‰Ûªt be stereotyped away as a sourpuss who just needs to chill out, lie back and smile. She‰Ûªs already smiling, and she‰Ûªs killing it, joke after joke.
‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Dirty minds and jokes.

As with any young talent, she has a way to go, including as a screenwriter. ‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù has groaners and dead spots (including a dreary art-film parody with Daniel Radcliffe and Marisa Tomei), and its jokes about race don‰Ûªt have the penetrating wit that her material on sex and gender does. Like a lot of white people, Ms. Schumer can fumble when latching onto race; unlike a lot of white performers, she takes on race directly. The looming appearance of LeBron James, who plays himself as well as Aaron‰Ûªs odd-couple-like best friend, may be a heat-seeking gimmick (he‰Ûªs the movie‰Ûªs biggest star), but he‰Ûªs a surprisingly limber comic presence and he helps set up a sharp scene in which Aaron challenges Amy‰Ûªs bumblingly false claim about having black friends.

Mr. Allen‰Ûªs habit of not giving his performers much direction means that they sometimes end up fending for themselves, which can create an almost unintentional Brechtian alienation effect as they struggle to get a hold on their characters. At times, Mr. Phoenix doesn‰Ûªt seem to be grappling; he seems disengaged, as if he ‰ÛÓ rather than Abe ‰ÛÓ were estranged from what‰Ûªs happening around him. That‰Ûªs especially true in his scenes with Emma Stone, who plays Jill, an eager A student who‰Ûªs attracted to Abe because that‰Ûªs how she was written. Much of the time Ms. Stone, who leads with a smile that dims, seems to be trying to coax a reaction out of Mr. Phoenix. That gives the movie an uneasy edge, as does Parker Posey‰Ûªs turn as Rita, a sexed-up clichÌ©.

The story turns on chance and its absence and starts humming when, after eavesdropping on a dramatic conversation in a diner, Abe decides to commit a crime in the name of a greater good. Armed with poison and some spurious reasoning, he does the deed and finds himself rejuvenated creatively, spiritually, sexually: It makes him tumescent. Mr. Allen plays this notion for some weak laughs; better is the powerful close-up of Abe‰Ûªs face after the crime ‰ÛÓ his unfocused eyes staring ahead and ringed in violent red ‰ÛÓ that suggests the frenzied madness of the void. It‰Ûªs startling and unsettling for what it conveys about Abe and because unlike in ‰ÛÏCrimes and Misdemeanors,‰Ûù in which a rabbi responds to another void by plaintively invoking a ‰ÛÏmoral structure,‰Ûù there‰Ûªs no real argument being advanced here.

The faces in those movies change as do their budgets and all the contingent rest ‰ÛÓ the support staff, locations, costumes and so forth, even as the preoccupations remain much the same. In ‰ÛÏIrrational Man,‰Ûù the usual resident Allen philosopher is an actual philosopher, Abe Lucas, a newly arrived East Coast college professor whom Joaquin Phoenix makes equal parts attraction and repulsion. A soulful presence, Mr. Phoenix excels at playing characters who often struggle to express themselves one tormented or comically inarticulate word at a time. Here, though consistently watchable, he often seems ready to flee the scene, perhaps because his character is so uneasy or because Mr. Allen hasn‰Ûªt given Mr. Phoenix enough material to turn Abe into a thinker who can persuasively cite Heidegger.
‰ÛÏIrrational Man‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence most foul.

The exchange is in keeping with Mr. Allen‰Ûªs oft-repeated insistence, on-screen and off, that life is meaningless, which may be true even if he seems feverishly bent on refuting it with his prodigious cinematic output. If you‰Ûªve seen any of that yield, you have seen a version of ‰ÛÏIrrational Man.‰Ûù As tends to be the case with his work, this new light and dark film looks, sounds and plays a lot like some of his previous titles. That isn‰Ûªt a dig. One of the givens of Mr. Allen‰Ûªs screen work and sometimes its attractions is how each new film registers as another chapter in a project that, in its scale and scope, and in the way in which it seems to speak to his personal life, has come to resemble a weird metafiction. In his short story ‰ÛÏThe Book of Sand,‰Ûù Jorge Luis Borges creates ‰ÛÏan infinite book‰Ûù without beginning or end, which is another way of describing how it can feel when considering the entirety of Mr. Allen‰Ûªs films.

In Woody Allen‰Ûªs 1987 drama ‰ÛÏSeptember,‰Ûù a writer and a physicist walk into a room (well, really, they‰Ûªre playing pool) when the writer asks the physicist, ‰ÛÏIs there anything more terrifying than the destruction of the world?‰Ûù The physicist, sunk deep in gloomy shadow, answers, ‰ÛÏYeah, the knowledge that it doesn‰Ûªt matter one way or the other ‰ÛÓ that it‰Ûªs all random, radiating aimlessly out of nothing and eventually vanishing forever.‰Ûù The physicist says that he‰Ûªs not talking about the world. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm talking about the universe,‰Ûù adding, ‰ÛÏall space, all time, just a temporary convulsion.‰Ûù

The thinly written Jill is certainly no match for, or answer to, Abe, who in putting (distorting) some of his philosophical beliefs to criminal ends evokes Leopold and Loeb, 1920s ‰ÛÏthrill killers‰Ûù who misread Nietzsche. The horror of where rationalism can lead (the death camps, for one) hangs over ‰ÛÏIrrational Man‰Ûù and helps hold you as does Mr. Phoenix, even with some bad writing and Mr. Allen‰Ûªs narrative laxity and lack of interest in how real people live. At one point, he includes a fairground scene, perhaps to evoke Alfred Hitchcock‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStrangers on a Train‰Ûù and its mad, murderous theorist. It makes for a nice shiver by proxy in a film that goes dark without going deep and keeps you wondering just how personal the title ‰ÛÏIrrational Man‰Ûù is or if it‰Ûªs more of an existential shrug.

Craig‰Ûªs fear of commitment manifests itself in an odd way. He decides to take a tour of the South (something that requires lying to his girlfriend) and visit an assortment of ‰ÛÏlargest‰Ûù attractions. The world‰Ûªs largest rocking chair. The world‰Ûªs largest cedar bucket. The world‰Ûªs largest frying pan.

‰ÛÏBig Significant Things‰Ûù is a cute idea in search of substance. This wan film, a first feature by Bryan Reisberg, gives us Craig (Harry Lloyd), a young man who is on the verge of taking the next step with his longtime girlfriend. No, not that next step ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªre about to buy a house.

Along the way, he has numerous telephone conversations with his girlfriend, a device that never makes for very lively cinema. He also meets a few local residents, has a flirtation with another woman and, well, that‰Ûªs about it. The humor here is thin, and Craig‰Ûªs small epiphanies along the way don‰Ûªt amount to much. They‰Ûªre the kinds of not very insightful insights common among first-time filmmakers still learning that there‰Ûªs more to storytelling than a quirky premise.

And the film crosses its metaphorical wires: The creature, a tree dweller, is fighting encroaching overdevelopment on its habitat (attacking those who don‰Ûªt ‰ÛÏrespect the land,‰Ûù says a part-Shawnee bartender). But later it attacks huddled citizens seeking refuge in a church, as if to assault their faith. An ecologically minded demon that‰Ûªs some kind of godless instrument of the Devil? Even in a horror movie, that‰Ûªs hard to believe.

There‰Ûªs certainly talent in Jack Heller‰Ûªs fright film ‰ÛÏDark Was the Night,‰Ûù beginning with its cast. The busy TV actor Kevin Durand (‰ÛÏThe Strain‰Ûù on FX, ‰ÛÏVikings‰Ûù on History) ‰ÛÓ here playing a small-town New York sheriff contending with a supernatural monster of Native American legend ‰ÛÓ conveys tender sorrow and steely resolve with understated dexterity.

The trouble lies in Tyler Hisel‰Ûªs script, which teems with wheezy conventions (as its title suggests): Durand and Kajlich‰Ûªs characters lost a child in an accident for which the sheriff blames himself; Haas‰Ûªs character has moved to the country from the big city after his own personal tragedy; and Durand must win over townspeople skeptical of his ability to thwart the entity terrorizing them.
The seasoned actor Lukas Haas, as his deputy, has an easy, wide-eyed naturalism, while Bianca Kajlich (from ‰ÛÏUndateable‰Ûù on NBC) has an earthy dignity as Durand‰Ûªs estranged wife.
The film‰Ûªs cinematographer, Ryan Samul, employing a cool, desaturated palette, manages to transform upscale Southampton, N.Y., into a wintry and remote upstate hamlet.

Slow and steady, and with remarkable assuredness, Keith Miller‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFive Star‰Ûù plays mean-streets drama in the lowest of keys. Relying on neither raised voices nor cocked weapons ‰ÛÓ although both appear sparingly ‰ÛÓ this documentary-fiction hybrid observes gang culture with a calm eye and a clear head.

‰ÛÏI did not raise you to be a player,‰Ûù John‰Ûªs watchful mother (Wanda Nobles Colon) admonishes, advising fidelity to his sweetheart (Jasmin Burgos) and his minimum-wage job. But mothers are not the point here: ‰ÛÏFive Star‰Ûù is about being a father and mourning the absence of one. Mixing professional and nonprofessional actors with naturalistic street sounds, Mr. Miller draws less on hard-guy hierarchies than on the softness that threatens their power. In this volatile place, the past has a long reach, and the future defies contemplation.

Both attributes belong to Primo (James Grant, playing a dramatized version of himself), a so-called five-star general whose Brooklyn fief straddles gang boundaries. Bald and bearded, solid and solemn, Mr. Grant is a natural performer whose mournful gravitas grounds the ghost of a plot. His opening monologue, in which Primo laments the prison term that kept him from witnessing the birth of his son, has a quiet intensity that no amount of acting tuition could improve.

While raising four rambunctious children and working as a bouncer in a neighborhood bar, Primo takes John (John Diaz), a nervy teenager, under his tattooed wing. Before taking a bullet to the head, John‰Ûªs father had been Primo‰Ûªs highly respected mentor, and now John wants an introduction to the drug business that‰Ûªs humming softly in the film‰Ûªs background.

Clair and Isolda join forces with the commune‰Ûªs bewhiskered old-timers, who hang out in the local bar, jawing in their Down East accents. They may not look like heroes, but they are the good guys here. On the dark side are the owner of a junkyard empire, Cyrus Gast (William Sadler), and his dozen or so thuggish progeny.

There is another bright spot: a big brawl that begins at a Gast barbecue when Isolda reveals who set the commune fire. As that exposition unspools, one Gast son (unwittingly tripping on LSD, courtesy of the old-timers) worships a blade of grass at close range, while Clair sets fires of her own with purloined lighter fluid.

There, Clair meets the most significant player, Frank (Andy Comeau), a gentle man with schizophrenia and psychic abilities (or delusions thereof) ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏBoo Radley in the barn,‰Ûù Isolda calls him ‰ÛÓ who proves to be a missing piece in her personal puzzle. Complex and possessed of an otherworldly serenity, Frank gets too little screen time; developing his character further might have redeemed this movie.
The indecipherable motivations and half-baked subtexts present formidable challenges to the cast and the audience. Thank heaven for the one-liners.

It turns out that a few relatives remain. Among them is the disheveled, gruff and whiskey-toting Cousin Alice (Wendy Vanden Heuvel) ‰ÛÓ who, to quote Isolda, ‰ÛÏputs the noir back in pinot‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ who grudgingly lets them stay at the farm, which is about to be foreclosed.

But now, newly divorced and drained by anxiety attacks, Clair (Rachel Miner) returns, dragged by her bestie, Isolda (Shamika Cotton) on a fact-finding adventure into her past. Their quest anchors (just barely) this overreaching, scattered melodrama.
Clair Defina has few memories of her first six years, spent at the Maine commune where she was born. When her mother died in a fire there, her father whisked her away.

His austere style, which favors long takes, minimal lighting and settings that don‰Ûªt announce their locations, has divided critics. But even for those fascinated by the Fontainhas project, Mr. Costa‰Ûªs new film makes for demanding, often baffling viewing.

Its fragmented episodes are based on the experiences of Ventura, the protagonist of ‰ÛÏColossal Youth,‰Ûù who again plays a version of himself. If that earlier film, set in a memory-haunted shantytown, was already a sort of ghost story, ‰ÛÏHorse Money‰Ûù dips further into the cinema of the fantastic. (It is certainly the only Costa film that pauses for a long musical interlude.)

When a doctor asks Ventura for his age, this disoriented protagonist, who is perhaps 60, says he is 19 ‰ÛÓ repeating a lie from his youth ‰ÛÓ and gives the date as March 11, 1975, the day of a failed military coup in the aftermath of Portugal‰Ûªs Carnation Revolution. At around this time, Ventura was involved in a fateful knife fight.

Pedro Costa, the Portuguese director of ‰ÛÏHorse Money,‰Ûù is one of a handful of filmmakers who could claim to have invented their own approaches to narrative. Beginning with ‰ÛÏOssos‰Ûù (‰ÛÏBones‰Ûù) in 1997, he made a trilogy of films set in the Lisbon slum of Fontainhas, an enclave of Cape Verdean immigrants that has since been razed. In the subsequent ‰ÛÏIn Vanda‰Ûªs Room‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏColossal Youth,‰Ûù Mr. Costa veered away from pure fiction and allowed Fontainhas residents to shape their dialogue and scenes. Drawn from real-life details though hardly documentaries, Mr. Costa‰Ûªs movies unfold through monologues and tableaux, finding poetry and myth in the lives of the marginalized.

Audiences unfamiliar with Mr. Costa are likely to find the experience incomprehensible, but ‰ÛÏHorse Money‰Ûù offers a challenge worth meeting for viewers prepared to give it patience. The puzzle-box narrative only grows more hypnotic with repeat viewings. The movie insists on having the audience, like Ventura, pass through madness to reach catharsis.

Mr. Costa‰Ûªs high-contrast compositions only heighten the ghostly atmosphere; the barely lit hospital might as well be operating on emergency power. The actors are often positioned against squarish pools of light that resemble film projections. Nothing can be taken at face value: The chronology is slippery. When Ventura is trapped in an elevator with a soldier, the dialogue doesn‰Ûªt match the visuals.

In a sense, it is an old-fashioned Freudian loony-bin tale in which a hero grapples with repressed guilt. As the film opens, Ventura descends into what appears to be a dungeon, only to wind up in a hospital where he is greeted by comrades from his past. These (likely) phantoms include Vitalina, a Cape Verdean who has traveled to Portugal for the funeral of her husband, a man who Ventura says is still alive. (The men‰Ûªs ability to provide for their families figures heavily in the elliptical narrative.)

‰ÛÏPixels‰Ûù is a special-effects eyeful burdened by the fact that it is also yet another film in which Adam Sandler plays a man-child who somehow turns the head of an attractive woman. In this one, his character, Brenner, was an arcade superstar as a child but grew up to be a schlump. His old skills prove useful when extraterrestrials who misunderstood a message sent into space during Ronald Reagan‰Ûªs administration attack Earth with giant Pac-Men, Centipedes and such.

Poor Washington is having a bad summer. The city was destroyed on television Wednesday night in Syfy‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSharknado 3: Oh Hell No!,‰Ûù and it takes a beating again in theaters with Friday‰Ûªs release of ‰ÛÏPixels,‰Ûù in which it is attacked by giant versions of 1980s video-game characters. Expect some of those many presidential candidates to begin dropping out of the race this weekend.
‰ÛÏPixels‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) though it needn‰Ûªt have been; it‰Ûªs harmless.

The special effects are pretty cool, but the film is working nostalgia already thoroughly mined in movies (including the video-game-themed ‰ÛÏWreck-It Ralph‰Ûù) and television (‰ÛÏThe Goldbergs‰Ûù and such). So it‰Ûªs not as original as it wants to be, despite having the able Chris Columbus in the director‰Ûªs chair. When the story shifts to New York for the climactic battle, the unlikely saviors might call to mind the ‰ÛÏGhostbusters‰Ûù gang ‰ÛÓ another 1980s reference ‰ÛÓ and make you wish the film had the wry freshness the original installment of that franchise did.

Josh Gad, Kevin James and ‰ÛÓ if you can‰Ûªt get a ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù actor these days, don‰Ûªt bother making your movie ‰ÛÓ Peter Dinklage play his comrades in arms. Michelle Monaghan is a lieutenant colonel who, besides helping to fend off the attack, has to gradually find Brenner appealing.
‰ÛÏSouthpaw‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood in the ring and out, and a lot of swearing.

The same goes for Mr. Gyllenhaal, whose recent performances have been both impressive and more than a little mannered ‰ÛÓ bouts of showy extremism. In ‰ÛÏSouthpaw,‰Ûù his mumbling seems as studious as his fastidious enunciation in ‰ÛÏNightcrawler.‰Ûù His physicality feels more natural than his diction, though. Watching Billy train for a fight or struggle to stand up straight the next day, you believe you are witnessing the discipline and agony of a real boxer.

Not that Billy has much privilege to check, racial or otherwise. We first encounter him defending his title with a late-round knockout at Madison Square Garden, which an announcer notes is a few blocks (and also ‰ÛÏa million miles‰Ûù) from the Hell‰Ûªs Kitchen orphanage where the champ grew up. His wife, Maureen (Rachel McAdams), is also a product of the foster-care system, and they‰Ûªve gone to great lengths to ensure that their beloved 10-year-old daughter, Leila (Oona Laurence), is protected from the kind of life they knew. Billy throws the punches, and Maureen, as he puts it, ‰ÛÏmakes all the plans.‰Ûù

If Antoine Fuqua‰Ûªs new film, ‰ÛÏSouthpaw,‰Ûù were a boxer, if would be a lot like its hero, a light heavyweight named Billy Hope. Played with downcast eyes and rock-hard abs by Jake Gyllenhaal, Billy is a bleeder and a brawler, an earnest, inarticulate guy with a ferocious punch and not much in the way of grace. In case his last name isn‰Ûªt a broad enough hint, you might take a moment to read his tattoos. ‰ÛÏFighter‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏFather‰Ûù are scrawled along his sinewy forearms. His back says ‰ÛÏFear No Man.‰Ûù Only ironically, and late in the game, do the words ‰ÛÏGreat White‰Ûù precede his name.

It wouldn‰Ûªt be a fight picture without a ruthless businessman, a gruff coach or a suffering wife. And this wouldn‰Ûªt be a review of a boxing picture without a few clichÌ©s of its own. I wish I could say ‰ÛÏSouthpaw‰Ûù was a knockout, or even a contender, that it went the distance or scored on points. But it‰Ûªs strictly an undercard bout, displaying enough heart and skill to keep the paying customers from getting too restless.

There isn‰Ûªt really much more you need to know. The plotting is somehow both flat-footed and operatic in its absurdity. Character arcs are tangled, flattened and foreshortened.
