Common sense is knocked silly. But Mr. Fuqua has never been a director to let ridiculousness get in the way of visceral action. With a new Eminem song tucked into one of the montages, an old-style melodramatic score by James Horner (one of his last, sadly; he died in June and the film is dedicated to his memory) and plenty of muscular brawling, ‰ÛÏSouthpaw‰Ûù is effective without being terribly convincing.

But you can‰Ûªt plan for every twist of fate. Unless you‰Ûªre a screenwriter, of course, and the author of the ‰ÛÏSouthpaw‰Ûù script, Kurt Sutter, torques this baby until it screams. A loudmouth challenger (Miguel Gomez) taunts Billy at a charity event. Words are exchanged, fists fly, and a gunshot robs Billy of everything he has. He loses his wife, his mansion, his cars, his title and custody of Leila, who is placed in child-services limbo under the eye of a social worker played by Naomie Harris. Abandoned by his manager (Curtis Jackson, better known as 50 Cent), Billy sets out to take back what he can. He walks into a scruffy New York gym and finds a battered, philosophical trainer named Willis with the melancholy mien of Forest Whitaker.

Connoisseurs of boxing sometimes wax eloquent on the nuances of the sport, but boxing movies tend to value impact over finesse. Few genres are so reliably and bluntly conventional. Primal stories ‰ÛÓ rise and fall, ruin and redemption, the love of a good woman ‰ÛÓ are punctuated by scenes of carefully choreographed pugilism. Violence and sentimentality dance in the ring, and the audience leaves satisfied, if not exactly surprised.

And you‰Ûªre definitely watching a real boxing movie, which is of course not the same as a movie about the reality of the sport (despite participation by the former multiweight champion Roy Jones Jr., who plays himself). Even biopics about practitioners of the sweet science (‰ÛÏRaging Bull‰Ûù partly excepted) have a habit of preferring formula to verisimilitude, but while ‰ÛÏSouthpaw‰Ûù sings a familiar tune, it features some pretty appealing players. There are worse things to see at the multiplex than Ms. McAdams playing a tough cookie standing by her man, or Mr. Whitaker speaking hard truths over a glass of whiskey or a battered Bible, or 50 Cent smiling sharkishly in a beautiful suit.

Angela goes from sunny to malevolent through freak events that leave her in a coma, which proves temporary. People are hurt around her; her military-man dad (Dougray Scott) and boyfriend (John Patrick Amedori) fret; ravens keep turning up. Moving to a psychiatric hospital only brings on more violence (and mind-reading skills). When she‰Ûªs sent home, a Vatican cardinal (Peter Andersson) arrives to perform an exorcism; she could be the Antichrist, and the church keeps an eye out for that sort of thing.

The tapes of the title seem to fulfill some universal contractual obligation to feature found footage in horror movies, but the ending at least is gratifyingly grandiose. What helps most is having an actress who knows how to say those four little words: You all will die. NICOLAS RAPOLD
THE VATICAN TAPES
1 hour 28 minutes

Evil often takes the same tired forms in horror movies, but in ‰ÛÏThe Vatican Tapes‰Ûù it shines ‰ÛÓ and glowers and shrieks ‰ÛÓ when it takes the form of Angela (Olivia Taylor Dudley), a suitable candidate for exorcism. In the routine role, Ms. Dudley works up an expressive arsenal of gestural detail and shades of mood that are worth watching amid the film‰Ûªs rigmarole of satanic possession.
Opens on Friday
Directed by Mark Neveldine

The director Mark Neveldine deploys queasy lighting and a trembling score, but his best choice is to let Ms. Dudley stare at us. She conveys unnerving shifts in self-awareness and sinister intent with her eyes. Her flick of an eyebrow or odd change in posture is more gripping than the film‰Ûªs usual scare tactics.
‰ÛÏThe Vatican Tapes‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Terrible houseguest behavior and some sexual references.

‰ÛÏåÊ‰Û÷Lucky Stiff‰Ûª is the work of writers who, with seasoning and much tougher editing and direction, might give their generation its own ‰Û÷Bells Are Ringing‰Ûª or ‰Û÷Pajama Game,‰ÛªåÊ‰Ûù the critic Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times in 1988 about a new musical that had opened Off Broadway at Playwrights Horizons.

The writers he was talking about were a pair of newcomers, Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty, and the words proved prophetic ‰ÛÓ they would soon be writing shows like ‰ÛÏRagtime‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏOnce on This Island.‰Ûù So although ‰ÛÏLucky Stiff‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt performed much these days, and even if it still isn‰Ûªt much of a musical, a new film version of it holds some historical interest.

Nikki M. James, a Tony winner, plays a representative of an animal shelter who scrutinizes Harry‰Ûªs every move, hoping he will fail to follow the terms of the will, which would cause the inheritance to go, as it were, to the dogs. Pamela Shaw and Jason Alexander (another Tony winner) ham it up as a sister and brother who also have designs on the big payday.

It is, in short, an old-style farce, and the film version accentuates that with dashes of animation reminiscent of the ‰ÛÏPink Panther‰Ûù movies. With songs about shoes and dogs, ‰ÛÏLucky Stiff‰Ûù couldn‰Ûªt be sillier, but Mr. Marsh and especially Ms. James make it an enjoyable curiosity for fans of musical theater.

It‰Ûªs the utterly inconsequential story of Harry Witherspoon (Dominic Marsh), a shoe salesman who receives word that an uncle he has never met has died and left him a substantial inheritance. He can claim it by fulfilling the rather odd terms of the uncle‰Ûªs will, which specifies that Harry take the corpse on a tour of Monte Carlo.

It‰Ûªs a familiar story insipidly told on screen. Comparing movies with their literary sources isn‰Ûªt always useful, but it‰Ûªs instructive that while the book validates Q‰Ûªs ordinariness, the movie tries to obscure it. Q isn‰Ûªt one of literature‰Ûªs young rebels, riding the Mississippi like Huckleberry Finn or denouncing phonies ÌÊ la Holden Caulfield. Q‰Ûªs parents are nice, his friends are nice, he‰Ûªs nice. The only significant character who isn‰Ûªt immediately ‰ÛÏrelatable‰Ûù (a noxious industry mantra and the most damaging word in American cinema) is Margo, a prickly, complex object of desire who rejects the world that Q embraces. ‰ÛÏI do believe in college,‰Ûù he quietly assures himself, after Margo goes on a mild anti-establishment harangue. Here, most young people don‰Ûªt howl; they scarcely bleat.

Mr. Wolff puffs up this likable, unsurprising hero with a bit of charm. A practiced scene-stealer, having swiveled heads in earlier films, including ‰ÛÏThe Fault in Our Stars,‰Ûù Mr. Wolff is appealing in ‰ÛÏPaper Towns.‰Ûù But his performance is far too self-confident and knowing, at times almost slick, for a teenage character whose questioning nature and narrative purpose is inscribed in his single-letter nickname. He comes off exactly like the Hollywood up-and-comer he is, and is finally as out of place in this world as Ms. Delevingne is. She‰Ûªs nice on the eyes, no doubt, but she doesn‰Ûªt have the tools to take this underwritten screen role and make it hurt, and you spend a lot of time watching her Groucho brows hold steady over her sunburst smiles.

Teenage angst has been a lucrative movie racket for years, but what happens when the kids are pretty much all right? Not a whole lot, at least in ‰ÛÏPaper Towns,‰Ûù a serenely bland adaptation of the John Green young-adult novel about a regular boy in love with the mystery girl next door. Once upon a Hollywood time, when American adolescents were in the grip of social mores and studio censorship, nice guys wooed nice gals with boyish smiles, well-behaved hands and tamped-down desires. What‰Ûªs old is new again in ‰ÛÏPaper Towns,‰Ûù a melodrama in which smiles still tremble, hands largely behave and freedom‰Ûªs just another word for everything an ordinary boy doesn‰Ûªt want to lose.
‰ÛÏPaper Towns‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). PG-13 teenagers.

Directed by Jake Schreier from a script by Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber, who also adapted Mr. Green‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Fault in Our Stars,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏPaper Towns‰Ûù tracks Q as he sets off on one of those classically entwined excursions that take him out into the world and inside his being. It‰Ûªs a passage that starts in childhood, when Margo and Q find a dead body (she creeps toward it while he recoils), and lurches forward in adolescence after Margo vanishes, leaving what look like clues in her wake. Seeing Margo as an idea and ideal (and himself as a savior), Q seizes on the clues ‰ÛÓ scattered in books of poetry and in more prosaic locations ‰ÛÓ in a search of a woman who leads him straight to, as is often the case, himself.

In the end, what makes Q such a deceptively tricky literary creation ‰ÛÓ his averageness ‰ÛÓ is the very thing the filmmakers struggle with, partly because movies of this commercial scale and bottom-line ambition rarely know what to do with ordinary life. So they pump it up. That struggle is evident in the wall-to-wall pop songs that make it seem as if someone hired a D.J. to get the party going and, in particular, in the almost tic-like overuse of slow motion, a stylistic clichÌ© that, intentionally or not, suggests Q has already begun packaging these moments of modest excitement into memories as they happen. And why not? This is, after all, a story about a boy who idealizes a girl he barely knows and, for a brief time, chases after in his family‰Ûªs minivan. Even the choice of car speaks volumes: Q was born to be mild, and knows it.

The narrator and audience proxy is Quentin Jacobson (Nat Wolff), Q for short, who opens up the story by explaining that he thinks everyone gets a miracle. In his case that would be Margo Roth Spiegelman (the model Cara Delevingne), one of those women ‰ÛÓ guide, muse or free spirit, she comes in flavors as varied as Pocahontas, Zelda and Tinker Bell ‰ÛÓ who aid men on their journeys, metaphysical and literal. Q and Margo meet when they‰Ûªre children, and while she doesn‰Ûªt seem all that impressed, he‰Ûªs smitten. Years later, after they‰Ûªve grown apart and are on the verge of graduating from high school, Q remains under Margo‰Ûªs spell and she‰Ûªs actually noticed him again.

Mr. Petzold is not the kind of director to indulge in showy homages, but his films are nonetheless steeped in the cinematic styles and genres of the past. ‰ÛÏJerichow‰Ûù was a reimagining of ‰ÛÏThe Postman Always Rings Twice.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBarbara,‰Ûù set in East Germany in the 1980s, was a suspenseful romantic melodrama, and in both cases Ms. Hoss evoked the blond hauteur and old-Hollywood heat of Lana Turner. With its themes of suppressed desire and mistaken identity, ‰ÛÏPhoenix‰Ûù has more than a touch of ‰ÛÏVertigo,‰Ûù but instead of Hitchcockian psychological puzzles, it explores unsolvable and perhaps unspeakable moral conundrums.

In Christian Petzold‰Ûªs new film, Phoenix is the name of a Berlin nightclub where Nelly Lenz goes searching for her husband, a piano player she calls Johnny. World War II has just ended, which suggests that ‰ÛÏPhoenix,‰Ûù the title of this compact, haunting thriller, might have other, larger, metaphorical meanings as well. In a few years, Germany will ascend from the ruin of military defeat into an era of political stability and economic growth. Nelly, a Jewish singer who survived the Nazi death camps, is undergoing her own tentative rebirth ‰ÛÓ her face has been reconstructed after it was damaged by a gunshot wound ‰ÛÓ and her friend Lene (Nina Kunzendorf) encourages her to prepare for a new life in Tel Aviv.
‰ÛÏPhoenix‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Horrible memories.

But Mr. Petzold, a fixture of the Berlin School of historically informed, emotionally challenging realist filmmakers, is more interested in the ashes of the past than the bright plumage of the future. He gravitates toward ethical shadows and ambiguous states of feeling, using film noir techniques as a tool kit for probing dark regions of German history. Nina Hoss, who plays Nelly, has, since 2007, starred in four of this director‰Ûªs features ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏYella,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏJerichow,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBarbara‰Ûù and now this one ‰ÛÓ and seems to function for him as a combination of muse, alter ego and personified sensibility. Quietly charismatic, able to flicker from steeliness to desperation with an eye movement or a hand gesture, Ms. Hoss embodies Mr. Petzold‰Ûªs fluctuating idea of postwar Germany itself: vain, guilty, vulnerable, confused.

Nelly, a victim and survivor of her country‰Ûªs worst era, suffers from an especially acute form of confusion. She is desperate to find Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld), even though ‰ÛÓ as we and Lene discover before Nelly does ‰ÛÓ he divorced her during the war and denounced her to the Gestapo. When she does run into him, he insists on being called Johannes and doesn‰Ûªt recognize her, thanks to the plastic surgery and also, perhaps, to his own guilty conscience.

Or at least it tries. Never less than intriguing, coolly intelligent and flawlessly paced, ‰ÛÏPhoenix‰Ûù often feels trapped in the logic of its conceit. Neither the full horror nor the absurdity of Nelly‰Ûªs situation registers, partly because the self-conscious genre touches keep her story at a distance. Mr. Petzold has made a suave and suspenseful entertainment that doesn‰Ûªt seem entirely sure that it wants to be ‰ÛÓ or is able to be ‰ÛÓ more. It comes closest at the very end, in a final scene that infuses an old popular song with the full weight of cruelty, betrayal and hope.

But he does decide that Nelly, who calls herself Eva in his presence, is a close enough match to impersonate his dead former wife. He is eager to get his hands on her estate, which is being held by Allied authorities, and he rehearses Eva in an elaborate and dismaying ruse. They will stage a reunion for the benefit of their old friends, collect the cash, split it and go their separate ways. It‰Ûªs hardly the worst or the strangest scam to be contemplated in the chaos of a defeated, occupied city. Nelly agrees to Johnny‰Ûªs plan, and it‰Ûªs hard to tell whether she is passively going along with it out of love, longing and denial or pursuing a hidden agenda of her own.

Directed by the team behind the hit French odd-couple comedy ‰ÛÏThe Intouchables,‰Ûù the breezy ‰ÛÏSamba‰Ûù centers on a Senegalese immigrant (Omar Sy) and his caseworker (Charlotte Gainsbourg). Hovering between the insider and outsider perspectives the two characters represent, the filmmakers Eric Toledano and Olivier Nakache deliver a mostly buoyant take on the immigration travails that preoccupy France today (and more and more of its movies).

That might sound like a glib evaluation, but the filmmakers are shameless in leavening Samba‰Ûªs woes with blushing scenes between him and Alice, who seems instantly mesmerized. Around them buzzes a small circle of side characters ‰ÛÓ Samba‰Ûªs boisterous friend (Tahar Rahim) and pessimistic uncle, and the kibitzing staff members at the immigration center, who seem to be descended from a 1930s Hollywood comedy set in New York.

Mr. Toledano and Mr. Nakache, who wrote the scattered screenplay, have a well-honed touch for comic beats and a feel for workaday details. That comes in handy when their points about French identity miss the mark, or when the main characters share special moments without really acquiring depth. Most of all, it‰Ûªs a film that feels like a mild pressure-valve release.
‰ÛÏSamba‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for the verbal frustration borne of bureaucracy.

Mr. Sy‰Ûªs tenacious but somewhat opaque Samba plays out the absurdities of hard-working residents who don‰Ûªt have the right papers. And in Ms. Gainsbourg‰Ûªs clueless Alice, a corporate drone taking a stress-related sabbatical by working at an immigration center, Mr. Toledano and Mr. Nakache provide an entry point for viewers who sympathize with the plight of migrants, or harbor crushes on them.

Tucker (1887-1966) was used to hobnobbing with all kinds of royalty ‰ÛÓ gangster, European, show business. She palled around with Helen Keller ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏShe was a darling and full of fun,‰Ûù Tucker wrote ‰ÛÓ and knew Lucille LeSueur before she became Joan Crawford. The names fly fast in Tucker‰Ûªs memoir, ‰ÛÏSome of These Days‰Ûù (1945), which was also the title of her signature song. That song‰Ûªs history, like Tucker‰Ûªs, is a quintessentially American story, having been written by Shelton Brooks, a black Canadian who took it to Tucker‰Ûªs longtime maid, a black American, Mollie Elkins (a former performer). Tucker, a Jewish immigrant from Russia born during her family‰Ûªs journey to the United States, first recorded ‰ÛÏSome of These Days‰Ûù in 1911 and then again in the 1920s with Ted Lewis.

Her thunderous instrument ‰ÛÓ along with Tucker‰Ûªs exploits, loves, towering hats, bejeweled gowns and sense of theater ‰ÛÓ lifts the documentary, with the support of interviewees like Tony Bennett, Carol Channing and Barbara Walters, whose father, Lou Walters, owned a string of nightclubs. Some of these interviews look pretty shabby, and Mr. Gazecki gives far too much screen time to the Tucker specialists Lloyd and Susan Ecker, who produced this movie. There‰Ûªs some weird animation, too, and little about Tucker‰Ûªs union work, but Michael Feinstein is on hand to put her in context as a white woman singing music largely associated with black performers. Mr. Bennett calls Tucker one of jazz‰Ûªs great singers, but she was also singing the Jewish blues.

If you close your eyes and randomly select a page from the autobiography of the singer Sophie Tucker, you may well end up reading a throwaway anecdote like this: ‰ÛÏQueen Marie of Romania came to Chicago during our run there. We all hoped she would come to see the show, and an invitation was sent to Her Majesty. But she sent a gracious letter of apology, and we had to be content that night with Al Capone and a party of 20.‰Ûù Flip a few more pages, and there‰Ûªs this: ‰ÛÏWill I ever forget the hamburger dinner I cooked for Fanny Brice and Aunt Jemima!‰Ûù

Nowadays, Tucker may be best remembered by fans of Bette Midler, who channeled the early, bawdy days of jazz greats like Tucker with a character called Soph. Viewers of the HBO show ‰ÛÏBoardwalk Empire‰Ûù may also recall the brassy singer (played by Kathy Brier) who uses some of the same comically smutty patter. It would be nice if William Gazecki‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏThe Outrageous Sophie Tucker‰Ûù helped nudge its subject even further into the limelight, where she belongs. The movie isn‰Ûªt especially well made, yet because Tucker is such a gloriously rich figure ‰ÛÓ immigrant turned runaway mother turned vaudevillian turned superstar ‰ÛÓ she renders its formal and aesthetic shortcomings (mostly) irrelevant. Sophie Tucker, you learn, didn‰Ûªt only sing ‰ÛÓ she also roared.

You see (and hear) just how loudly in the movie, which tracks her life through interviews, toe-tappers plucked out of the American songbook and images from a treasury of personal and professional artifacts, including hundreds of Tucker‰Ûªs detailed scrapbooks. These are especially valuable because Tucker was born before the movies were, and these two didn‰Ûªt really hit it off, largely, it seems, because Hollywood didn‰Ûªt know what to do with a woman with her looks and powerhouse affect. (Her films include ‰ÛÏBroadway Melody of 1938,‰Ûù in which she‰Ûªs upstaged by a teenage Judy Garland.) You may wish there were more film footage of Tucker, but it‰Ûªs a testament to her charisma that she comes so vibrantly alive both in still photographs and, of course, through the many recordings.

At a crucial moment, Brian can‰Ûªt deal with the looming responsibilities, and he and Leslie endure a long separation. Although the word ‰ÛÏlove‰Ûù is mentioned, it is more theoretical than actual. Padding out the movie are unfortunate, black-and-white fantasy sequences that interrupt its flow.

Leslie is not only pregnant, but pregnant with twins, even though she and Brian used a condom. It happens. Brian, in a state of barely controlled panic, halfheartedly goes through the motions of agreeing to support Leslie‰Ûªs decision to reject an abortion and to remain by her side. The movie is to be commended for using the word ‰ÛÏabortion‰Ûù rather than a euphemism.

Brian, who narrates the story in fits and starts, has all the polish of a jittery junior-high student. His bumbling manner may remind male viewers of their first dates in early adolescence. When he meets Leslie at a student house party she is so drunk on beer that she can hardly walk or talk. Because the good-looking Leslie seems way out of Brian‰Ûªs league, he is all the more anxious when he escorts her home. By the time, hours later, when they have sex, she has considerably sobered up.

Leslie‰Ûªs insistence on keeping the twins because it ‰ÛÏjust feels right‰Ûù will push buttons on both sides of the argument for and against her continuing the pregnancy. You are acutely aware of the consequences either way. Meanwhile, Leslie ‰ÛÏrethinks the whole Christian thing.‰Ûù If Brian and Leslie aren‰Ûªt exactly dislikable, their impulsiveness and difficulty communicating signals hard times ahead no matter what happens.

There are no grand romantic flourishes in ‰ÛÏThe Young Kieslowski,‰Ûù an uncomfortable comedy about an accidental pregnancy that upends the lives of two freshmen at the California Institute of Technology. The title character, Brian Kieslowski (Ryan Malgarini), is a whiny dweeb with wide, frightened eyes who is obsessed with losing his virginity. He is certain that his lack of experience is visible to all. Leslie Mallard (Haley Lu Richardson), whom he accidentally impregnates in his first go at sex, is a self-professed Christian who has sworn to remain chaste until marriage.

This small, observant movie, directed and written by Kerem Sanga, is the better for not going in predictable directions. A story that you half-expect to turn into a melodrama stays true to the sensibilities of its immature, painfully sincere characters, who are faced with life-changing decisions.
‰ÛÏThe Young Kieslowski‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sexuality, brief strong language and drug use.

Both students must cope with controlling parents. Brian‰Ûªs meddlesome mother (Melora Walters), who is being treated for lung cancer, embarrasses him in the opening scene with a haranguing lecture about sex and birth control. Leslie‰Ûªs father (James Le Gros), a best-selling author of military-themed novels, is an angry know-it-all who cuts her off financially when she balks at his insistence that she have an abortion.

Yet the movie‰Ûªs calm levelheadedness is a subtle detriment. Everything is a little too easy. The characters‰Ûª problems and tentative solutions ring true but are a little too pat, and life in Jasmine‰Ûªs high school is a little too orderly and cheerful. ‰ÛÏUnexpected‰Ûù offers the satisfactions of a very good made-for-television movie. For all the unexpectedness endured by the characters, it studiously plays it safe.

Her carefully laid path is threatened when she finds herself pregnant. The couple‰Ûªs initial response is frustration and disappointment. John quickly adjusts to the news, proposes to Sam ‰ÛÓ she accepts ‰ÛÓ and vows, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll float us.‰Ûù

The core of the movie is Sam and Jasmine‰Ûªs relationship. But Sam‰Ûªs attitude of take-charge do-gooder obsessed with solving Jasmine‰Ûªs problems grows grating and conflicts with the realities of Jasmine‰Ûªs precarious situation. Although the movie plays down any underlying racial tension to the extent that race is never even mentioned (Sam is white and Jasmine is black), there is a cultural divide between teacher and student. Sam can‰Ûªt fully grasp the economic gap between her comfortable middle-class existence and Jasmine‰Ûªs struggles in a household rife with dysfunction.
Sam has aggressively mentored Jasmine and is helping her apply for a scholarship at a state university.

At around the same time, Jasmine (Gail Bean), a high school senior who is one of Sam‰Ûªs star students, announces that she is pregnant. The sullen reaction of the father, her boyfriend, Travis (Aaron J. Nelson), prompts Jasmine to break up with him.

There is barely a false note in Kris Swanberg‰Ûªs intelligent, well-mannered drama ‰ÛÏUnexpected,‰Ûù which tells parallel stories of two unforeseen pregnancies. Sam (Cobie Smulders), 30, who teaches science at a crumbling, soon-to-be closed high school in a poor Chicago neighborhood, lives with her boyfriend, John (Anders Holm). With no immediate plans to marry and start a family, she has her heart set on landing a high-powered job at the Field Museum designing a science curriculum for the city school system.

Another player is Sam‰Ûªs high-strung, fluttery mother, Carolyn (Elizabeth McGovern), whose dreams of a big wedding with all the trimmings for her daughter are dashed when Sam and John exchanges vows at City Hall.
‰ÛÏUnexpected‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has strong language.

Jasmine is adamant about keeping her baby, even though the father refuses to be involved. When the realities of transportation, off-campus housing and scholarship support are discussed, the difficulty of Jasmine‰Ûªs situation becomes clear. Sam has much more trouble accepting it than Jasmine, whose view of her situation is more pragmatic than her idealistic teacher‰Ûªs is. The movie‰Ûªs greatest strength is its picture of a generous, good-hearted teacher who is determined to do what she believes is the right thing but who, without realizing it, becomes condescending and controlling. The nuanced performances of Ms. Smulders and Ms. Bean are flawless.
The kid with the potty mouth may cost Warner Bros. some business at the box office, but in a strange way he elevates ‰ÛÏVacation,‰Ûù a very funny R-rated movie with a PG-13 heart.

Strengthening of brotherly and marital bonds is the real agenda, of course, but happily the movie never stays on these laugh-killing themes long. Before an epic fight on a roller coaster wraps things up, Mr. Chase and Beverly D‰ÛªAngelo have wandered through, reprising their roles as the Griswold patriarch and matriarch, grandparents who should be proud of what they have wrought.

Ed Helms and Christina Applegate, who play the couple, are skilled comedy veterans, and Ms. Applegate has what is surely the summer‰Ûªs best vomit scene. But the young actors playing their sons come close to stealing the movie: Skyler Gisondo as James, the older child, and especially Steele Stebbins as Kevin, who curses like a sailor and bullies his much bigger brother. The parents aren‰Ûªt exactly oblivious to Kevin‰Ûªs vileness, but they seem to put it in the same class as, say, not asking to be excused from the table at the end of dinner.
‰ÛÏVacation‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bawdy humor and bawdy language.

Kevin is not entirely responsible for the R rating ‰ÛÓ the movie has sex gags and even a flash or two of nudity ‰ÛÓ but he could have certainly earned it on his own. Some moviegoers might recoil, yet ‰ÛÏVacation‰Ûù would have been drab had it been populated with the same bratty-but-harmless youngsters as every other family movie. Kevin at least has a distinctive personality.

The film is a sort of sequel to ‰ÛÏNational Lampoon‰Ûªs Vacation,‰Ûù the 1983 comedy in which Chevy Chase played Clark Griswold, a father determined to drag his family across the country for a vacation at an amusement park called Walley World. One of those children, Rusty, has grown up and now embarks on the same ill-advised odyssey with his wife and two sons.

In any case, Rusty, after procuring a ridiculous Albanian rental car that steals a few scenes of its own, makes one mistake after another as he blunders toward Walley World with his reluctant family. There is a memorable stop at a hot-springs park where line-jumping lands the Griswolds in the wrong type of hot water, in several senses. And there‰Ûªs a visit to Rusty‰Ûªs sister, Audrey (Leslie Mann), who has also grown up and whose husband (Chris Hemsworth of the ‰ÛÏThor‰Ûù movies) is a weatherman who exudes a dangerous amount of sexiness.

There‰Ûªs not enough of the nonconformist likes of Baldwin in the movie, but then it seems impossible to cram an existence as fully lived as Brando‰Ûªs ‰ÛÓ which reaches from his Nebraska childhood to California, New York, Tahiti and beyond ‰ÛÓ into a few hours. That said, you get a sense of that life because, for a celebrity who became known as a recluse in his later years, Brando played the public relations game for a very long time, as the many interview clips show. Some of these are available online, including a 1955 ‰ÛÏPerson to Person‰Ûù profile by Edward R. Murrow, which was shot soon after Brando won his first Oscar, for ‰ÛÏOn the Waterfront.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a thoughtful interview, as far as these things go, and Brando plays along nicely, even when his abusive father, Marlon Sr., whom he loathed, bigfoots into view.

That‰Ûªs the straight world‰Ûªs take on Brando ‰ÛÓ call it the revenge of the mediocre on genius ‰ÛÓ and one reason it‰Ûªs such a blast to hear the man himself talking about that life in the documentary ‰ÛÏListen to Me Marlon.‰Ûù The movie is almost entirely narrated by Brando, largely through snippets of audio recordings that he made over decades. Although it opens with a bit of text about the recordings, it doesn‰Ûªt explain how the British director Stevan Riley and his collaborators got their hands on them. The press notes state that the recordings were ‰ÛÏuniquely gifted‰Ûù to the production company for the movie; a recent article in The Los Angeles Times suggests a more commercially expedient reason: The actor‰Ûªs estate, Brando Enterprises, ‰ÛÏdecided it was time‰Ûù for a flick to introduce him to a new generation.

While its subject means that ‰ÛÏListen to Me‰Ûù is easy to like, Mr. Riley‰Ûªs shaping of Brando‰Ûªs words can make the movie, every so often, difficult to fully embrace. Mr. Riley‰Ûªs handling of the fatal 1990 shooting of Dag Drollet by Christian Brando, Brando‰Ûªs son, is especially unfortunate, and the use of some tabloidlike news material sleazes up the movie a touch. (Mr. Drollet was the boyfriend of Brando‰Ûªs daughter Cheyenne.) Mr. Riley‰Ûªs use of a disembodied, floating Brando head created from digital scans that the actor made in the 1980s is initially amusing, but it‰Ûªs a needless distraction, as are the cutaways to murkily lit, messily appointed rooms that are actually re-creations of those in his Mulholland Drive mansion.

Whatever the motivations, the movie gives you the opportunity for its loquacious title subject to pour his thoughts into your ears for some 100 babbling minutes. This was a cat who could rap, as his longtime friend and former roommate James Baldwin might have said. The movie is stuffed with boldface names like Baldwin, who (with his pal Norman Mailer) first encountered Brando in Greenwich Village in the mid-1940s. ‰ÛÏI had never met any white man like Marlon,‰Ûù Baldwin later said. ‰ÛÏHe was obviously immensely talented ‰ÛÓ a real creative force ‰ÛÓ and totally unconventional and independent, a beautiful cat.‰Ûù Baldwin said that Brando was ‰ÛÏcontemptuous of anyone who discriminated in any way,‰Ûù adding that the actor, a professional seducer, made him feel that ‰ÛÏreports I was ugly had been much exaggerated.‰Ûù

Brando doesn‰Ûªt need that kind of embellishment, and neither does this movie. As his admirer James Dean probably knew all too well, Brando was a true rebel, partly because he thought being a star was absurd and partly because, as clip after clip shows, he always had a cause, whether it was civil rights, black power, Native American sovereignty or his own independence. At its most satisfying, ‰ÛÏListen to Me Marlon‰Ûù brings you close to a man whose legacy seems to have been tarnished less by his widely reported (and misreported) actions than by an entertainment press that punishes those who refuse to play the game. Brando found the game ludicrous. But he played along until he didn‰Ûªt, and while he occasionally suffered the consequences, along with too many fools, his work outlasts it all.

When Marlon Brando died in 2004 at 80, more than a few obituary writers decided he hadn‰Ûªt been a contender, after all. For them, this brilliant actor had devolved into as much a loser as Terry Malloy, his punch-drunk boxer in ‰ÛÏOn the Waterfront,‰Ûù who is sold down the river and, with a face battered by fights and the pain of a brother‰Ûªs betrayal, famously eulogizes himself: ‰ÛÏI coulda been a contender, I coulda been somebody, instead of a bum, which is what I am.‰Ûù Those who dismissed Brando reviewed his life as if it were some kind of movie, one with a strong opening act, a bewildering middle and a disappointing conclusion deserving of a collective thumbs down.

In 1968, as the summer political-convention season approached, ABC News decided to take a gamble. The network seemed permanently stuck in third place, and its news division in particular suffered from the lack of a brand-name on-air authority figure to compete with Chet Huntley and David Brinkley at NBC or Walter Cronkite at CBS. Back in those days, the two leading networks covered the conventions live from beginning to end. (Can you imagine?) Instead of comprehensiveness, ABC went for provocation and at least the illusion of intellectual heft, hiring Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr. to conduct a series of debates during the Republican circus in Miami and the subsequent Democratic debacle in Chicago. ‰ÛÏBest of Enemies,‰Ûù Robert Gordon and Morgan Neville‰Ûªs lively new documentary, an accessible assemblage of archival footage and talking-head analysis, mines the Buckley-Vidal skirmishes for nuggets of historical insight.

‰ÛÏBest of Enemies‰Ûù provides adequate biographical portraits of both men, although capturing the full range of their complexities, in particular as literary figures, lies beyond its modest, compact scope. It‰Ûªs too bad that both Buckley and Vidal died before this film was made ‰ÛÓ not that they would have necessarily participated ‰ÛÓ but Mr. Neville and Mr. Gordon make up for this absence by using Kelsey Grammer to read Buckley‰Ûªs words about Vidal and John Lithgow to read Vidal‰Ûªs reflections on Buckley.

This is brilliant casting, and the journalists, biographers, colleagues and kin invited on camera to fill out the story have been judiciously chosen. A few are current or former employees of The New York Times, including Sam Tanenhaus, a former editor of The Times Book Review and Buckley‰Ûªs authorized biographer.

The filmmakers build to this moment as if it were D-Day or the Rumble in the Jungle, excavating a biographical Before and adumbrating a news media After. The smeary, hot hues of old video ‰ÛÓ the ‰Ûª68 conventions were the first to be broadcast in color ‰ÛÓ add both immediacy and distance. Some protocols and artifacts of network television look quaint: the antenna-bedecked headsets of correspondents on the floor; the scripted prose of their reports. And the two antagonists, with their upper-crust accents and their compulsive displays of erudition, are not the kind of guys you see much on the tube these days, or anywhere else for that matter.

There‰Ûªs no doubt that the debates were a harbinger of cable-news shouting matches to come, as television journalism transformed itself from democracy‰Ûªs buttoned-up superego into its snarling id. The arguments about sex, war, race and culture have hardly quieted since 1968. Buckley and Vidal may rest in peace, but the rest of us have stayed plastered.

And also ‰ÛÓ not quite the same thing ‰ÛÓ for zingers and gotchas and other flashes of that mysterious, you-know-it-when-you-see-it phenomenon called ‰ÛÏgreat television.‰Ûù The most memorable such moment occurred late in the battle, as the Chicago Police Department rampaged in Grant Park. What looked like law and order to Mayor Richard J. Daley and like ‰ÛÏGestapo tactics‰Ûù to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut set off a series of especially nasty personal volleys between ABC‰Ûªs designated intellectuals. Vidal needled Buckley, calling him a ‰ÛÏcrypto-Nazi‰Ûù until Buckley lost his patrician cool and snapped back: ‰ÛÏNow listen, you queer. Stop calling me a crypto-Nazi or I‰Ûªll sock you in your goddamn face and you‰Ûªll stay plastered.‰Ûù Ratings gold.

This antipathy was only partly a political matter. Buckley, founder and editor of National Review, host of ‰ÛÏFiring Line‰Ûù and a champion of Barry Goldwater and Ronald Reagan, was a leading strategist and theoretician of the rising right. Vidal, while temperamentally not a joiner or a leader of movements, was at the time stationed at the respectable left wing of American liberalism, a critic of the nation‰Ûªs foreign policy and an evangelist for cultural and sexual freedom. His best-selling novel ‰ÛÏMyra Breckinridge,‰Ûù a blithe and naughty satire of modern hypocrisy with a gender-fluid heroine (played on screen by Raquel Welch), can be said to represent nearly everything Buckley loathed and feared about the ‰Ûª60s.
‰ÛÏBest of Enemies‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Riots, war, sexual revolution and a threatened punch in the face.

Mr. Tanenhaus and others work hard to invest the ABC debates with significance, not always successfully. Part of the occult power of television lies in its ability to collapse the distance between the trivial and the consequential. Vidal and Buckley were authentically important and interesting writers and thinkers, but sitting under the lights they were, above all, celebrities, signifiers of their own distorted individuality. The film provides little evidence that over the course of the 10 debates they said anything of real substance, even as the fabric of the Republic was unraveling and being rewoven before their eyes. To understand their thoughts on what was unfolding around them, you will have to consult their writings. Meanwhile, the spectacle of what Mr. Tanenhaus calls ‰ÛÏintellectual debate as blood sport‰Ûù provides a visceral, slightly vulgar thrill.

Buckley and Vidal were remarkable characters, at once bona fide intellectuals, true-blue aristocrats and knowing caricatures of those very types. Each one had, earlier in the decade, run a losing campaign for elective office in New York State: Vidal earnestly sought a congressional seat in the Hudson Valley in 1960; Buckley staged a lively protest candidacy in the New York City mayoral election of 1965. They were scions of powerful, privileged families, prep school graduates (Vidal never went to college), military veterans and tirelessly entrepreneurial men of letters happy to dabble in mass media when it suited their needs. They also genuinely and sincerely hated each other‰Ûªs guts.

Is this chronicle of their combat an occasion for nostalgia or a cautionary tale? The film‰Ûªs perfectly sensible, not entirely satisfying answer is ‰ÛÏboth.‰Ûù The Buckley-Vidal dust-ups are seen as a pinnacle of high-mindedness from which we have long since descended, and also as the beginning of a slide from civility into endless belligerence.

It isn‰Ûªt obvious from watching ‰ÛÏCounting‰Ûù that the window belongs to Mr. Cohen; I read it in the press notes. Mr. Cohen is telling a story about the modern world, but he‰Ûªs using visual and aural fragments ‰ÛÓ think of them as story shards ‰ÛÓ instead of three distinct acts and character arcs. Sometimes the meanings of these fragments unfold clearly; sometimes you need to piece the fragments together, as you would a jigsaw puzzle. Not every chapter has a particularly strong story; in the untitled Chapter 3, Mr. Cohen cuts from an opening shot of yellow autumnal leaves to a figure in an apartment and then to a close-up of a woman‰Ûªs face bathed in warm light. You may guess that the light is pouring from the same window that will soon be blocked by a condo, and you‰Ûªd be right.

In ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù Mr. Cohen draws upon other influences as well, evoking place films like Walter Ruttmann‰Ûªs 1927 classic ‰ÛÏBerlin: Symphony of a Great City‰Ûù and nodding at narratives like Virgil‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Aeneid.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏCounting‰Ûù is another type of travel story, one in which the world is often framed in the window of a moving car, train or plane. That‰Ûªs because, among all the many stories that Mr. Cohen tells, the most personal one is that of an itinerant, persistently independent filmmaker who continues to practice his art and follow his path with the support of far-flung festivals and art foundations, several of which are listed in the credits. From Portugal to Turkey, Mr. Cohen has been gazing out at worlds and people on the long, winding road that leads every artist back home.

At one point in ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù a wistful meditation on the world, its beauties, mysteries and injustices, the independent filmmaker Jem Cohen cuts from a photograph of Soviet cosmonauts to a view out a plane window. There are a number of aerial images scattered throughout the movie, which Mr. Cohen has stitched together from visual fragments that he shot over a period that took him from Coney Island to Moscow. Mr. Cohen, born in 1962, turns out to be another type of space-age traveler, if one who‰Ûªs specifically crossing cinematic time.

Protest, by turns organized and more diffuse, is a leitmotif in ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù though it‰Ûªs easy to see the entire movie ‰ÛÓ with its insistence on ordinary beauty and its undertow of leftist politics ‰ÛÓ as an act of resistance. For the most part, Mr. Cohen‰Ûªs protest is quietly expressed, although it gathers force with the repetition of certain visuals, notably with the images of building construction and seemingly uprooted men and women. Over the course of the movie, the references to gentrification, commercialization, urban overbuilding and the lack of affordable housing dovetail with Mr. Cohen‰Ûªs own marginalized status as a New York artist working outside the cinematic commercial mainstream who, as you see, is watching a condo go up right outside his window.

Early in ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù Mr. Cohen inserts a shot of a Japanese good luck cat, an early, overt acknowledgment of the debt that he owes the French filmmaker Chris Marker, who died in 2012. Good luck cats populate Mr. Marker‰Ûªs essay film ‰ÛÏSans Soleil,‰Ûù an exploration of time, place and memory. At one point, the narrator of ‰ÛÏSans Soleil‰Ûù says (memorably!): ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm writing you all this from another world, a world of appearances. In a way the two worlds communicate with each other. Memory is to one what history is to the other: an impossibility.‰Ûù As Mr. Cohen shifts from one space and time to the next in ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù the filmmaker ‰ÛÓ who has long been ‰ÛÏwriting‰Ûù from the world of appearances with his camera ‰ÛÓ expresses the melancholy and longing embedded in that impossibility.

Time rushes and drifts in ‰ÛÏCounting,‰Ûù and gives it a formal logic, as the title suggests. The movie is divided into 15 numbered chapters, most of which open with titles (‰ÛÏA Day Is Long,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThere and Back‰Ûù) and end with time-and-place setting text. In Chapter 6, which is bookended by the words ‰ÛÏThe Blues‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏNew York City, 2012-2014,‰Ûù Mr. Cohen juxtaposes rainy street shots with those of homeless people, the words ‰ÛÏTrump is a monster‰Ûù etched on a sidewalk, and a man and woman ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs playing a guitar, she‰Ûªs wearing a sign, ‰ÛÏDisarm the Pentagon‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ next to the statue of another dissenter, George Washington, on the steps of the Federal Hall National Memorial.

Can a 5-year-old boy be a literary genius? And if so, how might his precocious gift be nurtured and protected? These are, on the surface, among the main questions posed by ‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher,‰Ûù a self-assured, remarkably powerful film from the Israeli writer-director Nadav Lapid.

The teacher is Nira (Sarit Larry), a woman with a warm professional manner and pleasant, ordinary middle-class life. She has a son in the army, a daughter in high school and a devoted husband (Lior Raz) with a decent government job. As a hobby ‰ÛÓ or perhaps as a vehicle for unexpressed ambitions and frustrated desires ‰ÛÓ she attends a poetry workshop with other amateur versifiers. Then one day she witnesses a startling act of creation. One of her pupils, a cherubic, sleepy-eyed boy named Yoav (Avi Shnaidman), is being picked up at the end of the school day. ‰ÛÏI have a poem,‰Ûù he announces and recites a brief, elliptical love lyric, pacing back and forth as his nanny writes his words in a notebook.

In that film, which tracks the parallel stories of a group of left-wing Jewish militants and an elite police unit, Mr. Lapid explored the alienation and class conflict that fester beneath the prosperous surface of contemporary Israeli society. ‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher‰Ûù is a furious indictment of the materialism and complacency of 21st-century life, in Israel and implicitly beyond. Yoav, innocent and barely conscious of the meaning of his poems, is the uncanny voice of a disinherited tradition. His father, a flashy restaurateur, has no use for poetry. The boy‰Ûªs uncle, who published a volume of verses before drifting into bitterness and penury as a journalist, is a grim specter of literary failure. Such poets as exist in the world ‰ÛÓ the shouters at the reading, Nira‰Ûªs workshop instructor ‰ÛÓ run the gamut from vulgar to pretentious.

Experiencing Yoav‰Ûªs poems is its own kind of eavesdropping. It‰Ûªs hard for a Hebrewless reader of English subtitles to judge their literary merits, but the film‰Ûªs internal experts, Nira included, are impressed enough with their linguistic polish and thematic sophistication to elevate them above mere verbal child‰Ûªs play. Nira introduces her protÌ©gÌ© to the work of his precursors, including the Israeli ‰ÛÏnational poet‰Ûù Chaim Nachman Bialik. She is concerned with the progress of Yoav‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏcareer,‰Ûù a strange notion given his age.

For most of the movie, Mr. Lapid keeps Nira on the near side of normalcy. ‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher‰Ûù works perfectly well as a subtle, astute psychological drama, venturing into thriller territory toward the end. The director and his cinematographer, Shai Goldman, favor shallow-focus compositions and low, odd angles. At times you feel like a child observing the grown-up world, peering up at legs and hands, trying to decode the meaning of gestures and words. At other times, as the camera tiptoes around conversations and peeks over shoulders, you feel like a spy or a voyeur, privy to vaguely inappropriate information.

Nira is startled and intrigued, and the evolution of her interest in Yoav drives the film‰Ûªs suspenseful, unnerving, bizarre and strangely believable plot. At first, like any conscientious teacher, she is solicitous and encouraging. It‰Ûªs always good to recognize and celebrate what is special in a child. The budding bard is in most respects a perfectly ordinary child, roughhousing and practicing swear words with his best pal, playing in the sandbox and demanding snacks when he‰Ûªs hungry. It‰Ûªs possible to read signs of unusual intelligence in his expressions, but his most prominent feature is a face that seems created to invite a grandmother‰Ûªs pinches.

But it‰Ûªs also hard to shake the suspicion that she may be right about Yoav, and correct in her increasingly despairing assessment of his environment. Like many Israeli filmmakers, Mr. Lapid uses cinema as a vehicle for social criticism, but both the intensity and the orientation of his critique set him apart from his peers. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict, an unavoidable and in some respects easy subject for liberal-minded artists and writers, is largely absent from ‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher,‰Ûù as it was from his previous feature, ‰ÛÏPoliceman.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏBeing a poet in our world is going against the nature of the world,‰Ûù Nira says, and the most surprising ‰ÛÓ the most radical ‰ÛÓ aspect of ‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher‰Ûù is how fiercely it defends that view. Yoav may be, in the eyes of a reasonable viewer, an odd kid with an unusual knack for language. Nira, for her part, may be a frustrated poet sliding from midlife crisis into mental instability. Certainly there is no condoning the extremes to which she takes her pedagogical mission.

But Nira, a 20-year veteran of the kindergarten classroom, is immune to his cuteness. He acts serious in her company because that‰Ûªs what she expects and also perhaps because he‰Ûªs a little confused by her attention. She wakes him up from his nap and takes him outside in the rain, hoping to stimulate his creativity. She takes over from the nanny as his principal secretary and spends more and more time with him outside school. She signs him up for a poetry reading. And then things become really strange.

‰ÛÏThe Kindergarten Teacher‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the film as well as the character ‰ÛÓ yearns for different values, for intensity, beauty and meaning. Its sobering lesson is that the search for those things is most likely to end in madness, confusion and violence.

There is video of Mr. Farley‰Ûªs sketches at the Second City comedy theater in Chicago, where he sharpened his skills. Bob Odenkirk recalls performing with Mr. Farley in a stage version of his ‰ÛÏmotivational speaker‰Ûù sketch as a high point of his own show business career.

The movie presents Mr. Farley as a natural entertainer and generous collaborator, but it inevitably takes a dark turn. Like Mr. Belushi, Mr. Farley died at 33 of a drug overdose. The story of dependence and excess is sadly familiar ‰ÛÓ and as with most of its material, ‰ÛÏI Am Chris Farley‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt find a fresh way to tell it.

Mr. Farley‰Ûªs brothers and sister offer insight into how Mr. Farley, a family clown and school athlete, was drawn to comedy, and they note the autobiographical elements in the film ‰ÛÏTommy Boy‰Ûù (1995), in which Mr. Farley appeared alongside David Spade, his frequent sparring partner. (One sibling, Kevin Farley, is an executive producer on the documentary.)
‰ÛÏI Am Chris Farley‰Ûù paints an effusive portrait of its title subject, a man the ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù creator Lorne Michaels is shown calling an ‰ÛÏinfuriatingly talented‰Ûù comedian.

Adhering to an overused backstage template, this documentary conveys a sense of Chris Farley‰Ûªs quick wit and comic ethos, as well as the gusto with which he approached his routines (at times plunging forward for laughs and not even using his arms to break his falls). Everyone interviewed ‰ÛÓ including Mike Myers, Christina Applegate, Adam Sandler and Dan Aykroyd, who is perhaps most wistful among those who compare Mr. Farley to John Belushi ‰ÛÓ speaks of him affectionately.

Most movingly, we learn how Dr. Daniel LeGoff, who treats autistic children in New Jersey, has used Legos in his practice, and how Adrian Pitt, a New York City child in speech and language therapy, has benefited from the plastic bricks. ‰ÛÏA Lego Brickumentary‰Ûù might be a resounding cheer for a brand, but it‰Ûªs an eye-opener, too.

Sure, there are celebrity endorsements ‰ÛÓ the pop singer Ed Sheeran; Trey Parker, a co-creator of ‰ÛÏSouth Park‰Ûù; and the N.B.A. player Dwight Howard testify to the value of building with Legos (and Jason Bateman narrates the film). But more interesting testimonials, to use fan parlance, come from AFOLs (Adult Fans of Lego) in LUGs (Lego User Groups), who assemble in the movie at conventions in Seattle and Chicago. We meet Adam Reed Tucker, an architect building miniature Lego skyscrapers; David Pagano, a New York filmmaker specializing in Lego stop-motion animation (‰ÛÏbrickfilms‰Ûù); and Nathan Sawaya, an artist whose show ‰ÛÏThe Art of the Brick‰Ûù comes to Times Square in the course of filming.

You‰Ûªd expect ‰ÛÏA Lego Brickumentary‰Ûù to be an extended plug for Lego products, and it is certainly that ‰ÛÓ to an extent. (Lego did not finance the film.) And this nimble, expertly paced family-friendly film by Daniel Junge and Kief Davidson dutifully covers the origins of the Lego company in Billund, Denmark, and its growth into a global toy brand rivaling Mattel and Hasbro. But it delves into other things: how engineers and psychologists have employed the pieces as tools, and the ways in which people have adopted Legos as a medium to realize their creative visions.

Mr. Henriksen (fresh off the horror comedy ‰ÛÏStung‰Ûù) does what he can, while Ms. Azlynn flails hopelessly against the two-dimensional constraints of her frightened-mother role. As for Mr. Cook, he bravely attacks his part, imparting shifting shades of sinister intent. But all their efforts prove in vain against a movie beyond salvation.

‰ÛÏDark Awakening,‰Ûù directed by the makeup-effects veteran Dean C. Jones, is good for a game of Name That Influence: ghostly playmates (ÌÊ la ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity 3‰Ûù), a fallen clergyman (‰ÛÏThe Exorcist‰Ûù), a drenched female apparition crawling toward the camera (‰ÛÏThe Ring‰Ûù) and secrets in the basement (too many to count). But the fun ends there. Overabundant diffuse lighting and wide-angle perspectives only compound this horror movie‰Ûªs deficiencies in plot and dialogue. A procession of gruesome set pieces toward the end (including child murder and the killing of a cat) offers copious gore but little payoff.

The district attorney of a Southern town, James Thomas (Jason Cook), has a lot on his docket. First he has to put up with an angry court spectator who shoots a leering defendant just declared innocent. Then James‰Ûªs mother dies, and he and his wife, Jennifer (Valerie Azlynn), and 7-year-old son, Danny (William Pifer), move into Mom‰Ûªs country home, where spectral residents befriend Danny and terrify Jennifer. The local priest (Lance Henriksen) clearly isn‰Ûªt sharing all he knows, and before long James just isn‰Ûªt acting like his old self.

In ‰ÛÏThat Sugar Film,‰Ûù Damon Gameau, an engaging Australian actor-director who has been off refined sugars for years, shifts his consumption for two months to include 40 teaspoons of sugar a day, the average Aussie‰Ûªs intake. And he isn‰Ûªt scarfing candy and soda: Instead, to highlight the hidden sugars in so-called healthy alternatives, he consumes products like low-fat yogurt, juice and cereal.

He also travels across Australia and the United States, investigating the consequences of a high-sugar diet and discussing health and business-related issues with scientists, physicians and journalists (including Michael Moss, a former reporter for The New York Times and author of ‰ÛÏSalt Sugar Fat‰Ûù). Mr. Gameau‰Ûªs breezy blend of computer imagery, musical numbers, sketches and offbeat field trips makes the nutrition lessons easy to digest.

If this sounds like Morgan Spurlock‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSuper Size Me,‰Ûù in which Mr. Spurlock ingested McDonald‰Ûªs menu items for a month, it should; Mr. Gameau has followed Mr. Spurlock‰Ûªs playbook almost page for page. Like ‰ÛÏSuper Size Me,‰Ûù Mr. Gameau keeps a team of doctors and nutritionists handy, and the health effects are alarming. Within three weeks, he starts to develop fatty liver disease, and by the end incurs early Type 2 diabetes and increased heart-disease risks.

The food-doc shelf is crowded with good-for-you movies, including ‰ÛÏFed Up,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFast Food Nation,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFood Inc.‰Ûù and, yes, ‰ÛÏSuper Size Me.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThat Sugar Film‰Ûù is a worthy addition, entertaining while informing. Timely, too: Just last week, the Food and Drug Administration proposed requiring companies to list added sugar in their labeling.

As Jenny, a social worker in Cleveland, Katherine Heigl seems barely able to control her impatience with a lesbian character whose charade of heterosexuality means constantly lying to her marriage-obsessed family. Her ridiculously narrow-minded parents (Tom Wilkinson and Linda Emond) are happier believing that she is seeing a married man than that she‰Ûªs on the shelf. And her vinegary sister, Anne (Grace Gummer), can‰Ûªt resist crowing.
‰ÛÏJenny‰Ûªs Wedding‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Homophobic slurs and embarrassing dancing.

But ‰ÛÏJenny‰Ûªs Wedding‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt really about a lesbian romance; it‰Ûªs about secrets and lies and entrenched bigotry. From supermarket to firehouse, Jenny‰Ûªs marital status is the sole topic of conversations packed with antiquated attitudes and who‰Ûªs-to-blame arguments. The result is a movie so hopelessly late to the coming-out party that you want to haul everyone connected with it into the 21st century.

‰ÛÏI have everything she wants,‰Ûù she says, smugly. ‰ÛÏTwo kids and a husband.‰Ûù Anne‰Ûªs desiccated lawn suggests otherwise, but excruciating metaphors are par for the course in a story (by the director, Mary Agnes Donoghue) that chokes authenticity with clichÌ©d speeches and hectoring pop songs. Worse, as Jenny‰Ûªs supposedly longtime lover, the usually winning Alexis Bledel must play a blank slate whose connection to Jenny is as invisible as her personality.

‰ÛÏJenny‰Ûªs Wedding‰Ûù begins with a christening and ends with a conga line ‰ÛÓ a finale signaled so clearly that even those in the cheap seats can‰Ûªt miss it. And that‰Ûªs one of the many irritants in this trite, well-intentioned lecture on tolerance: The audience is always several moves ahead of the script.
‰ÛÏMission: Impossible ‰ÛÓ Rogue Nation‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Kids, don‰Ûªt try this at home.

Mr. Cruise looks comfortable with Ms. Ferguson, another plus. For most of his action-movie career, he has come across as a less romantically nimble, less self-amused version of Douglas Fairbanks, the swashbuckler who leaped through the silent era. Like Mr. Cruise, Fairbanks performed many of his own white-knuckle stunts, as when he climbs up the chain of a closing drawbridge in ‰ÛÏRobin Hood.‰Ûù (Fairbanks helped start United Artists, which Mr. Cruise owned a piece of for a while.) All too often, Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs insistence on doing frightening stunts in the ‰ÛÏMission: Impossible‰Ûù series has become its most distinguishing quality. In this movie, though, when he goes airborne like a barnstormer, the scene‰Ûªs self-conscious sense of the absurd suggests he‰Ûªs trying to let his inner Harold Lloyd out to play.

As the clock tick-tocks, and Ethan struggles to keep his cool ‰ÛÓ a single drop of sweat splashed on the floor would blow the operation ‰ÛÓ the visual gloss and high-tech gobbledygook, Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs graceful athleticism and Mr. De Palma‰Ûªs New Hollywood suspense chops flow together, turning the scene into the emblematic ‰ÛÏMission: Impossible‰Ûù showstopper. It‰Ûªs the kind of pure cine-spectacle that jolts you before sweeping you up. There‰Ûªs never been a scene in the series as memorable as that one, even if the exploding fish tank, the film‰Ûªs other eye-popper, comes close. These sequences set a high bar both for directors who followed in Mr. De Palma‰Ûªs wake and for Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs physical performance, which in the later installments has largely involved progressively scarier stunts.

The writer and director of the latest movie ‰ÛÓ its goofy full title is ‰ÛÏMission: Impossible ‰ÛÓ Rogue Nation‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is Christopher McQuarrie, who‰Ûªs been tethered to Mr. Cruise for the past decade. They worked together on Mr. McQuarrie‰Ûªs adaptation of ‰ÛÏJack Reacher,‰Ûù a grim genre bummer that was a bad fit for Mr. Cruise, who can rarely go tough and dark with conviction. Mr. McQuarrie also had a hand in writing ‰ÛÏEdge of Tomorrow,‰Ûù Doug Liman‰Ûªs underloved science-fiction romp that dovetailed with Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs strengths, including a too infrequently tapped gift for light comedy. Mr. McQuarrie, who made his name with his rebuslike script for ‰ÛÏThe Usual Suspects,‰Ûù tends to work the more lugubrious end of the entertainment spectrum, so it‰Ûªs a nice surprise that ‰ÛÏRogue Nation‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt just another clenched-jaw blowout.

That helps speed up ‰ÛÏRogue Nation,‰Ûù which slows down when the plot tangles or some ceremonial manly peacocking ensues, usually from Mr. Renner and Mr. Cruise. Clearly Mr. McQuarrie and his star feel the need to stamp the series with seriousness, something that Mr. De Palma knew better than to do. And throughout ‰ÛÏRogue Nation,‰Ûù you can sense the filmmakers comfortably, at times awkwardly, playing tug of war with the mood, which grows sinister with the excellent Sean Harris as the regulation evil genius and almost frisky with Alec Baldwin as an intelligence blowhard and Tom Hollander as a political boob. Mr. Pegg‰Ûªs second-banana flair is especially crucial here because it helps show that Mr. Cruise, whose smile at times seems awfully strained these days, can still take a ribbing as well as a licking.

Sleek and bloated, specific and generic, ‰ÛÏRogue Nation‰Ûù is pretty much like most of the ‰ÛÏImpossible‰Ûù movies in that it‰Ûªs an immense machine that Mr. McQuarrie, after tinkering and oiling, has cranked up again and set humming with twists and turns, global trotting and gadgets, a crack supporting cast and a hard-working star. Jeremy Renner, Ving Rhames and Simon Pegg (with his valuable comic timing) are all back, joined by the series newcomer Rebecca Ferguson. She plays a super-vixen, the amusingly named Ilsa Faust, who enters with the camera peeking up her skirt and rises like a half-shell Venus, ÌÊ la the original Bond Girl, Ursula Andress. Even so, Ms. Ferguson has more going for her than man-throttling thighs (and an ace stunt double, Lucy Cork); she holds her own both on the ground and in midair.

The first ‰ÛÏMission: Impossible‰Ûù movie, a spinoff from the 1960s television show, was released 19 years ago and was, though it‰Ûªs almost hard to believe it now, something of an auteurist event, having been directed by Brian De Palma. Mr. Cruise was an established action star by 1996, but he also helped produce the first film, which strengthened his status as an international brand. As a star-auteur, he has always been the most important feature and effect of the series, although it‰Ûªs telling that Mr. De Palma oversaw the set-piece that gave the movies their foundational image: Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs operative, Ethan Hunt, hovering like a spider (or a puppet) above a luminous white floor while suspended by a very thin rope.

Watching Tom Cruise hurtle through the latest ‰ÛÏMission: Impossible,‰Ûù taking one blow after another, you can‰Ûªt help worrying that he won‰Ûªt be able to keep this action stuff up. It looks so hard! But here he is, the 53-year-old Tom Terrific, holding onto a plane as it takes off, defying sense and gravity, and making you wonder (not for the first time) if he would actually die for our pleasure. By the time he‰Ûªs flailing underwater without an oxygen tank, struggling against violent surges as breath and time run out, you can almost feel the life leaving his body.

One theme through the years is the resistance that Paulo faces in pursuing his chosen path. ‰ÛÏNo one makes a living by writing,‰Ûù his father pleads. Even his editor, when he submits ‰ÛÏThe Alchemist,‰Ûù tells him, ‰ÛÏThis book isn‰Ûªt good.‰Ûù A writer recalling every slight and naysayer? This film gets that right, at least.

To be fair, dramatizing an author‰Ûªs process is never easy: Paulo bangs away on his typewriter, smokes, tosses pages. JÌ_lio Andrade‰Ûªs performance seems limited to displays of rage and self-satisfaction. (Ravel Andrade, though, is an effective welter of youthful confusion.)

Before the Brazilian author Paulo Coelho published his mythic quest of a fable, ‰ÛÏThe Alchemist,‰Ûù he had already written plays, put out a magazine, made hit records with the Brazilian rock star Raul Seixas and became a music executive. So the title of this biopic, ‰ÛÏPaulo Coelho‰Ûªs Best Story,‰Ûù is apt: His own life might well be his greatest work.

A pity, then, that the film, directed by Daniel Augusto, doesn‰Ûªt chronicle his evolution better, leapfrogging among decades instead. There‰Ûªs Paulo (JÌ_lio Andrade) in 2013, stopped for autographs while heading to a party for the 25th anniversary of ‰ÛÏThe Alchemist.‰Ûù There he is in the ‰Ûª60s in Rio de Janeiro, a rebellious, suicidal teenager (played by Ravel Andrade, JÌ_lio‰Ûªs brother) fighting his stern father, and twice winding up in psychiatric institutions. In the ‰Ûª70s, he‰Ûªs collaborating with Raul (Lucci Ferreira); and in the ‰Ûª80s, he‰Ûªs married and restless, taking a life-changing trip along Camino de Santiago in Spain that will be the source of his first novel, ‰ÛÏThe Pilgrimage.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe End of the Tour‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language. So much language.

David L., a new, probationary hire at Rolling Stone magazine, convinces his skeptical editor (Ron Livingston) that David F.W. is worthy of a feature article, and so finds himself in Bloomington, Ill., in the middle of winter. (Wallace taught for many years at Illinois State University.) The plan is that the reporter will accompany the novelist to Minneapolis, the last stop on his book tour. He does, and that‰Ûªs pretty much the plot of the movie.

In real life, David Lipsky might be a great guy, but on screen he is played by Mr. Eisenberg, which means that his genetic material is at least 25 percent weasel. Wallace at one point playfully describes himself as ‰ÛÏpleasantly unpleasant.‰Ûù Lipsky is unpleasantly pleasant, which is much worse. Twitchy and ingratiating, he wants to be a tough journalist and a pal. He desperately wants Wallace to regard him as a peer and can hardly contain his jealousy. He berates Sarah after she chats with Wallace on the phone and falls into a defensive snit after Wallace accuses him of flirting with Betsy (Mickey Sumner), a poet who had known Wallace in graduate school.

There are two Davids in the movie, which takes place in 1996. Both of them are writers. One is Wallace (Jason Segel), whose third book of fiction, the 1,079-page dystopian tennis-rehab epic ‰ÛÏInfinite Jest,‰Ûù has just been published to hyperbolic acclaim. The other is David Lipsky (Jesse Eisenberg), whose own recently released novel, ‰ÛÏThe Art Fair,‰Ûù has met with polite indifference. An early scene finds him on his couch reading ‰ÛÏInfinite Jest‰Ûù while his girlfriend, Sarah (Anna Chlumsky), is curled up with the season‰Ûªs other fictional blockbuster, the anonymously published political roman ÌÊ clef ‰ÛÏPrimary Colors.‰Ûù (Oh, the ‰Ûª90s. Sorry you missed all the fun, kids. Kind of sorry I didn‰Ûªt.)

Some of the people closest to Wallace, who committed suicide in 2008, have condemned the movie sight unseen, and friends of his who did see it (one of them also a friend of mine) have found fault with both its details and its overall design. As an ardent, ambivalent reader of Wallace‰Ûªs prose and a complete stranger to him personally, I can only respect such objections. But the movie, in my view, disarms them ‰ÛÓ not because it offers an especially loving or lifelike picture of its subject but rather because David Foster Wallace is not really its subject at all. ‰ÛÏThe End of the Tour‰Ûù is at once an exercise in post-postmodern literary mythmaking and an unsparing demolition of the contemporary mythology of the writer. It‰Ûªs ultimately a movie ‰ÛÓ one of the most rigorous and thoughtful I‰Ûªve seen ‰ÛÓ about the ethical and existential traps our fame-crazed culture sets for the talented and the mediocre alike.

You may find yourself wishing that he didn‰Ûªt have to, which is to say wishing that ‰ÛÏThe End of the Tour‰Ûù didn‰Ûªt exist even as you hang on its every word and revel in its rough, vernacular beauty. In an ideal world, we would all sit at home reading ‰ÛÏInfinite Jest‰Ûù and then go out to eat hamburgers, argue about philosophy and watch cheesy action blockbusters. There would be no pseudo-authoritative biographies or prying, preening magazine profiles to complicate our pleasures, and ambitious actors would not dare to impersonate beloved novelists. But the world we live in is plagued by all of those things. There will always be films about writers and writing, and this one is just about as good as it gets.

Many of the words are Wallace‰Ûªs own, uttered into Mr. Lipsky‰Ûªs tape recorder in 1996 and transcribed, 14 years later, for publication in a book called ‰ÛÏAlthough of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself.‰Ûù Funny, intriguing and revealing as this talk may be, it does not have anything like the status of Wallace‰Ûªs writing. The film not only acknowledges this distinction, but it also insists on it. In his would-be profiler‰Ûªs company, occasionally glancing at the menacing red light of the predigital tape recorder, Wallace is by turns cagey and candid, witty and earnest, but he is always aware, at times painfully, that he is playing the role of a writer in someone else‰Ûªs fantasy. Actually writing is something he does when no one else is around.

His awfulness is, to some degree, structural. A profile writer, especially in the company of another writer, is a false friend who dreams of being a secret sharer. Lipsky‰Ûªs assignment is to pry, distort and betray, to use Wallace‰Ûªs words and the details of his existence as material for his own dubious project. Wallace knows this and acquiesces to it ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏyou agreed to the interview‰Ûù is Lipsky‰Ûªs fallback when his subject gets prickly ‰ÛÓ and generally handles himself with grace and forbearance.

‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs an unhappy paradox about literary biographies,‰Ûù David Foster Wallace observed in The New York Times Book Review in 2004, in reference to ‰ÛÏBorges: A Life.‰Ûù Readers who pick up such books, drawn by their admiration for a writer‰Ûªs work, are likely to find themselves distracted and disappointed by a welter of iffy theories and picayune data. In the case of Borges, Wallace argued, ‰ÛÏthe stories so completely transcend their motive cause that the biographical facts become, in the deepest and most literal way, irrelevant.‰Ûù

Mr. Segel‰Ûªs performance, whether it captures the true Wallace or not, is sharp and sensitive, in no small part because it‰Ûªs modest and appropriately evasive. The essential David Wallace is precisely what the film reminds us we can‰Ûªt see, even as David Lipsky wants desperately to track him down and display him to the readers of Rolling Stone. Wallace is caught in a familiar set of contradictions. He wants attention but craves solitude. He‰Ûªs willing to collaborate with the machinery of publicity even as he worries about the phoniness of it all. He‰Ûªs ambitious and eager to protect himself from the consequences of his ambition. In short, he‰Ûªs a famous writer.

Mr. Ponsoldt, whose earlier features include ‰ÛÏThe Spectacular Now‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSmashed,‰Ûù would much rather observe two people in aimless conversation than usher them through the tollbooths of narrative convention. And conversation, including the uncomfortable silences that punctuate it, is pretty much the entire substance of ‰ÛÏThe End of the Tour.‰Ûù Yes, there‰Ûªs a fair amount of smoking and junk-food eating, an excursion to the Mall of America and a multiplex showing of ‰ÛÏBroken Arrow‰Ûù (with John Travolta taking a missile to the gut), but Mr. Ponsoldt and the screenwriter, the playwright Donald Margulies, allow words to speak louder than actions.

As such he is, for his short-term companion, both alpha dog and prey, an object of envy as well as admiration, a meal ticket and an imaginary friend. The film poses the question ‰ÛÏWho is the real David Foster Wallace?‰Ûù as a feint. He is its premise, its axiom, its great white whale. The more relevant question, the moral problem on which the movie turns, is ‰ÛÏwho is David Lipsky?‰Ûù

The same can be said of Wallace himself, and, for that matter, of just about any author worth reading. The work is everything; the life is trivia. And since I‰Ûªm about to praise a movie about David Foster Wallace that claims fidelity to at least some of the facts of his life, I should perhaps identify myself as a devoted nonconsumer of literary biographies, an avowed biopic skeptic and, unless someone offers me a lot of money to write one, a habitual avoider of celebrity profiles. So by all rights I should hate ‰ÛÏThe End of the Tour,‰Ûù James Ponsoldt‰Ûªs new film, a portrait of the writer that has its origins in a (never-published) magazine profile. In fact, I love it.

The possibility of getting his hands on some real money, along with the frustration of having to wait to empty James‰Ûªs account because of banking regulations, drives Webb into a frenzy of greed and violence, and what little sense of caution he had evaporates.

Mr. HÌ©bert, who suggests a rancid younger cousin of Dax Shepard, summons a superficial joviality that barely masks the instincts of a poisonous snake. Webb‰Ûªs scam was telephoning seniors, impersonating a grandson and convincing them to wire him money. James‰Ûªs grandmother was one of his victims.

A recurrent image of grackles lined up on a wire as if on the lookout haunts ‰ÛÏTwo Step,‰Ûù a creepy indie thriller set in the seedier environs of Austin, Tex. That image reinforces the movie‰Ûªs acrid portrait of a scuffling working-class milieu where the lines between legitimate employment and petty crime blur. Several of the characters run scams in addition to holding jobs.

In a daze, he strikes up an acquaintance with his grandmother‰Ûªs neighbor Dot (Beth Broderick), a salty woman in her 50s and the movie‰Ûªs moral grounding wire. Dot has been married and divorced three times and is being pursued by a married policeman. ‰ÛÏA lot of people in this town just think I‰Ûªm naturally horizontal,‰Ûù she remarks. ‰ÛÏBut I am content, and I am complete.‰Ûù A former dancer with a Houston ballet company, Dot‰Ûªs career was derailed when she broke her leg at 20. Now she teaches a dance class.

In the opening scene, James (Skyy Moore), a sullen young man who has just flunked out of college, pays a surprise visit to his ailing grandmother. Within minutes of his arrival, she has a seizure and dies. James, whose parents are dead, learns from the family lawyer that she left him everything: $85,000 and her house.

‰ÛÏTwo Step,‰Ûù the feature-length debut of Alex R. Johnson, who wrote, directed and produced, is a nasty, flawlessly acted little gem that goes deep inside its characters‰Ûª psyches. Before his incarceration, Webb worked in a store run by his crooked boss, Duane (Jason Douglas), to whom he owes $10,000. Duane, who despises Webb for his stupidity and hotheadedness, contemptuously orders him to pay up and get out of town. Webb lashes out.

A second, seemingly unrelated story line follows the release from prison of Webb (James Landry HÌ©bert), a predatory grifter who returns to the shack he shares with his girlfriend, Amy (Ashley Rae Spillers), who is not pleased to see him. When they were last together, he broke her nose. He unconvincingly claims it was an accident.

Upon discovering that Amy has spent what money he had hoarded, Webb flies into a rage and resumes his con artistry. He returns to the grandmother‰Ûªs house where James is staying, beats up James, ties him to a chair and pries banking information that allows him to begin stealing the inheritance.

This lean character-driven movie has such an acutely observant screenplay that it is easy to empathize with people struggling to make a decent living by hook or crook. Its psychological precision elevates it to something more than a genre piece. It is a disquieting study of life among Americans who have less and for whom $85,000 is a pot of gold. It suggests a tough, contemporary answer to ‰ÛÏThe Last Picture Show,‰Ûù reimagined as neorealist thriller, without a patina of romantic sadness.

The crisscrossing pursuers and pesky police suggest a watered-down version of the treacheries in ‰ÛÏCity on Fire.‰Ûù But the cluttered, unfolding dynamism of Mr. Lam‰Ûªs action scenes remains resilient when gunplay or knife fights are thrust into street life. He also captures one gangster squad‰Ûªs camaraderie, whether its members are hanging out or ceremonially burying one of their own.

T-Man is a former cop who runs a club and makes the mistake of helping a drunk woman (Tong Liya) who turns out to have a big briefcase full of someone else‰Ûªs money. T-Man and his cab-driving stepbrother, Chung (Shawn Yue), go on to protect the woman from triad gangsters out to kill her and her ex-boyfriend, a slimeball lawyer. The two take more risks than Good Samaritanism seems to require.

Mr. Koo is almost too low-key as the responsible sibling to Mr. Yue‰Ûªs less coolheaded Chung. And in case we missed the message about money and corruption, Mr. Lam hammers it home during the climactic scene, which features a shattered statue of the scales of justice.

Much has changed in Hong Kong since Ringo Lam‰Ûªs classic 1987 undercover thriller, ‰ÛÏCity on Fire,‰Ûù starring Chow Yun-fat, but one scourge of urban life apparently persists: sidewalks and shops plagued by careening car chases. ‰ÛÏWild City,‰Ûù Mr. Lam‰Ûªs respectable but average return to directing feature films after a recent hiatus, follows an accidental hero, T-Man (Louis Koo), who often laments the evils of cash. But it‰Ûªs mayhem, not moralizing, that perks up the story.

Babe, the sheep-herding pig, had an oddly similar experience in the 1998 film ‰ÛÏBabe: Pig in the City,‰Ûù accidentally putting Farmer Hoggett in the hospital and having to travel to the city to save the day. So Babe could have told these sheep that when farm animals go to urban areas calamity follows.

It certainly follows the sheep, with results that are alternately hilarious, a bit scary and rather touching. A nasty-looking animal control officer is soon in pursuit of the herd, which manages to disguise itself in human clothing, a sort of thrift-shop chic that is just good enough to do the job because in this city, as in most, no one really looks at anyone else too closely.

The film tries something unusual in the world of animated family fare: It tells its 84-minute story without words. That doesn‰Ûªt mean it‰Ûªs a silent film. There is plenty of communication among the characters, but it‰Ûªs all done with gestures augmented by squeaks, grrr‰Ûªs and a bit of singing (and surprisingly few baas, given the subject matter). There are human characters along with the animals, but they too aren‰Ûªt talkers so much as mumblers.

That complicates the sheep‰Ûªs task and makes for a bittersweet reunion, but it all works out in the end. The movie is based on a British TV series, and if the individual sheep characters are not as well defined here as they are in that long-running show, their general irresistibility comes through. There is not a lot in the movie for tweener-and-above children, but some amusing film homages and such have been slipped in for adults.

The sheep soon realize that life without their farmer isn‰Ûªt as blissful as they thought it would be ‰ÛÓ for one thing, they can‰Ûªt reach their feed, which is stored high in the barn. So they set out for the city, determined to bring him home. The farmer‰Ûªs loyal dog has embarked on his own rescue mission, and eventually sheep and dog put aside their differences and join forces for the greater good.
