Disguises, though, work for only so long, and eventually we‰Ûªre inside the Animal Containment Unit. A scene here on adoption day, with all the animals primping to catch the attention of the one human pair looking for a pet, might well bring a tear to the eye of animal lovers young and old.

While the rescuers are bumbling their way around town, the farmer stumbles into a ridiculous career as a famed hairstylist, using his sheep-shearing skills. But he doesn‰Ûªt realize the source of these skills because the accident that laid him up also cost him his memory.
‰ÛÏShaun the Sheep Movie‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) because when humans bend over, sometimes their pants aren‰Ûªt up to the task of covering their entire backsides.

So it will be interesting to see how much explanatory help, if any, the youngest viewers need to follow the story, but it‰Ûªs perfectly clear to adult eyes. A smart and mischievous sheep named Shaun, feeling held down by the daily routine of the farm and perhaps a bit miffed about being shorn, rallies his flockmates to a mild rebellion that accidentally lands their farmer in a hospital in an anonymous big city.

It wouldn‰Ûªt be summer without a movie that stars one or more animals. ‰ÛÏFree Willy‰Ûù (1993). ‰ÛÏBabe‰Ûù (1995). ‰ÛÏJaws‰Ûù (1975). ‰ÛÏJaws: The Revenge‰Ûù (1987). And now, ‰ÛÏShaun the Sheep Movie,‰Ûù a charming and clever concoction from the stop-motion animation studio Aardman Animations, which is known for the ‰ÛÏWallace & Gromit‰Ûù franchise.

Complications ensue as the assassins face off against Japanese hit men, two-faced informants and a soapy, separated-at-birth subplot that gradually takes center stage. Great care is lavished on shootouts and explosions, but from the beginning, we know that Ahn (Gianna Jun), an army sniper and lead assassin, is the one to watch. If we just keep our eyes on her milky close-ups and handy thigh holster, everything will make sense.
2 hours 20 minutes; not rated
Directed by Choi Dong-hoon
Opens on Friday

Set mainly in the 1930s, when Korea was chafing under Japanese occupation, the story (by the director, Choi Dong-hoon) swings from Seoul to Shanghai as Yem (Lee Jung-jae), an agent of the Korean provisional government, is ordered to assemble a triad of assassins. Their mission is to kill the head of the Japanese occupiers, then strike another blow for freedom by wasting a wealthy collaborator (an enjoyably vile Lee Kyung-young).
In Korean, with English subtitles
ASSASSINATION

Lushly photographed by Kim Woo-hyung, who gives scenes the golden-brown patina of aged copper, ‰ÛÏAssassination‰Ûù has sprinkles of wit and a nicely restrained anchor in Lee Jung-jae. Yem‰Ûªs complicated past has bequeathed him the pained air that women find irresistible, but neither Mr. Lee nor his director exploits this in predictable ways. So when the double-dealing hits the fan, Yem is going to be one of only two people that you‰Ûªd like to see stick around. JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

If you set your mind to it, it‰Ûªs possible to follow the Korean historical drama ‰ÛÏAssassination‰Ûù without taking notes, but I wouldn‰Ûªt recommend it. Brimming with characters ‰ÛÓ many in near-identical military garb ‰ÛÓ and bristling with double crosses, this unnecessarily lengthy homage to resistance chooses breadth over depth at every turn.

Although stand-up comedy is often fueled by anger, the rage expressed in Mr. Crimmins‰Ûªs diatribes knows no bounds. His particular targets are the United States government and the Roman Catholic Church. In the movie‰Ûªs first half, many colleagues give him credit for being a founder and mainstay of the stand-up scene in Boston. The film includes snippets of his notoriously profane stage rants. But not enough of his work is shown to give a satisfying taste of a live performance.

‰ÛÏCall Me Lucky,‰Ûù Bobcat Goldthwait‰Ûªs documentary portrait of his professional mentor, the political comedian Barry Crimmins, is an earnest homage that also honors Mr. Crimmins‰Ûªs crusade to drive child pornography off the Internet.

The Internet was relatively new and largely unregulated in the 1990s, and in those early days chat rooms in which pedophiles exchanged photos and information flourished. In the most devastating scene, Mr. Crimmins, testifying at a 1995 congressional hearing on child pornography, clashes with a clueless executive of AOL, which eventually shut down such chat rooms. For that alone, Mr. Crimmins is a hero.

The movie strains to drum up mystery as to the sources of Mr. Crimmins‰Ûªs rage. When it finally spills the beans, you feel unnecessarily manipulated. Those beans, which have to do with his childhood sexual abuse in the basement of his house, are even more horrifying than most people could imagine. And your heart goes out to Mr. Crimmins, 63, for his courage, honesty and fearless truth-telling.

Reed is working on a teleporting machine that attracts the attention of Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey), who runs some kind of boarding school/research center in Manhattan. There, Reed meets the Storm kids, Sue the scientist (Kate Mara) and Johnny the hot-rodder (Michael B. Jordan), and also a brooding intellectual named Victor von Doom (Toby Kebbell).
‰ÛÏFantastic Four‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Death rays.

Some of us have long memories, though, and can summon the bad cinema of the mid-aughts with furious clarity. Looking back on those days, I remember ‰ÛÓ Jessica Alba. O.K., forget it. I‰Ûªll just go ahead and reboot my 2005 review of the first ‰ÛÏFantastic Four‰Ûù origin story, which I said was ‰ÛÏfantastic only in its commitment to mediocrity.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs still true, though a decade later it‰Ûªs true in different ways. Are you offended that I‰Ûªm recycling material? Sorry, but I‰Ûªm as susceptible to the influence of movies as anyone else.

‰ÛÏFantastic Four,‰Ûù despite the dogged efforts of its talented young cast, has nothing. The special effects are at about the level of the early ‰ÛÏHarry Potter‰Ûù movies ‰ÛÓ lots of glowing green clouds and ice-blue bolts and force fields. The human drama is meager. Once again, the only real pathos belongs to Mr. Bell‰Ûªs Ben, who finds himself trapped in a stony new body and weaponized by a ruthless government. Mr. Teller stretches, not as an actor but as a digitally enhanced body. Mr. Jordan burns in the same way, and Ms. Mara disappears. Her character also has the power to make other things vanish. I would say she should have exercised it on this movie, but in a week or two that should take care of itself.

The opening scenes of ‰ÛÏFantastic Four‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ 20th Century Fox‰Ûªs reboot of its Marvel superhero franchise ‰ÛÓ take place in 2007, which happens to be the year that the second movie in the prerebooted franchise (‰ÛÏRise of the Silver Surfer‰Ûù) was released. Ben Grimm and Reed Richards (played as children by Evan Hannemann and Owen Judge, later by Jamie Bell and Miles Teller) don‰Ûªt mention that fact, because if they did the cinematic universe would collapse on itself and all light would be extinguished from the cosmos. Also, the thoughtful people at Fox probably don‰Ûªt want to remind anyone of those earlier movies.

This ‰ÛÏFantastic Four,‰Ûù directed by Josh Trank from a script he wrote with Simon Kinberg and Jeremy Slater, feels less like a tale of superhero beginnings than like a very long precredit opening sequence. As boys growing up on Long Island, Reed and Ben are brains-and-brawn science-fair buddies.

Much later, after they have traveled to a parallel dimension where a planet full of energy (please just fill in whatever exposition you feel will get you to the next part of this sentence), Victor will face down his erstwhile classmates and say: ‰ÛÏThere is no more Victor. There is only DOOM!‰Ûù There is nothing wrong with that kind of line ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs a newly fledged ultravillain in a comic-book movie, after all ‰ÛÓ but it needs to be earned, with gravity or wit. The best superhero entertainments have both.

The tight-knit bunch range in age from a diaper-clad 1-year-old boy to the caring 13-year-old girl who‰Ûªs in charge. Mom vanishes early, driving off and distressingly ignoring cellphone calls. Her absence casts a shadow that lengthens like the real ones as the day goes on, but the children ‰ÛÓ and the filmmakers ‰ÛÓ create a seemingly oblivious world of make-believe, storytelling, goofing off and hanging out.

The secret may be that the filmmakers seem to let the children‰Ûªs internal dynamics ‰ÛÓ the five kids are the progeny of Mr. Machoian and Rebecca Graham, a fellow writer of the film ‰ÛÓ drive the action and the rapport instead of putting them to work as symbols of freedom or traditional characters. Their blooming personalities (a blustering smart-aleck, a wiry underdog, the patient eldest) come through with a warm and wonderful immediacy.

Directed by Robert Machoian and Rodrigo Ojeda-Beck, ‰ÛÏGod Bless the Child‰Ûù poignantly illustrates what busy, tired parents have told bored offspring for years: You have to make your own fun. This extraordinary movie immerses us in the playtime of five California siblings abandoned to their own devices.

This is like few other movies about children you‰Ûªve seen, resembling Jean-Pierre Gorin‰Ûªs nonfiction classic ‰ÛÏPoto and Cabengo‰Ûù in its wild energies and nuanced staging in depth. But the free-form activity is immediately recognizable to anyone who‰Ûªs gone rambling or scootering, put a squalling baby to sleep with a story (in one scene of nearly Warholian real-time magic) or shared a sourball. Shot with available light, the suburban rambles are portrayed so naturally that it‰Ûªs hard to believe they are scripted.

Mr. Wirthensohn, who has known Mr. Reay since both were models, sees Mr. Reay‰Ûªs life as a metaphor for the vanishing middle class. But Mr. Reay merely comes across as an aging casualty of Manhattan fashion, vainly chasing his fortune in a fickle industry that prizes youth. ‰ÛÏLiving the dream,‰Ûù says a neighbor. If only.

Poignancy and pathos distinguish Thomas Wirthensohn‰Ûªs polished documentary, ‰ÛÏHomme Less,‰Ûù a portrait of Mark Reay, a former model struggling as a photographer. The New Jersey-born Mr. Reay had a moment more than 20 years ago, posing for shoots in Europe. Now in his 50s, he entreats Marc Jacobs for work by leaving a photo of the designer at his office; talks women into posing for him on the street; and works as a day player on movie sets. But the title derives from Mr. Reay‰Ûªs nightly shelter: an East Village rooftop, where he sleeps under a tarpaulin.

The graying, dapper Mr. Reay gets around: In one sequence, he wakes at 6:30 a.m., photographs women on a beach, hits a runway show, attends an art opening and parties with attractive company until after 1 a.m. At other times he edits photos on a laptop at Starbucks, keeps belongings in Y.M.C.A. lockers, jumps a subway turnstile and shaves in a public bathroom. His more dire circumstances contrast with Mr. Wirthensohn‰Ûªs glittering streetscapes and Kyle Eastwood and Matt McGuire‰Ûªs lush jazz score.
‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, including extreme child and cow peril.

They continue to do so in spite of the appearance of the custodian of the car or, really, just Kevin Bacon. He plays Sheriff Kretzer, one of those flamboyantly bad men who are easy to love in movies if not life, and who really, really wants his car back. With his shades and a mustache that rides his lip like a fuzzy frown, Kretzer looks as if he‰Ûªs stepped out of a classic grindhouse flick. Look closer, though, and there‰Ûªs no mistaking that both he and the movie are far slicker than any genuine sticky-carpet fare. ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù may be a streamlined genre exercise, but it‰Ûªs one that, in its self-consciousness and breezy, instrumental violence, overtly and ambitiously announces itself as the latest spawn of neo-exploitation artists like Quentin Tarantino and the early-era Joel and Ethan Coen.

That‰Ûªs the idea, at any rate, although there‰Ûªs not enough personal style or soul in ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù to make it Tarantinoesque or even Coenesque, and not enough wit or joie de vivre either. It‰Ûªs an extremely well-lubricated entertainment machine filled with attractive images and wall-to-wall appealing performances, including from Camryn Manheim and Shea Whigham, an invaluable player. (The directors of photography, Matthew J. Lloyd and Larkin Seiple, do a lot of heavy lifting, as do the editors, Megan Brooks and Andrew Hasse.) Part of what makes ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù such easy viewing is that it doesn‰Ûªt ask much of you narratively or ethically. Mr. Watts, who wrote the screenplay with Christopher Ford, just oils it up, turns the key and goes zoom-zoom, flexing his skills as the audience eats his dust.

More important, they also have Jon Watts, a technically polished director (this is his second feature, after ‰ÛÏClown‰Ûù), who seems to have made a close study of art-house exploitation flicks like ‰ÛÏBlood Simple.‰Ûù From the moment that ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù opens on Travis and Harrison, walking and talking in a parched field, in long shot, dwarfed by distant mountains and the wide-open sky above, it‰Ûªs clear that Mr. Watts knows how to shoot. He also knows when to cut, and a few edits later you‰Ûªre within breathing distance of the children; the spatial configuration has rapidly flipped to a more intimate and conventional one, and now Travis and Harrison loom large in the frame.

When the 10-year-old heroes of ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù first see the cruiser in question, it‰Ûªs parked unattended in a field, ready to be plucked like a daisy. Travis (James Freedson-Jackson) and Harrison (Hays Wellford) make a fine pair of pipsqueaks, and they‰Ûªre on a great journey when they find the car, having run away from home that same day. They have no real reason or complaint or plans, just a single piece of beef jerky and a boy‰Ûªs own sense of adventure.

The film explores the world of obsessive sneaker collecting, where shoes aren‰Ûªt so much worn as stockpiled. The talking heads include Frank Rivera, known as Frank the Butcher, who designed a New Balance sneaker inspired by John F. Kennedy; Hommyo Hidefumi, a leading figure in sneaker culture in Japan; and Russ Bengtson, sneaker editor at Complex magazine, which was involved in producing the film.

Footwear enthusiasts left wanting by ‰ÛÏThe Rise of Sneaker Culture,‰Ûù an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum this summer, can continue exploring that snug niche in ‰ÛÏSneakerheadz,‰Ûù an unrelated, fans-only documentary.

Rapid editing leaves little time to absorb vocabulary (such as ‰ÛÏdeadstock,‰Ûù a new shoe that has never been worn) or intricacies of design. There are few representatives from the major manufacturers (like Nike and Adidas), which are discussed in the way some comic-book readers might speak of Marvel.

Aficionados recall a golden age of collecting before the Internet removed geographic obstacles. The movie draws connections among hip-hop and sports, noting the price fetched at auction by the shoes that an ailing Michael Jordan wore during Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals in 1997, his ‰ÛÏflu game.‰Ûù

Dr. Carolyn Rodriguez, an assistant professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia when the film was made (she is now at Stanford), raises the question of what distinguishes normal collecting from a hoarding disorder. For some sneakerheads, money is apparently no object. There is talk of rowdiness when new shoes become available and deadly altercations over footwear. According to an unattributed title card, ‰ÛÏsneakers are estimated to be responsible for as many as 1,000 deaths per year.‰Ûù If that is true, this documentary buries and tramples the lead.

‰ÛÏThe Diary of a Teenage Girl‰Ûù is rated R. (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian.) The movie has sex scenes between a minor and an adult, as well as drug and alcohol use, seen through a girl‰Ûªs eyes.

Aline shows up just when Minnie needs her, materializing on a street and parked in a diner booth. Charlotte is at once present and not, and few other adults are of any help to Minnie, including her mother‰Ûªs former squeeze, Pascal (Christopher Meloni). Not that Minnie, who keeps her own counsel, no matter how unwise, would pay attention. As the title announces, the movie isn‰Ûªt about the arguments of lawyers, judges or any other guardians of the moral galaxy, any more than it‰Ûªs about questionable child rearing, predatory men and regrettable girlfriends. It is the diary of a specific, complex, sometimes muddled teenager who owns her story, her life and her pleasure, from the moment she says, ‰ÛÏI had sex today,‰Ûù to her rueful, hopeful closing declaration of self.

Using a sharp scalpel, Ms. Heller extracted the story from Phoebe Gloeckner‰Ûªs trippy, autobiographically informed novel of the same title. Both versions of the story follow Minnie as she rides out adolescence, which goes very dark in Ms. Gloeckner‰Ûªs novel. Ms. Heller plays down or elides its more harrowing episodes (rape, hard drugs) and sweetens the overarching narrative by emphasizing its comic absurdity. She also embellishes the movie with cartoon hearts and flowers that wouldn‰Ûªt be out of place in Disney‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSnow White.‰Ûù Truer to the novel‰Ûªs spirit, she brings in (via the animator Sara Gunnarsdottir) an illustrated version of Aline Kominsky-Crumb, a.k.a. Mrs. Crumb, a feminist cartoonist who pops into the picture and functions as part imaginary friend, part groovy fairy godmother.

What you call Monroe, other than an expletive, depends on what you call a man having sex with a 15-year-old girl. ‰ÛÏThe Diary of a Teenage Girl‰Ûù takes place in 1976, when the age of consent in California was 18 (it still is), but it unfolds in an anything-goes milieu in which Monroe might be branded more of an opportunist than a creep. Drinks and pot smoke flow through its rooms, in between snorts of cocaine. Charlotte works as a librarian and parties like, well, someone with no children, having apparently traded in Dr. Spock for Dr. Feelgood. In her hedonism, if mostly in her egotism (it‰Ûªs all about her), Charlotte comes off like a case study for ‰ÛÏThe Culture of Narcissism: American Life in an Age of Diminishing Expectations,‰Ûù Christopher Lasch‰Ûªs 1979 era-defining classic.

The terrific actress Bel Powley was in her early 20s when ‰ÛÏDiary‰Ûù was shot, but looks more like a teenager than most of the generically buffed and prettified adolescents who populate American screens. She has the wide-open look children have before life gets in the way. But she‰Ûªs on the short side and is dwarfed by Kristen Wiig (great), who plays Charlotte, Minnie‰Ûªs boozy, inattentive mother. Ms. Powley looks almost doll-like, Lilliputian, when staring up at Alexander Skarsgard (a perfect worm), who plays Monroe, a mustachioed loafer with pitiful self-improvement plans. He‰Ûªs Charlotte‰Ûªs boyfriend when the movie opens, and he‰Ûªs also sleeping with the very willing, all-too-eager Minnie, although calling him her lover doesn‰Ûªt seem quite right ‰ÛÓ but neither does predator.

It would be easy to call Minnie a victim, and Monroe the villain, even if that‰Ûªs not at all how it plays out in the movie. Monroe may not be exactly the light of Minnie‰Ûªs life, but for much of the story, he is the fire of her loins, to borrow and bend some opening words from Nabokov‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLolita.‰Ûù In the preface to a later edition of her novel, Ms. Gloeckner writes that, in many ways, it is about her, but that it‰Ûªs also about the reader. ‰ÛÏAlthough I am the source of Minnie, she cannot be me ‰ÛÓ for the book to have real meaning, she must be all girls, anyone.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a familiar universal appeal and also insistently political. The novel is life-specific, but what makes Minnie ‰ÛÓ on the page and now on the screen ‰ÛÓ greater than any one girl is how she tells her own story in her own soaringly alive voice.

That wee self is by turns a joy and a heartbreaker, and often an affectingly honest hormone bomb waiting to explode. Minnie looks together when you first meet her, sailing through a city park with a Cheshire cat smile, her saucer eyes bugging as she takes in the local color (facial hair and liberated, jauntily bouncing breasts) that starts to set the freewheeling, at times freaky, San Francisco scene. Once back in her bedroom ‰ÛÓ where a large poster of a bare-chested Iggy Pop watches over her, next to a photo of Janis Joplin ‰ÛÓ Minnie begins making audiotapes, using a recorder as a diary into which she can pour her desires, dreams, fears and thrillingly dirty secrets.

Minnie Goetze, the 15-year-old heroine of ‰ÛÏThe Diary of a Teenage Girl,‰Ûù is a would-be cartoonist who, despite her first name, is closer in lusty spirit and scratchy pen to Robert Crumb than to Walt Disney. When, partway through this gutsy, exhilarating movie, she draws her first cartoon, it‰Ûªs of a bodacious female colossus striding across San Francisco. As this inky giant keeps on trucking, she evokes the 50-foot-woman of cult film fame, if one that has received a Crumb makeover, with thighs as mighty as giant sequoias and a bottom that rolls like a ship in a storm.

The writer-director Marielle Heller doesn‰Ûªt judge the partying; she leaves that to her viewers, assuming that they come to this movie with their own ideas on the subject. She knows you can fill in all kinds of blanks, including the explicit details of Minnie and Monroe‰Ûªs encounters. Her discretion is a commercially expedient choice, of course; Ms. Heller wants to turn you on rather than off. But she also wants to be true to Minnie. Given this, it‰Ûªs important that the one time you see Minnie fully naked is when she‰Ûªs alone with her body and thoughts in her bedroom, gazing into a mirror. She may be the object of Monroe‰Ûªs lust (and he is unambiguously hers), but Ms. Heller ensures that Minnie ‰ÛÓ who‰Ûªs never lighted or framed for the viewer‰Ûªs erotic contemplation ‰ÛÓ isn‰Ûªt ours.

Directed, too earnestly, by Roger Allers and shepherded into being by Salma Hayek ‰ÛÓ who acts as a producer and overacts as the voice of a voluptuous house cleaner ‰ÛÓ this collection of eight mini-sermons falls flat. Liam Neeson‰Ûªs creamy Irish brogue is an odd fit for Mustafa, a Christ-like poet in a fictional Mediterranean village who has been accused of sedition and who, en route to his demise, bursts into parable whenever the opportunity arises. This makes him rather annoying, but opens up the picture to a selection of the world‰Ûªs most talented animators, who illustrate Gibran‰Ûªs philosophies in segments that offer shining relief from the stale, computer-assisted images that tell the main story.

Bursting with color, movement and originality, these stimulating vignettes deserve to be viewed without Gabriel Yared‰Ûªs overbearing score and the occasional sappy song. They also merit a sturdier frame, one that‰Ûªs a little less determined to sanctify its subject.
‰ÛÏKahlil Gibran‰Ûªs The Prophet‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). ‰ÛÏMommy, you can‰Ûªt be killed just for writing something, can you?‰Ûù

On boomer bookshelves the world over, grubby copies of the text, most likely given by a first love, nestle alongside the collected works of Rod McKuen. Our window for welcoming poetry ‰ÛÓ and probably enlightenment ‰ÛÓ is narrow but deep, and any author who slips through it can be life-altering. But ‰ÛÏKahlil Gibran‰Ûªs The Prophet,‰Ûù an animated attempt to turn the essays into a family movie, won‰Ûªt give you goose bumps of nostalgia; it‰Ûªs more likely to put you to sleep.

The burning question during my freshman year in college was whether ‰ÛÏThe Prophet,‰Ûù a slim volume of poetic essays by the early-20th-century Lebanese writer and artist Kahlil Gibran, was more spiritually profound than Captain Beefheart‰Ûªs seminal album, ‰ÛÏTrout Mask Replica.‰Ûù I still haven‰Ûªt decided.

Anyway, Ricki‰Ûªs former spouse, Peter (Kevin Kline), lives in a well-appointed mini-mansion in a gated community, a notable contrast to his ex-wife‰Ûªs rundown, late-with-the-rent California lifestyle. Their daughter, Julie (Mamie Gummer, who is Ms. Streep‰Ûªs daughter in real life), has recently survived a bad divorce and a suicide attempt, and is in need of maternal care. Peter‰Ûªs current wife, Maureen (Audra McDonald), who would have provided that, is traveling, so after some angry exchanges, Ricki takes Julie out for a haircut, a mani-pedi and a clothes-shopping spree with Julie‰Ûªs ex‰Ûªs credit card.

Ricki is played by Meryl Streep, which may be sufficient reason to believe in her. On lead guitar, the Flash features an actual rock star: none other than Rick Springfield. (Go ask your mom. She might still have the poster.) In case you were unclear about the generational profile of this kind of rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll, Mr. Demme provides plenty of shots of jowly, gray-fringed faces onstage and at the bar, and of less-than-limber bodies boogieing on the dance floor. The Flash dabbles in Lady Gaga and Pink to keep the younger customers happy, but the band‰Ûªs collective heart, like the movie‰Ûªs, beats in time to the hits of the ‰Ûª60s, ‰Ûª70s and ‰Ûª80s, when the music, you know, really meant something.

Things go a little less smoothly between Ricki and her sons, Adam and Josh. Josh (Sebastian Stan) is engaged to Emily, a young woman (Hailey Gates) whose face registers the disapproval that everyone else either swallows or expresses through clenched teeth. Adam (Nick Westrate) is gay, which Ricki acknowledges with a cluelessness as dated as her wardrobe.

It‰Ûªs not Mr. Demme‰Ûªs fault that things didn‰Ûªt quite work out that way. But ‰ÛÏRicki and the Flash‰Ûù seems like a squandered opportunity for this humane, curious and liberal-minded filmmaker to reflect on some uncomfortable realities. This isn‰Ûªt really rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll. It‰Ûªs easy listening.
‰ÛÏRicki and the Flash‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Sex, drugs, etc. Go ask your grandparents.

Ricki‰Ûªs attitudes, and their place in the family and the society she inhabits, are the most interesting part of the movie, or at least they would be if Ms. Cody and Mr. Demme were not so weirdly conflict-averse. Ricki is an outspoken Obama-hater with a Tea Party tattoo across her back, and she has no trouble reconciling the rebellious music of the past with right-wing politics in the present. But the actual content of her views is never explored, and the gap between them and those of her abandoned family is hinted at rather than dramatized. A confrontation between Ricki and Maureen ‰ÛÓ a black woman who has been the de facto mother of Ricki‰Ûªs children for most of their lives ‰ÛÓ simmers with all kinds of implications, racial and otherwise. Yet the movie adamantly refuses to go there.

It meant enough to Ricki ‰ÛÓ who used to be known as Linda Brummell ‰ÛÓ that she fled a husband and three children in Indianapolis to pursue her dreams of stardom in California. She never made it big, but she never gave up either, even though her main, meager source of income is a checkout job at a Whole Foods-like supermarket. A family crisis summons her back to Indiana, where she experiences some fish-out-of-water moments. Hoosiers, we‰Ûªre asked to believe, are not used to seeing middle-age adults walking around in zippered leather jackets, multiple earrings and boots, so Ricki gets a lot of quizzical looks. Wait a minute, though: Isn‰Ûªt this John Mellencamp‰Ûªs home state? Axl Rose‰Ûªs too?

‰ÛÏRicki and the Flash,‰Ûù a gentle-hearted baby boomer guilt-trip family drama directed by Jonathan Demme and written by Diablo Cody, is bookended by two musical performances from the rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll bar band that gives the movie its name. It would be a spoiler to say too much about the number that ends the movie, a Bruce Springsteen cover, but the opener, sung to a sparse, appreciative audience at a scruffy club in Tarzana, Calif., is a competent version of an old hit by Tom Petty. (If that name doesn‰Ûªt ring a bell, go ask your dad.) Ricki, the lead singer, sporting a blue Telecaster, heavy eyeliner and half of Bo Derek‰Ûªs haircut from ‰ÛÏ10‰Ûù (ask your dad about that too), belts out the lyrics with perfect credibility, landing somewhere between Chrissie Hynde and Bonnie Raitt on the spectrum of available reference points.

Or anywhere else, really. We don‰Ûªt necessarily need to see Ms. Streep and Ms. McDonald trading slurs and accusations, but two such formidable performers should be allowed to give us something more than tentative, evasive exchanges. Unlike ‰ÛÏRachel Getting Married,‰Ûù Mr. Demme‰Ûªs earlier tale of a wayward relative returning to the family fold, ‰ÛÏRicki and the Flash‰Ûù tiptoes around like a barefoot child afraid to step on a thorn. The redemption in ‰ÛÏRachel‰Ûù felt authentic and hard won, and the film itself, released shortly before the 2008 election, felt like a hopeful premonition of an inclusive, tolerant, forgiving era.

The next day, a bottle of wine is left on their doorstep. It is followed a day or two later by fish deposited in their small front-yard koi pond as a housewarming gift. By then the couple, uneasy about Gordo‰Ûªs too-eager overtures, decide not to pursue the friendship. But Gordo pressures them to be his dinner guests at his luxurious home, which Simon later visits and finds occupied by others with no knowledge of Gordo. The couple‰Ûªs resolve to keep away from Gordo strengthens when a letter arrives from him declaring that he is willing to ‰ÛÏlet bygones be bygones.‰Ûù

Gordo is quite handsome, but dead-eyed and excessively polite in a slightly ominous way. Clearly there is a hidden agenda. When Gordo leaves, Simon, whose memory seems to have been refreshed, recalls their guest‰Ûªs high school nickname, Gordo the Weirdo.

The emotionally fragile Robyn, increasingly unnerved, sets about looking into Simon‰Ûªs past. From one of his high school friends, she pries the story of how Simon, who became president of his class after campaigning with the dictum ‰ÛÏSimon Says‰Ûù as his motto, behaved like a teenage Iago.

Simon is a plum role for Mr. Bateman, who is an expert at playing slightly undersexed nice guys and domesticated husbands while also evoking, when called upon, the demonic underside of smiling cordiality. His subtle performance locates a vague unease and coldness behind Simon‰Ûªs bonhomie. But because the screenplay adroitly adheres to the thriller playbook, you barely notice the danger signs.

The couple are childless. Robyn, depressed after a miscarriage, is anxious and sullen. Simon, a go-getter on the fast track to a promotion at his new job, is an attentive husband, but a little too brusque and beady-eyed for comfort. While shopping for housewares one afternoon, they are approached by a stranger. Introducing himself as Gordo (Mr. Edgerton in a sly, troubling performance), he says he remembers Simon from his high school class. Simon, claiming no recollection, invites Gordo for dinner, and the three spend an uncomfortable evening making awkward conversation.

Even if ‰ÛÏThe Gift,‰Ûù the Australian director Joel Edgerton‰Ûªs creepy stalker thriller, didn‰Ûªt make a dramatic U-turn at around the halfway point, it would still rank as a superior specimen. This movie doesn‰Ûªt foam at the mouth like ‰ÛÏFatal Attraction.‰Ûù No bunnies are boiled. But fish are poisoned, a family dog goes missing and the soundtrack is tricked out with the sudden jolts dear to the genre. Any revenge is more pitiable than cathartic.

Who was he then? And who is he now? I won‰Ûªt elaborate except to say that ‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù insists that leopards don‰Ûªt change their spots: Once a bully, always a bully. A measure of the film‰Ûªs moral seriousness is that it doesn‰Ûªt culminate with a fight to the death in which evil is vanquished, demons are exorcised and virtue triumphs. As the conventions employed to trick us fall away, ‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù emerges as a Hitchcockian exercise in deception that expresses a dour view of the capitalist rat race. The world it portrays is a ruthless arena of winners and losers. The victors will do anything to get ahead and, for an extra thrill, exult in torturing and stomping on the weak.
‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language.

Eventually ‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù abandons its formulaic premise, in which prosperous young adults are menaced by malevolent outside forces, and a subtext reveals itself. The movie morphs into a different subgenre ‰ÛÓ closer in spirit to ‰ÛÏGaslight‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏDial M for Murder‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ in which a frightened wife fears her husband, but that, too, is only suggested before being abandoned. Underneath it all, ‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù is a merciless critique of an amoral corporate culture in which the ends justify the means, and lying and cheating are O.K., as long as they‰Ûªre not found out. Bullying and cruelty are good for business.

The first half of ‰ÛÏThe Gift‰Ûù observes a reasonably happy, attractive couple settling into their beautiful new home in the Hollywood Hills. Simon (Jason Bateman), an executive at a computer security company, and his wife, Robyn (Rebecca Hall), an interior designer, have moved from Chicago to a dream house in Los Angeles, where Simon grew up.

It‰Ûªs 2010, and the Deepwater Horizon oil catastrophe gives Colin a chance to make an impassioned speech that raises his political profile considerably. But it also subjects him to a heightened level of scrutiny, which is a problem, because of his infidelity to his hard-charging wife (Connie Nielsen), and soon he is a former congressman.

In ‰ÛÏThe Runner,‰Ûù a political drama without much drama, Nicolas Cage plays a Louisiana congressman, Colin Pryce, whose personal choices ‰ÛÓ too much alcohol, an affinity for extramarital affairs ‰ÛÓ make him thoroughly unlikable and a walking clichÌ©. It‰Ûªs difficult to feel the sympathy for him that Austin Stark, who wrote and directed, wants us to feel.

It‰Ûªs hard to care, and not just because of Colin‰Ûªs self-destructive tendencies. All of the characters here are underwritten, and Mr. Cage and most of the other actors don‰Ûªt seem to be putting much effort into them. This brand of political soap opera is being done better on television by shows like ‰ÛÏScandal,‰Ûù where this story would be little more than a secondary plotline.
‰ÛÏThe Runner‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and a flash of nudity.

Will Colin be able to salvage his reputation by helping business owners claim reparations from BP? Will he plunge back into politics and take oil money to do so? Will he lose his hard-won sobriety, and will he sleep with his attractive consultant (Sarah Paulson)?

Screening with this feature is ‰ÛÏHappy Mother‰Ûªs Day,‰Ûù a 1963 short that Mr. Leacock made with Joyce Chopra about the Fischer quintuplets of South Dakota, the objects of a media and business frenzy. Like Mr. Leacock‰Ûªs other films, it helps give the ‰ÛÏfeeling of being there‰Ûù that he strove for. In ‰ÛÏHow to Smell a Rose,‰Ûù Mr. Blank and Ms. Leibrecht humbly join their fellow traveling cameraman to explore the feeling of seeing there too.

In the film, the directors visit Mr. Leacock at the home he‰Ûªs made in a Normandy farmhouse with his companion, Valerie Lalonde. Food is the way in for the soft-spoken Mr. Blank, as it has usually been in a filmography that includes Cajuns, bluesmen and beer. Mr. Leacock shops for vegetables and then, in his country kitchen, reminisces about beauty and misadventure in between cooking roast lamb, salmon, pot au feu and caramel. Mr. Blank, an admirer and a master of the hangout, eats it all up.

We hear how Mr. Flaherty impressed on Mr. Leacock the pure and spontaneous power of the image when they collaborated on ‰ÛÏLouisiana Story,‰Ûù a portrait of a bayou oil rig. But it‰Ûªs evident in the excerpts from Mr. Leacock‰Ûªs films shown here, and from observing Mr. Leacock himself, that he had the avid eye and affable awareness for catching the right moments wherever and however they came. So did Mr. Blank: These may be tamer environs than in most of his films, but one fantastic shot here rests on Mr. Leacock‰Ûªs alert eyes, darting back and forth, in his backyard.

Documentary masters like Mr. Leacock and Mr. Blank have long been drawn to filming other artists, even though the enigma of artistic endeavor may appear to elude portrayal on film. But in ‰ÛÏHow to Smell a Rose,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs just as important to feel the relationship between these two, with Mr. Leacock as something of a mentor.

Not bad for someone who grew up on a banana plantation in the Canary Islands. (But then again, that might be exactly what you‰Ûªd expect of such fanciful-sounding origins.) In addition to recounting Mr. Leacock‰Ûªs storied career, ‰ÛÏHow to Smell a Rose‰Ûù is directed (with Gina Leibrecht) by Les Blank, also a prodigiously talented cameraman, whose films simply make you happy to be alive. The same sensation wafts off this breezy final feature from Mr. Blank, who died in 2013 ‰ÛÓ two years after Mr. Leacock.

Through its subject and its maker, ‰ÛÏHow to Smell a Rose‰Ûù puts us in the vibrant presence of documentary history. Ricky Leacock ‰ÛÓ the film‰Ûªs twinkly man of the hour ‰ÛÓ helped pioneer the documentary approach called direct cinema in the 1960s, using portable cameras and synchronized sound to record everyone from John F. Kennedy to a mother of quintuplets. But in his nine decades on earth, Mr. Leacock also apprenticed with Robert J. Flaherty, director of the silent classic documentary ‰ÛÏNanook of the North‰Ûù; shot combat photography in World War II; taught rising filmmakers at M.I.T.; and embraced shooting on video.
‰ÛÏFort Tilden‰Ûù is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nudity, drug use and acutely ribald language.

When Harper (Bridey Elliott), the petulant, chronically impulsive daughter of an affluent father, and Allie (Clare McNulty), her comparatively responsible but equally self-obsessed roommate, meet two guys at a rooftop party in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, they resolve to bicycle the next day to the Fort Tilden beach in Queens to meet them. But en route, they encounter assorted distractions: an errand to score drugs, shopping opportunities, a failed quest for good coffee, a stolen bicycle, a fickle livery-cab driver and a bike collision with a baby carriage whose occupant has parents even more demanding than the young women. (A concerned citizen is played by Jarreau Carrillo.)

Take the potty-mouthed, woman-centric millennial sensibility of HBO‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGirls,‰Ûù turn down the drama and turn up the comic amorality, and you have ‰ÛÏFort Tilden,‰Ûù the highly amusing debut feature from Sarah-Violet Bliss and Charles Rogers. Rarely has a movie so humorously illustrated the meaning of ‰ÛÏfrenemy.‰Ûù

This picaresque lark benefits from sunny locations, a percolating rhythm and the tart chemistry of its principals. Ms. McNulty, a skillful performer in her own right, must take a back seat to Ms. Elliott, an Upright Citizens Brigade regular and the daughter of the comedian Chris Elliott. Her fearless willingness to embody venality has a magnetism all its own.
Allie, who skips a job interview with the Peace Corps, resents pestering calls from her point of contact; Harper ‰ÛÓ well, she‰Ûªs just annoyed by anything smacking of personal accountability.
‰ÛÏWe can‰Ûªt just decide who lives and who dies!‰Ûù one character says in ‰ÛÏAir.‰Ûù

Bauer and Cartwright awaken occasionally to monitor conditions, then return to hypersleep. When Cartwright‰Ûªs sleeping chamber is damaged, they must secure another before the ambient air is exhausted.

Mr. Reedus and Mr. Hounsou fill the screen well enough for a movie with just two main characters (Sandrine Holt plays a small supporting role), while the claustrophobic mood conceals the low budget. Yet the script would benefit from more moments when hard questions are considered and unexpected actions are taken. Sure, it can be difficult for a character to make a tough choice. But for an audience, that‰Ûªs one of the best things to watch.
Yet if he doesn‰Ûªt choose, we‰Ûªre told, he will perish. ‰ÛÏYou need to pick one,‰Ûù his partner replies. ‰ÛÏRight now.‰Ûù

In that scene and others, juicy dilemmas are dangled in front of the audience, then disappointingly yanked away. (Wait, ‰ÛÏthere‰Ûªs another way,‰Ûù the first character soon says.) After a while, you learn to stop salivating.

‰ÛÏAir,‰Ûù written by Chris Pasetto and Christian Cantamessa, introduces some interesting notions, not the least of which is that the privileged sleepers survive only because of two working-class men. But once an idea is introduced, it‰Ûªs tossed aside, unexplored; though there‰Ûªs plenty of talk, this isn‰Ûªt exactly a sci-fi ‰ÛÏMy Dinner With Andre.‰Ûù Tense music substitutes for genuine tension.
‰ÛÏAir‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, language and sexual references.

‰ÛÏAir‰Ûù is set in an underground missile silo where two men, Bauer (Norman Reedus of ‰ÛÏThe Walking Dead‰Ûù) and Cartwright (Djimon Hounsou of ‰ÛÏBlood Diamond‰Ûù), keep ‰ÛÏthe last remnants of human civilization‰Ûù alive. Earth‰Ûªs air is ruined, and the men care for a collection of people who sleep in suspended animation.

But the film rests on the attractive but opaque Ms. Thorne, who is not ready for such weight. Commendably, she stretches her acting muscles, but Hazel‰Ûªs internal struggle remains elusive. Viewers need more to connect with.

The actress Bella Thorne (‰ÛÏThe Duff‰Ûù; MTV‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏScream‰Ûù) dips her toes into grown-up desert noir with ‰ÛÏBig Sky,‰Ûù a lean exercise that leaves her over her head. Ms. Thorne plays Hazel, a teenager with acute agoraphobia and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Her lonely, mildly disheveled mother, Dee (Kyra Sedgwick), is accompanying her to a treatment center when the van carrying Hazel, Dee and four others is violently ambushed in a sandy wasteland. (The film was shot in New Mexico.) Their assailants are kidnappers (Aaron Tveit and Frank Grillo) who believe they have killed all the passengers save their quarry (Jodi Lynn Thomas), whom they stick in a car trunk. But Dee, though shot, is still alive, and Hazel, who has witnessed the carnage from a concealed spot, must surmount her fears to seek help in the wilderness.

The movie bears a sheen belying its low budget, and the director, Jorge Michel Grau, working with the cinematographer Santiago SÌÁnchez, skillfully suggests the vertiginous unease Hazel experiences with her tentative steps into the vast, threatening landscape. Ms. Sedgwick blends working-class sass and maternal backbone, and Mr. Tveit and Mr. Grillo, playing half brothers, have a convincing rapport. The script, by Evan M. Wiener, coheres, though it uses the overfamiliar ‰ÛÏMexican standoff‰Ûù in its climax.

Charlie speaks in double talk. Announcing the end of her marriage to Will, she says she loves him. ‰ÛÏThe problem is I don‰Ûªt love my life,‰Ûù she explains. A whiny, high-strung control freak and compulsive scold, she is such a pill that you wonder what the brokenhearted Will, who moves to Astoria, Queens, could possibly have seen in her. The story jumps ahead a year. After class one afternoon, Will is approached by Kat (Jessica Williams), a talented student who offers to introduce him to her beautiful 45-year-old mother, Diane (Regina Hall), a teacher of American literature at Columbia. When they meet, it is obvious that they are compatible. At the very moment when ‰ÛÏPeople Places Things‰Ûù has a chance to soar, it turns prissy, indecisive and picayune. The story meanders along with too-cute scenes of Will bonding with his daughters. Meanwhile, Charlie, now pregnant, plans to get married.

From its opening moments, ‰ÛÏPeople Places Things‰Ûù seems at odds with itself. It is realistic about New York place names yet disconnected from reality. Will, who is handsome in an appealingly scruffy way, is a faithful husband with a warm, self-deprecating sense of humor and an acute roving intelligence. Only a fool would trade him for Gary, a glum, pudgy blob. Although this cowering, monosyllabic marshmallow makes several more appearances in the film, Mr. Strouse‰Ûªs screenplay doesn‰Ûªt give him a single likable trait.

As the movie fizzles, Mr. Clement‰Ûªs endearing performance breathes what little life is left into a movie that, much like the insufferable Charlie, can‰Ûªt make up its mind about where to go or how to get there.

The story begins at a fifth birthday party for Will‰Ûªs twin daughters (Gia and Aundrea Gadsby) in his family‰Ûªs Brooklyn brownstone. In the middle of the celebration, Will goes upstairs and finds his wife, Charlie (Stephanie Allynne), having sex with their friend Gary (an ill-used Michael Chernus), an Off Broadway performance artist.
‰ÛÏPeople Places Things‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language, mild sexual situations and brief nudity.

The fleeting pleasures of ‰ÛÏPeople Places Things,‰Ûù Jim Strouse‰Ûªs winsome trifle of a comedy, derive almost entirely from the charm of its star, Jemaine Clement, the New Zealand-born actor best known in America as one-half of the musical comedy duo Flight of the Conchords.

Mr. Clement plays Will, a married 40-year-old graphic novelist and teacher of comic book art whose college classes are perceptive, witty mini-essays on drawing and narrative (illustrated by Mr. Strouse, a faculty member at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan).
The stakes become higher when William gets out of prison. Nick Nolte does nice work as Miranda‰Ûªs father, who is drawn into the evolving cat-and-mouse game.

Having carefully built tension, the movie, written by Patricia Beauchamp and Joe Gossett, doesn‰Ûªt seem to know what to do with it. The film ends on a note that is supposed to be disquieting but registers more as: ‰ÛÏWhat? Is it over?‰Ûù

Ms. Pike is Miranda, a nurse who loses her bearings after she is raped. This is not the fantasy rape that used to be popular in bodice-ripping novels, where a dashing, strong-willed man forces himself on a maiden who actually pines for him. It‰Ûªs a violent, terrifying attack, and the director, Fouad Mikati, portrays it vividly.

For most of the way, ‰ÛÏReturn to Sender‰Ûù merges creepy and sexy to good effect, thanks to a close-to-the-vest performance by Rosamund Pike, the missing wife of ‰ÛÏGone Girl.‰Ûù The story works an old and distasteful trope ‰ÛÓ the rape victim who falls for the attacker ‰ÛÓ but the treatment is restrained rather than salacious.

So it is eerie when Miranda, after her rapist (Shiloh Fernandez) is convicted and sentenced, begins visiting him in prison. Ms. Pike keeps you guessing as to whether Miranda is actually interested in rehabilitating and perhaps becoming involved with him, or is just baiting a trap for him once he is released. Mr. Fernandez, too, has to invest his character, William, with two possibilities. He might be repentant, or he might just be the same old brute with an improved ability to disguise himself.

A pocket-size pleasure, the French movie ‰ÛÏThe Great Man‰Ûù opens with a fairy-tale flourish as a child narrator winds up the once-upon-a-time. The movie then takes a break in a war zone, where a monster with glowing eyes briefly sends it into fantasy and a wounded soldier yanks it back to terra firma. Not long after, swells of emotion seep in like low-rolling fog and suddenly you are watching a drama about real people wrestling with life blow by blow.

The filmmaker Sarah Leonor has a keen eye and a gentle, unassuming touch. In ‰ÛÏThe Great Man,‰Ûù she discreetly changes moods and storytelling modes like a pianist sliding her hand down a short, soft glissando. She has a graphic visual style, if one that loosens over the course of the movie, but she isn‰Ûªt a show-off. You notice how she arranges soldiers in an overhead shot, lining them up like dolls or bowling pins. Yet she doesn‰Ûªt linger over the image, like one of those directors who hold on a shot to make sure you can admire its every detail. Ms. Leonor isn‰Ûªt interested in the hard sell; she lets you wander into the story, discover it, savor it.

About an hour into the movie, a tragedy upends the scrupulously arranged parts. By that point, Markov and Hamilton, who‰Ûªs been enduring a difficult convalesce in a military hospital, have been happily reunited. It‰Ûªs also around then that Ms. Leonor, who slips little complications into the story as it unfolds (Chechnya figures in the mix, as does Markov‰Ûªs dead wife), risks gumming up the works by having one man give his identity papers to the other. After an accident, this exchange, however, leads to another, more profound trade that transforms ‰ÛÏThe Great Man‰Ûù into an emotionally affecting and gently political exploration of identity, trauma and the limits of empathy. It‰Ûªs a modest stunner that‰Ûªs so suffused with generous humanity that you‰Ûªre never sure who the title actually refers to.

It‰Ûªs in Afghanistan that the soldiers confront the monster, a big wild cat whose ominous ember eyes prefigure graver dangers. And it‰Ûªs there, too, while hunting the cat (at behest of the locals), that Hamilton and Markov stumble into an ambush. Hamilton is badly wounded and dragged to safety by Markov, who leaves his gear and gun behind in order to carry his friend to safety. In this soldier‰Ûªs world abandoning a gun, for the higher-ups, trumps saving a comrade. Which is why after his five-year stint, Markov returns to civilian life, resumes using his real name ‰ÛÓ Mourad Massaev ‰ÛÓ and reunites with his 10-year-old son, Khadji (Ramzan Idiev), a child who‰Ûªs a near stranger. The two warily circle each other before settling into the kind of easy rapport that Markov once had with Hamilton.

The story beings with two Foreign Legion soldiers, Hamilton (a superb JÌ©rÌ©mie Renier) and Markov (Surho Sugaipov, very fine), best friends stationed in Afghanistan. Similar in stature, compact physique and closely shorn hair, the two men do everything together, from patrolling the desert terrain in formation to spit-polishing their boots across from each other. Like an image and its shadow, they fit seamlessly, with gestures and movements that follow the same choreography. If they don‰Ûªt say much it‰Ûªs because the narrator, an unnamed boy (his identity obscured for maximum emotional impact) who introduces Hamilton and Markov, is doing all the talking. There‰Ûªs a casual intimacy to this show-and-tell passage, as if the boy were reading aloud a bedtime story that he knew by heart.

The core of the movie, adapted from a play by Michel Marc Bouchard, who shares a screenwriting credit with Mr. Dolan, is the relationship between the bullying Francis and the sultry Tom, whom he torments with a heavy undertone of flirtation. Eventually Sara is summoned to the farm by Tom, at which point the movie loses some coherence. As Tom, Francis, and Sara (Ìävelyne Brochu) dance around one another, you expect them to form a diabolical Pinteresque triangle, but her arrival comes too late in the movie for it to amount to much. When Francis orders her around with the same tone of brusque authority that he uses to coerce Tom, she will have none of it.

Tom‰Ûªs destination is the dairy farm where Guillaume grew up and where his mother, Agathe (Lise Roy), lives with Guillaume‰Ûªs older brother, Francis (Pierre-Yves Cardinal). How and why Guillaume died, at 25, is never explained, but we learn late in the movie that he was a wild creature who slept with everybody.
The most telling repeated gesture of humiliation and arousal is a light slap across the face. Francis applies it to Tom, and Agathe to Francis, and Mr. Dolan to us.

The screenplay idly plays with the concept of stolen identity when Tom dresses in Francis‰Ûªs clothes, and you half-expect the movie to turn into a latter-day ‰ÛÏThe Talented Mr. Ripley.‰Ûù For at heart, ‰ÛÏTom at the Farm‰Ûù is a dark comedy about playing games of dress-up: musical, sexual and directorial.

What unfolds on the farm is a kinky, suspenseful, psychosexual drama that suggests a hybrid of Harold Pinter and Sam Shepard joined to a sadomasochistic fantasy in which the hunky, homophobic Francis plays sexy mind games with Tom, who becomes his willing captive. He even allows Francis to beat him up.

‰ÛÏTom at the Farm,‰Ûù the fourth film from the 26-year-old French Canadian wunderkind Xavier Dolan, is a teasing exercise in unfettered narcissism that sticks its out tongue out and goes, ‰ÛÏNyah, nyah, nyah‰Ûù as if it were a 5-year-old running wild on a sugar high. I should add that the movie, completed in 2013 and just now being released, is wildly entertaining, sexy and beautifully shot in the Canadian heartland.

From the outset, ‰ÛÏTom at the Farm‰Ûù is slathered in a feverish hyper-romantic orchestral score by Gabriel Yared (‰ÛÏThe English Patient‰Ûù) that incorporates a fragment of Arnold Schoenberg‰Ûªs early pre-12-tone masterwork, ‰ÛÏVerklÌ_rte Nacht.‰Ûù Written when the composer was roughly the same as age as Mr. Dolan, it expresses a boundless intensity that matches the sensibility of a filmmaker who fearlessly embraces extremes. The movie‰Ûªs musical bookends are the ultraromantic ‰ÛÏThe Windmills of Your Mind‰Ûù (sung in French) and Rufus Wainwright‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGoing to a Town,‰Ûù which asks, ‰ÛÏDo you really think you go to hell for having loved?‰Ûù

Mr. Dolan, with tousled bleached blond hair and a saucy pout, is front and center as Tom, a pretty young man who drives from Montreal to attend the funeral of his boyfriend, Guillaume, in the Canadian equivalent of the Bible Belt. Throughout the movie, shot by AndrÌ© Turpin, Mr. Dolan uses the camera for unabashed self-adoration.

Francis is desperate to keep Agathe from finding out that her golden younger son was gay. Francis has convinced Agathe that a friend of Guillaume, Sara, was the love of his life and was devastated by his death. Agathe then wonders bitterly why she didn‰Ûªt come to the funeral. Underneath her air of propriety, Agathe has a pornographic imagination that is revealed in a bizarre conversation in which Tom graphically describes a sexual situation involving Sara, and Agathe roars with laughter about what a ‰ÛÏslut‰Ûù Sara must be.

Blindingly beautiful and meticulously assembled by the award-winning editor Bob Eisenhardt, ‰ÛÏMeru‰Ûù easily makes you forget that what you are watching is completely bananas. Having failed to reach the summit in 2003, Mr. Anker returned in 2008, accompanied by his longtime climbing partner Jimmy Chin (who directed the film with his wife, Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi) and the young climber and artist Renan Ozturk.

That expedition, and a later one in 2011, bookend a middle section that‰Ûªs every bit as tense as the two ascents. Yet it‰Ûªs not only the near-fatal mishaps and knife-edged escapes that ultimately make ‰ÛÏMeru‰Ûù so compelling. Assisted by essential commentary from the author Jon Krakauer, the directors poke at the psychology of extremity, zeroing in on push-the-limits personalities for whom calculating risk is a way of life.

Thankfully free of the usual triumph-of-the-will score, ‰ÛÏMeru‰Ûù is an ultrasmooth blend of conventional documentary techniques ‰ÛÓ the talking-head interview; the back-in-the-day photograph ‰ÛÓ and uncommon ambition. The immediacy and clarity of the images (Mr. Chin and Mr. Ozturk did most of the filming) is critical, capturing the grandeur of the Himalayas in shots both mystical and menacing. So when Mr. Krakauer describes the mountain‰Ûªs location as ‰ÛÏthe point where heaven and earth and hell all come together,‰Ûù his meaning could not be clearer.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). White storms and blackened toes.

Jenni Lowe-Anker, Mr. Anker‰Ûªs wife and the widow of his mentor, Alex Lowe, understands the draw of danger so well that she didn‰Ûªt plan to fall for another climber. ‰ÛÏI still think I might‰Ûªve been better off with a cowboy,‰Ûù she tells us, smiling. Some might say that‰Ûªs exactly what she got.

What makes a man want to haul 200 pounds of equipment more than 20,000 feet above sea level in well-below-zero temperatures? Watching Bear Grylls rappel cheerily down a cliff face doesn‰Ûªt prepare us for the blizzards and avalanches, frostbite and trench foot visited on our three daredevils, all of whom brave terrifying events with enviable composure. The audience might not feel so Zen-like: When the camera places you inside a tiny tent that‰Ûªs seemingly dangling in midair, listening to shards of ice batter the roof, you‰Ûªll be very glad to feel the theater seat beneath your behind.

To dedicated mountaineers, an unconquered ‰ÛÓ and believed unconquerable ‰ÛÓ peak is an irresistible, insistent taunt on their to-do lists. ‰ÛÏMeru‰Ûù is the story of one such peak, the notorious Shark‰Ûªs Fin atop Mount Meru in India and the pea beneath the mattress of the climber Conrad Anker.

Brooke, when first seen, appears to lead a charmed life at the center of a traveling three-ring circus. A gleaming electropop score by Dean Wareham and Britta Phillips gives you a sense of teetering on a merry-go-round. Brooke, 30, has a million grand schemes, of which the most urgent is her plan to open a restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with the backing of a Greek boyfriend, Stavros. This future eatery, Mom‰Ûªs, is a combination bistro, hair salon, art gallery and homey retreat for the hipoisie. And while juggling to keep many balls in the air, she still has the time to lead a spin class.

Mamie-Claire and Nicolette are two of the meanest female characters to be found in a contemporary film, especially one with an upscale, literary setting. Shallow, treacherous, jealous and vindictive, they cast a pall of ill will over a film that can‰Ûªt transcend the petty demons nipping at its characters‰Ûª heels. Levity is just not Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs thing.

The story is sporadically narrated by the 18-year-old Tracy (Lola Kirke), Brooke‰Ûªs soon-to-be-stepsister, whose mother, Stevie (Kathryn Erbe), is about to marry Brooke‰Ûªs widowed father. Tracy, who wants to be a writer, has just begun her first semester in college and is deeply disappointed in higher education. Bored with her classes, she has few friends and is rejected for membership in a prestigious literary society. Brooke, whom she first meets in Times Square, pulls Tracy out of her slump, and the pair become gal pals. In Brooke, Tracy finally has an interesting subject to write about.

Brooke‰Ûªs bubble begins to burst when Stavros abruptly pulls out of the restaurant deal, and Brooke, facing a very short deadline, has to scrounge for other investors. In desperation, she gathers a posse that includes Tracy, Tracy‰Ûªs literary-minded classmate Tony (Matthew Shear), and Tony‰Ûªs sullen, fiercely possessive girlfriend, Nicolette (Jasmine Cephas Jones). Together they drive to Greenwich, Conn., to entreat Brooke‰Ûªs rich ex-boyfriend Dylan (Michael Chernus) to save the day.

What distinguishes Brooke from most New York women on a fast track is her willful naÌøvetÌ©. She talks a mile a minute, but is neither a shameless name-dropper nor a compulsive networker. Even when disparaging someone else, she doesn‰Ûªt sound bitchy so much as mystified.

As in all of Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs films, the characters are nervous, insecure and acutely self-conscious. Even in the climactic comic set piece of sustained, high-velocity banter, the rat-a-tat-tat dialogue is tense and seamed with hostility, suspicion and hidden agendas.

A blubbery nice guy who doesn‰Ûªt lord his wealth over others, Dylan hasn‰Ûªt seen Brooke since her former best friend and nemesis Mamie-Claire (Heather Lind) stole him from her, along with her idea for a T-shirt from which she earned a handsome profit. When the posse appears at the door of Dylan‰Ûªs mansion, a scowling Mamie-Claire answers the door.

The characters include one authentic madcap in the classic screwball tradition of Carole Lombard and Jean Arthur. Brooke (Greta Gerwig), a peripatetic New York gal about town and dynamic human whirligig is the movie‰Ûªs captivating energy source. Spectacularly embodied by Ms. Gerwig, who wrote the screenplay with Mr. Baumbach, she is a movie archetype out of time, and Ms. Gerwig‰Ûªs charm is such that she makes Brooke lovable even when she‰Ûªs behaving like a flake.

Far from romanticizing creativity and the artistic process, Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs films portray the world of painters, filmmakers and literati as an overcrowded, amoral jungle of viperish entitled narcissists stealing from one another for fame and profit. Overweening personal ambition trumps the possibility of joy, an emotion seldom seen in a Baumbach movie.

Beginning with Mr. Baumbach‰Ûªs 2007 film, ‰ÛÏMargot at the Wedding,‰Ûù the concept of artistic appropriation and the piracy of inspiration has loomed large in the director‰Ûªs canon. But in the backbiting world of ‰ÛÏMistress America,‰Ûù it is understood that you do what you have to do to get ahead, even if it means sacrificing a friendship.

Noah Baumbach‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMistress America‰Ûù advertises itself as a screwball comedy. But this smart, fast-paced film is not really the zany, lighter-than-air divertissement that the term usually conjures. There are scattered sharp one-liners, but not enough to infuse the movie with a sustained bonhomie. It‰Ûªs fair to say that ‰ÛÏMistress America‰Ûù revises and subverts this most buoyant of genres with a steady undertow of anxiety, dread and anger.
‰ÛÏMistress America‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language, including some sexual references.

It was his partnership with Booker T. Washington, though, that made the greatest impact, creating more than 5,300 schools in the Jim Crow South. At one point in the pre-civil rights era, it was estimated, one in three black youths in the South attended a Rosenwald school.

If Rosenwald is not well known today, that is partly because of his belief that foundations should not be self-perpetuating; the Rosenwald Fund closed in 1948, 16 years after his death. All the more reason, then, to thank Ms. Kempner for this rich and fascinating biography.

For the documentary ‰ÛÏRosenwald,‰Ûù the director, Aviva Kempner (‰ÛÏYoo-Hoo, Mrs. Goldberg‰Ûù), interviews historians, civil rights leaders and Rosenwald family members to draw a stirring portrait of a modest yet moral man committed to the Jewish concept of tikkun olam ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏrepairing the world.‰Ûù Rosenwald school alumni like Maya Angelou and Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, recall their clean, bright havens. Moreover, Ms. Kempner widens her focus on Rosenwald‰Ûªs time and the context and consequences of his charity. We learn about the rise of Sears; about Chicago‰Ûªs vibrant Rabbi Emil G. Hirsch, an adviser to Rosenwald; about the amazing Tuskegee Institute.

In the first half of the 20th century, Julius Rosenwald was not only a leading businessman ‰ÛÓ the chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, one of the country‰Ûªs wealthiest men ‰ÛÓ but a leading philanthropist and civil rights advocate as well. With challenge grants, he spurred the building of Y.M.C.A.s that would accept blacks as residents; his Rosenwald Fund dispensed fellowships for a who‰Ûªs who of black artists and academics, from W. E. B. Du Bois to James Baldwin.

The film, geared to devotees rather than general viewers, centers on the music and dance of the tango and posits that this Latin American art form has deep roots in Africa. According to interviews with a few musicologists, historians and percussionists, slaves who were brought to Argentina and Uruguay introduced the beats that underlie the rhythm.

Visuals are also allowed to wander, with pleasant yet aimless footage of cities, rivers and street musicians. It‰Ûªs as if Mr. Pedro were one of those peppy neighbors who simply must show you all the video he took on his latest vacation, outtakes and all.

An interesting idea is overexplained in the documentary ‰ÛÏTango Negro: The African Roots of Tango.‰Ûù Here, theories that are worth voicing are apparently worth repeating, and beats that sound catchy are sure to be replayed many times.

The most intriguing scenes in ‰ÛÏTango Negro‰Ûù are when the film traces the influence of immigration and slavery on South America, then explores the concept that cultures pass on information through art. But if at first you miss that section, don‰Ûªt worry ‰ÛÓ you‰Ûªll see and hear it again.

Aided by plenty of music (though not enough dance), the director Dom Pedro sets a breezy tone. Though the theory that tango has African origins is said to be controversial, no one is presented to challenge that view. Most irksome, friendly interviewees are permitted to chatter on for long stretches as they circle the subject and then stray into other topics.

If you are one of those people who romanticize the East Village in New York when it was at its grungiest, ‰ÛÏTen Thousand Saints‰Ûù might be the movie of your dreams. Even if you‰Ûªre not, it‰Ûªs still a very fine film, full of quietly impressive performances and young characters who register as authentic.

When Jude‰Ûªs aimlessness takes a tragic turn, his mother (Julianne Nicholson) sends him to live with his estranged father, Les, adroitly played by Ethan Hawke. It‰Ûªs a curious way to rescue a young person headed down a dubious path; Les lives in the East Village, cultivates an illegal crop and is the type of parent who scolds a son because the pot he scored wasn‰Ûªt high-grade enough.
Also central to the story are Eliza (Hailee Steinfeld), the daughter of Les‰Ûªs girlfriend, and Johnny (Emile Hirsch), Teddy‰Ûªs half brother.
‰ÛÏTen Thousand Saints‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and drug use.

The film, directed by Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini and based on the novel by Eleanor Henderson, takes us back to the late 1980s, when clubs like CBGB were the place to be in the East Village, and the neighborhood‰Ûªs unwashed ambience was beginning to be threatened by gentrification. But the story starts in Vermont, a considerably greener place than Manhattan, yet one with its own set of problems. A teenager named Jude (Asa Butterfield of ‰ÛÏEnder‰Ûªs Game‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏHugo‰Ûù) embodies a number of them, spending his days huffing with his friend Teddy (Avan Jogia).

This is a coming-of-age story for all the young characters involved, but it‰Ûªs more. It catches a moment in time for both the East Village and the overall cultural landscape, one that builds to the Tompkins Square disturbance of 1988, when the old East Village collided violently with the East Village of the future. As Jude and Eliza find themselves in its midst, the film completes its mission, deftly telling a small story in the context of a larger one, and vice versa.

At times ‰ÛÏThe Man From U.N.C.L.E.‰Ûù works better as a fashion show than a movie, with a wardrobe ‰ÛÓ Mary Quant-like minis, form-fitting bespoke suits, a caftan that Jean Shrimpton could have worn (a few years later) for a Vogue shoot ‰ÛÓ that expresses more about the era than anything in the script. (The costume designer is Joanna Johnston.) Mr. Ritchie tends to flaunt his wares like a store clerk, fawning over the clothes, chairs and cars, and his usual rabbity pace slows to a tortoiselike crawl whenever the actors deliver a lot of words, which gratefully isn‰Ûªt often. His talent, as he proves repeatedly, is making bodies and cars crash through space, and there‰Ûªs a long, divertingly twisty and wordless chase near the end that suggests he would have just killed in Mack Sennett‰Ûªs studio.
‰ÛÏThe Man From U.N.C.L.E.‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Bloodless mayhem.

Gaby also serves as the political football in the opener, which finds Napoleon coercing her to go over the wall in the name of the greater good or some such. First, though, they need to outmaneuver Illya, which they do in one of those Tom-and-Jerry chases that nicely shows off the stunt performers‰Ûª wheel skills in providentially emptied streets. Written by Mr. Ritchie and Lionel Wigram, the movie throws out a lot of plot, most of which disintegrates on impact but pragmatically leads to Napoleon, Illya and Gaby in cahoots. Locations change as fast as the actors‰Ûª outfits, and at one point Hugh Grant shows up at the races as does another attraction, the villainous Victoria (Elizabeth Debicki), who brings to mind by turns a lost Redgrave relative and Madonna, Mr. Ritchie‰Ûªs ex.

Guy Ritchie makes the kind of enjoyably disreputable movies that are fun to watch until they‰Ûªre not. He‰Ûªs a talented flimflam artist and, for the industry, I imagine, a useful one because of how he glosses up schlocky, sketchy projects (his ‰ÛÏSherlock Holmes‰Ûù movies and other hyperkinetic baubles), making them seem as if there‰Ûªs more to their slick surfaces than naked commercialism, agency fees and facile pleasure. It works for him (he keeps getting hired), and sometimes also for us. Pleasure is, after all, rarely overrated, including in the often mind-bludgeoning arena of franchise cinema, and there‰Ûªs a lot to be said for watching beautiful people doing very silly stuff on screen.

His latest, ‰ÛÏThe Man From U.N.C.L.E.,‰Ûù is, as its title trumpets, a big-screen rendering of that 1960s television series. Running from 1964 to ‰Ûª68, the show centered on a pair of operatives, an American, Napoleon Solo (named by Ian Fleming, an early creative adviser, and played with unctuous suavity by Robert Vaughn), and his nimble Soviet counterpart, Illya Kuryakin (a professionally enigmatic David McCallum, working a blond Beatle fringe and contrasting turtlenecks). In a flourish of showbiz dÌ©tente, the spies have been teamed to fight one of those fictional criminal outfits (T.H.R.U.S.H.) that make it seem as if real-world villainy can be handled with little more than charm and Zippo lighters that fire bullets. The television series is a goof, and a fig leaf for Cold War dread.

The movie opens in 1963 but tries hard not to be a museum piece, partly with a slick, agitated style. It revs up in the vicinity of Checkpoint Charlie, somewhere in East Berlin, but stays there only long enough to crash some cars and pick up the actress Alicia Vikander. She plays Gaby, one of those amusingly all-purpose characters who, in addition to having some useful relatives ‰ÛÓ her father is a nuclear physicist, her uncle an unreconstructed Nazi ‰ÛÓ can fix a car engine, slip into a couture outfit and snap a flaccid line to life. Mostly, she is the regulation Girl and narrative bridge uniting the new Napoleon (Henry Cavill, a charming stiff who seems mostly interested in trying to mimic Mr. Vaughn‰Ûªs staccato) with the new Illya (Armie Hammer, easier on the eyes than ears).

Planes also figure heavily in Mr. Sauper‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWe Come as Friends,‰Ûù a follow-up of sorts to ‰ÛÏNightmare‰Ûù that can stand on its own or play as a riveting and damning companion piece. Although it lacks a big hungry fish, the guiding metaphor is also the stuff of science fiction. Crisscrossing Sudan before and after South Sudan declared its independence in a 2011 referendum, Mr. Sauper likens his perspective (and that of the audience) to that of an alien approaching a planet called Africa. ‰ÛÏWe come as friends‰Ûù is the suspect message of the investors we see in the film. Part of the argument here is that South Sudanese independence was heavily driven by outside forces because of the potential for profit from development.

In ‰ÛÏDarwin‰Ûªs Nightmare‰Ûù (2005), a searing Oscar-nominated documentary about economic exploitation in Tanzania, the director Hubert Sauper found a perfect microcosm for colonialism in the invasive Nile perch. The fish was artificially introduced into Lake Victoria in the 1950s and ‰Ûª60s, ate all the other fish and then was exported as food for Europe and Japan. In the meantime, Tanzania suffered from a famine, and as the film repeatedly sought to demonstrate, the planes arriving to pick up the fish sometimes brought in weapons for use in the continent‰Ûªs civil wars.
The movie suggests that the benefits are decidedly skewed.

Mr. Sauper gets further grist for his sci-fi conceit in a scene that shows Chinese oil workers watching ‰ÛÏStar Wars,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ2001: A Space Odyssey‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏStar Trek.‰Ûù (‰ÛÏWe come in peace,‰Ûù Captain Kirk is seen saying. ‰ÛÏBut we‰Ûªll defend ourselves if necessary.‰Ûù)

Piloting an ultralight tin can of an airplane nicknamed Sputnik that he designed for filming the movie, Mr. Sauper produces the sort of angled aerial footage that you might associate with ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now.‰Ûù With an eye for landscapes stunning and hellish, he is the rare documentary filmmaker who not only takes on tough subjects but also explores them with a vivid visual and aural approach. Beginning with the steel railroad tracks cut through the region in the Victorian era, the movie draws a through line to the bulldozers of the present day.

Working in a surreally inflected vÌ©ritÌ© style ‰ÛÓ with few title cards or identifications other than what is spoken on screen ‰ÛÓ Mr. Sauper also has a knack for catching his subjects in unguarded moments. A British bomb disposal expert wonders about the locals‰Ûª capabilities: ‰ÛÏThere must be a reason they‰Ûªre still 200 years behind the rest of the world.‰Ûù A Christian missionary from the United States calls South Sudan ‰ÛÏNew Texas.‰Ûù Another says that the Toposa people of South Sudan ‰ÛÏdon‰Ûªt understand property ownership the way you and I do.‰Ûù A United Nations representative seems unusually concerned with oil. Foreigners are shown partying like frat boys when the country declares its independence.

The more skeptical of the Sudanese talk of poisoned water, being cheated out of their land and the barriers to communication. In one of many bleakly comic moments, a South Sudanese lawmaker who wants residents to lease their property mumbles his way through the national anthem. Peripherally, there are sound bites from Hillary Clinton, who says that ‰ÛÏmore and more, the world will look to Africa to be its breadbasket,‰Ûù and expresses hope that Africans will profit from that.

Running through the movie is an insistent, underdog nationalism. Can India produce fighters? You bet she can. They come, like all Indian champions, from its streets. That‰Ûªs something to be proud of, ‰ÛÏBrothers‰Ûù suggests, even if the cause is troubling: those streets and the people who live on them, as depicted here, are part of a society with no safety nets. Are you ready to fight?

‰ÛÏBrothers‰Ûù is dense with plot in the Bollywood way: two long, operatic flashbacks in the first half provide the back story. We learn how two brothers, David (Akshay Kumar) and Monty (Sidharth Malhotra), became estranged, and how their alcoholic father (the sad-eyed Jackie Shroff) destroyed the family with his drinking, cheating and too-quick fists. We also learn how David acquired a new life: He went from fighter to physics teacher, with a wife (Jacqueline Fernandez) and a cute little girl, Poopoo.

These words ring out again and again during the mixed martial arts tournament that dominates the second half of Karan Malhotra‰Ûªs body-thudding, blood-spurting Hindi movie ‰ÛÏBrothers ... Blood Against Blood.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs also the question that might be asked of every child born into the film‰Ûªs world, in which the fight to survive plays out on the mean streets of Mumbai, where the story takes place, but also in its mean drawing-rooms and kitchens, full of primal scenes and deadly violence.

As David‰Ûªs trainer tells him: ‰ÛÏThe world is cruel, master. It laughs at your pain.‰Ûù And it applauds your pain, too, especially the punishing physical kind. It‰Ûªs up to you to keep the tears flowing.

Fighters also cry. The climactic brother-on-brother matchup (that‰Ûªs no spoiler ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs inevitable from the film‰Ûªs first frame) is, oddly, a nice moment for a tears-through-the-pain relationship talk: ‰ÛÏI can‰Ûªt hurt you anymore,‰Ûù one brother tells the other, after smacking him silly. Later, from the depths of a chokehold: ‰ÛÏDid you forget she was my mother, too?‰Ûù

The characters in this movie don‰Ûªt live in the new ‰ÛÏshining India.‰Ûù David may seem to at first; we meet him at Poopoo‰Ûªs 7th-birthday party, complete with Hello Kitty cake and happy little princesses. But Poopoo is sick, and that makes David‰Ûªs middle-class toehold precarious. A schoolteacher can‰Ûªt afford to pay hospital bills. An M.M.A. champ can.
‰ÛÏFighter, are you ready?‰Ûù

Although ‰ÛÏBrothers‰Ûù is a remake of Gavin O‰ÛªConnor‰Ûªs 2011 ‰ÛÏWarrior,‰Ûù its plotting, timeouts for montages and a song or two ‰ÛÓ Kareena Kapoor appears as a spangly item girl, the sole female in a sea of leering chorus boys ‰ÛÓ are echt Hindi movie. Even more so is its emotional appeal.

That‰Ûªs all prelude to the present, in which both brothers are training for Right to Fight, India‰Ûªs first-ever mixed martial arts tournament. It will give locals ‰ÛÓ street brawlers and guys who brutalize each other in cage fights ‰ÛÓ a chance to take on some of the world‰Ûªs best fighters, including a fellow called Luca, who‰Ûªs announced as ‰ÛÏgruesome, and very, very dangerous.‰Ûù (He‰Ûªs from Germany, which the broadcasters call ‰ÛÏHitler‰Ûªs country.‰Ûù Note to Bollywood: this isn‰Ûªt 1933.)

Men here pummel each other, of course. But they also weep; Mr. Shroff, a Bollywood star since the 1970s, is the Cry King of ‰ÛÏBrothers.‰Ûù A photo of his dead wife, a confrontation with his son, a chair out of a place at home ‰ÛÓ all are occasions for tears.

The movie, directed by Arne Birkenstock, the son of a lawyer for Mr. Beltracchi and his wife, Helene (who was sentenced as an accomplice to four years in prison), is hardly impartial about its subject, positioning the maned, urbane con artist at its center as a man of enormous talent and ingenuity. The film suggests that his deception was enabled by the skewed economic incentives of the art world, where the authentication of a painting has the potential to reap financial rewards.

In the documentary ‰ÛÏBeltracchi: The Art of Forgery,‰Ûù the German forger Wolfgang Beltracchi ‰ÛÓ who was sentenced in 2011 to six years in prison but released this year ‰ÛÓ professes to be able to paint anything. The art historian Henry Keazor gives him names. Leonardo? ‰ÛÏOf course. He‰Ûªs not difficult,‰Ûù Mr. Beltracchi replies. When Mr. Keazor notes that the forger has the potential to deceive even scholars like him, Mr. Beltracchi replies, ‰ÛÏIf you write a catalog of works, bring it to me first.‰Ûù This is ostensibly to make sure that undiscovered fakes are not accidentally included.
By the end, though, it seems hard to accuse Mr. Beltracchi of hypocrisy. Shown painting under his real name, he says he doesn‰Ûªt mind that his own works aren‰Ûªt forgery proof.

Mr. Birkenstock watches Mr. Beltracchi undertake a painting in the style of the Russian artist Marie Vassilieff (‰ÛÏhigh on my list‰Ûù of prospects, Mr. Beltracchi says). The swindler approaches the task with an artist‰Ûªs attention to detail: He adds dust to the back of a frame to create the appearance of age; he notes that a real painting would smell of the room in which it hung. It is hard not to draw the conclusion that Mr. Beltracchi‰Ûªs punctiliousness and ability to paint in a chameleonlike array of styles are themselves a form of flair worth appreciating.
