While Mr. Beltracchi is an agreeable raconteur, and is much more knowledgeable than a mere armchair art historian, ‰ÛÏBeltracchi: The Art of Forgery‰Ûù is a case in which a great documentary topic hasn‰Ûªt yielded a great documentary. Significant questions remain unanswered. There is not enough information on those whom Mr. Beltracchi deceived, the fate of an authenticator who made procedural errors, the seeming ignorance of the Beltracchis‰Ûª children or how the case was resolved in a German court. Putting identifying title cards in the same part of the screen as the subtitles doesn‰Ûªt make the presentation any clearer.

Part of what allowed Mr. Beltracchi to fool collectors ‰ÛÓ he grew rich off what he estimates were 300 paintings and drawings created between 1970 and 2010 ‰ÛÓ is that he was canny about filling in gaps in catalogs. Rather than copying existing works, he made new paintings in the style of particular artists, creating the illusion of important and logical historical finds. In the film, he even has the hubris to suggest that he may have improved on some of the original artists‰Ûª ideas.

The movie mostly trails Mr. Beltracchi during his time in an open-prison arrangement, which allowed him to leave prison during the day and continue working as an artist in a studio. It doesn‰Ûªt look like much of a punishment. (We learn that he and Helene separate when they return to prison at night.)

Reid Scott (‰ÛÏVeep‰Ûù) is the comfortable ladies‰Ûª man next door, and Bobby Moynihan and Cecily Strong of ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù make their cameos sting. The screenplay is credited to Matt Serword, but many lines feel as if the cameras had kept rolling while everyone improvised. Only a few scenes fail to draw laughs in a movie that‰Ûªs unexpectedly smart and consistently amusing. In August, yet.

The romantic comedy ‰ÛÏSlow Learners‰Ûù opens with Jeff (Adam Pally from ‰ÛÏThe Mindy Project‰Ûù) enduring his latest first date to go south: ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre just soft and doughy,‰Ûù she explains helpfully. ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre sort of like an old baby.‰Ûù

But ‰ÛÏSlow Learners‰Ûù shows that there doesn‰Ûªt need to be. Directed by Don Argott and Sheena M. Joyce, on leave from making documentaries (‰ÛÏThe Art of the Steal,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Atomic States of America‰Ûù), the film traffics in the usual genre suspects: the parents who ask whether Jeff is gay, the married B.F.F. who coaches Anne from the sidelines. Even so, Mr. Pally, Ms. Burns and the rest of the cast deliver sharp dialogue in weapons-grade deadpan.

Apparently, all that‰Ûªs required is ditching your khakis and cardigans, getting new hairdos and drinking heavily in clubs where women dance on bars and guys get into fights. Hipness has its hazards, of course: by the time they are sexually hyperactive, Jeff and Anne have become cruel and indifferent to their friends and family. Raise your hand if you know how this one ends; as rom-coms go, there is nothing new here.

His friend Anne (Sarah Burns of ‰ÛÏEnlightened‰Ûù), a fellow nerdy high school teacher, is equally tired of the wallflower life, and they vow to use the summer break to become the cool hedonists of their dreams. ‰ÛÏI want to be sex-in-a-bathroom people!‰Ûù Anne chirps. Well, sure, who doesn‰Ûªt?

Ms. Harden is fine in a role that requires little, but her character is a lazy stereotype that ought to make real librarians wince. Sure, librarians tend to be well read and take great pleasure in books, but most also probably have friends, social lives and a curiosity about the world. That Jane has none of those things costs the character credibility, and her transformation at the hands of Juan is also nonsense. A few beers and a zip line ride can undo a lifetime of timidity? Only in flimsy fantasies.

In September, television viewers will have a chance to see Marcia Gay Harden play a brusque, decisive, rule-bending doctor in the new CBS drama ‰ÛÏCode Black.‰Ûù Anyone who wants to see her play more or less the polar opposite of that character is hereby referred to ‰ÛÏAfter Words,‰Ûù a romance novel of a movie featuring the world‰Ûªs most stereotypical librarian.

Ms. Harden plays that librarian, Jane, a mousy woman who as the film opens is laid off and uses the occasion to give up on life, which she seemed not to be enjoying much anyway. She plans a one-way trip to Costa Rica, leaving her last will and testament behind on her table. Once in that country, though, she hires a personal guide named Juan (ÌÒscar Jaenada) who gradually draws her out of her shell.

Performing his feats in a spangled outfit evoking Liberace and Elvis Presley, Knievel earned millions, especially from licensing, at a profound physical cost (a record-setting number of broken bones). The film doesn‰Ûªt skimp on his wince-inducing wipeouts, notably at Caesar‰Ûªs Palace in Las Vegas in 1967 and at Wembley Stadium in London in 1975; you almost hear snapping vertebrae. (He survived a steam-powered jump over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho in 1974 with minor injuries.)

George Hamilton (who played Knievel in a 1971 movie); Johnny Knoxville (who routinely injured himself on ‰ÛÏJackass‰Ûù on MTV); and the sportscaster Frank Gifford, who died on Aug. 9, offer comments, while the BMX champion Mat Hoffman discusses Knievel‰Ûªs influence on action sports today.
There were other failures: his financial, sexual and alcoholic profligacy, and a temper that led him to attack his former publicist with a bat, losing him major contracts and landing him in jail.

The movie overreaches when trying to contextualize Knievel as a hero inspiring the country after Vietnam-Watergate disillusionment. He was simply an all-American self-promoter. But ‰ÛÏBeing Evel‰Ûù largely nails his story.

There‰Ûªs something fundamentally American about the stunt motorcyclist Evel Knievel, as this latest informative documentary by Daniel Junge (a director of the Oscar-winning ‰ÛÏSaving Face‰Ûù) demonstrates. Robert Craig Knievel (1938-2007) ‰ÛÓ police officers tired of his persistent minor offenses created his nickname when he was growing up in Butte, Mont. ‰ÛÓ was determined to transcend humble origins.

‰ÛÏDigging for Fire,‰Ûù Joe Swanberg‰Ûªs new feature is, like many of his previous movies, a case study in heterosexual ethics. Its scope is narrow and, the title notwithstanding, it plumbs no great depths. But like Mr. Swanberg‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDrinking Buddies‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏHappy Christmas,‰Ûù the film has an appealing honesty and an enjoyably low-key comic style.

As things threaten to get out of hand for Tim, his wife is courting some disruption of her own, visiting some better-off friends whose relationship looks like a bad New Yorker short story from the ‰Ûª70s and then setting off alone into the night. Everywhere she goes she finds a copy of Dr. David Schnarch‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPassionate Marriage,‰Ûù which feels like both an earnest, obvious metaphor and a sly running joke.

Mr. Swanberg has made a tight, satisfying narrative that unfolds almost entirely in the subjunctive mood. This is a story about what almost happens, what might happen and what is happening under the banal surface of things. The modesty of ‰ÛÏDigging for Fire‰Ûù is among its virtues, and Mr. Swanberg has become an increasingly trustworthy filmmaker. He doesn‰Ûªt necessarily have a lot to say, but he always makes sure that he knows what he‰Ûªs talking about.

Anxieties about status and money hover over the couple like a fine mist. Tim is supposed to spend the weekend doing their taxes, and they quarrel about that. They also argue about whether to accept help from Lee‰Ûªs mother and stepfather so they can send their young son, Jude (played by Mr. Swanberg‰Ûªs young son, Jude) to an exclusive preschool.

To say that their marriage is in trouble would be an exaggeration, but there are tiny cracks in it through which trouble might enter. They spend most of the movie apart. Lee drops Jude off at his grandparents‰Ûª house so she can spend a night out with friends.

It‰Ûªs not so easy, and ‰ÛÏDigging for Fire‰Ûù successfully dramatizes the difficulty without overstating it. At the center of the story is a married couple ‰ÛÓ Tim (Jake Johnson, who wrote the script with Mr. Swanberg), a public-school gym teacher, and Lee (Rosemarie DeWitt), a yoga instructor ‰ÛÓ doing a bit of house-sitting. The house, a rustic, rambling, beautiful pile in the hills of Malibu, Calif., belongs to a client of Lee‰Ûªs who is off somewhere shooting a movie.

The opening titles promise a big ensemble, and a good deal of suspense comes from wondering just when some of those intriguing names will show up. It would almost be a spoiler to tell you when and in what capacity they do, but it‰Ûªs fun to anticipate the arrival of Melanie Lynskey, Sam Elliott, Brie Larson, Chris Messina (who gets naked) and Anna Kendrick (who almost does). Orlando Bloom appears at almost the precise moment you‰Ûªve forgotten he was supposed to, wearing a man-bun and an air of rugged weariness.

Tim stays behind and involves himself in a bizarre project. He has unearthed a rusty gun and a possibly human bone from a patch of dirt on the far side of the swimming pool, and over the next 24 hours his curiosity blossoms into obsession. He becomes an amateur detective and forensic archaeologist, and also, without quite realizing it, a man digging himself ever deeper into an existential hole.
‰ÛÏDigging for Fire‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Mostly weed and naughty words.

You might almost mistake this for a middle- or late-period Woody Allen movie, in other words. Mr. Swanberg shares Mr. Allen‰Ûªs abiding interest in the swerves and reversals of romance, but he conducts his investigations on firmer moral and philosophical ground. His characters evince mumbling anomie rather than eloquent neurosis. Their conversation is stripped of cultural references and instead of grappling with the meaning of existence they struggle with the competing demands of hedonism and responsibility. They want to be cool, fun, laid back and nonjudgmental, but they also want to behave decently.

But in the meantime, he has some fun. A few pals show up to drink beer, swim and wield shovels. One (Mike Birbiglia) is the uptight guy. Another (Sam Rockwell) is the party guy, who brings cocaine, unattached women and an even wilder buddy (Mr. Messina).

Funny, rugged and raw, ‰ÛÏThe Mend‰Ûù fits its story together from rough patches in the lives of two nose-diving New York brothers. Mat (Josh Lucas) is a freeloader (and sometime jerk) who is thrown out of the house by his girlfriend, Andrea (Lucy Owen). The slow-burning Alan (Stephen Plunkett) is treading water with his girlfriend, Farrah (Mickey Sumner), and hopes to take a big step when they are on a planned trip together. Directing his first feature after some shorts, John Magary digs into his characters with fresh eyes and a sly sense of adventure.

The morning after, Alan and Farrah leave on their trip, but Mat doesn‰Ûªt, having crashed in a bedroom at some point. He squats in his brother‰Ûªs apartment, and in one of several odd and unpredictable little chapters in a roundly restless story, he invites his recently estranged girlfriend and her son to come over. Mr. Magary has obviously taken a tragicomic page or two from the French filmmaker Arnaud Desplechin ‰ÛÓ the obtrusive music cues, the expressive transitions, the headlong self-destructive characters, the vaguely moody interiors ‰ÛÓ but he puts them to good use.

Mr. Magary brings Mat and Alan into focus with a party at Alan and Farrah‰Ûªs apartment, which goes through an entire believable life cycle of its own. By the end, we get a quick sketch of Mat‰Ûªs irascibility, see the tensions boiling in Alan and Farrah‰Ûªs relationship, watch a bunch of Farrah‰Ûªs dancer friends laze and sway, and meet an old-school artist friend of the family who drops by with lewd stories about the brothers‰Ûª father.

Alan‰Ûªs return from his trip, without Farrah, eventually sets him and his brother down a rude, regressive path that leads to drunken antics and frustration. Mr. Magary accumulates a layered look at masculinity, with added perspective provided by Andrea‰Ûªs sharp, observant son and the boy‰Ûªs accountant father. Much of the film‰Ûªs action takes place in Alan and Farrah‰Ûªs cramped dark apartment, which, plagued by mice and a broken door, stands in for a palpable psychological inertia.

Mr. Plunkett embodies a tamped-down exasperation that has built up over the years, and easily suggests the shared secret understanding between two siblings who can behave awfully around each other. Mr. Lucas gives Mat a stubborn heedlessness that‰Ûªs past its sell-by date, while Ms. Owen brings an amusing officiousness to her dialogue, suggesting someone who hasn‰Ûªt figured out as much as she lets on. But no one has really figured much out, in Mr. Magary‰Ûªs generous sprawl of scenes, which are playfully stretched and cut into different shapes with the lurching vigor of life.

Some of the many, many promotional spots for ‰ÛÏAmerican Ultra‰Ûù make it seem like more of a comedy than it is. That‰Ûªs not said as a criticism, just a warning. If you go, expect a diverting summer action adventure with occasional laughs, not a diverting stoner comedy with occasional action.

Mike is so wasted most of the time that it doesn‰Ûªt seem odd to him that he has no memories of his childhood, or how he ended up in the ratty West Virginia town where he lives, or anything else. There‰Ûªs a reason for this: He‰Ûªs a remnant of an old C.I.A. experiment to create superagents, and he was placed there, memory-free, when the experiment was shelved. He begins to figure this out when an agency bureaucrat (Topher Grace) decides that ‰ÛÏwe‰Ûªre clearing the portfolio‰Ûù and sends assassins to kill him.

Jesse Eisenberg and Kristen Stewart, who were paired in ‰ÛÏAdventureland‰Ûù in 2009, are romantically linked again here, though when we first meet their characters it‰Ûªs a romance shrouded in a haze. Mr. Eisenberg is Mike Howell, a perpetually stoned young man with a job at a grocery store that seems to have no customers. Ms. Stewart is his girlfriend, Phoebe, whom he wants to marry, and in his clearer moments he‰Ûªs trying to find a way to propose.
‰ÛÏAmerican Ultra‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language, lots of blood and, of course, drug use.

That‰Ûªs a problem with ‰ÛÏAmerican Ultra‰Ûù: a lot of it seems familiar, and Mr. Eisenberg and Ms. Stewart aren‰Ûªt stretched much. But Mike finds amusing ways to defend himself using ordinary household items, Walton Goggins and John Leguizamo enliven things in goofy small roles, the plot has a nice twist or two, and your theater is probably air-conditioned.

That awakens Mike‰Ûªs long-buried training, and he‰Ûªs the one who does the killing. A lethal-weapon character who doesn‰Ûªt realize his powers until a crisis brings them out ‰ÛÓ you‰Ûªve seen the conceit before, and you‰Ûªll see it again if you watch the new NBC series ‰ÛÏBlindspot‰Ûù next month.

I‰Ûªll spare you a lecture on the historical significance and cultural import of Ms. Tomlin, and her particular relevance to the popular culture of 2015. On second thought, I won‰Ûªt. Too much gets taken for granted these days. And while Ms. Tomlin has been a consistent presence on television, in movies, in recordings and onstage for roughly the past half-century ‰ÛÓ from ‰ÛÏLaugh-In‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏThe Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏAll of Me‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏThe Magic School Bus‰Ûù and beyond ‰ÛÓ she is currently having a bit of a renaissance, thanks to this movie and to ‰ÛÏGrace and Frankie,‰Ûù the Netflix sitcom that splendidly pairs her with Jane Fonda. (I will save my lecture on the zeitgeist-transcending awesomeness of Ms. Fonda for another time.)

Judy, like many children of bohemian parents, is a driven, disciplined professional. Sage, like many children of superachieving parents, is diffident and a little adrift. Ms. Garner, with her nimbus of curls and her delicate features, looks far too childlike for the predicament she finds herself in. But Sage is tougher than she looks, and like her mother and her grandmother, she is much more than an easy comic archetype. Mr. Weitz treats them all with a fondness that feels entirely unforced, and his sentimental tendencies are balanced by their mostly dry-eyed performances, and above all by Ms. Tomlin‰Ûªs peppery honesty.

In need of cash ‰ÛÓ we‰Ûªll get to why in a minute ‰ÛÓ Elle Reid, a poet and sometime professor in her 70s, decides to sell some precious old books. She figures that even though they‰Ûªre a bit worse for wear, her first editions of Betty Friedan and Simone de Beauvoir should fetch a few hundred dollars at the local feminist bookstore-cafe. Her outrage when she‰Ûªs grudgingly offered a lot less than that compounds her dismay at her teenage granddaughter‰Ûªs cluelessness about the authors of ‰ÛÏThe Feminine Mystique‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Second Sex.‰Ûù What‰Ûªs wrong with the world these days?

Sage is pregnant. She has an appointment for an abortion but not enough money to pay for it, and Elle, in a quixotic gesture of rebellion that is also a convenient plot device, has recently shredded her credit cards. Hence the trip to the bookstore-cafe (where Olivia happens to be working), and hence the zigzagging mini-road trip, during which they encounter Sage‰Ûªs jerky ex-boyfriend (Nat Wolff), an old flame of Elle‰Ûªs, and Judy, who makes both her mother and her daughter nervous, though for different reasons.

For Elle, this truth is personal as well as political, and anything but simple. ‰ÛÏGrandma‰Ûù is, among other things, a portrait of grief. For more than 30 years, Elle shared her life with Vi, whose relatively recent death casts a long shadow over Elle‰Ûªs daily routines. In the first few scenes, we see Elle brutally dumping her younger lover, Olivia (Ms. Greer), and then weeping alone in the shower once Olivia has left. Bereavement, it seems, has set Elle firmly in her solitary, sarcastic ways. She doesn‰Ûªt talk much to Judy (Marcia Gay Harden), the daughter she and Vi raised together, and is therefore somewhat startled when Judy‰Ûªs daughter, Sage (Julia Garner), shows up at her door in need of help.
Someone should start a petition to put her face on the $20 bill. It wouldn‰Ûªt solve all our problems, but it would be a pretty good start.

It‰Ûªs fitting that this renewal of attention arrives amid a flowering of feminist comedy, and worth acknowledging Ms. Tomlin‰Ûªs status as a foremother ‰ÛÓ a big sister, a wild aunt, however you want to put it ‰ÛÓ of the frank, fearless, funny women who have recently rescued American humor from its bro‰Ûªed-out doldrums. Tina Fey, the Amys (Poehler and Schumer), the ladies of ‰ÛÏBroad City‰Ûù and the shape-shifters of the current ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live‰Ûù cast did not come out of nowhere. To revisit Ms. Tomlin‰Ûªs old LPs or videos of her one-woman shows is no more a matter of nostalgia than Elle‰Ûªs embrace of de Beauvoir and Friedan. It‰Ûªs a matter of memory, of understanding the continuities and ruptures of history. And that‰Ûªs the truth.

That‰Ûªs a long conversation, but as of this writing one thing that is absolutely right with the world is the existence of ‰ÛÏGrandma,‰Ûù Paul Weitz‰Ûªs wry and insightful movie about an eventful day in the life of Elle and her granddaughter. There is much to praise about this sweet, smart comedy of intergenerational conflict and solidarity: the way the script captures the speech patterns of the young, the old and the middle age; the way the story feels at once frantic and relaxed, as the two main characters race against the clock and meander through Los Angeles in Elle‰Ûªs wheezy vintage car; the brief, memorable appearances from supporting performers like Judy Greer, Sam Elliott and Elizabeth PeÌ±a (in one of her last roles). But honestly, the wonder that is ‰ÛÏGrandma‰Ûù can be summed up in two words: Lily Tomlin.

Elle is to some extent an elaboration of the maverick matriarch Ms. Tomlin played in ‰ÛÏAdmission,‰Ûù Mr. Weitz‰Ûªs uneven and unsatisfying 2013 comedy. ‰ÛÏGrandma‰Ûù is a much more lucid film, less crowded with story points and more open to the idiosyncrasies of its characters. It regards them all, in particular Sage, Judy and Elle, with clarity and sympathy, acknowledging the distinct risks and opportunities each one faces as she tries to pursue happiness and avoid compromise.

‰ÛÏMom says you‰Ûªre a philanthropist,‰Ûù Sage says to her grandmother. The word she‰Ûªs looking for is misanthrope, but of course there is a core of tenderness and generosity underneath Elle‰Ûªs caustic surface. That might be the wrong way to put it. What Mr. Weitz and Ms. Tomlin understand about the character, and about many other feminists of her generation, is that her grouchiness and her compassion issue from the same source. She is impatient with the world and suspicious of the motives of a lot of people in it, but that is partly a result of her idealism, her uncompromising commitment to behaving like a free human being.
‰ÛÏGrandma‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The talk is talked; the walk is walked.

‰ÛÏStay out of the sun,‰Ûù a doctor warns David (Pat Mills) early in ‰ÛÏGuidance,‰Ûù a ferociously black comedy about growing older without growing up. On the heels of a diagnosis of Stage 3 melanoma, David makes a beeline for the tanning salon, cigarette in hand. He‰Ûªs not in shock, he‰Ûªs in denial.

Shot in Toronto, in daylight-bright scenes that soften the darkness of the material, ‰ÛÏGuidance‰Ûù eventually finds a bilious heart beneath David‰Ûªs buttoned-up corduroy jacket and keep-off demeanor. That‰Ûªs the thing about good deeds: They have a way of bouncing back at you, whether you want them to or not.

But disavowal is David‰Ûªs modus operandi. A former child star who obsessively watches reruns of his television-show glory days, he‰Ûªs also a profoundly closeted gay man and a flamboyantly heedless drunk. By day, he makes audio recordings of self-help affirmations for women who prefer to face up to their failings. What they also favor, David‰Ûªs boss says before firing him, is a guru who sounds straight.

We‰Ûªve seen this selfishly inappropriate behavior before, most recently in higher-profile projects like the 2011 duo ‰ÛÏBad Teacher‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏYoung Adult,‰Ûù both of which relied on liberal levels of acidity to sell their jokes. ‰ÛÏGuidance‰Ûù also risks comparison with any number of films that present white teachers as saviors of nonwhite high schoolers, but Mr. Mills isn‰Ûªt preaching that particular sermon. Flipping the script just enough to matter, he creates a mutually beneficial, if wildly unhinged, union built on damage and desperation.

A guarded black student whose chronic truancy shields an abusive home life, Jabrielle inches closer as David‰Ûªs unconventional counseling methods ‰ÛÓ like sharing vodka shots with his students and encouraging one to be an inspiration for ‰ÛÏall the other sluts out there‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ win him some fans. But Jabrielle, in keeping with most of the movie‰Ûªs satellite characters, is written so flimsily that she operates mainly as a mirror for David‰Ûªs unacknowledged issues.

Pursuing his character‰Ûªs self-destructive, often tasteless agenda, Mr. Mills (drawing on his own experiences and doing triple duty as the director and screenwriter) gives a performance of rancid single-mindedness. It‰Ûªs a fearlessly unsympathetic role that provides plenty of space for train-wreck humor but almost no wiggle room for redemption. If your tolerance for self-loathing antiheroes is as high as mine, that won‰Ûªt be a problem; taken to extremes, however, they can suck the air from those around them. This becomes evident when David fraudulently acquires a probationary position as a high school guidance counselor and forms a wary connection with Jabrielle (an intriguing Zahra Bentham).

But the thrills aren‰Ûªt the same. ‰ÛÏSinister‰Ûù trafficked in musty horror riffs (old technology ÌÊ la ‰ÛÏV/H/S‰Ûù; almost-other-dimensional house interiors, as in ‰ÛÏInsidious‰Ûù; very naughty kids, as in ‰ÛÏChildren of the Corn‰Ûù), but benefited from actors like Mr. Hawke and inestimably from Christopher Norr‰Ûªs high-contrast, deep-focus cinematography. Despite Mr. Ransone‰Ûªs goofy charm, ‰ÛÏSinister 2‰Ûù can‰Ûªt claim the same finesse, substituting pedestrian plotting and a more graphic gore for the original‰Ûªs restraint. Bughuul, take me away!

In ‰ÛÏSinister,‰Ûù from 2012, a true-crime writer (Ethan Hawke) moved his family into a house that had been the site of a multiple murder. In the attic he discovered grainy home-movie-like films of other killings. He also met a pagan entity, Bughuul, who in whisking the souls of children to a nether realm, creates minions who do his homicidal bidding.

The longhaired, pale-faced Bughuul (Nicholas King) returns in ‰ÛÏSinister 2,‰Ûù to terrorize 9-year-old twins, Dylan and Zach (the brothers Robert and Dartanian Sloan), and their mother, Courtney (Shannyn Sossamon), who have escaped to a country home to elude Courtney‰Ûªs abusive husband (Lea Coco). Also back is the sympathetic and now former deputy sheriff So & So (James Ransone) ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs the character‰Ûªs name ‰ÛÓ who assists Courtney and her sons. The kids aren‰Ûªt all right: Dylan and Zach (representing the movie‰Ûªs apparent target demographic) are coached in Bughuul‰Ûªs recruitment program by tweenish specters using, yep, grisly homemade snuff films.
‰ÛÏSinister 2‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Immolations, impalements, hungry rats.

There are engrossing elements in Craig William Macneill‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Boy,‰Ûù the tale of a creepy motel (no, it‰Ûªs not ‰ÛÏPsycho‰Ûù) and a child sociopath (no, not ‰ÛÏThe Bad Seed‰Ûù). Building on their Sundance short ‰ÛÏHenley,‰Ûù Mr. Macneill and his co-screenwriter, Clay McLeod Chapman, have developed a feature stunning to behold if somewhat unpersuasive in narrative.

It‰Ûªs 1989, and 9-year-old Ted (Jared Breeze) has grown up alone, bored and left to his feral instincts in a dilapidated mountain motel run by his father, John (an impeccable David Morse), who flails under the burdens of running his business and raising his son alone. (The hills of muggy Colombia stand in for a Western backwater, though you‰Ûªd never guess it from Thomas Hallbauer‰Ûªs vivid crumbling-Americana production design, abetted by Noah Greenberg‰Ûªs hypnotic cinematography.)

For diversion, Ted collects roadkill and logs his gruesome finds in a notebook. He also deposits garbage on the road to attract prey. When a shady drifter (an excellent Rainn Wilson) has the misfortune to crash his car into a large animal, stranding him at the motel, he and Ted develop a bond, though the drifter‰Ûªs past and Ted‰Ûªs proclivities are an ill-fated combination.

Ted‰Ûªs inclinations boil over when drunken upper-crust high school seniors occupy the motel for prom-night revels and torment the boy. Donning a crude ‰ÛÏLord of the Flies‰Ûù-type crown, Ted exacts an incendiary class comeuppance. And yet ‰ÛÏThe Boy,‰Ûù despite remarkable performances and gorgeous imagery, does not sufficiently flesh out its subject. (Two projected sequels may prove illuminating.)
An unfortunate Sabbath-related twist leads to her captivity lasting longer than planned. Feisty and cunning, she is a formidable captive who wriggles and squeals like a trapped animal.

In the early scenes, Shaul stalks Dafna (Gita Amely), a high school classmate, and surreptitiously photographs her with his cellphone. What initially appears to be a heavy schoolboy crush is revealed to be something much more sinister when the brothers drag a mattress to a concrete bomb shelter in the basement of their building where Dafna will be held captive.

Their fraternal loyalty is the driving force behind this tragic farce, the feature directorial debut of Tom Shoval, in which Yaki and Shaul foolishly take it upon themselves to save their family from financial ruin by kidnapping a girl from a wealthy family as she walks home from school.

Their father, Moti (Moshe Ivgy), recently lost his job, and the family, mired in debt, faces eviction from their apartment in a Tel Aviv suburb. The depressed Moti, who has given up looking for work, puts on a grotesquely jolly face, leaving his wife and children to try to fill the gap by taking odd jobs. At meals, Moti and his wife, Paula (Shirili Deshe), carry on as though nothing is wrong.

Yaki and Shaul Cooper, teenage siblings played by the brothers David and Eitan Cunio in the Israeli film ‰ÛÏYouth‰Ûù look almost identical but for the fact that the 18-year-old Yaki, the older of the two, has scruffy facial hair. Their bond is so primal that when embracing, they resemble wrestlers standing head-to-head before trying to throw each other to the floor. You have the eerie sense of observing two halves of a severed whole struggling to reunite and break apart at the same time.

The kidnapping and ensuing complications make for a harrowing spectacle of cruelty and bumbling from which the camera doesn‰Ûªt shrink. Wearing ski masks, the boys affect a B-movie machismo as they grab Dafna off the street and obscure her vision with eye patches and conceal her identity with sunglasses, then force her onto a bus, which they abruptly exit when her cellphone rings. The other passengers pretend not to notice.

Shaul works as a ticket taker at a multiplex that shows action films, and the apartment is littered with promotional detritus and memorabilia. The brothers‰Ûª preferred garb consists of T-shirts for movies like ‰ÛÏRambo‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Black Dahlia.‰Ûù When Yaki, a recent army recruit, returns on a short leave, proudly toting a rifle that rarely leaves his side, crude fantasy seems to merge with the day-to-day reality of Israel‰Ûªs militarized society.

‰ÛÏYouth‰Ûù creates an acrid vision of a country under economic and military stress, as the middle class is disappearing and the proliferation of arms is putting assault weapons in the hands of teenagers. In Mr. Shoval‰Ûªs grim view, Israel is under siege from within.

Moments of humor gently tilt ‰ÛÏLearning to Drive‰Ûù toward comedy. In the wittiest scene, a blind date that turns into a one-night stand leaves Wendy wrung out after a protracted session of tantric sex. Such little detours add a lighthearted gloss to a delicate film that steers clear of preaching or of slipping into mawkishness.

Wherever he goes, Darwan, conspicuous in his turban, faces possible harassment. When Wendy, flustered and fearful behind the wheel, damages another vehicle, Darwan is assumed by the police to be responsible until Wendy steps in. The chemistry between Darwan and Wendy has an unspoken romantic subtext, but the attraction never bursts into flame. Ms. Clarkson, with her Cheshire cat smile and twinkling eyes, conveys the mysterious allure of a sensual woman with secrets. Under her seductive charm percolates a volatile, combative temperament.

Wendy Shields (Ms. Clarkson) is a high-strung Manhattan literary star whose marriage explodes when her husband, Ted (Jake Weber), abruptly leaves her for another woman. Adapted from an essay in The New Yorker  by the feminist author Katha Pollitt, the movie lightly touches on many subjects: divorce, rage and financial warfare; conflicting philosophies of marriage; and mother-daughter strife.

Wendy is an upper-middle-class woman of letters with a highbrow reputation. One of her saddest realizations when abandoned is that her marriage might have lasted had her passion for literature not taken precedence. This is the rare film that conveys the intense, private experience of the dedicated reader.
‰ÛÏLearning to Drive‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and some sexual content.

Her driving teacher, Darwan (Mr. Kingsley), is a Sikh Indian and part-time cabdriver who shares a drab Queens apartment with fellow Indian immigrants, some of whom are in the country illegally. There is a raid in which several roommates are chased out of the house. In India, Darwan was a university professor, imprisoned for his religious beliefs. He won political asylum in the United States.

Among the charms of ‰ÛÏLearning to Drive,‰Ûù a small, observant dual portrait of a New York book critic and her Indian-American driving instructor, are the detailed, lived-in performances of its stars, Patricia Clarkson and Ben Kingsley. The film belongs to a school of grown-up, low-drama two-handers, of which the most famous example is ‰ÛÏDriving Miss Daisy,‰Ûù but ‰ÛÏLearning to Drive‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt half as sentimental. As this movie, directed by Isabel Coixet, tracks the deepening friendship between people from different cultures and backgrounds, it acquires an unforced metaphorical resonance.

Darwan is about to enter into an arranged marriage with Jasleen (Sarita Choudhury), a Sikh woman of whom he knows next to nothing beyond that they were born in neighboring villages. With Jasleen, as with Wendy, he is stern but polite, persistent but not authoritarian. Even when he realizes, to his disappointment, that Jasleen is uneducated, speaks poor English and is scared to leave the house, his frustration never boils over.

Like many longtime New Yorkers, Wendy has relied on public transportation. Only when her marriage ends does she realize that she has to learn to drive if she wants to visit her fiery college-age daughter, Tasha (Grace Gummer), on a farm in Vermont.

Mr. Kingsley‰Ûªs penetrating brown-eyed gaze can project everything from pure evil to near-divinity, and in ‰ÛÏLearning to Drive,‰Ûù his demeanor is benign but not holy. With his stiff-backed posture and alert expression, he projects an unflappable self-control, even when Wendy has a near-meltdown on the Queensboro Bridge. His lessons in patience and concentration convey a calm, farsighted perspective steeped in Eastern philosophy.

In the concise, droll screenplay by Sarah Kernochan (‰ÛÏImpromptu,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ9 å_ Weeks‰Ûù), the seven-year relationship described in Ms. Pollitt‰Ûªs essay has become a 21-year marriage, the better to illustrate the chasm between Indian and American marital customs and to suggest that the American ideal of unlimited personal freedom has its price.

But do we really need another movie about a man who‰Ûªs a ‰ÛÏperfect killing machine‰Ûù? Or another evil corporation dreaming about cloning him into an army? Mr. Bach and his backers clearly believe that we do, going so far as to reboot the 2007 headache ‰ÛÏHitman‰Ûù (based on the video game series with the same title) and adding more eye candy. But no amount of killer good looks can save a project with only an echo chamber of destruction where a story ought to be.

But formula demands a (preferably beautiful) woman in peril, and so we have Katia (Hannah Ware), whom we meet holed up in a Berlin library. She‰Ûªs looking for her father (poor Ciaran Hinds), Agent 47 is looking for her, and Smith is looking for both of them. One wants to kill her and the other wants to protect her, and kudos to you if you can work out which is which. (Maybe the movie‰Ûªs continuity issues aren‰Ûªt confined to Katia‰Ûªs on-again, off-again lipstick.)

A grab bag of random notions lifted primarily from the ‰ÛÏTerminator‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMatrix‰Ûù universes, ‰ÛÏHitman‰Ûù is a sexless, virtually bloodless chain of preposterous battles rendered in a two-dimensional gloss. But it will almost certainly be back: There are currently seven installments of the video game, with an eighth on the way. Though if they return with a steamy romance between Smith and 47, I might be forced to buy a ticket.

Blasting through Singapore and Berlin, Agent 47 (Mr. Friend) and his nemesis, John Smith (Mr. Quinto), are aces at slaying but not so great at dying, popping up like Weebles after every encounter. This is easy for Smith, a genetically engineered assassin whose ‰ÛÏsubdermal titanium body armor‰Ûù repels weapons, while Agent 47‰Ûªs nonexistent emotions repulse any concern for his welfare. For that, he has a slinky handler, played by a Chinese actress whose stage name, Angelababy, should be bestowed by law on at least one newborn per year.
‰ÛÏHitman: Agent 47‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Lethal tailoring and a deadly asthma inhaler.

Dumb as dirt and just as generic, ‰ÛÏHitman: Agent 47‰Ûù trades brains for bullets and characters for windup toys. So it‰Ûªs all the more shocking that honest-to-goodness actors like Zachary Quinto and Rupert Friend have signed on to play the film‰Ûªs two leads; maybe the director, Aleksander Bach, told them they could have a lifetime supply of their smoking-hot suits.

If only the title of ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Funny That Way‰Ûù were true, then maybe this creaky throwback padded with Hollywood names and fake accents could be forgiven its many failings. But there‰Ûªs barely a whiz-bang punch line or smoothly executed setup to be found in a movie that longs to be a sparkling bedroom comedy and winds up a tortured, fizz-free farce.
Rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, please, we‰Ûªre pretending not to be British.

Carelessly framed and halfheartedly lighted, the actors strain to accommodate unfamiliar screwball rhythms and an abundance of screaming and slapping. Rising above both are the prodigiously talented Lucy Punch, as an Eastern European call girl trying to service the wrong john, and Jennifer Aniston ‰ÛÓ proving once again that tartness is her friend ‰ÛÓ playing a tough-love therapist with a blithe disregard for emotional filters and professional ethics.

Unfolding in flashback as Izzy recounts her streets-to-stardom rise for a jaded journalist (an eye-rolling Illeana Douglas), ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs Funny That Way‰Ûù marks the first feature from Peter Bogdanovich in more than a dozen years. But the sizzling energy he brought to ‰ÛÏWhat‰Ûªs Up, Doc?‰Ûù (1972) is missing here, as is the touching authenticity of ‰ÛÏThe Thing Called Love‰Ûù (1993). Choking on nostalgia and forced connections, the dusty screenplay (by Mr. Bogdanovich and his former wife, Louise Stratten) leans much too heavily on pop-up celebrities who spit bread crumbs of dialogue and then disappear.

And no one is more tormented than Owen Wilson, who plays a hooker-loving Broadway director named Arnold with a puppyish haplessness that‰Ûªs completely wrong for a character who is so clearly a jerk. Arnold is on a mission to get working girls off their backs and into respectable careers, doling out generous seed money ‰ÛÓ after, of course, he has thoroughly accepted their gratitude.

His latest save is Izzy (the British actress Imogen Poots, chewing strenuously on alien Brooklyn vowels), a wide-eyed tootsie and ground zero for the film‰Ûªs romantic bedlam. Everyone, it seems, is dizzy for Izzy: The geeky playwright (Will Forte) who unwittingly auditions her for a role in Arnold‰Ûªs next project; a pathetic former client (Austin Pendleton) who tails her obsessively. Even Arnold‰Ûªs caustic wife (Kathryn Hahn), the star of the play and the onetime lover of her torch-carrying co-star (Rhys Ifans, hardly anyone‰Ûªs idea of a tasty bit on the side), can‰Ûªt wait to bring Izzy on board.

But a few good women and a handful of amusing lines are far less than we expect from such an intelligent, resourceful filmmaker. ‰ÛÏI believe in happy endings,‰Ûù Izzy says at the beginning of the film, and so does Mr. Bogdanovich. This time, though, the audience will just be happy to see him fashion any kind of ending at all.

In the most excruciating moment of a 99-minute film that seems to last for three hours, Ms. Hayek imitates the grunts, groans and howls of different men in the throes of orgasm. They could just as easily be my suppressed cries of agony at having to endure one of the worst films to sport the label ‰ÛÏromantic comedy.‰Ûù

The execrable romantic comedy ‰ÛÏSome Kind of Beautiful‰Ûù is the kind of embarrassment a studio dumps into the market in August while hoping no one will notice. Directed by Tom Vaughan from a screenplay by Matthew Newman, this witless, offensively sexist farrago stars a flabby Pierce Brosnan as Richard Haig, a self-satisfied professor of English romantic poetry at Cambridge and a serial womanizer who sleeps with his students. When his latest girlfriend, Kate (Jessica Alba), an American, informs him she‰Ûªs pregnant, he promptly throws up.

A chip off the old block, he is following in the footsteps of his father, Gordon (Malcolm McDowell), who has an advanced case of satyriasis. A vain, bilious misanthrope, Gordon has all the charm of a troll dragged up from a sewer outlet under a bridge. After the baby is born, he sarcastically refers to him as ‰ÛÏthe little turd.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏSome Kind of Beautiful‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language, sexual content, some nudity and drug use.

Determined to change his ways and to be a good father, Richard moves with Kate to Los Angeles, where she falls in love with Brian (Ben McKenzie), a charisma-free dullard, and complications about parenting ensue. Who should appear but Kate‰Ûªs zany older sister, Olivia (Salma Hayek), whom Richard was trying to seduce the very evening Kate announced that she was pregnant?

Theirs is not the only commerce. Snacks and small toys are also available for purchase, and, of course, cigarettes. Mr. Sniadecki does not show his face on screen, but he is nonetheless a presence in the film. You hear his voice as he chats with passengers, and as the camera pushes through crowded, narrow spaces, you‰Ûªre subliminally but palpably aware of the body and the eye attached to it. ‰ÛÏThe Iron Ministry‰Ûù belongs to a school of documentary filmmaking (associated with the Sensory Ethnography Lab at Harvard) that is sometimes described as ‰ÛÏimmersive.‰Ûù There is no voice-over, no narrative, no attempt to establish context ‰ÛÓ just a raw, at times bewildering, flood of sensations.

The interior of a train can be made into an allegorical space, a microcosm of social organization. Bong Joon-ho‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSnowpiercer‰Ûù imagined that the entire population of the world had been packed into a very long, very fast train, sorted by status and function and governed by a strict set of policies. ‰ÛÏThe Iron Ministry,‰Ûù J. P. Sniadecki‰Ûªs new film, could almost be described as the documentary version of Mr. Bong‰Ûªs dystopian, futuristic fantasy. Mr. Sniadecki‰Ûªs trains, which criss-cross China and on which he spent nearly three years filming, doesn‰Ûªt quite hold all of humanity. It just feels that way.
‰ÛÏThe Iron Ministry‰Ûù is neither boring nor confining, which is just to say that it‰Ûªs not a long trip through a faraway country. It‰Ûªs a work of art ‰ÛÓ vivid and mysterious and full of life.

Early on the journey ‰ÛÓ which lasts only 82 minutes but feels endless in a mostly good way ‰ÛÓ the camera moves from the close contemplation of grime and detritus to the butchering of meat. This happens in the space between cars, and it‰Ûªs somehow both disgusting and alluring. Huge slabs of fatty pork are carefully cut, rolled and hung on wires, to be sold alongside fruits and vegetables by farmers from market towns along the route.

If a pop culture web publication ever asked me to make a list of the most cinematic forms of transportation, the train would be at the top, probably followed by the horse. Car chases are cool and everything, but the very first publicly shown movie (at least according to legend) was about a train. Trains on film are both sublime and intimate: The camera can trace the muscular movement of railway cars across the land or venture inside to observe the complicated actions of people in motion.

In some films of this kind ‰ÛÓ Lucien Castaing-Taylor and VÌ©rÌ©na Paravel‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLeviathan,‰Ûù for example, which takes place on a commercial fishing trawler ‰ÛÓ the viewer plunges into a strange, intense reality and almost drowns in it. To me, ‰ÛÏThe Iron Ministry‰Ûù is a more interesting movie partly because, for all its immediacy, it allows you a certain analytic distance from its subject. In other words you can think about what you‰Ûªre seeing and hearing, and glean nuggets of meaning from what can seem like random encounters and observations.

The last decade has had a boom in documentaries from and about China, films that trace the effects of that country‰Ûªs social, economic and technological transformation on its workers, peasants, students and entrepreneurs. While ‰ÛÏThe Iron Ministry‰Ûù stands perfectly well on its own, it is also an illuminating companion to a movie like Lixin Fan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLast Train Home,‰Ûù about the migration from rural villages to urban factories.

Many of Mr. Sniadecki‰Ûªs passengers are part of that movement, which carries tens of millions of people across China every year. His attempt to find more affluent citizens of the People‰Ûªs Republic are thwarted when conductors shoo him out of a first-class dining car. Back in the cheap seats, in the coach-class sleeping cars, in the noisy smoking areas outside the lavatories, people talk about the hope of finding better jobs in newly built cities, about the frustrations of a bureaucratic, undemocratic system and (at least in one instance) about the wisdom and decency of China‰Ûªs rulers. They also manage to fall asleep in what look like impossible positions and to find ways to amuse themselves and one another amid the tedium and claustrophobia.

The director, however, may have guided the more recent veterans to the subject (their answers sound very similar). Eric Christiansen, whose earlier documentary was ‰ÛÏHomecoming: A Vietnam Vets Journey,‰Ûù has organized the new film neatly by topic: what the veterans were like as small children, how they feel about what they saw and did overseas, what it was like coming home, what post-traumatic stress disorder is, how they have adjusted (with support groups, support dogs, psychotherapy, marathon running) and, finally, how they‰Ûªre seeking a sense of home.

The film also presents one woman, a Korean-American who served in Iraq more than a decade ago. Her greatest emotional scars were inflicted not on the battlefield but in her own quarters, in a sexual assault by a man to whom she opened her door (‰ÛÏa friend of mine‰Ûù). That horror seems like a separate subject, but at least it reminds moviegoers that women also go to war.

The oddest thing about ‰ÛÏSearching for Home: Coming Back From War‰Ûù is how often the military men interviewed talk about having been surprised that real war wasn‰Ûªt like the movies. They make a Korean War veteran seem like a master of emotional distance and control when he sticks to real-life parallels in a speech about his memories.

Most veterans say they feel devastated about having taken human life. A token soldier takes the opposing side. ‰ÛÏEvery one of them deserves to die and burn in hell,‰Ûù he declares. ‰ÛÏWomen, children, old people ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt matter.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏSearching for Home‰Ûù is strikingly photographed by Mr. Christiansen and is sure to give comfort and support to countless veterans and their families. For others, there is little new insight, although the film does create an instructive tension between admiring bravery and sacrifice and being appalled by war itself.

Perched comfortably between art house and mainstream filmmaking idioms, Mr. Perry does a great deal with his hybrid visual style, emotional palette, restricted location and a minimal cast that includes a very good Patrick Fugit as Virginia‰Ûªs neighbor. The story folds in several time frames, including the days of Catherine‰Ûªs visit that are announced on screen in red, elegant typeface. The typeface was designed by Teddy Blanks, who created the Philip Rothian books strewn through Mr. Perry‰Ûªs last feature, ‰ÛÏListen Up Philip,‰Ûù a few of which ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMadness & Women‰Ûù included ‰ÛÓ pop up in ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth.‰Ûù As beautiful and slashing as Catherine and Virginia, the typeface looks similar to the one in Rainer Werner Fassbinder‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Marriage of Maria Braun,‰Ûù one of the classics that inform Mr. Perry‰Ûªs work here.

Like the movie, these close-ups are alternately mesmerizing and suffocating, which dovetails with Mr. Perry‰Ûªs pull-push strategy of bringing you uncomfortably close to the action, to the tears and the drama, only to shove you away. Some of this may be a matter of artistic temperament and Mr. Perry‰Ûªs interest in exploring the more rancid manifestations of human behavior, but it also serves his narrative experimentation here. ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth‰Ûù largely focuses on Catherine during a summer visit with her ostensible best friend, Virginia (Katherine Waterston), who‰Ûªs been given the keys to a country retreat belonging to relatives. And while Catherine may be ready to lick her wounds, she doesn‰Ûªt stand a chance given how deeply Virginia jabs her fingers in them.

When you first see Catherine, she‰Ûªs looking upward, her teary, blotchy face filling the frame. She‰Ûªs suffering, all right, you better believe it, although she doesn‰Ûªt seem to be doing a particularly good job of convincing the guy who‰Ûªs mostly off-camera. She looks like a mess ‰ÛÓ pathetic, really, with her smeared black eye makeup and the tears that just keep pooling and dribbling. The funny thing is that with her wet raccoon eyes and red nose, Catherine ‰ÛÓ a sensational Elisabeth Moss ‰ÛÓ also looks like a sad clown. All that‰Ûªs missing is the black velvet background.

You may also think of the two women in Ingmar Bergman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPersona,‰Ûù whom Susan Sontag described as ‰ÛÏengaged in a desperate duel of identities‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a nice, concise description of what happens in ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth‰Ûù too. In ‰ÛÏPersona,‰Ûù a mute patient and a talkative nurse circle each other in what Sontag also described as ‰ÛÏthe duel between two mythical parts of a single self.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs worth nothing that someone in ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth‰Ûù has put a statue of two fencers in the room that Catherine stays in and where she retreats into herself. It‰Ûªs there that she stares down plates of wilted salad that would make suitable appetizers for the putrefying rabbit (a would-be dinner) that haunts Catherine Deneuve in Roman Polanski‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRepulsion,‰Ûù yet another touchstone about crazy women and the male directors who love them.

By the time Catherine exits ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth,‰Ûù her frown has turned upside down and a grimace of abject misery has transformed into a vision of manic happiness as if she had traded in her tragedy mask for a comedy one. That it‰Ûªs unclear which face is scarier, more unnerving, is in keeping with the director Alex Ross Perry‰Ûªs gift for destabilization, for setting a mood only to violently upend it with cutting looks, dissonant musical chords and off-kilter camera angles. That Catherine seems to be swapping theater masks even as Ms. Moss brings tremendous depth of feeling to the role is in line with the arch self-consciousness of ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth,‰Ûù an art film in quotation marks.

Mr. Perry and his cinematographer, Sean Price Williams, oscillate between fixed and moving cameras, and there‰Ûªs a terrific scene in which the camera shifts from Catherine to Virginia and back again as each shares a defining story. Ms. Waterston, a Modigliani in motion and often in black, easily holds your attention, but it is Ms. Moss, with her intimate expressivity, who annihilates you from first tear to last crushing laugh.

Women‰Ûªs tears ‰ÛÓ drops of joy and madness both ‰ÛÓ have nourished innumerable movies, art cinema included. The wellspring for Catherine‰Ûªs opening waterworks is twofold: Her beloved father, a famous painter, has recently died, and her lover, James (Kentucker Audley, all smiles and spinelessness), is now leaving her for another woman. In many contemporary movies, the director would cut back and forth between Catherine and James‰Ûªs faces during this scene, for a typical shot, reverse-shot exchange. Often, the camera would make like Tinker Bell, flitting between the characters to peek from behind one and gawp at the other. Mr. Perry avoids over-the-shoulder shots, but, as suggested by the opener that turns Catherine‰Ûªs face into a landscape of pain, he likes claustrophobic close-ups.

There are times in ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth‰Ûù when Mr. Perry, who‰Ûªs content to skim the surface rather than break it, comes across like an exceptionally gifted student trying his hand at art-cinema pastiche. To that end, it can be entertaining to watch him flip through its playbook, trying out oblique angles and off-center staging while the composer Keegan DeWitt‰Ûªs dissonant, mood-altering score samples the Euro-style hits.
‰ÛÏNo Escape‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for much blood, gore and menace. And that karaoke number.

Directed breathlessly by John Erick Dowdle (‰ÛÏAs Above/So Below‰Ûù), the movie is filled with jittery shots from hand-held cameras, and hurtles along at a pace that is especially helpful in racing past the holes in the paper-thin plot. Hammond shows up fortuitously to provide small-arms fire, temporary haven and a plan to get out.

Now Mr. Wilson returns for run-for-your-life seconds. In ‰ÛÏNo Escape,‰Ûù he is again in hostile territory, as Jack Dwyer, an engineer who has joined a multinational corporation after his own company failed, and is moving his family to an unnamed Southeast Asian country. As brave a front as he and his wife, Annie (Lake Bell), put up for their two young daughters, they know the situation is bad. Of course, it‰Ûªs about to get much worse.

For Mr. Wilson, this is probably just a detour from his usual comedic roles. Mr. Brosnan, though, continues to shed the smooth and silky customs of his James Bond days. Among the most terrifying scenes is an early shot of Mr. Brosnan in the hotel bar, shouting lyrics to a Huey Lewis tune. Oh, the horror.

In 2001, already developing a comic acting career, Owen Wilson tried to stretch. In ‰ÛÏBehind Enemy Lines,‰Ûù he played a naval aviator shot down and pursued by bloodthirsty Serbian paramilitary units. Not quite an action hero, he conveyed the intense fear and desperation of a fugitive in the cross hairs.

As ‰ÛÏNo Escape‰Ûù begins, the Dwyers are landing, befriended on their flight by Hammond (Pierce Brosnan), a seatmate with the rough beard, fresh scars and randy cheer of an old post-colonial hand. When Jack takes a walk out of their luxury hotel the next morning, he‰Ûªs caught in a clash between the police and mobs, then scrambles back minutes before anti-Western revolutionaries go room to room, slaughtering foreigners. From that point, the film is a series of fight-or-flight set pieces of the panicked family trying to stay alive.

Considering how aimless its screenplay, how lost its hero and how unglamorous its setting, Bob Byington‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏ7 Chinese Brothers‰Ûù is remarkably appealing. The title might suggest a kung fu caper ‰ÛÓ rather than the R.E.M. song we hear over the end credits ‰ÛÓ but this droll, dry comedy has some moves of its own.
7 CHINESE BROTHERS
1 hour 17 minutes; not rated
Directed by Bob Byington

Drifting and sweet, ‰ÛÏ7 Chinese Brothers‰Ûù (like Mr. Byington‰Ûªs gentle 2009 love story, ‰ÛÏHarmony and Me‰Ûù) leaves a melancholy but hopeful aftertaste. His story may appear weightless, but it has a lot to say about the indignities of service-economy jobs that offer a uniform and a training manual in lieu of an identity. The film‰Ûªs jokes are small and quick, but its repurposed resentments cut deeper as workers violate one another‰Ûªs property and use their uniforms to thieve and deceive. When the name stitched on your chest isn‰Ûªt even your own, self-reinvention seems a fair compensation.  JEANNETTE CATSOULIS
Opens on Friday

Most of them are accomplished by Jason Schwartzman, snufflingly assisted by his real-life pet, a French bulldog named Arrow. Together, their characters share a small apartment in Austin, Tex., consoling each other when one is fired from yet another job and the other has insufficient nap time. As though written with Mr. Schwartzman‰Ûªs low-energy gifts in mind, the role of Larry ‰ÛÓ a boozy, lonely, congenial slacker ‰ÛÓ is familiar but not stale, and his company isn‰Ûªt a drag. Moving resignedly from a chain restaurant to a Quick Lube, he works without enthusiasm or obvious ambition, despite the proddings of his spiky grandmother (Olympia Dukakis). Marking time in a nursing home, Grandma knows that the window for change is always slowly closing.
Directed by Max Joseph
WE ARE YOUR FRIENDS
And then the movie stalls.

If the filmmakers were aiming to mimic the flow of electronic dance music, they succeeded. The action slowly builds and breaks down, with dance beats kicking in periodically. Not much resonates here; it‰Ûªs all facile entertainment. This is not the fault of its stars; Mr. Efron and Mr. Bentley do what they can with the material. (One compelling subplot, however, involves an unscrupulous businessman targeting homeowners in foreclosure.) Max Joseph, making his directorial feature debut, and Meaghan Oppenheimer wrote the script, adapted from Richard Silverman‰Ûªs story.

In one scene early in ‰ÛÏWe Are Your Friends,‰Ûù a Los Angeles art gallery filled with dancing revelers morphs into a dreamlike animation. This alternate reality is seen through the eyes of an aspiring D.J., Cole (Zac Efron), who is there, high on PCP, with his newfound mentor, James (Wes Bentley). His euphoria is vivid, almost palpable, as the paintings and people begin to transform in unison to the pulsing beat.

Cole‰Ûªs bros, archetypes all, feel as if they belong in different movies. In their early 20s, they share an aimless existence, promoting parties and pining for a ticket out of the San Fernando Valley. When James, a burned-out alcoholic, takes Cole under his wing ‰ÛÓ a contrived move that sets up a clichÌ©d love triangle involving James‰Ûªs assistant and girlfriend (Emily Ratajkowski) ‰ÛÓ Cole sees his potential future. He takes the bait, and we can hardly blame him.
‰ÛÏWe Are Your Friends‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for nothing you haven‰Ûªt seen or heard before.
1 hour 37 minutes
Opens on Friday

And after reading Hannah Arendt‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏEichmann in Jerusalem‰Ûù for that darn philosophy class, Damien learns that his beloved grandfather was happy to work for the Vichy government and didn‰Ûªt worry about deporting French Jews to concentration camps. Damien is stricken with remorse for his own random killing. Maybe he‰Ûªs not such a psychopath, after all.
Opens on Friday
Zoe‰Ûªs curiosity shakes up her sedate routine, stirring her from complacency. Pierre, racked with regret, has trouble coping with the normal social and academic pressures of senior year.
1 hour 21 minutes; not rated

‰ÛÏFever‰Ûù at first just appears to be a French version of the Leopold and Loeb case, a suspense flick about two teenagers who kill for the thrill of it. But the film, directed by RaphaÌÇl Neal and adapted from a novel by Leslie Kaplan, proves to be a quirky parable of guilt, passion and social responsibility.
FEVER

As it begins, Damien (Martin Loizillon) and Pierre (Pierre Moure), Parisian high school seniors, have just killed a woman. The boys were testing a theory that Damien ‰ÛÓ the smug, blond, deeply deviant one ‰ÛÓ has been developing in philosophy class. For a crime to occur, he argues, there must be a personal motive; if something happens by chance ‰ÛÓ a random act of violence, say ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs no culpability.
In French, with English subtitles
Directed by RaphaÌÇl Neal

Leaving the victim‰Ûªs apartment at midday, they bump into Zoe (Julie-Marie Parmentier), who works nearby. When she hears of the murder and that the police don‰Ûªt have any leads, she remembers the boys and tries to find them.

‰ÛÏFever‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt come to a neat ending and ultimately feels unsatisfying. Before then, though, it‰Ûªs an intriguing and intelligent update of a true crime still chilling more than 90 years later. DANIEL M. GOLD
In English, Spanish and Portuguese, with English subtitles
I TOUCHED ALL YOUR STUFF

In ‰ÛÏI Touched All Your Stuff,‰Ûù the documentarians MaÌ_ra BÌ_hler and Matias Mariani hand the mike to Chris Kirk, a slippery American computer technician who became infatuated with a Japanese-Colombian woman and was later convicted of drug smuggling. Mr. Kirk sings his song of obsession, amid a visual barrage of online chats and personal photos from his hard drive, but apart from the not very surprising fact that our narrator may not be telling the whole truth, his well-rehearsed story feels increasingly belabored.
The filmmakers pop their story‰Ûªs bubble in a confusing finish, but it all ends up feeling like a mystery novel that simply never revealed the key clues. NICOLAS RAPOLD
Directed by MaÌ_ra BÌ_hler and Matias Mariani

Ms. BÌ_hler and Mr. Mariani came across Mr. Kirk while shooting an earlier documentary about foreigners in Brazil‰Ûªs prison system, and their subject delivers his monologues here as that project‰Ûªs participants did, clad in saffron prison garb behind a table. Bright-eyed and cue-ball bald, Mr. Kirk recounts falling hard for the ‰ÛÏexotic‰Ûù beauty he identifies only as ‰ÛÏV.,‰Ûù who was apparently a serial philanderer.
1 hour 31 minutes; not rated
Opens on Friday

Or he‰Ûªs making some of it up; as friends testify, he‰Ûªs a tricky one. With an invisible femme fatale ‰ÛÓ V. is glimpsed only in blurry photos and glancing video clips ‰ÛÓ what we‰Ûªre left with is the sense of a con, drawn out to extravagant lengths. Unlike the exhilarating fabulist at the heart of Errol Morris‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏTabloid,‰Ûù Mr. Kirk is a solo player on this stage, and none too riveting. And online chats on computer screens, no matter how damning, make for tedious visuals.
‰ÛÏThe Second Mother‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Wrong ice cream.
In Portuguese, with English subtitles

The director, Anna Muylaert, augments the tension with her visual style, using the wide frame and doorways to establish Val‰Ûªs perspective. But ‰ÛÏThe Second Mother‰Ûù goes soft toward the end, defusing its conflicts too easily and inconsequentially. BEN KENIGSBERG
THE SECOND MOTHER

To Val, these are rules a person knows from birth, yet the relationships seem to defy a natural order. Jessica calls her mother Val. Fabinho, nearing college age, hops into bed with his nanny to cuddle.
Directed by Anna Muylaert
1 hour 50 minutes

Jessica, while not quite rude, blazes through the house undaunted by the boundaries that Val takes for granted. Dissatisfied with her mother‰Ûªs cramped room, Jessica lays claim to the more comfortable guest bedroom. Carlos (Lourenco Mutarelli), Barbara‰Ûªs smitten husband, permits Jessica to eat the ice cream normally reserved for Fabinho (Michel Joelsas), his and Barbara‰Ûªs son, raised by Val as if he were her own. Will she dare take a dip in the swimming pool ‰ÛÓ a further affront to Val‰Ûªs sense of propriety?
Opens on Friday

Class friction has been a major subject in recent South American cinema, whether in the movies of the Argentine director Lucrecia Martel (‰ÛÏThe Headless Woman‰Ûù) or those of the Chilean filmmaker SebastiÌÁn Silva (‰ÛÏThe Maid‰Ûù).

The Brazilian drama ‰ÛÏThe Second Mother‰Ûù centers on Val (Regina CasÌ©), the live-in housekeeper for a wealthy family in SÌ£o Paulo. When Val announces that Jessica (Camila MÌÁrdila), the daughter she hasn‰Ûªt seen in a decade, is coming to town, Barbara (Karine Teles), Val‰Ûªs employer, is happy to welcome the young woman as a guest.
Directed by Simeon Rice
UNSULLIED
‰ÛÏUnsullied‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and sexual situations.
1 hour 33 minutes

The movie flirts with 1970s exploitation revenge pictures, complete with a 1971 Chevrolet Chevelle Super Sport, but comes up short on the attendant payoffs. (Even a third-act reversal lacks a sufficiently rewarding comeuppance.) The actors, including Erin Boyes as another captive, try to infuse their characters with depth, and the cinematographer, Scott Winig, lends the proceedings a professional gloss, especially in nighttime scenes. But their efforts cannot lift the story beyond its thin, lurid premise. ANDY WEBSTER

Though Reagan, as played by Ms. Gray, seems far too smart to fall for her captors‰Ûª ruse, she does. But before you know it, she‰Ûªs off: escaping from their house and running through forests, diving into lakes and swimming across ponds, the men in constant pursuit. Though she has a contrived back story (about her vanished sister, who always encouraged her athletic aspirations), she fortunately doesn‰Ûªt have ‰ÛÓ and doesn‰Ûªt miss ‰ÛÓ a boyfriend (‰ÛÏRight now, I‰Ûªm just focused on me‰Ûù).
Opens on Friday

‰ÛÏUnsullied‰Ûù? ‰ÛÏUnrelenting‰Ûù is more like it. This nasty low-budget thriller, the first feature directed by the former N.F.L. defensive end Simeon Rice, tells a story rife with implausibilities. But it does have a few redeeming aspects, including a hardy newcomer, the actress Murray Gray, as Reagan, a competitive runner with the misfortune of having her car break down in a remote Florida backwater. It‰Ûªs Reagan‰Ûªs further bad luck to encounter two wealthy, hunky, smooth-talking brothers (James Gaudioso and Rusty Joiner) with a big estate and a penchant for kidnapping and rape.

In American popular culture, lycanthropy has typically been a guy thing. For the hapless Eisenhower-era protagonist of ‰ÛÏI Was a Teenage Werewolf‰Ûù and for the studly Jacob Black in the ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù movies, sprouting fur, fangs and claws was a metaphor for uncontrollable adolescent male rage. But girls are angry, too, and the teenage werewolf in ‰ÛÏWhen Animals Dream,‰Ûù a spare and smart Danish thriller, comes of age in particularly infuriating circumstances.

That becomes clear only gradually. First, Marie (Sonia Suhl) must contend with some alarming physical and mental changes. She notices odd hairy patches on her chest and back. Her temper has grown shorter and more violent. Her dreams are bloody. Her father (Lars Mikkelsen) and the local doctor (Stig Hoffmeyer), an elderly man, are aware of what‰Ûªs going on, but they also seem to be hiding the truth, and Marie‰Ûªs mother (Sonja Richter), who sits silent in a wheelchair, heavily drugged because of an unexplained affliction, can‰Ûªt supply maternal advice.

‰ÛÏWhen Animals Dream‰Ûù is as much a romantic coming-of-age story as a horror movie. Mr. Arnby emphasizes Marie‰Ûªs dread and confusion ‰ÛÓ her panic at her own feelings and her growing distrust of the people around her ‰ÛÓ rather than the fear she provokes. The dialogue in the script (written by Rasmus Birch) has been pared to a minimum, and nearly all the exposition is handled by precise imagery and efficient editing. Mr. Arnby knows all the genre codes, and how to subvert them when necessary.

In time, the connection between Marie‰Ûªs condition and her mother‰Ûªs is explained, but in the midst of trying to understand what‰Ûªs happening to her, Marie endures taunting and harassment from the men at the fish processing plant where she works. They shove her into a vat of rotting fish carcasses as part of an initiation ritual, and look at her with barely disguised predatory interest. Not that she is simply a passive victim. She has her eye on a young man named Daniel (Jakob Oftebro), who serves as the film‰Ûªs reminder that not all men are misogynist jerks.

‰ÛÏWhen Animals Dream‰Ûù is a beguiling parable of cruelty and the resistance to it. Its special effects are pretty minimal, its scope is modest, and it is, in the end, more touching than terrifying, intent on jolting its audience not with dread but with compassion.

Slender and watchful, Ms. Suhl doesn‰Ûªt look especially frightening ‰ÛÓ instead of howling at the moon, she seethes quietly ‰ÛÓ but the contrast between Marie‰Ûªs frail appearance and her latent ferocity is crucial to the film‰Ûªs emotional power and its feminist themes. It‰Ûªs partly a movie about the male terror of female sexuality, and the lengths that men will go to tame and suppress a force that threatens their control of the world. That Marie turns out to be a werewolf is both a confirmation of patriarchal fears and a convenient excuse for the men who would be inclined to mistreat her anyway.

Directed by Jonas Alexander Arnby, ‰ÛÏWhen Animals Dream‰Ûù is moody and austere. Like the recent Swedish vampire film ‰ÛÏLet the Right One In‰Ûù (and its English remake, ‰ÛÏLet Me In‰Ûù), it regards its monstrous heroine with empathy rather than horror. And like the unnamed Girl in Ana Lily Amirpour‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏA Girl Walks Home Alone at Night‰Ûù (speaking of vampires), Marie, a quiet and fine-boned teenager living with her parents on a windswept island, is a figure of righteous vengeance.
‰ÛÏWhen Animals Dream‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Animal appetites.

‰ÛÏZ for Zachariah‰Ûù may not be the most eventful post-apocalyptic drama, but its grip is strong and sure. Set in a verdant valley (with New Zealand standing in for the American South) that has somehow survived the fallout from an unspecified nuclear catastrophe, this minimalist but deeply affecting morality play slowly tugs you in.
‰ÛÏZ for Zachariah‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Add one curious virgin to one sexy drifter, and stand back.

This pairing alone is thematically fertile, but the director, Craig Zobel, is after more than just a joust between religion and rationality. And though the two belief systems butt heads when Loomis wants to tear down the church built by Ann‰Ûªs father and repurpose the wood as a water wheel for hydroelectric power, faith-based conflict is not the film‰Ûªs primary engine. That would be jealousy.

Nursing him back to health, Ann is drawn to his intelligence and enterprising spirit, each finding a renewed purpose in the other‰Ûªs companionship. Sex and romance seem inevitable, and Ann is more than game, but Loomis, who exudes an innate decency, prefers to wait. Older, African-American and atheist, he may still feel constraints that should no longer apply.

The film‰Ûªs casting, like its aesthetic, is golden. Ms. Robbie is almost unrecognizable as the woman who played the brassy wife of Leonardo DiCaprio‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏThe Wolf of Wall Street,‰Ûù and Mr. Pine sways from cunning to innocuous with sly skill. Mr. Ejiofor, of course, never disappoints, and here he gives Loomis the beguiling vulnerability of a man carrying a dreadful secret ‰ÛÓ one that could alienate Ann for good.

From its magical setting (what gives this valley its environmental protection?) to its vacillating mood and chillingly vague conclusion, ‰ÛÏZ for Zachariah‰Ûù keeps you off balance. In wondering what will matter at the end of the world, the story neither excavates nor resolves all of its themes. It‰Ûªs just as well that the pleasures of the journey are more than enough.

Its fulcrum is Ann (a mesmerizing turn by the young Australian actress Margot Robbie), a preacher‰Ûªs daughter left alone when her family headed out to seek other survivors. Pale and purposeful, she grows vegetables and traps small animals, radiating the calm confidence of those accustomed to leaning on faith ‰ÛÓ unlike Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor), the research scientist who stumbles into her valley one day, unwisely strips off the protective suit he designed and jumps into an irradiated waterfall.

Shot with shimmering naturalism by the cinematographer Tim Orr, ‰ÛÏZ for Zachariah‰Ûù responds to future doom with primal instincts. Race still rankles (at one point, Loomis comments that white people belong together), and the bruising realities of age are amplified. But repopulating a blasted earth requires commitment, not passion, and Mr. Zobel ‰ÛÓ as he proved with his profoundly unnerving 2012 thriller, ‰ÛÏCompliance‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ has no problem depicting sex as a destabilizing force used to exert superiority. Maintaining a strict formal allegiance to reserve and restraint, he shapes a dreamily elegant emotional ballet from glances and gestures and subtle shifts in power.

Adapting a 1974 novel by Robert C. O‰ÛªBrien (posthumously completed and published by Mr. O‰ÛªBrien‰Ûªs wife and their daughter), the screenwriter, Nissar Modi, conjures an admittedly trite Eden metaphor ‰ÛÓ with the camera zooming pointedly on a children‰Ûªs book titled ‰ÛÏA Is for Adam‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ rived by uneasily jagged undertones. If Ann and Loomis are our original sinners, then the snake is Caleb (Chris Pine), a rangy former miner who slithers, destitute and devastatingly handsome, onto their doorstep and into their heads.

It would all be eye-roll-inducing were it not for Ms. Jeon‰Ûªs striking poise and the luminous presence of Ms. Kim, an eager performer who imbues the film with energy. So bright is her light that when Hong-yi receives a near-fatal sword thrust, it‰Ûªs alarming. She is one character you do not want to see departing from this movie. It gives nothing away to say that she doesn‰Ûªt.
In Korean, with English subtitles

Though rich in period detail, the movie grows tiresome with solemn, protracted soap-operatic encounters laden with glowering stares and tearful outbursts. (Conspicuously absent is any hint of humor.) And then there are the all-too-familiar genre trappings: lavish palace interiors, pastoral tableaus, a wizened master imparting wisdom and battle maneuvers, an assassin mowing down palace guards en route to a climactic confrontation, blades clashing in a snowy courtyard.
Directed by Park Heung-sik

In Park Heung-sik‰Ûªs historical martial-arts spectacle ‰ÛÏMemories of the Sword,‰Ûù the visuals dazzle and the emotional temperature boils. It is the Goreyo era in Korean history, and two warriors, the blind swordswoman Wol-so (Jeon Do-yeon) and the royal chancellor, Yu-baek (Lee Byung-hun), are locked in enmity over the long-ago death of Wol-so‰Ûªs sweetheart, who was fatally betrayed by Yu-baek. Complicating matters is Hong-yi (Kim Go-eun), a young woman raised by Wol-so who believes that Yu-baek is responsible for the deaths of her parents. A skilled fighter, she advances toward vengeance.
Opens on Friday
2 hours 1 minute; not rated
MEMORIES OF THE SWORD

These young actors ‰ÛÓ bouncy, naughty, striving, hesitant ‰ÛÓ are not the expected high achievers. Many come from schools on the lowest academic rung; some are blind; others have discernible behavioral or learning issues; a number of their families live in public housing.
In Cantonese, with English subtitles
MY VOICE, MY LIFE

Led by teachers with heart who push, pull, discipline and inspire them, the 31 performers undergo six tough months preparing their musical, ‰ÛÏThe Awakening,‰Ûù which is patched together from familiar tunes appropriated from other shows. Student filmmakers shoot the unfolding action, and the final product incorporates their work.
1 hour 31 minutes; not rated
Opens on Friday

And pain arises here, as cruelty does toward the shunned children in ‰ÛÏThe Blood of Yingzhou District.‰Ûù Tsz Nok, who sings the male lead in ‰ÛÏThe Awakening,‰Ûù lost his sight only the year before. His elegantly turned out mother is in denial and prefers to hide his condition, while her son faces it with equanimity and curiosity. HELEN T. VERONGOS

There are few feelings as glorious as spreading your wings onstage for the first time. Ruby Yang captures that rare electricity in her documentary ‰ÛÏMy Voice, My Life,‰Ûù about Hong Kong teenagers who put on a show.

The kids ‰ÛÓ among them Ah Bok (credited as Jason Chow), the handsome troublemaker; Fat Yin, the class clown (‰ÛÏHe was so cute, like a steamed bun,‰Ûù his principal says, showing an old photo); and Sio Fan, the visually impaired girl who takes such joy in dancing ‰ÛÓ are transformed by the experience.

Although ‰ÛÏMy Voice, My Life‰Ûù lacks the raw emotion of ‰ÛÏThe Blood of Yingzhou District,‰Ûù Ms. Yang‰Ûªs Oscar-winning film on Chinese AIDS orphans, this movie does depict young lives changed, and perhaps saved.
Directed by Ruby Yang
Opens on Friday
1 hour 52 Minutes
‰ÛÏZipper‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nudity and sexual situations.
In the third act, the film digs into wider implications, with Richard Dreyfuss in a delicious turn as a back-room political kingmaker. Eliot Spitzer, you are not forgotten. ANDY WEBSTER
Directed by Mora Stephens
ZIPPER

The actor Patrick Wilson has a gift for delectably malign roles: He was a possessed parent in two installments of ‰ÛÏInsidious,‰Ûù an oily C.I.A. officer in ‰ÛÏThe A-Team‰Ûù and, in his most disturbing portrait, an online predator in ‰ÛÏHard Candy.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏZipper,‰Ûù Mora Stephens‰Ûªs engrossing tale of a legal eagle‰Ûªs sexual addiction, Mr. Wilson plays Sam Ellis, a straight-arrow prosecutor in South Carolina skilled at taking on errant politicians. Married to a smart, supportive ex-lawyer (a fine Lena Headey), with whom he has a son, Sam is egged on to seek elected office.

But he develops an Achilles heel: his libido, fired by salacious websites, an aggressively seductive intern (Dianna Agron) and a case witness (Elena Satine) who is an unapologetic escort-service employee. Soon he is caught in a spiral of $1,000-an-hour hotel trysts, with his marriage, bank account and career on the line. Mr. Wilson, as dexterous with righteous bravado as with calibrated self-disgust, ably captures Sam‰Ûªs growing enslavement to his impulses. The script, by Ms. Stephens and Joel Viertel, though lurching at times into overstatement, is enhanced with worthy if fleeting performances from John Cho and Christopher McDonald as Sam‰Ûªs colleagues. Ray Winstone, as a journalist, effectively melds sleaze and compassion.

That great untamed being emerges these days in Mr. Nolte‰Ûªs lumbering, dominating physicality (he takes up space with personality and not just girth) and in the stubbornly insubordinate hair that insists on sneaking out from under his hat. Mostly, you see it the way that you‰Ûªve always seen it: in the unyielding, liberated spirit that can‰Ûªt be tamped down either by age or by an easygoing, easy-viewing entertainment like ‰ÛÏA Walk in the Woods.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs a relief, because while the movie involves a leisurely excursion on the Appalachian Trail, it nervously runs from anything that might lead it into uncharted, unsafe territory. Here, the cooked outpaces the raw from first mile to last.

There‰Ûªs a scene in ‰ÛÏA Walk in the Woods,‰Ûù a low-impact amble through hill, dale and cinematic nostalgia, when our two crusty trekkers face down a pair of bears. The men ‰ÛÓ Robert Redford and Nick Nolte ‰ÛÓ are slumbering in their tents when the bears descend and begin tearing into the hikers‰Ûª food, which they have failed to properly stash. The bears roar and the men thunder back, flapping uvulas and arms to chase off the animals. It‰Ûªs a mildly funny scene, partly because of its light physical comedy and sight gaggery, although also because Mr. Nolte, his signature growl now often at sepulchral depths, has been doing a fair impression of a wild beast for years.

Mr. Kwapis, who has directed movies like ‰ÛÏThe Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants‰Ûù (a title that seems to cry out for a regulation joke about this one‰Ûªs brotherhood), has signed his name to ‰ÛÏA Walk in the Woods.‰Ûù Its more obvious authorial presence, though, is Mr. Redford, who makes an appealing, modestly glamorized and fictionalized (and older) Bill Bryson.
