The actors (including Holt McCallany as a police detective who gives Leah some no-nonsense advice) certainly had more to offer than the paint-by-numbers script asks.

Ms. Lathan (‰ÛÏThe Best Man‰Ûù) is Leah, a hotshot lobbyist who in the film‰Ûªs first few minutes ends a two-year relationship with Dave (Morris Chestnut) because they disagree on what to do about her ticking biological clock. It‰Ûªs not a convincing break-up scene, but the story must be moved along, and soon it is: Leah meets the smooth, handsome Carter (Mr. Ealy). She may be smart in the political world, but she is naÌøvely easy prey for Carter, who quickly charms her into a relationship.

The match, which was played in Iceland, was a classic pre-Internet media circus, and the film efficiently captures the bombast it inspired in the United States, not to mention the chess mania. Liev Schreiber has an impossible job as Spassky, thanks to too many comedians who have created too many caricatures built on taciturn, tanklike Russians and East Europeans; he seems like a caricature himself.

It was a challenge to play Bobby Fischer in chess, and it‰Ûªs a challenge for an actor to play him on the screen. Anyone taking on the task needs to be careful not to get carried away with the man‰Ûªs eccentricities, to make sure to retain the pathos beneath the sideshow.

And, ultimately, it is only partly about Bobby Fischer. It is equally about us ‰ÛÓ Americans or any other nationality inclined to put too much importance on chess matches, soccer matches, space races, whatever. It‰Ûªs about how we manufacture celebrities on scant pretext and then destroy them, or allow them to destroy themselves while we watch.

The Fischer-Spassky match in the summer of 1972 took place, of course, during the Cold War, with the title of world champion at stake. Chess was a game the Soviets owned, but Fischer had been a force to be reckoned with since he was a child.

The film gives a sketch of Fischer‰Ûªs youth, hitting just enough of it to link his future paranoia to mommy issues. (Robin Weigert plays his mother, Regina; Lily Rabe is his sister, Joan.) This section of the film feels a little pat, but it at least helps set up the coming political dynamics, Regina having been under the F.B.I.‰Ûªs watchful eye for suspected Communist sympathies.

Pity any ardent chess fans who go to this movie; they‰Ûªll be pounding the walls over the differences between Mr. Zwick‰Ûªs depiction and reality, and will no doubt be irked that the film doesn‰Ûªt dwell much on the actual chess playing. But this isn‰Ûªt a chess movie, it isn‰Ûªt a biopic, and it isn‰Ûªt a documentary. (For that, see ‰ÛÏBobby Fischer Against the World,‰Ûù a very good 2011 treatment from HBO.) It‰Ûªs a dramatization, one aimed at a general audience.

But the focus is on Fischer, and Mr. Maguire, though not as imposing as the 6-foot-1 Fischer, is certainly as unpredictable. Fischer put all sorts of demands on the organizers of the match and skipped one game entirely. The film doesn‰Ûªt delve into his life after the match, in which he forfeited his title; became known for incendiary remarks, especially about Judaism and Israel; and ultimately faded into obscurity before his death in 2008.

But Mr. Maguire certainly shows us the beginnings of all that and gives us a man who, while a great chess player, was poorly suited to become the central figure in a Cold War carnival. He was clearly beginning to melt down during this high-profile moment in time, with his coach, a chess-playing priest named Bill Lombardy (nicely portrayed by Peter Sarsgaard), shouldering much of the burden of keeping him on track.
‰ÛÏPawn Sacrifice‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for a hint of sexuality and a smattering of strong language. Oh, and cigarette smoke.

Tobey Maguire meets that challenge adroitly in ‰ÛÏPawn Sacrifice,‰Ûù a film by Edward Zwick about Fischer‰Ûªs chess match against the Soviet grandmaster Boris Spassky. His character is infuriating ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏJust play the game, already,‰Ûù you want to shout at the screen as Fischer‰Ûªs real and imagined demons cause him to disrupt the match. Yet you regret succumbing to that feeling because you know intellectually that the guy is not being merely petulant.

Retired from public service, Mr. Lawrence is shown at work repairing sewage pumps. (‰ÛÏActually, it‰Ûªs a step up from being a politician,‰Ûù he jokes.) He also now assists in investigations of instances in which law enforcement officers are accused of using excessive force elsewhere in Utah. He scours homes to determine who stood where and when during police raids, and faults what he sees as shoddy post-mortem detective work.

Some of the most quietly powerful footage shows Mr. Lawrence hanging lines to reconstruct bullet trajectories, and lying on a driveway to show the position of his son-in-law when he died. While ‰ÛÏPeace Officer‰Ûù could offer more information, what is here is disturbing and sometimes eye-opening.

At the same time, ‰ÛÏPeace Officer‰Ûù does little to examine the impact of race on the deployment of force, and by emphasizing drug enforcement it skirts the role of the Sept. 11 attacks in augmenting police militarization. There is also little sense of how police officers are trained to use these weapons. The film‰Ûªs most shocking moment is a shooting in a drug raid captured by an officer‰Ûªs helmet camera.

Its central figure is Dub Lawrence, a former sheriff and county commissioner in Utah. In 1975, Mr. Lawrence started the first SWAT unit in Davis County. Decades later, he got a new perspective on the results: In September 2008, his son-in-law Brian Wood was killed by a member of that unit in a standoff after a fight with Mr. Lawrence‰Ûªs daughter. Mr. Lawrence saw the killing as a wildly overzealous reaction that flew in the face of expectations of police professionalism and training, and he resolved to determine exactly what happened.
‰ÛÏPeace Officer,‰Ûù a documentary about the militarization of law enforcement, is nothing if not timely, though its focus is mostly confined to one state.

The directors, Scott Christopherson and Brad Barber, selected Mr. Lawrence as a subject before last year‰Ûªs unrest in Ferguson, Mo., prompted a surge in reporting on the flow of military weapons to municipal police forces. They provide some national context through interviews with experts on that issue, like Kara Dansky, a lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union, and Radley Balko, who writes a blog for The Washington Post. The movie‰Ûªs limited geographic focus seems prescient in one respect: Last year Utah issued reporting requirements on the use of tactical assault groups.

Built four decades ago, the town of 30,000 already looks ancient but not in a good way. Its public housing resembles decaying prison architecture, and the streets are covered with a thin blanket of dirty snow. How, you wonder, could anything good flourish in this ugly, dehumanizing cesspool of social rot, entrenched corruption and brutish inhumanity overseen by a cabal of bigwigs whom the movie observes like suspects in a police lineup.

Against the advice of his mother ‰ÛÓ who fears for his safety, but is contemptuous of her husband and son‰Ûªs virtuous refusal to grab their share of bribes and kickbacks ‰ÛÓ Dima impulsively barges into a raucous bacchanal where Nina‰Ûªs 50th birthday is being celebrated.
‰ÛÏThe Fool‰Ûù is a hard movie to shake.

Nina is a stout, bejeweled diva who gives orders with a peremptory bark. Impatiently, she summons council members to an emergency meeting in another room while outside the thudding party music measures the ominous heartbeat of a race against time. The drunk, surly council members show up scowling as Dima describes the crisis, which he thinks requires the building‰Ûªs immediate evacuation. Inspectors, including Dima‰Ûªs boss, Federotov (Boris Nevzorov), rush to the site, and Dima‰Ûªs warnings are confirmed.

This house of horrors is inhabited by addicts and impoverished pensioners who fight about money and steal from one another. Furious squabbles echo through the narrow hallways in which clusters of sneering teenagers consume heroin.

Grilled by Nina about what happened to funds allocated for the building‰Ûªs upkeep, the council members describe how money for repairs was systemically diverted for personal use. The looks they exchange are more defiant than guilty, and no blame is assigned.

In the warning words of the imperious mayor, Nina (Nataliya Surkova), a.k.a. Mama, addressing the city council during a crisis: ‰ÛÏA fish rots from the head down. If I am tainted, then so are all of you.‰Ûù

Nina admits to skimming money from many civic projects, but unlike several underlings, including Federotov, she has pangs of conscience. Once it is determined that there is no money or space for housing potential evacuees, Nina, whom Ms. Surkova imbues with an operatic ferocity, faces an acute moral crisis. Federotov, reminded by Dima that the endangered people are human beings, dismisses them as ‰ÛÏtrash and rejects.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏMaybe they should die,‰Ûù he shouts, bringing the party to a momentary silence before the festivities resume, and a grisly cover-up begins.

The trouble begins when Dima and a repair crew are summoned to fix a burst steam pipe in a decrepit nine-story structure that houses more than 800 people, and he discovers a crack in the wall. Further inspection reveals the fissure extends from the building‰Ûªs foundation to the top and that the structure is leaning to one side. It is only a matter of hours until it collapses, he believes. If the residents aren‰Ûªt relocated, many will die.

The dreary unidentified Russian town that is the setting of Yuri Bykov‰Ûªs devastating film, ‰ÛÏThe Fool,‰Ûù is an outpost of hell. If you can bear to look at it, I recommend you pay a visit and study it from behind bulletproof glass, because similar places aren‰Ûªt all that uncommon.

As Nina‰Ûªs sinister husband, for whom she once worked as a secretary, explains: ‰ÛÏHere you either live like a human being or like cattle. There‰Ûªs not enough of the good life to go around. If you divided everything equally, everybody would be poor.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏThe Fool‰Ûù wraps its Hobbesian vision of squalor around a fable worthy of Frank Capra, but twisted to suggest a cruel inversion of Capra‰Ûªs inspirational allegories of humble Everymen crusading for justice and democratic ideals.

The third film by Mr. Bykov, who also wrote the screenplay, ‰ÛÏThe Fool‰Ûù is the latest in a lengthening list of Russian miserablist films. Others include Andrey Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏElena‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLeviathan,‰Ûù both of which offer damning portraits of everyday life under Vladimir V. Putin. Unlike ‰ÛÏLeviathan,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Fool‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt refer directly to Mr. Putin, but its depressing portrayal of oligarchical privilege and lawlessness is every bit as scathing.

The title character, Dima (Artem Bystrov), is a naÌøve plumber who tries to avert a catastrophe brought on by the civic leaders‰Ûª greed and indifference to the people they serve. Dima, who is studying construction and lives with his family in a shabby apartment, is an anomaly: a good Samaritan toiling in a jungle. When he feels compelled to alert the city council to imminent danger, his embittered mother and fearful wife urge him not to rankle the powers that be.

Britni West, the screenwriter and director, resists opportunities to over explain desires and motivations. In scenes that are often only semi-scripted, Adam Ginsberg‰Ûªs camera explores the farms, bars and motels where residents spend their days, and the small pleasures that get them through their nights ‰ÛÓ a cool drink, a fireworks display.

The film recalls ‰ÛÏBeasts of the Southern Wild‰Ûù in its rough edges and use of first-time actors. Liz Randall, in her acting debut as Dawn, and Mr. Dickinson, as Paul, are wonderful in a courtship that is by turns tender and cringe-inducing. Like everyone here, including Alex Karpovsky as that caring son and Hillary Berg as the young woman, they keep their words to a minimum; there are many lengthy sections with no dialogue.

In that part of the country, ‰ÛÏEvery town has a post office, lovers, guns, switch blades and beer,‰Ûù Mr. Dickinson says, reciting one of his poems. ‰ÛÏYou just have to know where to look, and when to look the other way.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏTired Moonlight‰Ûù weaves together several wispy story lines to create a picture of small-town life in Montana: A middle-aged couple fumbles through a burgeoning romance; a son cares for his immigrant mother; a young woman endures some disappointments.

A voice-over sporadically chimes in with verse during ‰ÛÏTired Moonlight‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the words, by the poet Paul Dickinson, are gritty, stark, aching. But images supply even finer poetry in this bleakly beautiful film.

To be sure, even at under 80 minutes, this mostly plotless film can feel drawn out and stingy with details. It certainly demands patience (and a forgiving eye) as it experiments with an odd style. Yet it‰Ûªs also a compassionate look at characters who don‰Ûªt dwell on life. Instead, they live.

Mr. Depp, with sweptback silver hair, a dead front tooth and a grayish complexion offsetting icy blue eyes, gives Jimmy a vampirish air. He sips ginger ale from a bottle while his colleagues down shots and pints of beer, and speaks in a fierce whisper. He is nice to old ladies on the street, devoted to his mother and brother, and shows himself to be a doting (and then a grieving) father. The contradiction between this apparent soft side and his general disregard for human life feels less like an insight than like boilerplate, a clichÌ© to set alongside the splattering of brains against car-window glass, the surprise whackings of guys who thought they were on their way to whack other guys, and the invocations of loyalty.
‰ÛÏBlack Mass‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Explosive profanity, exploding heads.

Currently a permanent guest of the federal government after 16 years as a fugitive, James J. Bulger was, in the 1970s and ‰Ûª80s, Boston‰Ûªs most notorious criminal. While his younger brother William served as president of the Massachusetts State Senate, James (referred to as Whitey, though he disliked the nickname) ran the Winter Hill Gang, an especially vicious enterprise in a business not known for delicacy. He also enjoyed a cozy relationship with the local office of the F.B.I., which turned a blind eye to his crimes in exchange for information about the activities of his rivals.

The other side of the law is populated, as usual, by colorful thugs with rougher faces and thicker accents. (Hey, guys, can we give Boston a rest as a crime-movie backdrop, and maybe try Chicago for a while? I say this as a former resident of both cities and a longtime fan of the letter R.) The episodic narrative is framed by testimony from some of Jimmy‰Ûªs former underlings, who turned on him when a new prosecutor (Corey Stoll) came to town. Jesse Plemons as Kevin Weeks, Rory Cochrane as Steve Flemmi and W. Earl Brown as the slow-moving hit man John Martorano are all credibly gamy and mean, and the matter-of-factness of their testimony is the best, most honest part of the movie.

Benedict Cumberbatch plays William Bulger with a slyness that makes you wish ‰ÛÏBlack Mass‰Ûù had delved deeper into the mysteries of blood and power. And the appearance, at the margins of the story, of Julianne Nicholson (as Connolly‰Ûªs wife, Marianne), Dakota Johnson (as Lindsey Cyr, the mother of Jimmy‰Ûªs son) and Juno Temple (as Deborah Hussey, a young victim of Whitey‰Ûªs paranoia) exposes the limitations of the film‰Ûªs angle of vision on the world its characters occupy. We‰Ûªre in historically masculine genre territory, of course, but this movie‰Ûªs collection of mothers, wives and mistresses is especially threadbare. More boilerplate.

He was a government informer who meted out lethal punishment to suspected rats; a remorseless killer viewed as a folk hero by some of his fellow citizens; a sentimental son of South Boston who brought drugs into his own neighborhood, and his story all but begs for a movie. Some elements of it have already made it to the screen. ‰ÛÏThe Departed,‰Ûù Martin Scorsese‰Ûªs remake of a classic Hong Kong crime film, incorporates aspects of the Whitey Bulger legend. ‰ÛÏWhitey,‰Ûù Joe Berlinger‰Ûªs solid documentary, looks squarely in the faces of his victims and their families, dispelling some of the aura of gangster romance that always seems to surround white ethnic practitioners of organized crime.

I‰Ûªm not really raising a moral objection here. I have seen ‰ÛÏGoodfellas‰Ûù and the ‰ÛÏGodfather‰Ûù movies more times than I can count, and I‰Ûªm as susceptible as any other deskbound, conflict-averse fantasist to the visceral appeal of a good gangster movie. But ‰ÛÏBlack Mass‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt one. Mr. Cooper‰Ûªs direction is skillful, if overly reliant on borrowed Scorseseisms (especially when it comes to music), and the cast is first-rate, but the film is a muddle of secondhand attitudes and half-baked ideas. It feels more like a costume party than a costume drama.

It‰Ûªs possible, though, to think of the shortcomings of ‰ÛÏBlack Mass‰Ûù as fitting comeuppance for Mr. Bulger. He may have thought he was a big deal, but in the end all he merits is a minor gangster movie.

Not to mention the scenes of men in suits slamming their hands on desks and yelling at one another. ‰ÛÏBlack Mass‰Ûù pivots between the streets and bars of Southie and the F.B.I. offices at Government Center, where Jimmy‰Ûªs boyhood pal John Connolly (Joel Edgerton) has set himself up as the scourge of the Italian mob while also serving as Whitey‰Ûªs inside man. Mr. Edgerton‰Ûªs hot-blooded strutting and shouting contrasts intriguingly with Mr. Depp‰Ûªs chilly reserve, but Connolly remains a one-dimensional character, a garish bad apple in a barrel full of mostly honest but fatefully credulous lawmen. (His office mates and superiors are played by Kevin Bacon, Adam Scott and David Harbour as John Morris, who follows Connolly down Whitey‰Ûªs rabbit hole.)

‰ÛÏBlack Mass,‰Ûù Scott Cooper‰Ûªs new film, puts some of that luster back. It‰Ûªs not that Mr. Cooper necessarily set out to portray Mr. Bulger as a charismatic antihero whose actions are both appalling and exciting. (The screenplay by Mark Mallouk and Jez Butterworth is based on the book by the reporters Dick Lehr and Gerard O‰ÛªNeill of The Boston Globe.) His protagonist, played by Johnny Depp and called Jimmy by most of his friends and associates, does terrible, unforgivable things, nearly all of which the real Mr. Bulger actually did. But the conventions of popular culture, conventions to which Mr. Cooper hews with slavish or perhaps unthinking devotion, treat those things with a certain reverence. This guy is evil, but you have to admit he‰Ûªs also kind of cool.

The practice of attributing the emotions and aspirations of people to wild animals is questionable, but it‰Ûªs not uncommon in nature films and TV shows, especially those trying to appeal to children. For grown-ups, at least, it‰Ûªs distracting here, and you‰Ûªre never quite sure how much of what you‰Ûªre seeing actually occurred. But none of that diminishes your admiration for Ms. AndrÌ© and the staff members at the sanctuary as they labor to preserve bonobos, one animal at a time.
‰ÛÏBonobos: Back to the Wild‰Ûù is an uncomfortable mix of fictionalized account and nature film, but you have to admire the work it documents.

The movie examines the efforts of a conservationist named Claudine AndrÌ©, who has spent years working to rescue bonobos, a species of great ape in Central Africa that has been feeling the pressures of poaching, habitat destruction and war. She runs a sanctuary in the Democratic Republic of Congo for orphaned and otherwise rescued bonobos, and the film portrays her first efforts to release some of them back into the wild.

But the film is not a documentary; instead it is, the screen credits say, ‰ÛÏfreely adapted from an original idea by Claudine AndrÌ© and the true story of Beni,‰Ûù whatever that means. Beni, a particularly inquisitive bonobo, comes to the sanctuary as a very young orphan. As he grows, we hear his thoughts via a cloying voice-over, and they‰Ûªre very human.

Is ‰ÛÏCooties‰Ûù funny enough or scary enough or both to override its distastefulness? Tough call. Depends, really, on how you feel about a blood bath set in a school, a teacher beating a zombified student to death and name actors romping through the groves of gross-out humor.

All this mars the first day on the job for Clint, a dorky substitute teacher played by Elijah Wood ‰ÛÓ  yes, Frodo from ‰ÛÏThe Lord of the Rings.‰Ûù And it happens just when he was striking a spark with another teacher, Lucy (Alison Pill of ‰ÛÏThe Newsroom‰Ûù), and wondering if he might possibly lure her away from her cloddish boyfriend and fellow teacher, Wade (Rainn Wilson). Jack McBrayer, Nasim Pedrad and Jorge Garcia are among the other familiar adult faces.

The role-reversal possibilities inherent in children-prey-on-adults stories can‰Ûªt really be exploited well when the kids are mere zombies, and in any case there is a lot of horror comedy around lately. So, though ‰ÛÏCooties‰Ûù has a reasonable amount of laughs and frights, and though real teachers may find it an apt allegory for the zombielike charges in their classrooms, it‰Ûªs not really funny enough to achieve grown-up cachet, and it‰Ûªs too ugly and violent for younger viewers.
‰ÛÏCooties‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A school seized by zombies is a very gruesome place.

Tainted chicken nuggets served at an elementary school turn its students into zombies, and ‰ÛÓ as if the teacher shortage weren‰Ûªt already bad enough ‰ÛÓ a number of educators are quickly eaten. But a handful survive and spend the movie alternately running from the little rotters and trying to kill them.

Down at the base camp, Helen Wilton (Emily Watson), Hall‰Ûªs business partner and a kind of den mother to his clients, keeps an eye on the weather and an ear on her two-way radio. From time to time, we peek in on Hall‰Ûªs wife, Jan Arnold (Keira Knightley), who is pregnant with their first child, and on Peach Weathers (Robin Wright), who shares her husband‰Ûªs bluff confidence until it‰Ûªs time to start worrying.

In theory, the stakes should be high and the drama intense, as human beings battle the brute forces of nature in a life-or-death struggle. But though it assembles a first-rate cast in a story taken from reality, ‰ÛÏEverest‰Ûù feels icebound and strangely abstract, lacking the gravity of genuine tragedy or the swagger of first-rate adventure.
‰ÛÏEverest‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Meteorological brutality.

Mr. Kormakur, an Icelandic director whose films include ‰ÛÏJar City‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏ2 Guns,‰Ûù hits his stride once the preliminary conversations and expository scenes give way to practical decisions and perilous mishaps. As his camera swoops down on the climbers from above ‰ÛÓ and, on a few vertiginous occasions, from below ‰ÛÓ you feel some of the grandeur and terror of their undertaking. They are small, slow-moving creatures, their bright-colored gear vivid and incongruous amid the sparkling whites and swirling grays of snow, cloud and wind. Their progress is grueling and slow, but Mr. Kormakur generates suspense through deft crosscutting and an accelerating sense of doom.

This may be partly because one of the film‰Ûªs themes is the commodification of adventure, the colonization of a wild and dangerous terrestrial spot by tourists and thrill seekers. The individual climbers who receive most of our attention are treated with empathy and respect ‰ÛÓ the Westerners, that is; the Nepalese Sherpas who guide and assist them barely figure at all ‰ÛÓ but Everest itself is a mob scene. The feeling of discovery, of primal wonder at the inhuman sublimity of the mountain, has been compromised. People with a lot of money and little climbing experience turn the base camp into a virtual trailer park and litter the upper slopes with discarded ropes, flags and oxygen tanks. Professional tour leaders are expected to ensure the safety of clients who insist on pushing toward the summit despite potentially fatal risks.

‰ÛÏEverest‰Ûù turns partly on the rivalry between two seasoned climbers: Rob Hall, a stoic, disciplined New Zealander played by the ever-solid Jason Clarke; and Scott Fischer, a gonzo American played with marvelous mischief by Jake Gyllenhaal. Their ascent in the spring of 1996, during which eight people died and many others suffered severe frostbite, was the subject of Jon Krakauer‰Ûªs best-selling book ‰ÛÏInto Thin Air.‰Ûù

This movie, written by William Nicholson and Simon Beaufoy, tells a somewhat different version of the story, with Mr. Krakauer (Michael Kelly) as a marginal and not entirely sympathetic character. His participation in the climb as a writer working on an article for Outside magazine is part of the competition between Hall and Fischer. Both climbers crave the publicity a magazine feature would bring, even though Hall is also aware that such attention is contributing to dangerous and unpleasant conditions on the mountain.

At one point, Krakauer asks members of Hall‰Ûªs expedition why they are there, and though their answers are potted or evasive, ‰ÛÏEverest‰Ûù fills in some of the blanks. Beck Weathers, a gung-ho Texan played by Josh Brolin, eventually lets his bravado slip and admits that the malaise that plagues him in daily life dissipates in challenging conditions at high altitudes. Doug Hansen (John Hawkes), a quiet postal worker who has tried and failed to reach the top of Everest before, is seeking a fulfillment that eludes him elsewhere. Yasuko Namba (Naoko Mori), the only woman in Hall‰Ûªs group, has already climbed six of the seven highest mountains in the world, and needs Everest to complete the set.

In telling its terrible true story, ‰ÛÏEverest‰Ûù gets stuck between celebrating the indomitability of the human spirit and reckoning with the awful consequences of hubris and bad luck. It aspires to something large and lofty, but in the end it‰Ûªs a big pile of rocks, ice and vain and valiant human effort.

‰ÛÏBecause it‰Ûªs there‰Ûù is a perfectly valid justification for climbing an enormous mountain ‰ÛÓ a famous one, at any rate ‰ÛÓ but maybe not a good enough reason to see a movie. Or to make a movie, for that matter. Technically, of course, a film isn‰Ûªt really ‰ÛÏthere‰Ûù until someone makes it, and ‰ÛÏEverest,‰Ûù a breathless, large-scale 3-D action spectacle (directed by Baltasar Kormakur) about an ill-starred attempt to scale the planet‰Ûªs highest peak, was called into being with impressive star power and technical bravura. It definitely exists. But it never seems to get anywhere, taking up space and time without managing to be especially memorable or imposing.
KEN JAWOROWSKI

Chloe Rose, as Dora, is convincing enough in a role that‰Ûªs primarily reactive. Robert Patrick, as a small-town cop, remains dedicated even when making some blatantly bad decisions. (‰ÛÏStay here,‰Ûù he tells Dora before venturing upstairs alone. Lifetime spoiler alert: In horror films, such moves never end well.)

Yet as the terror shifts from suggested to explicit, the eeriness wanes and this supernatural story becomes muddled. Mr. McDonald then piles on the gore, perhaps to distract from the plot holes. It also doesn‰Ûªt help that the script, by Pascal Trottier, uses dream sequences that seem designed only to stretch the film to feature length.
Dora, a young woman terrorized by demonic trick-or-treaters in ‰ÛÏHellions,‰Ûù has bigger worries than running out of candy.

Even before being left alone on Halloween night, she was feeling uneasy. Earlier in the day, this high school student learns she is pregnant, and the resulting anxiety has made her extra jumpy as the first knock sounds at the door.

That setup and other early moments are creepy. Bruce McDonald, the director, is adept at building dread through spooky noises ‰ÛÓ a creaking floorboard, a sinister whisper ‰ÛÓ and claustrophobic sets. Scenes in a basement and attic are no less unnerving for being almost obligatory, and a few ‰ÛÏWhat‰Ûªs that behind her?‰Ûù shots create a sense of menace (as do nods to ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏRosemary‰Ûªs Baby‰Ûù).

A jumbled third act and an indifferent ending ultimately make ‰ÛÏHellions‰Ûù disappointing. But there‰Ûªs a bit of fun to be had in its opening frights, and in trying to figure out what these costumed little monsters really want. Here‰Ûªs a hint: It‰Ûªs not a Snickers bar.

‰ÛÏOffice‰Ûù is based on Sylvia Chang‰Ûªs popular stage musical,  ‰ÛÏDesign for Living,‰Ûù which shares its title with the 1933 NoÌÇl Coward play. In the play, one of Coward‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏglib,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏamoral‰Ûù characters (his words) confesses: ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs all a questions of masks, really; brittle, painted masks. We all wear them as protection; modern life forces us to.‰Ûù Ms. Chang and Mr. To play with some of the same ideas in ‰ÛÏOffice,‰Ûù which focuses on a group whose masks are rapidly slipping off, loosened by modern life and love as well as the collision between private lives and public lies. Ho and Chang‰Ûªs affair is one lie, but there are other untruths, including that of capitalism‰Ûªs equally rising boats, which is why when Lee sings, ‰ÛÏI want everyone to see me doing great,‰Ûù there‰Ûªs a stooped man in the background pushing a load of trash.

At once sharp and exceedingly playful, ‰ÛÏOffice‰Ûù registers as up to the minute because of China‰Ûªs economic turmoil. Its smashing look gives visible form to the idea of China as an enormous machine even as Mr. To nods to other reference points, from the pinwheeling Busby Berkeley-like formations to the huge office clock that seems transported from ‰ÛÏMetropolis,‰Ûù to Lee‰Ûªs popping eyes and swooping bangs, which invoke Robert Morse in the 1967 movie musical ‰ÛÏHow to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.‰Ûù The songs in ‰ÛÏOffice‰Ûù aren‰Ûªt especially memorable. But it‰Ûªs hard to care too much when you have a director who knows how to create tension by moving the camera and characters even while he‰Ûªs delivering a nimble political softshoe with filmmaking dazzle.

Set in the wake of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, ‰ÛÏOffice‰Ûù takes place largely in a Chinese company, the amusingly named Jones & Sunn, that jumps to the rhythms of the stock market, its vertiginous ups and downs, its soaring promises and crushing defeats. The company is on the verge of going public and, with billions in the balance, there are complications, among them the hush-hush affair that the married chairman, Mr. Ho (Chow Yun Fat), has been having with the single-gal chief executive officer, Ms. Chang (Sylvia Chang). After years of tag-team Machiavellianism, Ho and Chang have drifted apart, their bonds frayed by the corporate and family intrigues that ‰ÛÒ with a lot of singing and a little dancing ‰ÛÒ put a human face on China‰Ûªs authoritarian capitalism.

These computer multitudes give way to would-be market warriors like Lee Xiang (Wang Ziyi), a striver with eyes the size of hubcaps who starts working as an intern at Jones & Sunn the same day as another newbie, Kat (Lang Yueting). A willowy wisp with a peekaboo curtain of hair, Kat catches Lee‰Ûªs attention when she‰Ûªs ushered alone into an express elevator while the rest of the building‰Ûªs workers serenely line up to ride steerage. Dressed in their regulation business uniforms (shades of blue, black, gray and white), these other men and women wait in aligned rows that echo the set‰Ûªs floor-to-ceiling patterning, turning them into points on an all-encompassing grid. Only Lee‰Ûªs exuberance and a few close-ups of strappy, polka-dotted shoes suggest the yelp of the individual amid the herd.

One of the best-directed movies that you can see in New York right now isn‰Ûªt playing in an art cinema but in a multiplex slab, where a pleasurably different entertainment has been slipped in among the familiar offerings. ‰ÛÏOffice‰Ûù is the latest from the Hong Kong auteur Johnnie To, who, at 60, has directed more than 50 features. If you‰Ûªve heard of him, it may be because of thrillers like ‰ÛÏPTU‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTriad Election,‰Ûù in which his peerless technique, eye for beauty and grasp of darkness flow as fluidly as his prowling cameras. If Mr. To were an American, his name would fall from lips as easily as Martin Scorsese‰Ûªs, another artist alive to cinema‰Ûªs past as well as its present.

From the first images in ‰ÛÏOffice,‰Ûù which opens on a man tending a comatose woman in a hospital bed, you know that you‰Ûªve entered a place a little to the left of the usual realism. The hospital, like most of the locations, the homes, the after-hour joints and the office, is made of see-through geometric forms instead of solid walls. It‰Ûªs a world of grid patterns and transparency, one that looks as if it had been made out of framing materials, like a house under construction or one that‰Ûªs soon to be razed. For a brief moment, the design evokes the empty stage in ‰ÛÏOur Town‰Ûù and the deconstructed sets in Lars von Trier experiments like ‰ÛÏDogville.‰Ûù But then a multitude of computer-generated people begins trooping through the credits, suggesting a new kind of army on the march.
‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong sexual content and graphic nudity.

Mr. Duris‰Ûªs Virginia and Ms. Demoustier‰Ûªs Claire make a delightful couple whose clandestine friendship is inevitably complicated by deepening mutual sexual attraction. It is left for us to consider whom Claire desires more, David or Virginia. ‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend‰Ûù never pretends to be more than what it is, a delicious and frothy fantasia with a teasing erotic frisson.

No sooner has Claire adjusted to the revelation than her curiosity is piqued. Before long, she and David venture out on shopping expeditions, with Claire providing grooming tips and pointing out David‰Ûªs slips in his effort to pass as a woman. As his enthusiasm for drag deepens, he assumes a female alter ego named Virginia. In a magical excursion to a gay bar, he and Claire revel in an atmosphere of complete acceptance and freedom.

The dead woman, Laura (Isild Le Besco), is the childhood playmate of Claire (AnaÌøs Demoustier), with whom she sealed a vow of eternal friendship that culminated in their double wedding to sleek Prince Charmings: Laura to David (Romain Duris), and Claire to Gilles (RaphaÌÇl Personnaz).

Laura‰Ûªs death leaves behind an adorable baby daughter, Lucie. Shortly after the funeral, Claire pays an unannounced visit to David, finds the front door unlocked, and comes upon Lucie being rocked in the arms of an unfamiliar woman, whom she is shocked to discover is really David in a blond wig and one of Laura‰Ûªs dresses. Her initial distaste quickly gives way to sympathy when David reveals that his sometime compulsion to cross-dress returned after his wife‰Ûªs death, and that putting on her clothes is his way of keeping her alive. Lucie also seems delighted with her feminized papa. Laura, he insists, was comfortable with his cross-dressing; he assures Claire that he is not gay.

Mr. Ozon, like Hitchcock and Mr. AlmodÌ_var, has always been more interested in storytelling than in heavy psychological realism. That‰Ûªs why ‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend,‰Ûù despite its forays into gender bending, doesn‰Ûªt feel like a personal or political statement. It has no axes to grind.

David is a mesmerizing star turn for Mr. Duris, whose resemblance to a young Mick Jagger (except for the lips) is uncanny. Movie magic makes the diminutive actor entirely convincing as a haughty 6-foot-plus cross-dresser. In her full glory, Virginia is a chic honky-tonk siren in high heels with a wicked leer and eyes that flash with a haughty defiance.

At heart, it is an elevated French farce, a much hipper, more relaxed and sophisticated update of ‰ÛÏLa Cage aux Folles.‰Ûù The characters, not the issues, drive a story about upscale Gallic suburbanites risking social embarrassment, but little more, if they‰Ûªre discovered.

Mr. Ozon has never tried to conceal his influences, foremost among them Alfred Hitchcock. In ‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend,‰Ûù Hitchcock‰Ûªs diabolical sense of humor is evident in little surprises like the bridal corpse. But here, the master of suspense‰Ûªs winking hide-and-seek games coincide with Pedro AlmodÌ_var‰Ûªs brazen rebelliousness in a movie that feels like a fashion editor‰Ûªs glossy tribute to that Spanish iconoclast. Where androgyny in Mr. AlmodÌ_var‰Ûªs movies is often raucous, disruptive and provocatively sexualized, in Mr. Ozon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend,‰Ûù it is sweet, unthreatening and almost cozy. A sparkling, sugar-frosted score by Philippe Rombi supplies a wistful romantic gloss.

The close-up shot that opens ‰ÛÏThe New Girlfriend‰Ûù evokes a glamorous church wedding, as lipstick is carefully applied to the impassive face of a beautiful woman while an organ plays a triumphal ‰ÛÏHere Comes the Bride.‰Ûù But it takes only a moment before you realize that the ceremony is really a funeral.

So begins the French filmmaker FranÌ_ois Ozon‰Ûªs playful screen adaptation of a dark story by the British mystery writer Ruth Rendell. By turns mischievous, sentimental, subversive and silly, this serio-comic exploration of cross-dressing, gender fluidity and desire suggests the career-opening salvo of a cheeky cinematic enfant terrible and not the work of an old hand with well over a dozen features behind him. But that‰Ûªs one of Mr. Ozon‰Ûªs gifts; he makes everything old feel new and fresh.

And it mostly stands up to the comparison. Mr. Ryoo (‰ÛÏThe Unjust,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe City of Violence‰Ûù) isn‰Ûªt known for his sense of humor, but ‰ÛÏVeteran‰Ûù is amusing throughout, even if the funny scenes are more subdued or go on a beat or two longer than American viewers are used to. He may not have Walter Hill‰Ûªs or Richard Donner‰Ûªs gift for melding comedy to action and maintaining a tone of antic menace, but he delivers a solid, consistently entertaining story punctuated by the balletic action sequences he‰Ûªs known for. (He also wrote the screenplay, which is considerably more linear and coherent than the South Korean norm.)

Ryoo Seung-wan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏVeteran,‰Ûù in which an honest detective takes on the pampered, sociopathic heir to a family-owned business conglomerate, must have had plenty of resonance in South Korea. Released in August, nine months after the daughter of the chairman of Korean Air threw a fit over a bag of nuts and blew up her career, it is already one of the 10 highest-grossing domestic films in that country‰Ûªs history.

Hwang Jung-min is cool and capable as the longtime detective whose investigation of a friend‰Ûªs suicide attempt pits him against the conglomerate‰Ûªs lawyers, thugs and paid-off policemen; he‰Ûªs a quieter version of the Eddie Murphy or Mel Gibson cop who plays the fool but is good in a fight. The Korean heartthrob Yoo Ah-in plays the preening adversary, whose response to being shown up is to humiliate the nearest woman or assault the nearest pet. Oh Dal-su of ‰ÛÏOldboy‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Host‰Ûù steals most scenes he‰Ûªs in as a weary police chief ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs the real veteran of ‰ÛÏVeteran.‰Ûù

American audiences are less likely to care about the film‰Ûªs treatment of chaebols and their undue influence in South Korean society, however, than its strong debt to 1980s American cop comedies like ‰ÛÏBeverly Hills Cop,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ48 Hrs.‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLethal Weapon.‰Ûù (The link to the period is reinforced by the use of Blondie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHeart of Glass‰Ûù on the soundtrack in the movie‰Ûªs opening seconds.)

‰ÛÏThe Scorch Trials‰Ûù adds nothing new to the unkillable dystopian genre, but it‰Ûªs at least less ponderous than its predecessor. The many chases and ludicrous narrow escapes offer respectable doses of adrenaline.

Thomas discovers that Janson is stringing kids up, unconscious and riddled with tubes, for some reason related to the virus. That‰Ûªs enough info for him to grab his friends and skedaddle. Their unlikely jailbreak sends them blinking into a blasted landscape of ruined skyscrapers and giant sand dunes, like some combination of Tatooine and Detroit, where they hope to survive long enough to find a fabled group of resistance fighters.
Science doesn‰Ûªt yet know how many movies it will take to answer this century‰Ûªs most pressing question: How will attractive teenagers survive the apocalypse?
‰ÛÏWhat do we do now?‰Ûù a weary character asks near the end. With one last rousing speech from Thomas, that‰Ûªs obvious: Make a third movie, due in 2017.
‰ÛÏMaze Runner: The Scorch Trials‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Occasional gun violence and fewer bad words than you would utter under similar duress.

‰ÛÏMaze Runner: The Scorch Trials,‰Ûù the second in a series about a racially diverse but otherwise interchangeable set led by a hardy hunk named Thomas (Dylan O‰ÛªBrien), throws us right into the action. Stiff, vague bits of exposition establish that the youths had, indeed, been in some kind of maze. Now they are in a large industrial compound, saved from a nefarious organization called WCKD by another mysterious crew led by Janson (Aidan Gillen), a transparently shady guy himself. The teenagers are among the only people left immune to a virus that turns humans into zombielike mutants that shriek like velociraptors.

The campaign, Operation Condor, that inspired this fictional film was a reality in South America from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s, when right-wing dictators in Bolivia, Argentina, Chile and several other countries, reacting to a perceived threat from leftist dissidents, had their political opponents kidnapped and executed.

The focus in this Bolivian film is mostly on a retired general (DamiÌÁn AlcÌÁzar) whose memories of his past linger. Convalescing after a heart attack, he confesses his role in a letter to his son, who apparently was unaware of the true nature of his father‰Ûªs work. As if echoing a fever dream, ‰ÛÏOlvidados‰Ûù frequently lurches back in time, showing the general‰Ûªs role in the persecution of a group of activists and a journalist (Carloto Cotta) and his pregnant wife (Carla Ortiz, also a producer of the film and one of its three screenwriters). At times, the less-than-graceful transitions are accompanied by the crackling sound of electricity, in case you missed the scenes of detainees‰Ûª being electrocuted. (Some of the technical flourishes evoke one of those basic-cable shows with cheesy re-enactments.)

In dark detention centers overrun with mice, bloodied detainees debate the dangers of extremism by those on the right and the left as well as what constitutes a democracy. The opening breezes through archival footage from the era, dossiers on dictators and newspaper clips. While it would be a tall order to fully elucidate this complicated history in two hours, ‰ÛÏOlvidados‰Ûù is hamstrung by Mr. Bolado‰Ûªs lack of focused direction and a convoluted plot.

‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs men like these that will keep the backbones of our countries straight.‰Ûù In the director Carlos Bolado‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏOlvidados‰Ûù (‰ÛÏForgotten‰Ûù), those words, a vote of confidence in two Bolivian generals, are more ominous than noble. These men are soon rolling up their sleeves to terrorize activists and anyone else considered a threat to their government.

The chief attraction of Colorado City, or so it would seem from the brief entry on the website of the Arizona Office of Tourism, isn‰Ûªt Colorado City but the ‰ÛÏnearby scenic attractions‰Ûù that include the Vermilion and Shinarump Cliffs. Set at the base of ravishing red cliff mountains, the city and its twin, Hildale, Utah, look straight out of Canaan. To watch ‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey,‰Ûù Amy Berg‰Ûªs tough and disturbing documentary about a secretive, polygamous Mormon fundamentalist sect with unsettling roots in the region, is to grasp, perhaps, the unspoken reason the Arizona tourism office seems to be suggesting that visitors drive right on by.

In ‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey,‰Ûù Ms. Berg has found an eerie counterpart to Mr. O‰ÛªGrady in the person of Warren Jeffs, a Mormon fundamentalist serving a life sentence for the sexual assault of two followers, including a 12-year-old girl and a 15-year-old he impregnated. By the time he was on trial, Mr. Jeffs was thought to have 78 wives, including 12 who were 15 or younger when they wed.

Drawing on archival material, landscape beauty shots and testimonials, including from former F.L.D.S. members, Ms. Berg has created an unnerving, sometimes infuriating documentary. She makes smart choices throughout as she weaves together this chronicle of faith and abuse, but her decision to include an audio recording that was used at Mr. Jeffs‰Ûªs trial of him allegedly molesting a 12-year-old girl was wrong. This decision contrasts sharply with the scene in the documentary ‰ÛÏGrizzly Man,‰Ûù when an on-camera Werner Herzog listens to ‰ÛÓ but doesn‰Ûªt share ‰ÛÓ an audio recording of the mauling death of two people. Mr. Herzog ratcheted up the drama by withholding the recording, but his decision was also a de facto ethical statement about documentary and the uses of the suffering of others.

The writer Jon Krakauer didn‰Ûªt get the message. As he explains in ‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey,‰Ûù his interest in these particular fundamentalists was sparked when, in 1999, he stopped at a gas station close to Colorado City and Hildale. There, he saw a group of women dressed in the sort of long prairie dresses that Laura Ingalls Wilder might have worn if she had liked frocks stitched out of pastel polyester. This curious sight led him on a journalistic investigation into Mormonism and its extremes, including the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (F.L.D.S.), a breakaway sect with thousands of polygamous true believers in the United States, Canada and Mexico. His book, ‰ÛÏUnder the Banner of Heaven: A Story of Violent Faith,‰Ûù hit in 2003, but Mr. Krakauer, a guiding voice in the documentary, is still on the case.

‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey‰Ûù was written and directed by Ms. Berg, whose earlier documentaries include ‰ÛÏDeliver Us From Evil,‰Ûù a contemporary horror story about Oliver O‰ÛªGrady, a Roman Catholic priest and admitted pedophile who evaded punishment as he was moved from parish to parish for decades. He was finally defrocked and deported to Ireland, after doing time in prison.

For the most part, though, Ms. Berg gets it right, burying Mr. Jeffs with persuasive witness testimony and documentation. Along the way, she gestures at larger, underexplored issues, including the rise of homegrown religious fundamentalism in the light of rights movements for women and children. Fundamentalist Mormons are having some kind of moment, including in cable shows like ‰ÛÏSister Wives‰Ûù and documentaries like this one, which is based on Mr. Brower‰Ûªs 2011 best seller of the same title. More movies are still to come, including an adaptation of ‰ÛÏUnder the Banner of Heaven‰Ûù that is being developed by Brian Grazer and Ron Howard, two of the executive producers of ‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey,‰Ûù and written by a third executive producer, Dustin Lance Black, who wrote for ‰ÛÏBig Love.‰Ûù The story continues.

The documentary tracks the rise and fall of Mr. Jeffs, who in 2002 assumed leadership of the church after the death of his father, Rulon Jeffs. With the on-camera assistance of Mr. Krakauer and Sam Brower, another dogged investigator, Ms. Berg fills in a harrowing portrait of Warren Jeffs as a deluded prophet and serial abuser, especially of girls and women who seem locked in another century. Their old-timey look will be familiar to fans of the HBO drama ‰ÛÏBig Love,‰Ûù about a polygamous family trying to find a middle way between faith and the modern world. In ‰ÛÏProphet‰Ûªs Prey‰Ûù there‰Ûªs little evidence of love in what emerges as a tale of madness and abuse, wealth and criminality, mixed in with anti-government rhetoric ‰ÛÓ all in in the name of God.

‰ÛÏWhen you lose the small things, everything fails,‰Ûù Mr. Psihoyos points out, as we try to erase the image of a terrified shark with nothing but gaping wounds where its fins had been. Yet it‰Ûªs the film‰Ûªs sounds that really wrench. If you‰Ûªve ever wondered what a breaking heart sounds like, it‰Ûªs right here in the futile warble of the last male of a species of songbird, singing for a mate that will never come.

If you can watch ‰ÛÏRacing Extinction‰Ûù without bawling at least once, then its director, Louie Psihoyos, suggests you consider that all the tenderly photographed endangered species that flood its frames are only signposts to the disappearance of our own.

Noting that our planet‰Ûªs five major extinctions had in common a spike in carbon dioxide, Mr. Psihoyos worries that the emissions of our own age, aptly dubbed the Anthropocene, are damaging our oceans in ways that are mostly invisible. And that the devastating consequences of more direct human behaviors ‰ÛÓ like the mass slaughter of exotic marine life for food and folk medicines ‰ÛÓ are also largely overlooked.

These scenes are shocking but necessary. Contrasting the ugliness of destruction with the beauty of its victims is the film‰Ûªs core aesthetic, whether in the ripple of an ocelot‰Ûªs fur or the dazzling luminescence of the phytoplankton that provide half of the earth‰Ûªs oxygen.

But not if Mr. Psihoyos can help it. Cucumber-cool and with the look of someone who has seen too much, he and his team don the buttonhole cameras and eco-sleuth personas familiar to viewers of his dolphin-massacre exposÌ©, ‰ÛÏThe Cove‰Ûù (2009). Inside illegal Chinese warehouses where skyscrapers of shark fins are bloodily stacked, and to an Indonesian village where manta rays are butchered for their gills, he provides gory proof of breathtaking wastefulness.

Recent Mexican films ‰ÛÓ including fictional features like Amat Escalante‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHeli‰Ûù and a number of brave and powerful documentaries ‰ÛÓ have examined how the drug trade and the power of the cartels have affected all aspects of life there. A subplot in ‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù concerning a Sonoran police officer and his family gestures in that direction, yet the film stays mostly in shallow action-thriller waters. Ms. Blunt is impressively glum and intense, but Kate is a bit of a blank, on hand as a filter through which the audience can scrutinize Matt and Alejandro, who are far more intriguing characters.

‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù tells the story of an ambitious operation undertaken by an alphabet soup of American law enforcement agencies against top-ranking members of the Sonora cartel. The action is viewed mostly through the eyes of Kate Macer (Emily Blunt), an F.B.I. agent who is brought into the plan for reasons she doesn‰Ûªt quite understand. Nor is she given much information about what‰Ûªs going on once she‰Ûªs on board.

Mr. Villeneuve, aided by Taylor Sheridan‰Ûªs lean script, Roger Deakins‰Ûªs parched cinematography and Johann Johannsson‰Ûªs slow-moving heart attack of a score, respects the imperatives of genre while trying to avoid the usual clichÌ©s. It‰Ûªs not easy, and he doesn‰Ûªt entirely succeed. But he‰Ûªs also trying to scramble some of the usual codes, and to paint a morally complicated picture instead of restaging a morality play.
‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Grave bodily harm, threatened and enacted.

Kate and Reggie are appalled to discover that their new assignment is being carried out with almost complete disregard for national sovereignty, the rule of law or basic human decency. As Alejandro suggests late in the film, there are no good guys and bad guys in this world, only packs of wolves competing for territory and dominance. ‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù suggests that United States government authorities are one such pack, acting not in the name of justice or security but rather of expediency and order. The idea that the war on drugs might be won is not something anyone takes seriously. The only question is how the forces are aligned and who is enforcing the rules of engagement.

The dry, menacing scenery surveyed in ‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù is real, of course, as are some of the aspects of its harrowing story. But the desert and the drug war ‰ÛÓ a landscape evoking old westerns populated with a new cast of outlaws and would-be sheriffs ‰ÛÓ has also become fertile pop-cultural ground. We know the territory, thematic and geographic, from ‰ÛÏNo Country for Old Men‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad,‰Ûù from ‰ÛÏThe Counselor‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTraffic‰Ûù and even ‰ÛÏWeeds.‰Ûù

Mr. Villeneuve‰Ûªs 2009 feature, ‰ÛÏPolytechnique,‰Ûù was the almost unbearably meticulous reconstruction of an actual mass shooting at a Montreal university. He followed it with ‰ÛÏIncendies,‰Ûù a grim family chronicle set mainly in a thinly fictionalized Lebanon during that country‰Ûªs long civil war. ‰ÛÏSicario,‰Ûù his new movie, visits a different war zone: the United States-Mexico border, where the murderous business practices of the Mexican drug cartels threaten to bleed across the Rio Grande.

It‰Ûªs not so simple, though. Her boss (Victor Garber) hands her over to a jaunty supervisor, Matt (Josh Brolin), whose organizational affiliations are unclear. (D.O.D.? C.I.A.? Something else? Are flip-flops part of the uniform?) Matt is all smiles, treating possibly extralegal combat missions like pickup basketball games and answering Kate‰Ûªs earnest inquiries with mock-sheepish good humor. His closest colleague ‰ÛÓ minion? supervisor? consultant? evil twin? ‰ÛÓ is a more somber fellow known as Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro), haloed in sorrow and capable of extreme acts of brutality.

Plenty of directors make violent movies. Denis Villeneuve makes movies about violence, which is not quite the same thing. A Canadian filmmaker equally comfortable in French and English, he is especially interested in preludes and aftermaths, in the tense moments before the eruption of violence and in the shock and confusion that follow. His framing, cutting and sound design evoke the feelings that motivate and arise from the shedding of blood: rage, grief, steely resolve and wild panic.

Kate‰Ûªs expertise is tactical. She and her partner, Reggie (Daniel Kaluuya), are SWAT-team specialists who, in the movie‰Ûªs first scene, raid a house whose walls are filled with corpses, anonymous victims of the cartel who died horrible deaths before being sealed between layers of drywall. Two agents died in the raid, and payback is among Kate‰Ûªs motives. She wants to get the guys responsible for killing her co-workers, she tells the guys responsible for the new task force.

Though maybe not quite intriguing enough. Mr. Villeneuve conjures an atmosphere of menace and pervasive cruelty, but after a while ‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù starts to feel too easy, less an exploration than an exploitation of the moral ambiguities of the drug war. We glimpse mutilated bodies hanging from bridges, hear stabbings and shootings just out of sight and study the face of a man whose family is being killed in front of him. But after a while these sounds and images start to feel like expressions of technique, and they become at once numbing and sensational, and instead of a movie about violence we‰Ûªre watching another violent movie, after all.

Suffice it to say that the divide is torn, freeing Moira to practice the passive-aggressive telekinetic torture that is her forte. When she digs a blade into her arm or slices her own throat, the pain and carnage are also visited on her chosen victim. Jammy gouts of grenadine blood bubble from her wounds and theirs, making a hemorrhage of the screen. She kills, but survives.

‰ÛÏSome Kind of Hate‰Ûù succeeds at being discomfiting, and Mr. Rubinstein‰Ûªs role is played well, but the film, directed by Adam Egypt Mortimer, simply does not cohere. Worse yet, it fails to deliver a thrill ‰ÛÓ not even a shiver, except of revulsion ‰ÛÓ rendering all that slasher gore downright anemic.

There, a bully (read sadist) is waiting to dole out pain and humiliation ‰ÛÓ until the day Lincoln loses his Zenlike cool. Releasing an almost primal rage, he sinks his fork satisfyingly into his tormentor‰Ûªs face.

Just on the other side of the filmy divide between this world and the next, is another victim of bullies, the one blob of ectoplasm that no one at Mind‰Ûªs Eye wants to meet: the walking-dead alum Moira, with her greenish pallor and choker strung with razor blades. She is played by Sierra McCormick, who packs Disney Channel credentials.
Watching self-mutilation become a weapon turns sickening fast, and you do not want to see Moira‰Ûªs thuddingly disgusting technique for inflicting head injuries. Mind you, she has her reasons.

As punishment, Lincoln (Ronen Rubinstein, who set hearts to beating in his single appearance on ‰ÛÏOrange Is the New Black‰Ûù) is shipped off to Mind‰Ûªs Eye Academy, a desert ‰ÛÏschool‰Ûù for troubled kids that has a habit of losing its charges.

Lincoln Taggert, a human target and luckless hero, lives with his abusive, alcoholic biker father. His mom survives only in Lincoln‰Ûªs sketches, crowned by a penciled-in halo. His school is no escape.

More art-video installation than typical documentary, ‰ÛÏSongs From the North‰Ûù is mostly nonnarrative, drawing on North Korean film and TV clips to sketch a sensibility that ‰ÛÓ however stoked by propaganda ‰ÛÓ prizes family above all and melds that with a zealous commitment to the fatherland. Song and music invoke shared ideals of sacrifice, honor and patriotism; one televised event that features a young boy crying as he sings of his love of country ‰ÛÓ as an audience of dignitaries also sobs ‰ÛÓ is moving and disturbing.

To the outside world, North Korea is unknowable, a nation reduced to caricature by its own isolation and by cartoonish satires like last year‰Ûªs James Franco-Seth Rogen comedy ‰ÛÏThe Interview.‰Ûù The director Soon-Mi Yoo hopes to penetrate such presumptions in ‰ÛÏSongs From the North,‰Ûù an essay built on three trips she took to the country and fortified by extensive use of archival material.

Ms. Yoo, born in South Korea and now on the faculty of the Massachusetts College of Arts and Design, was escorted by state-supplied guides, unable to travel or photograph freely. Even so, her portraits of those she films convey their humanity and individuality, and the glimpses of pool halls, amusement parks and school groups are small surprises themselves, at odds with the relentlessly dour images associated with the nation. Scattering history lessons and ambiguous imagery amid Ms. Yoo‰Ûªs engagement with North Koreans, her film implicitly asks: What must they think of us?

As vividly portrayed in Peter Anthony‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Man Who Saved the World,‰Ûù Lt. Col. Stanislav Petrov was in charge of the Soviet early warning systems overnight on Sept. 26, 1983. Computerized satellites detected first one, then other launches ‰ÛÓ five in all ‰ÛÓ of nuclear missiles by the United States. But there was no visual confirmation, and Colonel Petrov decided to tell his superiors they were false alarms, despite being required to report these ‰ÛÏmaximum verifications.‰Ûù Had he followed protocol, retaliatory strikes would surely have followed, triggering an American response in kind and mutually assured destruction.

Accidental nuclear attacks have been the stuff of high-tech thrillers for a half-century, at least since ‰ÛÏFail-Safe‰Ûù (1964). But this apocalyptic fiction almost became fact in 1983, averted only by the doubts of a single Soviet Union officer.

Somewhat clumsily, this hybrid documentary blends re-enactments of those and other events with Mr. Petrov‰Ûªs real-life trip to the United States in 2006 to accept an award from the United Nations. Mr. Petrov is a secretive, unlikable old pensioner, who softens over time in the presence of his young interpreter and in meetings with Walter Cronkite, Robert De Niro and Kevin Costner. Depicting Mr. Petrov‰Ûªs bleak life since the death of his wife, the film reflects on the links each individual has, willingly or not, to the rest of humanity. ‰ÛÏI was just at the right place at the right time,‰Ûù Mr. Petrov says, a simple truth that becomes shocking when considering the alternative. For that alone, this account of a Cold War near miss deserves a wide audience.

The simmering mystery ‰ÛÏUncle John‰Ûù is so subtle, so exquisitely paced and so determined not to go in any of the obvious directions that it‰Ûªs hard to believe the film is Steven Piet‰Ûªs first feature. Mr. Piet, who with Erik Crary also wrote the script, sketches some memorable characters while keeping his two-pronged story sparse, ominous and deliciously ambiguous.
Or will they? It‰Ûªs tantalizing, sublimely creepy stuff that keeps you guessing even after the credits roll.

John Ashton is just right as the inscrutable title character, an older fellow in a rural town where an unlikable man named Dutch has gone missing. Shortly before his disappearance, Dutch apparently found Jesus, and he had been visiting various townspeople, confessing to misdeeds and such. Dutch and John‰Ûªs sister were an item long ago, but something murky happened to the sister, and perhaps now something murky has happened to Dutch.

While all of this is being slowly revealed, many miles away in Chicago a young man named Ben is becoming smitten with a new co-worker, Kate. Alex Moffat and Jenna Lyng are very watchable as this might-become-a-couple, but what do they have to do with the goings-on out in the country? Turns out Ben has a beloved uncle who raised him, a man by the name of John. And when the two young flirters head his way for an impromptu visit, all secrets will be revealed.

By many accounts, the rebellion was led by drag queens and gay street people who for the first time stood up to the police, and ‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù dutifully acknowledges their participation. But, its invention of a generic white knight who prompted the riots by hurling the first brick into a window is tantamount to stealing history from the people who made it. A trailer that focuses on that moment has led some gay activists to threaten a boycott of the film. No matter how much Mr. Emmerich and Jon Robin Baitz, the estimable playwright who wrote the screenplay, insist that the movie pays tribute to a full multiethnic range of gay and lesbian characters, ‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù falls short. Like it or not, symbolism matters.

Early scenes jump between Danny‰Ûªs final days in Indiana, before he is observed having sex in a car with a high school quarterback, and his new life in New York. Exiled from his biological family, he bonds with a group of outsiders, homeless drag queens and hustlers who live on the streets or pile, as many as a dozen at time, into a shabby apartment. The neighborhood center of gravity is the seedy mob-owned Stonewall Inn, which is subject to periodic police raids.

The movie, filmed in Montreal, does a reasonably good job of evoking the heady mixture of wildness and dread that permeated Greenwich Village street life in those days. In the summer of ‰Ûª69, homosexual behavior between consenting adults was illegal in New York. At any moment, the police could descend on a gay bar, round up the customers and haul them off.

On another level, the movie wants to be as specific as possible in its reconstruction of chaotic events that took place 46 years ago and have acquired a mythic dimension that demands heroic enlargement. In hindsight, the Stonewall riots are rather like the Woodstock music festival later that summer. More people claim to have been present than could possibly have been there. But except for its identification of actual police officers, ‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt bother to distinguish among facts, fiction and urban legend.
‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sexual content, strong language, violence and drug use.

The strident tone of Mr. Baitz‰Ûªs screenplay is so far removed from the subtlety and sophistication of his plays, like ‰ÛÏOther Desert Cities,‰Ûù and television shows, like ‰ÛÏBrothers and Sisters,‰Ûù that the most logical explanation for its bluntness is that he felt compelled to substitute strident melodrama and agitprop for psychological complexity. Too much of his dialogue gives ‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù the self-conscious tone of an inspirational teaching tool for future generations of young people.

Had the movie‰Ûªs central character been Ray, a.k.a. Ramona (Jonny Beauchamp), an androgynous, volatile Puerto Rican who unrequitedly falls in love with Danny, there might be no quarrel. Ray‰Ûªs saucy ‰ÛÏgirlfriends‰Ûù include characters with nicknames like Queen Cong (Vladimir Alexis) and Little Orphan Annie (Caleb Landry Jones), who are treated with respect but remain peripheral.

The feisty, lovelorn Ray is far and away the strongest, most complex character, and Mr. Beauchamp gives him his due, even though too many of his speeches sound like a mix of biographical filler and boilerplate sloganeering.

The movie goes off on weird tangents, of which the most unnecessary and exploitative is a scene in which Danny is forcibly pimped out by Ed Murphy (Ron Perlman), one of the bar‰Ûªs real-life managers (who later became a respected gay-rights advocate), to a cross-dressing gargoyle who suggests a nightmare fantasy of J. Edgar Hoover. A terminally sullen Jonathan Rhys Meyers plays Danny‰Ûªs first New York crush, Trevor, a leader of the Mattachine Society, the seminal gay-rights organization.

On one level, ‰ÛÏStonewall‰Ûù is a sweeping social allegory whose central character, Danny Winters (Jeremy Irvine of ‰ÛÏWar Horse‰Ûù), is an all-American boy from the provinces (Indiana) thrown out of the house by his father (David Cubitt), a high school football coach, for being gay. Arriving in New York with little money and no fixed abode, Danny is radicalized by observing, then experiencing, police brutality.

‰ÛÏStonewall,‰Ûù Roland Emmerich‰Ûªs would-be epic film about a turning point in the gay liberation movement in 1969, is far from the first historical movie to choke on its own noble intentions. For its two-hour-plus duration, the movie struggles to fuse incompatible concepts.

The protests stretched over four nights in 1969 but are condensed into one night in the film, and the severity of the violence in scenes of police harassment during the rebellion makes your blood boil. But in these overwrought scenes, Mr. Emmerich has reverted to the hyperadrenalized style of his big-budget disaster films like ‰ÛÏThe Day After Tomorrow‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIndependence Day.‰Ûù

Dennis Nash learns this lesson the hard way. A skilled construction worker idled by a sour economy ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏ99 Homes‰Ûù seems to take place around 2010, in the recessionary aftermath of the financial crisis ‰ÛÓ Dennis (Andrew Garfield) is unable to keep up with his mortgage payments and so loses the modest house where he lives with his mother, Lynn (Laura Dern), and his young son, Connor (Noah Lomax). At the stroke of a pen, their world has come undone, and Mr. Bahrani captures the scene of his dispossession with almost unbearable precision, plunging the viewer into a storm of agonized feeling as Dennis struggles with rage, grief and shame at having been pulled, in front of his neighbors, into the ranks of society‰Ûªs losers.

Mr. Bahrani went a bit astray with ‰ÛÏAt Any Price,‰Ûù an overplotted, overacted movie with Dennis Quaid and Zac Efron as a father and son trying to save their family farm. With ‰ÛÏ99 Homes,‰Ûù which he wrote with Amir Naderi, Mr. Bahrani has recovered his balance and sharpened his already formidable knack for concise, emotionally potent storytelling. True to its neorealist pedigree, the film works partly as a fable, an illustration of how impersonal forces shape individual human destinies. Its palette of feeling includes a bright streak of anger at the way banks, judges and politicians conspire to bully and bamboozle hard-working people like Dennis, and also at the way the pursuit of wealth has eclipsed all other sources of value in our lives.

Mr. Garfield, who was an annoyingly needy Spider-Man, is entirely credible as a man risking his decency to protect himself and his loved ones. When Dennis starts carrying out evictions for Rick, his natural empathy proves to be an asset. He can give predatory capitalism a friendly human face. Mr. Shannon, though, is the film‰Ûªs center of gravity ‰ÛÓ its supernova, its black hole, its avatar of cosmic disorder. Like Michael Douglas in ‰ÛÏWall Street‰Ûù or Alec Baldwin in ‰ÛÏGlengarry Glen Ross,‰Ûù he is the seductive embodiment of capitalist amorality, a handsome devil offering a small amount of cash for your house keys and slightly better terms for your immortal soul.
‰ÛÏ99 Homes‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Economic horror. Class violence. Real estate porn.

‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt get emotional about real estate.‰Ûù That bit of wisdom ‰ÛÓ among the mantras shared by a predatory broker named Rick Carver ‰ÛÓ is both upheld and defied by ‰ÛÏ99 Homes,‰Ûù Ramin Bahrani‰Ûªs stunningly effective melodrama of flipped houses and mortgaged souls. While the film hardly endorses Rick‰Ûªs coldblooded, dog-eat-dog view of the world, it is too cleareyed to oppose his ruthlessness with soft, easy appeals to sentiment. The foreclosed properties Rick acquires and resells may be repositories of hopes, dreams and family memories, but they‰Ûªre also economic units, ‰ÛÏboxes‰Ûù to be emptied out, refilled and written down on a balance sheet. That‰Ûªs a fact of life, and also a tragic contradiction.

Some of the suspense comes from the realization that Mr. Bahrani has taken a big risk of his own. As Dennis‰Ûªs inner conflict becomes unbearable, you may start to become aware of the traps ‰ÛÏ99 Homes‰Ûù has set for itself, and to anticipate endings that seem too bleak, too soothing or too sensational to fulfill the film‰Ûªs promise. But the ending, if I may say so without giving anything away, is just right, absolutely consistent with Mr. Bahrani‰Ûªs acute, impassioned understanding of contemporary American reality. The final shot is at once perfectly clear and perfectly ambiguous, a reminder that some contradictions are more easily understood than resolved.

In contrast, Rick (played with tiger-shark ferocity by Michael Shannon), could conduct a self-help seminar on how to think, act and dress like a winner. With an e-cigarette clenched between his teeth, a pistol strapped to his ankle and a cellphone glued to his ear, Rick may be heartless, but he certainly isn‰Ûªt dumb. His assessment of the brutalities of the housing market in Central Florida ‰ÛÓ and of the Darwinian logic that underlies them ‰ÛÓ is hard to dispute. The bubble has burst, and as homeowners like Dennis find themselves underwater, trapped in treacherous and complicated loans, Rick is on hand to clean up the mess, or at least to profit from it. Compassion is for suckers, and one man‰Ûªs misery is another‰Ûªs opportunity.

Three of Mr. Bahrani‰Ûªs earlier features ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMan Push Cart,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏChop Shop‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGoodbye Solo‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ were exemplary works of American neo-neorealism, using mostly nonprofessional casts and a stripped-down shooting style to tell stories of economic striving and spiritual struggle. Like the original Italian neorealists (and like the Belgian filmmakers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, their most prominent present-day heirs), Mr. Bahrani is especially interested in how the material circumstances of his characters affect their moral decisions. The need for money, and for the security, dignity and status it brings, can force terrible choices on people, but hard times and systemic injustice don‰Ûªt absolve anyone of ethical responsibility.

But if ‰ÛÏ99 Homes‰Ûù is a scolding look at a society gone astray, it is also a minor masterpiece of suspense, as tightly wound as ‰ÛÏSicario,‰Ûù Denis Villeneuve‰Ûªs white-knuckle drug-war thriller, and almost as brutal. Not that there‰Ûªs much in the way of physical violence: fists are raised now and then, and weapons are sometimes brandished. But the threat of destruction is pervasive, and everything ‰ÛÓ the hand-held camerawork, the swift editing, the anxious music by Antony Partos and Matteo Zingales ‰ÛÓ contributes to an overpowering sense of danger.

He shows up on eviction day, backed up by sheriff‰Ûªs deputies and bank documents, to tell families that they are now trespassing on property they thought was theirs. The furniture goes out on the sidewalk and the residents enter a spiral of downward mobility. Some plead for more time, others wave papers and invoke lawyers, and a few threaten violence, but the result is always the same. Dennis, Connor and Lynn wind up sharing a room in a motel overflowing with families in similar circumstances. Maybe the game is rigged, or maybe the laws of nature just work that way. It hardly matters to Rick ‰ÛÓ or to Dennis, whose passage from Rick‰Ûªs victim to his protÌ©gÌ© forms the main axis of the film‰Ûªs narrative.
Lizzie Velasquez was born with a rare syndrome that prevents her from gaining weight. From birth, her illness altered her features and left her body stick thin. Now 26, she weighs about 63 pounds.

‰ÛÏA Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). An absurd rating if it keeps away the young people who most need to hear these harsh descriptions of bullying.
Despite the disfiguring effects of the disease and some ostracization in grade school, she grew up happily. At 17, ‰ÛÏI was on the high road,‰Ûù she says.
Then the Internet found her.

The makers of ‰ÛÏA Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story‰Ûù leave a few too many questions unanswered, but their subject‰Ûªs immense optimism steamrolls through the documentary‰Ûªs shortcomings. Indeed, there seems to be little this woman can‰Ûªt vanquish.

One day, as Ms. Velasquez is about to speak before a crowd of 10,000, she receives another hate-filled message. It‰Ûªs a searing scene that makes you want to rush to her aid. Yet for all this dauntless woman can teach us, it‰Ûªs clear we need her help far more than she needs ours.

While doing homework she came across a YouTube page titled ‰ÛÏThe World‰Ûªs Ugliest Woman.‰Ûù She clicked on it: Someone had posted a video of her, and hundreds of vicious comments had been written. The anonymous taunting intensified, leading her to film her own videos, dedicated to acceptance. A TED talk that has been viewed by millions followed. By the film‰Ûªs end she is lobbying Congress for anti-bullying legislation.

Sara Hirsh Bordo, directing her first feature, keeps the scenes bright and fast-moving, but several important topics ‰ÛÓ Ms. Velasquez‰Ûªs health, her deeper emotions, her college years ‰ÛÓ are barely addressed. The film also stirs up an intense urge to see at least one Internet troll tracked down and confronted, an opportunity not taken here.

Ed, a slender type who should know better, wants to play football on his school‰Ûªs team. Never mind that the coach is a loathsome boor and the other teammates are bullies and yahoos. His speed and agility win him a place as a wide receiver. Mr. Wolff is a hot enough commodity (since ‰ÛÏThe Fault in Our Stars‰Ûù) that he has to win every game. The football sequences are laughably perfunctory.
‰ÛÏAshby‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian).Strong language, some sexual material and violence.

Mickey Rourke, who plays the title character in ‰ÛÏAshby,‰Ûù is a bizarre sight in this overstuffed semicomedy, which has no idea what it wants to say. In his towering gray pompadour, Ashby suggests a vain, surgically altered Mafioso relocated to Virginia through the witness protection program. In fact, Ashby is something even more exotic: a retired C.I.A. assassin who by his own account killed 93 people in the line of duty. Is he a heroic patriot or a sociopath? The movie doesn‰Ûªt dare ask, but Mr. Rourke‰Ûªs gruff, sentimental performance suggests a little of both, tilting toward patriot.

Ms. Silverman‰Ûªs character has little to do, but she at least gets off a couple of amusingly barbed remarks. ‰ÛÏHe came out of my vagina, and now he‰Ûªs like this man with wings on his feet,‰Ûù June shrieks after Ed scores a touchdown.

Ashby, who passes as a napkin salesman, spills the beans to Ed (Nat Wolff), a nerdy teenager who lives next door with his divorced mother, June (Sarah Silverman). Ed and Ashby meet when Ed, given a high school assignment to interview and write about an older person, notices Ashby and pays him a visit. Rummaging around Ashby‰Ûªs house, Ed discovers shelves of guns and knives and asks questions. As they drive around town, Ashby tells his story on the condition that Ed not reveal his cloak-and-dagger past. An unlikely mentor-protÌ©gÌ© bond develops.

Meanwhile, Ed pursues a romance with Eloise (Emma Roberts), a precocious classmate who is studying brain injuries among football players and has an M.R.I. machine in her basement. When she takes off her glasses, she is va-va-voom gorgeous. If this wispy subplot were detached from the rest of the movie and developed, it might be the basis of an amusing screwball farce.

‰ÛÏAshby‰Ûù winds the story of Ed‰Ûªs personal growth around Ashby‰Ûªs coming to terms with his dirty deeds after he collapses and learns he has three months to live. Discovering that one of his victims was innocent, he visits a priest seeking absolution and also confronts a C.I.A. colleague who dismisses the dead man as ‰ÛÏthe enemy of the state of my bank balance.‰Ûù

Written and directed by the Australian filmmaker Tony McNamara, ‰ÛÏAshby‰Ûù is a movie divided against itself. It‰Ûªs a comedy afraid of being too funny lest its macho sentimentality seem even more ridiculous than it is, and a drama afraid of appearing too serious lest you dismiss it as hogwash.

Besides the usual ordeals of moviemaking ‰ÛÓ missed lines, bad cues, lighting woes ‰ÛÓ Mr. Barnett looked at the cast and crew‰Ûªs friendships and struggles. These men and women with Down syndrome, cerebral palsy and other disorders speak frankly (and with plenty of humor) about sexuality, relationships and anxieties. There‰Ûªs some sadness and tears, but never pity or mawkishness.

A. J. Murray, a man with severe cerebral palsy, flies from Atlanta to the film‰Ûªs set in California to realize his dream of becoming an actor, despite constant pain from his condition. He needs to be fed and bathed by others (‰ÛÏMore people have seen me naked than I can remember‰Ûù) but his determination is moving. A segment near the end, when the group reunites at a theater to watch the finished product, is wholly honest and beautiful.

The film inside the film seems a bit slapdash. But that‰Ûªs the only false note in ‰ÛÏBecoming Bulletproof,‰Ûù a wonderful documentary that follows a group of disabled adults who work together to make a movie.

‰ÛÏBecoming Bulletproof‰Ûù focuses on Zeno Mountain Farm, a nonprofit organization that assembles troupes of disabled and able-bodied actors to produce films. Recently the group decided to make a western, its first ever, and Michael Barnett, the documentary‰Ûªs director, trailed them.

While the scenes shown from ‰ÛÏBulletproof,‰Ûù the western they complete, are haphazard, that‰Ûªs of little concern. If you want to see real courage, it‰Ûªs not in that movie anyway. It‰Ûªs in this documentary.
