‰ÛÏFinders Keepers‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Malapropisms and mummified remains.

‰ÛÏYeah, I saw it,‰Ûù a police officer admits when asked about the leg, recalling Mr. Whisnant‰Ûªs 911 call in 2007 to report his ‰ÛÏplum nasty‰Ûù find. ‰ÛÏI just didn‰Ûªt want to pick it up.‰Ûù Mr. Whisnant had no such qualms, turning it ‰ÛÓ and himself ‰ÛÓ into a tourist attraction (‰ÛÏThey want to see it, and watch the cholesterol drip out of it‰Ûù) and denying Mr. Wood‰Ûªs pleas to return his property, which had been severed in a plane crash.

An amputated leg leads everyone in a merry dance in ‰ÛÏFinders Keepers,‰Ûù the kind of documentary that makes you suspect that Christopher Guest is hiding behind the curtain. But this shockingly funny, weirdly touching custody battle between John Wood, the aggrieved amputee, and Shannon Whisnant, the fast-talking entrepreneur who unwittingly bought the appendage in a storage-unit auction, is as authentic as the North Carolina vernacular in which it unfolds.

Yet the hicks-at-loggerheads story that was propagated by a snickering news media (and that is grasped, sometimes uneasily, by the directors, Bryan Carberry and Clay Tweel) veils a deeper, more resonant tale of fathers and sons and wounded feelings. And as hilarious graphics follow the limb‰Ûªs bizarre journey from funeral home to Hardee‰Ûªs drive-through, from embalmer to possum tree (don‰Ûªt ask), those feelings push insistently against the desire to mock.

Revealing its humanity slowly and a little tardily, ‰ÛÏFinders Keepers‰Ûù finally does justice to its dueling antiheroes, one addicted to attention and the other to multiple substances; one indulged and the other violently abused; one who finds himself and one who becomes increasingly lost.

Still, some jokes actually work (a GPS-voice gag induced unforced laughter), and the whole thing is amiable and colorful and surprisingly low on body-function gags. It may not kill you to take your kids.
‰ÛÏHotel Transylvania 2‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Scary images, action and rude humor.

In the 2012 animated picture ‰ÛÏHotel Transylvania,‰Ûù the comedy stalwart Adam Sandler voiced a Dracula who juggled concerns over his troubled spooky-lodging business with concerns over losing his vampire daughter, Mavis, to the outside world. Mr. Sandler‰Ûªs cronies and frequent co-stars in live-action movies voiced Dracula‰Ûªs classic-monster cohort. As a homage to beloved old-movie myths, it fell into the ‰ÛÏeach man kills the thing he loves‰Ûù category of tribute, setting a level of sacrilege so high that its sequel, ‰ÛÏHotel Transylvania 2,‰Ûù directed by the returning Genndy Tartakovsky, is more tolerable simply by dint of inoculation.

Mavis (Selena Gomez) and her human husband, Johnny (Andy Samberg), have now produced a son, and while Drac yearns for him to show a vampirish side, the in-laws do not. Conflicts over parenting styles and bits about out-of-touch oldsters ensue. As it turns out, gags about texting-challenged seniors are no less tedious when applied to the undead. Similarly, an animated children‰Ûªs movie might seem an unusual vehicle for airing grievances about helicopter-parenting culture. On the other hand, at this particular juncture in Western civilization no one cares about what‰Ûªs appropriate or, for that matter, coherent. The movie is also disinclined to consider the cognitive dissonance arising from the replacement of the lullaby lyrics ‰ÛÏTwinkle, twinkle, little star‰Ûù with ‰ÛÏSuffer, suffer, scream in pain.‰Ûù

Ms. Argento has a florid visual style, and she likes turning up the heat. Her characters seem to yell as much as they speak, with shivers of violence running through their words and gestures. It‰Ûªs not for nothing that the first scene in ‰ÛÏMisunderstood‰Ûù takes place at the dinner table, that familiar stage for dramatics. Here, as it does so often in this film, an ordinary family room ‰ÛÓ painted a rich blue and ornamented with a gilt-framed pastoral painting ‰ÛÓ takes on an exaggerated, near-operatic quality as the parents begin a cruel performance that they have clearly given before. ‰ÛÏSee?,‰Ûù Mother says, her chin jutting at Father, after Aria says that she isn‰Ûªt hungry. ‰ÛÏYour daughter‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the two words and the maternal rejection they announce cut like a knife ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏbehaves just like you. Fine example.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏMisunderstood,‰Ûù a buoyantly funny, sometimes desperately sad film about a child searching for love and home, could easily be titled ‰ÛÏThe Girl, Her Bag and Her Beautiful Cat.‰Ûù These three are the film‰Ûªs holy trinity and its defining image, one that is almost Chaplinesque in its graphic clarity and emotional punch. The director, Asia Argento, has a finely tuned sense of the absurd, but isn‰Ûªt afraid of tears. This may be because she once shared the name of the 9-year-old girl, Aria, who observes this turbulent world as if it were a drama she might one day stage.

In a sense that‰Ûªs what Ms. Argento has done in ‰ÛÏMisunderstood,‰Ûù a film that, despite its allusions to her own life, she has characterized as personal rather than autobiographical. An actress turned director (‰ÛÏScarlet Diva‰Ûù), she is the daughter of Dario Argento, the Italian cult filmmaker, and Daria Nicolodi, an actress and screenwriter. Ms. Argento wrote ‰ÛÏMisunderstood‰Ûù with Barbara Alberti, and they have come up with a story that wavers between realism and surrealism, and sometimes feels like a faraway dream and at times a nightmare. One reason for this instability is that the film ‰ÛÓ from its initial images of a small hand writing in a book ornamented with scrawls and hearts ‰ÛÓ has been filtered through Aria, an intensely sympathetic presence who may also be somewhat of an unreliable narrator.

The story tracks Aria (a terrific Giulia Salerno) as she journeys ‰ÛÓ gingerly, pluckily, forlornly ‰ÛÓ between the competing needs of the monstrous narcissists she calls Mother and Father. At once cartoonish and all too viscerally real, Father (Gabriel Garko) is a dandyish actor with blond hair, big white teeth and ravenous ambitions. On the brink of a career breakthrough, he shows little interest in anyone other than himself, with the exception of his daughter Lucrezia (Carolina Poccioni), from an earlier relationship. For her part, Aria‰Ûªs mother (Charlotte Gainsbourg, excellent), a pianist and sadist, has eyes only for Donatina (Anna Lou Castoldi), yet another daughter from another coupling. This leaves Aria, the only product of HER mother and father‰Ûªs unhappy union, very much the odd girl out.

Aria scarcely seems to notice this parental theater, probably because she‰Ûªs seen it before. She‰Ûªs an astonishingly resilient child, at least until she isn‰Ûªt, and she escapes partly through her imagination (that‰Ûªs her scribbling in the opening credits) and partly through her friendships with another schoolgirl and especially the cat she calls Dac. Ms. Argento makes the most of her young star‰Ûªs blue eyes, which only seem to grow larger after Aria cuts her hair, and uses the girl‰Ûªs small stature to occasionally devastating effect. Aria looks as if she could break in half, especially when she staggers into the street alone with her bag and cat. Her parents have each rejected her, turning her into an orphan of a kind. What they can‰Ûªt know, but we do, is that they‰Ûªre also helping turn her into an artist.
Perhaps he‰Ûªll do better in the sequel, which a last-minute image may or may not presage. Too bad you‰Ûªll have to sit through the end credits to decide.

Unconvincing in premise or setting (the couple‰Ûªs gloomily cavernous home suggests that teaching salaries have soared since I was in academia), Dan Kay‰Ûªs filament-thin story, accessorized with flapping vultures and disturbing graffiti, relies entirely on Mr. Cage‰Ûªs desperate-dad energy. Sludgy greens and smudged blacks assault the eyes, and crashing sound cues accompany every scare ‰ÛÓ dead giveaways of a director, Uli Edel, who trusts neither his audience nor his images. This is all the more surprising when you consider that Mr. Edel, with his 2009 thriller ‰ÛÏThe Baader Meinhof Complex,‰Ûù displayed an aptitude for tension that‰Ûªs completely missing here.

‰ÛÏPay the Ghost‰Ûù does little to correct that imbalance. Getting a jump on the Halloween glut of heebie-jeebie entertainments, this lukewarm frightener, set in an unrecognizable New York City, recycles missing-child drama through a Celtic folk tale filter. One year after Mike (Mr. Cage), a newly tenured English professor, loses his young son at a Halloween carnival, he‰Ûªs still on the streets posting fliers and in the doghouse with his estranged wife (Sarah Wayne Callies). He‰Ûªs also the tormented curator of a ‰ÛÏcrazy wall‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ that hieroglyph-splattered signifier of extreme mental obsession.

Good actors making poor choices ‰ÛÓ especially when the actor is Nicolas Cage ‰ÛÓ is nothing new, but I worry that the dross in his career ledger is rapidly outpacing the gold. A compellingly idiosyncratic performer, he has languished too long in movies unworthy of his commitment and with no room for the seat-of-the-pants improvisations that make him so riveting.

Each of these romantically bereft creative types brings a different shade of anguish to the table. Alley Scott, a multitalented designer, is freshly dumped by her partner of several passionate years. Her fair skin is often flushed from crying and appears all the more blotchy in frequent Skype footage. For Michael Hariton, a translator, the sting comes from the casualness with which he was dropped, on the way to drinks; he lends a caustic, self-lacerating perspective, with the expression of a dog fearing another beating. Finally, the burlesque dancer Rosey La Rouge lives in a what-if world, pining for a man she met once in costume at Coney Island.

A running thread in the film, quite literally, is Helen Fisher, a biological anthropologist who studies the basis of romantic feelings. Often shown jogging or observing human mating rituals at a bar, she‰Ûªs a strident, repetitive proponent of the view that love is an addiction, an opinion that quickly acquires the ring of a self-help talking point.

Cinema may be fluent in the language of romance, but breakups are another, excruciating story, and Christian Frei is happy to chronicle them in ‰ÛÏSleepless in New York.‰Ûù Following three lovelorn city dwellers over an extended period, Mr. Frei‰Ûªs raw documentary plumbs the soul-searching, pain and dark, obsessive thoughts that afflict these victims of lost love.

Mr. Frei adds to the medley of misery with warped shots of subway riders and their imagined musings. There‰Ûªs something woebegone about the film itself as it staggers along, ever in danger of tipping into the abyss inhabited by one of its subjects.

It is, in short, an Eli Roth movie, and only fans of the grisly and the grotesque should go to it. It‰Ûªs called ‰ÛÏThe Green Inferno,‰Ûù but it quickly turns blood red as a group of students meet a tribe of cannibals in the Peruvian Amazon.

Mr. Roth, whose earlier work includes the ‰ÛÏHostel‰Ûù horror movies, is not doing a parody of those movies. He‰Ûªs playing it straight and very graphically. The students, naÌøve and poorly prepared, travel to the Amazon to stop bulldozers that are threatening a primitive tribe‰Ûªs land, but when their plane crashes they become the tribe‰Ûªs captives, and its dinner.

The movie is a revisiting of what is often called the cannibal subgenre, a vile strain of films in which Westerners encounter tribes in the jungle. The heyday of those films, many of which were by Italian directors, was in the 1970s and ‰Ûª80s, and they were known for their depictions of indigenous people as savages, and for their explicit gore.
‰ÛÏThe Green Inferno‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or guardian). It‰Ûªs awash in blood, some of it over naked bodies.

It‰Ûªs a homage written in blood. It‰Ûªs an excursion into the forbidden land of unpalatable ideas, with the severed limbs and disemboweled bodies of idealistic young college students serving as signposts.

The film reawakens long-repudiated notions of white supremacy and such, but Mr. Roth is surely not trying to peddle them. He‰Ûªs merely seeing if he can replicate the formula of the subgenre. And he does, fairly slickly, in fact. Is there some artistic reason for doing so? Not really.

Sometime during the war, two white sisters Augusta (Brit Marling) and Louise (Hailee Steinfeld) are holed up in the family homestead with a slave, Mad (Muna Otaru). The men are long gone, and soon enough the three must reckon with a predatory pair of Union soldiers (Sam Worthington and Kyle Soller). The louts notice Augusta when she journeys out for medicine, and their nighttime siege of the three women dominates the film.

To a certain extent, Mr. Barber, who also directed the Michael Caine movie ‰ÛÏHarry Brown,‰Ûù has simply made a mild exploitation film in dress-up, but he‰Ûªs overly concerned with ensuring every line leaves its mark.

Mr. Barber can work up a fair sense of menace, but he seems to have directed most of the talented cast to speak their lines in a mannered fashion learned from other movies. Mad is an especially unfortunate font of homespun wisdom, and when she finally delivers a shattering monologue, the effect is lost through its self-conscious staging.

Rather than a credible historical setting, the deserted wartime landscape is more a backdrop for drawn-out showdowns and portentous moments, broken up by an overbearing score. Mr. Barber and the screenwriter Julia Hart take the feminist potential of the premise for granted, rather than nurturing the story into something as rich as, say, Don Siegel‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Beguiled,‰Ûù a 1971 portrait of another house of women during the Civil War.
The ravages of the Civil War shouldn‰Ûªt require much jazzing up for the movies, but the British director Daniel Barber labors to impress with his Southern period thriller ‰ÛÏThe Keeping Room.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe Keeping Room‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong violence, including sexual assault.

And raw it is, as Xu Lai dashes though the splendid scenery of Hong Kong, followed closely by Cai Lala. The film is leavened by slapstick and studded with stunt sequences involving actors‰Ûª dangling from high places; colliding with movie shoots; outrunning gangsters; and encountering every possible messy, malodorous or dangerous landing place.

Xu Zheng directs and stars in this comedy (the same arrangement as in ‰ÛÏLost in Thailand,‰Ûù its precursor). He plays Xu Lai, once a hip art student with ideals and now a bra designer sustained by memories.

‰ÛÏLost in Hong Kong‰Ûù is a very, very, very, long-feeling movie with identity problems: At times it seems like an extended, sappy pop-music video; at others, a buddy film, with no love lost between the buddies. An unresolved love lies at the center, and a tacked-on homicide unreels into an irrelevant side plot. Perhaps because it tries too hard to be too many things, the movie loses its punch.

His heart was fixed on a beautiful but pragmatic classmate, Yang Yi (Du Juan), who left him to take a spot in art school in Hong Kong. Now, 20 years after they parted, Yang Yi, a celebrity artist, summons Xu Lai to Hong Kong for her exhibition.
In the end, however, no one comes out smelling like a durian.
Xu Lai‰Ûªs wife, Cai Bo, or Spinach (Zhao Wei), encounters no impediments to her own rendezvous with a dashing Frenchman.

He arrives there, accompanied by his wife‰Ûªs entire family, for his secret meeting with Yang Yi. If only he could shed the goofy, bewigged Cai Lala (Bao Bei‰Ûªer), the documentarian-wannabe brother-in-law who, video camera in hand, is epoxied to Xu Lai‰Ûªs side, determined to capture raw reality.
Documentaries about disabilities don‰Ûªt come any smarter or more touching than ‰ÛÏMission to Lars,‰Ûù a beautiful sibling road trip tale with a heavy-metal flourish.

So ‰ÛÏMission to Lars‰Ûù is as much about Kate and William‰Ûªs learning process as it is about Tom and the quest. They slowly come to appreciate their brother‰Ûªs challenges ‰ÛÓ for instance, an expert on fragile X explains to them that part of Tom‰Ûªs trepidation about attending a concert is that ‰ÛÏfor him, the sound is maybe 10 times louder than it is for you.‰Ûù

Do they ever overcome the obstacles and accomplish the mission? It‰Ûªs touch and go the whole way, but by the film‰Ûªs end, we know one thing: Heavy-metal drummers can be surprisingly, movingly gracious.

So his brother and sister take him to the United States, where Metallica is touring, and make arrangements that they hope might get him a handshake from Mr. Ulrich. But Tom has been living in a group home; his siblings don‰Ûªt really know him well, and they have no idea of the challenges of traveling with someone with Tom‰Ûªs disability. Routine is important to Tom, and such a trip disrupts his world so much that his defense mechanisms kick in, jeopardizing the whole effort.

It‰Ûªs about Tom Spicer, a British man with fragile X syndrome, which impairs cognitive and emotional functions, and his siblings, Kate and William, who are determined to help him fulfill his long-stated desire to meet Lars Ulrich, the drummer for Metallica. Tom, whose disability can manifest itself in fixations of various kinds, doesn‰Ûªt say much, but one thing he has said endlessly over the years is ‰ÛÏWant to meet Lars.‰Ûù

The filmmakers and the actors have a keen ear for the vicissitudes of male friendship, for the dance of bluster, affection and rivalry that can bind two guys together. The movie is also wise about the different ways men can be messed up about women, without losing sight of the individuality of the women they encounter. These include Gerry‰Ûªs ex-wife (Robin Weigert), who lives in Arkansas, and two women in St. Louis: Vanessa (Analeigh Tipton), who is kind to Gerry; and Simone (Sienna Miller), who is either the love of Curtis‰Ûªs life or a knowing patsy in his long emotional grift.

Winning is better, of course. That‰Ûªs an article of faith, an ideological tenet, a campaign slogan. And Curtis (Ryan Reynolds) and Gerry (Ben Mendelsohn), two guys whose friendship begins at a poker table, want to believe that they‰Ûªre winners. Curtis, at first, seems to have the better shot. Gerry describes him as ‰ÛÏa handsome leprechaun‰Ûù (a pretty good characterization of Mr. Reynolds, it must be said), and there is indeed something magical about him. Curtis lights up a sleepy card room with jokes and wild stories, hooking Gerry so quickly with his charm that you suspect some kind of con must be afoot.

Gambling is where the iron laws of probability collide with the human propensity for magical thinking. Gambling movies tend to stack the deck in favor of the miraculous. Can you believe that long shot came in a winner? That ace showed up on the river? That seven landed again? Maybe not, but what‰Ûªs the harm in pretending? Gerry is a walking answer to that question, but never mind. ‰ÛÏMississippi Grind‰Ûù indulges in some of the fantasies of the genre without sacrificing credibility. There‰Ûªs plenty to see here that‰Ûªs grubby and sad, and a lot more going on than just games of chance.

There is, above all, a two-handed demonstration of actorly skill. Mr. Reynolds, whose ventures outside Hollywood leading-man territory have been admirable if not always successful (see ‰ÛÏThe Voices‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSelf/less‰Ûù), uses his natural likability as a kind of disguise. You can‰Ûªt always tell what‰Ûªs sincerity and what‰Ûªs misdirection, and after a while he lets you see that Curtis isn‰Ûªt entirely sure himself. Gerry, who at first seems merely pathetic, gradually reveals layers of guile, pride, gentleness and fury, and Mr. Mendelsohn shows himself, once again, to be an almost infinitely resourceful actor.

As the story drifts southward from Iowa toward New Orleans, stopping in St. Louis, Memphis and Little Rock, it‰Ûªs hard not to be swept along on currents of wistful patriotism. In America, at least according to the rough romanticism this movie embraces, even the bad stuff ‰ÛÓ loneliness, regret, lousy poker hands, cheap booze, unpayable debts ‰ÛÓ can make you feel good. Even a sad song can bring you joy. A game can be fun even when you lose.

Even if you are not a sucker, as I am, for any movie about gambling with an American geographical reference in the title ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏCalifornia Split,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Cincinnati Kid,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏAtlantic City‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ you will find a lot to like about ‰ÛÏMississippi Grind,‰Ûù a low-key road movie written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck. Who can resist a soundtrack full of well-chosen blues and country-and-western songs, many of which offer further testimony to the place of cards, poker chips, dice and racehorses in our national mythology? There is also a cameo from James Toback, screenwriter of ‰ÛÏThe Gambler‰Ûù (the good one, from 1974, with James Caan), and as such a kind of tutelary deity of long odds and risky bets.
‰ÛÏMississippi Grind‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bad luck, bad habits, bad language.

Mr. Fleck and Ms. Boden, whose previous collaborations include ‰ÛÏHalf Nelson,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏSugar‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs Kind of a Funny Story,‰Ûù have consistently refused to chain themselves or their characters to the machinery of plot. ‰ÛÏMississippi Grind‰Ûù has a loose, behind-the-beat rhythm. It slows down, wanders off, hangs out and kibitzes, confident that the company, the scenery, the music and a few sneakily profound themes will hold your interest.

When a climactic sequence of events arises ‰ÛÓ big bets, revealed secrets, a flurry of punches ‰ÛÓ it all feels fresh, surprising and plausible. ‰ÛÏMississippi Grind‰Ûù itself may be a bit of a throwback to the lived-in, character-driven, landscape-besotted films of the 1970s, but it‰Ûªs less a pastiche or a homage than the cinematic equivalent of a classic song, expertly covered.

Gerry, with his creased face, his tentative manner and his wobbly chin, seems like an easy mark. A divorced real estate agent who lives with his cat, Gerry owes money to the friendly neighborhood loan shark (Alfre Woodard), and to a lot of other people, too. Of course, like most problem gamblers, he‰Ûªs one lucky break away from making everything come around right. When the truth is inconvenient, he‰Ûªs full of excuses, evasions and outright lies. He revises his winnings upward, his losses downward, and at one point claims that a disastrous hand of Texas Hold ‰Ûªem was a big win. It almost was. It should have been.

A satirical magazine started by three Harvard graduates ‰ÛÓ Doug Kenney, Henry Beard and Robert Hoffman ‰ÛÓ The National Lampoon took the ball passed by forerunners like the comedy troupe Firesign Theater and ran with it to the bank. For dope-smoking, left-leaning baby boomers, The Lampoon enshrined the concept of hip.

The Lampoon branched into radio, records and theater, a high point being the Off Broadway musical ‰ÛÏLemmings,‰Ûù a parody of a Woodstock-like festival whose audience is invited to commit mass suicide. Its star, John Belushi, came into the Lampoon orbit from the Chicago comedy troupe Second City. Belushi, like Gilda Radner and other Second City alumni, were quickly filched by ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live.‰Ûù The movie portrays the evolution of this multimedia juggernaut as a cultural explosion that inevitably led to the demise of the magazine as more lucrative horizons beckoned.

The film is also the story of the ascent of the generation of writers and performers who took over and reinvented American comedy. In 1974, the magazine‰Ûªs peak year, monthly circulation exceeded one million. Even when newsstand sales were healthy, nobody would buy advertising, because the humor was so raunchy and irreverent. One talking head recalls that an ad for tequila was the magazine‰Ûªs advertising breakthrough.

This documentary, directed by Douglas Tirola, is a concise but rich history of The Lampoon‰Ûªs rise and fall as it expanded into a comedic juggernaut that culminated with the 1978 movie blockbuster ‰ÛÏNational Lampoon‰Ûªs Animal House.‰Ûù Focusing on the magazine and not its offshoots, the film is uproarious, not for what its many talking heads say but for its astonishing procession of brilliant, boundary-breaching illustrations and captions (augmented by some animation), many of which are as explosively funny today as they were when first published. The sampling of the magazine‰Ûªs most famous work includes its cover of a revolver pointed at a dog‰Ûªs head with the words ‰ÛÏIf you don‰Ûªt buy this magazine, we‰Ûªll kill this dog.‰Ûù Another infamous moment was a fake ad, ‰ÛÏIf Ted Kennedy drove a Volkswagen, he‰Ûªd be president today,‰Ûù which alluded to a deadly car accident involving Kennedy and prompted a lawsuit by the carmaker.

A spinoff from The Harvard Lampoon, The National Lampoon was founded in 1969 and first published in 1970, and it quickly established itself as a kind of Mad magazine with a post-countercultural readership for whom nothing was sacred and everything ripe for satire. The closest thing to a contemporary descendant is probably ‰ÛÏSouth Park.‰Ûù

Among the many writers and performers whose careers are sketched in the movie, Mr. Kenney is the connective thread. Recognized as a genius and the magazine‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏheart and soul,‰Ûù he was a driven, astoundingly productive workaholic with a worsening cocaine problem who ‰ÛÏwent Hollywood‰Ûù with a vengeance and died in Hawaii in 1980 after falling off a cliff. He was 33.

Though the magazine was founded three years earlier, it found its tone in 1972, when Michael Gross became its art director, and the shaggy, Robert Crumb-influenced visual style of its first issues became sleek. An early success was a dead-on parody of Mademoiselle magazine, followed later by eerily perfect re-creations of Time, Life and Sports Illustrated. One of the magazine‰Ûªs greatest achievements was its ‰ÛÏ1964 High School Yearbook Parody,‰Ûù written by P. J. O‰ÛªRourke and Mr. Kenney, a cover-to-cover, edgy facsimile of a generic high school yearbook of the period.

‰ÛÏDrunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of The National Lampoon‰Ûù looks longingly back at the 1970s when a smart, tasteless joke could make you laugh out loud without worrying about hurting someone‰Ûªs feelings or being attacked on social media. Hedonism was in full sway and political correctness in its infancy.

Jules‰Ûªs problem is as familiar as the last headline that recycled the plagues of career women who want it all, apparently can‰Ûªt have it all and are unsure if they want any of it in the first place. ‰ÛÏWhat do women want,‰Ûù Forbes asked a few years ago, echoing (still!) Dr. Freud. Among the suggestions: a little sadomasochistic me time ÌÊ la ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey.‰Ûù For her part, Jules mostly wants someone to tidy up a cluttered table that sits like a reproach in the middle of the immaculate office and that for some reason she won‰Ûªt or can‰Ûªt tell someone to clean. Structurally, the messy table is a means for Ben, the ultimate can-do type whom Jules doesn‰Ûªt want to engage, to at last catch her attention. And he does just that when he clears it, inaugurating a work relationship that soon turns into a friendship.

The director Nancy Meyers doesn‰Ûªt just make movies, she makes the kind of lifestyle fantasies you sink into like eiderdown. Her movies are frothy, playful, homogeneous, routinely maddening and generally pretty irresistible even when they‰Ûªre not all that good. Her most notable visual signature is the immaculate, luxuriously appointed interiors she‰Ûªs known to fuss over personally ‰ÛÓ they inevitably feature throw pillows that look as if they‰Ûªve been arranged with a measuring tape. These interiors are fetishized by moviegoers and Architectural Digest alike, ready-made for Pinterest and comment threads peppered with questions like, ‰ÛÏWhere do I get that hat?‰Ûù

Ms. Hathaway, who‰Ûªs regularly forced to take Jules‰Ûªs inner girl out for a sniffle and a sob, does her best, but it‰Ûªs hopeless. Jules is less of a character and more of a fast-walking, speed-talking collection of gender grievances, some of which originate with a squirmy house husband Matt (Anders Holm). One look at that guy‰Ûªs smile and you want Mr. De Niro to wipe it off. He doesn‰Ûªt, but there‰Ûªs no need to because Mr. De Niro owns the movie from the moment he opens his mouth, and is staring into the camera and right at you. (Oh, yes, he‰Ûªs lookin‰Ûª at you.) You can‰Ûªt look away, and soon you don‰Ûªt want to. Certainly Ms. Meyers doesn‰Ûªt want anyone to because, though she loves the idea of the successful, independent woman, she also ardently wants to make room for daddy.

The table is a silly, lazy screenwriting contrivance, and it says more about Ms. Meyers‰Ûªs conflicted ideas about powerful women than it conveys anything interesting about Jules. A successful Hollywood director like Ms. Meyers, for starters, would never have gotten this far and with a number of hits to her name if she had been afraid of telling other people what to do. But Ms. Meyers has some distinct ideas about women, work and power, and so she piles on the issues: Jules is chronically late to meetings, among other sins, although that seems to be because she likes riding slowly through the office on her bicycle. The bike suggests that she‰Ûªs a nonconformist, although the neat rows of her pretty, young, overwhelmingly white employees doing something in front of their computers suggest otherwise.

In her latest, Robert De Niro plays Ben Whittaker, a 70-year-old widower who shakes up his life when he becomes an intern at a web start-up where he soon becomes an office mascot and geezer Tinker Bell. Mostly, though, Ben is the benign face of patriarchy, a gentler, kinder father figure who comes equipped with a laundered handkerchief and the wisdom of the elders. He shares both with his new boss, Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), the founder of an online clothing site that has rocketed from zero to zillions in record time. She runs her company with a steely grip and a forced smile in a refurbished Brooklyn warehouse the size of Grand Central Terminal. She‰Ûªs a success and possibly an obsessive-compulsive (she all but showers in hand sanitizer), but she‰Ûªs also floundering, one crisis at a time.

Ben doesn‰Ûªt sweep up the damsel like Daniel Day-Lewis in ‰ÛÏThe Last of the Mohicans,‰Ûù but he proves more than up to the task. Ms. Meyers‰Ûªs script makes sure that‰Ûªs the case, as does the smartest choice she makes in ‰ÛÏThe Intern‰Ûù: Mr. De Niro, her loosest, most valuable player. Long celebrated for his vein-popping intensity, Mr. De Niro has been yukking it up in comedy since the 1960s. Part of what distinguishes his later laugh-ins is that they‰Ûªre inextricably haunted by the ghost of Travis Bickle and sometimes ‰ÛÓ as when Mr. De Niro breaks out his terrifying ear-to-ear Soupy Sales grin ‰ÛÓ Rupert Pupkin, his nut job from ‰ÛÏThe King of Comedy.‰Ûù However straight his character, he can‰Ûªt help but be a destabilizing force, which is crucial when a movie is as hermetically sealed as ‰ÛÏThe Intern.‰Ûù

Ben serves as a kind of Mr. Fix-It, who, with quiet confidence, paternal competence and a driver‰Ûªs license, helps Jules get on track at work and home in the way that none of the man-children in her life can. Ms. Meyers has clearly been binging on Judd Apatow comedies, and she stacks her movie with assorted bromantic schlumps (including a troika that functions like a farm team version of Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill and Michael Cera), whose sloppy clothes and facial hair emblematize not only their arrested development but also a crisis in masculinity. That guys like these help run the world (and the entertainment business) without hauling around a leather briefcase is immaterial to Ms. Meyers, presumably because it would get in the way of her new take on the rescue narrative.
‰ÛÏThe Intern‰Ûù is rated PG-13. (Parents strongly cautioned.) Tumescence and the usual tee-hee-hee gaggery.

Written and directed by Frank Hall Green, this drama makes an odd-couple match not just of its main characters, but of film types. ‰ÛÏWildlike‰Ûù pairs a small, nuanced story of sexual abuse and its fallout with a travelogue of spectacular vistas, as if immersion in the great outdoors could itself hasten recovery from trauma.

A final act ‰ÛÓ with Bartlett, Mackenzie and her uncle (Brian Geraghty) all on the same ferry to Juneau ‰ÛÓ is a misstep, unnecessarily juicing a previously low-key study. The ‰ÛÏWildlike‰Ûù landscapes are exhilarating, but when the film works, it‰Ûªs because of the interiors.

In ‰ÛÏWildlike,‰Ûù Mackenzie (Ella Purnell), a 14-year-old from Seattle whose father has died and whose mother is in rehab, is sent to live with her uncle in Alaska for the summer. But when the creep starts molesting her, she runs away, alone and desperate in strange if beautiful country. Scrambling to stay ahead of her uncle, Mackenzie eventually attaches to Bartlett (Bruce Greenwood), a middle-aged backpacker headed to Denali National Park, in the unspoken hope that he‰Ûªll help her get home.

Maybe it can. Mr. Greenwood (‰ÛÏFlight,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏMeek‰Ûªs Cutoff‰Ûù) is solid, every close-up revealing Bartlett‰Ûªs confusion, frustration and eventual realization about what to do with this girl he cannot shake. As a teenage cipher, Ms. Purnell is less successful; her constant fingernail biting is supposed to convey anxiety, while she remains mostly in a sullen pout. (As Mackenzie becomes more trusting, she sheds the raccoon-eyed goth look.) Ann Dowd makes a brief but reassuring presence as a vacationer who hosts the two at her campsite.

It has often been said that Mr. Petit taught New Yorkers to love the twin monoliths that were initially viewed as bland, arrogant interlopers on a cherished skyline. His coup, recounted in his book ‰ÛÏTo Reach the Clouds‰Ûù and in James Marsh‰Ûªs excellent documentary ‰ÛÏMan on Wire,‰Ûù is a cherished and bittersweet part of local history, and Mr. Zemeckis, astonishingly, brings it back into the present tense. Even though the outcome is never in doubt ‰ÛÓ this may be the most spoiler-proof movie ever made ‰ÛÓ you can‰Ûªt help holding your breath and clutching the armrests when Philippe steps out into the sky. The reality of the moment is so vivid that you may reflexively recoil, as if you risked plunging onto the sidewalk below. And the moment lasts. I had forgotten just how long Mr. Petit stayed up there, stretching a daredevil act into an astonishing and durable work of art.

‰ÛÏNow I‰Ûªve seen everything,‰Ûù an anonymous New Yorker remarks, marveling at the spectacle unfolding more than a hundred stories above street level. It‰Ûªs the morning of Aug. 7, 1974, and Philippe Petit is walking across a steel cable strung between the towers of the World Trade Center. Amid the gasps and murmurs, that line stands out, and invites a bit of pondering. It‰Ûªs an expression of wonder, for sure, but it also carries an implication of jadedness, especially for moviegoers. All the surround-sound bells and whistles and digitally enhanced fireworks in the world can‰Ûªt quite shake us out of the feeling that we‰Ûªve seen it all before.

After some practice and planning, the coup plotters head to New York, where they acquire a few more accomplices (including James Badge Dale, Ben Schwartz and the scene-stealing Steve Valentine) and begin their infiltration of the as-yet-unfinished Trade Center. Almost magically, ‰ÛÏThe Walk‰Ûù transforms itself into a beguiling caper movie, full of comic energy and nimble ingenuity. Whereas the earlier sections suffered from an absence of dramatic conflict ‰ÛÓ Philippe is immune to doubt, averse to introspection and impossible to argue with ‰ÛÓ the Manhattan chapters hum with practical, tactical excitement. There are so many problems to solve: security guards to evade, equipment to test, disguises to wear.

It‰Ûªs a lot of fun, with darker implications falling across the story like early morning shadows on a sunny day. There are tensions among Philippe and his comrades, including Annie. There is the danger of the coup itself. And, of course, for the audience, there is the inevitable premonition of grief. But Mr. Zemeckis, who wrote the script with Christopher Browne, spares us heavy-handed portents of destruction. Instead, he acknowledges the loss of the towers by lovingly and meticulously resurrecting them at the moment of their birth. The film becomes a poem of metal and concrete, a symphony composed in glass and rebar, light and air, and brought alive by an antic, crazy inspiration.

You might have a harder time. Let me see if I can put the matter in scientific terms. Philippe, in addition to being an aspiring wire walker, is a juggler, a mime and a unicyclist. He is, as I‰Ûªve mentioned, played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt. This makes him, objectively speaking, the most annoying person on earth. And ‰ÛÏThe Walk,‰Ûù before ascending into the New York sky, tries to seduce you with forced amazement and sleeve-tugging displays of whimsy. Instead of wowing you, the movie gets in your face and yells, ‰ÛÏWow!‰Ûù It‰Ûªs not quite the same feeling.

In paying tribute to that accomplishment, Mr. Zemeckis has also matched it. He has used all his brazenness and skill to make something that, once it leaves the ground, defies not only gravity, but time as well.

But we haven‰Ûªt. There is always something new under the sun. To stop believing that ‰ÛÓ to mean it when we say we‰Ûªve seen everything ‰ÛÓ would be to give up on art and surrender to cynicism. ‰ÛÏThe Walk,‰Ûù Robert Zemeckis‰Ûªs painstaking and dazzling cinematic re-creation of Mr. Petit‰Ûªs feat, stands in passionate opposition to that kind of thinking. There will always be fresh, unimagined wonders in store. And fresh horrors, too, as the sight of the twin towers can‰Ûªt help reminding us.

The impossible, as you may have read on a poster somewhere, can take awhile. ‰ÛÏThe Walk‰Ûù does not hit its stride right away. I might go a little further: The first half of the movie treads the boundary between mildly irritating and completely unbearable. Mr. Petit, an elfin Frenchman with a terrible haircut, is played by the manic-pixie song-and-dance man Joseph Gordon-Levitt as an irrepressible imp, greeting the audience in accented English from a perch on the Statue of Liberty‰Ûªs torch. The Manhattan skyline ‰ÛÓ digitally rendered to include the towers and to omit more recent construction ‰ÛÓ stretches out in the background, and the lady in the harbor stoically tolerates the presence of her voluble compatriot.

But all of the bustling 3-D IMAX mugging and pratfalling is really just the warm-up act, as is the mildly diverting tale of the period in Philippe‰Ûªs life leading up to what he calls ‰ÛÏthe coup.‰Ûù Glimpsing a pretty busker on a Paris street (she‰Ûªs singing a Leonard Cohen song in French), he steals her audience and then, bien sÌÈr, her heart. Her name is Annie, she‰Ûªs played by Charlotte Le Bon, and she becomes the first of Philippe‰Ûªs accomplices. Joining them are a photographer named Jean-Louis (ClÌ©ment Sibony) and a math whiz named Jean-FranÌ_ois (CÌ©sar Domboy), who is afraid of heights. Philippe‰Ûªs mentor is an irascible Czech funambulist played, as an irascible Czech funambulist in a movie of this kind must be played, by Ben Kingsley.
‰ÛÏThe Walk‰Ûù is rated PG (Some material may not be suitable for children). It condones trespassing, disregard for authority and neglect of personal safety. Your kids will love it.

Innocence has often been a theme of Mr. Zemeckis‰Ûªs films ‰ÛÓ not so much its loss or recovery, as its stubborn persistence. ‰ÛÏForrest Gump,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏCast Away‰Ûù and the ‰ÛÏBack to the Future‰Ûù movies are stories of optimists battling the cruelty of history and the indifference of the universe. They are also, each in its own way, testaments to the ingenuity of their maker. Though he may see himself as more of a tinkerer than a visionary, Mr. Zemeckis frequently uses the novelty of special effects in the service of an aesthetic idea that is also a moral ideal. Like Mr. Petit, he‰Ûªs interested in tackling the impossible, which is to say in discovering new possibilities for delight and awe and celebrating the transformative power of human creativity.

The trials ended a period of relative calm during the reconstruction of a divided Germany, when the prevailing attitude toward the Nazi past was a state of willful amnesia. Ordinary Germans who had joined the Nazi Party and committed atrocities returned to civilian life. A statute of limitations prevented prosecutions for war crimes, excepting murder.

The directorial feature debut of Giulio Ricciarelli, ‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies‰Ûù has the dogged tone of an honorable, well-made television movie from the late 1950s or early ‰Ûª60s. Its most admirable trait is a refusal to sensationalize its subject. There are no flashbacks to grisly acts of torture and killing, no scenes of skeletal inmates huddled behind barbed wire.

‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies‰Ûù shoehorns in a love story between Radmann and Marlene (Friederike Becht), a gifted young dressmaker. This is freighted with symbolism; Marlene‰Ûªs business flourishes when the wives of former Nazis become her principal clientele.

It is difficult to believe that in the 1950s so many Germans born after 1930, like Radmann, knew little if anything about Auschwitz, even though many older family members belonged to the Nazi Party and some even worked at the camp. Those confronted with committing atrocities in the past smugly trot out the familiar defense that they had no choice and were just following orders.

Studying the voluminous files stored at the United States Army Document Center, Radmann finds his worst fears substantiated. He is encouraged in his investigations by Fritz Bauer, a real-life prosecutor wonderfully played by Gert Voss, who died in 2014 and to whom the film is dedicated. Bauer wears an expression of wide-eyed, infinitely sad knowledge of evil.

But ‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt belabor such moral subtleties or try to make a grand statement about good Germans versus bad. It is content to be a chilly, disquieting study of a society in a state of denial until the truth is bared.
‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes a sex scene.

As Radmann pursues his research, evidence of what might be called a national conspiracy of silence accumulates. There comes a point when he is sidetracked by his obsession with capturing the notorious Nazi doctor Josef Mengele  and bringing him to justice. In one of the creepiest scenes, Radmann learns that Mengele, who fled to South America, has secretly returned to Germany under a pseudonym for the funeral of a family member in GÌ_nzburg. The prosecutor crashes a family banquet; Mengele, as we now know, was never apprehended, and the film portrays the guests at that dinner as tacit conspirators in helping him evade capture.

The earnest post-Holocaust drama ‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies‰Ûù can be viewed as a sequel of sorts to ‰ÛÏJudgment at Nuremberg,‰Ûù the much-decorated 1961 Stanley Kramer film about the Nuremberg trials of the 1940s, in which top-ranking Nazis were tried for crimes against humanity. The trials are still imprinted in many people‰Ûªs minds as the ultimate moment of reckoning, after which a horrific chapter of history was more or less closed and the world moved on. Of course, it wasn‰Ûªt as simple as that.

Once the trials begin in 1963, witnesses are shown testifying, but their verbal accounts of what they endured are excerpted and made into a montage, their words camouflaged by Niki Reiser and Sebastian Pille‰Ûªs soundtrack, which, although mournful, is never mawkish. There are no emotional meltdowns, no grandiose speeches.

‰ÛÏLabyrinth of Lies,‰Ûù which opens in 1958, resurrects a later chapter in the aftermath of the Holocaust that has largely faded from view, at least for many Americans: the Frankfurt Auschwitz trials of the 1960s, in which 22 former mid- and lower-level functionaries at the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp were tried for murder.

The central character, Johann Radmann (Alexander Fehling), a fictitious composite of three lawyers, is an idealistic new employee in the public prosecutor‰Ûªs office in Frankfurt, frustrated by his banal work in a traffic court. Through Thomas Gnielka (AndrÌ© Szymanski), a journalistic acquaintance, he learns of Simon Kirsch (Johannes Krisch), an Auschwitz survivor who has accidentally crossed paths with one of his wartime persecutors, who is now a schoolteacher. Radmann has never heard of Auschwitz, which the screenplay (by Mr. Ricciarelli and Elisabeth Bartel) pointedly reminds us, was not in Germany but in Poland.

When he sets out to prosecute the teacher, Radmann faces stern resistance. Voicing his frustration that thousands of former Nazis went unpunished and simply returned to ordinary life after the war, he encounters stony-faced indifference and hostility, although the only outright threat is a rock imprinted with a swastika thrown through a window.
The film, directed by Jamie Babbit, features a few high-profile stars in small roles, among them Aubrey Plaza, Fred Armisen, Molly Shannon and Jessica St. Clair.
You can get away with this sort of thing if your humor is sharp, but here it‰Ûªs mostly sophomoric and rarely surprising.
‰ÛÏAddicted to Fresno‰Ûù is one of those comedies that seem not to care whether you laugh. Parts of it seem openly hostile to the idea.

Ms. St. Clair is currently half of a female-buddy TV series called ‰ÛÏPlaying House,‰Ûù where she and Lennon Parham find a symbiosis that works. Ms. Greer and Ms. Lyonne never quite seem that comfortable, and the dour script by Karey Dornetto doesn‰Ûªt give them many opportunities to be anything but off-putting.

Soon, however, they have a body to dispose of, one of Shannon‰Ûªs sexual relapses having ended badly. The rest of the movie documents their efforts to deal with this problem, which, among other things, leads them to try their hand at robbery.

Shannon (Judy Greer) and Martha (Natasha Lyonne) are mismatched sisters whose relationship is defined largely by Shannon‰Ûªs bad behavior. She is a sex addict whose licentious ways have gotten her into trouble, not to mention rehab, and as the story opens, she and Martha are working as hotel maids, with Martha trying to keep Shannon on, or at least near, the straight and narrow.

The 1974 Canadian-produced ‰ÛÏBlack Christmas‰Ûù offended pious sensibilities with a serial-murder-on-a-silent-night theme; in 1977, the Ontario-born director David Cronenberg took dry glee in the accidental machine gunning of a shopping mall Santa in his ‰ÛÏRabid.‰Ûù Canada‰Ûªs scary-movie war on Christmas is taken up once more in ‰ÛÏA Christmas Horror Story,‰Ûù a quasi omnibus of horror scenarios requiring no fewer than three directors (Grant Harvey, Steven Hoban and Brett Sullivan) to deck its halls. Unsparingly gory and on occasion actually shock-inducing, it can‰Ûªt help falling prey to Genre Overreach syndrome, in which horror fans turned horror creators maniacally pile up their favorite terrorizing tropes, as if they‰Ûªd never get the chance again.

William Shatner‰Ûªs virtually phoned-in turn as a Christmas Eve D.J. ties the proceedings together, or as together as they can get, and his character provides the requisite nod to a John Carpenter film (in this case, ‰ÛÏThe Fog‰Ûù). A story line involving a ‰ÛÏchangeling‰Ûù never rises above the promising. Another that culminates in a nice teenage girl‰Ûªs turning all sex-crazed is too tiresome to be redeemed by its ultimate gruesomeness.

And the most initially risible of the stories, involving an anti-Santa called Krampus and featuring deathless dialogue, like ‰ÛÏElves becoming the walking dead? No, it does not make sense,‰Ûù winds up having the most effectively diabolical payoff of the bunch. Nevertheless ‰ÛÓ or perhaps the proper word here is ‰ÛÏtherefore‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the picture can be wholly recommended only to not-too-demanding horror junkies who‰Ûªve been successfully nurturing their inner adolescents since the late 1970s.

Ms. Timoner, who showed some skepticism about the machinery of celebrity in her earlier documentary ‰ÛÏDig,‰Ûù treats Mr. Brand with a courtier‰Ûªs credulity. The film traces his biography, from his beginnings as the child of a kind mother and a mostly absent father (both of them interviewed on screen) through his early success as a comedian, his drug addiction and his conquest of MTV and Hollywood. He appeared in ‰ÛÏForgetting Sarah Marshall,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGet Him to the Greek‰Ûù and the remake of ‰ÛÏArthur,‰Ûù had sex with Ms. Perry and a lot of other people, and was then radicalized by Occupy Wall Street and a visit to Africa.

He is much less adept at defending his own ideas, or even expressing them with much clarity or cogency. He wants revolution, a total change in consciousness, a new system based on peace, truth and freedom to replace the current one. ‰ÛÏI may be a narcissist,‰Ûù he says to a crowd of supporters at a London demonstration. ‰ÛÏBut I‰Ûªm your narcissist.‰Ûù The film includes lengthy excerpts from his ‰ÛÏMessiah Complex‰Ûù one-man show, in which he appeared on a stage alongside large pictures of Gandhi, Jesus, Malcolm X and Che Guevara.

So do I, and I don‰Ûªt want this review to be taken as yet another a snide dismissal of a celebrity‰Ûªs sincere engagement with serious causes. Fame can be put to constructive use, and Mr. Brand is clearly determined to do some good in the world. He comes off best in Ms. Timoner‰Ûªs movie when confronting people on television who question his credentials as an advocate for change. Shaggy-haired, casually dressed and comfortable in his skin, Mr. Brand does a fine job of showing up the inane pomposity of the BBC News and the aggressive inanity of American cable television.

Does he think really think he belongs in their company? There‰Ûªs a lot of evidence that he does. Much as he likes to make fun of his own inflated ego, he declares himself also willing to answer the call of history and become the leader of a mass movement. His idea of what such leadership entails is a little fuzzy, as he seems to think that political influence and fame are identical, or that they should be.

‰ÛÏBrand: A Second Coming‰Ûù wants to tell the story of a man overcoming temptation and trading a shallow approach to life for something more sustaining and profound. It‰Ûªs undone by its own shallowness, and by the limited appeal of its subject. Mr. Brand is occasionally quite funny, but the brief clips Ms. Timoner includes of George Carlin, Lenny Bruce and Richard Pryor are if anything more presumptuous than the images of Jesus and Gandhi. Mr. Brand‰Ûªs work in comedy hardly approaches theirs in terms of honesty, rigor or impact. And nearly two hours in his company is at least an hour too much.
‰ÛÏBrand: A Second Coming‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Raunchy language.

There are a lot of famous people ‰ÛÓ pop stars, movie stars, artists, athletes ‰ÛÓ who use their celebrity to bring attention to issues that concern them. ‰ÛÏBrand: A Second Coming,‰Ûù Ondi Timoner‰Ûªs exhausting new documentary, does the opposite. It uses a handful of urgent global problems ‰ÛÓ climate change, poverty, corporate power, political corruption ‰ÛÓ to call attention to Russell Brand. You will learn very little about those matters other than that Mr. Brand, an English comedian and actor who was once married to Katy Perry, cares a lot about them.
‰ÛÏHe Named Me Malala‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Disturbing themes and images.

It‰Ûªs the father-daughter thread that comes closest to being provocative. Did her father, Ziauddin Yousafzai, an educator who had spoken out against the Taliban‰Ûªs repressiveness, push Malala into activism to further his own views, just as a parent might pressure a child to excel at a sport when all the kid really wants to do is be a kid? The question is asked, and Ms. Yousafzai asserts that her choices were her own, but so much in this movie sounds as if it‰Ûªs well rehearsed that you‰Ûªre not really sure what to take at face value.

You‰Ûªll still be wondering after watching ‰ÛÏHe Named Me Malala,‰Ûù a documentary about her by Davis Guggenheim (‰ÛÏAn Inconvenient Truth‰Ûù). The film is primarily interested in spreading her message and seems pitched to a young audience. Nothing wrong with that. But it only occasionally delivers the kind of unguarded moment that makes you feel as if you‰Ûªre getting beneath the media image, and it is not at all interested in discussing broader issues raised by Ms. Yousafzai‰Ûªs fame.

Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani teenager who was shot by the Taliban in 2012 but has continued to speak out on behalf of education for girls, is a familiar face in the West by now thanks to a best-selling book, television appearances, speaking engagements and, of course, the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize (which she shared with Kailash Satyarthi). But you may wonder about the real person behind the media phenomenon.

Beyond that, the film doesn‰Ûªt particularly examine the price of Western superstardom. Ms. Yousafzai, now 18, doesn‰Ûªt say much about demands and intrusions on her personal life that must rival those experienced by young rock stars. And just how her fame is affecting things back home in the Swat Valley of Pakistan, if at all, remains unexplored, as does the uneasy question of how much heritage you have to give up to become a Western media darling.

The film is at its best when it shows Ms. Yousafzai in her adopted home in England interacting with her brothers, who steal the show every time they‰Ûªre on camera. They seem largely indifferent to her fame and make wiseacre remarks about her just the way any brothers would. But the film doesn‰Ûªt linger on these vignettes long because it is also trying to chart her path to the Nobel, tell the story of her early advocacy and the assassination attempt, and explore the influence of her father on her.

Mr. Howden‰Ûªs gorefest, set and filmed in New Zealand, has way too much projectile vomiting of blood for genteel tastes, a series of close-up beheadings and one too many scenes (i.e., one) of a slain human‰Ûªs internal organs tumbling onto the floor.
As the human villain‰Ûªs girlfriend kills him by stabbing him in the mouth, she observes, ‰ÛÏNow who doesn‰Ûªt have a gag reflex?‰Ûù

Ms. Crossman is appealing, too, as Medina, who shows up with a big ax at the appropriate times and inexplicably knows how to use it. In between the rampant four-letter words and the occasional partial nudity are likable attempts at humor ‰ÛÓ some sweet, some saucy.

Few things are scarier than born-again Christians turned into demons by heavy-metal music and attacked with their own giant sex toys. ‰ÛÏDeathgasm,‰Ûù written and directed by Jason Lei Howden, offers that scene about halfway through, when pretty much everybody in the Christians‰Ûª town is in the same shape because members of a newly formed teenage band didn‰Ûªt notice that the ancient sheet music they found was decorated with satanic symbols.

But the film has its charms. It‰Ûªs easy to empathize with the handsome young protagonist, Brodie (Milo Cawthorne), the new metalhead in town, who is beaten up by bullies, yearns for the prettiest girl in school (Kimberley Crossman) and explains his taste in music with, ‰ÛÏLife is better because somebody else knows the pain and the rage that you‰Ûªre going through.‰Ûù

The fictional ‰ÛÏFreeheld‰Ûù botches this story from casting to script and direction. Ms. Moore never fits comfortably into her role or alongside Ms. Page, displaying better, more persuasive chemistry with Michael Shannon, who plays Dane Wells, Laurel‰Ûªs heart-of-mush work partner. The equally miscast Ms. Page looks ill at ease wherever she‰Ûªs plunked, never more so than in an unconvincing garage scene that‰Ûªs dedicated to proving Stacie‰Ûªs mettle and muscles. It‰Ûªs a bummer to see Ms. Page and especially Ms. Moore ‰ÛÓ who at this point in her career can usually act her way out of any clichÌ© ‰ÛÓ so badly stranded by a generic script, credited to Ron Nyswaner, and by a director, Peter Sollett, who can‰Ûªt figure out how to lift his actors and the material above the bad writing.

The lives behind this movie deserve better. In 2004, not long after the real Ms. Hester learned she had advanced lung cancer, she tried to bestow her benefits on Ms. Andree ‰ÛÓ the women were registered domestic partners ‰ÛÓ a request denied by the county‰Ûªs governing body, the Board of Freeholders. When one of these freeholders told The Asbury Park Press that granting the pension to Ms. Andree would violate ‰ÛÏthe sanctity of marriage,‰Ûù this local story vaulted into the national news and onto the front lines of the fight for gay rights, including marriage equality. As Ms. Hester says in Cynthia Wade‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFreeheld,‰Ûù the 2007 short documentary on which the feature is based: ‰ÛÏWere it not for the fact that we‰Ûªre not a heterosexual couple,‰Ûù Ms. Andree would receive the pension like any other spouse.

Mr. Sollett directed ‰ÛÏRaising Victor Vargas‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏNick and Norah‰Ûªs Infinite Playlist,‰Ûù which, unlike ‰ÛÏFreeheld,‰Ûù were at least visually proficient. There‰Ûªs little of visual interest here in a story of love, death and political righteousness that‰Ûªs occasionally interrupted by some risibly staged action scenes and enlivened only by Mr. Carell‰Ûªs exuberance.

It‰Ûªs worth noting that Mr. Nyswaner wrote ‰ÛÏPhiladelphia,‰Ûù the 1993 Jonathan Demme film in which Tom Hanks plays a lawyer with AIDS fighting discrimination. ‰ÛÏPhiladelphia‰Ûù is imperfect and didactic, but it has some transporting moments and the kind of real filmmaking that finally transforms the Hanks character from a cause into a person. No such metamorphosis happens in ‰ÛÏFreeheld,‰Ûù which never puts a human face on its message.
‰ÛÏFreeheld‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). There‰Ûªs some adult language and gunplay.

‰ÛÏFreeheld,‰Ûù a television movie of the week gone uninterestingly wrong, stars Julianne Moore as a real New Jersey detective turned gay rights activist. Slinging a Farah Fawcett-esque shag and an accent as thick (and sloppy) as a triple-decker sandwich, Ms. Moore plays Laurel Hester, an Ocean County detective who becomes headline news after she can‰Ûªt secure her pension benefits for her lover, a mechanic, Stacie Andree (Ellen Page). In better hands this might have made a heart-rending, personal story, but ‰ÛÏFreeheld‰Ûù is as generic as the bullet points in a gay rights brochure, even when Steve Carell roars in as an activist, leading with his lungs and a purple yarmulke.

It is never a good sign when a movie produced and distributed throughout much of Asia in 2010 doesn‰Ûªt make its American theatrical debut until five years later. And given the temperamental and editorial idiosyncrasies of the Weinstein Company, which executive-produced and controls distribution of ‰ÛÏShanghai,‰Ûù a period espionage thriller directed by Mikael Hafstrom, you might be forgiven for expecting either an unfairly squelched masterpiece or an unholy mess.

The movie is neither, although it falls closer to the mess side of the table. Its convoluted plot seems to promise an early death by exposition in the first 20 minutes, although the fact that the story begins in October 1941, and that John Cusack plays a naval intelligence operative ought to clue most viewers in on where it‰Ûªs going. A shot of Mr. Cusack playing cards in white tux and black tie means to evoke ‰ÛÏCasablanca,‰Ûù while the titular city‰Ûªs who‰Ûªs-in-charge-here division of authority has a strong ‰ÛÏThe Third Man‰Ûù redolence.

‰ÛÏShanghai‰Ûù never grazes those heights, but the spectacular international cast, including the Asian film legends Chow Yun-Fat and Gong Li (as beautiful and charismatic here as she was in her screen debut almost 30 years ago ‰ÛÓ O.K., 25 years ago, given the current film‰Ûªs actual production date), bring a lot of life to the movie‰Ûªs uncooperative story material, as do Ken Watanabe, Franka Potente, and Mr. Cusack himself, despite his applying some too contemporary stresses to his good-man-in-a-bind character. The movie‰Ûªs violence is loud and lurid, possibly needfully by the director‰Ûªs standards, but gratuitously by this reviewer‰Ûªs lights.
‰ÛÏShanghai‰Ûù is rated R for strong violence, some drug use and brief (too contemporary) language.

This kind of ambiguity is part of the fun: ‰ÛÏTaxi‰Ûù is full of wry jokes, surprising incidents and allusions to Mr. Panahi‰Ûªs earlier work. He is a pretty bad taxi driver, unsure of the routes to well-known Tehran landmarks and less than diligent about collecting fares and delivering customers to their destinations. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll let you out here and you can get another cab,‰Ûù he says more than once. This creates a lot of turnover, and a series of ‰ÛÏchance‰Ûù encounters with fellow citizens, including a dealer in pirated DVDs (Mr. Panahi used to be one of his customers) and two older women carrying goldfish in an open glass bowl.

The first, shot largely on a mobile-phone camera when Mr. Panahi was under intense legal pressure from the government in 2011, was ‰ÛÏThis Is Not a Film,‰Ûù a meditation on cinema and freedom as nuanced as its title is blunt. It was followed by ‰ÛÏClosed Curtain‰Ûù (2014), a through-the-looking-glass hybrid of documentary and melodrama that explores the porous boundary between cinema and reality.
‰ÛÏTaxi‰Ûù is not rated.

A camera, too, of course. Which hardly counts as special equipment these days. In ‰ÛÏTaxi,‰Ûù everybody has one, and the conceit of the movie is that its auteur is a humble cabdriver with a camera mounted on the dashboard of his car. He‰Ûªs not really trying to fool anyone. Mr. Panahi is well known enough to be recognized by some of his passengers, most of whom may not really be passengers at all, but people he has cajoled into playing versions of themselves. A lot of what we see seems contrived. But then again, a lot of it seems spontaneous. It‰Ûªs almost impossible to tell the difference until the brilliant final shot. But can you even call it a ‰ÛÏshot‰Ûù when the camera has been left running by accident?

‰ÛÏTaxi,‰Ûù though, happens to be the work of a great one, one of the most humane and imaginative practitioners of the art currently working. ‰ÛÏThe Circle‰Ûù was an unsparing look at the condition of women under the thumb of traditional patriarchy and religious dictatorship. ‰ÛÏCrimson Gold‰Ûù cast a harsh light on Iran‰Ûªs economic inequalities and on its neglect of its military veterans. These films are powerful pieces of social criticism, but it is their combination of structural elegance with tough naturalism that places them among the essential movies of our time.

Those women may remind Mr. Panahi‰Ûªs fans of ‰ÛÏThe White Balloon,‰Ûù his first feature, which also involved a goldfish. ‰ÛÏTaxi‰Ûù abounds with similar reminders: anecdotes that recall episodes in ‰ÛÏThe Circle‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏOffside‰Ûù; a glimpse of a man delivering pizza brings to mind ‰ÛÏCrimson Gold‰Ûù; Hana‰Ûªs wait for her uncle to pick her up at school is an echo of ‰ÛÏThe Mirror.‰Ûù This may sound like artistic vanity, but it‰Ûªs actually a kind of humility. Mr. Panahi pulled those stories from the life that surrounded him, and that life ‰ÛÓ the bustle and contention of Tehran; the cruelty and hypocrisy of Iranian society; the kindness and tenacity of ordinary people ‰ÛÓ remains an inexhaustible reservoir of narrative possibilities.

Mr. Panahi is a longstanding expert in such matters, with extensive firsthand knowledge of how Iranian authorities deal with filmmakers who displease them. In 2010, he was officially barred from pursuing his profession, and ‰ÛÏTaxi‰Ûù is the third feature he has made in defiance of ‰ÛÓ and also, cleverly, in compliance with ‰ÛÓ that prohibition.

The same can be said about ‰ÛÏTaxi,‰Ûù which offers, in its unassuming way, one of the most captivating cinematic experiences of this year. Though it is gentle and meditative rather than confrontational, the film nonetheless bristles with topical concerns. It begins with a tense back-seat argument about the death penalty and eventually turns its gaze on poverty, violence, sexism and censorship. Like Mr. Panahi‰Ûªs cab, his film is equipped with both windows and mirrors. It‰Ûªs reflective and revealing, intimate and wide-ranging, compact and moving.

And also a fertile breeding ground for cinema. Hana‰Ûªs school project is just one of several movies tucked inside of ‰ÛÏTaxi.‰Ûù An old friend of Mr. Panahi‰Ûªs shares a security video recording a crime committed against him. A man who has been in a motorbike accident, his bleeding head cradled in the lap of his anguished wife, asks Mr. Panahi to make a cellphone video of his last testament. Even the simplest, most unmediated records of human behavior are shaped, edited and manipulated. Everyone is a filmmaker.

A section of ‰ÛÏTaxi‰Ûù is devoted to an encounter between two Iranian filmmakers. One of them is Jafar Panahi, the director of this movie and one of the most internationally celebrated figures in contemporary Iranian cinema. The other is his niece Hana, a sharp-tongued tween who must make a short movie as part of a school assignment. The teacher has handed out a set of guidelines that are more or less consistent with the government‰Ûªs censorship rules.

‰ÛÏTaxi,‰Ûù which won the top prize at the Berlin Film Festival in February, takes up some of the same themes. It‰Ûªs playful and thoughtful, informed by the director‰Ûªs affable, patient, slightly worried demeanor. His kind face is almost always on screen, but he‰Ûªs not a self-conscious presence like, say, Woody Allen (whose name is dropped) or Nanni Moretti. He‰Ûªs a regular guy going about his day. What does it take to be a filmmaker? Maybe just curiosity, compassion and open eyes.

After some self-surgery to deal with the rod spearing his gut, along with some anxious stock-taking ‰ÛÓ he has plenty of tunes but not enough air, water and food to survive for long ‰ÛÓ Watney gets down to the business of living, including farming. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm not going to die here,‰Ûù he helpfully mutters, helpfully because he talks out loud a lot whether just murmuring to himself or recording a video entry in his growing space log. The log keeps the words flowing in what could have been a fairly quiet movie, creating an animated lively babble that approaches the chummy feel of a video face chat. Watney makes for affably pleasant if worrisome company, and if there isn‰Ûªt much mystery to him it‰Ûªs because the purity of his struggle doesn‰Ûªt leave him, at least, time for deep dives into questions of existence.

A space western and a blissed-out cosmic high, ‰ÛÏThe Martian‰Ûù stars Matt Damon as an American astronaut who, like a latter-day Robinson Crusoe, learns to survive on his own island of despair. At once epic and intimate, it involves a dual journey into outer and inner space, a trip that takes you into that immensity called the universe and deep into the equally vast landscape of a single consciousness. For this accidental castaway, space is the place where he‰Ûªs physically marooned, but also where his mind is set free ‰ÛÓ a dynamic that of course invokes moviegoing itself.

Although Watney is isolated at first, with no means of communicating with Earth, the parallel narrative means that he‰Ûªs never truly alone, unlike, say, Crusoe (before Friday) or Tom Hanks‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏCast Away‰Ûù (before Wilson), whose profound isolation is critical to how you experience them and their stories. Like these other marooned souls (including the 1964 ‰ÛÏRobinson Crusoe on Mars‰Ûù), Watney is physically and psychologically apart, but even before he pings Earth with his big news, you know people are mourning him. The Earth scenes interrupt these solitary interludes with other faces and voices, keeping the narrative jumping, but they also assert that no matter how lost and seemingly forgotten, no one is alone because to be human fundamentally is to exist with other people. We are social, therefore we are.

Gradually, the two stories become one as Watney and everyone else gets to work. At NASA, various brainiacs take hammers and tongs to physics at both the Johnson Space Center and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where supernerds take on the logistics of a rescue mission. The movie gently thumps several issues: It‰Ûªs unambiguously on the side of science and rationalism with glints of manifest destiny, American can-do-ism and a little flag-waving folded in. It is also about willing yourself out of the lonely room ‰ÛÓ call it Mars or your head ‰ÛÓ and into the world, however inhospitable, so you can breathe the air and drink the water (Watney learns to make both) and yearn for others. It‰Ûªs a moving testament from the 77-year-old Mr. Scott, whose art comes in all shades of dark.

Perhaps that‰Ûªs one reason Ridley Scott keeps returning to deep space. This is the third of his films ‰ÛÓ after ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù in 1979 and ‰ÛÏPrometheus‰Ûù in 2012 ‰ÛÓ set beyond the dark side of the moon. Hands down it‰Ûªs also the funniest, loosest and most optimistic of the group, at once an ode to far-out adventuring and to terra-firma home, a sweeping, old-fashioned entertainment and a plaintive portrait of solitude as both a creative necessity and a danger. It also serves as a nice plug for NASA, which has returned the favor by pushing the movie on its website. (On Monday, scientists announced that signs of liquid water could be seen in photographs taken on Mars by a camera on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, timing that suggests NASA certainly has the whole cross-promotion thing down.)

Here, by contrast, he seems almost giddily attuned to the buzz of human endeavor. The NASA scenes with their friendly, familiar faces ‰ÛÓ Chiwetel Ejiofor, Kristen Wiig and Jeff Daniels ‰ÛÓ unfold with charming predictability with corrugated brows, hushed and raised voices, acres of glowing screens and warehouses of space stuff. The vibe is of serious, smart people doing serious, smart work for the good of the rest of us. Mr. Ejiofor‰Ûªs enormous, pleading eyes signal how grave the situation is, while Ms. Wiig‰Ûªs prickly warmth and Mr. Daniels‰Ûªs Daffy Duck mouth-flapping keep the whole thing from getting too heavy. Mr. Scott is a brilliant assembler of casts, and he knows how to organize groups so they seem to naturally fit, and can bob and weave in unison with his roving cameras.

Based on the novel ‰ÛÏThe Martian‰Ûù by Andy Weir that Drew Goddard has turned into a fast-moving, streamlined script, the movie focuses on Mark Watney (Mr. Damon), who, during a windstorm on Mars, is accidentally left behind by his team. Mr. Scott likes the action to hit hard and fast: One minute Watney is joking with his space buddies ‰ÛÓ Jessica Chastain leads a crew that includes Kate Mara and Michael PeÌ±a ‰ÛÓ and minutes later he‰Ûªs been hooked like a fish by some flying metal that knocks him out. Believing him dead, the crew takes off, as does the movie, which soon becomes a tale of two planets with initially competing narratives, one involving Watney‰Ûªs efforts simply to stay alive and the second centered on NASA‰Ûªs postdisaster strategizing.

Unlike some advertising directors who transitioned to filmmaking, he has always been a good director of actors, though it‰Ûªs instructive that he uses performers who are either forceful enough screen presences or strikingly beautiful enough (usually both) to stand up to his lush visual style, who can meet the challenge of his meaningfully complex sets and natural vistas. When the film works, the bold drama of his visuals and the dramatic boldness of his stories flow together, becoming all of a narrative piece. Some of these pieces resonate with other meanings, like the red-rock buttes in ‰ÛÏThelma & Louise‰Ûù and the similarly rust-colored formations in ‰ÛÏThe Martian‰Ûù that are suggestive of John Ford‰Ûªs Monument Valley films. Sometimes here, Mr. Scott seems to be returning to his own work, which may be why you can see Susan Sarandon (Louise), with her protuberant gaze and thin-skinned tremulousness, in Mr. Ejiofor. And of course Mr. Scott loves tough women, so it‰Ûªs no surprise that Ms. Chastain and Ms. Mara are on board.

‰ÛÏThe Martian‰Ûù has sweep but not the vanity that creeps into many large productions, turning them into bloated vehicles for directorial self-aggrandizement. Mr. Damon‰Ûªs Everyman quality (he‰Ûªs our Jimmy Stewart) helps scale the story down, but what makes this epic personal is Mr. Scott‰Ûªs filmmaking, in which every soaring aerial shot of the red planet is answered by the intimate landscape of a face. There‰Ûªs a touch of Cecil B. DeMille in his cinematic DNA (for better and occasionally for worse), though, like many who saw ‰ÛÏ2001: A Space Odyssey‰Ûù during their esthetically formative years, there‰Ûªs even more Stanley Kubrick. But Mr. Scott is very much his own artist, one whose reputation as a visual stylist has at times obscured that his great, persistent theme is what it means to be human.
‰ÛÏThe Martian‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Life, death and science.

Funny and feisty, gritty and sometimes grim, this first feature from the photographer Elaine Constantine delivers a sweaty snapshot of a very specific time and place. Surrounded by industrial drabness, the dance halls of Lancashire pulse with light and movement. Squeaky-clean pop is fading, and disco is waiting in the wings, but for these kids, it‰Ûªs Edwin Starr and Frankie Valli who offer escape from sausage factory futures and nagging parents.

Two dreamers take center stage. John (Elliot James Langridge), a high school misfit and all-around mope, is dazzled and flattered when Matt (Joshua Whitehouse), a skinny show-off and virtual orphan, befriends him at the youth club. Introduced to flared trousers and flashy dance moves ‰ÛÓ with a side order of aggro and amphetamines ‰ÛÓ John is soon a willing member of the cult of rare recordings.
‰ÛÏNorthern Soul‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bad words and good drugs.

Performed with loose energy and studded with beautifully observant moments ‰ÛÓ like the worn spot on the hideous bedroom carpet where John practices his spins ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏNorthern Soul‰Ûù suffers most from a lack of dramatic focus and a tendency to elbow women out of the frame. There‰Ûªs tragedy, and there is disillusion, but Ms. Constantine‰Ûªs writing is no match for her empathy and ability to conjure atmosphere. That said, the songs are smashing and the stomping joy infectious, smoothly summoning the way music can inject hope into the bleakest of lives.

A celebration of spinning vinyl and twirling teenagers, ‰ÛÏNorthern Soul‰Ûù captures a brief, blazing moment in 1970s England when the passionate lyrics and addictive beats of American soul ignited dance floors and working-class dreams.
At last, in confronting Gregori, Alexander becomes a partisan of sorts, while we are left to marvel: Is this all really merely a commercial enterprise?
Otherwise, the action-packed scenes are heavy-handed, like sequences depicting aggressive acts involving semi-free-range chickens, living and roasted.

Usually, partisans stand for something, but in this movie, which is stripped of a specific time frame and relevant geopolitical context, the term becomes hollow. The screenwriters, Ariel Kleiman (who is also the director) and Sarah Cyngler, have cut their story loose from any real significance, leaving us with Gregori, who has no discernible political views and no unifying beliefs, even delusional ones. Without this foundation for the character, the actor doesn‰Ûªt stand a chance. As a cult leader, he is full of grand gestures but as aimless as a tiny plastic man in a terrarium.

‰ÛÏPartisan,‰Ûù in title at least, carries a whiff of the wild history of the Balkans. There is a postwar air to the opening scenes of Gregori (Vincent Cassel) salvaging pieces of broken furniture. He already has mattresses. Lots of mattresses. And eventually a compound with a harem of weirdly trusting women devoted to being baby machines despite Gregori‰Ûªs lack of personal magnetism.

Eventually, he sends the children on assignment as assassins. The teenage Alexander (Jeremy Chabriel) goes on the job equipped with baby blue cotton balls as ear plugs. As adolescent boys should, he begins to question his elders. What have his targets done ‰ÛÓ the shopkeepers and mechanics he is sent to kill? Why should they die?

In a wavering accent that is sometimes Borat, sometimes generic American game-show host and sometimes Christopher Walken (as himself and as ‰ÛÏS.N.L.‰Ûù ‰Ûªs Continental), Gregori lectures his growing brood, educates them and teaches them to shoot, using balloons as targets. He is training them to defend against ‰ÛÏthe outsiders,‰Ûù he says, but never specifies what they have to fear.

Sherpas (though that name is synonymous with mountain guides, it denotes their ethnic group) have long been viewed as smiling servants. Yet, in recent years, they‰Ûªve become more educated and aware of the meager rewards they receive for taking immense risks.

A visiting climber navigates the notoriously treacherous Khumbu Icefall twice. A Sherpa, carrying huge amounts of equipment and food for such clients, may walk it 30 times a season, often in the dark. Add to that the arrogance of some wealthy visitors who expect more and more luxuries at base camp, including flat-screen TVs, and resentment is inevitable.

What is the moral justification ‰ÛÏfor you to play what is essentially a game of Russian roulette‰Ûù with someone‰Ûªs life? It‰Ûªs a brutal question posed by a journalist against the breathtaking backdrop of Mount Everest. It‰Ûªs also one that nags at you throughout ‰ÛÏSherpa,‰Ûù an exceptionally absorbing documentary.

Jennifer Peedom, the director, and her team went to Nepal in 2014 to document the climbing season and observe the Sherpa leader Phurba Tashi, who was to hike to the summit of Mount Everest for a record 22nd time. While they were on the mountain, a gigantic ice block crashed onto one of the routes, killing 16 Sherpas.

Several days later, foreign climbers (who pay upward of $100,000 each) wanted to continue their trek. Many Sherpas demanded that the season be canceled to honor the dead. That dispute lies at the heart of the film.

The beautiful views of Nepal, juxtaposed with the occasionally ugly tensions between the groups, make ‰ÛÏSherpa‰Ûù complex and sometimes as suspenseful as an action film. Still, despite the disagreements, we‰Ûªre told that everyone agrees on one thing: To do this type of dangerous work, they all must go on pretending that it‰Ûªs safe.

The cause is simple: a lack of medical care. In the West, if there were problems delivering a baby, ‰ÛÏyou‰Ûªd just automatically have a C-section,‰Ûù says one of the talking heads. (Others include Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian activist playwright and Nobel laureate, and the philanthropist Melinda Gates.) But there is often no one to perform a cesarean, and fistula is a common consequence.
