Played with a relentless abandon by Rachel McKeon, the rowdy Irene heads north to discover that it‰Ûªs an abandoned rowhouse in a rundown neighborhood. She plans to fix it up with Cam (Jack Culbertson) and flip it for a quick profit, but over the course of weeks, and then months, finds that while wrecking the house‰Ûªs interior is a drunken delight, rehabilitating it is vastly more rewarding. It‰Ûªs becoming something the rootless Irene never felt she had: a place of her own.

Milgram conducted his first obedience experiments in 1961 at Yale, where he was an assistant professor. ‰ÛÏI set up a simple experiment,‰Ûù he explained, ‰ÛÏto test how much pain an ordinary citizen would inflict on another person simply because he was ordered to by an experimental scientist.‰Ûù Individual test subjects ‰ÛÓ the ordinary citizens ‰ÛÓ were ushered into a room where a facilitator (called the experimenter) said the participant (called the teacher) would be administering electrical shocks to another participant (a middle-aged man called the learner) when the learner made a mistake. The teacher was to deliver the shocks via a bland apparatus that looked right out of a first-generation ‰ÛÏStar Trek‰Ûù episode and ostensibly zapped out 15 to 450 volts.

It was all a sham: The learner was a confederate of the experiment, the teacher was the actual subject, and Milgram, of course, was the great experimenter, who, film director-like, watched his little fictions unfold from behind a two-way mirror. The movie opens just as one test is about to begin, with Milgram busily scribbling notes while talking aloud about his intentions. An assistant is parked next to him, but Milgram ‰ÛÓ as he often does ‰ÛÓ is addressing us. Inside the lab, a newly arrived, nervous teacher (the cannily cast Anthony Edwards) is settling in, meeting the blustery jolly learner (Jim Gaffigan) under the supervision of an experimenter (John Palladino) who‰Ûªs wearing a lab coat, a funeral director‰Ûªs poker face and a head of brilliantine hair.

What did Milgram learn from his experiment? What did history? Mr. Almereyda circles around these questions slyly, poking at them (testing them) amid an occasional soliloquy and assorted biographical snippets, some featuring an excellent, wild-eyed Winona Ryder, who plays Sasha, Milgram‰Ûªs wife. As he mixes austerely dressed sets with overtly artificial tableaus, Mr. Almereyda seems to be suggesting that Milgram, in his quest for truth, ended up living in a world that hovered between the real one and one of his own imagination. At one point, Mr. Almereyda, with delectable wit, introduces an elephant, which, as it lumbers behind Milgram, raises the question that haunts every room in this movie: Did his experiments finally turn Milgram into a kind of accomplice?

In ‰ÛÏExperimenter,‰Ûù an aesthetically and intellectually playful portrait of the social psychologist Stanley Milgram, the director, Michael Almereyda, turns a biopic into a mind game. It‰Ûªs an appropriate take on a figure who‰Ûªs best remembered for his experiments in which subjects delivered punishing electric shocks on command. Working in the shadow of the Holocaust, and shortly after the capture of the SS official Adolf Eichmann, Milgram (1933-1984) was interested in questions of authority, conformity and conscience. ‰ÛÏCould it be that Eichmann and his million accomplices in the Holocaust were just following orders,‰Ûù Milgram asked. ‰ÛÏCould we call them all accomplices?‰Ûù
‰ÛÏExperimenter‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). I cannot imagine why.

Mr. Almereyda takes Milgram, his work and ideas seriously but doesn‰Ûªt suffocate them: Despite the story‰Ûªs freight, the laboratory shocks and Milgram‰Ûªs insistent melancholia, ‰ÛÏExperimenter‰Ûù is a nimble, low-frequency high. Mr. Almereyda‰Ûªs self-conscious approach to the material hovers between the quasi-Brechtian and the gently absurd (as a director, his eyebrows are raised, not jumping), which keeps the story and characters grooving right along and ensures that while the past informs the story, it never torpedoes it. Milgram turns out to be somewhat of a downer, understandably so given his interests and the later harsh, career-damaging criticisms of his most famous work. His is very much a voice of the 20th century, but as he chronicles the age with Eeyore-like mournfulness he can also feel like one of history‰Ûªs comedic straight men.

The restlessly original Mr. Almereyda comes at this question inventively, sometimes with Milgram ‰ÛÓ a delicate, sensitive Peter Sarsgaard ‰ÛÓ talking right into the camera. Mr. Almereyda has a boundless gift for finding new ways to tell old stories, and ‰ÛÏExperimenter,‰Ûù as befits its title, is less a straight biography than a diverting gloss on human behavior, historical memory and cinema itself. It‰Ûªs a story about a man whose work was haunted by the death camps, was conducted as the United States escalated its presence in Vietnam and was destined to speak to the ages (to the abuses at Abu Ghraib and beyond) because his subject ‰ÛÓ the all too human being ‰ÛÓ is reliably barbaric. (Mr. Almereyda‰Ûªs films include the vampire tale ‰ÛÏNadja‰Ûù and several Shakespeare adaptations, including a superb ‰ÛÏHamlet‰Ûù with Ethan Hawke.)

Of all the filmmakers associated with the French New Wave, Ms. Varda wears the liberties demanded by that alliance most lightly; she never seems to be showing off. Her work always, it appears, derives directly from her way of seeing, and her admiration of Ms. Birkin is unequivocal. And it not infrequently bleeds into outright cinematic adoration. In one sequence of bracing intimacy, Ms. Varda‰Ûªs lens practically caresses a nude Ms. Birkin‰Ûªs skin.

There are a handful of North American film and music enthusiasts who are at least mildly confounded that the actor, singer, model and muse Jane Birkin is best known in the United States for inspiring a very costly handbag. The American premiere of the director AgnÌ¬s Varda‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏJane B. par AgnÌ¬s V.,‰Ûù a distinctive, delightful and sometimes even surreal portrait of Ms. Birkin (and of the filmmaker) released in France in 1988, could act at least as a slight corrective.

The farthest thing from a straightforward documentary, this companion piece to Ms. Varda‰Ûªs fiction film ‰ÛÏKung-Fu Master,‰Ûù in which Ms. Birkin played the lead role, ‰ÛÏJane B.‰Ûù seems the result of a deep, sympathetic collaboration between director and subject. Ms. Varda interrogates the coltishly beautiful Ms. Birkin directly and by having her perform in a series of written scenes placing her opposite actors like Jean-Pierre LÌ©aud and Philippe LÌ©otard. Ms. Varda also turns the camera on herself, and on her photographic equipment. Ms. Birkin, around 40 at the time of filming, retains a slightly breathy girlishness that complements her largely cheery, open personality and her intrepid intelligence.

This is not a tell-all picture; details of Ms. Birkin‰Ûªs marriages to the composer John Barry and the notoriously outrageous songwriter Serge Gainsbourg (who turns up here), say, are not disclosed. Speaking of life with her first two children, Ms. Birkin says with a shrug, ‰ÛÏI was like any other mother, except more photographed.‰Ûù Ms. Varda then shows a picture of a nearly nude Ms. Birkin chained to a radiator, followed by Ms. Birkin‰Ûªs cheerful recollection of the image. Always likable, and when enacting the film‰Ûªs many pastiches, entirely lovable (as in a Laurel and Hardy tribute with the Italian character actor Laura Betti), Ms. Birkin embodies the strong subject who chooses to be relatively agreeable to a certain level of objectification. While the word ‰ÛÏfeminism‰Ûù is never uttered in this movie, ‰ÛÏJane B. par AgnÌ¬s V.‰Ûù is an exemplary feminist work, one in which two female artists, self-aware but hardly self-conscious, create beauty by exchanging notes.
‰ÛÏJane B. par AgnÌ¬s V.‰Ûù is in French and English, with English subtitles. It is not rated.

Just as at sea but in a much different way is Phillip, a police officer, and Mr. Wilson makes the most of his scenes. So do some recognizable faces in the surrounding cast, especially John Leguizamo as a member of a support group Phillip attends.

This movie could have easily turned into a version of the 1983 film ‰ÛÏWithout a Trace,‰Ûù another missing-child story that was mostly interested in the search for the boy and the buildup to a feel-good ending. ‰ÛÏMeadowland‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt ignore the missing child, but it‰Ûªs squarely about the parents and the toll grief can take. The setup is a scriptwriting gimme ‰ÛÓ if your central couple lose a child, practically any subsequent behavior is justifiable ‰ÛÓ but the actors sell what they‰Ûªre given quite effectively.
They play Sarah and Phillip, a couple whose young son disappears during a family trip. Most of the movie takes place a year later, with the boy still missing and his parents still struggling to cope.

Ms. Wilde, who gets most of the camera time, is convincingly fragile as Sarah, a teacher who is slowly becoming unmoored. She fixates on a special-needs child in her school ‰ÛÓ a stand-in for her lost son, of course. It‰Ûªs not the most subtle device, but it‰Ûªs persuasive in Ms. Wilde‰Ûªs hands.

People respond to grief in myriad ways, some of them even positive, but in television and the movies, the go-to reaction is the downward spiral, because that gives actors a chance to try all their emotive tricks. ‰ÛÏMeadowland,‰Ûù a drama directed by Reed Morano from a script by Chris Rossi, follows that familiar template, but its stars, Olivia Wilde and Luke Wilson, do a fine job of making you forget how often you‰Ûªve seen similar treatments.
‰ÛÏMeadowland‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A bit of strong language and a not-very-revealing sex scene.

‰ÛÏMi America,‰Ûù a small-town crime drama, opens with the murder of five migrant workers ‰ÛÓ lured to an empty factory in the fictional upstate New York town of Braxton, then set upon by a gang of masked men swinging clubs. Robert Fontaine, who wrote and directed the film, plays Rolando Ramirez, the detective who works the case and begins to suspect that friends he grew up with in Braxton may well have been involved.
‰ÛÏMi America‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence and emphatic cursing.

In its structure and themes, ‰ÛÏMi America‰Ûù is reminiscent of John Sayles‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLone Star,‰Ûù another film that knew something about how small towns contain decades of wounds, and how the behaviors in one generation have consequences in the next. ‰ÛÏMi America‰Ûù is not just about a murder case but about how residents of divided communities share a history and deal with one another, sometimes hopefully, always warily.

From the murders to their discovery to the investigation and what follows, the events play out over many months, the flashbacks over many years. That unhurried pacing makes some threads hard to follow, and to keep all the relationships straight. Nor is the plot free of holes, but it‰Ûªs clear that Mr. Fontaine, quite good as Ramirez, put a lot of thought into his story.

What unfolds is a gritty tale that ties Ramirez‰Ûªs past to a present now filled with subtle confrontations among residents of an economically stressed town who have long memories and hold grudges. The best moments of the movie, which was filmed in Newburgh, N.Y., are scenes involving characters who took part in events they have not discussed for decades.
‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Rape and other violence.

Jack‰Ûªs unboundedness, the joy he expresses with Ma, the room and their meager possessions ‰ÛÓ his laughter and delight and kidness ‰ÛÓ are visceral and pleasurable. Crucially, he doesn‰Ûªt live in a room or the room, but in Room, which he refers to as if it were another living being. (In the novel, Ms. Donoghue capitalizes Jack‰Ûªs significant nouns.) This anthropomorphizing is a charming, humanizing quirk. Heard again and again onscreen, though, it might have also registered as overly calculated if Mr. Tremblay‰Ûªs electrically alive performance carried a trace of artifice. But his presence in the movie has a crystalline purity, and while Jack makes life bearable for Ma, Mr. Tremblay makes the movie bearable for you. His essential child being, his fragility and buoyancy, his shrieks of happiness and complaint, air the room out.

‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù can weigh on your heart like a stone because it summons the terrors suffered by real victims. But while it flickers with grace and imagination during its initial half, largely because of Jack, it devolves into a dreary, platitudinous therapy movie in its second, largely because of Ma. This part of the story, which takes place outside their prison, is filled with violently disgorged emotions that give Ms. Larson plenty to do and ornamented with a handful of bustling guest stars ‰ÛÓ a crisp Joan Allen, a poorly served William H. Macy and a nice, loose Tom McCamus. It turns out that telling this kind of grim story through the eyes of a child isn‰Ûªt just a shrewdly palatable device, it‰Ûªs also artistically liberating, because the more the world opens up, the smaller ‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù becomes.

The constricted narrative and Jack‰Ûªs point of view flow together. He doesn‰Ûªt live in the same inhumane prison that Ma suffers in, but in a wide-open universe trembling with possibilities, with dancing lights, hand-shadow puppetry and amusements made with cardboard and eggshells. At moments, as the screen floods with close-ups, you share in Jack‰Ûªs wonderment, in the granular, sensual splendor of this child‰Ûªs cosmos in a few inches of sink, a shimmer of light, a mote of dust. ‰ÛÏHow many rainbows can light create for the untutored eye?‰Ûù the avant-garde filmmaker Stan Brakhage once asked. Jack is as much an inmate as Ma, but because he‰Ûªs unaware of what lies outside the room ‰ÛÒ and not wholly aware of its inside horrors ‰ÛÒ his vision remains untutored, his soul free.

‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù has been adapted from Emma Donoghue‰Ûªs critically lauded captivity novel, which is told through one of those child voices ‰ÛÓ sensitive, never savage or sloppy ‰ÛÓ written for adult readers. Ms. Donoghue also wrote the movie, which commences with Jack opening his eyes, and lifts off with his fifth birthday, a milestone that has profoundly different significance for him and for Ma. As that day dawns, you may not initially grasp just how cramped their living quarters are. The director Lenny Abrahamson and his crew have created a space that opens and close like an accordion, one that expands into a virtual suite depending on the camera angles and lenses, the editing and especially the close-ups that obscure its dimensions until a jolting wide shot cuts it back down to size.

Together, Jack‰Ûªs vision and Mr. Tremblay‰Ûªs presence create a curious paradox because they help make ‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù an oddly comfortable viewing experience, especially in its first hour. Mr. Abrahamson, by following the book‰Ûªs lead and embracing Jack‰Ûªs point of view so strongly, specifically in his Expressionistic translation of the novelistic first-person to the screen, has managed the difficult task of externalizing the inner life of another person. In the process, however, he leaves Ma behind. Ms. Larson, her bright face dimmed and eyes ringed, works hard to bring Ma to persuasive life, digging into grief in her corner of the room between hopeless smiles, but Mr. Abrahamson‰Ûªs lack of attention turns her into an overly muted supporting player.

Like some mother-and child stories, ‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù is about two people who have yet to cut the cord. In the case of Ma (Brie Larson) and her 5-year-old, Jack (Jacob Tremblay), the separation has been delayed because they‰Ûªre prisoners in a tiny shed that has been her cell, her hell, for seven years. Having been kidnapped at 17 by a man she‰Ûªs named Old Nick (Sean Bridgers), and given birth in captivity, Ma ‰ÛÓ as she‰Ûªs known for most of the story ‰ÛÓ has held onto life through her child, whose world is circumscribed by four pitiful walls, his mother‰Ûªs heart-heavy love and his own imagination.

Jeffrey Schwarz‰Ûªs documentary portrait ‰ÛÏTab Hunter Confidential‰Ûù is as mild-mannered and blandly likable as its subject, the blond screen heartthrob who in the 1950s embodied the quintessential pretty boy next door. Mr. Hunter, now 84, was seemingly every teenage girl‰Ûªs dream date. Gay and closeted, he was protected from exposure by Warner Bros., the studio to which he was under contract. The biggest career mistake of his life, he recalls, was securing his release from Warner, a decision he soon regretted when his movie career all but died.
‰ÛÏTab Hunter Confidential‰Ûù is not rated.

‰ÛÏTab Hunter Confidential‰Ûù has little of the impact of ‰ÛÏVito,‰Ûù Mr. Schwarz‰Ûªs heartbreaking documentary portrait of Vito Russo, the gay activist and author who died of AIDS in 1990. And Mr. Hunter isn‰Ûªt as lively a subject as Divine, the drag performer affectionately profiled in Mr. Schwarz‰Ûªs 2013 film, ‰ÛÏI Am Divine,‰Ûù and with whom Mr. Hunter starred in ‰ÛÏPolyester.‰Ûù

Mr. Hunter, the former Arthur Gelien, was discovered while working on a horse ranch and was signed by Henry Willson, a powerful agent who also represented Rock Hudson. The name Tab Hunter was Mr. Willson‰Ûªs idea, but it was a moniker the actor detested. Mr. Hunter gained notice in the 1952 film ‰ÛÏIsland of Desire,‰Ûù opposite Linda Darnell, and he spent much of the movie with his shirt off. The peak of his film career was the 1955 film ‰ÛÏBattle Cry,‰Ûù adapted from the Leon Uris best seller. A little later he had a No. 1 record with ‰ÛÏYoung Love,‰Ûù although his singing was barely passable. Once his movie career dried up, he spent grueling years on the dinner-theater circuit.

Because Mr. Hunter was eye candy, the documentary lingers on images of him in his prime, when he dated female stars like Natalie Wood but didn‰Ûªt sleep with them. For nostalgists and anyone who likes to gawk at pictures of pretty celebrities at their peak of beauty, there is plenty to look at.

Mr. Hunter‰Ûªs affairs with men, most notably Anthony Perkins, are noted but not explored in any great depth. Their story alone might make a powerful feature film about gay Hollywood in the 1950s. A more ambitious documentary would address the workings of the publicity machinery that kept the scandal out of the press.

The spine of the film, adapted from a 2006 autobiography he wrote with Eddie Muller, is an interview with Mr. Hunter, whose career enjoyed a brief resurgence in the 1981 John Waters film, ‰ÛÏPolyester.‰Ûù Reflecting on his life and times with a dispassionate amiability, he recalls the emotionally devastating events of the death of his older brother, Walt, in Vietnam in 1965, and the mental illness of his mother, Gertrude, to whom he was devoted caretaker.

Where do the assassin‰Ûªs loyalties lie? Will affection and family feeling override her professional duties? And how will her target, Ji‰Ûªan, reconcile the demands of power and mercy? He seems like a thoughtful, sensitive man, but his survival may depend on his ability to be cruel and cunning.

‰ÛÏThe Assassin‰Ûù is a stately action movie, graceful and slow-moving, with bursts of smoothly choreographed violence. Apart from those moments, the film unfolds almost like a series of exquisite paintings: landscapes and interiors composed with an exacting eye, every shape and color measured and placed according to a rigorous aesthetic.

Nie Yinniang (Shu Qi) is the title character, trained in her deadly vocation by a fierce, soft-spoken mentor and dispatched, at the start of the film, on a fateful and complicated mission. Yinniang‰Ûªs home province, Weibo, is in a state of revolt and factional strife, and she is ordered to kill Tian Ji‰Ûªan (Chen Chang) a local potentate who is also her cousin. Yinniang, who was taken to the imperial capital as a child, receives a cordial welcome, and lurks in the shadows as various intrigues are plotted and thwarted. Imposing, almost Shakespearean themes waft through the air like smoke from the censers and braziers that are fixtures in every room.

‰ÛÏThe Assassin‰Ûù takes place in ninth-century China, and concerns the consequences of a provincial rebellion against imperial authority. But the history being explored is less political than cinematic. Mr. Hou‰Ûªs interest in the movie past is evident in frequent acts of homage ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏCafÌ© LumiÌ¬re,‰Ûù for example, is, among other things, a loving and gently critical meditation on the legacy of the Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu ‰ÛÓ and here he joins a growing list of filmmakers embracing wuxia, the medieval sword-fighting genre that is in many ways a Chinese analog of the American western.

You could say that Mr. Hou is satisfying his inner nerd, or perhaps experimenting with the constraints and conventions of genre filmmaking. And for cinephiles of a certain temperament, ‰ÛÏThe Assassin‰Ûù will be pure catnip: an auteurist artifact with sumptuous costumes, simmering palace rivalries and acrobatic displays of blade-wielding virtuosity.

‰ÛÏThe Assassin,‰Ûù in contrast, offers subdued and partial delights. It reminds you of the sublime and enigmatic power of cinematic images without quite supplying the grandeur of mystery. Mr. Hou rejects some of the traditional satisfactions of the wuxia genre ‰ÛÓ the intricate but orderly plotting; the jolts of romantic passion and vengeful rage; the kinetic excitement ‰ÛÓ without offering much in their place. The film is intriguing, but ultimately opaque, a lovely, inert object that offers, in the name of movie love, an escape from so much that is vital and interesting about movies.

These problems are addressed ‰ÛÓ or at least gestured at ‰ÛÓ in a series of decorous, elliptical scenes. Mr. Hou is a reluctant dramatizer, preferring the oblique indication of emotion to its direct expression. In many of his movies, the feelings that characters might be experiencing are displaced into the light, the scenery, the nuances of quiet that surround them. This can produce, in movies like ‰ÛÏThree Times‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMillennium Mambo,‰Ûù a special kind of bliss, a sense of being moved by invisible forces that are at the same time right in front of your eyes.

The eye in question belongs to Hou Hsiao-Hsien, the Taiwanese filmmaker whose work, over more than 30 years, is a catalog of visual beauty and formal innovation. ‰ÛÏThe Assassin,‰Ûù which won the prize for best director at Cannes in May, certainly exhibits both of those qualities. It is as gorgeous to behold as anything you are likely to encounter on a movie screen or a museum wall. And it‰Ûªs a reminder that Mr. Hou, many of whose recent films have found mystery, sensuality and artistic possibility in modern cities (Tokyo in ‰ÛÏCafÌ© Lumiere,‰Ûù Paris in ‰ÛÏFlight of the Red Balloon‰Ûù), is also a master at imagining the past.

In this brutally powerful documentary, that fear is manifested in the violent persecution of people with albinism in rural Tanzania, where some believe albinos‰Ûª limbs have magical powers, resulting in a grisly trade in body parts. (Graphic news footage of a newly dismembered body is particularly grim.)

The film follows two harrowing assaults and their aftermath. One concerns a woman, Mariamu Staford, who was maimed with a machete by a neighbor. She lost one arm at the elbow, and more of her other arm. The other, larger case pertains to Adam Robert, a boy from the region in the title who was set up by his father and stepmother for an attack. He lost the use of a wrist and some fingers.

Mr. Ash ‰ÛÓ a former Baptist minister, the owner of a real estate company in Vancouver, British Columbia, and an albino himself ‰ÛÓ travels to Tanzania and ensures that Adam has surgery to restore at least partial use of his hands. Mr. Ash also founded Under the Same Sun, an education and advocacy group fighting discrimination against albinos. ‰ÛÏIn Africa, ignorance is the major disease that we suffer,‰Ûù says Adika Ferdinand, the principal of a Tanzanian school. The same could be said for much of the world. ‰ÛÏThe Boy From Geita‰Ûù is an effective salvo against that plague.

An agonizingly all-too-familiar truth is expressed anew in Vic Sarin‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Boy From Geita‰Ûù: ‰ÛÏHuman beings are fundamentally afraid of what they don‰Ûªt understand,‰Ûù the heroic Canadian businessman Peter Ash says.

The movie, written and directed by James Vanderbilt, who is best known as the screenwriter of ‰ÛÏZodiac,‰Ûù focuses not on Mr. Rather, who is played with a dignified folksiness by Robert Redford, but on Ms. Mapes, whose 2005 book, ‰ÛÏTruth and Duty: The Press, the President, and the Privilege of Power‰Ûù is the basis for the movie.
‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and a brief nude photo.

Mr. Rather‰Ûªs exit from the anchorman job at CBS, of course, was less momentous than a presidential assassination. But because it coincided with the run-up to a presidential election, it was potentially very consequential. At the time the story aired, Mr. Bush was a little bit ahead of John Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, in the polls and the ‰ÛÏswiftboating‰Ûù campaign to discredit Mr. Kerry‰Ûªs military record had already begun.

The explosive reaction to the story, once it is broadcast, turns ‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù into a suspenseful detective story in which the minutiae of typewriters, typefaces and word-processing technologies are explored with an increasingly frantic sense of desperation.

Ms. Mapes is the heart and soul of ‰ÛÏTruth.‰Ûù The family breadwinner, she lives in Dallas with her husband, Mark Wrolstad (John Benjamin Hickey), and young son. Ms. Blanchett plays her as fiery-eyed go-getter who pursued the story with a dogged ferocity. Her eyes flashing, she describes a tip linking Mr. Bush to the bin Laden family that went nowhere as ‰ÛÏa juicy piece of brisket.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt try to resolve mysteries that may never be solved or to drum up paranoia for the sake of extra heartbeats. But it still casts a pall of dread, an ominous sense that people in high places, whether in government or the news media, will stop at almost nothing to protect themselves and their interests. The retaliation against Ms. Mapes and her crew is similar to the smearing of the San Jose Mercury News journalist Gary Webb after his articles about cocaine smuggling and the funding of Nicaraguan rebels by the C.I.A. That story, told in Michael Cuesta‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKill the Messenger‰Ûù (2014), a lesser film than ‰ÛÏTruth,‰Ûù though still a powerful one, sends the same warning. Investigative journalism intended to upset the status quo can be dangerous and costly.

Just as there are conspiracy theorists who will never be satisfied with the Warren Commission report on the Kennedy assassination, there are some who passionately believe that Mr. Rather and his producer Mary Mapes (Cate Blanchett) conspired to tarnish George W. Bush‰Ûªs reputation.

The screenplay brings in her bitter relationship with her abusive father, whose unkind words about her after the scandal breaks incite savage, profane invective from the right-wing bloggers who call her ‰ÛÏfeminazi‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏwitch.‰Ûù Ms. Mapes has a thick skin but not so thick that she isn‰Ûªt wounded by her father‰Ûªs public scolding and asks him to stop speaking out.

The Sept. 8, 2004, episode of ‰ÛÏ60 Minutes II‰Ûù alleged that family connections enabled Mr. Bush to avoid the draft in the Vietnam era by serving in the Texas Air National Guard. After Ms. Mapes‰Ûªs failure to authenticate documents indicating that Mr. Bush, during his term of National Guard service, was lax in his duties and went missing, she was fired, and Mr. Rather stepped down as anchorman.

Just below the facade of professional decorum in ‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù run deep currents of fear, suspicion and hatred. In the creepiest scene, Ms. Mapes is interrogated by a panel convened by CBS, whose members treat her with barely disguised contempt. When she eventually lashes out, she seals her own fate. It is a sad ending to a brilliant career.

Their defenders believe that Mr. Rather and Ms. Mapes and her team were fed to the wolves for political reasons. The movie insinuates that CBS, to avoid further embarrassment and to curry favor with conservatives should Mr. Bush win the election, allowed it to happen. ‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt voice an opinion, and none of its characters express their political beliefs even in private. Still, its treatment of Mr. Rather, who exudes the stately aura of a grand old man, and Ms. Mapes, who was a kind of surrogate daughter, makes it perfectly clear whose side it takes.

The most colorful member of Ms. Mapes‰Ûªs crack team of researchers and interviewers is Mike Smith (Topher Grace) an impatient firebrand with a very short fuse. Other team members include Lt. Col. Roger Charles (Dennis Quaid), a military consultant who worked with Ms. Mapes on the program‰Ûªs Peabody Award-winning piece on Abu Ghraib, and Lucy Scott (Elisabeth Moss, underused), a Texas journalism professor.

The title of ‰ÛÏTruth,‰Ûù a gripping, beautifully executed journalistic thriller about the events that ended Dan Rather‰Ûªs career as a CBS anchorman, should probably be appended with a question mark. More than most docudramas about fairly recent events, it is so well written and acted that it conveys a convincing illusion of veracity.

‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù which tells Ms. Mapes‰Ûªs side of the story, is sympathetic, but doesn‰Ûªt try to exonerate her. Ms. Blanchett, in one of her greatest screen performances, offers a compelling portrait of a driven, high-strung television journalist fearlessly operating in a cutthroat professional climate. She is relentless in tracking down documents that appear to have been written in the early ‰Ûª70s by Mr. Bush‰Ûªs commander, Jerry B. Killian, who died in 1984. And when she finally secures an interview with Lt. Col. Bill Burkett (Stacy Keach), an ailing National Guard veteran, who produces incriminating documents that seem to be authentic, her case momentarily seems airtight.

In a broader and sadder sense, ‰ÛÏTruth‰Ûù portrays network television news as a grim corporate culture obsessed with remaining above the political fray and maintaining an attitude of imperial detachment. Andrew Heyward (Bruce Greenwood), the president of CBS News from 1996 to 2005, is an unflappably cool operator who never raises his voice and maintains a chilly cordiality in the best of times that freezes into ice in the worst. In such a hypercompetitive environment, undercurrents of anxiety and tension of run deep. To combat the stress, a conspicuous amount of alcohol is consumed by both Mr. Rather and Ms. Mapes.

Flashbacks and fantasy sequences undercut the claustrophobic atmosphere. What‰Ûªs left is amateurish play acting ‰ÛÓ pointless for anyone who hasn‰Ûªt seen ‰ÛÏPortrait of Jason‰Ûù and redundant for those who have.
Courting questions about the ethics of the camera and the nature of Mr. Holliday‰Ûªs performance, ‰ÛÏPortrait of Jason‰Ûù is already a movie about its own making.

Nevertheless, ‰ÛÏJason and Shirley,‰Ûù a work of speculative fiction from Stephen Winter, reimagines the shooting of ‰ÛÏPortrait of Jason‰Ûù in December 1966. (‰ÛÏOnce upon a time in the Chelsea Hotel,‰Ûù as the title cards so cheekily put it.) It takes a disturbing, ambiguous film and reduces it to the comforting expository contours of a biopic.

When Jason (Mr. Waters) arrives, Mr. Winter‰Ûªs movie weighs in on what it sees as the vampirism of Ms. Clarke‰Ûªs methods. ‰ÛÏJason is doing everything that we want him to do,‰Ûù the character Shirley tells a crew member (Eamon Fahey). ‰ÛÏBut don‰Ûªt let him know.‰Ûù The most novel aspect of ‰ÛÏJason and Shirley‰Ûù is its use of VHS, likely a nod to Ms. Clarke‰Ûªs advocacy for video as an artistic medium.

In Shirley Clarke‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏPortrait of Jason‰Ûù (1967), Jason Holliday, a gay African-American hustler, shares stories and celebrity impressions. As Ms. Clarke and her sometime companion, Carl Lee, steer the conversation from off-camera, the material turns darker, to the police and to Mr. Holliday‰Ûªs difficult childhood.
‰ÛÏJason and Shirley‰Ûù is not rated. It runs for 1 hour 19 minutes.

For those unfamiliar with Ms. Clarke, the movie‰Ûªs fictionalized Shirley (Sarah Schulman, who wrote the script with Mr. Winter and her co-star, Jack Waters) quickly name-drops fellow experimental filmmakers. Yet even the history in Mr. Winter‰Ûªs movie can‰Ûªt be trusted: Although Ms. Clarke, who died in 1997, directed the Academy Award-winning ‰ÛÏRobert Frost: A Lover‰Ûªs Quarrel With the World,‰Ûù the producer, Robert Hughes, took the award, contrary to what Mr. Winter‰Ûªs film implies.

What follows is partly a meditation on loss and love that begins with the death of her mother and moves on to include the deaths of Ms. Anderson‰Ûªs talented and tuneful rat terrier, Lolabelle; her friend, the brilliant artist Gordon Matta-Clark (1943-1978); and her husband, Lou Reed. Mr. Reed, who died in 2013, hovers over ‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog,‰Ûù his face surfacing intermittently and fleetingly, wavering into visibility like an image that‰Ûªs caught behind glass or reflected in a mirror, a distancing that suggests that he is present and not present at the same time. (One of his most moving appearances occurs during the final credits.) ‰ÛÏEvery love story is a ghost story,‰Ûù Ms. Anderson says at one point, quoting David Foster Wallace, yet another lingering spirit.
‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog‰Ûù is not rated. It runs 1 hour 15 minutes.

Her ghosts can materialize in unexpected fashion. In addition to her more private reveries, Ms. Anderson ventures, as she has throughout her career, into overtly political terrain, as when she introduces Sept. 11. Her entry into this fraught subject is characteristically disarming. She begins by talking about her home in the West Village, which overlooks the West Side Highway, and how, after Sept. 11, with her neighborhood smothered in ash, she escaped to the mountains of Northern California with Lolabelle. The idea was to see if she could talk to Lolabelle ‰ÛÓ rat terriers, Ms. Anderson says, can understand about 500 words. It‰Ûªs a whimsical objective that turns serious when, amid the brightly lighted nature shots of her and Lolabelle, she connects the threat of soaring hawks to that of airplanes.

It‰Ûªs hard to think of many artists who could pull off that kind of connection. Ms. Anderson‰Ûªs lulling voice smooths the way, as does the movie‰Ûªs associative form. Although ‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog‰Ûù can seem somewhat shapeless at first glance, as if Ms. Anderson were just aimlessly floating from topic to topic (from her mother to the surveillance state and how dogs see color), she is recurrently circling back rather than simply moving forward. Much like a philosopher, she advances, loops back, deepens the argument ‰ÛÓ with a tender image of Lolabelle, a reference to Tibetan Buddhism, a shot of trees, a nod to Wittgenstein ‰ÛÓ and then she advances again and circles back once more. At times, it feels as if she too were haunting her movie even as, with every image and word, she fills it with life.

‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog‰Ûù is about telling and remembering and forgetting, and how we put together the fragments that make up our lives ‰ÛÓ their flotsam and jetsam, highs and lows, meaningful and slight details, shrieking and weeping headline news. This purposefully fissured quality extends to the movie itself, which is by turns narratively straightforward and playfully experimental, light and heavy (it‰Ûªs a fast 75 minutes), accessible and opaque, concrete and abstract. And while it‰Ûªs drizzled in sadness ‰ÛÓ one of its recurrent images is of rain splattered across glass ‰ÛÓ it joyfully embraces silliness, as when a blind dog named Lolabelle plays the piano. It‰Ûªs a home movie of a type, if one that, like a stone skipped across a still lake, leaves expanding rings in its path.

Near the end of her dreamy, drifty and altogether lovely movie ‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog,‰Ûù Laurie Anderson does what she is so great at doing: She tells a story. This one is too powerful to ruin here, but the story and its placement speak to how she makes meaning. Speaking in voice-over, as she does throughout, with her perfect phrasing and warm, gently wry tone, she recounts a harrowing episode from her childhood. It‰Ûªs one that she had described before, she says. But one day she realized that she had been omitting some horrifying details. She had ‰ÛÏcleaned it up,‰Ûù as she puts it, because that‰Ûªs what we do: ‰ÛÏYou get your story and you hold onto it, and every time you tell it, you forget it more.‰Ûù

Ms. Anderson shot much of ‰ÛÏHeart of a Dog‰Ûù herself, which gives it a distinct personal quality that dovetails with her intimate, sometimes confessional narration. Like many filmmakers, she offers you a kind of interpretive key to the movie in its opening moments, starting with close-ups that move across an artwork washed in sepia and embellished with dark squiggles and words. The closeness of these shots makes it initially difficult to grasp the literal big picture, though there are readable words (‰ÛÏhot tin roofs‰Ûù upside down) and then human figures. Suddenly, an illustration of Ms. Anderson‰Ûªs face materializes and begins speaking. ‰ÛÏThis is my dream body,‰Ûù she says, ‰ÛÏthe one I use to walk around in my dreams.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs her version, I think, of ‰ÛÏOnce upon a time.‰Ûù

All of the above possibilities, and more, are dangled out there, but none are explored. The consequence is a glossy but superficial addiction tale (written by Paige Dylan and Amy Koppelman, and based on Ms. Koppelman‰Ûªs 2008 novel), a wearying loop of slug-snort-crash that leaves Ms. Silverman out on a ledge and the audience with no way to reach her. It‰Ûªs a performance in a vacuum, one that could have cut deeper had her scenes with Mr. Charles displayed even a fraction of the emotional anarchy that John Cassavetes could write with one hand tied behind his back.

Instead, Laney must box her own shadow, debasing and endangering herself in a downward spiral of despair. It‰Ûªs too bad, because Ms. Silverman has a vulnerability that feels artistically fertile and that rarely pierces her standup comedy persona of the nice Jewish girl with the dirty mind. But it‰Ûªs there in her turn as a gutsy lesbian on the Showtime drama ‰ÛÏMasters of Sex,‰Ûù a recurring role that has allowed her to stretch in surprising ways.

During awards season, it‰Ûªs well known that certain roles offer more reliable routes to the podium than others. Playing a drunk is one of them (though somewhat less of a slam dunk than portraying a Holocaust survivor or someone struggling with a disability), and each year we wait to see which variety of pickled protagonist ‰ÛÓ the degenerate genius, the woozy bombshell ‰ÛÓ will stagger onto our movie screens.
‰ÛÏI Smile Back‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Adultery, violence, drugs, nudity and sexual abuse of a child‰Ûªs teddy bear. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes.

She does, however, grab our attention as Laney, an upscale New Jersey housewife who dives into some combination of a bottle, a gram of coke and the neighbor‰Ûªs bed as soon as her two young children are safely in school. But the source of her self-punishing and increasingly degrading behavior remains vague. Is she dulling the pain of privilege and the numbing routines of motherhood? Depressed about her sagging breasts and jawline? Maybe she‰Ûªs bored with her loving, if self-satisfied husband, Bruce (a regrettably marginalized Josh Charles), an insurance salesman who seems weirdly oblivious to his wife‰Ûªs mental torment.

Directed by Adam Salky with a decorousness that ill-serves the material, ‰ÛÏI Smile Back‰Ûù briefly touches a nerve when a trip upstate brings Laney face to face with her estranged father (a wonderfully nuanced Chris Sarandon). The encounter has an unstable complexity that illuminates some of Laney‰Ûªs damage; for the first time, she and the movie feel like they‰Ûªre moving as one.

Maybe it will be the sozzled suburban housewife, lurching daintily, gin bottle in hand, between her hunky, concerned husband and adorably distressed kids. But unlike, say, Meg Ryan in ‰ÛÏWhen a Man Loves a Woman‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ so prettily plastered you‰Ûªd think booze were a beauty treatment ‰ÛÓ Sarah Silverman burns through the indie drama ‰ÛÏI Smile Back‰Ûù without making the slightest move to gain our sympathy.
‰ÛÏRock the Kasbah‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gunplay, bombs and other wartime violence. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

The filmmakers appear to be trying for the kind of comedy that infused ‰ÛÏM*A*S*H‰Ûù and, to a lesser extent, ‰ÛÏGood Morning, Vietnam,‰Ûù which Mr. Levinson directed. ‰ÛÏGood Morning, Vietnam‰Ûù centers on a disc jockey (played by Robin Williams) who is changed by his tenure in Vietnam; ‰ÛÏM*A*S*H‰Ûù zeroes in on doctors and nurses who, during the Korean War, keep insanity more or less at bay with gallows humor while up to their necks in battlefield blood. ‰ÛÏKasbah‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt remotely on the level of either; its laughs die mid-delivery, and there‰Ûªs no sense that anyone is interested in what conflict does to the soul. In each of those earlier films, war has some kind of meaning.

Mitch Glazer wrote the script and Barry Levinson directed, and each presumably called in a few favors to fill out the cast. Bill Murray, who starred in ‰ÛÏScrooged,‰Ûù co-written by Mr. Glazer, here plays Richie Lanz, a dead-ended music promoter and one of those putative lovable losers who are more adored by filmmakers than the rest of us. Marooned in a dusty corner of Los Angeles, Richie has a hot-cha-cha assistant who‰Ûªs also an aspiring singer and is played by an ill-served Zooey Deschanel in raccoon eye makeup and animal-print leggings. One minute they‰Ûªre wisecracking in La-La Land; the next they‰Ûªre sweating in Kabul, set to entertain the troops. High jinks ensue.

ClichÌ©d, enervating, insulting ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs tough to settle on a single pejorative for ‰ÛÏRock the Kasbah,‰Ûù though abysmal might do. Crammed with performers who apparently didn‰Ûªt read the script before signing on, the movie offends your intelligence on every level, starting with its use of Afghanistan as a Western playground. And it does so while trying to pump laughs from the threat of beheadings and honor killings alongside crude yuks about bedding Danielle Steel ‰ÛÓ questionable fodder made worse partly by some colossal bad timing: President Obama recently announced that American troops would remain, through 2017, in Afghanistan, where the Taliban has made a comeback and the so-called Islamic State is on the rise.

There‰Ûªs nothing truly at stake for Richie, who first goofs around with some tired wartime types, including a smiley, servile local (Arian Moayed); a mercenary (Bruce Willis ‰ÛÓ what a waste!); a happy hooker (Kate Hudson); and two giddy, gonzo arms dealers (Scott Caan and Danny McBride). In time, Richie also sets off on an adventure that allows him to play the big hero-savior while earning a few bucks. His means to both is a Pashtun songbird, Salima (Leem Lubany), whom he places on a television competition, ‰ÛÏAfghan Star‰Ûù (a real show). Sure, her father and others disapprove of this public display by a young woman. But like many outsiders, Richie believes that he knows what Afghans really want ‰ÛÓ and, like this movie, he delivers imperialism with a smile.

In ‰ÛÏBone Tomahawk,‰Ûù an old-timer, an invalid and a gunslinger set out across the blistering desert to rescue three innocents from a band of savage cannibals. Their mission seems beyond futile, but don‰Ûªt count them out too soon: Their leader is Kurt Russell.

Yet Mr. Russell is far from the only reason to see this unexpected low-budget treat, a witty fusion of western, horror and comedy that gallops to its own beat. That rhythm is dictated entirely by the writer and director, S. Craig Zahler, a novelist and musician who flips genre conventions upside-down and cares more about character than body count. As a result, he has given us a horror movie whose monsters are withheld until the tail end of its 132 minutes, and an action movie whose longest section involves mostly walking and talking.
‰ÛÏBone Tomahawk‰Ûù is not rated. Running time: 2 hours 12 minutes.

But what talking! Listening to the wonderfully weird and off-kilter dialogue, you can see why actors with the heft of Patrick Wilson and Richard Jenkins were moved to join Mr. Russell in his trek. (‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs like a tree fell on you,‰Ûù a bartender remarks to a less-than-coherent patron. ‰ÛÏA redwood.‰Ûù) Even Matthew Fox, whom I have always found underwhelming, is terrific as the worldly gunslinger with a creamy wardrobe and an itchy trigger finger. Rising to the bait of the movie‰Ûªs meandering asides and pithy one-liners, the actors never oversell, instead using their bodies to convey the weight of responsibility (Mr. Russell‰Ûªs sheriff), the vanity of the professional killer (Mr. Fox) and the bone weariness of a deputy who‰Ûªs too old for this posse nonsense (Mr. Jenkins).

For sheer physical endurance, though, Mr. Wilson bests them all as O‰ÛªDwyer, a cowboy whose wife has been kidnapped by the deviants and whose broken leg threatens to stall the rescue mission. The kidnappers ‰ÛÓ helpfully described as inbred cave dwellers, or ‰ÛÏtroglodytes,‰Ûù lest we think that Native Americans are being depicted as people eaters ‰ÛÓ lurk a three-day ride from the little town of Bright Hope, where the abductions occurred. For some, this interlude will be a richly rewarding highlight as veteran performers gnaw on their roles and Benji Bakshi‰Ûªs arid photography adds gravity and grandeur; for others, it will be a longueur to be endured before the splatter commences.

When it does, Mr. Zahler doesn‰Ûªt disappoint with scenes that are swift, sure and shockingly brutal. Right to the end, the movie‰Ûªs idiosyncratic sensibility doesn‰Ûªt flag, with villains who sew animal bones into their throats to facilitate their bloodcurdling battle cries, and a victim who meets his end in the manner of a wishbone at Thanksgiving dinner. Even the song that plays over the end credits ‰ÛÓ a frontier-ditty parody by Mr. Zahler and Jeff Herriott ‰ÛÓ is worth staying seated for. Grisly and offbeat, ‰ÛÏBone Tomahawk‰Ûù may boast abysmal racial politics, but they‰Ûªre also true to the terrors of the time. Of all the things we can expect from an Old West picture, cultural enlightenment isn‰Ûªt one of them.

Barely more than an hour, this shaggy-dog story doesn‰Ûªt sustain its ingenuity to the end, when Candy encounters a projectionist running a Turkish knockoff of ‰ÛÏSuperman.‰Ûù Yet it‰Ûªs hard not to succumb at least somewhat to this sci-fi whatsit‰Ûªs strange, whimsical spell.

Candy (Daniel Tadesse) spends the day scavenging and avoiding thieves, including one who wears a gas mask and a Nazi armband. Candy lives with (and loves) Birdy (Selam Tesfaye). After Birdy observes a long-defunct bowling alley begin to operate on its own, Candy sets off, with a toy sword tucked under his belt, on a fact-finding mission, questioning a witch (Shitay Abreha) and, eventually, a belligerent Santa Claus (Tsegaye Abegaz).

This debut feature from the Spanish-born director Miguel LlansÌ_ can‰Ûªt claim a coherent mythology, but it has a lo-fi charm and humor. Doing a lot with a little, Mr. LlansÌ_ pulls off some stunning sights, as when Mr. Tadesse wanders train tracks that run over a body of water.

‰ÛÏCrumbs,‰Ûù a miniature post-apocalyptic adventure shot in Ethiopia, takes place after a war of some sort has ravaged the planet. Whatever happened has left behind a trove of pop-cultural detritus. The characters maintain a shrine to Michael Jordan. A shop owner marvels at a Ninja Turtle action figure. The hero barters with a record of Michael Jackson‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDangerous.‰Ûù

When an Ethiopian girl who survives abduction and rape in ‰ÛÏDifret‰Ûù finds safe haven with her lawyer, you may not expect the question she poses in a quiet moment: Is her host a bad woman? The 14-year-old Hirut (Tizita Hagere) is asking because her newfound defender, Meaza (the Ethiopian star Meron Getnet), lives alone in her Addis Ababa apartment, without a man and perhaps therefore without morals. Hirut, an eager grade-school student, shot an attacker after he tried to kidnap her for the purpose of marriage, but she‰Ûªs still a product of her elder-run community, and not simply a walking symbol of courage.

Shot in sunny locales, ‰ÛÏDifret‰Ûù has an earnestness that hovers between plain-spoken and pedestrian, and there are scenes and sequences that just don‰Ûªt come together as written and edited, no matter how admirable the film‰Ûªs existence is.

Such multilayered depiction of the deep roots of tradition is a hallmark of this film from Ethiopia, although it‰Ûªs not bolstered by an equivalently subtle sense for storytelling. The director, Zeresenay Berhane Mehari, follows Meaza, a women‰Ûªs-rights advocate, as she prepares a defense of Hirut on charges of murder and targets the misogynists in the legal system who keep waving off justice. Set in the mid-1990s, this docudrama presents Meaza ‰ÛÓ in real life the founder of the Ethiopian Women Lawyers Association ‰ÛÓ as a bold voice of freedom and autonomy, but when it comes to the drama part, Mr. Mehari keeps losing his footing.

But whether it‰Ûªs the dignified tones of Christopher Lee, in his final film role (he died in June), leading us through the mental and dynastic decline of ‰ÛÏThe Fall of the House of Usher,‰Ûù or the sepulchral voice of Bela Lugosi reciting ‰ÛÏThe Tell-Tale Heart‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ potently rendered in the style of the comic-book artist Alberto Breccia ‰ÛÓ the best sections reverberate with the power of Poe‰Ûªs words. As such, they serve as apt tributes to yarns that will always be more formidable on the page than on the screen.

Inspired by the stories of Edgar Allan Poe, ‰ÛÏExtraordinary Tales‰Ûù strings five animated short films into a curiosity of torture, murder, pestilence and madness. Harnessing a range of appropriately spooky-oddball narrators and striking visual styles ‰ÛÓ including graphic novels, early photography and Expressionist painting ‰ÛÓ the Spanish director and animator Raul Garcia simultaneously honors and reimagines.

Two have a decaying beauty that‰Ûªs particularly evocative. In ‰ÛÏThe Facts in the Case of M. Valdemar,‰Ûù a doctor hypnotizes a dying man while mauve, yellow and mossy green comic-book panels prove that you don‰Ûªt need fancy technology to achieve a third dimension. And in ‰ÛÏThe Masque of the Red Death,‰Ûù the rosy wash of oily color that flows over the story‰Ûªs plague-stalked revelers gives them the appearance of having been dipped in blood.

Compressed to its horrific essence, each tale illustrates the movie‰Ûªs rather obvious framing device: A graveyard conversation between Poe, in the guise of a raven, and Death, whom he fears and obsesses over. As the author frets about the robustness of his legacy, the segments emphasize the many ways terror of the hereafter can manifest.

‰ÛÏNasty Baby‰Ûù is not really ‰ÛÓ or not only ‰ÛÓ a loving farce about non-heteronormative reproduction and multicultural friendship. Without leaving Mo and Freddy‰Ûªs leafy, brownstone-lined street, Mr. Silva transports us to a much deeper, darker place. The word ‰ÛÏgentrification‰Ûù is not uttered on screen, but the economic and literal violence that lurks within its bland, euphemistic syllables turns out to be the movie‰Ûªs hidden theme. As misunderstandings spiral from awkward to horrifying, the gentle tickle of comedy is replaced by the barb of satire, and the audience‰Ûªs smile of recognition is replaced by a grimace of complicity. Mr. Silva starts out with his tongue in his cheek; you may wind up with a fishhook in yours.

Mo (Tunde Adebimpe) is black, Polly (Kristen Wiig) is white, and Freddy is an immigrant. He‰Ûªs played by SebastiÌÁn Silva, the 36-year-old Chilean filmmaker who wrote and directed ‰ÛÏNasty Baby,‰Ûù a sly comedy that shares its title with Freddy‰Ûªs art project. Not that anyone makes a big deal about race or sexuality or national background, except occasionally to make a knowing, careful joke.

In one scene, a moment that turns out to be a turning point in the film‰Ûªs devilishly clever plot, Freddy and his gallerist argue over his version of ‰ÛÏNasty Baby.‰Ûù The gallerist (Neal Huff) had been expecting ‰ÛÏhonesty and embarrassment‰Ûù and is disappointed to encounter what he perceives as cuteness instead. Mr. Silva‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNasty Baby‰Ûù fools you into thinking that it exists on a similar aesthetic boundary line, and that its bustling energy is an expression of Mr. Silva‰Ûªs struggle to stay true to his characters and their environment without making something too stale, small or safe.

Mo, Freddy and Polly ‰ÛÓ and others in their social circle, including Freddy‰Ûªs brother (AgustÌ_n Silva, the director‰Ûªs brother), Freddy‰Ûªs assistant (Alia Shawkat, a co-producer of the film) and a kindly older neighbor (Mark Margolis) ‰ÛÓ live a specifically Brooklyn version of the good life, in which gratifying work, nice friends, fulfilling leisure and good food are not aspirations but entitlements. Anything that‰Ûªs missing (like a baby) can be acquired without too much trouble. Or if there is trouble, it‰Ûªs likely to be more amusing than agonizing.

Everyone is too busy to seem complacent, and too appealing to be subjected to overt mockery. As a result, the humor in ‰ÛÏNasty Baby‰Ûù seems low key and small scale. The movie operates mainly as a comedy of postmodern manners, poking at the unexamined sensitivities and tiny contradictions that are part of the daily rhythms of the character‰Ûªs lives. If bigger issues sometimes intrude ‰ÛÓ racism, homophobia, money ‰ÛÓ they can be dissolved in irony or smothered in political correctness. City living has its rough spots, like the possibly unstable neighbor known as Bishop (Reg E. Cathey), who insists on running his leaf blower at the crack of dawn outside Freddy and Mo‰Ûªs window. But surely he‰Ûªs just a harmless local character.

You see what I mean about familiarity, right? If Mr. Silva had simply made the movie I‰Ûªve tried to describe so far, it would be a mild and enjoyable addition to the library of contemporary comedy that includes films like ‰ÛÏObvious Child‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Skeleton Twins‰Ûù and television like ‰ÛÏTransparent.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs well observed, welcoming and affectionate, occasionally sharp but never mean. Let me finish, though.

With its haute Bohemian locations and its hectic, hand-held style ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs a flurry of ragged scenes shot in shallow-focus digital video, with plenty of off-center close-ups and nervous cuts ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏNasty Baby‰Ûù presents itself as something familiar. As, you might say, the kind of movie the people in it might go to see and enjoy, with a few of the usual self-conscious reservations. The characters are gratifyingly individual, but they are also recognizable 21st-century urban types, inhabiting a milieu that is hardly exotic to casual browsers in the meadows of independent cinema and off-network television comedy.

But what had looked like a meandering, anecdotal story turns out to be a carefully constructed narrative machine, one that dispenses a brilliantly nasty series of surprises. Mr. Silva‰Ûªs accomplishment is not just in pulling off a jarring plot twist, but in handling a change of tone that turns the movie ‰ÛÓ and the audience‰Ûªs assumptions about it ‰ÛÓ upside down. If you‰Ûªve seen his earlier films, like ‰ÛÏThe Maid,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏOld Cats‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏCrystal Fairy,‰Ûù you‰Ûªre aware that he possesses this skill, and also a keen eye for the cruelty that underlies even the most apparently harmonious social arrangements.

The greatest risk anyone seems to face, and the most reliable source of laughter for about an hour, is the awkwardness that arises when unspoken boundaries are transgressed. And the work of the diverse, good-natured group of people who inhabit this movie is precisely to figure out the rules for living now that the old norms and taboos have gone away. When this happens, their world will become an achieved Utopia of tolerance, love, creativity and coolness. With a crazy real estate market and Byzantine parking rules, of course.

Freddy and Polly are trying to have a baby together. They aren‰Ûªt a couple: Polly is single, and Freddy lives with his boyfriend, Mo, (and also with a skinny, scene-stealing cat) in a light-flooded walk-up on a generally quiet Brooklyn block. But Polly and Freddy are best friends, and Freddy, who is an artist, is intrigued by the concept of creating a partial replica of himself. He‰Ûªs incorporating the idea into a video installation. When Freddy and Polly learn that his sperm count may be too low, Polly asks Mo if he‰Ûªd be willing to serve as a donor. Though he‰Ûªs ambivalent ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs quieter and calmer than Freddy, and seems more protective of his privacy ‰ÛÓ he might be open to persuasion.
‰ÛÏNasty Baby‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Oh baby, is it ever nasty. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

The film pointedly tells an unfinished story, one that ends on a bittersweet, equivocal note. It takes place in 1912, at an important moment in the British suffragist movement and very much in the middle of the long journey toward equality. Agitation for the vote had been going on for decades, and the franchise would not be extended fully to women until 1928. In ‰ÛÏSuffragette,‰Ûù demonstrators fill the streets of London and militants carry out acts of vandalism, smashing windows and blowing up mailboxes. The chancellor of the Exchequer, David Lloyd George, holds hearings on a parliamentary amendment. The cause of voting rights is embodied by Emmeline Pankhurst, who is seen in newspaper photographs and briefly seen in the person of Meryl Streep.

‰ÛÏSuffragette‰Ûù unfolds partly as an Edwardian thriller, with a Special Branch detective (Brendan Gleeson) chasing after the militants as they plot their actions. It also has a strain of melodrama, as Maud is forced to make terrible sacrifices for the cause. What joins these narrative strands is the feminist insight that the subjugation of women extends from the highest reaches of government through the workplace and into the domestic sphere. They have no voice in Parliament, on the factory floor or at home, and while nobody ‰ÛÓ least of all Maud ‰ÛÓ supposes that the vote will solve everything, it will at least be a start.

‰ÛÏSuffragette,‰Ûù directed by Sarah Gavron from a screenplay by Abi Morgan, could easily have fallen into this kind of trap. The specific battle it chronicles ‰ÛÓ for the right of women to vote ‰ÛÓ was won, in Britain and the United States, a long time ago. Britain elected its first female prime minister in 1979; we might have a woman president before too long. A more conventional film about the fight for suffrage could easily have riled us up with a portrait of bygone oppression and then congratulated us on the progress we‰Ûªve made. But this one has an argument to make, or rather a series of arguments about the workings of patriarchal power, the complexities of political resistance and the economic implications of the right to vote. You might come for the feminism, stay for the class consciousness and arrive at the conclusion that they‰Ûªre not so distinct after all.

‰ÛÏSuffragette‰Ûù is an admirably modest movie. It does not quite have the grandeur and force of ‰ÛÏSelma,‰Ûù and the script has a few too many glowingly emotive speeches. The final turns of the tale are suspenseful, but also a bit frantic. But it is also stirring and cleareyed ‰ÛÓ the best kind of history lesson.

This does not mean that the film depicts all men as monsters, though Maud‰Ûªs supervisor (Geoff Bell) is a fine portrait of male depravity. But ‰ÛÏSuffragette‰Ûù also avoids the all-too-common tactics of placing a sympathetic member of the oppressor class at the center of the drama or making it all about the awakening of a man‰Ûªs conscience. Instead, it shows the limits of solidarity even when the sympathetic ties of family or class are involved. It also underlines the viciousness with which power reacts when it is challenged.

Ms. Streep is on hand more to supply a benediction than to play a fully dramatic role. One of the ways ‰ÛÏSuffragette‰Ûù escapes the traps of its genre is to focus not on the leadership but on the rank and file, on an ordinary woman whose life is changed by political engagement. Her name is Maud Watts, and she‰Ûªs played by Carey Mulligan with somber determination and inspiring pluck. Maud works in an industrial laundry, alongside her husband, Sonny (Ben Whishaw), and scores of women for whom dangerous labor, low pay and sexual harassment are matters of daily routine. Maud accepts her lot, finding happiness with Sonny and their young son, George. She is caught up in suffragist activities almost by accident, out of curiosity and loyalty to a co-worker (Anne-Marie Duff). Before long she is attending clandestine meetings in the back room of a pharmacy run by Edith Ellyn (Helena Bonham Carter).
‰ÛÏSuffragette‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, domestic and public. Running time: 1 hour 47 minutes.

Movies about the injustices of the past ‰ÛÓ and about the struggles to overcome them ‰ÛÓ are frequently prisoners of their own good intentions. Too often, attempts to illuminate the dark parts of history cast a complacent, flattering light on the present and turn history into a morality play or a horror show. The audience is invited to look back at how terrible things used to be and reflect on how much better they are now. The note of hard-won triumph that comes in the final scenes has the effect of tying up loose ends and suppressing uncomfortable continuities.

The actress Dorothy Tristan returns to the screen after a nearly 30-year absence in ‰ÛÏThe Looking Glass,‰Ûù a family drama she also wrote, and in which she‰Ûªs directed by her husband of four decades, John Hancock (‰ÛÏBang the Drum Slowly,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏPrancer‰Ûù). After a flurry of standout lead and supporting roles in the early ‰Ûª70s (in the likes of ‰ÛÏEnd of the Road,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏKlute‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏScarecrow‰Ûù), the strikingly beautiful and very talented Ms. Tristan was not always well used by Hollywood, so it‰Ûªs regrettable to have to note that this comeback is not an altogether auspicious one.

The strongest scenes in the picture are intimate exchanges, shot in close-up, between Ms. Tristan and the engaging Ms. Tarnow; Ms. Tarnow‰Ûªs interactions with Jeff Puckett, who plays a family friend, are similarly attention-getting. But the fact that the film‰Ûªs most resonant and likable portions are those in which nothing actually happens almost too nicely encapsulates why ‰ÛÏThe Looking Glass‰Ûù falls sadly flat throughout much of its running time.

‰ÛÏThe Looking Glass‰Ûù is set and was shot in LaPorte County in Indiana, where Ms. Tristan and Mr. Hancock live, and the movie has a bit of a homespun feel. Its story concerns an aged onetime actress (Ms. Tristan) who is looking after and mentoring her displaced and emotionally scarred 13-year-old granddaughter (Grace Tarnow). The film teems with overfamiliar commonplaces (the looming debilitation inherent in aging, the metaphor of an unseen neighbor‰Ûªs sorely neglected dog, and so on) as it saunters to its climax, at an elaborate local production of David Del Tredici‰Ûªs symphony ‰ÛÏFinal Alice.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏA decent girl won‰Ûªt roam around at 9 o‰Ûªclock at night‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ certainly not with a man who is not her father or brother. That‰Ûªs what Mukesh Singh, interviewed in Tihar Jail in Delhi in Leslee Udwin‰Ûªs documentary, ‰ÛÏIndia‰Ûªs Daughter,‰Ûù says about the young woman he and his friends picked up in their bus on Dec. 16, 2012. They raped her, brutalized her (Mr. Singh dispassionately recounts how one of them ‰ÛÏput his hand in her and pulled out something long ‰ÛÓ it was her intestines‰Ûù) and then dumped her by the side of the road. Sitting in his cell, Mr. Singh can‰Ûªt figure out what the big deal is. Things would have gone easier with her if she hadn‰Ûªt fought back, he says. And, after all, haven‰Ûªt others done worse?

The victim‰Ûªs story made headlines and incited protests across India about rape and the treatment of women. Ms. Udwin‰Ûªs film also made headlines: It was to air on Indian television but was banned because officials said they feared it would cause more civil unrest. If the contours of this story are well known from news accounts, Ms. Udwin adds some chilling images, especially the interviews with Mr. Singh and with his lawyers, who parrot similar ideas about appropriate conduct for young Indian women. (‰ÛÏKissing from the mouth is bad,‰Ûù one says.)
‰ÛÏIndia‰Ûªs Daughter‰Ûù is not rated. English and Hindi with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 3 minutes.

The tale that Ms. Udwin, a British filmmaker, tells is the one that captured the Indian imagination and made the victim‰Ûªs case a sensation: an aspirational young woman, modern and educated ‰ÛÓ she was a medical student; her parents sold their ancestral lands to pay for her schooling ‰ÛÓ cut down by men whose attitudes about women seem to come from a different world. At the end of her film, Ms. Udwin reminds us of the obvious ‰ÛÓ violence against women is not merely an Indian problem. But ‰ÛÏIndia‰Ûªs Daughter‰Ûù is a portrait of a place and time. And for all of its horrors, the movie has a positive message, too: Out of tragedy ‰ÛÓ and this case is just one of many ‰ÛÓ can come galvanizing change. RACHEL SALTZ
‰ÛÏJem and the Holograms‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) because there‰Ûªs a certain recklessness to the rock star life. Running time: 1 hour 52 minutes.

There are a few sweet moments early in ‰ÛÏJem and the Holograms,‰Ûù as we are reintroduced to the long-dormant characters from the three-decade-old animated series and see how they‰Ûªve been reimagined for a 2015 live-action film. But then the movie‰Ûªs lumbering, overstuffed, unfocused plot shows up, and whatever high hopes we might have had for this latest exploitation of 1980s nostalgia are slowly ground away.

The ‰ÛÏJem‰Ûù series, which ran from 1985 to 1988 and is fondly remembered by many who were young girls then, was a Hasbro product, and the movie is, too, which puts it in the lineage of ‰ÛÏBattleship‰Ûù and the various ‰ÛÏTransformers,‰Ûù among others. It‰Ûªs almost as noisy as those films because it‰Ûªs about a girl band that finds Internet fame and, apparently, a pile of rejected Katy Perry orchestration.

Erica ‰ÛÓ paging Yoko Ono ‰ÛÓ wants to break up the band and make Jem a solo act. Erica‰Ûªs son, Rio (Ryan Guzman), and Jem are flirting with romance. The girls‰Ûª aunt is having money problems. Jerrica is having identity problems ‰ÛÓ am I me or my rock star alter ego? ‰ÛÓ that were mined more engagingly in ‰ÛÏHannah Montana.‰Ûù

Instead, the movie, written by Ryan Landels and directed by Jon M. Chu, uses Synergy as an excuse for a treasure hunt subplot in which the girls, even as they‰Ûªre riding the fame monster, track down pieces of the robot that Dad, for some reason, left in hiding places years ago and that, improbably, are still there. But Synergy is just one thread in this undisciplined tangle.

As the story begins, Jerrica (Aubrey Peeples of TV‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNashville‰Ûù) and her sister, Kimber (Stefanie Scott), are being raised by their aunt (Molly Ringwald), along with two foster children, Aja (Hayley Kiyoko) and Shana (Aurora Perrineau). Kimber uploads a video of the painfully shy Jerrica singing, identifying her only as ‰ÛÏJem,‰Ûù and it quickly goes viral. Starlight, a record company run by the scheming Erica (Juliette Lewis), signs Jem, with the other three girls as her backup band.

Already, fans of the animated series will be noticing variations on the original story, in which Jerrica inherited part of Starlight and its charity, a group home for foster girls, when her father died. Here, all that her father, an inventor, has left her is a robot that she calls Synergy, which at first doesn‰Ûªt appear to work. In the cartoon, Synergy had magical powers that transformed Jerrica into the flashy Jem; in the movie, once Synergy finally wakes up and starts doing its thing, its powers aren‰Ûªt quite so fantastical.

The movie doesn‰Ûªt put enough effort into any of these subplots; it seems to be merely tossing ideas into the pot that it thinks might appeal to 9-year-olds. Its biggest sin, though, is to miss the girl-power allure of the cartoon, in which Jerrica, in addition to being a rock star, was also a businesswoman. Instead, it grabs for the YouTube generation by making Jem a heroine for every kid who has ever been fat-shamed, had parents who don‰Ûªt listen, has been anxious about sexual identity and so on. Homemade-looking videos, thanking Jem for giving voice to their concerns through her bland songs, keep cropping up to try to sell this conceit.

Both parents who loved the cartoon and their young children will see through this manipulation. If you hate spoilers, stop reading now: In case you were wondering what ever happened to the Misfits, the rival band that gave the animated series its driving dynamic, they eventually turn up here, though if you‰Ûªre in a hurry to leave the theater ‰ÛÓ which would be understandable ‰ÛÓ you might miss them.

A smorgasbord of empty calories, the Vin Diesel vehicle ‰ÛÏThe Last Witch Hunter,‰Ûù for all its overstuffed visuals, leaves you hungry. But not for more. Mr. Diesel plays Kaulder, who for 800 years has hunted followers of the dreaded Witch Queen, who cursed him with immortality around the time he impaled her with a fiery sword back in the medieval day. Now she‰Ûªs reawakening.
‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt know what happens next,‰Ûù Kaulder says near the end, to which Mr. Caine‰Ûªs priest responds: ‰ÛÏDo you know what mortals call that? Living.‰Ûù I call it a hint at an ill-advised sequel.

There‰Ûªs an insectlike monster with a glowing maw, which Mr. Diesel rides like a bronco, and a burly (Olafur Darri Olafsson) who kills Kaulder‰Ûªs blind friend (the Jim Jarmusch alumnus Isaach de BankolÌ©). But where are the witches? In displeasing representations: Runway models reveal their disfigured faces in mirrors; the queen‰Ûªs return darkens Manhattan‰Ûªs sky with swarms of bugs, prompting Mr. Caine‰Ûªs character to comment, ‰ÛÏLook at you, you ugly bitch of a morning.‰Ûù Ick. Almost all of the female characters are untrustworthy or vile except for Ms. Leslie‰Ûªs and, in flashbacks, Kaulder‰Ûªs fawning wife and daughter.

For millenniums, Kaulder has been attended by faithful priests called the Dolans; Michael Caine and Elijah Wood, both cashing paychecks here, are the 36th and 37th. One witch (Rose Leslie of ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones,‰Ûù deserving better material) signs on to help Kaulder, unaccountably happy to betray her queen.
‰ÛÏThe Last Witch Hunter‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Flaming swords, bug swarms, creeping misogyny.

At one point, Mr. GuzmÌÁn asks a wizened tribal woman the equivalents in her language for certain words, and hits a dead end: ‰ÛÏNo, not ‰Û÷God.‰Ûª We don‰Ûªt have that.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs the kind of mysterious yet crystallizing moment that the film is rich with. His introspection finds a kind of justice through poetry, and shows how memory must always be a continuing process.

Mr. GuzmÌÁn follows somewhat in the footsteps of his ‰ÛÏNostalgia for the Light,‰Ûù which grounded its ruminations in another Pinochet disposal area, the Atacama Desert. A master of voice-over and metaphor (the title alone has an amazing payoff), he sifts through essential truths and draws links between Chile‰Ûªs past and present inhabitants.

For decades, the Chilean filmmaker Patricio GuzmÌÁn has made nonfiction movies about his country‰Ûªs troubled history, specifically the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet and the murders and disappearances during Pinochet‰Ûªs regime that continue to reverberate. The subject exerts something like a tidal pull on Mr. GuzmÌÁn, but in ‰ÛÏThe Pearl Button‰Ûù he turns his lyrical, probing mind to the ocean that lines Chile‰Ûªs seemingly endless coast and defines his homeland.

Mr. GuzmÌÁn begins by simply depicting water and landscapes with mind-altering nature photography that primes us for his meditations on memory and loss. An exquisite essayist and intuitive interviewer, he embarks on a wondering examination of indigenous coastal tribes, subject to extermination long before Pinochet‰Ûªs crackdowns on civilians. From there, he discusses (and visualizes) one of that dictatorship‰Ûªs signature atrocities: flying helicopters over the Pacific to dump the bodies of torture victims into that vast anonymous grave.

Even by the standards of the Japanese provocateur Sion Sono, ‰ÛÏTokyo Tribe‰Ûù is an eccentric project: a hip-hop musical, its dialogue delivered almost entirely in rhymes, set in a near-future Tokyo ruled by rival gangs. It has a message, about the corrosive effects of the yakuza, but what matters is Mr. Sono‰Ûªs endless dexterity in moving masses of dancing, running and fighting people around big junkyard-like sets. The film has a simultaneously frantic and droning flow frequently punctuated by the bare breasts, panty shots and baroque violence familiar from Sono opuses like ‰ÛÏCold Fish‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLove Exposure.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏThe Warriors‰Ûù and the ‰ÛÏMad Max‰Ûù films will come to mind as you watch ‰ÛÏTokyo Tribe,‰Ûù and from scene to scene Mr. Sono‰Ûªs visual inventiveness and sure hand with action stand up to the comparison. The cumulative effect, however, is numbing. This has partly to do with the lyrics, which clearly suffer in translation, and with the effort it takes to keep track of all the gangs and characters, which were initially created for, and fleshed out in, a series of manga.

The biggest problem, though, is a screenplay by Mr. Sono that doesn‰Ûªt provide much motivation for all the insults, battles and chases (and casual mistreatment of women), besides some peace-and-love bromides and a deliberately juvenile plot point that surfaces near the end of the movie.

Some of Mr. Sono‰Ûªs images will stick with you, though, like the scene in which a boy uses his break-dancing footwork to pick the lock of a jail cell, or the chilly room, like something out of a Kubrick nightmare, whose minimalist furniture consists entirely of naked, white-painted extras.

A young, affluent California family ‰ÛÓ Ryan (Chris J. Murray); his wife, Emily (Brit Shaw); and their 6-ish daughter, Leila (Ivy George) ‰ÛÓ are settling into a sizable new home. It‰Ûªs Christmastime, and Ryan‰Ûªs mustachioed, somewhat hapless brother, Mike (Dan Gill), who has just broken up with a girlfriend, is moving in for a while. When Ryan and Mike find a video camera and a cache of old videos left by the previous residents, they unearth a strange history, some of it featuring Katie (Chloe Csengery) and Kristi (Jessica Brown), the young girls haunted by the malevolent and largely unseen wraith Tobi in ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity 3.‰Ûù Now Tobi is visiting Leila, to her parents‰Ûª alarm.

Most ‰ÛÏParanormal‰Ûù installments raise the technology bar a notch higher than their predecessor, often to diminished charm. ‰ÛÏParanormal 4‰Ûù played with Skype; ‰ÛÏThe Ghost Dimension‰Ûù ushers in 3-D, which, aside from floating specter dust, an impalement and tricks with flying furniture, doesn‰Ûªt bring much to the party. Nor does the plot. But then, the ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity‰Ûù movies have always been about carnival-ride sensations, the narrative through-line secondary. That‰Ûªs fortunate, because those seeking closure to what continuity there has been will go home mostly disappointed.

Cue a dark miasma gathering on the ceiling; mysterious writing appearing on Leila‰Ûªs bedroom wall; and a visit from a priest (Michael Krawic) attempting an ‰ÛÏextermination,‰Ûù he says, ‰ÛÏnot an exorcism.‰Ûù The child actor Aiden Lovekamp, from ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity 4,‰Ûù makes an appearance, but not the appealing Katie Featherston, whose presence enhanced other chapters in the series. Humor and jagged jump cuts, both series staples, are in abundant supply.

The folks behind ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension‰Ûù say that the film is the last in the found-footage horror series, and if so, the franchise concludes with more of an afterthought than a finale. While this installment ‰ÛÓ the sixth, if you include a spinoff ‰ÛÓ does acknowledge what slim legacy the series might have, it merely retains the qualities of the previous entries without adding much of significance.
‰ÛÏParanormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Naughty language and a suggestion of drug use. Running time: 1 hour 35 minutes.

Tears flow like the river under the house in which the title character (Hilda Koronel), a serene beauty and Filipino Everywoman, lives, works, endures and finally fights. The director, Mr. Brocka (1939-91), makes the house, a patchwork of metal, wood and cardboard, an early focal point, turning it into a microcosm of the sprawl and misery that surround it. Here, Insiang lives with her harsh, bullying mother, Tonya (an excellent Mona Lisa), and a gaggle of relatives that includes a fistful of young children. As Mr. Brocka plays with his framing, going from tight to wide, putting the scene‰Ûªs combustibility into stark visual terms, he transforms this one family into a pungent city.

As the relatives tumble into the street, their bodies creating a confusion of crying and yelling and jagged motion (a cacophony accompanied by Tonya‰Ûªs continuing tirade), they are all but swallowed up by a neighborhood contingent gathered outside. It‰Ûªs a raucous, seemingly chaotic scene that takes on an abrupt narrative clarity when Tonya insists that two of the children return the clothes that she bought for them, a demand that leaves them literally naked. And, just like that, two more children have joined the ranks of those who are seen wandering and playing amid the garbage. Mr. Brocka likes to go big and blunt, but in ‰ÛÏInsiang,‰Ûù he does his strongest work when he delivers his politics quietly, as when Insiang, in another scene, hangs wet laundry on barbed wire strung outside her house.

The story, written by Mario O‰ÛªHara and Lamberto Antonio, from a novel by Mr. O‰ÛªHara, is the least of it. The melodramatic machinery kicks in after Mr. Brocka oils it with some grim scene-setting, starting with the ghastly image of a pig being gutted in a slaughterhouse filled with screaming, dying animals that leads to a documentary portfolio of human squalor ‰ÛÓ all this turns out to be a warm-up for the brutalization of Insiang, including by Tonya. Having been abandoned by her faithless husband, Tonya has become the family‰Ûªs volubly aggrieved, increasingly impatient main breadwinner. Insiang picks up a little money doing laundry, but it‰Ûªs never enough, and one day, in a fury, Tonya evicts her husband‰Ûªs relatives.

The barbed wire suggests that ‰ÛÏInsiang‰Ûù is as much a national captivity narrative as it is a very specific suffering-woman saga (with shades of the classic maternal melodrama).
