After some Guggenheim family history, Ms. Vreeland tracks the heiress, hungry for a crowd of her own, on her travels: In bohemian Paris in the ‰Ûª20s, she fell in with the Dadaists; in London, she opened the Guggenheim Jeune gallery, credited with introducing Britain to Modern art; returning to New York, she opened the gallery Art of This Century, giving first shows to seemingly every major Abstract Expressionist.

Ms. Vreeland has paced her documentary well, a chapter to each era, with hundreds of beautiful images spanning decades of artists, galleries, parties, scenes. She also makes good use of interviews Guggenheim gave to a biographer a couple of years before her death in 1979. On those tapes, she reveals little, but her clipped, rushed manner, so offputting to some, seems reasonable after a lifetime of being underestimated.

As a collector, Guggenheim was shrewd, learning from her cohort ‰ÛÓ Marcel Duchamp, an early lover, ‰ÛÏwas my great, great teacher‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and going where the art was. In wartime Paris, for example, she bought the core of her collection cheaply from artists desperate to sell. As a personality, she was difficult ‰ÛÓ her memoir described many affairs ‰ÛÓ and she eventually moved to Venice, buying a palazzo and making a museum of her works.

‰ÛÏPeggy Guggenheim: Art Addict,‰Ûù Lisa Immordino Vreeland‰Ûªs sleek, entertaining portrait of the collector and gallerist who assembled one of the great troves of Modern art, cannot be accused of hagiography. From curators to historians to biographers, art world denizens describe Guggenheim‰Ûªs flaws and failings: She had no formal training; she used art to promote herself; she was a narcissist. And that‰Ûªs just in the first five minutes.

Sex fills some of the emptiness. Connections between Dominicans and tourists are made easily, and there is no stigma. Sex is just another local commodity, one that the Dominicans take much less seriously than their clients, who ply them with cash and trinkets. Variations of the same mutual exploitation are explored in Ulrich Seidl‰Ûªs cruel, corrosive comedy ‰ÛÏParadise: Love,‰Ûù set in Kenya, and in Laurent Cantet‰Ûªs deeper, more tragic ‰ÛÏHeading South,‰Ûù set in Haiti. Desire may dwindle with the passing years, but the memory of it is always there, lurking somewhere, waiting to be reawakened in a sultry tropical climate when there is time to dream.

Anne reveals her story in bits and pieces. Alienated from her 40-year-old son for reasons that are never given, she is a grandmother, but the whys and wherefores of her family history remain largely unexplored. Proud, devious and guarded, NoelÌ_ survives by selling her favors to older male tourists she picks up on the beach. She grudgingly supports Yeremi, who has little compunction about not working. He is not threatened by ‰ÛÏthe old woman,‰Ûù his dismissive term for Anne, nor does he ask NoelÌ_ about that relationship.

A coldhearted prude might be tempted to describe ‰ÛÏSand Dollars,‰Ûù an empathetic portrait of the relationship between Anne (Geraldine Chaplin), a forlorn older woman of means, and NoelÌ_ (Yanet Mojica), a lithe 20-year-old beauty in the Dominican Republic, as a condemnation of sexual tourism. But Ms. Chaplin, in one of her most touching screen performances, imbues Anne with a world-weary melancholy that makes your heart sink. She is in love, despite her better judgment. And her paramour loves her back ‰ÛÓ a little.

The bond between the women is affectionate as well as erotic, and the movie‰Ûªs depiction of sex unusually circumspect. When Anne arranges for NoelÌ_ to secure a visa and leave the Caribbean to live with her in Paris, it is impossible to imagine a happy ending. Yet you hope otherwise. No abundance of good intentions can reconcile the age gap and power differential that both draws them together and keeps them apart.

Unbeknown to Anne, NoelÌ_ and her layabout boyfriend, Yeremi (Ricardo Ariel Toribio), whom NoelÌ_ passes off as her brother, have hatched a plan whereby NoelÌ_, once in Paris, will send him money each month. When Anne takes NoelÌ_ on a shopping spree, you begin to have an idea of how lavish her new life might be.

Ms. Chaplin, gaunt and weathered at 71, exudes an ethereal fragility. Beneath Anne‰Ûªs composure runs a silent current of desperation. In a foolhardy gesture, Anne, while at the beach with NoelÌ_, impulsively dives into the surf and swims much too far from shore for safety and returns exhausted. As the camera observes her trembling, blue-eyed gaze through smudged eye makeup, she conveys the sad self-knowledge of someone who understands full well that true love can‰Ûªt be bought but is too besotted to pull away.

‰ÛÏSand Dollars‰Ûù is the third feature written and directed by the husband-and-wife team Israel CÌÁrdenas and Laura Amelia GuzmÌÁn. Freely adapted from a novel by the French author Jean-NoÌÇl Pancrazi, the film portrays a tropical way of life in which time stretches out as a void waiting to be filled. In Las Terrenas, where the movie is set, you don‰Ûªt hear the words ‰ÛÏcareer‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏdeadline.‰Ûù Cocktail hour can be any time of day. One lazy afternoon, Anne, drinking alone on the beach, falls on her face while getting up from her chair.
‰ÛÏSand Dollars‰Ûù is not rated. In Spanish, English and French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes

NoelÌ_‰Ûªs most revealing scene is in a doctor‰Ûªs office where she discovers she is pregnant and confesses that she has already had one abortion. One night while riding her motorbike, she crashes and injures her hand, and for a while disappears from Anne‰Ûªs life, leaving the older woman distraught. Anne‰Ûªs only confidant, Thomas (Hoyt Rogers), a gay man of a certain age and fellow hotel guest, shares her attitude of bittersweet resignation.

Mr. SembÌ¬ne‰Ûªs films form the documentary‰Ûªs spine. Clips and feisty interview appearances show his fearlessness in a country with no cinematic tradition, during an era scarred by the problems of colonialism. From ‰ÛÏBlack Girl‰Ûù (about a maid who loses her self after being brought to France) to ‰ÛÏMoolaadÌ©‰Ûù (on female circumcision), his features confront the ills of modernity and tradition alike. If Mr. SembÌ¬ne was absent as a husband and father, and by some accounts willing to betray people in the name of making a film, he told stories that prized freedom.

Cinema is lucky that Mr. SembÌ¬ne, who lived to 84, was one tough customer. Although he would become a global voice of Africa on film, he grew up the son of a fisherman; working the docks in Marseille, he broke his back, read voraciously and became a novelist. His belief that film could help Africa speak infused his technique with not only a robust humanism and dramatic vigor but also a clear-eyed view of injustice at home and abroad.
Mr. SembÌ¬ne was an inspiration; as a film, ‰ÛÏSembÌ¬ne!‰Ûù is something less than that, petering out as it goes on, but at least offering a fair-minded tribute to a master.

Though its title, ‰ÛÏSembÌ¬ne!,‰Ûù might suggest a musical, this film is closer to a college seminar, Ousmane SembÌ¬ne 101. A documentary about Mr. SembÌ¬ne, the trailblazing Senegalese filmmaker, this movie covers the essentials about a cultural warrior whose nine varied features and assorted shorts could still use better recognition. But the film, by Samba Gadjigo, a professor and SembÌ¬ne biographer, and Jason Silverman, is more dutiful than deep, and is bogged down by Mr. Gadjigo‰Ûªs drab asides about himself.

‰ÛÏThe House That Jack Built,‰Ûù a New York City kitchen sink drama, was written by the Bronx-born filmmaker Joseph Vasquez (‰ÛÏHangin‰Ûª With the Homeboys‰Ûù), who died in 1995. The movie overflows with pungent street flavor: yelling in stairwells, confrontations, threats, countless expletives and the occasional family gathering. But as directed by Henry Barrial, there is solid ensemble acting, particularly by Mr. Bonilla, who dependably anchors a movie that is almost too busy.

There is theatrical excess, as well, in the unrelenting pileup of dramatic situations, which hobbles the film‰Ûªs credibility. In particular, Jack‰Ûªs problem with his sister‰Ûªs sexuality and his mother‰Ûªs blindness to his line of work defy belief. A third-act crisis, somewhat out of left field, leaves the film suspended in unresolved issues. That‰Ûªs not necessarily a bad thing, but it feels like a cop-out here.

Poor Jack (E. J. Bonilla) ‰ÛÓ so many things on his plate. His drug-dealing business at the corner bodega, which enabled him to buy the building where his family lives, is threatened by rival dealers; the marriage of his brother (Leo Minaya) is in trouble; he wants his sister (Rosal ColÌ_n), a lesbian, to stop seeing her girlfriend (and hopes to ‰ÛÏcure‰Ûù her by having a buddy sleep with her); his pregnant girlfriend (Melissa Fumero) won‰Ûªt stop asking about marriage; and his alcoholic father (John Herrera) keeps bickering with his mother (Saundra Santiago). But we know that Jack is decent, because he beats up a drug addict pimping out his own daughter.
‰ÛÏThe Peanuts Movie‰Ûù is rated G. Running time: 1 hour 28 minutes.

‰ÛÏThe Peanuts Movie‰Ûù may be simultaneously the most charming and the most daring experiment in human genetics ever conducted. At issue is whether the character summaries and back stories of fictional pop-culture figures can be passed from one generation to the next solely through DNA.

The genetics experiment comes into play with the many side bits in the movie, ones that will mean something to longtime ‰ÛÏPeanuts‰Ûù fans but go by so quickly that first-timers may be puzzled. Why is that dog trying to snatch that kid‰Ûªs blanket? Why does that girl keep acting strangely around the piano-playing boy? How come one girl is calling another girl ‰ÛÏsir‰Ûù? This is especially true of extended aerial battles that Snoopy has with the Red Baron (the visual high points of the movie‰Ûªs 3-D incarnation), a sort of movie-within-the-movie that may require a little explanation.

The movie is a pleasant G-rated grab bag of everything people over a certain age know and love from the Charles M. Schulz comic strip and its many offshoots, all centered, of course, on Charlie Brown. The question, though, is whether the 7-year-old demographic will fully grasp the intricate dynamics of the universe Schulz created around Charlie Brown over many decades.

The main story in the film will appeal to them regardless. Charlie Brown (voiced by Noah Schnapp) is smitten with his new neighbor, the Little Red-Haired Girl (Francesca Angelucci Capaldi), but all of his efforts to impress her end badly. There seems to be an opportunity when our blundering hero manages a perfect score on a standardized test and is to be honored at a school assembly, but once Charlie Brown realizes that the score is a mistake, his moment of triumph turns into an ethical dilemma instead.

It‰Ûªs a bit startling, and undeniably refreshing, to see a children‰Ûªs movie that doesn‰Ûªt involve a villain‰Ûªs effort to seize a princess‰Ûªs kingdom or some other high-stakes power struggle but instead is driven by the small anxieties a real child might experience on a daily basis. Charlie Brown is just an ordinary kid trying to find a comfortable place in an ordinary but daunting world. Rather than taking the pint-size moviegoers in the audience out of their realm of experience, the way fantasy-driven fare does, this movie, directed by Steve Martino, meets them on their own turf. (One nice touch that young viewers may or may not appreciate: As with ‰ÛÏA Charlie Brown Christmas,‰Ûù almost all of the character voices are provided by actual children, not adults with childlike voices.)

Or maybe not. If all of these things are perfectly clear to today‰Ûªs kiddies, we will have positive proof of fictional-character DNA transference. The mind boggles. That future children will be born already knowing the Harry Potter mythology isn‰Ûªt too alarming, but picture those infants also already knowing the more vile scenes from ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones.‰Ûù Ick.

Young children may have a passing acquaintance with the ‰ÛÏPeanuts‰Ûù gang from the annual holiday television specials and such, but presumably they aren‰Ûªt as thoroughly versed as youngsters of yore who read the comic strip daily and grew up in a time when the characters were as famous as any in the land.

With the help of photographs, newsreels and home movies, Mr. Sands retraces the men‰Ûªs family histories. He later accompanies the two to the site of a mass grave; their fathers were responsible for the murders there.

While researching the Nuremberg trials, Philippe Sands, a human-rights lawyer who lost members of his family in the Holocaust, came in contact with Niklas Frank. Mr. Frank‰Ûªs father, Hans, was known as the Butcher of Poland: a Nazi complicit in the slaughter of millions, who was tried for his crimes and executed. Mr. Sands also met Horst von WÌ_chter, whose father, Otto, was another high-ranking Nazi official.

David Evans, the director, also makes good use of the silences that fall among his subjects. Though, at times, it seems that nothing can be said of such horrors, remembrance is imperative. While these men aren‰Ûªt accountable for the actions of their fathers, they are obligated to recognize the truth of what happened. To see one of them deny that truth is difficult to watch, and just as hard to look away from.

That‰Ûªs the first sentence spoken in ‰ÛÏWhat Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy,‰Ûù and those that follow don‰Ûªt get any easier. Right from the start, this involving documentary asks much of its audience and poses questions that are unnerving yet engrossing.

Mr. Frank and Mr. von WÌ_chter, both now in their 70s, reflect on the emotions they felt as a result of their heritage. One man is eager to denounce his father. The other is an apologist whose excuses are infuriating. Their interactions and debates are civil yet intense.
‰ÛÏImagine what it must be like to grow up as the child of a mass murderer.‰Ûù

The subject of ‰ÛÏMadam Phung‰Ûªs Last Journey‰Ûù describes herself and the carnival family in orbit around her as neither male nor female but half and half ‰ÛÓ citizens who have no place within the strictures of Vietnam‰Ûªs official society and few opportunities for legitimate employment.
The group is always one crisis away from disaster, karmic credit notwithstanding. But saucy as ever, Madame Phung knows she can walk that line: ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm not scared of dying, but aging,‰Ûù she says.

Inches from performers shimmying into costumes, the lens‰Ûªs uncritical eye catches one young singer as she carefully daubs her cheeks with geisha-white foundation, another who has a delicate face but ravaged teeth, even an insect crawling up the tarp ‰ÛÏwall‰Ûù of a dressing room. Gentle, coaxing questions from off camera draw out their stories.

Bich Phung gives them a place. A natural leader, she is, at 40, a star, an impresario and a protector of a collection of slim-hipped boys with glittering eye shadow, extreme false lashes and marabou headpieces. Once a monk ‰ÛÓ she bolted when she was tempted by the beauty of some visitors to the temple ‰ÛÓ she remains a guardian of spiritual tradition, traveling with a large statue of a female bodhisattva and performing rituals to honor the ancestors.
Madam Phung confesses that she has high hopes for this documentary as a way to spread understanding: ‰ÛÏThey‰Ûªll see homosexuals‰Ûª everyday life, how hard it is,‰Ûù she said.
‰ÛÏMadam Phung‰Ûªs Last Journey,‰Ûù in Vietnamese, with English subtitles, is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 27 minutes.
And Madam Phung, her eyes on the future as well on as the past, takes the film crew along to a Buddhist pagoda where she gets a karma reading to find an auspicious time for some repairs.

Nguyen Thi Tham, who wrote, directed and shot the film, followed Madam Phung for a year as she took her brand of transgender glamour to remote provincial fairgrounds filled with villagers. Mostly, though, the camera reveals boisterous drunks. And after the stage is dark, violence breaks out more than once between cast members and thugs, and Madam Phung appeases the police with a case of beer.

Madame Hang, who runs the shooting gallery of the traveling show, is drowning in debt. At 46, she, too, is an elder of the troupe. When she talks about her past at an after-work gathering, she raises a shot glass to her lips with pinkie crooked in a concession to refinement.

‰ÛÏRock in the Red Zone‰Ûù has its best moments when it explores the anxiety of Sderot‰Ûªs residents and their endurance. It‰Ûªs the strongest topic here, and the one you‰Ûªre most sorry to see interrupted when the film inevitably switches over to something else.

‰ÛÏRock in the Red Zone‰Ûù takes place in Sderot, Israel, a town that has for years been the target of rockets launched from Gaza. Despite the attacks and the resulting casualties, the residents have persevered.

What starts out promising, however, soon rambles. There‰Ûªs a lengthy digression into the birth of Israel and immigration; talk of the psychological problems of citizens in a war zone; discussions of racial discrimination; surveys of bomb shelters; scenes from Ms. Bialis‰Ûªs engagement and marriage in Sderot; footage of a happy party she once attended; and so on.
The town is known for its rock music, and Laura Bialis, the director, initially flirts with an intriguing topic: the relationship between strife and creativity.

Long before the director inserts scenes from her own wedding video into ‰ÛÏRock in the Red Zone,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs apparent that she‰Ûªs grown quite close to her subject. A lack of critical distance isn‰Ûªt always fatal to a documentary. But here, that segment is just one more piece in an often scattershot project.
‰ÛÏRock in the Red Zone,‰Ûù in English and Hebrew, with English subtitles, is not rated. Running time: 1 hour and 27 minutes.

Each might be notable. Yet taken together, they give the film the feel of an unfocused travelogue. It doesn‰Ûªt help that the chatty voice-over by Ms. Bialis can seem shallow (‰ÛÏI loved hanging out with these guys‰Ûù; ‰ÛÏI felt an almost mystical connection that I couldn‰Ûªt describe‰Ûù) and that subtitled song lyrics are overused throughout.

Or at least in the California desert, where Mr. Turkington, known simply as the Comedian (and playing a version of his real-life stand-up persona, Neil Hamburger), schlumps from one seedy, underpopulated gig to another. Onstage, carefully arranged strands of comb-over cling to his pallid forehead like wet seaweed, and spare drinks nestle in the crook of his arm. Whether he‰Ûªs spewing tasteless riddles or responding to hecklers, his act is a sewer of misogyny, homophobia and sexual insult. There is also an unspoken sense that his audiences ‰ÛÓ trimmings of humanity trapped in a soulless limbo of dust and dive bars ‰ÛÓ deserve no better.

Even if he were, there‰Ûªs a strange nobility to this downward odyssey that‰Ûªs hard to shake off. Snippets of well-chosen music appear judiciously, though not in the movie‰Ûªs best scene: a squirmy bathroom encounter between the comedian and a tense young stranger (a perfect Michael Cera). When the comic warns his new acquaintance to back off, we know the younger man would do well to listen. JEANNETTE CATSOULIS
‰ÛÏEntertainment‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Foul language, flowing alcohol and frightening midwifery.

Watching ‰ÛÏEntertainment‰Ûù is a profoundly uncomfortable, some would say repellent, experience that isn‰Ûªt easily forgotten. Yet I left this barbed portrait of a cracking-up comic with more than a little respect for its fearless director, Rick Alverson, and his trusting star, Gregg Turkington. You can‰Ûªt deny that they‰Ûªre a match made in heaven.

Capturing a world of flyblown mirrors and sad carpeting, where shirts are washed in motel room sinks, and terrible things happen in public restrooms, Mr. Alverson jacks up the tension with exquisite restraint. Winding scene after scene to a breaking point, he brings our discomfort to a rolling boil, then quietly backs away. Amplified by the stillness of Lorenzo Hagerman‰Ûªs camera, these moments inspire an apprehension that feels slightly sadistic, as if Mr. Alverson were enjoying his screw-turning a little too much.

In Mr. Audley‰Ûªs capable hands, Gene becomes slightly more than an arbitrary conceit, but his co-stars are little more than quirky Belle and Sebastian songs in human form who bond through games of peekaboo and share status as heirs to fortunes. Gene helps Titty with talking to women. A subplot about militant animal activists lends the wispy story some plot fodder, but a shocking revelation about Ginger‰Ûªs past is more than the uneven film can bear.

The story opens with Gene (Kentucker Audley, the film‰Ûªs standout by a country mile), an earnest yet ineffectual motormouth, going door to door talking about the issue of childhood obesity. One house, a mansion, yields the film‰Ûªs second strange specimen: a rich and odd kid named Titty (Olly Alexander), who has the air and social graces of a stunned toddler. Titty has a web-chat crush, Ginger (Joslyn Jensen), a surly young woman who lives alone with a rabbit.

At one point, Gene expresses frustration that Titty hasn‰Ûªt asked him about his life or well-being. You might find yourself raising your own basic objections to the dramatic deficiencies of ‰ÛÏFunny Bunny.‰Ûù

Three characters in various states of arrested development would be a tall order for most films, and it proves too much for one as enamored of the fey and absurd as Alison Bagnall‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFunny Bunny.‰Ûù Ms. Bagnall‰Ûªs baffling story about a trio of oddball outsiders is stricken with a galloping case of romantic whimsy and falls short of its serio-comic aspirations.

But Vaughn has a sick daughter and a face like a rumpled bed you never want to get out of, so who cares about the hostages? Not his accomplice, Cox (Dave Bautista), a side of beef on legs who can‰Ûªt hold a gun and a thought simultaneously, and certainly not the cocky cop (a zippy Mark-Paul Gosselaar) who‰Ûªs itching to run the bus off the road. Its cargo might just be crowdsourced clichÌ©s ‰ÛÓ the precariously pregnant woman; the weaponized good ol‰Ûª boy ‰ÛÓ but Mr. Mann, jamming his camera tight against the action, gives everything a pulpy vigor that‰Ûªs mindlessly entertaining.

As a treat, he also gives us Robert De Niro as the wearily ruthless casino owner ‰ÛÓ a role this actor could sleepwalk through and no one would be the wiser. It won‰Ûªt erase the embarrassment of ‰ÛÏThe Intern‰Ûù (2015), but I doubt there‰Ûªs anything that will do that. JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

If the result doesn‰Ûªt give you indigestion, you can thank Jeffrey Dean Morgan, who has spent much of his career elevating ho-hum movies and classing up television series. Here, his signature blend of relaxed authenticity and low-key charm is on full blast to persuade us that his character, Vaughn ‰ÛÓ a longtime 21 dealer at a mob-owned casino ‰ÛÓ is a stand-up guy. This is very hard to do when he‰Ûªs just robbed the most poorly guarded vault in casino history and hijacked a bus filled with innocent commuters.

Whatever its flaws, ‰ÛÏHeist‰Ûù is to be commended for repeatedly finding ways to distract us from them. Battling a preposterous plot and second-tier performances that are, at best, serviceable, this roll-along thriller from Scott Mann works its keister off to turn beef jerky into chateaubriand.
‰ÛÏHeist‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Choose family over Family ‰ÛÓ and public over private transportation ‰ÛÓ at your peril.

These sometimes eclipse Bergman‰Ûªs free-spirited ways, which didn‰Ûªt always account for other people. Isabella explains that after her mother and father split, the Rossellini children didn‰Ûªt have everyday access to their parents, who went off to live with their new families, leaving them in what Isabella calls ‰ÛÏa children‰Ûªs home‰Ûù in Rome. ‰ÛÏShe came when she could,‰Ûù Ingrid says of their mother, adding, ‰ÛÏI missed her a lot.‰Ûù The children saw their father for Sunday lunch, yet it was their mother they seemed to long for and still do. ‰ÛÏI just missed her presence,‰Ûù Ms. Lindstrom says. ‰ÛÏAnd because she was so delightfully open and amusing, I craved, my whole life, to have more of her.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a bittersweet moment, one that suggests the true depths of yet another of Bergman‰Ûªs great love stories.

Bergman‰Ûªs voluminous personal archives have been a valuable resource for assorted popular biographies and academic studies, enriching the historical record of her films, family and loves. As its title indicates, ‰ÛÏIngrid Bergman ‰ÛÓ In Her Own Words‰Ûù tells yet another version of that life, through its subject‰Ûªs words and pictures, embellishing them with written and on-camera reminiscences from both intimates and acquaintances. Ms. Rossellini appears, as does her twin, Ingrid, and their older brother, Roberto. They‰Ûªre joined by their half sister, Pia Lindstrom, and a few others, including the academic Jeanine Basinger and two actresses with whom Bergman performed, Liv Ullmann (in ‰ÛÏAutumn Sonata‰Ûù) and Sigourney Weaver (in the play ‰ÛÏThe Constant Wife‰Ûù).

Directed by Stig Bjorkman, ‰ÛÏIn Her Own Words‰Ûù is cinephile catnip. For those who love Bergman, the behind-the-scenes images ‰ÛÓ many taken by her ‰ÛÓ are particularly delightful for the glimpses they offer of both her professional life (Hitchcock tooling around in a backyard) and personal (notably, the charming home movies of her life with her second husband, the Italian director Roberto Rossellini). When she wasn‰Ûªt performing for the camera ‰ÛÓ or writing one of her many letters, some read here by Alicia Vikander ‰ÛÓ Bergman, whose father owned a camera store, was often looking through a lens herself. She seems to have been a relentless moviemaker, particularly of people, from screen comrades to her children, some of whom feel rather more like extras than co-stars.

Ingrid Bergman, whose personal life could seem more electrifying than her movies, had the kind of towering self-possession that is a requisite for immortal stars, but also for modern women. Toward the end of her life, when her daughter Isabella Rossellini asked why she had kept so many letters, diaries, photos and other mementos, Bergman responded with consummate movie-star sang-froid: ‰ÛÏI always knew I was going to be famous.‰Ûù (She died in 1982 at 67.) Ms. Rossellini shared this anecdote in The New Yorker in 1989, in a Talk of the Town item in which she described her mother‰Ûªs trove ‰ÛÓ letters from Alfred Hitchcock and Ernest Hemingway included ‰ÛÓ and its meaning.

For those who know Bergman only as a Hitchcock brunette or as the dewy beauty who should have walked off with Humphrey Bogart in ‰ÛÏCasablanca,‰Ûù it may be hard to grasp that starting in the late 1940s, she became an international scandal by running off with Rossellini, ostensibly to make ‰ÛÏStromboli.‰Ûù They made the film and, while she was married to her first husband, Petter Lindstrom, a child. It was an affair that seemed to have started with a letter or maybe a shared dream. ‰ÛÏI was bored. I felt as if it was the end of growing,‰Ûù she is quoted as saying in an early biography ‰ÛÓ bored, too, it seemed, with a Hollywood she once sought. ‰ÛÏI was searching for something, I knew not what.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏIngrid Bergman ‰ÛÓ In Her Own Words‰Ûù is not rated. In Swedish, English, Italian and French, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 54 minutes.

Rossellini‰Ûªs films seemed to have helped her understand what she was searching for. ‰ÛÏDear Mr. Rossellini,‰Ûù she wrote in what became a famous letter, ‰ÛÏI saw your films ‰Û÷Open City‰Ûª and ‰Û÷Paisan,‰Ûª and enjoyed them very much. If you need a Swedish actress who speaks English very well, who has not forgotten her German, who is not very understandable in French, and who, in Italian knows only ‰Û÷Ti amo‰Ûª‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏI love you‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏI am ready to come and make a film with you.‰Ûù Bergman ended it with her kind regards. To which the great man responded, ‰ÛÏWell, who is this Ingrid Bergman?‰Ûù

This anecdote appears in Tag Gallagher‰Ûªs fantastic deep dive, ‰ÛÏThe Adventures of Roberto Rossellini: His Life and Films,‰Ûù which covers some of the same events that appear in ‰ÛÏIn Her Own Words‰Ûù and also fills in some of the documentary‰Ûªs holes. Part of what makes ‰ÛÏIn Her Own Words‰Ûù so pleasurable is that it‰Ûªs so insistently celebratory, despite the traumas and hurts that trickle in. To that upbeat end, it tends to soften and even elide some of the thornier passages in Bergman‰Ûªs life, including her painful public break with her first husband, Mr. Lindstrom, with whom she had a child, Pia Lindstrom. Only occasionally, as when Ms. Lindstrom tightens a smile here or one of the Rossellini children voices regret about their mother‰Ûªs absences, do shadows emerge.

The game continues in ‰ÛÏBy the Sea,‰Ûù which starts lightly enough with Vanessa and Roland‰Ûªs moving into a French hotel nestled in a Mediterranean cove seemingly used only by a single diligent fisherman and a few desultory extras. (Malta plays the South of France, if not especially convincingly.) There, they set up house with piles of Louis Vuitton luggage and bottles of booze and pills, as well as a red manual typewriter. A novelist, Roland has come to the hotel to work but ends up spending most of his time at the local bar, his pen impotently hovering over white pages, while Vanessa lounges in and out of bed, her ruined eye makeup streaking her wet face like black tears. These salty pearls are the foundation for the story that she will write, one monumental tear at a time.

It isn‰Ûªt long into ‰ÛÏBy the Sea‰Ûù that curiosity morphs into impatience as you wonder what Ms. Jolie Pitt means to do with her tears and poses and whether she‰Ûªs actually starting to punish you for wanting to look at her. Like a lot of stars, she has no problem making you wait. But she‰Ûªs also clearly working within the idiom of the classic art film, including through her deployment of narrative and character ambiguity. (The catchy soundtrack includes a song from Chantal Goya, the yÌ©-yÌ© pop star of Jean-Luc Godard‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMasculin FÌ©minin.‰Ûù) Vanessa‰Ûªs tears may be personal (and explained in one of the least persuasive scenes), but they flow from the same wellspring that has given us the female tears and snot that have streamed through art cinema since at least Carl Theodor Dreyer‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Passion of Joan of Arc.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs an unusual, at times destabilizing act when a woman both directs and puts herself on camera simply because it upends (still!) the historical balance in which men paint and shoot the pictures. The persistence of that inequity (and the world‰Ûªs comfort with that imbalance) is one reason that it‰Ûªs a creative choice when male directors and critically sanctioned artists like Miranda July turn the camera on themselves, but mere vulgar vanity when the popular likes of Barbra Streisand does. For her part, Ms. Jolie Pitt, a woman of well-publicized extremes, isn‰Ûªt content to merely parade around on screen; from shot to shot, she makes herself a full-scale cinematic spectacle, all but forcing her image on you. And, then, she does what you least expect: She surprises you by shifting Vanessa‰Ûªs gaze ‰ÛÓ and yours ‰ÛÓ to the hot couple next door.

And, man, does she know how to make an entrance. Supremely self-aware, Ms. Jolie Pitt introduces her marrieds ‰ÛÓ Vanessa and Roland ‰ÛÓ like the international movie stars they‰Ûªre played by, with the two roaring into the picture in a silver CitroÌÇn convertible with Mr. Pitt behind the wheel. They look as glamorous as a Vanity Fair spread, he in his sporty mustache and porkpie hat and she in an animal-print hat the size of a beach umbrella. It‰Ûªs the kind of statement accessory that you can imagine Elizabeth Taylor upstaging when she went tootling around with her husband, Richard Burton, back when they were co-starring, on screen and off, as the world‰Ûªs most famous couple.

Ms. Jolie Pitt takes chances in ‰ÛÏBy the Sea,‰Ûù including with the audience‰Ûªs patience and its laughter, and it proves far more adventurous than her previous feature as a director, ‰ÛÏUnbroken,‰Ûù a dully hagiographic biopic about the Olympian Louis Zamperini. Despite some early flashes of levity, ‰ÛÏBy the Sea‰Ûù seems as if it‰Ûªs terminally (and unconsciously) headed into self-parody or climes as grim as her earlier films when it takes an abrupt, unexpectedly witty and notionally perverse turn. (Her feature directing debut was the war movie ‰ÛÏIn the Land of Blood and Honey.‰Ûù) One day, Vanessa notices a sizable hole in the hotel room, leans into it like a distaff Norman Bates and begins spying on the young newlyweds next door (MÌ©lanie Laurent and Melvil Poupaud as Lea and FranÌ_ois), an interest that evolves into a passion that she later shares with Roland.

Meta with a vengeance, ‰ÛÏBy the Sea‰Ûù stars Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt as itinerant married artists who are suffering, beautifully, through a rough patch. Any resemblance to real life is strictly coincidental and completely intentional. At first luxurious blush it‰Ûªs a jet-setting marital melodrama, one of those he-said, she-said (and wept) encounter sessions decked with designer shades, to-die-for digs and millionaire tears. More interestingly, the movie, which Ms. Jolie Pitt wrote and directed, is a knowing or at least a ticklishly amusing demonstration of celebrity and its relay of gazes from one of the most looked-at women in the world. Take, watch, she seems to say, this is my body.

Every so often, the story, such as it is, switches over to Roland, who does most of his drinking, eating and not-writing in the company of the amiable barman, Michel (the great French actor Niels Arestrup), and the less voluble hotel owner, Patrice (Richard Bohringer, another welcome French face). Ms. Jolie Pitt may be married to one of the world‰Ûªs most famous men, but despite an occasional beauty shot of Mr. Pitt, she doesn‰Ûªt showcase him as an object of desire. For a long initial stretch, he instead plays the cozy, intimate role of the seemingly weary, inattentive husband, sometimes with stubble and boxer shorts, at other times with a perfunctory goodbye or a slammed door. Given Vanessa‰Ûªs waterworks, it‰Ûªs hard not to feel for the guy.

In effect, she turns Lea and FranÌ_ois into the movie‰Ûªs other Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt: the sexy, teasingly elusive and insistently watched couple who are often seen through a peephole that hides as much as it reveals. It‰Ûªs a surprisingly funny, spiky development partly because it transforms Vanessa into a voyeur, and a ravenous one at that. Lea and FranÌ_ois evolve into a marital aid for Vanessa and Roland, but with complications, as the peephole becomes a narrative rabbit hole leading to old hurts. That Vanessa is, however, also an audience member, a moviegoer of a type, becomes even clearer when the (unsurprising) tragic root of her tears is revealed, a disclosure that can be read as an acid commentary on those who watch, desire and live through others. Ms. Jolie Pitt may not mind if you look ‰ÛÓ but watch out!

And so Vanessa weeps and she weeps, sometimes while framed in a window of the hotel and generally while dressed in one of her black or white negligees. Working with the excellent cinematographer Christian Berger, Ms. Jolie Pitt seems to be giving her audience exactly what it demands, on screen and off: herself. In medium shots and close-ups, in daytime and night, she turns her face and body (or rather Vanessa‰Ûªs) into a landscape of classic feminine suffering, becoming our latest cinematic lady of perpetual misery. In one shot, Vanessa stands at a window smoking, her eyes hidden behind her oversize Yves Saint Laurent glasses; in another, she sits on a bed, eyes shiny and unfocused; in another, she stretches out catlike on a chair until her body fills the frame from coifed head to perfect toe.

‰ÛÏBy the Sea‰Ûù takes place in the early 1970s, just around the time Liz and Dick were starring in ‰ÛÏDivorce His, Divorce Hers,‰Ûù a marital made-for-TV drama that, like some of the big-screen films they made together, played on the similarities between the actors and their characters. (Their lives imitated fiction again when they announced their separation after the movie‰Ûªs broadcast.) It‰Ûªs impossible to imagine Ms. Jolie Pitt rip-roaring it up in public like Taylor, who lived her life out loud as she perfected playing Elizabeth Taylor, the role of a lifetime. Ms. Jolie Pitt, by contrast, like others in her elite Madonna-schooled sorority (BeyoncÌ©, et al.), has been engaged in an exceptionally skilled version of celebrity peekaboo for some time ‰ÛÓ now you see the ‰ÛÏreal‰Ûù her, now you don‰Ûªt.
‰ÛÏBy the Sea‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sex and nipples. Running time: 2 hours 2 minutes.

Mr. Barbosa and his cinematographer, Pedro Sotero, choose smooth, colorful surfaces and capacious compositions for their film, ensconcing Jean in a world that his family may no longer be able to afford. Mr. Cavalcanti, new to the screen, has a natural manner, by turns tentative and blustering. That offsets the prim confidence of some of Mr. Barbosa‰Ûªs grand design (which draws from his personal experience). Through his naÌøvetÌ©, Jean illuminates the world around him.

In his first feature film, Mr. Barbosa blends tales of a coming-of-age and a burgeoning class consciousness, and never loses sympathy for Jean (Thales Cavalcanti). The oafish adolescent sinks in social status at school, owing money left and right, like his father (Marcello Novaes, a soap opera star whose looks help express the superficiality of this well-drawn family‰Ûªs stability). Jean‰Ûªs mother (Suzana Pires) must stoop to selling makeup to bring in money; Jean distracts himself with a flirtatious maid and, more age-appropriately, a quick-witted teenager (Bruna Amaya) he meets on the bus.

Fellipe Barbosa‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCasa Grande‰Ûù opens with a shot of a house in Rio de Janeiro, piled high with rooms and viewed from a backyard with a swimming pool and hot tub. The opulence conceals a rot within the household. Dad has been playing fast and loose with his hedge fund, and soon his 17-year-old son, Jean, is taking the bus to school instead of the customary car with driver.

Before James begins to face his uncertain future, he travels to Mexico, where he meets a young woman who accompanies him back to New York after news arrives that Gail has taken a turn for the worse. The moment of truth has arrived.

This feature directorial debut of Josh Mond, who also wrote this film and who produced ‰ÛÏMartha Marcy May Marlene,‰Ûù is an exquisitely acted portrait of Gail and James‰Ûªs fraught bond. Gail, who loves her son unconditionally, gently prods him to find his own place and get a job. But even when she reprimands him, her tone is forgiving.

Ms. Nixon gives one of the year‰Ûªs most heart-rending screen performances. James and Gail‰Ûªs scenes evoke the most poignant moments of Margaret Edson‰Ûªs play, ‰ÛÏWit,‰Ûù whose 2012 revival starred Ms. Nixon as a dying cancer patient.

A latter-day slacker with vague writing ambitions, James sleeps on a couch in Gail‰Ûªs apartment, where he is her fly-by-night caretaker. As the story begins, she is being treated for Stage 4 cancer. There is talk of his getting a job at New York Magazine through a family connection, although it is obvious that he is in no condition to work. His best friend and wingman, Nick (Scott Mescudi a.k.a. Kid Cudi), tries to keep him in line, but to little avail.
‰ÛÏJames White‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt soften its message: You can only avoid facing reality for so long, until it catches up with you. Then it grabs you by the throat.

‰ÛÏJames White‰Ûù burrows so deeply into the consciousness of its title character, a flailing young Manhattanite played by Christopher Abbott (‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù), that his self-loathing and panic feel contagious. Who hasn‰Ûªt, at a certain point in life, faced a sink-or-swim moment when a promising future suddenly began to seem out of reach? James combats the terror of grown-up responsibility with copious amounts of booze and late-night carousing in which he picks fights in bars and behaves like a brat. But Mr. Abbott‰Ûªs performance makes you aware that James‰Ûªs bad behavior stems from fear; deep down he has a warm heart.
‰ÛÏJames White‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for drug use, some nudity and language. Running time: 1 hour 25 minutes.

Shot hand-held, ‰ÛÏJames White‰Ûù conveys a compressed sense of time. Suddenly James is back in New York. Just as suddenly, he is holed up for a night in a luxury building. The movie‰Ûªs refusal to explain James‰Ûªs peripatetic ways lends it an extra edge of anxious frenzy. Its abrasive portrait of contemporary New York as a place of noise and nerve-rattling turmoil captures the mood of the city more accurately than any recent film I can think of. And the jagged camera work exacerbates the film‰Ûªs jarring sense of immediacy.

The opening scene observes James in a daze amid the deafening clamor of an after-hours club. Plunging into the harsh morning light, he takes a taxi to the Upper West Side apartment of his mother, Gail (Cynthia Nixon), where guests are observing the Jewish custom of sitting shiva for his dead father. Barging into the gathering like a rowdy party guest, he is conspicuously rude and boorish.

The thread that comes closest to being absorbing is played out by Olivia Wilde and Jake Lacy, whose characters do an opposites-attract dance after meeting at the airport. But the film, written by Steven Rogers and directed by Jessie Nelson, is too obviously manipulative. Its shameless appropriation doesn‰Ûªt help. There is, for instance, a folksy narration straight out of ‰ÛÏA Christmas Story,‰Ûù which is also raided for its dogs-disrupt-dinner-plans gag.

‰ÛÏLove the Coopers‰Ûù wants to be as beloved as that movie and several others that it calls to mind, but its overwrought exchanges (especially between Charlotte and Sam) and efforts to push every emotional button in sight make it tedious, not tenderhearted.
‰ÛÏLove the Coopers‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for grown-up themes and a smattering of strong language.

Classic Christmas movies have a magic that can‰Ûªt be manufactured, but ‰ÛÏLove the Coopers‰Ûù desperately tries to do just that. It employs a familiar conceit ‰ÛÓ dysfunctional family gathers for holiday meal ‰ÛÓ and enlists recognizable actors to deliver it, but the result plays like a collection of ideas and jokes borrowed from other movies. The film is occasionally amusing but rarely feels genuine.

Diane Keaton and John Goodman are Charlotte and Sam, a long-married couple waiting for their extended family to arrive for the big meal, at which they intend to announce that they‰Ûªre separating. We see the various family members making their way toward the gathering. There‰Ûªs the son (Ed Helms) with the broken marriage, jobless and adrift. There‰Ûªs Charlotte‰Ûªs sister (Marisa Tomei), who is arrested while trying to shoplift a Christmas present. There‰Ûªs a grandson (TimothÌ©e Chalamet) in the throes of romantic infatuation.
‰ÛÏMan Up‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), mostly for salty sexual references.

‰ÛÏMan Up,‰Ûù a destined-for-romance story in the spirit of ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªve Got Mail‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSleepless in Seattle,‰Ûù has just enough edge to distinguish it from a Lifetime movie. It also has Lake Bell and Simon Pegg, versatile and likable actors who help the mild story considerably.

Through a serendipitous sequence of events, Jack mistakes Nancy for a blind date a friend has arranged for him to meet. Nancy, who has been under pressure from her sister (Sharon Horgan) to take more chances, sees no immediate reason to relieve Jack of his misimpression. By the time she confesses her true identity, they have already had enough wacky, revelatory bonding experiences that we know that they‰Ûªre destined for love. The only issue is how many obstacles they‰Ûªll have to overcome before they realize that themselves.

The funniest of the obstacles comes in the form of Sean (Rory Kinnear), a long-ago classmate of Nancy‰Ûªs who materializes unexpectedly and, it turns out, has been semi-stalking Nancy for years. This film, directed by Ben Palmer, reaches a feel-good conclusion at an anniversary celebration for Nancy‰Ûªs parents, where new love and enduring love are juxtaposed sweetly. NEIL GENZLINGER

Ms. Bell is Nancy, a 34-year-old woman who has been striking out on the dating scene, thanks to a quirky (she recites dialogue from ‰ÛÏSilence of the Lambs‰Ûù) and somewhat abrasive personality. Mr. Pegg is Jack, who is still recovering from a failed marriage and trying to force himself back into the world of relationships.

Ms. Connelly‰Ûªs miscast co-star, Anthony Mackie, plays Tahir, Hannah‰Ûªs partner on the streets, with whom she develops a mutually protective bond. A Nigerian immigrant and street musician who plays bucket drums for spare change, he is racked with guilt for atrocities he was forced to commit as a member of the Islamic militant group Boko Haram, but the screenplay barely begins to connect the dots between his past and his present. It is too busy preparing for its repellent money shots.

The more tolerable moments in ‰ÛÏShelter,‰Ûù Paul Bettany‰Ûªs overwrought cri de coeur about homelessness in New York City, show its characters desperately navigating the city‰Ûªs overstressed shelter system. These grim scenes, filmed in shades of brown and gray, suggest the combination of fear, exhaustion and uncertainty in people at the mercy of an impersonal bureaucracy that shuffles them from place to place. But the movie never bothers to show you life inside a shelter dormitory or tries to convey a broader vision of the city‰Ûªs street culture. It is too busy showcasing its star Jennifer Connelly (Mr. Bettany‰Ûªs wife) in degrading situations.

In one scene, Hannah shoots heroin into her crotch. Another finds her trying to go cold turkey, with very messy results. In the film‰Ûªs most miscalculated maneuver, she trades sexual favors with a building superintendent in return for cramped space in a boiler room during a blizzard. ‰ÛÏThis is New York,‰Ûù the superintendent smugly declares. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs not a something-for-nothing town.‰Ûù It recalls the actress‰Ûªs nightmarish turn in Darren Aronofsky‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRequiem for a Dream,‰Ûù in which she and another woman are paid to perform together at a party.
‰ÛÏShelter‰Ûù is not rated. Running time: 1 hour 45 minutes.

Her character, Hannah, is a heroin addict whose family has given up on her. Mr. Bettany‰Ûªs sketchy, unconvincing screenplay is more interested in Ms. Connelly‰Ûªs execution of exploitative stunts than in seriously examining the social crisis it purports to lament. And Ms. Connelly, an actress who rarely reveals any traces of humor, gives herself to the task with a self-punishing ferocity.

If all of ‰ÛÏSong of Lahore‰Ûù were as exciting as its ending, you‰Ûªd need an hour afterward to catch your breath. It‰Ûªs not, yet despite a lackluster start, this documentary redeems itself by the finale.

Set initially in Lahore, Pakistan, the film follows the Sachal Jazz Ensemble, a scrappy group of musicians working in a place where a love of the arts can cost you your life. Though the city was once bustling with performers, a strict Islamic government took control decades ago and stifled artists.
‰ÛÏSong of Lahore‰Ûù is rated PG (Parents strongly cautioned) for some violent images.

Early scenes in ‰ÛÏLahore‰Ûù outline the history and introduce the Sachal players. That can be interesting though uninvolving, and Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy and Andy Schocken, the directors, provide too few details on the Pakistani instruments and musical forms we hear.

As the ensemble‰Ûªs fame grows through Internet videos, it is invited to the United States to perform with Wynton Marsalis and his band. Almost immediately, what had been a flat story turns energetic and captivating; the Pakistani musicians‰Ûª worries over their skills are palpable, and their doubts visible on their faces. Once they arrive in New York, the stresses that arise during rehearsals with their American counterparts can bring to mind the tension in another jazz film, ‰ÛÏWhiplash.‰Ûù

It gives away nothing to say that the trip is (mostly) a triumph for the Sachal players. The scenes shown from their Jazz at Lincoln Center concert are delightful enough to have you wish for three or four more songs. It‰Ûªs a far cry from that slow-going beginning, and well worth the wait. KEN JAWOROWSKI
Restrictions have eased recently, but there is still a real threat of violence. Such oppression has also reduced the numbers of players and audiences, further disheartening musicians there.

McQueen was at the height of his considerable stardom in 1970 when he tried to make a scripted movie centered on the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the sports car race in France. ‰ÛÏThe Man & Le Mans,‰Ûù directed by Gabriel Clarke and John McKenna, focuses on that project, using interviews with people who saw it take shape (including Chad McQueen, McQueen‰Ûªs son) and audio recordings of McQueen, who died in 1980.

‰ÛÏSteve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans‰Ûù is a niche documentary about the making of a niche, rather unloved movie. It doesn‰Ûªt really succeed in conveying McQueen‰Ûªs great passion for auto racing. In truth, it mostly makes him seem like a jerk ‰ÛÓ but cinephiles might enjoy it as a case study of moviemaking gone wrong.

The movie that was finally made, ‰ÛÏLe Mans,‰Ûù which came out in 1971, was more documentary than story. (‰ÛÏDramatically, the picture is a bore,‰Ûù Howard Thompson wrote in The New York Times.) ‰ÛÏThe Man & Le Mans‰Ûù may not generate the sympathy for McQueen that it‰Ûªs aiming for, but it‰Ûªs certainly a cautionary tale about Hollywood and the swelled-head syndrome.

That shoot dragged on and on, hampered by the lack of a script, McQueen apparently having one particular vision that an assortment of writers were unable to capture. One who tried was Alan Trustman, who had writing credits on two previous McQueen hits (‰ÛÏBullitt‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Thomas Crown Affair‰Ûù) and who tells a painful story about a meeting with the star to discuss their clashing views for the racing film.
‰ÛÏI was the highest-paid screenwriter in town when I went to that meeting,‰Ûù Mr. Trustman says, ‰ÛÏand after that meeting, the phone never rang again.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏThe 33,‰Ûù a new movie directed by Patricia Riggen from a screenplay by Mikko Alanne, Craig Borten and Michael Thomas, revisits the episode, effectively stirring up those emotions all over again and adding some new ones inspired by the lives of the miners and the challenge of bringing them out alive. In some ways, it‰Ûªs foolproof material ‰ÛÓ moving and suspenseful even if you know the outcome. But Ms. Riggen, a Mexican-born filmmaker whose earlier features include ‰ÛÏLa Misma Luna‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGirl in Progress,‰Ûù has grappled with some formidable challenges, including the familiarity of the story. She also faced something of a numbers problem: 33 potential protagonists ‰ÛÓ as well as wives, sisters, children, government officials and engineers ‰ÛÓ is an awful lot to keep track of. To make matters trickier, most of those characters spend an awful lot of time confined in a small, stubbornly uncinematic space, not doing anything very dramatic.

A true story in print is a work of journalism. A true story in a nondocumentary film is something else: a fable, a moralized version of reality. ‰ÛÏThe 33‰Ûù sends out feelers in a lot of different directions. The circus outside the mine ‰ÛÓ the souvenir stands and cameras, the grandstanding politicians and opportunistic show business types ‰ÛÓ hints at a satire of modern media excess, a variation on the themes of Billy Wilder‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAce in the Hole.‰Ûù The plot sometimes wobbles between the personal and procedural sides of the miners‰Ûª plight, but both the science and the sentiment feel a little thin.

The nominal leader is Don Lucho (Lou Diamond Phillips), the captain of the shift, but the actual leader is Mario (Antonio Banderas), a charismatic and persuasive guy who rations food, rallies morale and refuses to give up hope when things look grim. The other miners supply comic relief and dramatic interest. DarÌ_o (Juan Pablo Raba) is an alcoholic, comforted in his worst moments by JosÌ© (Marco TreviÌ±o), a devout Christian. One man is about to become a father for the first time. Another is a few weeks from retirement. The Elvis impersonator (Jacob Vargas) teases the only Bolivian (Tenoch Huerta) in the group. Everyone teases Yonni (Oscar NuÌ±ez) because of his complicated love life.

The moral is plain. Capital and the state don‰Ûªt really care about you, though they can sometimes be shamed into acting in your interest. Better to put your trust in the Almighty, and in the solidarity of your fellow workers.

But with the help of some solid performances and James Horner‰Ûªs heart-squeezing, throat-constricting score (one of the last he composed before his death in June), ‰ÛÏThe 33‰Ûù holds your attention and pushes the required buttons. It starts above ground, at an outdoor party where miners eat, drink, dance, impersonate Elvis Presley and engage in some necessary preliminary exposition. By the time they pile into the bus for work the next morning, we are acquainted with the most important figures. Once the earth shifts and a giant rock seals them into a refuge hundreds of feet down, we know the function each one will play.

The film gains some clarity at the end, and delivers a strong and timely moral. ‰ÛÏGod was with us‰Ûù the miners write on the wall of their refuge as they prepare to return to the sunlight, and at several points the movie emphasizes the importance of religion in their lives. This seems like a faith-inflected movie for the age of a Latin American populist pope, a parable of spiritual endurance with an eye on social and economic iniquities. Before the credits roll, we learn that the miners were never compensated for their suffering, and that the mining company was cleared of any negligence, a judgment the film emphatically challenges. We also learn that the 33, whose real-life faces fill the screen at the very end, ‰ÛÏremain brothers to this day.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe 33‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Grave danger and mild profanity. Running time: 2 hours 6 minutes.

His wife (Adriana Barraza) and mistress (Elizabeth De Razzo) quarrel about who has the right to wait for him with the other kinfolk, who include DarÌ_o‰Ûªs sister (Juliette Binoche) and Mario‰Ûªs wife (Kate del Castillo). Their presence puts pressure on the Chilean government, represented by a handsome young minister of mining (Rodrigo Santoro) and the portly, silver-haired president (Bob Gunton). The government minister and an engineer (Gabriel Byrne) argue about practicalities, and about how long to keep drilling to find the missing men.

The ordeal of the 33 Chilean miners trapped deep inside the earth after the collapse of a mine shaft in August 2010 was both an intensely local story and a global phenomenon. As family members waited in a makeshift camp near the mine‰Ûªs opening, viewers across the world followed the progress of the rescue efforts thanks to round-the-clock news media attention. We breathed sighs of relief and wept tears of joy when the men finally emerged, after more than two months in subterranean heat and darkness. And then, as is our habit, we moved on.

The dialogue is direct to the point of hokiness. Nearly every scene lands squarely on a clear note of feeling. When people laugh, they laugh much longer and louder than the situation seems to warrant. It‰Ûªs that kind of movie. If you want richer context and deeper nuance, it can be found in ‰ÛÏDeep Down Dark,‰Ûù the book by the journalist Hector Tobar that is this film‰Ûªs credited source.

A fantasy about princes and princesses and perfect doubles, the story‰Ûªs roots are as firmly planted in Hindu myth and epic as in Bollywood romance. We first see our hero, Prem (Salman Khan), a sweetie-pie actor, in a Ramlila, a play about Rama and Sita, the royal husband and wife whose tale is told in the Ramayana.

The Bollywood movie ‰ÛÏPrem Ratan Dhan Payo‰Ûù is set in contemporary India, though it‰Ûªs one of palaces and quaint villages and low-rise cities, with the occasional iPhone and Mercedes thrown in for modernity and luxury branding‰Ûªs sake.

Later, Prem (his name means ‰ÛÏlove‰Ûù) impersonates a real prince (Mr. Khan again), a haughtier fellow who has been wounded in a foul-play horse-and-carriage accident and has then hidden in a cave to recover. And the Bollywood plot thickens: The prince is kidnapped and chained to a post in a sheesh mahal, or palace of mirrors, only to be rescued by Prem, their images multiplied in fun-house confusion. Through decency and playfulness, Prem brings peace to the warring parties of the royal family and snags the love of a princess (Sonam Kapoor) to boot.
‰ÛÏPrem Ratan Dhan Payo‰Ûù is not rated. It is in Hindi, with English subtitles. Running time: 2 hours 51 minutes.

With its full complement of lavishly produced song-and-dance numbers, its filmi heroes and villains, and a two-hour, 40-minute runtime, ‰ÛÏPrem‰Ûù hews closely to the old-style Bollywood formula. At one point, the prince‰Ûªs wayward brother plants his legs apart, swigs imported champagne from a bottle and shrieks ‰ÛÏFreedom!‰Ûù while the camera gazes up at him from below. (File under: ‰ÛÏVillain, temporarily triumphant.‰Ûù) In other words, the director, Sooraj R. Barjatya, courts and embraces clichÌ© at every turn, which is both the movie‰Ûªs charm and its limitation.

At 49, Mr. Khan, in the double role of nice guy/sophisticated prince ‰ÛÓ Bollywood loves a double! ‰ÛÓ has shed some of his boyish twinkle, gained a rap sheet and overbulked his upper body. His dancing can feel leaden and his movie-star allure has dimmed. But persistence has its rewards; in true Hindi-movie style, by this long film‰Ûªs end, Mr. Khan‰Ûªs Prem may have wheedled his way into your affections.
‰ÛÏDemocrats‰Ûù is not rated. It is in English and Shona, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

The fits and starts of the process put the opposing representatives, both charismatic fellows, through some fascinating changes. Mr. Mwonzora winds up in jail during a particularly crucial point of constitutional drafting, while Mr. Mangwana haplessly finds himself in that dangerous position of being termed a ‰ÛÏsellout‰Ûù later on. Ms. Nielsson‰Ûªs cameras take us only so far behind the scenes; Mr. Mugabe‰Ûªs own conference rooms are never entered. But the portrait of passionate people struggling to improve their government is urgent, vivid and satisfactory. Both inspiring and upsetting, ‰ÛÏDemocrats‰Ûù is, finally, a film that deserves to be called ‰ÛÏnecessary.‰Ûù

Shot over three years, the movie begins with archival footage and on-screen text that do a good job of acclimating viewers who may not be familiar with the political situation in Zimbabwe. Here‰Ûªs the short version: Since the country gained independence in 1980, it‰Ûªs been ruled by the autocrat Robert Mugabe. In 2008, compelled by international scrutiny over what many saw as a sham election, Mr. Mugabe was forced to share power with his rival, Morgan Tsvangirai. That situation led to the formation of a committee to draft a constitution that would push the country‰Ûªs government closer to a Western-style democracy.

‰ÛÏTo be called a sellout in Zimbabwe is to be condemned to death.‰Ûù This observation delivered with a dry, matter-of-fact tone comes late in the director Camilla Nielsson‰Ûªs outstanding, unsettling documentary ‰ÛÏDemocrats,‰Ûù a film that chronicles recent efforts to put a constitution into place in that country.

Ms. Nielsson and her crew had exceptional access to the two men steering the constitutional process: Paul Mangwana, representing ZANU-PF, Mr. Mugabe‰Ûªs party; and Douglas Mwonzora, a representative of the Movement for Democratic Change (M.D.C.). Both men are lawyers, and they each make a great show of being happy warriors, as it were, and approach each other with often deferential friendliness. But an indication of how big a struggle one side faces comes early on. At an outreach session held in a rural province, an unusually large number of citizens proclaim that only the president ought to be permitted to appoint judges.

What is happening here? Are the Zimbabweans of the old school, veterans of the war that won their country its independence, so flush with nationalist pride that they revere Mr. Mugabe so? Or is the whole process being rigged by Mr. Mugabe‰Ûªs secret service? Ms. Nielsson‰Ûªs handling of the events silently stresses that there are no simple answers to those questions.

Mutual attraction may be central to our notion of love, but it is a curiously rare occurrence in art, which tends to split desire into subject and object. Poetry traces a vector from lover to beloved. (‰ÛÏShall I compare thee to a summer‰Ûªs day?‰Ûù) In painting and sculpture, the eye of the beholder lingers on the face and body of the beheld. Students of film are schooled in the erotic power of the gaze, and readers of romance fiction know the seductions of the first-person narrative and the free indirect style, which concentrate lust and longing within a single consciousness. (‰ÛÏReader, I married him.‰Ûù)

There is plenty of melodrama, though, and more than a touch of film noir. ‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù filters a relatively happy romance through layers of anxiety, dread and psychological suspense. Mr. Haynes, a scholar of mid- and late-20th-century cinematic styles and sexual attitudes, is both a connoisseur and a theorist of female suffering. In early shorts like ‰ÛÏSuperstar‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏDottie Gets Spanked‰Ûù as well as in mature features like ‰ÛÏSafe,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFar From Heaven‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMildred Pierce,‰Ûù his attention has often gravitated toward women in danger and in distress.

There are obvious asymmetries to be discovered in the relationship between a penniless young bohemian and a wealthy, full-grown matron, but Ms. Mara refuses to be the ingÌ©nue in the arrangement. She is vulnerable and hungry, timid and ferocious, predator and prey. And the movie, with its gauzy, grainy images (shot by the incomparable Edward Lachman), ultimately depends on the clarity of Therese‰Ûªs vision, on her ability to discover who she is and to choose a course of action that expresses that identity.

Carol lights up Therese‰Ûªs world with her elegance and self-possession, her dazzling and mysterious allure. But Therese has mysteries of her own. Carol (in a line taken directly from the book) likens her to an alien, a creature ‰ÛÏflung from space,‰Ûù and Ms. Mara‰Ûªs face has a spooky, otherworldly quality. Dressed in mismatched plaids, including a dumpy yellow tam-o‰Ûª-shanter ‰ÛÓ a notable contrast to Carol‰Ûªs compact and deep-hued pillbox hats ‰ÛÓ Therese can look elfin and childlike. It‰Ûªs hard to tell whether her quiet manner bespeaks timidity or terrifying self-possession.

And when other people look at Carol and Therese (or through them or past them), what do they see? In the opening scene ‰ÛÓ which establishes most of what follows as a flashback ‰ÛÓ we accompany an anonymous, hat-and-coated fellow into a hotel bar, where he spots the two women (played by Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara) at a nearby table. The meaning of their togetherness is invisible to this guy (he‰Ûªs an acquaintance of Therese‰Ûªs) and, for the moment, opaque to us. Later, when the scene is repeated with the camera in a different position, the current of feeling passing between Carol and Therese as they chat over their teacups is so strong that the air around them seems to vibrate.

‰ÛÏCarol,‰Ûù like virtually every other movie Mr. Haynes has directed, is a period film, almost fetishistically precise in its recreation of the look and sound of the past. Like other historical fiction, it measures the distance between then and now. In 1952, the candid and sympathetic depiction of gay life was shocking; now it is commonplace. ‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù might have been content to be an archaeology of the closet, or a pitying backward glance at the mores of a less enlightened time.
‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex and cigarettes. Running time: 1 hour 58 minutes.

The camera ‰ÛÓ Therese‰Ûªs camera as well as Mr. Haynes‰Ûªs ‰ÛÓ searches out the pain and wisdom behind the Brancusi contours of Ms. Blanchett‰Ûªs face. Carol is richer and more experienced than Therese, and also more weighed down by compromises and responsibilities. Carol, in the middle of divorcing her bewildered husband, Harge (Kyle Chandler), has a young daughter and what used to be called a past. A sexual relationship with an old friend named Abby (Sarah Paulson) contributed to the breakup of her marriage, and Carol‰Ûªs romance with Therese adds further complication at a tricky time in her life.

By then, we are in on their secret, and accustomed to seeing them, in public places, hidden in plain sight, cloaked in unspoken assumptions that are at once painful and protective. We also know the extent of their intimacy, since we‰Ûªve watched it blossom from a chance encounter and a series of cautious conversations into a headlong, heedless affair. In this film‰Ûªs version of the 1950s, nobody necessarily suspects that two women out for coffee or cocktails or a drive in the country might in fact be lovers.

When such suspicion does arise, the consequences can be unfathomably cruel. Shame, exposure and ostracism lurk in every stranger‰Ûªs glance. A rumor can ruin a life. Terror hovers in the air along with yearning, but Mr. Haynes honors Highsmith‰Ûªs decision to tell a tale of same-sex love stripped of pathology or tragedy.

Not that Therese‰Ûªs situation is all that simple. A nice guy named Richard (Jake Lacy), who calls her Terry, wants to marry her, or at least take her to Europe. Another nice guy, Dannie (John Magaro), also has his eye on her. She is patient with them, as Carol tries to be with Harge, and they are puzzled by her lack of interest.

At first glance, the distraught diva in this picture can only be Carol, who is played with almost metaphysical movie-star blondness by Ms. Blanchett. Arrayed in full-cut coats and accessorized in bright, saturated colors ‰ÛÓ an early shot lingers over the pulsating orange hues of her fingernails, her scarf and her hat ‰ÛÓ Carol is postwar glamour incarnate.

But it is much more than that. Mr. Haynes is a historian of feelings, of the unspoken and invisible traces of the libido. In one scene, Carol helps Therese apply perfume, instructing her to spray it only on her pulse points, where the heat and movement of her blood will activate the scent. The images in ‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù are cool and elusive, but they also pulsate with life.

Patricia Highsmith‰Ûªs 1952 novel, ‰ÛÏThe Price of Salt,‰Ûù published under the pseudonym Claire Morgan, uses these conventional methods to tell the story of what was at the time a scandalously unconventional love. That story, which begins in Manhattan just before Christmas, is related from the perspective of Therese Belivet, a young theatrical set designer in New York who falls for an older suburban housewife named Carol Aird. Therese‰Ûªs infatuation with Carol is immediate and total. Carol‰Ûªs feelings, while equally intense, are more elusive, partly because the reader experiences them at second hand, from Therese‰Ûªs point of view.

In bringing this book to the screen in his gorgeous new movie ‰ÛÏCarol,‰Ûù Todd Haynes has, as filmmakers will, changed a few details, characters and plot points. (Therese is now an aspiring photographer, though still temporarily employed at the doll counter of a department store.) But Mr. Haynes and the screenwriter, Phyllis Nagy, have also done something more radical. In Highsmith‰Ûªs prose, desire is a one-way street. For Mr. Haynes, it‰Ûªs a two-way mirror. At once ardent and analytical, cerebral and swooning, ‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù is a study in human magnetism, in the physics and optics of eros. With sparse dialogue and restrained drama, the film is a symphony of angles and glances, of colors and shadows. It gives emotional and philosophical weight to what might be a perfectly banal question: What do these women see each in each other?

It‰Ûªs a film full of machismo (there is hardly a female character in sight), absurdist dialogue and hints of humor, and it owes as much to Quentin Tarantino as the four bunglers owe to Eddie. Yet it doesn‰Ûªt feel like a mere imitation; it has too much wit and too many striking performances for that.

Four young men (Michael Pitt, Dan Stevens, Christopher Abbott and Rob Brown) who have known one another for years join in a get-rich-quick investment scheme that backfires and leaves them owing a lot of money to Eddie (Mr. Travolta), a local crime boss. To pay the debt, he asks them to kidnap a man named Marques from a family he says is holding his niece hostage. Edi Gathegi is a chatty, foul-mouthed delight in that role as, bound in a chair, he tries to mess with the four amateur kidnappers‰Ûª heads.

If it sounds as if there‰Ûªs something more going on here, well, there is; a number of these characters and events are not what they seem. Jackie Earle Haley, directing a script by Robert Lowell, keeps the plot twists nicely disguised, and turns in a fine performance as one of Eddie‰Ûªs henchmen.
John Travolta gets Godfather-y in ‰ÛÏCriminal Activities,‰Ûù a spunky crime yarn in which he does fine work but is overshadowed by a guy who spends most of the film tied up in a chair.

Col. Lawrence Wilkerson, chief of staff to Colin Powell when he was secretary of state, says, ‰ÛÏThere has never been any technology of warfare that isn‰Ûªt ultimately adopted by your enemy or enemies.‰Ûù Then comes an aerial shot of Lower Manhattan.

This probably isn‰Ûªt the best moment to find a receptive audience for a film that questions the American use of drone strikes in the war on terror. Regardless of whether armed drones would have been useful countering the attacks in Paris, those events have many people locked into a ‰ÛÏwhatever it takes‰Ûù mentality when it comes to fighting extremism.

But ‰ÛÏDrone,‰Ûù a documentary by the Norwegian filmmaker Tonje Hessen Schei, has a lot to say that needs to be heard. Some of it is already fairly familiar, though that makes it no less urgent. The morality of killing people without trial and the substantial civilian casualties caused by the so-called targeted strikes have been the source of debate and protest for some time. And others have argued, as this film does, that drone warfare is actually a recruitment tool for terrorist groups because of the resentment it is generating.
There are no suggested solutions here to the difficult issues raised, but the film at least reminds us that it‰Ûªs important not to accept this new way of warring without scrutinizing it.

But this film examines some less familiar issues, too, including how the makers of traditional weapons will respond as the increasing use of drones reduces demand for heavy armaments. There is also a chilling nod to the fact that drones aren‰Ûªt the exclusive province of the United States or its allies.

The intrepid photographer, Farzana Wahidy, is one of four profiled in Alexandria Bombach and Mo Scarpelli‰Ûªs snapshot of photojournalism in today‰Ûªs Afghanistan. Press freedom has grown there since the 2001 American invasion, but the withdrawal of foreign forces raises the specter of resurgent fundamentalism. With that threat as a looming backdrop, Ms. Bombach and Ms. Scarpelli observe Ms. Wahidy and others at work, in poignant moments and in tedious ones true to the travails of their profession, but the film‰Ûªs four-person shuffle turns into a bit of a hash.

When an Afghan photojournalist in the documentary ‰ÛÏFrame by Frame‰Ûù is barred from entering a hospital ward of female patients, the staff‰Ûªs fearful response reflects the influence of the Taliban. If word got out of her visit, the journalist is told, the consequences could be grave ‰ÛÓ the hospital destroyed, the doctors killed.

The other two photographers we meet are accomplished, but the film needs streamlining and sharpening, and the same goes for the more generic interview bits. Afghanistan is strikingly picturesque, which is a bonus, but the film is strongest when staring deeply into the country‰Ûªs wounds.

Ms. Wahidy and Massoud Hossaini, a Pulitzer Prize-winning colleague and her husband, yield the best portraits. Her childhood as a girl beaten and kept away from school, and her tenacity and passion today in pursuing shots, suggest that she could have carried this film alone. Mr. Hossaini pays a visit to the subject of his award-winning photo, of an anguished 12-year-old surrounded by dead bodies, in one of many scenes where reality overwhelms the story of these chroniclers.

Burrowing inside the girls‰Ûª heads, Ms. Subkoff (an actress directing for the first time) forces us to see almost everything through their eyes. Exaggerated performances from ChloÌÇ Sevigny ‰ÛÓ swanning around in outrÌ© outfits ‰ÛÓ and Timothy Hutton as unrelated, monstrously clueless parents underline their offsprings‰Ûª warped immaturity. But the audience, given not an ounce of human warmth nor one person to care about, finally has no choice but to cheer for the anonymous cyberbully who wants them all dead.

And the writer and director, Tara Subkoff, makes it almost impossible to care. Obnoxious to a fault, her charges snipe and gossip and dress up, their moods as mercurial as their allegiances. Doling out the psychological damage, including bulimia and extreme loneliness (parents are neglectfully distant or recently expired), Ms. Subkoff creates a cabal of virtual orphans and surrounds them with the cold trappings of conspicuous wealth. Inside the luxury home where their mean-girl games unfold, life-size art lurks in cavernous corners and glass walls leave everyone exposed to the snowy darkness.

After a seizure-inducing credit sequence, ‰ÛÏ#Horror‰Ûù settles down to a world of brittle soullessness as a group of privileged preteen girls gathers for a sleepover. Morbidly attached to their cellphones ‰ÛÓ where online encounters play out through candy-colored flashes ‰ÛÓ these bratty babies are about to have the worst night of their lives.

Yet for all its bursts of violence and descending-guillotine sound effects, ‰ÛÏ#Horror‰Ûù feels driven more by social commentary than by outright terror. Like a warning to distracted parents, the movie‰Ûªs scariest threat emerges not from its empty landscapes and sleek interiors (photographed with frosty elegance by Learan Kahanov), but from a seductive online world of likes and followers.

In the weeks following the Six-Day War in 1967, the conflict that reshaped a victorious Israel, two kibbutzniks, Amos Oz and Avraham Shapira, recorded a series of talks with other soldiers just coming home. Mr. Shapira assembled those conversations into a book, ‰ÛÏThe Seventh Day,‰Ûù which came out later that year and was remarkably reflective given the national euphoria.

To evoke the events being discussed, Ms. Loushy skillfully uses war footage taken by the military itself. She also gives the older subjects the film‰Ûªs last words: One says that these days he‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏless of a Zionist,‰Ûù another that he‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏmuch more right wing.‰Ûù

For most, it was their first war, and they recount fears, horror and disgust. But the longer the discussions, the darker the stories. ‰ÛÏThey said: Show no mercy. Kill as many as possible,‰Ûù one reports about his commanders. Another agrees that ‰ÛÏthe war was just‰Ûù at its outset because of the threat to Israel‰Ûªs survival, but that ‰ÛÏit became something it wasn‰Ûªt in the beginning.‰Ûù Many were deeply troubled by the expulsion of Arabs from their villages. ‰ÛÏI had the abysmal feeling I was evil,‰Ûù one says.

An essential amendment to the historical record, ‰ÛÏCensored Voices‰Ûù reminds us that no war is entirely virtuous and makes clear that, even at the time, the dangers of becoming an occupying force were evident. Forty-eight years ago, one returning soldier noted that the war not only didn‰Ûªt answer Israel‰Ûªs problems, it ‰ÛÏcomplicated them in a way that will be very hard to solve.‰Ûù

But the Israeli military permitted only about 30 percent of the material to be published then. In Mor Loushy‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCensored Voices,‰Ûù Mr. Oz, now perhaps Israel‰Ûªs best-known author, and Mr. Shapira, an editor, along with some of their interviewees, listen almost a half-century later to tapes of their younger selves.
‰ÛÏMustang‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Mature thematic material, sexual content and a rude gesture. In Turkish, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 37 minutes.

Full of life even as it depicts lives in lockdown, ‰ÛÏMustang‰Ûù is a stunning debut feature by Deniz Gamze ErgÌ_ven about five sisters in rural Turkey. Confined to their grandmother‰Ûªs house, the girls bridle against losing their freedoms in a story grounded in both laughter and tears, and above all in the resilient strength of these girls against soul-deadening strictures.

The lockdown turns into a countdown as the girls are married off and worse, though Ms. ErgÌ_ven also shows how marriage can be happy when some choice is involved. People outside the family also emerge as oases of modern attitudes, along with an escape plan. But the girls‰Ûª heroism lies in being themselves and making noise, against their immediate society‰Ûªs wishes.

Ms. ErgÌ_ven, who was born in Turkey, brings deft timing and an unapologetic appreciation of beauty to the story, qualities missing from other, schematic portrayals of clashes with traditional mores, Turkish or otherwise. Feather-light camerawork by David Chizallet and Ersin Gok is matched by a nimble screenplay written by Ms. ErgÌ_ven with Alice Winocour. The ensemble of young actresses is a constantly restless and real presence, the perspective filtered mostly through the cheeky Lale but also through the group as a loving crew.

The supposed sin of Lale, the narrator, and her four sisters ‰ÛÓ ages extending into the teenage years ‰ÛÓ was to romp with boys at the beach on the last day of school. Their real offense is being girls with uncontainable independent spirits in a patriarchal culture. The anxious grandmother and uncle who look after the sisters forbid them to leave the house, and turn the place into a ‰ÛÏwife factory.‰Ûù Lale, Nur, Ece, Selma and Sonay keep on pushing, sneaking away to see a soccer game, and boys, and the walls keep on closing in. Virginity tests are administered by a doctor; bars are put on the windows; prospective husbands are entertained over tea.

‰ÛÏThe Night Before‰Ûù combines two weary genres ‰ÛÓ the sentimental Christmas movie and the naughty-boy comedy ‰ÛÓ as if knocking their heads together might wake them both up. You may ask: Do we need an R-rated holiday caper that wraps its gooey, good-cheer core in layers of profanity, drug use and nervous sexual humor? Maybe we do, and, in any case, it was inevitable.
