So like the office party or the homemade cookies from your neighbors, this movie is one of those seasonal things you either endure or enjoy. And honestly, at this time of year, what‰Ûªs the difference?

But this year there are some lessons to learn. Isaac (Mr. Rogen) is about to become a father. (His wife is played by Jillian Bell, a very good sport.) Chris (Mr. Mackie), an N.F.L. player, has resorted to steroid use to prolong his career. He is also involved in a marketing scheme that allows ‰ÛÏThe Night Before‰Ûù to mock product placement while flagrantly engaging in it, a tactic that has been old and obnoxious at least since ‰ÛÏTalladega Nights.‰Ûù

Sure, but the emotional moments don‰Ûªt pay off any better than most of the jokes, which reach for the safest kinds of provocative punch lines having to do with sex, race and religion. ‰ÛÏThe Night Before‰Ûù is like six different kinds of takeout pizza thrown into one box and served cold the next day. Of course you‰Ûªll eat it. It‰Ûªs sitting right there.
‰ÛÏThe Night Before‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Pictures of penises sent via text message, and a lot of words for penis. Running time: 1 hour 41 minutes.
Ethan is in the worst shape. His career is going nowhere, and he messed up a relationship with his dream girl (Lizzy Caplan, another good sport). Will he have another chance?

Whom they play is not so important. Michael Shannon is good as a philosophical weed dealer, and various people you know from television show up to give ‰ÛÏThe Night Before‰Ûù a sketch-comedy, holiday-special vibe. The writing, by a whole lot of guys, is uneven, and the direction, by Jonathan Levine, is adequate. He makes a few stabs at physical humor and doesn‰Ûªt mess them up too badly ‰ÛÓ Ms. Glazer on the run; Seth Rogen falling down ‰ÛÓ and otherwise sticks to the formula of pointing the camera at cast members talking.

The main actors are Mr. Rogen (slender of body and heavy of beard), Anthony Mackie and Joseph Gordon-Levitt. They are childhood friends who bonded when one of them, Ethan (Mr. Gordon-Levitt), lost his parents as a teenager. Since then, the guys, now in their 30s, have consecrated each Dec. 24 to wild abandon. They drink liquor and smoke joints, visit the Rockefeller Center tree while intoxicated and perform a karaoke version of Run-DMC‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏChristmas in Hollis.‰Ûù

The fun parts are the cameos and supporting performances. Some might count as spoilers, so I‰Ûªll leave them in their wrapping. The dude-centrism of the main story ‰ÛÓ three bros embarking on one last Christmas Eve debauch, with halfhearted overtones of Dickens and ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs a Wonderful Life‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is alleviated by the presence of Mindy Kaling and Ilana Glazer, who are funnier than anyone else in the movie, as they generally are in life.
‰ÛÏKingdom of Shadows‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for images of suspended corpses.

The soft-spoken Mr. Ford explains how poverty and debt led him to smuggling, and expresses anger at the United States‰Ûª draconian drug-sentencing laws (which are now shifting). Sister Morales, in the Mexican city of Monterrey, tirelessly comforts and rallies the bereaved, and grills prosecutors after leading a public demonstration of frustration and anger. (The mystery surrounding 43 missing students in Ayotzinapa is only the latest outrage.) Mr. Hagelsieb describes the origins of the Zetas, a onetime military unit that joined the Gulf Cartel before going into business for itself. One sequence visits a ‰ÛÏnarco-kitchen,‰Ûù where victims are immolated beyond recognition; another illustrates the Zetas‰Ûª grisly penchant for displaying their dead victims in public places.

A Hollywood feature like ‰ÛÏSicario‰Ûù might strive to capture the merciless grip drug cartels have on Mexico, but Bernardo Ruiz‰Ûªs visceral documentary ‰ÛÏKingdom of Shadows‰Ûù gives you a frontline glimpse. Three perspectives predominate: those of Sister Consuelo Morales, a Roman Catholic nun seeking answers for families of the ‰ÛÏdisappeared‰Ûù (civilians who have vanished because of drug gangs or police corruption); Don Henry Ford Jr., a Texas rancher who served time for smuggling marijuana from Mexico; and the Homeland Security officer Oscar Hagelsieb, a former undercover operative for the Border Patrol.

The American demand for drugs, which feeds the cartels, is mentioned, though regrettably not expanded upon. But as a rendering of Mexico‰Ûªs agonized convulsions, ‰ÛÏKingdom of Shadows‰Ûù is unforgettable.
‰ÛÏLegend‰Ûù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun and knife violence. Running time: 2 hours 2 minutes.

Frances serves as the movie‰Ûªs guide and rather less convincingly as its moral compass. A sparrow who flutters into a lion‰Ûªs mouth when she hooks up with Reggie, she pulls the movie in one direction (bad, Krays, bad), even as they and the mighty Mr. Hardy effortlessly yank it back. They may have been terrible, these two, but from the evidence of the movie, they were fairly amusing company, intentionally or not. That, at least, is how Mr. Helgeland plays it, dropping in lightly funny exchanges ‰ÛÓ as when Ronnie bluntly announces his homosexuality to a startled American gangster ‰ÛÓ with the Krays‰Ûª dirtier dealings. Yet while those get filthy and sometimes sanguineous, it‰Ûªs notable that the scariest Kray is their mother (a terrific Jane Wood, sliding in and out of the movie like a shiv).

In the end, the Krays‰Ûª most lasting contribution may have been cinematic. Duncan Campbell, writing in The Guardian, has zeroed in on a 1965 David Bailey photo of the Krays as a defining moment for the twins and their cultural impact. ‰ÛÏThe portrait became gangland‰Ûªs Mona Lisa ‰ÛÓ copied, pirated and imitated, it was central to their image and their brand,‰Ûù he writes. Soon afterward, Mr. Bailey released a photo collection  that featured the Krays as well as a third brother, Charlie, alongside boldface names like Mick Jagger and Jean Shrimpton. The Krays were cool only by proxy, but they became celebrities of a kind, and their look filtered into the gangster film iconography, inspiring the likes of Guy Ritchie. Every time you see another stupid thug playing the peacock, blame them.

More Mama Kray might have added additional layers to this dual portrait, but Mr. Helgeland has gone for broad, not profound. That shifts the burden to Mr. Hardy, who lightly hoists it with grimaces, body language, an apparent prosthetic and lots of swirling cigar and cigarette smoke. Mr. Hardy is one of those actors who periodically like to pull a Lon Chaney (silent cinema‰Ûªs man of a thousand faces) by hiding in plain sight. He‰Ûªs done bald and bulky, blond and sleek; more perversely, he has masked his face with beard fuzz and appliances. Here, he plays a long game of performance peekaboo, parading his good looks around as Reggie, and hiding them as Ronnie. As a character study, it proves about as deep as Goofus and Gallant in the British underworld, but it‰Ûªs also consistently fun to watch.

Tom Hardy and Tom Hardy are the reasons to see ‰ÛÏLegend,‰Ûù a gangster flick in which he does double duty as Ronnie and Reggie Kray, the British gangster twins who had a moment in the 1960s. Outside Britain, the Krays are probably now known less for their actual exploits than for their representations, either as vaguely obscured supporting attractions (in Mike Hodges‰Ûªs dazzling 1971 genre-defining ‰ÛÏGet Carter,‰Ûù starring Michael Caine) or as the main event (notably, the 1990 biopic ‰ÛÏThe Krays,‰Ûù with Gary and Martin Kemp of Spandau Ballet fame). The Krays weren‰Ûªt especially memorable as criminals, but they knew how to strut and swing through 1960s London.

In ‰ÛÏLegend,‰Ûù that milieu, with its flirty skirts and tight suits, swoony rides and tuneful hits, appears to have been the main impetus driving the writer and director, Brian Helgeland. Along with his team, he has kitted out the movie handsomely, from the sea-foam green Lincoln that glides through the East End like a pampered shark to the floral-choked wallpaper that lines the brothers‰Ûª ancestral home like pressed funeral flowers. (The director of photography is Dick Pope, who paints the scene with warm, dark colors, while the eye-soothing and -poking production design is by Tom Conroy.) It‰Ûªs all quite lovely, save for the occasional splash of red that reminds you that all the Krays‰Ûª flash came with a price, as the narrator, Frances (Emily Browning), regularly announces.
‰ÛÏMediterranea‰Ûù is not rated. In French, Italian, English, Arabic and Bissa, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 51 minutes.

The two are greeted enthusiastically by one of Ayiva‰Ûªs relatives, who leads them to a makeshift camp of shacks and tents on the outskirts of Rosarno. Although granted a three-month permit to stay, they face a wary reception from the Italians.

The dramatic climax is a re-enactment of a spontaneous rampage in 2010 by hundreds of migrant workers on the streets of Rosarno. Wielding metal pipes, they smash and set fire to cars. The police response is swift and brutal, and Abas is seriously injured.

Ayiva (the first-time actor Koudous Seihon) and Abas (Alassane Sy) are proud, strong-willed men who have few illusions that the journey will be easy, but they are still unprepared for the severity of the voyage. Arriving at their Libyan departure point after an arduous trek through the desert during which they are robbed by bandits, they discover that their guide expects them to pilot a fragile, overcrowded vessel by themselves.

To avoid immediate deportation, Ayiva and Abas have no choice but to pick oranges for subsistence wages. Although Ayiva manages to suppress his fury over the petty injustices and humiliations they endure, the arrogant, petulant Abas has little tolerance for frustration and shirks responsibility when he can get away with it. To survive, women who‰Ûªve migrated have little choice but to prostitute themselves, a choice the movie barely acknowledges.
The sentimental stereotype of primitive Africans agog over Western technology is nowhere to be found. Everyone dances to the music of Rihanna, which is heard on the soundtrack.

After the boat capsizes in a storm, they are rescued and dropped off in the Calabria region on the toe of the Italian Peninsula. The movie almost perversely plays down the rigors of the journey, which could be a movie in itself. It lands them in Europe as quickly as possible, the better to concentrate on the social tensions they encounter once they arrive.

‰ÛÏMediterranea‰Ûù is one of the earliest in what is almost certain to be a deluge of films about 21st-century migrants risking everything to seek a better life in Europe. The first feature film directed and written by Jonas Carpignano, it follows the harrowing odyssey of two close friends from Burkina Faso in West Africa who cross the Mediterranean to settle in Italy.

Ayiva is invited for dinner at the home of his boss Rocco (Davide Schipilliti), who is so admiring of his dedication that he finds him extra jobs. But there are limits to Rocco‰Ûªs good will. When Ayiva asks Rocco to help him get working papers, there is no response. This calm, hardheaded film never sacrifices its toughness for a swooning, misty-eyed moment of hope.

In the hands of a Hollywood studio, the story would be a natural platform for a stirring, picturesque melodrama with a bleeding heart. But  Mr. Carpignano, who covered the same territory in his 2012 short film, ‰ÛÏA ChjÌÊna,‰Ûù has adopted a low-key neorealist style, using hand-held cameras that intensify its ground-level perspective. The character-driven film focuses on the day-to-day experiences of people struggling to find a foothold in a hostile land that throws up nearly insurmountable barriers to assimilation. After their three-month permit expires, they face the prospect of having to get jobs to secure residency permits, but getting a job requires documentation that they don‰Ûªt have.

‰ÛÏMediterranea‰Ûù is impressive for the degree to which it lends its characters complex human dimensions and gives equal weight to everyone‰Ûªs joys and frustrations. Well-intentioned films about African immigrants tend to portray them as exotic outsiders with pure souls who are grateful for any largess. Neither Ayiva nor Abas could be described as a saintly innocent. Ayiva, who communicates with his African family via Skype, is a likable, principled man, but he is not a naÌøf. Adept at digital technology, he sends his 7-year-old daughter an MP3 player for which he barters with Pio (Pio Amato), a fast-talking teenage wheeler-dealer and the film‰Ûªs most vivid minor character.

The story begins with the grisly discovery of the body of Jess‰Ûªs daughter, Caroline, in 2002 during a post-Sept. 11 antiterrorism investigation. From there, the movie clumsily boomerangs back and forth between then and now. Thirteen years later, Jess is an ashen ghost of her former self. Ms. Roberts‰Ûªs performance may be a stunt that the movie, written and directed by Billy Ray (‰ÛÏCaptain Phillips‰Ûù), exploits for all it is worth, but it‰Ûªs still a brave one. It lends this sorry remake most of what little emotional resonance it stirs up.

The film‰Ûªs churning energy center is Chiwetel Ejiofor. His stormy character, Ray, is a former F.B.I. agent who, 13 years after the murder, is willing to break any and all rules to crack the still-unsolved case. Mr. Ejiofor goes for broke in an extreme performance that depicts his character as an out-of-control, foaming-at-the-mouth vigilante.

That chase comes as a relief after the yards of strained, flat-footed dialogue, which lacks the spontaneity of everyday speech. Sad to say: There is far more crackle in an average episode of ‰ÛÏLaw & Order.‰Ûù

Next to the showy antics of Ms. Roberts and Mr. Ejiofor, the movie‰Ûªs third marquee name, Nicole Kidman, barely registers as Ray‰Ûªs married former sweetheart, Claire, with whom he is still obsessed. The screenplay struggles to parallel Jess‰Ûªs bottomless grief and bitterness with Ray‰Ûªs still-simmering passion for Claire. But there is no chemistry between Mr. Ejiofor and Ms. Kidman, whose character remains chilly and remote. Her detachment makes Ray‰Ûªs fixation seem slightly demented. At moments, he suggests the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson on an oratorical bender.

The biggest shock of ‰ÛÏSecret in Their Eyes,‰Ûù a sluggish, semi-coherent remake of the 2010 Argentine film that won an Oscar for best foreign picture, is the bedraggled appearance of Julia Roberts. The million-dollar smile is barely a flicker on a face drained of color and expression. Her character, Jess, an investigator for the Los Angeles District Attorney‰Ûªs Office, has the vitality of a clinically depressed zombie.
‰ÛÏSecret in Their Eyes‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). There is violence, some strong language and some sexual references. Running time: 1 hour 51 minutes.

The timing of the film‰Ûªs release, days after the Paris terrorist attacks, is unfortunate. The references to Sept. 11 are superficial, confusing and crassly exploitative. Worse, they feel old hat and technologically behind the times. To stir up excitement, the movie devotes a lot of footage to the pursuit of a suspect in a baseball stadium. But a similar sequence in the original movie was much more visceral.

One of the decade‰Ûªs odder political stories is revisited, without much illumination, in ‰ÛÏSweet Micky for President,‰Ûù a documentary by Ben Patterson about how the current president of Haiti, Michel Martelly, came to win that office. It‰Ûªs a friendly and shallow look at the ascendance of a pop-star-turned-politician whose presidency, now more than four years along, has hardly been a panacea.

Mr. Martelly was a popular singer for two decades before deciding, seemingly on a whim, to run for president in 2010. The film tells the story somewhat obliquely, from the perspective of Pras Michel, once a member of the Grammy-winning group the Fugees, who is a producer of the film and here takes credit for persuading Mr. Martelly to run.

Guess what? It‰Ûªs been a rocky four years. Near the end the film tries to brush this off; the point, it claims, isn‰Ûªt how Mr. Martelly has performed in office, it‰Ûªs that the Haitian people were somehow empowered by his election. Eh. Haiti is now in the process of choosing a successor to Mr. Martelly. This film mostly seems to be getting an early start on burnishing his legacy.

The country, of course, was still reeling from the 2010 earthquake when Mr. Martelly was campaigning, but the film, after aggrandizing both Mr. Martelly and Mr. Michel, stops at Election Day. We learn nothing about how the transformation from pop star to president has played out.

We see moments from the campaign, mostly of Mr. Martelly spouting generalities to enthusiastic crowds, leading to a disputed first round of voting and then, in April 2011, his election in a runoff. A Fugees subplot is threaded in as well: For a time, Mr. Michel‰Ûªs bandmate in that group, Wyclef Jean, was also a candidate.

The success of ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù series has been itself, in its bottom-line fashion, a rejoinder to another intolerant regime, that of a movie industry that continues to treat women on and off the screen as a distraction, an afterthought and a problem. A few months into its run, the second installment, ‰ÛÏCatching Fire,‰Ûù became the first movie with a lone female lead to top the annual domestic box office in four decades. That‰Ûªs astonishing because it reveals the historical depths of the industry‰Ûªs inequities even while it speaks to the audience‰Ûªs embrace of this series. There are all sorts of reasons that viewers have flocked to these movies, including the studio hard sell, but I like to think the numbers prove that, in rallying to Katniss‰Ûªs side, they‰Ûªre also backing the other liberation struggle she has come to represent.

That has helped make Katniss the right heroine for these neo-feminist times, the you-go-and-fight girl who has led the empowerment charge at the box office and in the public imagination, often while slinging a bow and arrow borrowed from Diana, the Roman goddess of the hunt. It wasn‰Ûªt long before Katniss was making more like a latter-day Athena, the Greek goddess of war, even as this very human girl-woman was also suggesting a vibrant new take on the American Adam. You may not know the name, but you know the type: He‰Ûªs the hero whom the critic R. W. B. Lewis, in his 1955 study of 19th-century literature (and an ‰ÛÏAmerican mythology‰Ûù) described as being ‰ÛÏemancipated from history, happily bereft from ancestry, untouched and undefiled by the usual inheritances of family and race.‰Ûù

Intentional or not, their casting ensured that in the movies, just as in the books, Katniss was never going to be upstaged by a love interest. ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù may have shocked readers and viewers with its child-on-child violence, but even more startling and certainly far more pleasurable has been the girl-woman at its center who can lead troops like a reborn Joan of Arc, yet find time to nuzzle the downy lips of her male comrades before returning to battle. Her desire is as fluid as her gender, whether she‰Ûªs slipping into froufrou, shooting down enemy aircraft, kissing a boy or taking a punch. Unlike a lot of screen heroines, she has never settled into stereotype, which, despite the whole dystopian thing, makes her a lot like the contemporary girls and women watching her.

However mythic this figure ‰ÛÓ individual, self-reliant, ‰ÛÏfundamentally innocent‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the illusion of freedom he enjoys is meaningful, Lewis argues, because it makes for fiction capable of ‰ÛÏprofound tragic understanding‰Ûù rather than hopelessness. Even inadequately, this Adam struggles because, as with his biblical namesake, ‰ÛÏthe world and history lay all before‰Ûù him; by contrast, these lay all behind Katniss, who has endured history, violence and death. Yet she goes forth into her world because she too has an illusion of freedom, one which has spared us the nihilism polluting too many movies and has meant that she is neither Adam nor Eve but something else. And it is only by being this something else (not the Girl, not the Virgin or the Whore) that she has been able both to love and to fight, including against the big bad patriarch.

So, yes, of course Katniss is back, just as promised by the clumsy title of her last movie, ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏPart 2,‰Ûù she has returned as destined to finish the fight, defeat the enemy and send off a big-screen series that has had an astonishing run both in cold-cash terms and in its meaningful symbolism. She‰Ûªs ready. Since 2012, when the first movie landed, Katniss has grown into her role as a savior, an evolution that parallels that of Ms. Lawrence, who entered the series as a Sundance starlet and leaves it as one of the biggest stars in the world. Both have grown exponentially, rising to the demands of their loving audience.

It‰Ûªs crucial to the conception of Katniss that most of the character‰Ûªs more emotionally plangent scenes have been with other women, including her family, friends and other Hunger Games combatants. Some of this can be chalked up to casting and, together with Ms. Lawrence, Ms. Malone, Natalie Dormer, Patina Miller and Michelle Forbes make one of the toughest groups of women to band together on screen since Quentin Tarantino‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDeath Proof,‰Ûù his ode to exploitation cinema and its chicks. This series has had its share of robust male assistance (notably from Mr. Sutherland and Woody Harrelson), but it‰Ûªs been distracting and at times more than a little amusing that Katniss‰Ûªs love interests are played by the blindingly bland brotherhood of Mr. Hutcherson and Mr. Hemsworth.

Like the previous two movies, ‰ÛÏPart 2‰Ûù was directed by Francis Lawrence who, like most franchise filmmakers, was not hired for the quality of his mise-en-scÌ¬ne but for one job: to not screw up an extremely valuable property. (The first was shepherded by Gary Ross, whose cinematographer, Tom Stern, alas, also departed the series.) And, so, mission accomplished, largely with a lot of conversational face-offs and regular bursts of showy violence that sometimes turn panoramic, allowing you to admire the scale of the apocalyptically dressed sets. To that instrumental end, the actors hit their marks while running and gunning amid the gray rubble and black ooze, although Mr. Lawrence does raise some nice shivers in a tunnel sequence, making the horrific most out of the dark.

There‰Ûªs no risk that Katniss Everdeen, the warrior who has led the charge against oppression in ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù movies, can ever return to her current incarnation. Even if she and her world are rebooted back into franchise existence by a ravenous studio, her moment was now. Katniss, as played by Jennifer Lawrence over three years and four blockbusters, has evolved from a backwoods scrapper in the first movie into a battle-scarred champion and an exemplar of female power on screen and off ‰ÛÓ and the battles she‰Ûªs fought have extended far beyond the fictional nation of Panem.

And ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù has triumphed partly because it means so many different things to so many people. It‰Ûªs a story of war and peace, love and bullets, pegged to a girl-woman who fights for her family, her friends and the future. It‰Ûªs aspirational and inspirational, personal and communal, familiar and strange, and it speaks to the past as well as the present, sometimes unnervingly so. Suzanne Collins, who wrote the books, took her cues from reality television, the Iraq war, Roman gladiator games and the myth of Theseus and the Minotaur, and then filtered her influences through a heroine who embodies the adage that it‰Ûªs better to die on your feet than live on your knees. The result was a great character on the page and a transcendent one on the screen, where women tend to be sidelined or trapped in the virgin-whore divide.

‰ÛÏPart 2‰Ûù more or less picks up where the last movie left off, with Katniss and the rest of the rebel forces closing in on the government and Panem‰Ûªs leader, President Snow (the invaluable Donald Sutherland, leading with an insouciant self-amused smile). There are no real surprises, though many familiar faces, some of whom (Jeffrey Wright and, more movingly, Philip Seymour Hoffman) flash by so quickly that they feel like guests who have popped in only to say goodbye. As with a lot of contemporary franchises, this one stocked the supporting roles with veterans who have given ballast to a largely unmemorable young cast, including the insipid twosome ‰ÛÓ Josh Hutcherson as Peeta and Liam Hemsworth as Gale ‰ÛÓ who have wanly bookended Katniss from the start.

If Katniss escaped that old binary it‰Ûªs because Ms. Collins created a character who exists outside the traditional confines of the feminine-masculine split, and because the movies have stayed true to that original conception. At once a hunter and a nurturer, Katniss is tough and teary, stoic and sentimental, which give her layers that reflect her changeable inner states as well as her public and private identities as daughter, sister, lover and leader. It‰Ûªs instructive that she‰Ûªs worn her most overtly glamour-girl outfits as part of the farcical role forced on her by the totalitarian government that rules Panem, having been dolled up with makeup and smiles for the televised sideshows that accompany the murderous games of the series title. She‰Ûªs since graduated to basic battle black or unisex clothing that‰Ûªs suggestive of a Dystopian Gap.

‰ÛÏPart 2‰Ûù looks much like most contemporary dystopian future worlds, one that‰Ûªs by turns similar enough to ours to be reassuring and different enough to be diverting. What makes the material still feel personal ‰ÛÓ other than the yearslong investment and love that transform entertainments into fan communities ‰ÛÓ is the combination of Katniss and Ms. Lawrence, who have become a perfect fit. Ms. Lawrence now inhabits the role as effortlessly as breathing, partly because, like all great stars, she seems to be playing a version of her ‰ÛÏreal‰Ûù self. It‰Ûªs the kind of realness that can give you and the movie a jolt, as in a scene with Ms. Lawrence and a sensationally raw Jena Malone that thrusts it into that place where heroes and villains give way to something like life.
‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Apocalyptic violence. Running time: 2 hours 16 minutes.

Relief is at hand in the comely form of Auste (Aiste Dirziute, by far the more engaging and expressive of the film‰Ûªs two stars), a waitress whose twin hobbies of dressmaking and photography facilitate picturesque photo shoots in sylvan settings. But Auste‰Ûªs piquant personality and appetite for life only underscore Sangaile‰Ûªs drippy sullenness. (When asked by a relative what she‰Ûªll do after high school, she retorts, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll be a whore.‰Ûù) Lounging semi-naked in bed and sprawling by a lake, Sangaile dreams instead of being a stunt pilot, visiting air shows where swooping and soaring aircraft symbolize her need to fly free.

And perhaps it is, but the coltish Sangaile (Julija Steponaityte) won‰Ûªt be the one to convince us. Moody and uncommunicative, she wafts around her parents‰Ûª to-die-for summer home in the woods, looking like a young FranÌ_oise Hardy. When feeling particularly pensive, she lines up dead flies on her windowsill. To communicate a greater pain, she carefully slices her arms with a geometry compass ‰ÛÓ a behavior that the film troublingly trivializes by later repurposing it as a route to intimacy.
‰ÛÏThe Summer of Sangaile‰Ûù is not rated. In Lithuanian, with English subtitles. Running time: 1 hour 28 minutes.

Dreamy and delicate, trite and oh so earnest, ‰ÛÏThe Summer of Sangaile‰Ûù presents a soft-core frolic in teenage Sapphic bliss with the solemnity of a world-shattering event. Crowding the screen with more coming-of-age metaphors than either dialogue or story, the Lithuanian writer and director Alante Kavaite composes a hymn to infatuation and a sonnet to afterglow. When it‰Ûªs over, you‰Ûªll suspect that transcendent sex ‰ÛÓ preferably at sunset, beneath oodles of gauze ‰ÛÓ is more critical to realizing your dreams than a high school diploma.

It‰Ûªs all very heady and voluptuous, but it‰Ûªs also painfully superficial. A hint of the tension between Sangaile and her mother (the lovely Jurate Sodyte), a regretful former ballerina, remains unplumbed, as do the lovers‰Ûª clear class differences. Choosing height over depth, Dominique Colin‰Ûªs stunning cinematography slides over treetops and adolescent skin, giving buttery daylight and fuzzy twilight a fairy tale magic. In one enchanting scene, the teenagers gambol in the gloaming, wearing lighted tutus, like an illuminated Degas painting. And that‰Ûªs the problem: Their every move seems staged just to capture the prettiest picture. Summer lovin‰Ûª never looked so gorgeous, or so idealized.

It is not entirely fair to say that ‰ÛÏVery Semi-Serious: A Partially Thorough Portrait of New Yorker Cartoonists‰Ûù is an appropriately arch title for a movie about its subject. It‰Ûªs a truism, though, that New Yorker cartoons are meant to induce knowing chortles rather than guffaws. And this conventional wisdom is only slightly upended in this breezy and informative documentary, directed by Leah Wolchok, which opens in New York this week for an Oscar-nomination-qualifying run before airing on HBO on Dec. 7.

The cartoon laughs (or chortles), however, are abundant, and scintillating moments abound: Mr. Mankoff‰Ûªs body language in a cartoon-selection meeting with the editor in chief, David Remnick, is intriguing, to say the least. And while a few interview subjects determinedly comment on the magazine‰Ûªs push toward diversity in the cartoon department, the scene in which a new wunderkind is revealed as a wispy, pale, wide-eyed British man who speaks so softly with Mr. Mankoff that subtitles are needed, is almost too perfect.

Bouncing briskly between an intimate look at the magazine‰Ûªs cartoon editor, Bob Mankoff, and profiles of prominent cartoonists (Roz Chast is the first woman to show up, 20 minutes in), the movie covers a lot. If you‰Ûªve ever been curious as to how a cartoonist gets into The New Yorker and what happens then, ‰ÛÏVery Semi-Serious‰Ûù offers very satisfactory info. (For instance, no, most cartoonists don‰Ûªt make a living solely from their work for the magazine.) The alacrity of the film, though, proves a small but potent liability when a personal tragedy in Mr. Mankoff‰Ûªs life comes up and is practically shuffled off screen.

And a great deal more besides. The six Rocky movies before ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù to put it kindly, have had their ups and downs. From humble beginnings (and an improbable best picture Oscar, beating out ‰ÛÏAll the President‰Ûªs Men,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏNetwork‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTaxi Driver‰Ûù), the series rose in the 1980s to heights of grandiosity and preposterousness before stumbling into irrelevance. But don‰Ûªt call ‰ÛÏCreed‰Ûù a comeback. After the folly of ‰ÛÏRocky Balboa,‰Ûù the former champ is out of the ring for good. He‰Ûªs taken up the role, essential to the genre, of the gruff, grizzled trainer. And Sylvester Stallone, while happy to steal a scene every now and then, cedes the limelight to Michael B. Jordan.

But of course you can‰Ûªt take the fight out of the boy. Although Adonis is unbeaten in a string of semi-clandestine bouts in Mexico, he is turned away from his father‰Ûªs former gym. No one in Los Angeles will go against Mary Anne‰Ûªs wishes and allow her adopted son to participate in the sport that killed her husband. What else can Adonis do? He travels to Philadelphia, where Rocky (Mr. Stallone, as if that needed saying) is running a restaurant and keeping a low profile. He‰Ûªs all done with boxing, but Adonis persuades him to give it one more try. They start training, and before long a shot at the title materializes, a classic mismatch with a British brawler named Ricky Conlan (Tony Bellew).  Like Rocky himself almost 40 years earlier, Adonis is a designated tomato can  for a superior fighter.

At a recent screening of ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù as the familiar fanfare of Bill Conti‰Ûªs beloved ‰ÛÏRocky‰Ûù score signaled the start of the final round of the big fight, the audience burst into spontaneous applause. This was no sneak-preview crowd, primed with free admission and popcorn, but a room full of critics and journalists armored in professional skepticism. A cynic might say that the cheering was a Pavlovian reflex set off by a piece of commercial entertainment in the hands of a skilled, manipulative director. This cynic, however, was too busy choking up and clapping to form the thought.

Mr. Jordan plays a talented light-heavyweight whose rapid ascent in the sport is fueled by an identity crisis. Even his name is in question. The love child of Apollo Creed, Rocky‰Ûªs erstwhile nemesis and eventual best friend, the young man is unsure whether to embrace or spurn the legacy of a father he never knew. He calls himself Adonis (or sometimes Donnie) Johnson, and his background is a complicated tangle of deprivation and privilege. He grew up in foster homes and juvenile detention centers before being adopted by Apollo‰Ûªs widow, Mary Anne (Phylicia Rashad), who raised him in Los Angeles opulence and kept him away from the boxing ring.

In 2015, whether by coincidence or by the mysterious movements of the dialectic, a bunch of semi-dormant franchises have come roaring back to pop-cultural life, enrolling legions of new fans and managing both to transcend and to exploit the nostalgia of Gen-X old-timers. There was ‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road‰Ûù and then ‰ÛÏJurassic World.‰Ûù The next ‰ÛÏStar Wars‰Ûù arrives in a few weeks. In the meantime we have ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù which writes another chapter in the saga of Rocky Balboa and which is something that Italian Stallion‰Ûªs devotees have not seen in a long time, perhaps since the original ‰ÛÏRocky‰Ûù way back in 1976: a terrific boxing movie.

His relationship with Rocky is complicated, too. The older fighter is a mentor and a father figure, to be sure, but he also needs someone to take care of him, especially when illness adds a melodramatic twist to the plot. Rocky has reconciled himself to loss. The people he loved ‰ÛÓ Paulie, Mickey, Creed and Adrian ‰ÛÓ are all gone.

It‰Ûªs too simple to say that Adonis teaches him to care again. One of the most surprising things about ‰ÛÏCreed‰Ûù is how gentle and easygoing it is, notwithstanding the effective brutality of the fight scenes. It is a pleasure to watch Mr. Stallone amble through a movie with nothing much to prove. He is at his best when he works comfortably within his limitations as an actor. Mr. Jordan‰Ûªs limitations, in contrast, have yet to be discovered. With every role, he seems to delight in the unfolding of his talent, and to pass his excitement along to the audience.
‰ÛÏCreed‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). (Literal) blood, (metaphorical) guts and (discreet) sex. Running time: 2 hours 13 minutes.

A boxing movie without clichÌ©s is like a political campaign without lies. ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù directed by Ryan Coogler from a script he wrote with Aaron Covington, is self-aware without being cute about it. In the movie as in the world beyond it, Rocky is part of the cultural tapestry. Everyone in Philadelphia knows him. There‰Ûªs even a statue! But Mr. Coogler, a 29-year-old filmmaker whose debut was ‰ÛÏFruitvale Station‰Ûù (also starring Mr. Jordan), looks at the Rocky story and the tradition of Hollywood pugilism through a fresh prism.

Which partly explains the applause that is likely to echo through multiplexes this Thanksgiving. ‰ÛÏCreed‰Ûù is a dandy piece of entertainment, soothingly old-fashioned and bracingly up-to-date. The punches fly, the music soars (hip-hop along with Ludwig Goransson‰Ûªs variations on the old Bill Conti brass) and the ground is prepared for ‰ÛÏCreed II.‰Ûù We‰Ûªll see how that goes. But for now it is sweet to have this lesson in the importance of fast footwork, brute power and brotherly love.

The movie is also a Hollywood rarity: a boxing movie with a black hero. It is bizarre ‰ÛÓ though hardly surprising ‰ÛÓ that a sport dominated for decades by African-American and Latino athletes looks more like ice hockey on screen. And ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù like ‰ÛÏFruitvale Station,‰Ûù embeds its drama in the perils and pleasures of black life in America. Adonis is a complex character with a complex fate. He is at once a rich kid and a street kid, the proud carrier of an illustrious heritage and an invisible man.

‰ÛÏRocky‰Ûù was the story of a Great White Hope, and also a fable for an era of racial backlash. Apollo Creed, played by Carl Weathers, was the heavy in that movie, and Rocky was the noble underdog. Later, they set aside their differences and faced a common Soviet enemy as the series turned its attention to Cold War geopolitics. By then, Apollo was the sidekick and the sacrificial friend, an injustice that ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù by its very title, seeks to redress.

And like Rocky, Adonis falls for a lovely Philadelphian, a musician named Bianca (Tessa Thompson), who schools him in the local cuisine and the local slang. (‰ÛÏWhat‰Ûªs a jawn?‰Ûù he asks her over cheese steaks.) She teases him for having a white uncle (Adonis‰Ûªs nickname for Rocky is Unk) and gets mad when she finds out that Adonis has been hiding the truth about his pedigree.

By 11, Arlo (now voiced by Raymond Ochoa), is in full possession of his fear, which inspires some comedy and leads to some tender father-and-son moments. These include a nocturnal walk with Poppa, who, with his long, agile tail and the help of swarms of fireflies, draws phosphorescent swirls in the grass, a preview of the more visually entrancing passages to come. Arlo‰Ûªs fear soon sends him, like a really big Bambi, off on a lovely, daft, gently surreal and perilous journey. And, somewhat like Bambi, he initially sets off on that odyssey alone after a storm first sweeps away Poppa ‰ÛÓ a catastrophe that‰Ûªs blunt and subtle, delivered with panicked shouts and sealed with a merciful cut to black ‰ÛÓ and then sweeps away Arlo, too, leaving him stranded, frightened and far from home.

There‰Ûªs a lot of strange weather in Arlo‰Ûªs world, a violent churn that suggests the threatening turbulence of the dinosaurs‰Ûª climate and ours. Clouds don‰Ûªt merely gather, they also boil, creating whirlpools that bring monsoonal rains and swollen waters that defeat leviathans in an instant, as casually as a flick of Mother Nature‰Ûªs wrist. If ‰ÛÏInside Out,‰Ûù the last Pixar movie, asked what makes us human (laughter, for one, salted with tears), ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù suggests that there‰Ûªs a great deal more to the story than we Homo sapiens. Here, nature isn‰Ûªt a backdrop or an afterthought, but the main event ‰ÛÓ a buzzing, blooming wonder from the soft pink of a sun-kissed sky to the crystal waters that Arlo runs alongside and the huge pines that vault over him like a cathedral.

The first 20 minutes or so of ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù are dedicated to the family‰Ûªs life together on the farm, a large spread that‰Ûªs nestled next to a jagged mountain range and dominated by plowed fields and a house the size of an airplane hangar. The farm has its modest amusements, visual and verbal, including a pen crammed with ferocious prehistoric hens that alive look halfway plucked. (You don‰Ûªt see a kitchen or a waiting ax, so presumably the family gobbles the eggs, not the birds.) The director Peter Sohn, working from a story he concocted with a small posse (Erik Benson, Kelsey Mann, Bob Peterson and the screenwriter Meg LeFauve), lights a teasingly long fuse.

As with the asteroid, you may miss that nod to human nature. ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù has a few things on its mind, but its tone is overwhelmingly playful, not hectoring. Like most children‰Ûªs movies it offers a lesson or two, mostly about being true to yourself (and the equally helpful message to always follow the river), but what lingers is the beautiful animation that‰Ûªs by turns painterly and borderline photorealist and, in itself, an ode to the natural world. It‰Ûªs only when Arlo and Spot meet other talking dinosaurs that things become tricky, as when they encounter a troika of friendly Tyrannosaurs led by Butch (Sam Elliott, with his customary mellifluous cowboy drawl) in a meeting that, ever so briefly and transportingly, turns this recast fantasia into PG Cormac McCarthy.

Blink and you may miss the sly joke that sets ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù on its enchantingly eccentric way. It begins with a near apocalypse 65 million years ago and an asteroid racing toward Earth. And while that‰Ûªs around the time, more or less, that science hypothesizes the dinosaurs bit the dust, the wizards at Pixar have forged another creation story. Instead of crashing, the space rock zips past the big blue marble. Fast forward a few million years to what looks like the American Northwest, where two apatosaurs are farming the land, tilling the soil with honest sweat and giant noses.

As bouncy as a ball, with ductile physicality and emerald eyes, Spot injects a lot of anarchic physical comedy into the proceedings and more than a little violence. (He also introduces the concept of shame: Unlike all the other creatures, talking and otherwise, he wears a leafy loincloth.) A hunter and scavenger, Spot has a bite that turn out to be more fearsome than his bark, and soon he‰Ûªs tearing off the head of a bright, glittering beetle he brings Arlo. (Arlo, an herbivore, is understandably repulsed by this beastly offering.) It‰Ûªs no wonder that another dinosaur, a delicately designed, mournful Styracosaurus called Pet Collector (Mr. Sohn, working a lachrymose bleat), who melts in and out of the woods with an army of silent critters, wants to name Spot ‰ÛÏKiller.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Death and scenes of peril. Running time: 1 hour 40 minutes.

So, whose extinction is this, anyway? Not anyone‰Ûªs, as far as this quietly hopeful movie is concerned. In its outlines ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù spins a familiar tale in a boy‰Ûªs own story that‰Ûªs shaped by the usual highs and lows, frowns and smiles, with heart-swelling triumphs and even some Boy Scout-style bivouacking when Arlo builds a shelter out of trees. Except that here the boy is a talking agrarian dinosaur, who, after his calamitous separation, encounters a howling, snarling, scrambling, barking, nontalking human wild child who quickly becomes Arlo‰Ûªs faithful companion whom he names Spot (Jack Bright, a squalling a cappella orchestra of one). And, just like that, in the beginning there was a dinosaur ‰ÛÓ followed by a kid scampering after him on all fours.

O pioneers! O weirdness! Animated movies teach us how to watch magically strange, sometimes furry worlds, making it easy to go with the unfamiliar flow. As the flyover asteroid suggests, ‰ÛÏThe Good Dinosaur‰Ûù is charmingly different, but its oddness sneaks up on you only after the filmmakers lay out some storybook bona fides. Here, the once-upon-a-time begins with Momma (soothingly voiced by Frances McDormand) and Poppa (Jeffrey Wright) having three babies, who hatch within seconds of one another. The runt turns into a scene-stealer, Arlo (Jack McGraw), a pea-green pipsqueak who, after cautiously tumbling out of his shell, grows into a wee gentle giant.

Victor, in turn, is played with a lot of physical dash and a crazed smile by James McAvoy, who all but hurls himself into the fray. He and Mr. Radcliffe make a fine pair of scoundrel-heroes, particularly after Victor rescues Igor from the circus and performs an amusingly revolting operation featuring a siphon and bucket of pus before shooing him off for a shower and a shave. Igor cleans up nicely and then, with a back brace, straightens out agreeably, becoming Victor‰Ûªs well-coiffed match.
‰ÛÏVictor Frankenstein‰Ûù is rated PG-13 (parents strongly cautioned). Vivisection and other violence. Running time: 1 hour 49 minutes.

Thin as a halfpenny, ‰ÛÏVictor Frankenstein‰Ûù has nothing to offer on science and the mysteries of creation, but it does reaffirm the grip that Shelley‰Ûªs story retains on the imagination, no matter how far afield it‰Ûªs taken. (This version was written by Max Landis and directed by Paul McGuigan, who also directed episodes of the BBC show ‰ÛÏSherlock.‰Ûù) ‰ÛÏVictor Frankenstein‰Ûù promises new directions and other movies, mostly by recasting a story about gods and monsters into a buddy movie. It‰Ûªs vaguely cute, even if, despite the floating eyes and other attractions (notably Jessica Brown Findlay as a trapeze artist), the detective (Andrew Scott, best known as Moriarty in ‰ÛÏSherlock‰Ûù) who tries to ruin Victor‰Ûªs party can‰Ûªt help turning your thoughts from Shelley to Doyle.

Shelley didn‰Ûªt give Victor Frankenstein a lab lackey, though plenty of filmmakers have. In ‰ÛÏSon of Frankenstein‰Ûù (1939), the assistant is called Ygor and, somewhat confusingly in terms of monster genealogy, played by Bela Lugosi, of Dracula immortality. He‰Ûªs Igor here in this new movie and played by Daniel Radcliffe, who continues to take on roles that seem calculated to stick a fork in Harry Potter as deeply as possible. Hunched and filthy, Mr. Radcliffe‰Ûªs Igor enters head down and cowering, more beast than man. A whipped dog, Igor works as the lowest-level circus performer, a job that mostly entails his serving as the center attraction in a brutal round of kick the can.
Handily, Igor also turns out to be a genius of a kind, an expert draftsman and amateur sawbones who‰Ûªs eager to help Victor with some of his dodgier scientific experiments.

You cannot keep a good monster down, especially when there‰Ûªs franchise money to be made. This doubtless explains ‰ÛÏVictor Frankenstein,‰Ûù a pop romp that exhumes Mary Shelley‰Ûªs famous monster-maker for a jaunty bromance with his bestie, Igor. It‰Ûªs a hyperventilated resurrection that owes less to Shelley (or most Frankenstein flicks) than to Guy Ritchie‰Ûªs Sherlock Holmes diversions, which turned Holmes (Robert Downey Jr.) and Dr. Watson (Jude Law) into 19th-century action heroes complete with cheerfully deployed violence and self-regarding smiles.

Like the similarly themed ‰ÛÏThe Human Experiment‰Ûù this year, ‰ÛÏStink!‰Ûù struggles at times to weave disparate threads of evidence into a coherent whole. Relatably sincere, Mr. Whelan (whose wife died of breast cancer in 2009) may not be the most polished of filmmakers, but he has a dogged geniality that makes his occasional awkwardness easy to forgive. Scientists and other experts help him out, expressing their concerns ‰ÛÓ like the weaknesses in our legislation and the impotence of the Environmental Protection Agency ‰ÛÓ with alarming clarity.

The movie‰Ûªs director and narrator, Jon Whelan, did smell something ‰ÛÓ a strange stench from his daughters‰Ûª new pajamas ‰ÛÓ and began a three-year journey to track down its source. What he learned was that the seller of the nightwear, a store called Justice (owned by Tween Brands), was not the only company that closely guards the identity of the synthetic substances lurking in its products. He also discovered that any manufacturer could cram as many of these as it wanted, including known carcinogens, under the umbrella term ‰ÛÏfragrance,‰Ûù without being required to name a single one.

When Jon Stewart signed off from ‰ÛÏThe Daily Show‰Ûù with the instruction, ‰ÛÏIf you smell something, say something,‰Ûù he wasn‰Ûªt speaking literally. Yet he would probably approve of ‰ÛÏStink!,‰Ûù a heartfelt documentary about the chemical industry‰Ûªs aggressive efforts to conceal the thousands of potentially toxic ingredients contained in everyday products.

Sensible and unnerving, ‰ÛÏStink!‰Ûù is likely to incite, at the least, a purging of Axe body spray from adolescent boys‰Ûª bedrooms ‰ÛÓ even though, contrary to the suspicions of some of us who have smelled it, it is in no way linked to a mysterious shot of a container in a scent warehouse labeled ‰ÛÏMonkey Farts.‰Ûù

In 2010, Mr. Lanzmann (whose footage Mr. Grunberg often borrows from) devoted a documentary, ‰ÛÏThe Karski Report,‰Ûù to the man, who ultimately taught for years at Georgetown University. ‰ÛÏKarski & the Lords of Humanity‰Ûù is fascinating, but Mr. Lanzmann‰Ûªs efforts tower over it.

One of the many interviewees in ‰ÛÏShoah,‰Ûù Claude Lanzmann‰Ûªs definitive nine-and-a-half-hour 1985 documentary about the Holocaust, was Jan Karski, a Pole whose undercover missions in World War II gave early information to the Allies about the extermination of Polish Jews. Slawomir Grunberg‰Ûªs stately documentary ‰ÛÏKarski & the Lords of Humanity‰Ûù focuses exclusively on Karski‰Ûªs courageous adventures in intrigue and espionage.

The handsome, dapper, erudite and multilingual Karski (1914-2000), who was blessed with a photographic memory and educated as a diplomat before serving in the military, was an ideal candidate for the Resistance. Often working for the Polish government in exile in London, he conducted many missions, among them a trip incognito to the Warsaw Ghetto, illustrated here with utterly harrowing photographs. Karski presented his eyewitness account in person to officials in Britain and, eventually, President Franklin D. Roosevelt. His exploits ‰ÛÓ surviving brutal torture by the Gestapo; a daring hospital escape; smuggling microfilm; using medical mean to disguise his accent ‰ÛÓ are fleshed out with vivid animated sequences, while experts offer testimony.

Mr. Berardini‰Ûªs packed documentary makes its case early and often, perhaps too often, but it‰Ûªs more chilling than your average issue film. In the hands of a determined business, a violent invention can be a game-changer that gives rise to tragic losses.

Between the contentious talk about Tasers and the queasy video footage of zaps and falls, the movie becomes a dense stew of words and death. The company‰Ûªs boosterism of the benefits of ‰ÛÏneuromuscular incapacitation‰Ûù for law enforcement and its highly constrained sense of responsibility together suggest something out of ‰ÛÏRoboCop.‰Ûù (Company motto: ‰ÛÏProtecting Life. Protecting Truth.‰Ûù)

Mr. Berardini primes us to dislike the device by showing a Taser being tested on buffaloes, but the footage of the massive animals crumpling effectively illustrates a macho fantasy of violent control fulfilled by the weapon. The heavily researched documentary features surveillance and dashboard video of people killed by Tasers, and demonstrates the results of the device‰Ûªs widespread adoption by the police, often without sufficient training. Taser International also has its say through an empty-eyed publicity representative and the Smiths, who argue that the weapon saves lives as an alternative to a gun.

The rise, use and abuse of the Taser form the discomfiting subject of Nick Berardini‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKilling Them Safely,‰Ûù but an equally formidable weapon also goes on display: words. In the 1990s, the brothers Rick and Tom Smith amped up a decades-old invention to create their electricity-zapping ‰ÛÏhome run product.‰Ûù Since then, their company, Taser International, has defended the Taser‰Ûªs virtues with on-message verbiage in the face of deaths associated with the weapon.

There‰Ûªs claustrophobia to burn in Steven C. Miller‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSubmerged,‰Ûù a modest thriller offering glints of talent amid predictable plot threads. Matt (Jonathan Bennett), a military reservist, struggles to raise his faltering younger brother, Dylan (Cody Christian), after the death of their parents. He also covets ‰ÛÓ and looks out for ‰ÛÓ Jessie, the daughter (Talulah Riley) of a wealthy businessman (Tim Daly) for whom he is a driver and surrogate son.

In the passenger compartment are their friends: the flighty Amanda (Rosa Salazar), the unstable Todd (Giles Matthey), the sensible Eddie (Denzel Whitaker) and the broody Brandon (Caleb Hunt), all hysterical to a degree and bickering as the oxygen diminishes. If that‰Ûªs not bad enough, additional threats await them on the surface ‰ÛÓ one even visits their underwater hell.

In short order, Dylan dies of an overdose, and Matt is comforted by the magnate‰Ûªs mechanic, Hector (Mario Van Peebles). Then an attempted kidnapping of Jessie results in the sinking of an impregnable limousine in an estuary, an injured Matt at the wheel and an unconscious Jessie at his side.

The script, by Scott Milam, flirts with political convictions, but betrays its seemingly compact premise in the third act, when plot twists disappoint and the story lapses into conventional confrontations. But Mr. Bennett exudes a solid authority, and the aging Mr. Van Peebles demonstrates that he still has some fight left. As for Mr. Miller, he displays an impressive command of the camera, editing and subtle digital effects. He may not yet be ready for big budgets, but he‰Ûªs getting there.

Mr. Kapoor‰Ûªs character is a bore at work, but insufferably full of himself in Corsica. The big-eyed Ms. Padukone, who has co-starred with Mr. Kapoor before, dutifully, and regrettably, permits him to eclipse her own formidable charisma. But the biggest offender is the director, Imtiaz Ali, who, also again collaborating with Mr. Kapoor, actually celebrates two love affairs: Ved and Tara‰Ûªs, and (given Ved‰Ûªs universal adulation) Mr. Ali‰Ûªs with his own self-aggrandizing vision of his calling.

Years pass, and Tara, still smitten, tracks down Ved. He is now a dull if prosperous product manager, making remarks like ‰ÛÏCountries are companies, and companies are countries,‰Ûù while she is a globe-hopping businesswoman. His job stifles his theatrical imagination, and Tara soon rejects him. When she reconsiders, it is he who rejects her. But after an office meltdown, he is haunted by her observations, and discovers a life that lets him entertain others as he was entertained by the storyteller. Ved and Tara reunite after Ved has become an acclaimed director of stage extravaganzas.

The clues come early in the Bollywood melodrama ‰ÛÏTamasha,‰Ûù when a song mentions a love story within a larger story. The film (named after a kind of Marathi theater) begins with a boy, Ved, enraptured at the feet of a wizened storyteller in Shimla, India. Later, as an adult (Ranbir Kapoor), he meets Tara (Deepika Padukone) on vacation in Corsica. Their largely chaste relationship revolves around playacting, and they avoid exchanging real names. When Tara returns to India, they decide to never meet again, their idyll forever in amber.
‰ÛÏIraqi Odyssey‰Ûù is not rated. Running time: 2 hours 43 minutes.

For American audiences, conditioned to view Iraq through the lens of contemporary wartime journalism as a primitive fractious land of Shiites, Sunnis and other sects in continual conflict, the documentary will be a revelation. Not so long ago Iraq was much more westernized than it is today, and scenes of Iraqis in Western garb, living comfortable middle-class lives in happier times, puts a lump in your throat.

‰ÛÏIraqi Odyssey,‰Ûù a two-and-a-half-hour personal history written and directed by the Swiss filmmaker Samir (full name, Samir Jamal Aldin), is the kind of documentary whose length and complexity make you approach it with some apprehension. Watching it is like slowly leafing through a giant scrapbook whose contents include the individual stories of a large extended family.

Samir playfully compares the family history to Homer‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏOdyssey,‰Ûù and throughout the movie there are flashes of scenes from ‰ÛÏUlysses,‰Ûù a 1955 movie starring Kirk Douglas. If ‰ÛÏIraqi Odyssey‰Ûù is a Homeric parable, he suggests, Iraq is the equivalent of Penelope, patiently waiting for Odysseus to return. But in this version Penelope loses patience and marries one of her suitors. There isn‰Ûªt a triumphant homecoming, and it is doubtful whether, given all that has happened, such a homecoming is possible, but one can still dream. There is a joyful family reunion; it is not on Iraqi soil but in Switzerland.

The members of the Jamal Aldin clan are resilient, articulate, intelligent, attractive and cosmopolitan. They make the best of a bad situation. What is remarkable is the clan‰Ûªs cohesion, despite being separated by thousands of miles. They sadly acknowledge that the homeland they were forced to flee barely exists anymore. The country, one family member says, has ‰ÛÏgone back 500 years.‰Ûù

From here, things go mostly downhill. Hussein‰Ûªs rise led to Iraq‰Ûªs pointless eight-year war with Iran, and the worsening horrors of his dictatorship, followed by the American invasion of the country. For all the politics described in the film, ‰ÛÏIraqi Odyssey‰Ûù never becomes bogged down in strident rhetoric and analysis, although the family members who chose to settle in the Soviet Union instead of Britain regret their decision.
To begin to grasp the magnitude of the family‰Ûªs collective travels would take at least two viewings of the film accompanied by a who‰Ûªs-who chart of its members and their peregrinations.

The family history is inseparable from the history of the country. In the 1950s, members of the clan flirted with Communism, but they weren‰Ûªt infatuated with Marxist ideology so much as encouraged by the Communists‰Ûª determination to improve the lives of the working class. At a crucial turning point, one family member recalls, the Baath Party, which was solidifying its power, out of which emerged Saddam Hussein, waited in vain for help from the Soviet Union. He theorizes that the outcome of the Cuban missile crisis prevented the Soviets from intervening; they didn‰Ûªt want another confrontation with the United States.

Buffeted by war and political upheaval, Samir‰Ûªs relatives, who are seen at different ages and in different places, belong to the Jamal Aldin clan, a well-educated line of professionals who trace their ancestry to the Prophet Muhammad. They became secularists during the period, beginning in the 1920s, of British rule. Today they belong to a diaspora of Iraqi Ì©migrÌ©s scattered across the globe. Family members have landed in places as far-flung as Auckland, New Zealand; Buffalo; London; and Zurich, where Samir settled with his Swiss wife. Late in the movie, Samir remarks with some bitterness that since settling there, he hasn‰Ûªt made a single friend.
